title: Characterization of Materials
reviews: A very laid-back course that will still teach you a decent amount of things about important characterization techniques.
An excellent introduction to the imaging techniques and instruments available at Princeton.
Definitely take this class if you can. You'll love it.
It should help your GPA, and microscopy is useful.
It's a useful class, recommend to take.
TAKE THIS IF YOU LOVE MATERIALS SCIENCE
Take it if you want to learn the basics of SEM, TEM, etc.
Take this course at all cost
Take this course!
Yes
very useful
descrip: A multidisciplinary course offering a practical introduction to techniques of imaging structure and compositional analysis of advanced materials. Focus on principles and applications of various characterization methods. Covered topics include AFM, SEM, TEM, XRD, EDX/WDX, EELS, Raman, Ellipsometry, Confocal Microscopy, sample preparation and image processing, etc. Hands-on experience is emphasized.

title: Planning Methods
descrip: This course introduces a set of concepts and tools that are widely used in the practice of urban and regional planning. The focus is on developing an operational understanding of the models, techniques and data used in such applications as regional economic and demographic projections, cost-benefit analysis, and land use analysis. Emphasis is also placed on the limitations of the methods.

title: England from the Wars of the Roses to the Glorious Revolution
reviews: Don't take this course as a freshman unless you are already well-acquainted with and like British history, or you have a lot of time to do the dense, primary source readings. Beware: a final paper and exam for the class makes it a bit of a doozy!
I would definitely recommend this course.  Professor Hubbard is a really great lecturer and you will definitely learn a lot in the course.

If you are interested in the subject, this class is amazing! Professor Hubbard is so passionate about her lectures and she is super personable. Don't get behind in your readings because they can add up: while she gets repetitive at times in lecture if you do the readings before hand, the books offer more details that are necessary especially for exams.
If you're interested, take it, but there are history classes that I have enjoyed more.
If you're into Britain and/or pirates, this is one to take.
It's a fun class!
Take it if the topic interests you - definitely worth it!
Take this course if you are interested in Tudor/Stuart history, do not have significant prior knowledge, and are willingly to write a lengthy research paper at the end of term.
Take this!

This course is a great introduction to Tudor and Stuart England. I highly recommend it if you are interested in English history. I would suggest keeping up with the Readings and consistently keeping written answers to reading questions. They'll help a lot when it comes to exams!

This course was a lot more work than I thought it would be - there was a lot of reading for precept every week, a midterm, final and final research paper (12-15 pages) so be prepared to put in a lot of effort.
This is an amazing class if you are interested in early modern Europe.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: The two centuries between the Wars of the Roses and the Glorious Revolution saw the end of the feudal order, astonishing revolutions in church and state, a literary renaissance, two ruling queens and one executed king in a deeply patriarchal and hierarchical society, civil wars, the beginnings of the British empire, and the emergence of a recognizably modern society of newspapers, scientific experiments, and political parties. These extraordinary developments were, however, far from being natural or predetermined. This course will explore how such dramatic transformations took place in a society seemingly resistant to change.

title: East Asian Humanities II: Traditions and Transformations
reviews: I would recommend if you have somewhat of an interest in East Asia and East Asian literature.
Only good for those already interested in East Asian cultures. I learned a lot and was exposed to a lot of East Asian humanities that I will revisit in the future.
Take this course, especially if you like the humanities and East Asia.

This class gives a great introduction to important themes that are necessary to think about while considering East Asian literature and history and introduces you to many new texts!  The papers are challenging at first, but the professors are really great about making time to meet and discuss and recommend good sources.

This was a very very good class. You will get some classics, some things very few people have heard of, and have some good discussions when people participate. Not much on Japan this year, but that was okay by me.
descrip: This is the second half of a two-semester sequence introducing the humanities in East Asia. The course begins roughly around the fourteenth century and covers the arts, philosophy, religion and literature in China, Japan, and Korea. Special focus will be given to the question of modernity in East Asia. Lectures are given by specialists in the departments of East Asian Studies, Comparative Literature, Art and Archaeology, and Religion. Classes will be complemented by museum visits and performances.

title: Algebra II
reviews: Go to office hours.
I thought the course was super awesome.  Sadly Raicu is leaving, but if you want to learn Galois Theory, you should take it.
It was great.
It's harder than Algebra I.
Real men know Galois theory. All the best, Claudiu!
Take it.
Take this class even though it isn't a requirement. It's really cool.

Take this course if you love Algebra, but be prepared for a lot of work and a lot of time, Homework took me ~20 hours per week and the midterm and final were both ~36 hour endeavors. Make sure you keep up with the material and take advantage of office hours and problem sessions.
prereqs: MAT345 or equivalent..
descrip: A continuation of Algebra I, this course will cover the basics of ring theory, module theory, field theory, and Galois theory. Topics include structure theorems for modules, polynomial rings, field extensions, and solvability of polynomial equations by radicals.

title: Laboratory in Plasma Physics
reviews: Take it.  Be prepared to do outside reading and theory work.

Take the course even if you are a theorist and have little past lab experience or desire to be involved with experiment. I'd say take this course *especially* if you are pursuing a more hands-off first year project.
This course is a time commitment, but well worth it. Don't try to rush through it.

This is a most excellent course, and you should take it, even if right now you don't think you would like experimental work.

Advice: start the lab reports earlier rather than later. Also, consider learning LaTeX if you don't already know it while doing the lab reports.
You would need it.
descrip: Develop skills, knowledge, and understanding of basic and advanced laboratory techniques used to measure the properties and behavior of plasmas. Representative experiments are: cold-cathode plasma formation and architecture; ambipolar diffusion in afterglow plasmas; Langmuir probe measurements of electron temperature and plasma density; period doubling and transitions to chaos in glow discharges; optical spectroscopy for species identification; microwave interferometry and cavity resonances for plasma density determination; and momentum generated by a plasma thruster.

title: Advanced Modern Greek
reviews: Good class!

If you have to take a language requirement, try Greek! The class is easy to pick up and keep up with, the assignments are generally quick and painless, and the exams aren't stressful. Hellenic studies is a wonderful department, and Greeks have connections everywhere! I guarantee that if you take this class you will love it and have learned a lot.
Take it if you love Greek!
You had better like Modern Greek, or this won't be worth your time. My advice is to take German instead.
prereqs: HLS 105 or equivalent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: Advanced composition and oral practice aimed at developing idiomatic written and spoken style. Discussions entirely in Greek. Introduces students to contemporary Greek culture and literature through the study of works by Cavafy, Sikelianos, Seferis, Elytis, Ritsos, and Anagnostakis, among others. Readings from articles on current Greek topics.

title: Introduction to Urban Studies
reviews:
1) Do the readings 
2) Befriend preceptor and seek him/her out for clarification on readings 
3) not necessary to attend lectures
A LOT of reading/required video watching... you can get by without doing all of it, but in theory this class is a time suck. Don't be fooled by the fact that there is only 1 lecture per week...
Be careful - it's an interesting topic but the lectures are incredibly boring and the entire course is very disorganized.
Definitely take this course. If you go to precept and write the midterm and final you will get a good grade

Do the readings you're truly interested in. There's no need to do all of them, but do find a passion or an interest in the 12 weeks of material that you can focus your energy on because you will have to choose specific areas for your midterm and final essays.
Good PDF course.
Good class to take as an SA
Good class, not particularly difficult, but a good introduction to urban studies

I don't necessarily recommend the course. It isn't something that you take if you want to fill fulfillment as the end result. If you want to fulfill your half of your SA requirement in a almost easy way, go for it.
I would recommend this course for any student needing to fulfill their SA requirement and who has a general interest in cities and urban studies.
I would simply tell them to keep up on readings and stay engaged in class, and this would give them the most out of the course.
I would strongly recommend another student to take this course.

If you are looking for a class that requires a minimal level of involvement and don't mind being painfully bored to death by the unbearable lectures, this is your class. There is not much writing required: a take-home midterm, a take-home final, and a short weekly blog post (around 250 words or less). However, the class is extremely disorganized, there are paragraphs and paragraphs of just writing on each slide which makes it impossible to take notes or understand, the lectures are way too long and we never got through them in class, and my precept was, essentially, a waste of time. The readings were too long and complicated, to the point that next to nobody did them, which made precept even less productive. During precept we would spend time googling images and talking about them individually and fail to address the main themes we needed to know for the exam. Overall, it is easy to get by doing very little work, but it is almost not worth it because almost every aspect of the class is useless and boring.
If you are looking for a distribution requirement on the easier side, take this class. Very manageable workload.
If you think you might like urban studies, take this course. This workload is relatively light, and you end up learning a great deal by the end of the semester.
Incredibly interesting material   the easiest social science class I have taken at Princeton, to the point that I actually wished assignments were a bit more comprehensive...
Interesting course -- easy to understand lecture and follow along

Interesting, laid-back course with not too much work.  I did all of my weekly work for this course during my 2.5 hour library shift the day before weekly blog assignments were due (I didn't get to all the readings in those 2.5 hours, but more than enough to actively participate in precept).  I think it's especially enjoyable if you live near a city that was part of your life growing up.  It's a good choice to fulfill an SA without too much stress attached.
It was interesting and fun, and relatively low-key.
It's a little boring, but gets interesting in precepts when every one talks about where they are from! Hope to get an engaging preceptor!
Light workload, decently interesting. Good 4th or 5th class.
Make sure you do all of the readings because they are very interesting.
Maybe take it
Not a huge time commitment!
Not too hard but very interesting!
Participate in precept! Uncover your own views on urbanity and test them!
Read all of the readings and take a few notes. Throughout the whole course think of case studies from your own knowledge or research that are similar to those discussed in class.
Take if you are really interested in architecture or urbanism, but not otherwise
Take if you enjoy cities.
Take it if you are interested in studying cities. The course is fairly easy and very relevant to modern global trends.
Take it! You'll learn a lot and it's non-stressful
Take this course if you want an introduction to what urban studies is all about. Not a heavy workload, but you still learn something.

Take this if you want an easy intro course that you really only need to attend precept for. The lecture slides and readings online will help you through the material. Interesting if you want it to be and do the readings; otherwise, just an easy distribution requirement.
The class is very interesting and on the easy side. Take it!
This course is interesting and not a ton of work.  Provides a good background for urban studies.
This is a good SOC credit, and it was pretty interesting.
This was the worst course I have taken at Princeton thus far. Lectures are not well presented, precept was useless. Take the course if you have to, but avoid it if possible.

When taking this course be sure to complete the readings so you can be an active participant in class. Furthermore, make sure you clarify any questions you have regarding any topic with your preceptor if they do arise.
Yes, recommend it
easy class, interesting readings and lectures, not too much work, only a take-home midterm and final
interesting class and fun
nothing
descrip: This course will examine different crises confronting cities in the 21st century. Topics will range from immigration, to terrorism, shrinking population, traffic congestion, pollution, energy crisis, housing needs, water wars, race riots, extreme weather conditions, war and urban operations. The range of cities will include Los Angles, New Orleans, Paris, Logos, Caracas, Havana, New York, Hong Kong, and Baghdad among others.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Privacy Technologies
reviews: A good course that focuses much more on policy of privacy than technical implementations.

Arvind is one of the brightest young professors in the CS department and brings energy and tremendous expertise to his teaching.  If he's teaching any course whatsoever, it would be a mistake to pass up the opportunity to take it.
Great fusion of technical and societal perspectives.
I would advise students to consider this course, regardless of whether they have a computer science background.
If you have a penchant for thinking about privacy, then you will have a great time with this course.
Take it but expect it to be more policy oriented then you might imagine.
Take this course if you're interested in the intersection of tech and policy in the privacy sphere. If you're primarily interested in the technical aspects, you might be sometimes dissapointed.
This course was super interesting. Arvind was great at leading the seminars, and I learned a lot.
descrip: Explores privacy technologies - both their power and limitations - and interdisciplinary approaches to privacy. Detailed look at technical topics such as cryptography and anonymity (including Tor and Bitcoin) and critical analysis of their place in society. Overview of law, economics, and policy perspectives on privacy technologies. Serves as introduction to research in the security and privacy research group.

title: The Later Romantics
descrip: The flamboyant second generation of British Romantics: Keats, Percy Shelley, Mary Shelley, Byron, Hemans, Austen. Careful attention to texts--ranging from novels, to odes, to romances, and modern epics--in historical and cultural contexts, with primary focus on literary imagination.

title: Instrumental Music: The Concerto
reviews: Do listenings, take careful notes.
I would recommend this course to anyone who has played a concerto before. Musical theory background is not required, but definitely helps with writing assignments and exams.
TAKE IT!
Take it! It's not hard and really interesting if you're interested in concertos. That said, you should be genuinely interested in the subject matter or else it is rather mundane.

Take this class!  Professor Zavlunov may seem intimidating at first, but he really knows his stuff and has put together a great course here.  You'll learn a ton about concertos even if you know nothing about musical form going in, like me.  And you can perform a concerto in front of the class, or not!  AWESOME class, favorite elective I've taken here.
Take this class, very interesting and you will learn much.

The course pre-requisite does not require prior musical knowledge, but this class is filled with students who are extremely knowledgeable about music; be warned. It is still a worthwhile and laidback class, however, and an enriching experience.
definitely take it! kind of lots of work, but worth it in my opinion
prereqs: Some musical background preferred, but not required..
descrip: A study of the concerto genre persisting through stylistic and formal changes from the 17th to the 20th centuries and encompassing works by Vivaldi, Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, Mendelssohn, Brahms, Tchaikovsky, Rakhmaninov, Prokofiev, Berg, Ravel, Poulenc and others.

title: Topics in Analysis
reviews: It's a good course on topics inspired by moment problems; If you have interest in this, definitely take it.
Look at the specific topic being taught and see if you would be interested in learning it.
descrip: This course will be an introduction to the classical moment problem and its applications, particularly, in probability theory and mathematical physics. Connections to orthogonal polynomials, continued fractions and other topics will be discussed.

title: The Structure and Meaning of Words
reviews: As an introduction to morphology, this course is great. Professor Williams knows what he's talking about and is open to discuss interesting suggestions and questions. Low time commitment. Easier if you already have a background in linguistics.
If you are interested in more of the purely theoretical part of linguistics, you should take this class. Prof. Williams is quite logical in his lecturing.
If you are international, do not take the course - too heavily focused on English, often on paradigms you cannot understand. Otherwise an engaging course but lacking structure.
If you're interested in the material, it's a pretty easy PDF. Probably not too difficult either for a grade, if you have time to do the readings.
Morphology is not the most exciting of linguistic subfields - but Williams engages you in some interesting discussions.
This course helps better your understanding of the principles and theories of morphology. It takes a high level of self-motivation to keep up and stay attentive in class.
This course is a natural followup to the previous course in syntax.
This might be a little difficult if you don't know much about Linguistics, and it might be a little boring if you DO know about Linguistics, but morphology is the best, so take this class.
prereqs: LIN 201.
descrip: The course will treat the structure of words and the structure of the overall lexicon for human languages. Topics included will be: the rules of word formation; the relation between syntax and the lexicon; the psychology of the lexicon, including an examination of studies of the storage and access of lexical items; the semantics of complex words; the phonology of word formation; lexical redundancy and the learning of the lexicon. Students will prepare one short class presentation on a topic in consultation with the instructor.

title: Readings in Japanese Religions - The Buddhist Tradition
descrip: In this seminar we read representative examples of Buddhist texts in Japanese and kanbun from the Heian through modern periods. Readings are drawn from multiple genres and may include doctrinal writings, ritual manuals, didactic tales, sermons, and personal letters. Supplementary readings in Japanese and English scholarship may be assigned. To some extent, readings may be chosen to accommodate participants' research interests. Use of bibliographic and reference sources is also introduced.

title: Extragalactic Astronomy
reviews: Amazing speakers, don't overexert yourself on homework.
Highly recommend. Very helpful for the general knowledge of cosmology and galaxy.
Reading many papers related to the topics in this course.
You definitely want to take this if you want to know something about cosmology and extragalactic objects.
prereqs: Undergraduate Physics and Math.
descrip: This course is an overview of cosmology and extragalactic astronomy, with an emphasis on the connection between theoretical ideas and observational data. The Big Bang model and the standard cosmological model will be emphasized, as well as the properties and evolution of galaxies, quasars, and clusters of galaxies.

title: Introduction to Microeconomics
reviews: A good way to satisfy the SA distribution requirement.

Actually do all the readings, otherwise it'll come back to hurt you on the exams. It seems like a lot some weeks, but it's not essential you do it that week, as long as you get it done. Lectures are boring, but still go.

After the fact, I would advise not taking this with Reinhardt unless you have to. Don't get me wrong, he has a lot of very insightful things to say about economics. But if you want to seriously learn the material in lecture, I would wait until Rosen or someone new is teaching it. If you must take it with Reinhardt, be sure to do the lecture note and Mankiw readings, and go to office hours (I didn't find McGraw particularly helpful for this course, their guidance was often incorrect). Focus on the material's theory and problem-solving techniques - it's what you'll actually be tested on when you take the midterm and final, which total to 75% of your course grade.
Attend Office Hours regularly and get to know your preceptor.
Attend as many precepts as you can, because they help A LOT.
Be prepared to do a lot of the work on your own.
DO NOT LET THE MIDTERM SNEAK UP ON YOU! STUDY EARLY! BUY THE PRACTICE BOOK!

Definitely take this course - it's one of those courses you have to take to complete your education. It offers a great and solid understanding of how the market works and has discrete real life applications.

Do NOT take this with Reinhardt. He is unorganized, his lectures are unnecessarily long, and he assigns a ton of outside readings that he will test you on. Avoid at all costs. This class discouraged me from becoming a Woody Woo major because it was so bad. This is not an introductory to microeconomics class. I came in with no previous experience in micro and I payed the price. If you do take it, find some econ major friends and beg for their help.
Do not get behind, make sure you understand the current topic before moving on to the next
Do not take ECO 100 with Reinhardt
Do the readings
Do the readings when you can and work hard on the problem sets and you'll be fine.
Don't take it if you don't have to
Don't take it with Reinhardt.
Don't take it with Uwe. Only take it if you're interested in the subject or if you need to for a major. Don't take it to fulfill any sort of gen ed requirement.
ECO 100 is a great introduction course for anyone who is remotely interested in economics and how markets work. I strongly recommend this class.
ECO 100 is a major prerequisite for many departments. Because you will probably have to take it at some point, plan ahead and try to get Rosen.
Find something productive to do when lecture gets wild.
Go to lecture, do the readings, go to precept. If you do, it will be no problem.
Go to lecture, precept, keep up with the readings and work and you'll be fine.

I have heard that there are other professors for this course that lecture more effectively than Professor Reinhardt. If that is the case, I would recommend taking this course with that professor instead.
I mean, if you want to be WWS or ECO, you have to take this... and I think that Econ is a good class for anyone to take, but maybe not with Prof Reinhardt?
I would advise against taking the course if you have little to no prior Economics experience.

I would advise students that in order to do well in this course, they are going to have to spend a lot of time outside of lecture teaching themselves the concepts. I would definitely recommend regularly attending precepts even though participation is not part of their grade, and attending office hours/McGraw study halls.
I would definitely take the course but would make sure to read the readings and do the textbook questions before class.
I would not take this class with Professor Reinhardt if possible. I've heard that Professor Rosen does a great job.
I would recommend it, but it is not the best class.
I would recommend taking with another professor, but if you must take it with Reinhardt, go to precept and do as many of the readings as possible.
I would recommend that they only take it if they know they want to do economics in the future.
I would tell them to work together and read a lot.
I'd definitely make sure to take Reinhardt's course in micro, if you are looking for distribution requirements

If you have never taken econ in high school, take this course, regardless of your major. But it might not be worth it going to all lectures if they are 80 minutes long, because sometimes the important material is covered in only half an hour.
If you must take this as a departmental, just take the class. However, if you're looking to fulfill an SA, look elsewhere.
If you want to do well in the course make sure to read the textbook thoroughly.
If you're a non-economics major, I would recommend ECO 101 over this class.

If you're going to take this class, be aware that the Professor really does make or break the course.  From my personal experience, Professor Reinhardt did the latter, and if you can avoid it don't take this course if he's teaching it.

If you've never taken an economics course before, this course is going to be pretty hard. Lectures aren't very helpful, especially since he posts all of his lecture notes online. If you really want to learn microeconomics, this might not be the course for you. If you don't mind a bit of a broader educational experience (we covered taxes, corporate finance, how to start a business, etc.), then you'll probably enjoy this course.

It is important to prepare for lecture by reading the textbook, because Professor Reinhardt does not review the fundamental concepts found in Mankiw. I would also recommend taking advantage of office hours, because the preceptors are key to doing well on problem sets and exams. Lecture does not prepare the student for the problems.
It's a great and interesting class, with a fair amount of work.
It's easier than with other economics professors.
Keep up with all the readings and go to class and take notes
Learn material before the lectures.
Learn microeconomics before taking this course.

Lectures were a complete waste of time. I attended every single one, but realized that most people started to to attend at all. I do not recommend this class at all. His own office hours were specifically placed during lecture hours. Just terrible.
Maybe take 310 instead.
Only take this class if you know very little about economics. Otherwise, just skip it and take a higher level class.
Particularly because Reinhardt covers SO much material, studying for the final can be overwhelming. Stay on top of everything.
Practice
Read the textbook and go to McGraw for help with the problem sets.
Recommend this class if you are logically inclined and like doing economics through math, otherwise avoid

Reinhardt is neither the best nor the worst ECO 100 teacher. Don't let his personality get to you if you're not a fan. Print out his teaching memos, even if you usually don't print things. Allot plenty of time to problem sets and make sure you understand the solutions. Get a good preceptor (like Daniel or Josephine) and shop them if necessary. Use McGraw. Skim the articles on the syllabus. The Mankiw textbook is actually super helpful so start reading it early and keep it up.

Reinhardt teaches this course harder than a normal ECO 100. He uses multi and single var calculus. He also gets into upper level econ material, which makes it harder. But it is therefore a great first econ course if you plan on taking more
Reinhardt tells some funny stories during lectures but doesn't actually teach much. Most lectures were useless and I had to read the book and his notes to figure out what we were covering.
Stay on top of the readings and stay calm in the face of ridiculous problem sets and exams. Stay strong. I am sorry you have to take this course.
TAKE THIS COURSE IN THE FALL. Reinhardt is a mediocre lecturer at best while Rosen (from what I have heard) is great.
Take it before you take 310.
Take it but I would pdf it.
Take it for some fun ECO information.
Take it if you are required to. Otherwise, it isn't particularly interesting.
Take it if you don't want to do any writing.
Take it if you want the distribution and a bit of econ - it's not too hard.
Take it if you want to, only if your interested in the material, if you aren't you won't make it!
Take it if you've taken Econ before. Otherwise, wait for the fall.
Take it with a different professor.
Take it, it is very interesting
Take it. Do the readings and take notes
Take the 50 minute lectures
Take the course, and take it with Professor Reinhardt.
Take the course, but be prepared to go to McGraw or office hours in order to find out what the hell you're supposed to be learning.
Take this course if only to learn the basics of economics.
Take this course with another lecturer if you can.
Take with another professor
The assigned readings are useful. No need to read them too closely, but at least skimming is highly recommended

The course is pretty easy and the lectures can be hilarious when Reinhardt switches into storytelling mode. You end up learning a lot, from simple supply and demand to bond pricing, welfare economics, healthcare, etc.
There is a lot of reading each week. Try and get the readings done a week ahead of time to make lectures make more sense. Print the outlines of the lecture for the day before getting to class.

This could have the potential to be a really interesting course, but Reinhardt does not serve it justice. You should wait and take it in the fall with Rosen; I've heard nothing but positive reviews from Rosen.
This course is critical in the economics pathway. I would recommend preparing for lecture by reading the chapter to provide your own structure.
This is a quick-moving course in which a background knowledge of economics would be extremely beneficial for the class. The readings are necessary and should be done thoroughly if possible.
This was my first ECO class, and I'm glad to say it really opened me up to a new perspective. Take it.

With certain professors, this course will be very much self-taught. Read Mankiw, especially if you haven't been exposed to Economics at all before. Know your graphs. And go to your preceptors for help.

This is an intro class, but it isn't a blow-it-off class. Take it seriously. Enjoy the material. Really think about the problems that economics explores... beyond businesses and firms. It's really fascinating/
Worth it if you are a self-learner
You should go to the lectures and review its notes and the online handouts before beginning homework.
dont take econ 100 if reinhardt is the professor
descrip: Economics is the study of how people and societies deal with scarcity. This course focuses on the advantages and disadvantages of market systems for allocating scarce resources.

title: Special Studies in Medieval Literature - Romance Love
descrip: This course examines how some of the most important medieval English romances (and a few French ones) theorize love before it was romantic. The love we find is bound up in theology, philosophy, the matter of Rome, the Gesta Romanorum, vernacularity, dynastic succession, mimetic desire, technologies of restoration, the cipher of paternity, condilectio, the impossibility of "courtly love," meconnaissance, and the struggle for recognition. Readings include work by Lauren Berlant, D.W. Robertson, Slavoj Zizek, C.S. Lewis, Georges Bataille, and others.

title: Neuroscience of Being Human, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Survey of Selected Greek Literature - Survey of Greek Literature
descrip: A survey of major literary forms and works from the Archaic to the Greco-Roman period.

title: Founding, Building, and Managing an Architectural Practice - Business and Legal Issues in Architectural Practice
reviews: If you want to own your business and oopen your own office, you should take it
a course you cannot afford to miss if you plan on going into practice.
descrip: Review and analysis of the dynamics and process inherent in starting, developing, managing and operating an architectural practice, including marketing, finance, human resources, project process, liability, insurance, and general management. Areas of particular emphasis include project accounting, public presentations, and the development of a business plan.

title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
reviews: A very good course.
Hopefully by the time you take this, it will be a full course with proper departmental support.

Until something is done with the material, skip the lectures entirely. I think it would be more worthwhile to watch the online videos of Bill Tang given proper lectures and do the assignments on your own.
descrip: Advances in experimental and theoretical studies or laboratory and naturally-occurring high-temperature plasmas, including stability and transport, nonlinear dynamics and turbulence, magnetic reconnection, selfheating of "burning" plasmas, and innovative concepts for advanced fusion systems. Advances in plasma applications, including laser-plasma interactions, nonneutral plasmas, high-intensity accelerators, plasma propulsion, plasma processing, and coherent electromagnetic wave generation.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: Full-time research internship at a host institution, to perform scholarly research relevant to student's dissertation work. Research objectives are determined by advisor in conjunction with outside host. A mid-semester progress review and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students for up to two semesters. Special rules apply to international students regarding CPT/OPT use. Students may register by application only.

title: Embodied Computation
prereqs: The emphasis is on learning new methods of developing design, and there are no prerequisites, but a strong motivation to tackle new knowledge and work in an experimental design setting is expected.
descrip: Computational design is often presented as a problem solving tool for design implementation rather than as an integral part of design conceptualization and exploration. This seminar focuses on approaching computational design from the conceptual design direction extending existing or defining novel models of design along the way. A strong emphasis is put on prototyping as a mode of design iteration using both computational prototypes and computationally generated physical prototypes as embodiments of the design process.

title: Category Theory
reviews: A background in algebra is highly recommended, and knowing some topology wouldn't hurt either.
If you like seeing many different areas of math from a unified perspective, this is a great course to take. Professor Halvorson is a wonderful lecturer.

It's a great class for a wide variety of students: for math majors interested in algebra, topology, or algebraic geometry, category theory illuminates and unifies many commonplace techniques and constructions and is a useful framework for learning new concepts. For math or philosophy majors interested in foundations of math, category theory is an exciting and dynamic alternative to the much more rigid approach of set theory and classical logic as well as a new way to study logic. For computer science majors, category theory underlies many of the fundamental abstractions in things like functional programming. If this class is offered again, I would recommend any interested students to try it.
Office hours are helpful.

This course is hard, but very worth it. It definitely is taught like a math course, so expect to put in a math-course-like amount of time (rather than the time you'd expect for a philosophy course).

That said, it's doable (though difficult) as a non-math-major. The class gave me a cool introduction to many diverse areas of mathematics, as well as giving a framework for understanding and unifying them.

This is a really interesting course that clarifies a ton about the structure of mathematics. However, it is also EXTREMELY abstract (and I am a Math major), especially the second half of the course. It is not an easy course and is very mathematical in nature (beware philosophy students unless you have a strong background in logic). I would advise definitely having some knowledge of Algebra first, and it would be even better if you know Topology, Logic, or Algebraic geometry.

To math majors: I think you'll really like the first half of this course, but I doubt you'll get much out of the second half. And while Prof. Halvorson is an interesting lecturer, the lectures are nothing special. You'd probably feel no ill will towards this course, but you'd probably not love it either.

To philosophers: I have no idea whether you'll like this course. Sorry!
prereqs: One Course in logic, abstract algebra, or topology..
descrip: An introduction to category theory, including limits and colimits, functors, adjoints, natural transformations, monads and algebras. The material will be developed alongside applications to abstract algebra, topology, and mathematical logic.

title: The Poems and Plays of Seamus Heaney
reviews: If you have a chance to take a class with Professor O'Toole, do it. He is a wonderful professor.
Professor O'Toole is magnificent. Seamus Heaney is brilliant. This class was a joy in every way.
see above
descrip: Seamus Heaney, who died in August 2013, was rare among contemporary poets in having both a huge public following and the admiration of his peers: both a Wordsworthian romantic and a Joycean realist; an atheist in search of the miraculous; a cosmopolitan with a little patch of remembered earth; a lover of the archaic who could not escape the urgency of contemporary history. This course follows Heaney's rich career, placing him in the context both of modern Ireland and world literature.

title: Witnessing Disaster
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Global Seismology
reviews: I strongly recommend this course. You will learn many geophysical knowledge and enjoy the discussions.
None.
Stay engaged with the material. Three hours is a long class. Don't be afraid to tell instructor ideas for topics and going in a direction you're more interested in.
descrip: The Deep Earth - which constitutes the majority of our planet - controls many processes which have shaped our world. But the challenges of understanding the large scale features and fine details of the mantle and core, as well as Earth's crust, are immense. In this course, we explore a variety of seismological techniques, and examine both fundamental and new papers from seismology and other related branches of the geosciences, to illuminate different aspects of the Deep Earth through global seismology.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Political Approaches to Inequality
descrip: This seminar focuses on the politics and political economy of inequality and the welfare state, focusing on the institutions and policies of the advanced industrial economies. We review some simple models of policy choice by self-interested voters (e.g. concerned with their own incomes and economic risks) in a purely majoritarian setting. We also explore the role of different economic and political institutions such as firms, unions, parties, and electoral systems. We also consider more complex models of voter motivations including altruism, religion, and racial attitudes.

title: Quixotic Desires
reviews: It was good.
Take this class if you like reading; that's what it is. If you're looking for a more conversation based course, maybe think it over.
Take this course if you need an LA--there are a lot of papers, but short ones, and the readings are interesting. Professor Brownlee is great.

This is  great course if you are looking for something interesting but also low key. You an make this course as difficult or as easy as you want. Take note that it is not as discussion based as one might expect a comparative literature seminar class to be.
descrip: Since 1605, Don Quixote has been an icon of idealistic and misguided desire. This course explores quixotic desire and its representation (from the psychoanalytic to the cultural issues it raises) in Cervantes seminal text, Flaubert's daring update, 'Madame Bovary', Mann's 'Death in Venice', Kafka's 'Metamorphosis', Nabokov's 'Lolita', and Kathy Acker's post-feminist post-punk 'Don Quixote'. Films inspired by this topic (by Welles, Visconti, Chabrol and Kubrick) will also be considered.

title: Special Topics in Contemporary Practice - Body, Object, Sound: Translation and the Making of Performance
reviews: BY FAR, ONE OF THE BEST OPPORTUNITIES I'VE HAD IN PRINCETON.
I would absolutely take this course if you are interested in expanding your performance scope.
Take a course with any of these professors; all are great and will help you explore your art.
Take this class!
Take this course!! It will make you grow so much as an artist.
descrip: Join percussionist Jason Treuting, visual artist Suzanne Bocanegra, and choreographer Susan Marshall in creating and performing art works with your classmates. This course examines the art of engaging in playful cross-disciplinary collaboration. What happens when one medium is translated to another, then back again, and then to something else entirely? This hands-on workshop will focus on the process of collaboration and the how of constructing works that involve sound/music, objects and the body. This class is both for seasoned creators/performing artists and for those with less experience who possess an adventurous and curious spirit.

title: Algebraic Topology
prereqs: Topology MAT 365 (formerly 325) and Algebra MAT 345 (formerly MAT 322). For advanced level undergraduate and graduate students. Undergraduates must obtain permission from Instructor..
descrip: The aim of the course is to study some of the basic algebraic techniques in Topology, such as homology groups, cohomology groups and homotopy groups of topological spaces.

title: History of Criticism
descrip: This course will focus on the work of Friedrich Nietzsche, and that of his important readers like Georges Bataille, Pierre Klossowski, Michel Foucault, Gilles Deleuze, and others. We will seek to understand the complexity of Nietzsche's thought, as well as the pain and the promise of this thinker's oeuvre. We will also explore the relations between idealism and materialism.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Subwavelength Nanophotonics and Plasmonics
reviews: If you are working on photonic devices, this is the class for you.
It's deceptively low workload at first. Generous grading distribution was promised at the beginning. We shall see if that was the truth.
descrip: An introductory course for the 1st and 2nd year graduate students to understand the theory and application of the photonic devices which have feature size smaller than the wavelength of light, termed subwavelength photonics (SWP) or subwavelength optical elements (SOE). The devices include those with metallic structures, namely, subwavelength plasmonics. The course has three main sections: (i) rigorous Maxwell theory and mean-field theory for SWPs, (ii) non-resonant SWPs and resonant SWPs (photonic crystals), and (iii) applications of SWP.

title: Topics in Science Technology and Environmental Policy - Biotechnology Policy
descrip: This course provides in-depth analysis of selected topics in biotechnology that are currently the focus of intense debate in the public and policy arenas. Topics include genetic modification of plants and animals, genetic testing in human populations, stem cells, cloning, and advanced reproductive technologies. Each topic is examined from the perspective of potential commercial applications, risk/benefit analysis, impact on individuals and society, the viewpoints of supporters and detractors, and the political response in the U.S. and other countries.

title: Digital Neurocomputing
descrip: Machine learning algorithms allow us to induce rules based on empirical training data. The course establishes statistical and algebraic foundations essential to kernel-based learning approach, for vectorial and nonvectorial data analysis. More specifically, it covers: (i) aptive techniques for feature selection and dimension reduction PCA, SODA and DCA; (ii) unsupervised cluster discovery: K-means, SOM, kernel K-means, kernel SOM, and hierarchical clustering; and (iii) supervised learning algorithms: Fisher discriminate analysis (FDA), kernel ridge regressor (KRR), support vector machines (SVM), and ridge-SVM.

title: Financial Risk Management
descrip: This course covers the basic concepts of modeling, measuring and managing financial risks. Topics include portfolio optimization (mean variance approach and expected utility), interest rate risk, pricing and hedging in incomplete markets, indifference pricing, risk measures, systemic risk.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Political Science
descrip: This seminar is concerned with the professional obligations of political science researchers. This course is designed to raise those concerns and develop in students an appreciation for the issues that they might confront as they do their work. Topics addressed includes the relationship of political science as an academic discipline to democratic politics and institutions, advocacy and objectivity in political science, plagiarism and academic misconduct, human subjects and fieldwork in research, institutional review boards, funding sources and intellectual integrity, collaboration, and mentoring.

title: Ethics of Human Experimentation, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Latino Politics in the U.S.
reviews: Take this course! Aside from learning a lot, I think this course has made me more of a disciplined worker.
prereqs: No prior knowledge of the topic is required, but familiarity with the basics of American politics and scientific inquiry will be very helpful..
descrip: What is Latino politics and is it different from American politics? What do we know about Latino voting and attitudes in U.S. elections? How do policies and institutions impact Latinos, and how are policies and institutions impacted by them? What methods can we use to find out? In this course we will use social science to examine questions about Latino politics in the U.S. Topics include: party identification and policy preferences; patterns of political participation; ethnic and national identity; immigration, demographics and their political impact; Latino subgroup differences such as generation, national origin and religious affiliation.

title: General Computer Science
reviews:
1. Use the lab TAs to your advantage; DO NOT just use them without doing your own thinking, or else they will get annoyed, you are cheating, and you won't learn.
2. It is easy to think that you can do this stuff on your own, but you'd be surprised what a better experience it is to believe in the course and use their resources instead of looking at code online and risking some kind of plagiarism mishap. 
3. Lectures are awesome, precepts are awesome, and office hours are great. 
4. Oh man what a great course. Take it before the golden age is over!
9/10 would take again.
Attend Lecture and start the assignments early!!!!
Be active at the beginning and keep up with things otherwise you'll get confused especially if you have a bad preceptor. Take it, it's worth it, but it'll be a lot of work even to get by.
Be prepared for the time commitment and to be greatly challenged, but definitely worth a shot.
Be sure to keep up with the material as the course moves fast, and to stay engaged in lecture and precept.

Be sure to know what's going on at all times. Don't slack off and start assignments too late because at the end of the day, you have other classes and work you need to do, so staying up doing COS until 12am on Monday night will most likely mess up your schedule for the next couple of days, if not for the entire week. Just be proactive and definitely go to office hours and the lab TAs.
Big time commitment, but good payoff.

COS 126 is regarded as one of the best courses on campus, and other reviews will tell you as such. Nevertheless, you should keep in mind that programming, like math, can be somewhan binary. When taking it, you'll find out that you're either good at it, or you find it hard to understand. Some attribute this to prior programming experience, but precisely why this binary delineation exists is unclear. At any rate, if you have doubts about whether you'll do well in the course, learning the basics of logic and programming on your own, outside of the class, will give you a good indicator of success. A large part to it is understanding sentencial logic - knowing what Boolean algebra is and how conditional statements work is about half of all there is to programming. Logic is to programming as numbers are to arithmetic.
COS is really useful today. Take it
Changes the way you think. Very well-taught and lots of resources. Take it!!

DO IT!  This course is really fun and I think well taught, even for someone like me who has never had programming experience before.  This was a great class and it affirmed my inclination to get a COS certificate.
Definitely make use of the lab TAs. Going to classes is probably a good idea.
Definitely my favorite class at Princeton so far. The course is well-organized, informative, and even entertaining. May be difficult if you have never coded before.
Definitely start early on assignment and go to preceptors for individual help.
Definitely take it but expect to put in a fair amount of work.

Definitely take it, but try to take it during a semester wherein you have less demanding classes (if you're an engineer unfortunately you won't be able to make that happen...), so that you could fully devote your time to this class and get the most out of it without being too stressed.
Definitely take this class and go to all the lectures and precepts.

Definitely take this course! Because of the lack of the curve it might actually mess up your GPA, but if you have any interest in computer science as an end in itself or simply as a means to having an important skill or understanding computers better, this class is amazing. It may vary slightly based on lecturer, however.

Definitely take this course!! The material is fascinating and gives you a better understanding of computers as a whole, not just programming. Assignments are really fun (I always used them as a form of productive procrastination), and if you find them too difficult, you can always get help from lab TAs or on Piazza (an online forum where professors answer your questions). Try to get Doug Clark - his lectures are absolutely fascinating because he adds interesting material like Bacon numbers (like six degrees of Kevin Bacon, you know?), chaos theory, and how to design a computer using the game minesweeper. I promise you will always want to attend lectures and won't regret taking this class!
Definitely take this course, even if it is not required. Coding is a great skill to have, and this course gives you a very good foundation to build on.
Definitely take this course. It is very interesting and you get incredible hands on help. It is enjoyable.
Definitely to go to the TA's if you need help and finish assignments early.
Do as many exercises as you can until you really understand a concept.
Do assignments well in advance
Do not start the assignments the day before they're due.
Do not worry that much about the extra credit. Study like mad for the written midterms; they are pretty hard.
Do practice programs on the websheets before you do the assignments, if you are having trouble with the assignments. The websheets help solidify your understanding of that particular week's lessons.
Do the book readings, meet with your preceptor as necessary.

Do the reading each week, start studying for exams as soon as possible; do as many practice ones as you can and bring all your questions to preceptors. Make sure you can not just code, but code quickly; this is key on the practical exams.
Do the readings before lecture.
Don't PDF it because you will be putting in enough work anyway to merit the extra effort required to get a good grade
Don't be intidated! Just take it!

Don't be scared of COS.  It's hard, yes, but so rewarding. I had no background in computer science and considered myself fairly inept with computers going into it, but I still really liked the course. I think everyone should take it.  It is something everyone should know at least a little bit.
Don't freak out during the 50 minute midterms and make sure to answer the questions carefully
Don't let style mistakes ruin your homework grade.
Don't procrastinate!!
Don't settle for a bad preceptor (I switched into Dr. Israel's precept from a TERRIBLE preceptor mid semester) and this will be a great course. I think that everybody should take this course.

Don't take this as a 6th course... It's a lot of work, and a lot of TIME. The course gets a lot easier in the second half when the assignments start being partnered and you start learning more theoretical material than practical coding stuff.
Enjoy!  Ask Questions!   Go to Lecture!   Don't Get behind!
Even if you are not a COS major or an engineer, I highly recommend this class. You need to be willing to put in the time, but definitely worthwhile!
Every student should take this course. It may be frustrating at times, but it is very useful and there is a lot of help available.
Everyone should take this class to learn the basics of computer programming.
Everyone should take this course. It's great.

Fantastic course! Clark's lectures are extremely clear and you get to do a lot of really fun and interesting assignments. Furthermore, you get a huge amount of support. The preceptors are phenomenal in this course in making sure you are up to pace with things. Definitely do not be afraid to take this course. You will learn a lot and enjoy your semester.
For people who can, maybe PDF because I think getting an A is pretty hard but it's definitely something you should learn.

GREAT COURSE!!! Doug Clark is an AMAZING lecturer. For those who have taken computer science before, I can say that the assignments (beginning with n-body) were all really interesting and definitely learned a lot, especially with theory.
Get Donna Gabai as preceptor if you can, and you don't really have to go to lecture AND do the readings, one should be sufficient. It's an amazing class though, take it!
Get Donna as your preceptor.
Get started early and ask questions when needed
Give it time, coding grows on you.
Go to lab hours! Start assignments early.
Go to office hours and lab TA to help debug. Also start your programs before the day that it is due.
Go to one of these three: lecture, precept, book reading.
Good class, but the lack of a curve is pretty unfair. You can do fantastic work and still end up with a B simply due to the ridiculous cutoff.

Great class to learn the basics of computer science, and you feel like you walk away with a tangible skill. If you're unsure, PDF it. It can be very difficult for a non-math-y person to get an A, or even a B .
Great class! Should be taken by everyone!
Great course

Great introduction to computer science - the assignments are fun and there is a lot of help available. Go to lab TA hours! Newbie Nite was also extremely helpful. Try very hard to make sure that your preceptor speaks English well; I ended up skipping my precept a lot because I simply could not understand my preceptor.
Great to learn coding if you never have coded before
Hard to recommend for me since I didn't particularly improve my cos but I did enjoy it.
Have a little bit of computer science background coming in. The course progresses really quickly especially in the first few weeks.
I am an econ major, and I really enjoyed the course. I had zero experience in COS before, but still did well. The assignments are pretty time consuming, but I enjoyed them.
I really don't understand people raving about this course. I nearly died
I strongly recommend this course. It was very interesting.
I would advise students to take this course if they are committed to the workload and interested in computer science at all!

I would advise them to try other precepts if they didn't like their own (which I failed to do). I would also advise them to at least skim the textbook and take notes on important things. Ultimately, though, I did learn a ton about computer science and definitely recommend this course.
I would definitely suggest taking this course if you get the chance.

I would highly recommend taking the course as both one of the best lectures I've attended and as essential to living in the modern world. I would recommend learning basic programming online before taking the course to make the first weeks a little easier.

I would recommend P/D/F-ing this course, because the somewhat reduced quality of the lectures/precepts was frustrating when it came to the exams. But the programming assignments were great. The subject material is also useful for anyone as a global citizen.

I would recommend any student to take this class. The knowledge I gained is very helpful and there is a tremendous amount of resources available for help on the problem sets and in better understanding the concepts mentioned in class.
I would recommend taking the course, but I would mention that Lab TA hours are super helpful and super crowded, so get there early and expect to stay late.
I would recommend that students attend the lectures and really pay attention to the material in the book. Exams test knowledge of specific concepts.
I would recommend that students start assignments earlier rather than later. By starting earlier, the resources available can be better utilized.
I would recommend the course. I learned a ton even though it wasn't my number one priority for the semester.

I would recommend this course to anyone with any interest in computer science.  You will be so proud of all that you learned.  Do allot plenty of time to do some readings ahead of lecture, as this helps you to keep up with the fast pace.
I would recommend this course to anyone, especially if professor Clark is teaching it.
I would say to manage your time well and to budget coding sessions throughout the week. Being able to walk away from the code for a little when frustrated was a great thing.
I would tell them to make sure to get a good preceptor that explains the material well, and to schedule their time appropriately for the assignments.

IF THERE IS ONE COURSE THAT IS A MUST-TAKE AT PRINCETON, IT IS THIS COURSE!!! Honestly, Professor Clark's lectures are engaging, the assignments are fun and challenging, and you are given the tools to go from knowing nothing about computer science to being very competent in it. Computer science can be applicable to almost any other subject in this day and age, and knowing how to code is a skill that is useful in all walks of life. Even more so than learning to code in this class, however, you are taught how to think. If you want to better your critical thinking skills, learn a useful skill, and possibly fall in love with an entirely new academic discipline, take this course!
If you are technically minded, feel free to take it if you don't mind some stress and a workload.  If you are an AB major and have difficulty using Word, this is not the class for you.
If you are to choose any precepts, make sure Donna Gabai or Maia Ginsburg are teaching them. They are skilled and experienced.
If you don't understand an aspect of programming, ask before continuing; everything builds as the semester goes.

If you have any interest in CS, take this class in freshman fall. You learn a lot, and it makes a big difference to start early. It's one of the best-taught courses I've seen so far, and I strongly recommend that you take it.

If you have even a passing interest or curiosity about computer science and programming, you owe it to yourself to take this course. This is one of the most taken, most polished courses on campus. From what I can see, taking this class in the spring is preferable, especially if you have no computer science background (like myself). This is because 1) Professor Clark is one of the best lecturers I've had and 2) more of your inexperienced friends and engineers will take it then, so you'll get to work together or at least struggle together. Be aware that this class has a huge range in difficulty for different individuals. Although I didn't know anything about programming or COS before this course, I found this class to be very manageable and rewarding. I had friends with similar levels of experience who had to drop the course because it simply wasn't clicking for them. Also, I'd recommend against PDF'ing this class; there's a lot of work needed to pass the class, but if you can get that far, you're probably going to at least get a B anyways.
If you have the time, take it.

If you're a humanities kid looking to fulfill a QR requirement and learn something new, I wouldn't recommend this class. PDFing it doesn't really help because you still have a huge workload. This class is very, very time consuming.

If you're a non-science person, like me: don't be afraid to ask questions and to ask for help, start the assignments early, do practice exams and make sure you have enough time in the semester to devote consistent attention to the class. It's an incredibly-well-organized class and you will learn a lot, but bear in mind that it is time-consuming.
If you're at all interested in CS, take this course! It's well-run, and you'll learn to code in one semester with no prior experience.

If you're debating placing out of this course, do so. You won't get as much as you might think you will from taking it. If you haven't taken any COS before, also take it. It is taught well and will give you an essential skill for an ever more technology based world.
If you're interested in computer science, this is the BEST course to start with!

If you've coded before, don't get cocky. The written exams aren't as easy as you might think. Don't miss lectures about TOY, machine code, or binary - stuff that's theory and not Java. Those will throw you off on the exams if you're not careful. Also, I found those lectures to be the most interesting.
If you've never learned JAVA before, the book helps a lot. Also, even if you have, keep in mind that assignments can take hours and you should always start early.
It is a wonderful course, and really opens your eyes up to the power of computers. You should definitely take it, even if you don't plan on using computer science ever in the future.
It is very time consuming make sure to start early on all assignments and studying
It's a demanding course.
It's a good class so take it but be aware of the time commitment.

It's a great class and you learn a lot in only one semester- but beware! You won't be able to get away without doing any work even if you are PDFing. Be prepared to work really hard and if you feel like you are not doing well, seek help from the beginning.

It's a great course to get an understanding of programming and applications. The assignments are very interesting and there's a good cohesion between precepts, assignments, and lectures. Also, attend lab TA hours whenever you need help (preferably earlier than the night before it's due). Period.

It's a great opportunity to learn programming and the big ideas in computer science. If you're even considering taking this course, you should. Computer science skills are valuable in many academic disciplines and fields of work - if you don't take the course now, you will regret it when you are in the working world.
It's allot of work but very rewarding!
It's extremely useful, just be prepared to spend 6-10 hours per week on the assignments if you are new to coding.
It's literally a necessity for BSE freshmen, and it's fun for everyone else, just try to get a good preceptor or find someone (maybe a lab TA?) who can answer your questions
It's no walk in the park.
It's very enjoyable and useful.
Its interesting and helpful if you have interest in computers.
Just follow all the advice the lecturers and preceptors give you--especially about starting the problem sets early.
Keep on top of the workload, and try to understand the basics from the beginning.
Keep up with the material and assignments.  Attend precepts.  Use lab hours and Piazza as needed for help.
Keep up with the work and you'll get the most out of the course!
Loved the problem sets. Make sure to get 20/20 on all of them bc the grade is not curved (found that out too late) so you'll need every point.
MUST take it before you graduate.
Make sure that you get a competent preceptor as they will likely make or break you in this class.  They cut down the amount of self learning that you have to do.
Make sure that you go to lab TAs and office hours if you have questions.
Make sure to attend precepts, and office hours and TA hours are a great resource that everyone should use. The earlier you start assignments, the less stressful they will be to complete.
Make sure to do all the practice - ex. Websheets because they allow you to fully understand the concepts. And it is also a very good class to take even if you are not a COS/engineering student.

Make sure to do the readings BEFORE the lectures so the lectures will be more helpful. Go to office hours on a consistent basis (even review topics covered in lectures if you don?t have any issues with the assignments), and use Piazza!
Make sure to get Donna Gabai as your preceptor, and make sure you start the programming assignments as early as possible.
Make sure to keep up with your work.

Make sure to stay on top of the readings, and pay attention to the minute details about coding techniques and such brought up in lecture and the readings because they will be necessary in preparation for the written exam which is quite different from the coding assignments.
Make sure you have the time to devote to this course and start assignments early
Make sure you take the time to understand the material if you decide to take it.
Make sure you umdrstand what's going on early in the course because it provides a foundation for everything else in the semester.
Make sure your basics are strong.
Not a fan unless your pdf or have previous coding experience.
Not worth PDFing for the amount of hours you need to put in per week
One of my favorite classes at princeton. Really teaches you how to think and everyone should take this course.
Only take if interested in computer science
Pay very close attention the first couple weeks, because the course only builds from there
Practice programming even outside the assignments, and keep up with your theory.
Practice with lots of past written examinations.
Prepare well for the written exams
Programming exams are you either get it or you don't. Other than that the course was very interesting.

Programming is an absolute must of a life skill that you need to learn, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend learning it by taking COS 126. It is a fun and very interesting class, but you could learn more object-oriented programming by just taking AP CS in high school (which most people in the class have done before taking the course)
Read the booksite/textbook!

Read the textbook, start assignments early, and try not to get frustrated. Don't take this if you are not interested. It is incredibly time consuming if you haven't had prior coding experience and aren't naturally amazing at it. Even PDFing it would be hard.

Seek help. There are so many resources available for this course- office hours, lab ta's, piazza. Take advantage of them. People hate debugging code as much as you do. It is better to ask someone who made a commitment to help you than to ask a friend to look over your code when they are probably busy with their own work.

Shop preceptors because I had the worst one imaginable. She was very condescending, laughed when we got questions wrong or asked dumb questions, and kept asking us how we didn't understand the material.  We didn't understand it because she went over it in under 10 minutes every precept so we spend the last 40 minutes sitting there confused while she laughed at us. SHOP PRECEPTORS! And go to lab TA office hours of course.
So hard, so good. Even if you don't understand everything, it's worth it to learn some new, important, and interesting things.
Start all projects early and don't be afraid to ask for help.

Start assignments ahead of time, and take full advantage of the help available...there's so much help available that you should not have to spend a ridiculous amount of time finding one bug (although you should be able to debug on your own). If you're stuck, just ask! Also, partner programming can be a good experience, but tend to take more time than doing the assignment on your own, so always plan ahead.
Start assignments early so that you don't have to debug under time constraints.

Start assignments early. Don't get stuck on a problem in your code for too long, take it to Lab TAs or office hours, right away! And do yourself a favor and get Donna, Dave, Maia, or Judi as a preceptor. Guaranteed to understand. Donna is the best!
Start studying for the two midterms as far in advance as possible.
Start the programs as soon as possible. Also, if you are new to computer science, go to the Newbie Nights hosted by Donna Gabai. She is incredibly helpful.
Start working on your assignments as soon as possible, is a terrible idea to cram it the night of.
Stay on top of the assignments and the websheets.
Stay on top of the reading, pay attention during lecture, and do the precept assignments even if you have to do so out of class
TAKE IT AND START PROBLEM SETS EARLY! GO TO OFFICE HOURS (THERE ARE SO MANY OF THEM B/C TA's ARE FANTASTIC)
TAKE IT and don't be intimidated: there is a lot of help available, but it is up to you to make use of it. Enjoy the class - you get out of it as much as you are prepared to put in!
TAKE IT.
TAKE THIS CLASS

TAKE THIS COURSE!!! Everyone says this, because it is true: COS 126 is one of the best classes offered at Princeton. This is such a good choice. One of my biggest Princeton regrets was waiting until so late in the game to take COS classes. This course in particular is a well-oiled machine. That said, I've heard there are other phenomenal preceptors. Clark is a great lecturer, really engaging and always seeming so excited to teach us from his vast base of knowledge. The assignments aren't as scary as you may think before you take a COS class, and many are actually fun. The written exams are doable but just very long given the 50 minute time. descrip: An introduction to computer science in the context of scientific, engineering, and commercial applications. The goal of the course is to teach basic principles and practical issues, while at the same time preparing students to use computers effectively for applications in computer science, physics, biology, chemistry, engineering, and other disciplines. Topics include: hardware and software systems; programming in Java; algorithms and data structures; fundamental principles of computation; and scientific computing, including simulation, optimization, and data analysis. Two lectures, two precepts.

Here are the people who should take this class: you enjoyed 226, you want to learn more programming, you want a job in the tech industry, you will ever do any programing in the future. Go to lecture as much as possible because Wayne will trace through the algorithms in class and it is much easier to learn from him than read through the book, the book is not bad. The sunday excersises are incredibly annoying as you pretty much have to get 30/30 on every exercise, which can take 3-5 hours. However, these excersises do keep you up to date with the algorithms. When doing the assignments, read through the assignment page, checklist, and watch the videos. If you need help, go to Lab TA hours, but you should be fine. Most of the assignments are pretty straight forward. Code and test one step at a time and you will be fine. Debugging in this class is pretty straight forward, identify what is going wrong, where is it going wrong, how is it going wrong. If you do this you will be fine. If you code a little, test a little you can catch bugs early. For the midterm and exam take as many practice tests as possible. However focus on the more recent ones as some of the material on older exams may be outdated.  Learn how to trace through the algorithms that show up on those exams. Practice design questions like crazy. I took 226 with 217 and it is doable. If you decide to take them at the same time you have to work ahead. At first the two classes together are manageable. However, later in the semester the assignment deadlines start to overlap. 226 takes less time than 217, but you get less late days for 217. If you are someone who codes at the last minute, don't take these two classes together. You will also be coding/debugging a lot if you take these two classes together. If this is not something you enjoy, don't take these two together. These two classes took up the majority of my semester. If you are planning on taking them together, take them will really easy classes to make the

For example, blackboard exercises would be disabled the second it turned midnight, and assignments submitted 2 seconds after 2am were considered late. The readmes are deceptively long, and I often submitted assignments a few seconds (no exaggeration) after the deadline, thinking it wouldn't be a big deal. prereqs: COS 126, ISC 231-234, or approval by the COS placement officer..
descrip: This course surveys the most important algorithms and data structures in use on computers today. Particular emphasis is given to algorithms for sorting, searching, and string processing. Fundamental algorithms in a number of other areas are covered as well, including geometric algorithms, graph algorithms, and some numerical algorithms. The course will concentrate on developing implementations, understanding their performance characteristics, and estimating their potential effectiveness in applications.

title: Comparative Political Economy
reviews: Definitely take it! It's a solid departmental and Professor Londregan is a great guy. He'll definitely help if you feel behind.
Go to precepts and write down literally everything he says. Londregan basically gives you the problem set answers in precept.
Professor Londgregan is a great professor who is really engaged and always available for students if they are having trouble
Take it, very interesting subject matter, but be prepared for more math than you would think.
highly recommend
prereqs: Students are expected to have had ECO 101 and 102 and MAT 103 (or the equivalent of these three courses). Students who have taken ECO 300 (or ECO 310) will find the material in this course to be more transparent, and students who have not already taken POL 347 are encouraged to enroll in it concurrently..
descrip: This course forms part of the political economy core, and it introduces political economy models in the context of comparative politics. The course will emphasize the interaction between political institutions and economic goals and it will illustrate the application of the analytical and empirical methods developed in the other core courses in political economy. The course will apply the tools of political economy to understand the reasons for the differences among countries' levels of economic and political development, and to explain the interconnectedness of political and economic outcomes.

title: Slavic Dissertation Colloquium
descrip: A practical course devoted to scholarly writing intended to facilitate the dissertation writing process. The seminar meets every two weeks. Dissertation writers circulate work in progress for feedback and meet for discussion as a group. The seminar is required of all post-generals students in Russian literature who are in residence.

title: Fundamentals of Statistics
reviews: A hard class, but I definitely learned a lot. Professor Bubeck is a good lecturer who likes to talk about math if you ask him. I wouldn't take it just for fun, but I think that it was a very valuable investment of my time, since the material is so useful.
Avoid taking this course with Professor Bubeck. He goes on long irrelevant digressions and is not good at explaining the material.
Be on top of your work, go to office hours, and this course won't be all that bad!
Bubeck's exams are killer and do not match the quality and difficulty of the homework at all. Beware.

Depending on which semester you take it, it could be extremely challenging or doable.
Do not expect the exams to be as easy as the homework/precepts/prior exams posted. The first midterm completely surprised everyone.

You should go to precept--the material from the precepts will help you through the problem sets and also through the course project at the end of the semester.

This class requires a fair amount of work--don't take it if you have a heavy Dean's Date workload! There are 2 midterms, a project due on Dean's Date, and a final.
If you need to take it, and aren't afraid of learning R, do it! Having a great preceptor is really fundamental, but the lectures are also really helpful no matter who the professor is.

If you want to do well, you have to put in a LOT more work than the course asks you to during the semester, because there is large discrepancy between what is expected from you for the problem sets and what is expected from you for the midterms/finals. If you don't put in extra work, you will be absolutely miserable when final comes around.
If you're ORFE you have to take it: it won't be too bad, but it's not a good class. If you're not ORF, other statistics classes are way easier than this, take those instead.
It is a good course.
It's a great way to do statistics, but you may need to do work on your own.
It's really interesting material if you've never taken stats before!
