It's very informative and the most comprehensive intro to statistics here.  It's not very exciting and there is not much reason to go to lecture.  Read the book keep up with the problem sets, and you'll be fine
Just be aware that the work is nothing like the exams
Just be ready to be surprised on your exam.

Lectures by Bubeck are not very interesting. The final exam is not a good measurement of how well you understand the material that is taught in class. Final project also requires a lot of self learning too.
Not too challenging of a course, but keep ontop of the material as it picks up in difficulty at the second half of the semester.
Only take if needed

Only take it if you have to, its not worth it just because you generally are interested in or want to know statistics. If you do have to take it, know that the final is terrible and try to learn R before since they don't teach it well but expect you to know it after the class.
Pay attention, keep up with the class.
Pretty basic/standard statistics class. Take it for an intro to statistics.

Read the book; it'll make the concepts easier to understand.
Go to office hours if you can
Get a tutor!
Only take this course if you really have to. If you don't, take another stats class. It'll be a lot more approachable and you'll get more out of it. 
Be prepared for a difficult final. VERY difficult.
Really seek to understand the reasons behind things and take care doing the homework (no silly mistakes)
TAKE IT! You have to work hard for the midterm and the final but take it. However, if you don't have a strong math background, consider another stats class.
Take it if you must or you're interested in basic stats.
Take it if you need an intro to stats.
Take it if you need stats
Take it iff you have to
Take it. Best stats class on campus.
Take it1
Take practice tests. Don't be upset if the tests are too difficult. There really isn't a whole lot you can do for the difficult math parts.

The exams really require you to think and come up with new ways of using the equations/principles from class. Unlike the homework, most of the exam questions are not solved by plugging numbers into equations.
The only accurate measure of the midterms difficulty is the practice test. The material covered won't match very much.
This class has a manageable courseload. If you need a stats class, it's not a bad choice.
This course definitely provides you with a solid understanding of statistics, which is becoming more and more fundamental in any discipline. It is very well-taught and well-structured.
This course is not a huge time commitment, but there are two midterms, which is annoying. The tests are very hard but the homeworks are fairly easy and quick.

This course will give you a very solid understanding of introductory statistics and a few more advanced concepts. However, most of the students in the course are ORFE majors, engineers, or at least have strong math backgrounds. For anyone else, it is difficult to do really well as the curve is rather harsh.

This is a course whose material can be applied to many other fields. It is extremely valuable general knowledge. You will get to learn about both how to use statistics and how statistical concepts are derived. Lecture is very useful, as are precepts. Doing the practice exams before the midterm and final will give you an idea of what to expect. Proof-based questions may be different from what you have seen before, but thinking rationally through them enables you to make significant progress.

This is a good introduction to statistics. Do not take it with Professor Bubeck since his lecturing is inferior to Professor Rigollet and he makes you do a very laborious final project which wastes precious time during reading week. His exams are also very difficult. The one upside to Professor Bubeck's teaching is that his problem sets are just 12-15 question multiple choice questionnaires that are easy.
This is a pretty easy class, but beware of the final exam.

This is a relatively straightforward course. Though it does not require a huge time/effort commitment in the beginning of the year, the last few weeks are packed with dense information. Studying for the final and completing the final project will take a significant amount of time, so be prepared for that.

This is definitely not the easiest statistics course you could take, but I think it does provide a fairly in-depth introduction to the basics. Don't be afraid to ask questions during lectures or precepts.

This is essentially an AP stats course. If you took it in high school, don't make the mistake of not taking the actual exam, and then having to take this course. The material is already very dry, and Bubeck does not make a very good job of keeping you interested. Problem sets are easy, but midterms and the final can vary greatly in difficulty, which made the curve incredibly difficult. Also, the exams are graded with no partial credit..

You're likely taking this because you need either a stats class or a math elective (or you're ORFE). It's a pretty good class, just stay on top of the problem sets and readings and you'll do just fine.
go to office hours before the final
good class; tough grading
it is very useful to know, despite the professor and some preceptors not being the best
lectures aren't necessary but are very enjoyable to go to. use the slides and lot and the book as a reference for things you are confused about. very nice class to take-- useful interesting stuff
prepare for some disastrous grade deflation
really easy class if you have taken ap stats. almost no time commitment

unless you know stats. Do not take this course. unless you are highly proficient in math, do not take this course. If you are a scientist and want to learn these analytical tools - go to the lectures and buy the textbook, do the practice problems, or audit.
descrip: A first introduction to probability and statistics. This course will provide background to understand and produce rigorous statistical analysis including estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and regression. Applicability and limitations of these methods will be illustrated in the light of modern data sets and manipulation of the statistical software R. Precepts are based on real data analysis.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - The Future of Nuclear Energy after Fukushima
descrip: Course explores current debates about nuclear energy and reviews the basic science and technology and current uses of nuclear energy, with particular emphasis on the economic aspects and arrangements to prevent its use for weapons purposes. Policy proposals to facilitate the safe and rapid global expansion of nuclear energy are analyzed.

title: Germany since 1806
reviews: Definitely take this course if you're interested in German history. Professor James is an outstanding professor. Definitely recommend!
Take it!  Professor James is absolutely brilliant and always so receptive to student ideas.  Exactly what a college history course should be in its ideal form.

This course is very good at getting you to think critically, and the topic is extremely interesting! Everything is covered in depth, but extensive previous knowledge is not necessary: it's a wonderful course and it'll teach you a lot about what you're really interested in when historically analyzing articles and primary sources. Professor James is also an amazing teacher, and he's very knowledgeable about the subjects - he wrote one or two articles from the readings! Take it!
descrip: This course sets German history in a comparative context of international politics, demonstrating how nationalism and national unity emerged as responses to the European state system in the first half of the 19th century, how after 1871 German problems in turn affected the world, and finally why after 1945 Germany should be so prominent in super-power politics. It examines the origin of the German Revolution of 1989, and the place of Germany in Europe and the global order.

title: Topics in Evolution - Molecular Evolution
descrip: This seminar discusses the origin and evolution of life from a molecular perspective. Topics include the origin of eukaryotes, the last common ancestor, and organelles, comparative genomics, population genetics, the microbiome, and human evolution. One three-hour seminar.

title: Mathematics in Engineering II
reviews: Definitely take it. McAlpine is fantastic, and the material is clearly presented.
Definitely take this class but you should try to have a physics/MAE background.
Homeworks are very easy, you won't learn much in this class, but if you're looking for an easy 300 level math for physics it's a good choice.
I learned more about PDEs from Stone's notes in 305 but you get to learn interesting things about complex analysis.
I would take this course over other options that engineers sometimes take for the second math requirement. It is a light workload and material that may be very useful to have.

If you're confident in your ability to handle Princeton math classes, go ahead and take this class. If you're not sure, I'd find a different one to satisfy the requirement. You'll be a lot happier with your grade if you do.
If you're considering taking it, you probably need to. Do not take this course otherwise.
If you're physics and need complex, take this course.

In general, this is a good class to get an overview of a number of mathematical topics that are useful for scientists and engineers, is not too much work, and is quite enjoyable. For MAE's, it's often a choice between this class and ORF 245 for the second math requirement. Though I haven't taken ORF 245, I'd recommend this class because it wasn't too much work, was actually interesting, and McAlpine does a great job. It won't be the right choice for everyone, as you need to be ready to think mathematically, but if you enjoyed MAE 305, then go for it.
Not a course in PDEs - don't take it for that reason
Not as hard as MAE 305, but still thought-provoking.
Problem sets are not a very good indication of what you would expect on the midterm and the final. Examinations are heavily focused on the most recent material.
Really good math elective for engineers, although it isn't just a PDEs course, it also covers complex analysis and conformal mapping.
Relatively easy course to fulfill complex requirement.  McAlpine is mostly fair,  a sometimes interesting lecturer and a nice guy
Spend time on the problem sets--they may not be very long, but some of the later ones get pretty difficult conceptually.
Take it if you have to. But don't take it if you don't have to.
Take it if you're interested. Conformal mapping was really fun I thought and the class was generally enjoyable. It was well taught
Take it, though less rigorous than 305
Take this if you want to learn how to use complex analysis to solve PDEs for other classes which won't go over the mathematics required. I found it significantly easier than 305.
This class covers important material for engineers.
This is a good class and an easy way to fill the math requirement. take it, but put in the time especially when it comes to conformal mapping.

Tough course and tough material. Lectures could be better. I ended up learning most of the material on my own and with Ryan. It's annoying because there are tons of physics and math majors that have learned the material already and are taking it as an "easy A" course.
prereqs: MAE 305 or MAT 301 or MAE 303.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to partial differential equations, covering PDEs of relevant interest in engineering and science problems. The material covered includes: (i) Complex analysis, including complex functions and series, (ii) Fourier series, integrals, and transforms, (iii) Solutions of partial differential equations, (iv) Conformal mapping and Potential theory, and (v) Applications of all the above. The material will be covered in three weekly lectures, plus one weekly AI session. Grades will be determined from weekly homework assignments, the midterm and final exam.

title: Digital Photography
reviews: Good introductory class, but wish it had focused more on the technical aspects of making better photography rather than the artistic nature of photography.

I'd recommend it.  It's one of those classes where you can put in little work and still do okay but not get much out of it, or you can do a lot of work and really grow as a photographer.  It's really up to you.
Learn a good amount of photoshop and digital printing which is useful.
One of my favorite classes at Princeton. Really fun work. Lawson is great. Take if you have any interest in learning about how to use a digital camera, Photoshop, or color printing.
Prepare to supplement with outside learning sources; having to take photos every week for a class forces you to take more photos and is really fun; a great break from more monotonous academic work

Take opportunities outside of the class to improve your photo taking and editing skills. The class is a good introduction, but not enough to really master the skills, unless you have previous knowledge of them. That said, it is a fun class and very different from most classes at Princeton, which is a good thing.
Take this course! Put in the work and spend time in Lewis Center and you will get the most out of it.

This course is hard to asses since it's structure depends a lot on who is teaching it. 
I enjoyed it very much and I recommend it as a distribution requirement or "just for fun".
This is a very good course for an introduction to photography. I now feel that I have a good grasp on how to use my DLSR, and the basics of how to use photoshop.
Yes.
descrip: This studio course introduces students to aesthetic and theoretical implications of digital photography. Studio emphasis is on mastering digital equipment and techniques, managing print quality, and generally becoming familiar with all aspects of the digital workspace. Popular media, found photographs, and the "life" of digital images will also be investigated. Slide lectures, readings and class discussions of student work in critique format will augment visual skills with critical and conceptual understandings of contemporary photography.

title: Criticism and Theory - Keywords
descrip: In this course we explore some important keywords in literary studies--words, both classic and new, that unlock interesting questions, debates, and problems across fields. We begin with classic keywords that might include language and literature, or speech and performance, and move on to newer critical constellations like pain and suffering, object and thing, or suspicion and surface. Later, small groups identify or design a new keyword (or group of keywords) of their choice, select short readings for the class and make a case for the uses or possibilities of their word(s) for literary criticism today.

title: Ends and Means: Issues in Composition
descrip: This seminar investigates a variety of issues related to composing for orchestra including but not limited to: -where does composition end and orchestration begin? -concepts of space and time, case studies (Beethoven, Sibelius, Stravinsky, Ades, Adams, Lansky, Mackey and others) -who are we writing for the audience or the musicians? -the orchestra as an institution -the orchestra as an instrument

title: Childhood Psychopathology
prereqs: PSY 207 or PSY 254.
descrip: Examines major forms of childhood psychopathology, including autism and other life-span disorders. Issues such as childhood trauma, prevention, and continuity in the development of later adult disorders are also considered. Observations of and interactions with children with autism are also included in the course.

title: Turbulent Flow
reviews: Hard class, but the subjects add together to make sense.  Do your reading, and check out any relevant papers to the topic at hand.
It is very useful if you want to learn some basic knowledge in turbulence.
Take the course if you're interested in turbulence.  Work hard, and think about the lecture topics outside of class.
Take this class if you are at all interested in turbulence. It is a shame that he is leaving
This was an excellent course, I would honestly take it again if it was offered. It was hard to keep up at times, but always interesting.
descrip: Physical and statistical descriptions of turbulence, and a critical review of phenomenological theories for turbulent flows. The course examines scales of motion; correlations and spectra; homogeneous turbulent flows; inhomogeneous shear flows; turbulent flows in pipes and channels; turbulent boundary layers; calculation methods for turbulent flows (Reynolds stress equations, LES, DNS); and current directions in turbulence research. This course is offered in alternate years.

title: Cases in Financial Risk Management
prereqs: ECO 362 and ECO 465.
descrip: This course will teach students about financial risk management through the lens of the recent financial crisis. Topics covered will include market risk, credit risk, liquidity risk, and systemic risk. Students will draw on their background in economics, finance, probability theory and statistics. The class will be in seminar format and active participation in the discussion is encouraged.

title: Intermediate/Advanced Spanish
reviews: Always stay on top of he work.
Be on top of homework.
Be prepared to get lower grades than expected regardless of how good you think your work is.
Bookhamer is a good guy.

Bookhammer is a nice guy but I would not recommend him as a teacher. He was capricious and unfair about grades. He definitely picked favorites and was not clear about instructions. I think 107 is an okay course overall. Take it if you have too, but if you are looking for a spanish class for fun, don't take it. A lot of the exercises are superfluous and all the homework, while not collected, is busywork. Additionally, I think that the class in general put a lot of effort and most were upset and confused by the low grades that everyone was getting.
Check the calendar of assignments everyday.  only speak Spanish in class.
Do all the grammar exercises, they are really helpful for the exams.
Do the homework
Don't take it unless necessary.

Don't take this professor. I also feel as though the discrepancy in difficulty and time commitment between 107 and 108 is reversely large. By that I mean that I believe that the time commitment and amount of Busywork required for 107 makes it actually a more difficult class than 108. My roommate was in 108 and his homework and his tests seemed much more straightforward and easy than ours.
Go talk to the professor. Grading will be harsh no matter what, though.
Good course, as most language classes are here. Take it if you enjoy the language and want to learn how to become a better writer.
Good luck doing grammar exercises!

I do not feel like I can give advice to students because I feel like I had a completely different experience that others who were in different sections that my own. Therefore, I do not feel eligible to give advice to other students.
I recommend for students to take this course, because if you love spanish it would help you enhance your cultural knowledge and also the language itself.
I think this is a good course to take; just need to make sure you invest time into it.

I would recommend that they really spend time learning and studying the grammar pieces of the homework assignments because understanding those concepts is key to being able to write, speak and read Spanish well.
I would recommend this class, especially to solidify the grammar from 103 and get a lot more practice using Spanish.
I would recommend this course for anyone interested in speaking Spanish who is at the appropriate comprehension level.
If you can get through 103 or whatever sequence, 107 is a good look and you will learn spanish.
If you have to take it, go ahead. Otherwise I advise you not.

It is not one of my favorite courses at Princeton, and I would not have voluntarily taken it, but it is difficult to avoid given the strict language requirement at Princeton so just do the best you can.
It is what you make out of it. If you put in the effort, I guarantee that it will be rewarded! My Spanish has improved significantly.
Its a great opportunity to take an intensive language class 5 days a week!
Make sure to keep up with all the assignments!
Only take this class with Paloma as your teacher.
Read the syllabus closely and always ask the professor for clarification if there is any uncertainty about what is due and when.
Review old units as the semester goes on!

Spend time on the writing assignments and pay attention to the details in your papers.  Put effort into the homework assignments; the amount of work you put into the course directly relates to the success you will have with the language.
Stay on top of the work or you will not get as much out of the course as you could.
Study vocabulary and grammar well in advance to exams.
Take it! Especially with Lorena. Never be afraid to speak in class. If you put in the work, you'll love the class!
Take it.
Take this course.
Take this if you need the distribution, or even if you don't need it
There isn't too much work for it, and it really boosts your language skills.
This is the nicest, sweetest professor! You would be lucky to have her!
Too much busywork for an introductory language class.
You're probably taking this for the requirement but I strongly recommend Kevin Bookhamer's class. He's kind and explains things very well.
take this course but avoid Bookhamer
very straight-forward. If you study in advance, you will do well on the exams.
prereqs: SPA 102 or 103 with a passing grade..
descrip: An intermediate/advanced language course that continues and reviews the introductory level Spanish, while further developing students' communication skills, both orally and in writing. This is achieved through communicative activities in and out of the classroom, as well as various types of materials, both audiovisual and written. By the end of the course, students should have a better command of the four basic language skills: listening comprehension, speaking, reading and writing. Students will also be qualified to take 200-level Spanish courses.

title: Early Christian Women: From Mary Magdalene to Martyred Mothers
reviews: A wonderful course with a wonderful professor! If you are confused about Christian tradition, don't be afraid to ask! I was out of my depth and intimidated to ask, but you'll get more out of the class if you do.

Enjoy your time in class! Participate in class discussions because they are really encouraging and stimulating. If you have any interest in early Christian women/gender studies, you absolutely have to take this class.
Please take this! She really likes working with students, and you'll love her!
Study and work hard!

TAKE THIS - if you have any interest in understanding christian or hebrew women (even if you aren't one yourself), luijendijk will give you everything you need to personally understand life back then. this is a great GSS elective too to compare women under male oppression in historical texts.

TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Luijendijk is one of the few professors I've met at Princeton who goes out of her way to make her students feel at home and appreciated. (She even invited us to her home for dinner at the end of the semester.) This made the setting for discussion really strong, as people felt comfortable expressing opposing views and acknowledging their personal experiences and biases. We grew together as a class, and that was powerful. Obviously it's going to be a more liberal/feminist approach to traditional canonical texts, but she's willing to hear other perspectives in discussion, as are fellow students. The only problems with this class are that 1) from time to time we blend the line between reality and imagination in approaching history without acknowledging that we're doing so and 2) there aren't many (any? very few if so) readings that provide a more conservative approach to biblical interpretation. But it was a really powerful experience overall, both personally and intellectually.
Take it. This class (and Professor Luijendijk) is/are one of the best things that will happen to you at Princeton.
Take this course! Prof. Luijendijk is a gem. She is extremely smart and devoted to making the class interesting and productive for everyone. Truly one of my favorite classes at Princeton.
descrip: In this course we explore early Christian women as preachers, prophets, martyrs, mothers, and virgins. You will develop sophisticated reading skills by studying and interpreting a wide variety of early Christian texts and evidence from the material world (frescoes, papyrus letters). We meet, among others, Chloe, Jesus' mother Mary, Mary Magdalene, Thecla, and Perpetua and Felicitas. Questions we will investigate are: How did male Christian authors view the position of women in their communities? What can we extract historically about women? How do ancient debates relate to contemporary issues on gender and religion?

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Topics in Spanish Literature of the Golden Age - My Brilliant Career--Early Modern Discourses of Ambition
reviews: Be prepared to think creatively/not receive prompts for papers.
If you are SPA certificate or departmental, take a class with Surtz before graduating. He's phenomenal
Prof. Surtz is smart, interesting, nice, and entertaining. The papers are a pain to write and class discussions can be dry. Also, the readings are boring.
Try to do the readings or at least find summaries. Ask for help on the papers if you need it.
not a hard class; he's a pretty easy paper grader and class discussion was ok but the readings were crazy long
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course studies written accounts of the life trajectories of early modern Spaniards from Spain and Spanish America, examining figures that range from a failed [conquistador] to a cross-dressing ex-nun. We will explore how life experience and literary discourse interact in both biographical and autobiographical texts.

title: Transformations of the Self
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: High Tech Entrepreneurship
descrip: This "hands-on" practical course introduces students to the analysis and actions required to launch a successful high tech company. Using several conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques, it addresses the challenges of evaluating technologies for commercial feasibility, determining how best to launch a new venture, attracting the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners, and venture capital), preparing comprehensive business plans, structuring business relationships, and managing early stage companies toward "launch velocity" and sustainable growth.

title: Introductory Drawing
reviews: Always practice in your sketchbook and do the assignments.
Be prepared to pump several hours in assignments as the course progresses.
Daniel is fun and encouraging, and he really makes you THINK about drawing as well. I would definitely recommend learning drawing from him.
Do not take if you're not willing to put lots of time into it.
Enjoy it and commit to it, you're going to love it.

Homework assignments take a while, so do not wait until the last minute!  Also, in class, be prepared to work on one drawing for up to five hours at a time.  If you have a short attention span, this is not the course for you.

I felt that this course was not true to its "introductory" nature.  Almost all students had a very advanced background in drawing before coming in.  This is absolutely not a bad thing at all...however, I feel that it influenced the way the professor chose to teach the class.
I highly recommend this course if Professor Heyman is teaching it!

I took this class as a senior, with no prior drawing/art experience, and I do not regret it.  Even though it was a bit tough when things got more serious with thesis, I still always wanted to go to class and did not feel overwhelmed.  I learned so much!  Kurt was wonderful and if I were not graduating, I would definitely try to take another class with him.
Kurt Kauper is funny and instructional, I would recommend him as a professor.  The course quickly progresses from shapes to fruit to skulls to nude models.
Only take this course if you really like to draw!
Prof. Heyman is a really great instructor and made this intro class both challenging and doable
Strongly recommend taking this.

Take it if you really like drawing. You may want to consider the section taught by the other professor, as their projects looked a bit more interesting (but also the course looked like a lot more work, so...)
Take it if you're serious about drawing. It's fun but takes dedication.
Take the course.
Take this class because you love drawing/art or take it because you want to learn how to draw. Kurt was the best.
Take this course it's great, but be prepared to put in some hours of work fro the drawing assignments.
This is a very good beginner class and is quite informative.
You do not need to have any prior artistic experience. I recommend taking this course if you want to learn how to draw in a planar aspect.
take it!
take this
descrip: This course approaches drawing as a way of thinking and seeing. Students will be introduced to a range of drawing issues, as well as a variety of media, including charcoal, graphite, ink, oil stick, collage, string, wire and clay. Subject matter includes still life, the figure, landscape and architecture. Representation, abstraction and working from imagination will be explored. A structured independent project will be completed at the end of the term.

title: U.S. Medical Research and Researchers
reviews: Everyone interested in health should take advantage of the amazing faculty we have on this campus, like Prof's Rosenberg and Mahmoud.
If you are interested in science research, definitely take this class. If not, it's an entertaining class and you learn a lot.

Part of the reason why I took this course was because last year's reviews said that the material was so interesting that it made you forget that it was an 8:30 am class. However, because of my other course workload, sometimes it was very hard to participate. If you are going to take this class, make sure that you are really motivated because participation grade is huge.
TAKE THIS COURSE, especially if Leon Rosenberg and Adel Mahmoud are teaching.
Take it!!!
This is a great class! You don't need to do all the reading every time, but it's important to have questions for the presenters. The professors are very good and it's a really interesting topic.
This is a very interesting course that gives excellent background and perspective on medical research.
awesome class, take it
go to class
not a lot of science, even though it is listed as MOL.
prereqs: MOL 214/EEB 214 or MOL215/EEB215.
descrip: Medical research aims to improve and maintain human health. Accordingly, researchers employ such strategies as understanding biology, defining disease mechanisms, and developing ways to prevent, treat, or cure. Today, the U.S. is the preeminent global power in medical research through interactions among government, academia, and industry. This course will trace the evolution of this country's research enterprise, describe its diverse cultures, focus on its greatest achievements (and achievers), and identify a number of challenges confronting it currently. How the U.S. copes with these challenges will influence the future of world health.

title: Introduction to Interdisciplinary Theater
reviews: I think this class is relevant to both art and non-art students. Its just a different way of thinking about theater, about the body, about music. It really opened my mind to a new way of thinking. And everyone in the class was very friendly and comforting, so we were never scared to be ourselves.
Only take if you are interested in more abstract, experimental theater. It's difficult--certainly challenging if that kind of theater is not your thing.

Open your eyes to something new! The course loses some steam, but there is a spectacular world of theater being created. By forcing yourself to dabble in the interdisciplinary for a time, you will start to see all forms of art and performance in a different light.
Step out of your comfort zone.  Don't be nervous.  Try new things.
Take this course! New ideas and ways of seeing every moment. Requires no prior theater experience. Be prepared to move outside of your comfort zone.
prereqs: Open to actors, dancers, composers, musicians, designers, directors, writers, and visual artists who are interested in working across their usual disciplinary borders..
descrip: Practicing thinking like a writer-who-thinks-like-an-actor-thinking-like-a-dancer-who-thinks-like-a-musician-thinking-like-a-painter-who-thinks-like-a-composer-who-directs. Exploring theater from all angles (words, music, movement, sculpture, design), we will be building an understanding of multi-dimensional theatrical logic over the course of the semester. We will explore, provoke, invent, and analyze the phenomenal, the poetic, the sententious, the informative, the confrontational, and the entertaining.

title: Senior Project
descrip: The senior project is a year long independent study intended for students who choose to work in teams of two or more. Work begins in the fall, but enrollment is only in spring term when a double grade is awarded. Groups develop their own topic or select a topic from a list of topics prepared by the faculty. Groups develop a work plan and select an advisor for their work. A second reader is assigned by the instructor. A written progress report is expected at the end of the fall term. Groups submit a written final report and make an oral presentation to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests at the end of the spring term.

title: Psychology of Language
reviews: A very fun elective provided you actually enjoy the subject matter. While the workload is fairly minimal, you shouldn't take it for the sake of having an easy class. Adele is a fun lecturer.

Fascinating subject, might be hard to follow in the beginning if no linguistics background, but professor is always willing to help. Great professor, material, but slightly disorganized lecture style.
Great class! Adele is a great professor and fun to be in class with. This is also very interesting material. Though be warned, it is a little repetitive if you took LIN 201 with Professor Goldberg.
Great linguistics class for a science major! Very enjoyable for anyone who is interested in language. Professor Goldberg is very approachable.
I wouldn't suggest taking this for the distribution requirement, but definitely for your own interest.
If you like linguistics, you should take it--it's interesting.

If you're actually interested in linguistics, skip 201 and take this (201 is nominally a prereq, but there's no reason it should be). If you need an EC, this one is easy as hell. I put in ~12 hours of work outside of class over the semester (including the 4 hours of required psych study participation) and got the P. I personally didn't find the subject matter very interesting, though...
If you're interested in language and how it works in the brain, TAKE THIS CLASS! Adele is wonderful! The course is generally quite doable, but don't leave the paper until the last minute!
Interesting class...overlaps a lot with the LIN201 material.
It's a very interesting look at what's behind language, both in our brains and as a system itself. If you want a nice EC and are above taking intro classes like LIN 101, this is a good alternative.
Prof. Goldberg is absolutely amazing. Definitely take a class with her while at Princeton!
Really interesting course. Different perspective on linguistics. Good professor. Light workload.
Take it if you are interested in linguistics!
Take it!  It's a good fourth or fifth class in a heavy semester and is very interesting and applicable to life.
Take it! Not much work, really manageable.

Take it. You'll learn a bunch of underlying things about language you never thought about. Not terrible difficult, at least for psychology majors, but definitely worthwhile and requiring mostly attention in class.
Take this course if you have any interest in linguistics or psychology.
Take this course--people across all departments seemed to really enjoy it

This course is an excellent way to explore topics of language, particularly if you have an interest or background in linguistics. It's intellectually stimulating and taught by an impressive professor.
take it.
descrip: The cognitive processes underlying the use and understanding of language, and in learning to speak. Topics include speech production and perception, grammar and meaning, knowledge and words, and pragmatic aspects of language.

title: Computational Geophysics
reviews: Excellent primer to understanding and implementing numerical methods in a geophysical context.  Primarily wave equation-focused.

Good class for learning the finite difference, finite element, and spectral element methods. Knowing how and why to apply these methods, as well as how and why they work, can be extremely useful in engineering or seismology.
Start the homeworks before Friday so there is time to go to office hours before the weekend.
This is a fun course. Prof. Tromp's lectures are engaging, and the homework lets you solve PDEs with various numerical methods.
prereqs: Courses in partial differential equations and multi-variable calculus; experience with a computer language and basic programming skills..
descrip: An introduction to weak numerical methods, in particular finite-element and spectral-element methods, used in computational geophysics. Basic surface & volume elements, representation of fields, quadrature, assembly, local versus global meshes, domain decomposition, time marching & stability, parallel implementation & message-passing, and load-balancing. In the context of parameter estimation and 'imaging', will explore data assimilation techniques and related adjoint methods. The course offers hands-on lab experience in meshing complicated surfaces & volumes as well as numerically solving partial differential equations relevant to geophysics

title: Mind, Body, and Bioethics in Japan and Beyond
reviews: Do the readings. You get much more out the class when you are engaged. Easy PDF
Great class and amazing professor, definitely take it if you're interested in the topic!
Great course.
Great seminar, interesting discussions, take it!
TAKE IT, TAKE IT!
Take this class! Very interesting material and manageable workload. Prof. Borovoy is amazing!

Take this course! First, Prof. Borovoy is so knowledgeable and well-versed in the material. She'll ask you questions and make you think about bioethics in ways you haven't before! Secondly, the material is just very interesting. Finally, you'll come away reconsidering how you think about health and medical decisions in your own cultural context.

This is a FASCINATING course. Please take it. The readings are on point and the professor is very knowledgeable on the subject. If there was one seminar to take at Princeton, this would be it (and I'm PDFing the course).

This is a great class!  Whether you are interested in EAS or bioethics, the readings and themes in this class will challenge you to consider other ways of thinking about important medical ideologies.  The assignments and readings are reasonable and very interesting.
prereqs: One course in East Asian Studies or one course in cultural anthropology preferred..
descrip: The seminar will examine key concepts of the mind, the body, and the nature-culture distinction. We will study these issues in the context of Japanese beliefs about the good society, making connections between "lay culture," Japanese notions of social democracy, and "science culture." Topics include: diagnosis and care of the mentally ill, the politics of disability, notions of human life and death, responses to bio-technology, the management of human materials such as organs, cultural definitions of addiction and co-dependency, and the ethics of human enhancement.

title: The Body Under Suspicion: Latin American Visual Culture and the 20th Century
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs/ay201314/

title: Granada and the Fall of Spanish Islam, AD 1212-1492/1614
reviews: Definitely take
Pay attention in lecture but the readings are optional.

Professor Barry is by far my favorite professor at Princeton and I think every student should take at least one course with him.  If you put forth effect, you will learn a tremendous amount about the topic covered in the course and enjoy yourself immensely in the process. Some students are often dissuaded from taking this course and others like it because they are not history or humanities majors and feel that they lack the background information to do well and get good grades in a course like this.  However, this course, while easier if you know something about the topic covered, requires no outside knowledge and if you challenge yourself and take this course, you will not only do well and get a good grade in the course but will find that you came away with a much deeper understanding of the period in question as well as the history of the world in general.  This professor manages to weave the history of the world into covering minute details and seemingly obscure periods of history, demonstrating how interconnected events in human history are.  Although I have been very interested in history since I was very young, have been reading all types of history and thought myself to be so well informed that there was little that I could learn from any particular class that would have particularly mindblowing insights, my first course with Professor Barry taught me otherwise.  In the process of taking this and other classes with him, I learned far more about the world as a whole and how different motivations shape decisions and events in world history than from any other course or school that I ever been in or taken classes at before.  Professor Barry's classes have changed the way I think and the view in which I view and approach the world around me.  The sorts of insights gained by taking his courses go beyond the simple details of the history of medieval Spain, which is why I advise all my friends to take courses with him, even if you don't know anything about Spanish I
Take it!
Take it. Barry is a great lecturer and a very easy grader.
This course required you to work during midterms week and reading period. Prof Barry really has a lot to share, and I am sure that any course with him would be thought-provoking.
descrip: Thirteenth-century Christian "Reconquista" of almost all of Spain after 1212 - with the significant exception of the sultanate of Granada - subjected huge minorities of Muslims and Jews to Christian overlords and challenged the rising kingdoms of Castile, Aragon and Portugal to cope with religious diversity. The course explores how the Christian kingdoms at first imitated and tried to implement Islamic precedents in tolerance but then how social strains spawned increasing sectarian intolerance, mass expulsions or forced conversions of Jews and Muslims, and finally creation of the religiously absolutist monarchies of Spain and Portugal.

title: Live Film: Video Design for Performance
prereqs: Any 200-level course in CWR, DAN, THR, or VIS, or any course in ATL.
descrip: This course will explore the use of media in live performance. A facility with live video is an increasingly useful skill for artists in the visual arts, theatre, music, dance and performance art. This course will investigate the motivations for using live video and techniques for its implementation.Topics covered will include: the use of projectors, content creation, emerging technologies, live video software, live camera use, video container creation, media-infused performance styles and scripting for live film. The course will culminate in multimedia performance projects created by students.

title: African American Literature: Harlem Renaissance to Present
reviews: Be prepared to read a lot..and read closely.
Do the reading!
Great readings, definitely would recommend taking it!
Great! Definitely take it if Professor Brown is teaching!
I think I would have enjoyed the class significantly more with a different preceptor, I was very discouraged by the grading

I would encourage this class if you're willing to do a substantial amount of reading, but the professor is great and the texts are diverse and interesting. There isn't too much writing during the semester, so that makes up for the reading.
It's a good class. You read some great books!
It's definitely not easy to do well.

Professor Brown is a great and engaging lecturer. The reading list is really good! The course seems a bit more like a history course (with very factual/contextual lectures) rather than a literature course, however.
Take it. It's worth it.
Take precept with the professor.
Take the course! It's so worth it.
Take this course for the AAS certificate or for general interests in the subject area.
Take this course!! Professor Brown is amazing and the reading list is really great.
Take this if you are very interested in the material, because it's a lot of reading and not very easy.
descrip: This course explores the relationship between cultural production and historical phenomena (such as the Great Migration, the Harlem Renaissance, and the Civil Rights Movement, for example) in 20th- and 21st-century African American literature. Additionally, we will consider the place of African American literature and cultural production in a global narrative that encompasses decolonization, multiculturalism and globalization. Primary texts include novels, short stories, poetry and video and performance art.

title: Biomedical Anthropology
reviews: Definitely take it if you don't mind doing a lot for the final (20 pg paper and final exam take-home) but then only having readings the rest of the term.
I would recommend actively participating in class. You can take the most from the class by attending lectures and paying attention in class.
Start on the final paper early.

Take anything taught by Professor Mann! He is one of the best professors I have had! His passion for the subject matter, and importantly, for each of his student, is completely infectious. A must take!
Take it!  Such an interesting and informative class and Mann is amazing, he really loves what he is doing and it shows.

This course is definitely interesting and has a very interesting premise. It really did make me think about things that I already knew in a different way and from a different perspective, which is where it's value lay.
descrip: An examination of the interactions of evolution, biology and culture in human health and sickness. The course will emphasize the influence of pathogens and other environmental selective agents in the evolution of human biology and behavior. The action of cultural factors in the spread and containment of disease and other abnormal conditions will also be integrated. Each class session will include an initial lecture followed by seminar discussions of that week's readings. Discussions will focus on the patterns of health and disease over time and in a cross-cultural perspective.

title: Sound Design
reviews: Do it! Rob is an amazing professor and very approachable.
Take the class! you will love it
Take this course if you are vaguely interested in sound/theatre.

This course is what you make of it. If you want to learn about sound design, and you are willing to put in the time and effort to really do your best on the assignments, you will learn a lot. On the other hand, it is definitely possible to slack off and put in a minimum of effort on this course--if you are not really invested in the material, I would say you should give this one a pass.
prereqs: Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission..
descrip: An opportunity to explore what theatrical sound design is, how to look at a text from the point of view of sound, how to launch your creative process, and how to take the ideas based on that creative process and turn them into sounds to be used in a show. Students will also learn how to communicate their ideas, palate, and the arc of their design in a way that demonstrates to directors how they will fulfull the director's vision while embracing their own artistry and response to the text.

title: Seminar in International Relations - International Relations of South Asia
reviews: If you are considering it, take it
Professor Shah is very helpful and the seminar was an overall good experience.
descrip: Theories of international relations seek to explain the causes and consequences of conflict and cooperation between "great powers." How do IR theories travel to South Asia, a strategically important region of the world populated by several 'minor' powers? This seminar will explore the strengths and limits of IR theories by applying them to an array of South Asian security issues in both historical and contemporary contexts, including, the Indo-Pakistani territorial conflict over Kashmir, civil wars, the emerging geostrategic dominance of India, nuclear proliferation, terrorism, and regional cooperation in trade and economics.

title: Emerging Micro and Nano-Engineered Technologies
descrip: See website

title: Architects in Quest of the Ideal City
descrip: See website

title: Public Leadership and Public Policy in the U.S.
reviews: Interesting class. Take it if you want an overview of a number of important American historical political events. You'll also learn a little bit about leadership styles, but it's not what you'll be reading most about.

It's a decent course and not a lot of work, but Professor Scovronick can often come across as being uninterested in what students have to say, and that - plus his rather clear ideological leanings (keep any conservatism you may have in check) - prevents discussion from being as robust as it might be. Also know that you'll get very little in the way of feedback in terms of your performance, which can be frustrating. Still, the readings are generally interesting, and it's a good way to get exposure to some of the major events in modern American history.
Take it.
Take it. You will learn a lot and look at leadership in a different way.

The best part of this class, for me, was seeing Scovronick take students, especially WWS majors, down a peg. You cannot bs your response to his questions. He wants to know your opinion and you should provide it clearly. If you don't, he'll cut you off. He's done it to me, and I was glad he did. Scovronick holds strong opinions and if you disagree, you better be ready to fight for it. The readings are excellent, the films are interesting, and there are cookies every week. Don't fall behind on the readings or the midterm/final paper will hurt. The most valuable lesson learned isn't necessarily about the failings Nixon or Bush or Johnson, but rather how you can fail if you are not scrupulous about your ethics in the public sector. This class is a breath of fresh air in a category of classes often filled purely with amoral considerations.

This class is not too work-intensive, but you get to discuss many really interesting topics in U.S. history from a unique angle.  Plus, Professor Scovronick brings cookies and we watched part of a documentary every class, so that's pretty clutch.  Took it senior spring, which was a good call.
descrip: This course will review key Presidential decisions on domestic and foreign policy developments such as the passage of civil rights legislation and the intervention in Iraq, and will consider the ethical, legal, and operational frameworks for effective, responsible public leadership. Students will review relevant literature from history, psychology and politics, discuss the central policy issues in each case, and evaluate the decision-making process in view of these frameworks.

title: Dissertation Writers' Seminar
prereqs: This course is open only to post-generals students. Each student will give one fifty-minute presentation of work in progress..
descrip: A practical introduction to scholarly writing at the dissertation level and beyond, providing guidance on planning and completing the dissertation and on other aspects of becoming a professional scholar and teacher, such as mastering the craft of the journal article (conceiving, writing and submitting), writing effective syllabi for different kinds of courses, and turning the dissertation into a book (with visits by editors from leading presses). The seminar meets every two weeks and is required of all post-generals students in residence, who will have the opportunity to present and discuss their work in progress.

title: Science and Buddhism
descrip: See website

title: Electrical Engineering Master's Project
descrip: Spring course number to be used by Master of Engineering students who will be doing a project in lieu of a course.

title: Political Economy Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Political Economy. Third and fourth year graduate students are expected to attend; first and second year graduate students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Seminar in Pedagogy
descrip: Required weekly seminar for all English Department PhD students teaching for the first time at Princeton and scheduled to precept during the Spring 2013-14 semester. Balancing pedagogical theory with practical tips and collaborative discussion, the seminar helps students meet the challenges of their first semester in the classroom while also preparing them to lead their own courses. Topics include: integrated course design (preparing lesson plans; leading discussions; lecturing; teaching writing; assessment and grading); writing recommendations; and managing students, faculty, and time.

title: Between Renaissance and Revolution: Baroque Art in Europe
descrip: This courses surveys painting and sculpture in Europe ca. 1580-1780, with some attention to prints, drawings, and architecture. Lectures and readings present major artists and trends in their social, cultural, and political settings, along with varieties of interpretation. In preceptorials original works will be studied in Princeton and New York.

title: The Ethnographer's Craft
reviews: If you are considering anthropology, this course will give you the nitty-gritty on how to do fieldwork.
It's a good course, although Professor Rouse sometimes states her political opinions very strongly during class.

My issue with the lectures was that I didn't feel like the way issues were being presented was approachable. Prof. Rouse inserts her opinions into almost every class discussion in such a way that I didn't feel comfortable voicing my own or entertaining other ideas. I also really disliked the way "discussion" was moderated. What is the point of having a discussion when your professor chooses the order in which 10 are supposed to speak? Nothing ever followed in a logical sequence and it seemed like we were just getting our participation for the day checked off. Not only that, but there was little room left for anyone to have a productive discussion. I remember speaking up one time and Prof. Rouse just responded, "Okay, thanks," because she wanted to end the discussion so that one of our classmates could play the fiddle for 5 minutes. There's so much more that could have been learned from this course other than "racialism exists in America" over and over again. I feel really bad for all the sophomores who took this course thinking they might be anthro majors. Almost everyone changed her mind. I would recommend taking pretty much any other Anthro class if you're interested and then grin and bear this class as a junior?or hope there's a different professor.
Not my favorite. take notes on the conceptual ideas behind each main reading for the semester. Probably not the most interesting class if you are not considering Anthropology.
prereqs: ANT 301A and ANT 301B will meet together. Concentrators are required to enroll in a section of the junior seminar ("Lab" B01 or B02).
descrip: What are social and cultural facts? And how do we identify these facts using anthropological research methods? This field methods course is for students interested in learning how to work with complex and often contradictory qualitative data. Students will examine how biases and beliefs affect the questions we ask, the data we collect, and our interpretations. Key topics include objectivism, interpretation, reflexivity, participant-observation, translation, and comparison. In addition to reading ethnographies, this class will use ethnographic films as a lens through which to explore the extraordinary power and limits of qualitative research.

title: Empire and International Relations
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Energy for a Greenhouse-Constrained World
reviews: A great overview of energy. It is somewhat technical but nontechnical people can understand it if they're willing to put the time in. The midterm paper is 10-15 pages 1.5 spaced.
I would take this course if you are interested in energy. You will learn a lot.
Take it.
Yes, as long as you have the mathematical backing. We spend absolutely no time making sure that you can do the math behind the principles presented in the class, so it's up to you to keep up.
good for an intro into energy, but a lot of repeat material otherwise.
prereqs: Freshman physics and prior coursework in thermodynamics are required. Students from any department are welcome in the course. Graduate students are welcome..
descrip: Overview of technology challenges and opportunities for energy in the context of global warming. Physics of greenhouse warming, projected climate changes, and structure of US and global energy economy are reviewed. Majority of lectures emphasize understanding engineering and economics of low-carbon energy production systems, including solar, wind, nuclear fission, and capture/storage of fossil-fuel carbon. Energy storage and efficient energy use are also considered. Intersections of energy with economic development, international security, local environmental quality, and human behavior are also touched upon.

title: Elementary Chinese II
reviews: A necessity if you want to learn Chinese, be prepared to put work into learning it.
Ask questions a few days before quiz!

Be sure to practice each day. It will help you in the long run! Also, don't let the grade deflation scare you away. The Chinese classes are Princeton are absolutely wonderful. Don't pass up the opportunity!
Better be serious about this class.

Chinese is one of Princeton's strongest departments - the teachers are all engaging and work with each student individually to develop his/her skills. It does require a lot of time, but so far, the experience has been rewarding.

Despite the horrendous effects grade deflation (think a 98 to get an A, despite extremely challenging material), this is an excellent course. It's really hard, but you WILL learn Chinese, and you'll learn it very well. Maybe my favorite class so far, despite its very stressful nature.
Do the homework and go out of your way to interact with the teachers--they are incredibly nice!
Don't focus on the grades.
Highly recommended to anyone wanting to learn the language.
I took French last year, and compared to that, the Chinese courses are incredibly well-organized, well-taught, and you will learn to speak it properly (yes, even the tones)!
If you actually want to learn Chinese, take it. It's definitely not easy, but it pays off so much.

If you are interested in actually learning Chinese, take this course!!! It's rigorous, yes, but in my opinion very manageable. Additionally the classes are very fun and the teachers are excellent!! Highly recommended.
If you are interested, take it! It is so rewarding.
If you ever considered wanting to learn Chinese, take this class!!
It's worth your time.
Learn Chinese.
Once you've taken 101, you know what this is like.
One of the things about this course in particular is that the more effort you put into it, the more you enjoy it. I wouldn't necessarily recommend it with a heavy course load.
Only take this course if you really want to learn chinese because it is a lot of work and a lot of time
Practice the characters from previous lessons every week and take advantage of how much the professors are willing to help.
Simply put, be studious. Work hard, and you will make tremendous gains. It is really satisfying to learn a language like Chinese!
Take it.

The Chinese program here is excellent. You will learn so much in only 1 year!  Just make sure you have enough time to really study and memorize the characters and grammar structures. It definitely takes a good  amount of time each week.
You will have to work really hard and probably still will not get amazing grades, but you really do learn how to speak Chinese.
You've already taken 101 if you are looking at this so you should know what to expect.
good professors
take if willing to work hard!
you have to REALLY want to learn chinese to not be worn down by this course
prereqs: CHI 101 or permission of the Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of Chinese 101. To develop basic competence in understanding, speaking, reading and writing Mandarin Chinese.

title: Intermediate Persian II
reviews: Professor Mahallati is awesome. I'd highly recommend the course.
Take this class if you have any interest in learning a new language and discover a new culture!
Taking/continuing Persian is a wonderful choice you won't regret
prereqs: PER 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: The emphasis is on reading modern and classical prose, and writing modern prose. Classes are conducted mostly in Persian. Advanced grammar drills and translation exercises.

title: Special Topics in Entrepreneurship - Entrepreneurial Finance
reviews: A good entrepreneurship class if you're interested in it.
A valuable course when it comes to learning fundamental analysis: accounting and corporate finance.
Do not take this course.
Don't take it, but find a way to have coffee with the professor or meet with him if you're going into finance.
Fabozzi is a really interesting guy.  Good class overall.

I do hope a non-math finance course is offered again, but if it's this one, forget it. It was mostly accounting basics, which were in fact useful, but in that case the course should just be called "Accounting With References to Startups No One Has Heard Of." The lectures were the most boring I've ever experienced in my three years here to the point that it was shocking that the 20 students who would show up to lectures still did. I'm pretty sure after the midterm there were 10 people in class. If this course is being taught by Fabozzi, which it probably won't be, don't go, but there's huge potential in it for a better professor.
I highly suggest taking this course.  You will learn very applicable knowledge, unlike many other Princeton courses.
I would recommend Entrepreneurial Finance to anyone interested in entrepreneurship. It gives a great overview of the financial side of businesses and is a very practical course.
If you have investment banking or VC experience, this is a pretty easy class that doesn't add much to your knowledge. I could see it being useful for non-finance types though.
Interesting topic and learned a little, but horrible lectures by professor led to very boring class. Not too much work. Do not recommend taking if with Fabozzi.
It has been one of the more practical classes I have taken at Princeton.
Maybe

Professor Fabozzi is brilliant. The course is great for anyone interested in launching a startup or just generally curious about financing various types of companies. I don't think he's teaching it again but he's great!
Take it.
Take this course. Accounting is a great practical skill to have.
This class was taught by a visiting professor. It will likely be different in the future.

This is a good senior spring class to take because it gives room to work on thesis while still giving you the opportunity to apply what you have learnt in the group project and the exams. However, the lectures could get a bit boring and so you find that half the class just stops going. Perhaps something that could be done to make it better is to read the lectures before hand going in to class with the intention of asking questions and not just listening to him read from the slides.

You can go to lecture if you like Prof Fabozzi and his style. Otherwise I think it's reasonable to just look at the lecture slides and wikipedia whatever is unclear. The actual material is pretty interesting (for those that it's relevant to, at least). It's a lot of stuff that you just have to get comfortable with at some point if entrepreneurship is possibly in your future, and it's the kind of boring stuff you might not spent the time to understand otherwise.
take it if you need to learn more about finance, don't take it if you don't need to
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course. Students from all disciplines are welcome..
descrip: The focus of this course is on the financing of high-technology startup ventures that seek to raise external capital. We will address the following topics: how to develop a financial plan including how much money to raise and when to raise it; the alternative funding sources available at different stages of a new venture; the alternative funding vehicles; negotiating the terms of a financial deal; valuation of a venture; exit strategies. There are other important components that taken collectively lead to a successful venture: the value proposition, marketing, cost structure, key partnerships, key recourses, and firm governance.

title: Superhero Trials
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Economics of the Labor Market
reviews: Incredibly light coursework, hard to get good grade.
It is easy material, and the course moves slow with not much new econ learning, but is graded extremely hard. Unless someone other than Prowse is taking it, I would avoid the class.
Take the course if you want to take a course that uses basic economics--it's a straightforward departmental.
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 302 and MAT 102 or MAT 103..
descrip: To provide a general overview of labor markets. Covering labor force participation, the allocation of time to market work, migration, labor demand, investment in human capital (education, on-the-job training, man-power training), discrimination, unions and unemployment. The course will also examine the impact of government programs (such as unemployment insurance, minimum wages, or a negative income tax) on the labor market.

title: Chemical Biology II
reviews: Great class if you are enthusiastic about biological applications of organic chemistry
Great course
It covered a lot and got you a very good overview of chemical biology in general.
It is a good course for learning protein chemistry and biosynthesis pathway.
descrip: The course provides an in depth treatment of protein chemistry and natural products biosynthesis. Topics include; amino acid, peptide and protein chemistry; protein engineering; the logic and enzymology of natural product biosynthesis with a focus on non-ribosomal peptide synthesis and polyketide synthesis.

title: Soil Mechanics
reviews: Ask lots of questions and try to work through all the examples and get feedback on them.

I wouldn't particularly recommend it unless you're super interested in the material. If you have to take it - yes, it's tough to wake up for 8:30 class, but go to lectures and at least write down the example problems' solutions. They will be very helpful while you do problem sets. Also, Prof. Popescu is good about answering questions; don't be shy about attending office hours or emailing him.
If you're interested in structural engineering, you should take it.
Take it if you have to or have great interest, but it's kind of dry.
Take this course. Stay on top of the work because it can be easy to fall behind. Take advantage of office hours.
The material is not the most interesting, but Radu tries his best to make everything really clear. Overall, a good experience.

You may want to purchase the text for this course as I feel it would help to explain the material. Prof. Popescu is a good lecturer although he does not post all of the content from the slides he shows in class.
only take if you must for a departmental.
yes
descrip: General introduction to physical and engineering properties of soils. Soil classification and identification methods. Soil exploration, sampling, and in-situ testing techniques. Permeability and seepage. Soil consolidation and settlements. Shear strength. Lateral earth pressure. Bearing capacity. Slope stability.

title: Microeconomics for Public Policy
reviews: Amazing. Take this class, and take it with Rosen (Rosen literally went around the room on the second to last day of class and named every person there!). If you work hard and pay attention (and you'll have to do both -- no electronic notes, no handouts, and the textbook is almost useless except for occasional problem set questions), you'll learn a ton about economics. Note: there are a lot of bad reviews of "WWS 300" from the past. Before Fall 2012-2013, WWS 300 was a course titled "Democracy", which has nothing to do with this class. They just happened to have the same course number.
Be prepared to work hard, but it's a worthwhile class.

Calculus is a must.
Take this with HSR and no one else. He's my favorite person ever.
Definitely take WWS 300 with Harvey Rosen. He is an amazing teacher and you will learn so much.
Definitely take it, but only if Harvey is teaching it!
Difficult class but the grading is very forgiving, luckily! I really enjoyed learning economics with an eye for public policy.
Don't miss a lecture!
Excellent course. Go to all the lectures, stay on top of problem sets, and you'll be fine. Exams are tough so study up!
Great course - take with professor Rosen, but very challenging.

I was nervous about the math but Professor Rosen understands that most of the class is. He is clear, patient, and works hard to make sure that the math does not obscure the economics. His lectures are brilliant, entertaining and prepared with care. He was not only a wonderful teacher but also a wonderful person. Take this class, you will learn much more that just economics.
I would take this course instead of an equal Econ course because I think Rosen does a good job helping you learn.
I'm assuming most people take this as a requirement, so be sure to take it
If you can take it with Professor Rosen, this is a must-take.

If you're thinking about taking this course, it's probably because you don't want to take one of the other economics courses. Be warned that this class is still intensive, but you can do it. Professor Rosen is fantastic, don't miss out on an opportunity to learn from him.

If you've taken MAT 201, this course will not have enough math to satisfy your desire to know what is going on mathematically. Rosen is great at simplifying concepts, oftentimes using easy numbers to get his points across. I wish we worked more with proofs, but the math was definitely lacking in rigor. This course is truly non-math track econ, and woody woo econ at that.
It is a good class but get ready to work!
It was by far the hardest class I took, and I didn't do as well as I wanted, but learned SO MUCH.
It's hard, but you'll learn a lot.
Only take it if you have to or are proficient at economics.  The material is a large jump from Intro Micro.

Professor Rosen is a great lecturer -- he clearly loves his job and cares about his students. His passion for economics will spill over to you even if you think you hate econ. However, this was a difficult class so be sure that you are ready to put the time in to really understanding the problem sets, which are basically harder versions of the exams.
Professor Rosen is a great lecturer and gets you up to speed on anything you may have forgotten about econ or calc.

Rosen makes this class. If you're not an econ person and don't have to take this class, be warned: this class is hard. Probably not as hard as 310, if you are taking this for a WWS departmental, but if its just for general interest, I'd probably pass.
TAKE IT if Rosen is teaching it again.  Rosen is absolutely awesome and teaches this course extremely well.
TAKEITTAKEITTAKEITTAKEITTAKEIT
Take this course if econ interests you, even if 100 scarred you. Rosen is great and if you are willing to work hard, you should be fine.
Take with Rosen--you wont regret. DONT try to do psets on your own. You will waste time and hate yourself for it. Make friends with your classmates through strugglesss
Take your econ departmental with Rosen and no one else.
There's no better man in the world than Harvey Rosen. Take this class.

This course is ridiculous! The amount of math (advanced algebra and calculus) in the problem sets was so excessive that I doubt I learned any economics. I spent probably 85% of my time working through calculus proofs and algebraic systems of equations and 15% on economics (And public policy? Wait, there was supposed to be public policy?) In the future, please focus less on mathematical derivations and proofs which take hours to complete and more on what the results of these derivations actually mean! Harvey Rosen is very knowledgeable, but I wish I'd just taken ECO 300. Seriously.

This course is the best class I've ever taken. You will have a love hate relationship with it because Professor Rosen is hands down the most engaging professor, but the class is so difficult. Do the problem sets over and over again to do well on exams.
This course is very hard. Make sure you know your calculus.
as long as Prof Rosen is teaching, definitely take it
departmental. what else can i say?
if the other wws econ departmentals are easier i would take those instead.
if you're wws, you have no choice...sorry
prereqs: Prerequisite: ECO 100. This course is not open to students who have taken ECO 300 or ECO 310..
descrip: Microeconomics is the study of how people and societies confront scarcity. This course, taught at the intermediate level, focuses on markets as a mechanism for dealing with scarcity, and uses examples that cast light on public policy issues.

title: Wizardry and Wild Romance
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Sophomore Independent Work
reviews: Sure, if you want to do research. Allows you to plan your own time, but usually you have to spend a fair amount of time on if.

This course is highly adviser dependent. I had Prof. Barry Rand. He was extremely helpful and guided me at pretty much every stage of the research process/course. I recommend meeting with your adviser before signing up for this course on SCORE. Other than that, the course is run pretty well, and if you want to do ELE research as a sophomore, I'd definitely take it!
research is awesome.
research is cool for undergrads!
prereqs: For each project, the requirements are set in consultation with the faculty advisor, and depend somewhat on the nature of the project. An oral presentation during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and a written final report is required. A copy of the report must be turned into the ELE Undergraduate Office by Dean's Date. Details of requirements are available from the ELE Undergraduate Office. This course is open to qualified sophomores provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a state of the art project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the students. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. There is no formal reading list; however, a literature search is a normal part of most projects.

title: Witnessing Disaster
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Beginning Polish II
prereqs: PLS 101.
descrip: A continuation of PLS 101. This course continues to develop and refine the four language skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing), teaching all fundamental aspects of Polish grammar and basic communication skills on a variety of situations. As the course progresses, the rich Central European culture will be sampled through poetry, film and fictional, as well as expository prose.

title: Israeli Media: Barometer and Engine of Sociopolitical and Cultural Change
descrip: This course uses various forms of Israeli media, including television shows, web sites, blogs, and newspapers, to explore the ethical and moral dimensions of contemporary debates on cultural pluralism in Israel and tensions in Israeli society. Topics include relations between Jews and Arabs, rifts between Orthodox and secular Jews, and the challenges of accommodating and integrating into a single society immigrants who come from diverse backgrounds and lack a common immigrant experience. The course is intended for advanced speakers of Hebrew.

title: Advanced Arabic Reading: The Short Story
reviews: Good exposure to Arabic literature
I would definitely recommend this to another student looking to improve their Arabic reading and grammar skills. It's also a really enjoyable class to take out of general interest.

If you want your speaking ability to improve, don't take this class. Most of the discussion will be in English. That being said, your reading will improve and the stories chosen are all very interesting. Honestly if the discussion was mostly in Arabic the people who didn't come in with extra Arabic experience would be lost.
This class is a real gem. If you like Arabic and don't take this class while you're at Princeton then you've really missed out on one of the most fun, most interesting classes around.

This was a really great class!  If you need an LA and know Arabic pretty well (probably 300 level - like you've taken 301 or maybe after second year), I would recommend this!  Also, for 300-level for ARA certificate.  The class is really fun- the homework isn't too too hard, but sometimes translating and voweling can take a lot of time.  You're going to need to know your 'Araab but that isn't too hard.  The papers aren't too bad either.  The main thing you will need to do is read, in and outside of class, and get an understanding of the stories.  The short stories are so amazing and thought provoking and intriguing and you finally get to read famous Arab authors which is so awesome!  I would totally recommend this class- it's really fun and allows you to see yet another side of Arabic culture.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course will use the genre of the Arabic short story to help students expand their reading and, to a lesser extent, their speaking skills in Modern Standard Arabic.
