In addition, students will learn about the development of the Arabic short story through reading representative examples of the genre from a variety of periods and authors. The course will focus on a new short story each week, with one class meeting devoted to close reading of a portion of the week's story and the second focusing on a more general discussion - part in English and part in Arabic - of the story under consideration.

title: Modern Drama
reviews: Definitely take this course, even if you don't have any experience with theater!

Take it!!! Bob is excellent and even if you don't like all of the plays, you will find something to appreciate in the vast majority of them.  He's a great professor and there are some great plays here.

This class was filled with theater majors, and there was a clear theater/non-theater divide. I recommend this class if you have a strong interest in drama, but would probably choose a different lit class if going back.
descrip: A study of major plays by Ibsen, Strindberg, Chekov, Pirandello, Brecht, Beckett and others. Artists who revolutionized the stage by transforming it into a venue for avant-garde social, political, psychological, artistic and metaphysical thought, giving birth to forms of representation we live with to this day.

title: Introduction to Italy Today
reviews: Take this course. It is a good survey of Italian politics, history, and culture, and it will help improve your Italian.

This is a requirement for moving on to more interesting material so I would suggest taking the class.  The professors are wonderful, but the material can get a bit dry sometimes.  Also hearing valley-girls speak a foreign language is abominable.
prereqs: ITA 107 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course is designed to familiarize the student with major features of contemporary Italy and its culture. Its purpose is to develop the student's ability to communicate effectively in present-day Italy. The course emphasizes Italian social, political, and economic institutions, doing so through the analysis of cultural and social differences between Italians and Americans in such everyday concerns as money, work and leisure. NOTE: no books will have to be purchased for this course since all reading materials will be available on Blackboard.

title: Art and Science of Motorcycle Design
descrip: See website

title: Stochastic Analysis Seminar
descrip: This seminar course will introduce the students to recent developments in stochastic analysis.

title: Music and Power
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Literary and Cultural Theory - Performance and Performativity
descrip: This course investigates "performance" and "performativity" as both curricular objects and modes of inquiry. As the field of performance studies begins to take root in many contemporary locations, the seminar re-ignites a spirit of radicality to theories of performativity and engage critical and creative works that challenge the field's dominant paradigms of embodiment, liveness, and official theatrical stages. Through close attention to critical experiments in sound, visual arts, and literature, the seminar explores how performance and performativity enliven scholarly methodologies and aesthetic forms.

title: Special Topics in Molecular Biology - Pharmacology of Natural Products
reviews: Don't be intimidated by the fact that this is a 500-level course, as plenty of undergrads take it and thrive.
I would take the course if you want an easy 1-time-a-week course, where you'll definitely learn a lot about psychopharmacology.
I wouldn't take this course, unless you are looking for a relatively low work course, except at midterms.
It's interesting, and not a large amount of work. The subject matter is worthwhile, but could have been a little more in depth.
Really enjoyed it. Very relaxed. Make sure to do well on the midterm and work with people!
Take it! It is a very relaxing class, and you will learn a lot. Also, Prof. Stock has a great sense of humor and he is very understanding if you get to know him.
Take this course if you are looking for an upper level MOL class with less work than normal.
Take this course! Prof. Stock is the coolest dude.

This was a very interesting course and allowed for students to learn about a lot of things without stressing over the details as you would in a typical MOL class. I hope that this course can be classified under a different course name or code next spring so that we can enroll in it again next year, as the topic changes on a yearly basis (so it's really a different class than the previous one). Professor Stock is really inspiring in how knowledgeable he is about the field of pharmacology. His lectures are all very engaging and interesting as well. In addition, the class environment is relaxed but productive, and I feel like I learned a lot on my own time without feeling miserable about cramming every little detail possible.
Very chill class. Minimal amount of work, but you do learn a lot if you are interested in drugs that affect the brain

You MUST take this--Prof. Stock is GREAT. Do NOT be intimidated by the fact that this is a graduate course--most of the class were undergrads. But it is a grad course in the sense that the assignments really do make you think at a different level than you might have experienced in some of your other classes, but they allow you to learn a lot! Definitely, definitely, definitely take it!
You'll get as much out of it as you put in
the textbook isn't required to have
yes it requires very little previous knowledge
prereqs: Intro Biochemistry (MOL345) or equivalent..
descrip: The molecular biology and biochemistry of pharmaceuticals and natural products that target CNS function will be examined. Specific topics include: the blood-brain barrier, addiction and tolerance, analgesia, treatments for mood disorders, cognitive enhancement, stimulants and ADHD, treatment of dementias such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Disease, psychotropic drugs, antipsychotics and the treatment of schizophrenia.

title: Ancient Egyptian Art and Architecture
reviews: Definitely come to every lecture and try to synthesize the material.
I wouldn't take this course again.
descrip: A survey of ancient Egyptian art and architecture, which produced some iconic forms that remain current today. Coverage ranges from late prehistory (ca. 3500 BCE) to Graeco-Roman times (ca. 200 CE), and beyond. The approach is thematic, not chronological. After the introduction, architecture, including major forms of tombs and temples, is followed by statuary, relief and painting, and pictorial representation. Performance, attire, and ornament follow. Later lectures are organized by theme. Examples are: uses of the past, a specific period (late prehistory), a region (Nubia and Sudan), and the Egyptian legacy.

title: Advanced Quantum Chemistry
reviews: If you are interested in non-mainstream QM and conceptual issues,than that is good course
If you are not interested in lecturer's research area, the course is useless for you.
Take this, especially if you are familiar too with classical mechanics.  Useful if you want to understand much of the current research topics/methods.
descrip: Traditionally quantum mechanics is presented as the antipode to classical mechanics; as a result, no attempt at reconciliation is made. The primary purpose of the course is to present quantum and classical mechanics in a unified fashion by clarifying only essential differences. We will also see how quantum-mechanical methods can be applied to classical dynamics and how quantum phenomena have classical analogies.

title: Genes, Health, and Society
reviews: DONT WASTE YOUR TIME AND GO TO LECTURE! READ THE TEXT!
Do the readings and practices and you will be fine.
I would advise to do the textbook readings!
If you liked biology and want to understand it more past the basic levels then take this course to have an overall understanding.
If you've taken AP Bio, this class will be pretty dull. Low work level for a distribution requirement though
It's one of the best courses I've taken here. You should too!
Make sure you realize that you can't PDF this class before you take it. I wouldn't have taken it if I had realized this at the beginning.
Stay caught up on the reading.
Take it if you're interested in genetics!
Take this course for a not-too-rigorous but very interesting STN.
You can't take this anymore because Professor Rosenberg is sadly retiring. But this subject is very necessary for any student graduating from Princeton to learn.
take it if you're interested in biology but like all science classes here don't expect to cram for exams and get an A
descrip: What should students know about their genes and genomes? Today, the field of Human Genetics is explored and debated like no other. To understand the medical applications and ethical implications of Human Genetics, one must grasp its scientific foundations. We will approach these topics using: lectures, textbook, journal and newspaper readings, precept discussions, and patient interviews. We will consider the following subjects: gene structure and function; the genetics and genomics of populations and of selected human disorders (cancer, mental illness, metabolic diseases); and clinical genetics (inheritance patterns, diagnosis, treatment).

title: Crime and Punishment in American Culture
descrip: Using social theory, fiction, legal writing, and historical case studies, this course will investigate how Americans have historically constructed, prosecuted, and punished crime in the past and how that history is relevant to a present in which the United States has the highest incarceration rate in the world. Looking through many lenses--from Alexis de Tocqueville and Nathaniel Hawthorne to Angela Davis and Philip K. Dick--we will consider how crime and punishment reflects and reinforces the nature, operation, and meaning of power in the United States

title: Chinese Poetry
reviews: Definitely take it if you are interested in ancient Chinese poetry. Professor Wang has a very detailed style of teaching
Do the readings and brush up on your traditional chinese a little.

If you have the smallest bit of interest in Chinese poetry, do not hesitate to take this class. It was eye-opening and I felt that I came away with a great base of knowledge for continuing my study of Chinese poetry. I would mention that alongside this class, I took CHI 406. I know that this class says that you can be a second year Chinese language student and take it, but I honestly think that to get the most out of this class without it being frustrating, better Chinese language skills are needed. I can however say that I never took Classical Chinese before and did not experience too much difficulty understanding the poems in their original as they were accompanied by English translations. You'll actually probably pick up some prominent features of Classical Chinese simply by reading the amount of poetry that we read. This class consists primarily of reading and only had two presentations and an 8-10 page final paper. What you put in is what you get out. It is a very manageable, yet also enlightening class.

Take it! Honestly, even if you are afraid your Mandarin language ability might be prohibitive, still take the class if you're at all interested in the subject matter. You really don't HAVE to speak/understand Chinese to a native level to get a lot out of this class-- you just have to be patient and self-motivated (to look things up and do your own research).

This is a very engaging and enjoyable course. It is amazing to read and analyze classical Chinese masterpieces in their original language.This is invaluable to the study of poetry in any language, particularly Chinese, in which rhyme and tonal patterns are integral to poetry.
prereqs: 2 years of Chinese..
descrip: Close study of classical Chinese poetry from different historical periods; discussion of the art in the original, in English translation, and in its contemporary adaptation.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy Extensions: Basic (Half-Term)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Provides a thorough examination of statistical methods employed in public policy analysis, with a particular emphasis on regression methods which are frequently employed in research across the social sciences. This course emphasizes intuitive understanding of the central concepts, and develops in students the ability to choose and employ the appropriate tool for a particular research problem, and understand the limitations of the techniques. Prerequisite: 507b.

title: Christianity along the Silk Road
descrip: Syriac is a dialect of Aramaic very similar to the language spoken by Jesus in first-century Palestine. Aramaic-speaking Christians in the Near East soon adopted Syriac as their literary language; by the early fourteenth century, Syriac Christianity spread from the western Mediterranean to China. In this seminar we shall be exploring the origins of Syriac Christianity in the Near East and its spread along the Silk Road before 1500.

title: How to Write A Song
reviews: Amazing, fun class - take it if you love music!!
Don't be afraid to try new styles of music and tactics in songwriting. This is a great opportunity to leave your comfort zone, because the class environment is really open-minded!

I really enjoyed it! However, it's important to realize that the course is a workshop seminar. It's not really "How To Write A Song". It's more like "Write and Song and We'll Give You Constructive Criticism". Also, the goal is to write genuinely good songs, not necessary popular songs.
If you like music at all, take this class immediately.

It's a great class; just have fun with it. Not every group will create a hugely successful song, but every week, even just by listening to the songs of others and the professor's criticisms, you will learn.
Take it if you have any interest whatsoever.
Take this course for a really laid back, fun class.

This class is challenging (writing a song a week can be difficult), but extremely rewarding. It's also nice to be playing your guitar and not feel guilty about it because you're actually doing homework. Also, just getting to know Paul and Wes makes it worth taking.

This course was so enjoyable! It both allowed me to grow as a writer and meet new people who influenced my work in very meaningful ways. The whole process was extremely worthwhile. However, don't be fooled into thinking this will be a super easy, low-commitment course. It still sucks up quite a bit of time, but it's creative and a lot of fun nonetheless!
Too much work for a spring PDF class. A song  a week? It was hard for me to manage.
prereqs: Some familiarity with writing and/or music composition. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information. This course cannot be audited.
descrip: An introduction to the art of writing words for music, an art at the core of almost every literary tradition from Homer through Beowulf to W.B Yeats and beyond. Composers and writers will have the opportunity to work in small songwriting teams to respond to such emotionally charged themes as Contempt, Gratitude, Revenge, Desire, Disgust, Joyousness, Remorse, Loneliness, Despair and Defiance. Assignments are based on study of a range of works in the popular song tradition. The final exercise will be a public showcase of work from the semester.

title: The Literature of Fact - Narrative Writing
reviews: A wonderful way to learn more about writing and develop your own skills. It's a shame Evan Thomas is leaving, but I bet other journalism classes are also good.

Anyone reading this: I'm sorry for you that you'll never get the chance to take this with Prof. Thomas. It's that rare instance where an academic class illuminates things in your life, helps you understand the human condition and is honestly fun. Good luck to the professors who teach after Prof. Thomas tbh.

Doesn't really apply because Prof. Thomas won't be teaching again and I think these courses really depend on the professor. Though i would recommend that anyone even vaguely curious about journalism apply to take a course.

I don't know who will teach this course in the future, but Evan Thomas did a great job with it. However, now that he isn't teaching it, it is hard to give such a strong recommendation. However, Princeton has great Journalism professors, so I'm it will still be great.
I grew a lot as a writer from revising my assignments. Thomas is an excellent editor. Seminar can be a bit repetitive while workshopping, but guest speakers are awesome.
It won't be offered anymore with Professor Thomas, so I hope the next lady or guy to do it cares even half as much as he did. Best professor I've ever had at Princeton, hands down.
Professor Thomas is absolutely amazing. I would go on and on about him, but he is leaving for California, so I won't bother. Literally he is amazing. Best professor ever.

Professor Thomas is fantastic and will be sorely missed. Overall, the journalism program is a hidden gem, and I would highly recommend taking any class in the program if you enjoy writing and are interested in sharpening your writing and editing skills.
THIS WILL CHANGE YOUR LIFE!
Take it if you really love to write and are good at it. Expect to be pulled apart if you half-ass something.
Take it.
Take this class! Will completely change your Princeton experience and it's not a lot of work at all.
Yes
prereqs: Applications at http://humanities.princeton.edu..
descrip: This is a course in the art of telling true stories. We will examine all the essential aspects of successful narrative writing: timing and pacing, character development, the sharpening of conflict and plot, the art of interviewing and reporting - how to write stories that move and are human. There will be guest speakers and weekly individual conferences to go over written work.

title: Scientific Integrity in the Practice of Molecular Biology
reviews: Bring other work to do; data to analyze, etc.
Well I would tell them not to take it, but it's a requirement for our department so they have to.
descrip: This course satisfies the mandate of the National Institutes of Health for training of molecular biologists in the ethical practice of science. The nature of -- and response to -- personal "misconduct" will be a principle focus. Through case studies and class discussion, we will examine the societal framework for the public support of basic biomedical research, the rights and responsibilities of students and mentors in the conduct of that research, and the significance of intellectual property. We will also review regulations concerning research with human subjects and animals.

title: Quantitative Analysis II
descrip: This course builds upon POL 571 and introduces students to applied regression analysis in cross-section settings. It begins with the basic principles of statistical inference, and then covers various statistical techniques including linear regression, instrumental variables, structural equation models, maximum likelihood estimation, and discrete choice models. The materials are taught at the level of Hayashi's Econometrics, and Freedman's Statistical Methods. Prerequisite: POL 502 (or permission of instructor) and POL 571.

title: Electromagnetism and Modern Applications
reviews: As an electrical engineer, i think it's important to have a general idea of how electromagnetism works beyond the PHY 104 level.  It's a great course to take as it will help solidify these concepts as you use them for other classes (ie ELE 453, ELE 441/442, etc).
Ask questions and do not be shy in admitting that you do not understand something - the professor is extremely helpful!
Go to class. Always. Professor Sengupta is a good teacher and if you have questions do not feel afraid to go to him for help.
It will probably change because this is 1st year teaching undergrad course. It's a lot of vector calculus this year.
Take it if you want to learn more EM than what you learn in freshman physics. It is more or less a physics class than an engineering class except for the last week.

This course expands upon the material taught in PHY 104/106 and provides a good background knowledge for E&M. It also provides some interesting applications. If you have interest in the underlying physics of basic electrical systems, I would recommend it.

This course is reasonable, interesting, and informative.  Professor Sengupta is a decent lecturer, gives enjoyable, if sometimes long, problem sets, and writes reasonable exams.  If you are interested in bolstering your understanding of E&M, this course is an excellent way to do so.
prereqs: PHY 103 and PHY 104. Basic electromagnetism, basic understanding of differential equations, Laplace and Fourier Transformations..
descrip: The course will discuss electromagnetism (mostly classical electromagnetism) and its applications in modern day science and technology, with an emphasis on sensing and communication. The emphasis will be on fundamental theories and how they influence practical application ranging from biosensing, to modern day wireless, wire line communication and radar architectures along with multiple antenna array systems.

title: Asian Capital Markets
reviews: Highly recommend but a lot of class participation required, so be willing to speak in class.

I would take the class, and I would advise preparing for each class in advance not just by doing the readings but by reading finance publications (e.g. Financial Times / Wall Street Journal / Economist) to understand markets.

It is one of the classes I would most strongly recommend in this program. A great opportunity to develop your intuition, understanding about EM economies, and market sense. It was a great learning curve. The work load is manageable too. You would learn a lot from it if you go to every lecture, listen well, think and participate actively.
It's a purely business sense based course - a great supplement to very quanty classes at ORFE.
It's an interesting (and not very demanding) course.
Strongly recommend taking the course.
Take the class!
descrip: Course explores the increasing weight of Asia in global financial markets and its implications. It frames the discussion in the context of the globalization of financial markets, with emphasis on concepts of economic development, institutional reform of markets, and public and private market investments. Discussions combine analysis of historical trends and recent data and events with insights from practical experience in Asian markets. Course explicitly considers China's gradual shift toward a capital market-based financial system and the policy decisions faced by the Chinese and US governments relative to existing global imbalances.

title: Street Politics: Revolutions and Social Movements in the Middle East
reviews: Interesting class about a fascinating, relevant topic! If you are interested in the Middle East and the Arab Spring or just social movements in general its a great class to take.

It was a pretty good course.  Professor Harris was very good about making sure everyone understood everything and gave great feedback whenever you talked with him about an idea or handed in a paper.  The readings can get fairly long and very confusing, but if you come having read everything and with questions or ideas, the seminars will seem quick and enjoyable.

Obviously do the readings, they very interesting but also essential to learning in class. The class is discussion-based, so you would be doing yourself a disservice by taking this class and not engaging with the material.
Take the class, but take it seriously. It yields a lot of lessons that students can apply to their lives.

The subject material is incredibly thought-provoking and relevant, but it wasn't exactly a seminar. At times, it felt more like a Q&A with Professor Harris. There were few times that I felt like we really launched into a thought-provoking multilayered discussion (rather than simply bringing up interesting points and then moving on).
This is a wonderful bridge of both sociology and area studies. This class will both make you interested in the Middle East and comparative historical sociology. Take it!
descrip: Revolutions and social movements are at the center of contemporary politics in Western Asia and Northern Africa. Of course, most of them have not produced outcomes the protagonists intended. Yet the old Middle East order is likely kaput. Why did it happen, what are the variations, and how is it playing out today? This seminar explores the recent wave of Middle East social protest through the historical sociology of revolutions, states, and social movements. The 20th century produced plenty of all three as well as theories about why they intertwine. By paying attention to them, we can learn to think as revolutionaries and tyrants alike.

title: The Chinese Economy
reviews: Do not take this course.
Do the readings (they don't take long) and take good notes during lecture. Other than that, this is a really good low-maintenance course that can teach you a thing or two.
Easy to do well and you learn a lot! Just be wary that it gets kinda boring after a while.

For those of you who aren't ECO majors, just know that it is still primarily ECO majors who take this course and the professor is an economist.  If you have a decent understanding of economics it shouldn't be too bad but you might struggle a little more if you don't.
Good for people with not a lot of economics background.
If you're interested in learning more about China's current problems and its potential on the future, take this course!
It's pretty chill, not too much work, good as a secondary course.
Light workload
Needs to be better organized
One of my favorite course so far. Professor Ebenstein is great and the course covers some really important and interesting material.  Also not too hard as departmental's go.
Pretty enjoyable, not too hard, and helpful in giving a general background on an important country. Avi is a good guy and a solid professor, even if sometimes the class feels a little derpy at times.
Take it, avi is a great lecturer and the homework load isn't that large.
Take!

The class is not very hard, and you'll come away knowing a lot more about China than you did before, even if you aren't sure when you learned it.  However, consider that Professor Ebenstein likely won't be teaching this course again, as he was a visiting professor.
This class was more historical than economic, but interesting still.  Just not very technical.

This class was taught by a visiting professor so the course will likely be different. This is an excellent course for learning more about China's economy and the historical, cultural, and geographical settings surrounding around its development.

This class would be a great course for someone with limited background in China and economics, as it provides a great introduction to the issues in China that complicate economic analysis and growth in this region.
This was a good quality course. I think that it could benefit from a refined sense of purpose.

Unfortunately, it's taught by Prof. Ebenstein, a visiting professor. But under him, it was a very chill course, perhaps the least quantitative economics course I've taken, and I'm an econ. major! Lectures very engaging, material very relevant
prereqs: ECO 100 or 101, or permission of instructor.
descrip: Institutional, theoretical and quantitative study of the Chinese economy. Topics include historical background, period of planning and political movements, economic reform, economic growth and fluctuations, macro economic policy, consumption, regional disparity, population, human capital, banking and financial system, state enterprise restructuring, foreign trade and investment, the legal system, science and education, environmental problems and policy, and the functioning and characteristics of the Chinese economy in general.

title: Inorganic Chemistry: Reactions and Mechanisms
reviews:
Don't work in a group.  It is better to know where YOU stand and convince YOURSELF of whatever YOU think is logical and supported by the data.  Schwartz will accept any answer that is logical and supported by the data.

Also, I would recommend coming to some sort of consensus with your peers about which exams you want to talk about on which days of office hours during Reading Period. Otherwise, the same questions will be asked three or four times.

I may or may not have actually learned Inroganic Chemistry through this course, so if you like to know how you're doing in a class and get feedback, do not take this course. I liked Professor Shwartz a lot, however taking 407 instead of this class is definitely a better idea.
I recommend this class.

I would definitely recommend taking this course. Although the material may be difficult to grasp, you will gain a much better understanding of/feel for chemical reactions throughout the course of the semester. Be sure to stay on top of the material and go to office hours, if you are confused about anything. The course moves very quickly!

It's an incredibly stressful class, your grade is essentially completely dependent on the final exam.  The material isn't particularly interesting, and it seems very subjective, although there are definitely right and wrong answers.

Keep up with all of the material and make sure you find a good group for discussion of problem sets and concepts. Arguing over what may be happening in an experiment is the best way to ensure that you understand the concepts.
Schwartz is a character and not everyone likes the grade-it-yourself style, but you'll definitely learn a lot. Highly recommend it if you're doing any metals/catalytic chemistry.
Take 407 first!
Take if you are interested in organic chemistry or want practice in really synthesizing and applying concepts.
Take it, its a pretty cool way to learn some inorganic. Also Scwartz is quite the experience.
Take it.
Take the class
Take this without a doubt. It teaches you to think and you learn a lot, even if you aren't interested in inorganic.
This was one of the most interesting chemistry classes I've taken at Princeton- really taught me a lot about the fundamentals.  Study in study groups, go to OH, don't let this class slip by!
You will be basically be evaluated solely on your performance on the final exam.
descrip: Structure-reactivity correlations for inorganic complexes will be emphasized. Ligand substitution and electron transfer processes will be presented. The course will highlight applications of inorganic and organometallic chemistry to areas of current interest to both organic and inorganic chemists. These areas will include organic synthesis, "redox" reactions, catalysis, and materials. Prior completion of a full year of organic chemistry is required for enrollment.

title: Studies in Greco-Roman Religions - From Jesus to Constantine: The Origins of Christianity
descrip: We read basic primary sources, both Greek and Latin, that offer evidence for the origins of Christianity. To allow for breadth of reading, one may read in English, with reference to the original texts as necessary.

title: Physical Basis of Human Disease
reviews: Highly recommend!
I do not recommend this class unless you just need to take a fun and easy class
If you are interested in getting a broad introduction for human diseases, this is the course. But not if you want to go in detail.
might not be fun for grad students who expected more interactive, discussion-based class. The class would be very resourceful for those who want backgrounds on human diseases.
descrip: The course covers major diseases (cancer, diabetes, heart disease, infectious diseases), the physical changes that inflict morbidity and mortality, the design constraints for treatment, and emerging technologies that take into account these physical hurdles. Taking the perspective of the design constraints on the system (that is, the mass transport and biophysical limitations of the human body), course surveys recent results from the fields of drug delivery, gene therapy, tissue engineering, and nanotechnology.

title: Political Theory
reviews: Absolutely take this course It's a great overview of Western political thought, and the readings are amazing. Knowledge of the material is essential to anyone who wants to study politics, philosophy, or history. Unless you genuinely have interest in political theory, however, find a different EM, as there's a fair amount of writing. For the same reason, not a good PDF. Overall, it's a great class, and it's too bad Ryan is retiring. Avoid Ross' precept.
Be prepared for dense readings, but they're worth it if you prefer papers over exams as a mode of evaluation.
Consider taking Modern Political Theory instead.
Course is very unorganised but the knowledge is essential
DO IT
Decent for a P/D/F class
Do all the reading to get the most out of lecture and precept. Also, really understand the texts and ideas of different authors when writing papers.
Do the reading, make sure you ask questions where you don't understand and go to lectures.
Do the reading; it's the most interesting part and you'll learn the most from it.
Do the readings
Do the readings before the lectures about them.
Do the readings early, start essays early, discuss your drafts with your preceptor.
Don't hesitate to take this course.  Alan Ryan was great, and regardless of who the professor is, the readings are valuable.

Eh. ....
Ryan isn't teaching it anymore and he was kind of a big deal. I guess it's a good way to get an intro to the works of the Dead White Men without taking HUM--and i actually really enjoyed the readings--but there is a lot of work (4 papers  Dean's Date!). Probably a great class to PDF. Just be aware that there are lots of underclassmen in it deciding if they want to be POL majors so nobody really knows what they're talking about, which leads to pretty painful precepts.
Essential course. Take it.
Good EM, and very solid intro do pol theory. With four essays and weekly responses, it was definitely more work than expected.
I loved it. The readings can be a lot but they are very interesting and you will learn so much. Definitely take it
I would advise students to do all the readings carefully.
I would highly recommend this course if you're considering being a Politics major.  Unfortunately, Professor Ryan won't be back next year.

I would recommend it if there is a good lecturer. However, try and get into a decent precept as this will really make a huge difference to how much you get out of the class. Keep up with the reading as there is quite a lot.

I would recommend that any students taking this course do the readings multiple times. It helps ground your understanding in the material, and many of the political philosophers of the course make arguments with very subtle points.

I would recommend the course to other students, definitely. I know three people who dropped the class after the first couple of weeks because they didn't find the subject interesting, but each expressed a small regret in doing so. Because Alan Ryan is leaving, the class may decline, but I still think that anyone interested in politics or philosophy would appreciate this course.
I would recommend this course for people with a general interest in political theorist with the understanding that most of the discussion will be focused on ancient ideas of democracy etc.
If you are interested in politics and/or political theory it is a great class to take.

If you like Political Theory (pretty much philosophy with a focus on politics), this course is great because it introduces you to the classic works in theory. I personaly realized that I don't really like theory -- I prefer the more practical aspects of politics -- but if you like philosophy or theory, this is a great class and the lectures are engaging. Not sure who will teach next year though ...

If you take this course; make sure you have a good preceptor. I am pretty sure that I am going to get a C, even though I should have gotten at least a B . This is because my preceptor was just really bad--long story short, we had a change in preceptors in the middle of the semester, and so the new preceptor just did a bad job at responding to and answering our questions. Then there is the fact that he took forever to grade the assignment---and his feedback was never really helpful even though he gave us a lot (it seemed he gave us quantity as opposed to quality; some of it was basic stuff that did not even relate to the paper). Thus it did not seem that it actually helped to improve the grade (I know a lot of people feel this way).
If you're at all interesting in political philosophy, take it! It's extremely interesting and helps explain how people have thought over the last two thousand years.
If you're interested in Politics, take the class. If you're not, take it and become interested in politics.
It won't be the same as when Professor Ryan taught it, but it will probably still be a very good class.
It's okay. Maybe don't take it PDF if you really want to learn the material.
Just keep up with the readings and attend lecture, and the written assignments aren't too difficult at all.
Keep up with the readings as much as you can and pay attention in precepts.
Keep up with the readings if you can, but it's not the end of the world if you don't. Decide on your paper topics early so that you can read with those implications in mind.

Like with any other course, a recommendation to take it comes with the caveat of having some prior interest in the material. This sort of interest isn't inherently with freedom, democracy, government, and all that stuff, but rather, it is an interest towards philosophical and serious topics. People who have an idealistic view of the world, those who don't care for keeping up with politics or aren't seriously engaged with political issues, those who prefer to avoid controversy and go with the status quo, etc, will not find very much out of this course. But if you do like exploring new ideas, have a political orientation that you have reasoned, thought about, and acquired through looking at all sides of an issue and choosing one that best fits how you feel about the world, then taking this class should be a priority. 

In taking this class, one thing to do is to find the best translation possible. Some authors, such as Hobbes, can be undecipherable if the translation is dated, or in the case of old English, left untranslated. Other translations adhere far too much to the original wording and grammar of the authors, and this too makes them undecipherable. Don't just go to labyrinth and buy the one on the list - shop around online for a translation of the text that you like, and that you can read and understand. You'll enjoy the course a lot more because of this.

Something else to keep in mind is that you won't like all the authors you read. They're all different, and they sort of have a life of their own. In such a case, you may be tempted to skip that author. Thanks to the organization of the course, that is entirely possible to do, or at least it was when I took it. I think the option to ignore authors whom you think are ridiculous and undecipherable is a very desirable trait in a course, and ought to be a feature in all courses. 

Finally, the course does not go into extreme depth. It is meant to provide an overview, and that is a good thing. This means that

Lots of students don't attend lecture because Professor Ryan uploads all his notes - however, I did because he is very famous and for the most part interesting. Readings can be hard to stay on top of, but as long as you start papers early, you'll be fine. The midterm exam is only factored into your grade if it will help you - wish I had known this going into it, especially because there is no final
OK class to PDF. A non-trivial amount of work when writing papers, but from week to week, not too much maintenance.
Only take this class, if you are sure you WILL NOT GET RUSS NIELI AS PRECEPTOR.
Professor Ryan is an amazing lecturer and I really enjoyed the readings for this class. I strongly recommend this class for anyone who is interested in Political Theory.
Readings help to learn better and faster.
Ryan is a great lecturer and the class isn't too much work. Take it if you're interested in the readings and actually plan on reading them.

Sadly, with Alan Ryan retiring, I simply cannot give any useful advice to other students. The readings certainly stand on their own, and they should definitely incorporate Plato, Aristotle, Locke, Rousseau, Machiavelli, Marx, and Mill into their education. However, without professor Ryan's fantastic lectures, it may not be the best idea to do all that reading at once while juggling three to four other classes.
Take if interested in getting a basis of political theory
Take if interested. Start papers and reading early; get ahead.
Take if only if you know you like the subject, otherwise you will find readings, lecture, and precept to be boring.
Take it
Take it if you want to write about political theory. If not, skip it and take something else for your EM/POL requirements
Take it if you're considering POL, it will either change your mind otherwise or you'll like it.
Take it if you're interested in the subject matter, but don't expect to be enlightened.
Take it!
Take it--if you know how to write and skim readings, it isn't that difficult, but it's definitely not an easy A.  You have to (and this is good) engage with the material.

Take the class if you think you'll be really engrossed by the books themselves. That way lecture may be more exciting (instead of a way to get you excited about the books) and you can ask your preceptor to go more in-depth.
Take the course if you feel like you might ever need the authors for any work. Which is a lot of humanities and social science classes.
Take this course, do all the readings, and go to precept.  Lectures are optional, only go if you were confused about the reading or want some extra context.

The jury's out to lunch, since the legendary Alan Ryan (who was perhaps the chief reason to take this course. Really. He was incredibly erudite and also adorable) has now retired. Depends entirely on the professor; the course itself rests on that.
They recently changed the course curriculum. If you don't like writing a lot of pointless papers and you don't write quickly, then I wouldn't recommend this class.

This is really a history class of political theory before the 20th century. I did not get much out of this class that would be relevant today, but if you want to get academic credit for reading some old seminal political theory texts then this class is right for you. That's not meant to be insulting, but as it stands this is definitely a history course.

This would be a good course to PDF if you don't want to do all the readings but still want to learn about some important/influential philosophers and political theorists.  I'd highly recommend any course Professor Ryan is teaching, but unfortunately he will be retiring so this is probably a moot point.
Would recommend.
Yes, it's a great EM to take.
You like politics huh? Take this
You missed Alan Ryan. The course is good to give you a basic introduction to several representative big names in political theory.
good beginner politics class
its a good foundation for POL majors.
start the papers in advance.  attend lecture, they are interesting
take it!
try to go to lecture
prereqs: This course is open to first year students..
descrip: The course explores ideas about justice, authority, freedom, and revolution in the work of classical and modern authors from Plato to Marx. It will be both thematic and historical in nature - and introductory.

title: Structures and the Urban Environment
reviews: DONT assume that this class easy. If you go in with that approach, you will flop. If you take it serious, you will succeeded.
Definitely take the class. With just a little bit of work (almost none compared to most STLs) you can get a really good grade while enjoying lectures and labs the entire semester.
Definitely take this course. Easy STL with minimal work yet very rewarding.
Definitely. Its important to have at least a basic understanding of how structures work, and this is a great way to get that.
Go to class
Go to lectures occasionally.
Great STL if you need it.
Great for an easy STL, although the material is more difficult than CEE 102
I found this course much more interesting than I expected. A lot of other classes at Princeton teach you how to repackage information, but I actually learned new things in this class.
If you get yourself excited and interested in bridges and how they work, you will get something out of this class.
If you need an STL take this with Garlock. Easy class and also really cool/interesting

If you're thinking of taking this, you want an easy STL. This is an easy STL. Don't waste a PDF; take it for a grade. Garlock's a very good lecturer, and labs are usually interesting. However, as a liberal arts student, you will find the free response questions incredibly frustrating, as they rely on arbitrary distinctions and contrived patterns. You can write pretty much anything and still get an A on them. The calculations are pretty simple once you study. I'd say go for it, but you're going to get exactly what you expect--an STL that is neither in-depth nor stimulating.

It's a great STL, esp. for PDFing. Superchill, the "math" is not hard-core math, just dividing and multiplying stuff, so don't let the "calculations" scare you off. The labs are decently interesting even if you have no interest in bridges and the lectures are easy to follow.
Keep up with readings.
Most students obviously take bridges to get their distribution requirement out of the way, but it's probably the least stressful STL out there. That doesn't mean an automatic A though.
Take it
Take it if you have to?or want to.
Take it if you want and easy and (kind of) interesting STL.
Take it if you want to get your STL out of the way - you will be pleasantly surprised by the fact that this is not just an easy distribution, but actually quite a fun class
Take it if you're interested in the material, looking for a good STL, or want a great professor and teaching staff.
Take it! The course material is infinitely more interesting than it sounds and you'll love it. Be prepared to work some long nights on lab reports, but overall it's manageable and engaging.
Take it, and make sure you come to lectures.
Take it, it's easy enough for a science requirement

This class has fair grading if you put the time in.
This class is super easy if you just put a little effort into it. Also, its rather interesting.
This course is a well-organized, comprehensive introduction to the subject matter, and is worth taking for this reason if you have any interest in structures and their engineers.
This is a great way to learn about engineering in a way that's not too overwhelming.
This is a low stress class. I definitely learned more about structural engineers.
Very light and enjoyable experience for a lab class.
descrip: This course focuses on structural engineering as a new art form begun during the Industrial Revolution and flourishing today in long-span bridges, thin shell concrete vaults, and tall buildings. Through laboratory experiments students study the scientific basis for structural performance and thereby connect external forms to the internal forces in the major works of structural engineers. Students examine contemporary exemplars that are essential to the understanding of 21st century structuring of cities with illustrations taken from various cities in the U.S. and abroad.

title: Transmission and Compression of Information
reviews: Definitely take this course if the material looks interesting to you. I enjoyed it and learned a lot.
Professor Abbe is awesome! A must-take.
take it please
prereqs: ELE 301 and ORF 309 are prerequisites..
descrip: Introduction to information theory. Algorithms for data compression. Principles of error correcting codes. Digital modulation and demodulation.

title: Elementary Twi II
prereqs: TWI 101.
descrip: This course is a continuation of Twi 101 and continues to focus on the communicative approach to studying the language. It includes specific socio-cultural settings and events. Speaking, reading, writing and listening continue to form an integral part of the course and students will build on their grammatical skills. By the end of the course, learners are expected to reach proficiency level ranging between Novice High and Intermediate Low.

title: Program and Policy Evaluation
prereqs: WWS 507B/507C or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course introduces students to evaluation. It explores ways: to develop and implement research-based program improvement strategies and program accountability systems; to judge the effects of policies and programs; and to assess the benefits and costs of policy or program changes. Students study a wide range of evaluation tools; read and discuss both domestic and international evaluation examples and apply this knowledge by designing several different types of evaluations on programs of their choosing.

title: Dilemmas of Development in Asia
reviews: Be open to revisionist perspectives.
Definitely take this if you're at all interested in EAS. Leheny is a great lecturer, and you get a good overview of Asia across all the modules in the class

Do all the readings when they are assigned and take notes on them because they will help orient you during lecture and then you also will have created an efficient study guide for yourself when exams come around.
Do all the readings!
Even if Prof. Leheny is the only professor teaching it, would definitely recommend taking it.
Good course to PDF. Some very interesting topics, but the course is infuriatingly aimless.
Good course!  Do all the readings carefully, though, and it will be extremely rewarding.

I don't know if this course will be offered again bc Prof Sato was a visiting professor, but it was a GREAT class and if it's ever offered again you SHOULD TAKE IT! You don't have to know much about Asia, or development (I'm an engineer) but I thought it was great. I learned so much, the readings are great, Leheny and Sato are awesome!!

If you take this course, make sure that you do all the readings and really understand the arguments presented by each author. 

Also make sure you have an interest in development---and not only East Asia. Development is at times a difficult and super vague concept---and you'll need that passion for environmentalism, etc. to keep your energy up in the class.
Really engage in the course and it will be extremely eye-opening.

TAKE IT NOW 
LEHENY IS A GOD

Take it!

Take it, especially if you're at all interested in discussions, Asia, or thinking critically about the world and how we understand it. Take this course if you are genuinely interested in the topic of development in Asia.  The readings are reasonable in quantity, but can be dense and need proper time. If you have a stressful JP or thesis timeline, the 8-page research paper for this course falls right during this time--might be something to consider.
This course is largely conceptual, so it is sometimes confusing, but just do your readings, attend lectures and precepts, and you'll do well.
Unfortunately, it won't be offered again, but definitely take a class with Professor Leheny or with Professor Sato when he comes back from the University of Tokyo!
depends on their interests
if you decide to take it, read the readings if you want to do well.
descrip: East Asian development has been arguably the most important social, economic, and political phenomenon of the past half century. It has posed, and continues to pose, monumental challenges. These have included intellectual debates over the proper way to build national wealth, struggles over democracy and rights, environmental crises, and the changing demands and expectations of citizens themselves. In this course, we survey some of the dilemmas facing the countries of East and Southeast Asia, drawing attention the myriad connections between economic growth and political, social, cultural, and environmental transformation.

title: Cosmology
reviews: Definitely take this class. Aside from being an amazing researcher, Prof. Bahcall is a great teacher. She presents the material extremely well and is always available for her students. The class covers most of the important topics in cosmology and is a great introduction to theoretical cosmology.
Do not be deterred by the fact that the course is 400 level if you are an underclassman. It is more conceptual than mathematical, and you learn a lot.
Good
I strongly recommend taking this course even if you have no astrophysics background.

I would recommend this course for any student interested in the study of the Universe.  This is an upper level astronomy and physics course, so I would not recommend it if you are not willing to work hard on the problem sets and study well for the exams.

If you like a more mathematical presentation of physics topics and have had exposure to cosmology before, then I would recommend considering the cosmology course in the physics department instead. But this course would be an excellent first introduction to cosmology.
It is relatively laid back for a physics course, and some of it felt like review, but the subject matter is fun to think about.
It's an easy 400 level physics course that is engaging and teaches you interesting things. What's not to like?
Take it only if you don't know anything about cosmology, or if you are ver weak at math. Otherwise you will struggle to get an A through tedious homeworks.
Take it!  Not that much physics knowledge is required.  If you've taken AST 204, the beginning might feel slow/boring, but the second half is worth staying for.
Very clear, interesting course with reasonable expectations for the students.  Significantly less time consuming than most physics courses I've taken.
You need to take it.
prereqs: MAT 201 and MAT 202 and PHY 207 or 205.
descrip: A general review of extragalactic astronomy and cosmology. Topics include the properties and nature of galaxies, clusters of galaxies, superclusters, the large-scale structure of the universe, evidence for the existence of Dark Matter and Dark Energy, the expanding universe, the early universe, and the formation and evolution of structure.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half Term) - The Development Challenge of HIV/AIDS
descrip: This seminar will review the origins of HIV, the multiple impacts of AIDS, the reasons for sustained global neglect, the foundations of effective prevention & treatment programs & the urgent need to improve monitoring & evaluation. Special attention will be given to the role of social factors in the epidemic. Course participants will examine the policy-making process related to global public goods & consider whether the world is better positioned to avert a resurgence of this pandemic or the emergence of the next threat.

title: Language of Love, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Roman Architecture
reviews: Go to office hours to talk about your work and how to improve.
Going to class is definitely better than just skipping and doing the readings on your own.

Roman Architecture is a fascinating subject but be aware that because the it involves architectural planning and building, you should be ready to read lots of scholarly books/articles and be prepared to discuss such technical aspects in class
Take it if you can. The term paper will take some effort, but thats the only downside to this class. Professor Koortbojian is engaging and makes the material very interesting.
descrip: This course will examine the architecture of the Romans, from its mythic beginnings (as recounted, for example, by Vitruvius) to the era of the high empire. Topics will include: city planning; the transformation of the building trades; civic infrastructure; and the full breadth of Roman structures, both public and private.

title: Introduction to Portuguese II
prereqs: POR 101.
descrip: A continuation of POR 101. Students will continue to develop skills of oral/aural comprehension, speaking, reading and writing, while gaining further exposure to the Portuguese-speaking world through the media, literature, film and music of Brazil, Portugal and Lusophone Africa. Students who successfully complete POR 102 will place into POR 109.

title: Directed Research
reviews: Be sure to discuss with your advisor and have a clear idea of what your research direction is at the beginning of the semester.
Good course to start your graduate research, keep strong communication with your advisor to determine the research expectations for the semester and provide regular updates.
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed research is normally taken during the first year of study. The total grading of the course will be 25% poster presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: Technology and Society
reviews: (with professor Angela Creager) This course wasn't much work, but unfortunately it wasn't much fun either. While easy, it sometimes felt like a waste of time. However, precepts were much better than lecture. Additionally, there are a few noteworthy takeaways from this course, but in general I wish that I had learned more. Perhaps this course will get better organized in the future, and if so, by all means take it. This is a really interesting area of our culture that needs to be examined!
BEST COURSE FOR SENIOR SPRING
Decent course, made me think a little, assignments were pretty easy.
Do well on the projects. They tend to grade easier and the midterm / final exams will almost definitely sink your grade a bit.
EGR 277 definitely exceeded my expectations. Pretty chill workwise too. My only complaint is that the grading was quite arbitrary.
Fairly good course, I'd take it. Easy PDF
Get Nicole as a precdeptor.

I learned a lot in this class. If you are considering getting the certificate but are prepared to abandon it because you heard negative things about this class, I would tell you to not listen to those things. This class is worth it.
I would, if only is needed to be a core class.
I wouldn't recommend taking the course, only because it was kind of boring and I didn't really learn anything new.
It is a good survey course to gain a more broad understanding of a lot of different historically and modernly relevant topics.
Its a fun course and isnt too hard.
Lectures are kinda bad, but I liked precept and the assignments are enjoyable. Just do it. Don't let this class deter you from the CITP cert. It's not THAT bad.
Lots of interesting material. If you don't like a topic one week, you could love what you're doing next. There's a little bit of whiplash in this.
Not too much work, interesting topics but lectures are pretty dry and boring.
Only take it if for the certificate. The subject matter is mind numbingly dull and the lectures are useless. I stopped going to lectures after Week 2 and I have an A- in the course so far.
Pretty easy. Pick a topic for the podcast and website that you are interested in and it will be even easier.
Pretty interesting class, I'd take it if you're interested in the certificate. Definitely a lighter workload.
Read the powerpoints.

Stay on top of readings!
Take it -- not too much work, exams aren't easy but it's not impossible. The Midterm and Final projects are time-consuming but also interesting because you get to pick the topic. FIND A GOOD PARTNER.
Take it if you have a general interest in the topic.
Take it.

Take the course. It doesn't matter what you're thinking about doing or majoring in or not, take the course. It provided a great base of knowledge about today's society and the technology within, and helps with almost every other subject.

Take this class if you are already interested in the social implications of technology, or if you're trying to get the certificate. If you don't already find the subject material interesting, this course might not change your mind.

Take this course if you want a broad survey of many topics in technology and society.  The reading level is not extensive, and the material is accessible.  Assignments are not difficult, but small assignments such as short lecture responses are more frequent than in some other humanities courses.
Take this course.

This class is pretty dry, but if you are interested in this type of thing I would say go for it. Be ready for the podcast and website to be graded harshly, and for the class as a whole not to be an easy A
This course is a good pdf-able SA for scientists or engineers and the course doesn't have that much work. Some topics are a bit dull though.
When doing the projects, pick material you are interested in, because you'll be working on that all year.
You learn a lot in the class and it helps you see the world in a new way. The topics seem scattered, but they build well together.

great overview of the relationship between tech and society - no work at all except two medium sized projects that are pretty easy; readings aren't required and going to lecture isn't requried either... midterm and finals are really easy
i wouldn't take it...
there's gonna be a lot of fuzzies in this course. DO NOT choose them for the projects.
this is a great course. i loved professor creager
descrip: Technology and society are unthinkable without each other - each provides the means and framework in which the other develops. To explore this dynamic, this course investigates a wide array of questions on the interaction between technology, society, politics, and economics, emphasizing the themes of innovation and maturation, systems and regulation, risk and failure, and ethics and expertise. Specific topics covered include nuclear power and waste, genetically-modified organisms, regulation of the internet, medical mistakes, intellectual property, the financial crisis of 2008, and the post-fossil-fuels economy.

title: Economic Analysis of Development (Basic)
descrip: Introduction to the processes of economic growth and development. The course examines various theories of development; poverty and inequality measurement; and the role of markets for credit, labor and land, as well as education and health, in development. The role of public policy will be considered within each of these topics. The course may also cover topics such as foreign aid, commodity pricing, and tax policy. (Prerequisites: 511b; 512b can be taken concurrently.)

title: Sociology of Migration, Development and Ethnicity
descrip: This course is taught as a hands-on practicum on research on immigration and development, especially the former. It supplements the Center for Migration and Development's (CMD) symposium talk during the 2013-14 academic year, which meets approximately every other week from 12-1:30 on Thursdays. We discuss the ongoing work of CMD speakers, students, post-docs and other members of the university community that work on migration or development. We expect that participants attend the CMD symposium talks, read the paper associated with each week's discussion and be active participants in the discussion.

title: Brazilian Cinema
reviews: Awesome course!
Bruno is an awesome instructor, and the movies are great.
I would definitely recommend this course. I think Bruno's a great professor, and the content of the course was very engaging and covered a great range of subjects.
I would recommend it.
Take it! Prof Carvalho rocks !
watch every film. every discussion is worth being a part of
prereqs: POR 208 or permission of instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the richness of Brazilian film, this course explores major cinematic movements: from the Cinema Novo, to critically acclaimed documentaries and more recent commercial successes like 'City of God'. Recurrent and emerging trends will be discussed (e.g. the destruction of the Amazon, urban violence, literary adaptation, musical expressions).

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Analytics and Systems of Big Data
reviews: Good course! Take if interested.
I recommend those who is in Machine Learning to take this course.
Start the project early and work on it constantly.
The course is a good selection for students with system background because you can read good papers and have good discussions with classmates and the professor.
This is Professor Li at his very best.  He is one of the top educators in the CS department when he is teaching topics he finds exciting.
This is a good introduction to the research area of big data.
Useful
descrip: Study of recent papers on analytics and systems of big data. In analytics, we plan to read papers in mining, search and exploration techniques for images, audio, video and network data. In systems for big data, we plan to study recent developments in scale-out systems including storage systems and search systems. Students taking this course for credit are required to present a selected paper and work on a small course project.

title: Independent Work with Design
descrip: Course similar to MAE 339-340. Principle difference is that the project must incorporate aspects and principles of design for a system, product, vehicle, device, apparatus, or other design element. Written report and poster session at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work with design is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339D Fall Term project; 340D Spring Term project.

title: Religion and Critical Thought Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on current student and faculty research in religion and critical thought, designed primarily for graduate students working on dissertations and general examination essays on the philosophy of religion, religious ethics, and the role of religion in politics.

title: Macroeconomics/International Finance Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Intermediate Russian II
reviews: I would advise him or her to attend class regularly because the activities were very helpful for understanding the grammar. We had a lot of fun this year - the classroom atmosphere is excellent because the professors made us feel comfortable and encouraged us to speak up (so come prepared to participate). Do the homework regularly - that really helps to solidify the in-class grammar work.
Take this course!
The class is a decent amount of work and well taught.
Very important in developing spoken russian

You start reading literature in this class, which is great. We did some Tolstoy, Chekov, and even poetry. I really enjoyed the translation work we did, but we also went through the rest of the textbook at a reasonable pace. Mark did a great job preparing things.
prereqs: RUS105 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Major emphasis on the development of vocabulary and oral expression with continued presentation and review of grammar. Vocabulary thematically organized to include such topics as travel, city life, nature, hobbies, politics, etc. Training of all language skills in a cultural context. Vocabulary reinforced through reading of cultural texts.

title: Time and the matter of memory
reviews: If you notice that the professor is absent for a second, don?t listen to you for real sometimes, or does not pay attention to your ideas, don?t hesitate to keep trying. Eventually, when she allows herself to hear your opinion, you will have one of the best feedbacks that you can get in Academia.
Prof. Nouzeilles is for me the most accomplished scholar in the Department. I wouldn't hestitate to take her class again.

This seminar is a great opportunity to get in touch with a less know face of the Latin American 20th century literary production. It also allows a reflection about questions that regard even broader universe, like memory and time.
descrip: From Sarmiento's reconstruction of his childhood as foretold fiction and Manzano's re writing of a past without Self, to Garro's temporal aporias and Munoz's vanishing photography, modern writers and artists persistently have been preoccupied with the question of time, subjectivity, and the matter of memory. This seminar focuses on the notion of memory as inscription and narrative, both textual and visual, in Latin American modern culture. Topics discussed include: time and modernity; memory and technology; history and memory; memory and trauma; and memory and the archive.

title: Junior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared. BSE candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Statistical Theory and Methods
descrip: A graduate-level introduction to statistical theory and methods and some of the most important and commonly-used principles of statistical inference. Covers the statistical theory and methods for point estimation, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing.

title: Thermodynamics
reviews: Aaaa. Don't take this course unless you're CBE. And if you are, do your best. Do the readings, do the lectures, and ask a SHITTON of Questions. Why? Because the people teaching, regardless of it being professors, TA's, have probably taken a lot of courses in Thermo. Therefore, there are many things they assume you AUTOMATICALLY KNOW. Which of course, isn't true? What does this mean? You ask a crapton of questions in class, look like the clown, but get a damn better understanding of the material. Because Thermo is one tough subject to tackle, and the teachers don't make it easy for you unless you ask the questions.
Always go to office hours to get help on problem sets and to clarify any questions you have. Don't get behind since the material is cummulatvie.

Be prepared fro this course to be the most time consuming course the semester you take it. Go to office hours often, and make study groups. Do a good job on the problem sets, and you'll be prepared well for the exams. The class is has fairly interesting material and provides insights about chemistry, and thermodynamic processes.
Course attempts to rigorously present thermodynamics, so it is can be challenging at times. Not recommended for non-CBE majors.
Don't take it unless required.

GO TO OFFICE HOURS EARLY. Start the problem sets early in the week and make office hours a regular part of your schedule. The TAs want to help. Also, try your best to read the textbook before class. You will gain a much better understanding of the material. I also recommend reading the textbook again before the major exams. It is not a class where doing hundreds of practice problems is the best way to study. You really need to understand the concepts. It is a difficult course. The most difficult I have ever taken without a doubt. But if you are interested, and if you put in the work, it will be a very rewarding experience.
Go to class. Take advantage of office hours.
Go to office hours and work on problem sets together.
Go to office hours for every problem set and don't miss precept.
Go to office hours!
Go to office hours!!!! Get started on problem sets early, attempt them by yourself and then work through them with classmates.

I cannot emphasize reading the book enough. Unfortunately, the best advice is to read the book at least twice (as you are going through the course). This seems absurd but the concepts are difficult to the point that lecture and precept alone truly cannot prepare you to do problems. Try very hard to keep up with the reading. Mark up your text book, label it as it can be very helpful on exams (you may even find an exact example in the book that matches an exam problem and only by being familiar with the book will you be able to take advantage of this.) Last, attend office hours early in the week, the students who did best did this. You may not solve more than 1 or 2 problems but when it comes to the night before due dates and you are at office hours again you will be that much further along and have better understanding. Meet on on one with the professor to address concerns even if this is just "I am really struggling and cannot find a way to perform on exams". Then meet with TAs one on one to go through quizes step by step.
I would recommend starting on psets early because they take a really long time.
It is a hard course but go to precept and office hours! and read the book@@@
Just try to keep up with the class. Start pset early.
Keep up with the material and go to office hours!
Office hours and collaboration to understand ideas and solve problems is key.
Please do not take it if you do not have to.
Professor Aksay is the best and I hope he is teaching the course when you take it.
READ THE BOOK. CAREFULLY. FREQUENTLY. wash, rinse, repeat.
Read the book thoroughly
Read the chapter 1-3 times, and preferably read it and the lectures slides before each class. And go to office hours.
Read the textbook, GO TO OFFICE HOURS. JUST GO.
Spend time on the problem sets. You need that.
Start on pset early, or prepare for 4am marathons on Thursday nights.
Take it only if you have to.
Take to decide whether or not you would like to be CBE.

This is a difficult course and it will take up a lot of time. Start the problem sets early. Get familiar with Excel. Everything in the textbook is fair game so read the textbook well and learn the concepts. If you understand the textbook and are good at absorbing information from textbooks, you probably do not have to go to lecture. Precept goes over example and concepts not found in the book so that is almost always useful. START THE PROBLEM SETS EARLY. Don't take this class if you're not CBE. If you just want to take thermo, take chem thermo, don't put yourself through this.
prereqs: CBE 245 and MAT 201 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The course focuses on basic principles governing the equilibrium behavior of macroscopic systems and their applications to materials and processes of interest in modern chemical engineering. In the first half of the course we introduce the fundamental concepts: energy conservation (First Law); temperature and entropy (Second Law); thermodynamic potentials; equilibrium and stability; and the molecular basis of thermodynamics. These ideas are then applied to problems such as calculating the equilibrium composition of coexisting phases and reacting mixtures or analyzing the thermodynamic efficiency of cooling and power generation cycles.

title: Worlds of Form: Russian Formalism and Constructivism
descrip: The seminar examines the ways Russian formalists and constructivists problematized the role and importance of form in their writing. We explore systemic views, paying especial attention to the role of structure (and deconstruction); we investigate the links between materiality and form, and, finally, we see how form, texture, and system - are localized in particular artistic or historical contexts. This is an interdisciplinary seminar, and during the semester we move back and from literature to cinema, and from architecture to painting.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: Every student at Princeton should take at least one course from the Creative Writing department!
Professor Smith gives great feedback and is a warm and fantastic instructor.
Put as much energy as you can in this course - it's worth investing early in your final project and also asking Professor Smith for advice in any writing concerns!
Take a CWR course if you can while you are here. They have been the academic highlight of my Princeton writing career thus far.
Take advanced poetry! I do not know if Geoffrey Nutter will be teaching at Princeton again but he's a solid professor with a lot of poetic insights. Definitely sign up for his class.
Take this class! Start your poems early to get the most out of them and come to class prepared with questions.
Take this class.
Take this workshop - Prof. Smith is an excellent workshop leader.
Work hard and you will end up with work you are very proud of.
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two 200-level poetry courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of poetry for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the places of literature among the liberal arts.

title: Contemporary Dance: Advanced Technique and Choreography
reviews: Definitely take it if Silas and Rebecca are teaching it again.
I would recommend this course for anyone with a genuine interest in choreography and with a solid background in dance technique looking to improve.
If you want to work on your choreography skills, definitely take it.
Previous dance experience and know that this is a time commitment!
Silas is wonderful. So helpful, so kind, and really wants to see everyone improve. I feel a huge difference in my dancing.

The movement isn't "standard contemporary"--it is usually very different, odd, and open to interpretation, in that Silas doesn't necessarily tell you exactly what you're supposed to do.  And Rebecca really teaches you inspiring things and ways to think about dancing and choreography.  Silas and Rebecca are amazing.
This is a great class for students who are relatively new to choreographing.  The class is explorative and helps you grow as a dancer and an artist.
take it not only for the certificate, but also for great movement and new insight into he choreographic process
prereqs: DAN 409 is designed for students with minimum of two or preferably three dance program courses from the following: DAN 309 and/or DAN 319 and/or DAN 419 and/or DAN 420, or the equivalent outside experience. Attendance in all classes and completion of all work required..
descrip: Advanced dance technique and choreography, with a focus on contemporary practices. In technique, students will be challenged to expand their movement range and increase their mastery of various styles in ways required by today's dance world. Students will examine concepts such as skeletal support, sequential movement, and momentum to emphasize ease and efficiency in motion. In choreography, students will work together in movement-based laboratories to focus on collaboration and choreographic choice-making skills.

title: Religious Conversion
