reviews: If you're at all interested in learning more about religious conversion (or religion in general) I'd definitely recommend this course!

REL 369 is a fabulous course!  My preconception of religious conversion as an individualistic and internal transformation was completely overturned.  The class starts off slowly with the somewhat dense 'Varieties of Religious Experience' by William James, but each week's readings build on those of past weeks, until you gradually realize that conversion cannot be fully understood apart from larger historical and political contexts.  The class is a lot of work; it requires weekly one to two page BlackBoard posts, one class presentation on ALL of the readings from one week, a take-home midterm, a final paper, and a two to three page analysis of a television drama.  I imagine that the material would have been somewhat difficult if I had not taken previous courses in religion or philosophy.  But if you stick with the course, you will learn a lot!  Professor Batnitzky is one of the most knowledgeable instructors I've had at Princeton.  She is easy-going and has a great sense of humor.
Take the class and feel free to disagree with or not enjoy some of the authors/thinkers we read! It makes for a better discussion.
This class is great - Prof. Batnitzky is delightful and you'll get to look at many different faces of religious conversion across time and geography.
descrip: In the United States, we often think of religious conversion as a radical change in belief on the part of the individual. But historically, and still in much of the world today, religious conversion is as much political as theological. This seminar focuses on religious conversion from the perspectives of politics, international law and human rights, history, literature, post-colonialism, race, psychology, anthropology, and religious studies. Our aim is to understand the complexity of thinking about religious conversion as well as the very category of "religion."

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Scene Understanding
reviews: If you are interested in vision research, you should definitely choose this course.
If you're interested in computer vision, this is a very good seminar to take.
It's a good course for broadly learning emerging topics in computer vision.
It's good for grad students who want to specialize in vision

The lecture quality varied from presenter to presenter, but I ended up learning a lot in the end.  Begin preparing your own lectures well in advance so you can practice and get feedback on slides.  Minimal work besides your own presentations.
descrip: Review of current approaches and discussion of the fundamental principles underlying scene understanding in computer vision. We read a mixture of papers from computer vision and influential works from cognitive psychology. We also discuss how to leverage computational power, crowd sourcing and big data for computer vision research in general.

title: Hard-Boiled to Noir: American Crime Fiction and Film
reviews: I would say if the subject matter sounds interesting to you, jump on it. This course is a lot of fun and definitely worth taking.
If you're willing to put in the time and effort, take it, because it's definitely worth it and enjoyable.
Take it.  Not a ton of work and very interesting.
This is a very fun course and you will learn a lot. You need to put in the time to read the novels, but mostly the course involved analytical thinking.
descrip: A study of the emergence during the high modernist period of two genres that might be considered at once eminently American, distinctively modernist, and brazenly vulgar. The subject matter may be louche, but writers thereby more directly engaged issues of social inequality (racial, sexual, and economic), along with changing images of gender construction. As well they registered the impact of Freudian psychoanalysis on literary form, and in formal terms engaged the belatedness of narrative to event. Such fiction had tremendous appeal for cinema, and we will focus on the ways in which adaptation modified popular formulas.

title: Modern Regression and Time Series
prereqs: ORF 245 and MAT 202.
descrip: Heavy tailed distributions and copulas. Simple and multiple linear regressions. Nonlinear regression. Nonparametricegression and classification. Time series analysis: stationarity and classical linear models (AR, MA, ARMA, ..). Nonlinear and nonstationary time series models. State space systems, hidden Markov models and filtering.

title: Playwriting II: Intermediate Playwriting
reviews: If you are interested in developing your skills as a playwright. DO IT. The goal of the class is to develop YOUR work, and the assignments develop around the work you are doing as a writer.
prereqs: THR 205 and Program Director's permission. Please contact Professor Tim Vasen for more information at: tvasen@Princeton.edu.
descrip: A workshop in creating theatre collaboratively, with a specific emphasis on how the specific tools of playwriting (plot, character, structure, language, spectacle) translate to an ensemble devising process. How do we, as writers, participate actively as authors and visionaries in a landscape that has many voices? How do we write scripts that can serve as an instigating impulse for a company? How do we write scripts, on our own or within a group, that provide space for collaborators - without sacrificing our own authorial vision or voice?

title: Introductory Sculpture
reviews: A lot of work if you choose but absolutely worth the effort. I was pushed more so than in any other class to produce something I was proud of.
Amy is a very nice, laid back professor.  Her work in her own studio is very minimalist and abstract and this is reflected in the way she teaches the course.
Ask Amy for advice constantly as you go through a project, she might give you some great ideas.
Come with an open mind.

I would really recommend this class! I learnt a lot about interpreting a piece of art, and about what does and doesn't get communicated in my own pieces. We learnt a range of techniques (including welding and all manner of mould-making techniques), and each project really had us master these techniques in order to produce good work. The work load is manageable, however the week before a project is due we did spend a fair amount of time in the studio. Martha is a great teacher and a really interesting person and being able to do a class with her is an amazing experience!
I would take this class if you are looking for a creative outlet.  This is not a blow-off class. Do not take someone's spot if you are not going to appreciate the course.
If Martha is teaching this course and you don't mind spending a decent amount of time in the studio absolutely take it!
Its a great class to take to have a course that is fun, and also not mountains of work. You'll get out of the course what you put in.
Martha is awesome and you learn a lot of different skills in this class, as well as ways of thinking about sculpture. Was not a huge fan of all the assignments, though.
Take it take it take it! You do have to spend a good amount of time outside of class in the studio, but do it do it yes you'll love it I promise.

Take this class. You get to build art and work with your hands (instead of just your fingers on a key board or mouse). It will force you outside of your comfort zone, and make you think in new ways and try new things. Plus, Martha is amazing.
take it if you want some creative relief--one of my favorite classes i took in princeton and made me consider doing the fine arts certificate. Amy is cool
descrip: A studio introduction to sculpture, particularly the study of form, concept, fabrication and the influence of a wide variety of materials and processes on sculpture and its consequences. Students will develop an understanding of contemporary sculpture and a basic facilities in woodworking, metalworking, carving and casting.

title: Writing about Cities
reviews: HIS 451 asks one to read quite a bit, and enjoyment ones gets out of the class will be dependent upon what you and your peers do. If you are up for the challenge then I think you will learn quite a bit about the tradition of writing about cities in North America.

If don't mind writing--a lot of writing--this course is WONDERFUL--it's such a joy to be able to work on primary research with Prof. Isenberg! And you learn a lot about how American cities have been perceived and written about. I think every academic architect should take something like this!
Read the syllabus very carefully to get a sense of whether this is for you. It's heavy on the ethnographies and a more anthropological/sociological approach to cities, which isn't right for everyone.
prereqs: Interested students must apply by submitting a brief one-paragraph email to the professor, describing their interest in the course and include concentration and class year. Email to isenber@princeton.edu..
descrip: This seminar surveys influential writing about North American cities, towards the goal of students developing their own research. We begin in the 19th century but focus on the 20th. Why have some publications set popular frameworks, while others languished? Where have new ideas originated? Comparing different genres, what writing has shaped experiences of cities, and policy? How has region mattered? Writing about built environments poses unique challenges. Since the 1950s, oppositions have dominated urban frameworks, such as Jane Jacobs vs. Robert Moses. Students will explore the potential for fresh perspectives on past and present.

title: Form Finding of Structural Surfaces
reviews: Get a jump on assignments early, because they take awhile and things will go wrong.  If you ask a question, get the response in writing.
Put a lot of effort into the four projects.
The topics are interesting and you get to do a lot of independent thinking for the assignments.
prereqs: Open to all CEE and Architecture graduate students. Undergraduate students must get approval from Professor Adriaenssens..
descrip: The course looks at the most inventive structures and technologies, demonstrating their use of form finding techniques in creating complex curved surfaces. The first part introduces the topic of structural surfaces, tracing the ancient relationship between innovative design and construction technology and the evolution of surface structures. The second part familiarizes the student with membranes(systems, form finding techniques,materials and construction techniques) The third part focuses on rigid surfaces. The fourth part provides a deeper understanding of numerical form finding techniques.

title: The Medieval Period
reviews: Definitely take it!!
Great experience for both English concentrators and non-majors.
Great for anyone from any department. A background in medieval literature is not necessary.
Take it! It is great for both those students who are familiar with medieval english and for those who have never seen a yough or thorn before!
Take it! It is really great and Prof. Anderson is the best!
Take this course! You know you've always wanted to learn how to read in MIddle English and do the accent. Now's your chance!!
descrip: This course focuses on Middle English texts that establish the wonderfully wide range for reading and writing in a crucial pre-modern period ranging from ca 1100-1500. Not all courtesy and chivalry, the literature of this period concerns problems of love high and low, of making a nation and of the drama of the domestic, of humans from their mightiest to their meanest. Here is the trip of life--and in a language gorgeously rich and varied.

title: Greek Tragedy
reviews: If you're at all interested in Greek tragedy, take this course. Professor Holmes is great at leading thought-provoking discussions. The readings are thoughtfully chosen.

Taking this course should be a foregone conclusion for any serious student of Greek. The class covers a wide variety of topics and problems related to Greek tragedy, with plenty of time devoted to class discussion
The workload is manageable, and reading Greek tragedy in the original language is a rewarding, challenging experience.
prereqs: CLG 108 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Close reading of two or three tragedies in the original Greek, with attention to their literary, dramatic, and cultural significance. The primary aim of the course is to enhance students' knowledge and appreciation of Greek tragic poetry and of the genre of tragedy as a literary, cultural, and political institution of 5th- century Athens, with attention to later dramatic traditions. The focus this term is on Sophocles' Philoctetes, with additional reading from the Prometheus Bound.

title: Advanced Econometrics: Time Series Models
descrip: Concepts and methods of time series analysis and their applications to economics. Time series models to be studied include simultaneous stochastic equations, VAR, ARIMA, and state-space models. Methods to analyze trends, second-moment properties via the auto covariance function and the spectral density function, methods of estimation and hypothesis testing and of model selection will be presented. Kalman filter and applications as well as unit roots, cointegration, ARCH, and structural breaks models are also studied.

title: Studies in Spanish Language and Style
reviews: A lot more work than 100 level Spanish and it was kind of unevenly distributed, but a wonderful mix of homework materials and assignments, including movies, plays/role-plays, stories, and informational documents. Requires lots of attention to detail and great for improving writing skills- a little less so for speaking, but overall fantastic class.
Definitely take this course if you're coming from 108 and you want to keep up with Spanish.  I wouldn't have imagined that I would improve so much with one extra class
Definitely take this course to improve your writing. The stylistic and rhetorical skills you develop through this course are extremely worthwhile.
Don't take it if your goal is to learn how to speak.
If you are naturally good at spanish, take it! it wont be hard at all. if not, you must work hard
If you can get Marco as a teacher definitely take this course!

If you're looking for a class that teaches you about the intricacies of Spanish grammer then this is a good option. If you're looking for something that improves your speaking ability then this is probably not the class to take. However it is a lot of constant work so make sure you stay on top of it every week! Be prepared for the number of written assignments. The readings are fun and interesting!
If you're serious about becoming fluent or just learning more about the culture, take it.

It is a great class to take if you are considering going into the upper level classes since it has a small focus on grammar and contains difficult vocabulary and several essays. Be sure to review for the grammar exercises as those are the most difficult assignments.
Its a great way to get better at Spanish. Recommend this class if you are interested
Marco was the best! It's really too bad that he won't be teaching here next year, because he made the class so enjoyable for everyone.
Spend time on the writing assignments - it's worth it!
TAKE 207 WITH MARCO--HE KILLS IT
Take it if you need to!
Take it to improve your Spanish, especially with regards to writing.

While this class is a significant amount of consistent work throughout the semester, it will improve your written and speaking ability if you approach it with the right attitude. Prof Bono is great and very approachable, and don't be afraid even if you don't have a substantial background in Spanish - this class will make you a more confident speaker and writer and this will be reflected in your grade as long as you work hard. The texts are also very interesting, and not too difficult.
prereqs: SPA 107 or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score..
descrip: An advanced language course, its main goal is to increase students' fluency and accuracy in oral and written Spanish, and to acquaint them with the context in which cultural values and meanings are produced. To that end, students will engage in the analysis and discussion of texts, films, articles, songs and images about Buenos Aires and Madrid.

title: Why Global Warming is Controversial
descrip: See website

title: Research in Architecture
descrip: This course is an advanced pro-seminar that will examine the spatial histories and representational forms of the modern city. Students will read architectural, urban and theoretical texts and conduct individual research on how spatial theory affects the manner in which cities and architectural forms have been written about, envisioned and built.

title: Main Currents of Spanish Thought, 1848 to the Present - History and Memory Spanish Civil War
descrip: The course explores how the Spanish II Republic and the Civil War have been narrated, remembered and revised in historiography, prose fiction, poetry, film, journalism and other cultural venues throughout the decades and the generations. The course pays special attention to the politics of memory, but also to aspects of memory that challenge conventional political assumptions about history and memory.

title: Reading & Writing About the Scientific Literature in English (Half Term): Science and Engineering
prereqs: Course open to international graduate students in their second semester of study or beyond in any field related to science and engineering. Non-Credit. Enrollment by application..
descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature in science and engineering. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. Two 80-minute seminars. To apply, visit http://www.princeton.edu/writing/wse

title: Experimental Physics
reviews: A standout course in the junior physics curriculum. There are many labs to choose from. The labs are well constructed and have interesting theory behind them. Marlow gives great lectures and is very responsive to students.
Assuming you're a physics major, it's a required course. Otherwise, it's a good deal of work. Some labs are interesting, but be prepared to do a lot of independent learning.
Be ready- labs can be draining and will take a lot of time.  They can also be rewarding, though.
Definitely take it, but be mindful of deadlines. Start the lab reports early. Also, make sure to really understand how to do error analysis!

Great course when run by Marlow. He really revamped and improved a lot of the labs, and is a very relaxed and helpful instructor. I suggest not doing the Holography lab, though, as it is really hard to get working holograms (in particular, ones that look decent at all). Other than that, the rest of the labs are all pretty neat and worth doing.
If you're taking it you probably have to. You will spend a lot of time in lab, but from what I know the lab reports themselves are less stressful than those in other departments' core labs.
If you're taking this, you probably have to. But it's a fun course.
In comparison to the other sciences' core labs,  the physics core lab is excellent. Professor Marlow is an excellent professor for this course.
It will take some time, but it is worth it.
Learn how to code in python well before this, and brush up on statistics.

Nobody takes this unless they have to, but it's not all that bad. The labs I chose weren't especially hard to execute - Mossbauer effect and parity violation were particularly straightforward because after the initial setup the data was collected automatically without requiring adjustment. Lab reports are annoying, but not intrinsically that difficult - for me, the issue was just that I never had a clear idea about what was expected. The exams were also a pain because the lecture material was completely disjoint from the labs, and in the absence of problem sets it was hard to stay on track with it.
Some labs can be really boring, but overall the material of the labs and lectures was really interesting.
Start early on your labs reports. Try to enjoy them -- they actually are fun!.
Well you don't have any choice....
You probably need to take it, and it's great!
prereqs: PHY 103/104 or equivalent; PHY 208 or equivalent. Not recommended for sophomores..
descrip: Students work in small groups and perform four experiments and an electronics lab. The list of experiments to choose from includes muon decay, beta decay, optical pumping, Mossbauer effect, holography, positron annihilation, electron diffraction, single photon interference, NMR, the Josephson effect, and an observation of galactic hydrogen. Weekly lectures will provide an overview of various experimental techniques and data analysis.

title: China's Foreign Relations
reviews: A lot of reading, but a truly fascinating class.
A lot of reading, very challenging examinations, but learned a lot. More focused on history, so not the best if you want to focus on contemporary issues.
Absolutely take this course! It's very interesting and relevant material, but be prepared for a heavy reading load.

An incredible course, with a substantial amount of reading and a fair amount of work required. If you're willing to put in the time, this will be one of the most informative courses you'll take at Princeton (especially if you haven't been exposed to China before)!

Be aware that most of the people taking this course already have a lot of experience in the field of East Asian Studies and it can be pretty intimidating at times. The class takes a lot of preparation and focus, but the preceptors are always willing to help out.
Christensen focuses heavily on history, for a good reason. Take it, you will learn so much about China and Sino-US relations, and make sense of all the news reports around you.

Definitely take it if you are interested in China at all. This is great for students interested in U.S. foreign policy, regional politics in East Asia, and China (even if not strictly politically). Lectures are consistently good. Fair amount of reading.
Definitely take this class. Such a great foundation for anyone interested in China.

Definitely take this course! Don't be fazed by the reading - it's a lot, but it's definitely worth it and you will definitely find time for it. Professor Christensen is a great professor and lectures are worth getting up at 9 AM for. This is one of the best courses I have taken at Princeton!
Do the readings, take good notes, and go to all the lectures. It's all worth it.
Fantastic class. Don't expect to interact with the professor too much even if you're in his precept--he's super friendly but also a pretty busy guy.
Favorite course at princeton!
Go to lecture
I initially had reservations because I was concerned about the workload, but I have no regrets because it wasn't too bad and I learned so much. Take this course!
In addition to learning about foreign policy, you get a good overview of modern Chinese history. Lectures are good but readings are dense and history-focused.
Learned a lot in this course. If you're at all interested in China, take it.
Not easy but worth it
Professor Christensen is an amazing lecturer and very knowledgeable. The class is difficult but worth it if you like foreign policy
TAKE IT. YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT. 9AM is so worth it for Professor Christensen.

TAKE THIS COURSE! A really good course if you're even slightly interesting in China, the US, or politics. Very interesting, and Professor Christensen is actually amazing. He knows everything, and he's a fantastic lecturer.
Take it. you learn a lot.

Take this class! If you are a little interested in getting a better sense of China's history with other nations and China's foreign policy now, take this class. If you are not a morning person, record the lectures. But be warned there is a lot of reading. Do try to go to lecture. They are very helpful.

Take this course! Try to take an audio recording of lecture for your own academic purposes (Prof. Christensen doesn't really want what he says shared, so really, do it solely because his lectures are a little hard to follow and don't go around sharing your recordings), take scant notes during lecture (it's at 9am, and you WILL miss something if you don't), and then go back and fill in things you missed. (Either do that, or have a friend you can compare notes with) Professor Christensen's comments are worth getting down in your notes, even if that means having to spend another 1-2 hours outside of class getting yourself organized.

The readings for this course are EXTENSIVE, but if you put in the time you will emerge from the class having a working knowledge of Chinese foreign relations. I personally feel that I can finally have an educated conversation with people about China's future in the world. Professor Christensen is also one of the coolest professors I've met on campus. Whether you're just interested or looking for a rec, take this class (if you have the time).
This class will be helpful for students who are interested in china's foreign relations and domestic politics. It is recommended that you form a reading group to deal with the readings.

This has been, bar none, my favorite course at Princeton so far. It was definitely worth waking up twice a week at 9am for. Professor Christensen is an expert in the field, and taking a class with him is a real treat. He is an amazing lecturer, and presents the material in an accessible and interesting way. Professor Christensen, though he seems intimidating and intense, is also one of the nicest professors here. Definitely sign up for office hour slots. They fill up fast, but he's so willing to talk and meet up with students (even willing to open up time if you're desperate to meet with him), and I wish I had taken advantage of them earlier in the semester. There aren't a lot of China courses at Princeton outside the EAS department, and this one is fantastic. Professor Christensen has been teaching the course for a long time, and he's really one of Princeton's best. It's definitely difficult; he expects a lot, and the reading load is intense, but if you're interested at all in China, this is the course you want to take.

This is a solid course, particularly if you're interested in modern Asia or foreign relations. A ton of reading, but you don't need to do all of it. Probably a good idea to try to get into Christensen's precept.
Very tough, but great course
Worth the 9 AM class. Seriously. Christensen is great and it gives you a new perspective on U.S.-China relations. A must take for anyone who is even vaguely interested in the area.
join a study group and share readings
descrip: This course will review and analyze the foreign policy of the People's Republic of China from 1949 to the present. It will examine Beijing's relations with the Soviet Union, the United States, Northeast Asia, Southeast Asia, and the Third World during the Cold War, and will discuss the future of Chinese foreign policy in light of the end of the Cold War, changes in the Chinese economy, the post-Tiananmen legitimacy crisis in Beijing, and the continuing rise of Chinese power and influence in Asia and beyond.

title: Morals and Markets
reviews: Absolutely do not take this course.
Good, nice class. Recommended.

Interesting course, tackling key ethical questions that deserved their weekly three hours discussion. The discussions could get a bit lengthy at times and did not always cover the topic in a structured fashion, but the excellent readings did.
Take it, it will make you think.
The subject material is very interesting, but in order to get a lot out of the course you will have to put a lot into it.
This was a great course, though challenging at time. It is flexible in terms of work and the topics always kept me on my toes!
descrip: This class is a survey on the market. First, we examine defenses of the market emphasizing efficiency, deservingness and rights. Second we ask what the scope of the market should be across goods. Are there some goods that should not be traded? Third, we look at whether the market ought to be conditioned so as to limit inequality or poverty and insure opportunity. Finally, we examine putative rights and duties within markets, such as the duty of consumers to purchase fair trade goods, and the right of workers against exploitation. Authors covered include Nozick, Elizabeth Anderson, Sen, Sandel, G.A. Cohen and Jonathan Wolff.

title: Computer Architecture
reviews: I recommend this course to whoever are still interested in computer architecture after they take introductory level architecture courses.

If you are a CS guy, you will probably like this course... Most of the questions in the class are more like the ones in operating system... Therefore, you better equipped good CS knowledge to get a good grade...
Take it! You will learn SO much about what goes on underneath the hood to make a computer tick, and the labs are very rewarding.

Take this class if you are interested in the field of computer architecture, and you want to work on meaningful projects. The assignments can be extremely time intensive at times, but the material is very interesting, and you'll learn much about how a modern processor actually works.
This material is rarely offered at any university. Taking this class is a great opportunity.
Yes if they are looking for a system level understanding on the architecture.
prereqs: Permission of Instructor or ELE 375 or (COS 375 or its equivalent). Seniors and graduate students may waive prerequisites with instructor's permission..
descrip: Modern computer processor architecture. I/O Architecture. Instruction-set architecture and high-performance processor organization including pipelining and data and instruction parallelism. Cache, memory, and storage architectures. Multiprocessors and multicore processors. Coherent caches. Interconnection and network infrastructures.

title: Theoretical Machine Learning
reviews: 120% recommended but note: do your homework carefully.
Don't hesitate
Enjoy! Simple solutions work the best.
Great course.
Hard to comment given that it probably won't be with Schapire, but this course was fantastic.
I strongly recommend this class and all other classes taught by the professor.
I would recommend it to students interested in this area.
I would recommend this course.
If you are interested in understanding the basics of ML then this is a very good course for you.
If you want to do research in applied science, it's a wise choice to take it.
If you're interested in machine learning, don't think twice and just take it. The content is very theoretical, but you'll get a chance to implement practical algorithms as a final project
Must take it, if it is still offered (by Rob) next year.
N/A
Only take this course if you have to.
Students studying TCS or interested in ML should definitely take this class.
Take it - it's hard, but an awesome overview over a lot of ideas with appropriate depth.
The course is a good start if you would like to learn machine learning theory.

This course provides a useful theoretical framework to understand machine learning (error bounds, over-fitting, online vs. batch learning etc.) and also teaches many useful machine learning algorithms for classification and regression (of course, including AdaBoost). Excellent combination with COS 424 (which covers very different types of algorithms and is more "applied"). Lectures are well organized and clearly presented. Homework problems are very theoretical (no programming involved).

if the class is offered again definitely take it if interested in research involving the subject and not only. the workload is not too bad and you can really focus on understanding the concepts rather than being stressed about getting things done. make sure you get the most out of the interaction with the instructor which, despite his stellar accomplishments, is one of the most kindest and thoughtful teachers I've ever had.
take it if Prof. Schapire is taking it.
descrip: Introduction to theoretical machine learning, including mathematical models of machine learning, and the design and rigorous analysis of learning algorithms. Likely topics include: bounds on the number of random examples needed to learn; learning from non-random examples in the on-line learning model; how to boost the accuracy of a weak learning algorithm; support-vector machines; maximum-entropy modeling; portfolio selection; game theory. Regular problem sets and final project. Attendance expected at all lectures.

title: Seminar in Romance Linguistics and/or Literary Theory - Levinas and Blanchot
descrip: A seminar on the work of Emmanuel Levinas and Maurice Blanchot, following the development, from a common origin in German phenomenology, of the ethics and the aethetics for which they are respectively well known.

title: Into the Wild
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to the Evolution of Jazz Styles
reviews: Although it says you do not need a music background it would definitely help so I would recommend it if you know a bit about reading music and musical forms.

Interesting class and you will emerge having a good understanding of the history of jazz and a bit about racial relations as well. It could be a good fifth class, if it is your fourth class you might be bored in your semester because there isn't much work in this course at all.
It's a nice LA to take that isn't too heavy on reading and writing. You don't need to study extensively however if you aren't interested at all in jazz you probably won't enjoy the course
Take it!
Take it, it was a favorite of mine.
descrip: An introductory survey examining the historical development of jazz from its African origins through the present. The course will place an emphasis on the acquisition of listening skills and will explore related musical and social issues.

title: Statistics for Social Science
reviews: A fine course. Not at all as bad as people say it is.
Do all the problem sets, read the book before starting them.
Don't do it.
Don't take it unless you really need to.
Easy stats course if Kolesar teaches it again, although lectures are boring and not helpful.  Way easier than it has been in years past.
Find a study group right away and ask the preceptor questions after every lecture. At the end, questions pile up, and one can be overwhelmed.

For students not geared towards math and more politics/history oriented, I would recommend this course if one is in need of a stats pre-req. However, you have to make sure to take the time to understand how to apply the theory to the problem sets and exams and real life.
Go to McGraw Study Hours and to Professor Kolesar's office hours! Both were very helpful to me.
Go to lecture!
Good stats course for WWS
I would say you should definitely make it a point to visit office hours and pay attention in lecture. Also, McGraw is a lifesaver.

I would take a different course if I could. This is not a very clearly taught class and is painful to get through each week because of the long problem sets. Other stats classes are easier I've heard.
If you are doing Woodrow Wilson, I would take it. Otherwise, it is a LOT of work for an elective. You cannot PDF it, so really only take it if you have to.
If you need to take it for WWS, take this course. If not, try to take another statistics course.
If you took AP stats and don't need to take this course for the WWS prereq, don't take it.
It is a rather difficult course and I had a lot of trouble following Professor Kolesar, I would recommend taking Pol Stats or another stats class to fulfill the requirement.
It seems like no matter who you get for statistics, they will be a bad teacher but definitely do your best to stay away from Kolesar.
It's fairly easy if you focus on how the problems will be asked.
It's introductory statistics to fulfill the WWS requirement, not horribly painful but not very engaging
Its a struggle to wake up for this 9 am class.
Only take if you must. The material is not difficult, but it's taught extremely poorly. I only did well because of previous stats knowledge, didn't really learn anything at all in this course.

Originally, the final exam was supposed to be a take-home, but after WWS decided to have Michal teach the course, it somehow became an actual sit-down final.  For statistics in general, in which you already have a cheat sheet for the exam, it makes no sense to cram so much material in 2 50 minute midterms where they do not give any indication of your letter grade throughout the course anyways after the fact...  

Hardly anyone showed up for class, I was one of the few that attended lecture.  Problem sets in beginning of term would take too long to complete.

This course needs to be revamped and restructured for future years, but I would recommend it over a memorization class like ECO 202 for a stats rec.
Run as far from this course as you can get. If you're a Woody Woo major i'm so sorry. Good luck getting through it.
Seek help and do all the problem sets!

Shop around because there are a bunch of different options to fulfill the statistics requirement -- this one will be one of the easier ones but if you are looking to really understand statistics and prepare for your independent work, this probably isn't the course for you.
Take ECO stats instead, I regret taking this. I feel as if I learned nothing
Take if you need to
Take it if you have to. I feel like taking WWS 200 is better than taking ORF or ECO stats
Take only if you need stats requirement for woody woo. I don't regret taking it for my stats but hard, boring, painful course.
The readings are really helpful.
The textbook was an excellent supplement to the lectures and should be read religiously.

This course has immense potential for improvement. Prof seems sincerely committed to the class and you can tell that he is trying his best to teach the material. I guess it's his first year teaching at Princeton so we should give him some leeway in terms of the consistency of his lecture quality. I would have to say his lectures got progressively better and his notes helped a lot. There were some bumps here and there but this class seems infinitely better than what it used to be before Kolesar came.
This course is very easy if you have taken AP Stats or are good at math and programming, but it's very well run and a good refresher before your independent work.
This is a decent way to get your QA dist requirement and fulfill your Woody Woo pre-req.

This was one of the worst classes I have ever taken. It's not tough material, but I learned everything from the textbook and Khan Academy. The lectures are completely useless and the final exam was unfair. The upside is that problem sets are worth 30%.

Unless you already took stats and COS courses before (here or in high school), be prepared for a long uphill battle. Consider another stats course if you have to take one, preferably one that is PDFable.
Yep
You have to take it. Suck it up kiddos.
You have to take something like this for WWS, and I don't think any of the other statistics classes are much better than this. Still, don't expect to enjoy this class.

You might have heard horrible rumors about WWS Stats. I had heard them too before taking the course. If you take the class with Kolesar, the rumors are not true. It's not an easy class, but it's not ridiculously difficult. The grading and the teaching are both fair. And even if you don't like Kolesar's teaching style, you can learn everything from the book.
do the reading.
eh..
descrip: The course will consist of a brief introduction to probability theory as well as various topics in statistics and how they can be used in the public policy realm. Subject areas will include random variables, sampling, descriptive statistics, distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, and introduction to the regression model. The data sources will be actual examples taken from the public policy realm. R, a general purpose statistical programming package will be used to perform the statistical analysis.

title: Corporate Finance and Financial Institutions
reviews: As on ORFE i havnt been to single class (lecture or precept) or bought the text book and I have an A .   pretty easy.
Consider that it is a bit theoretical.

Don't take it.  Just do ECO 362 and then get out.  The material is literally exactly the same, you won't get anything new out of it.  Also be careful on the exams - they are basically like tabulating checks and small arithmetic mistakes on your calculators will really hurt you when the averages are so high.
Don't.
Dont take if not doing finance certificate
I would recommend this course with Professor Shin.
I would take this class. It is useful and interesting.
If interested in finance take this class, although this class made me realize I didn't really like finance.
If you are getting the certificate or really interested in finance, take this course.
If you're working in finance already, don't bother.
It is what has always been.
It was really boring, but you might learn a few worthwhile things.
Keep up with the lectures.
Learn the material on your own in two weeks and save a year of boring classes.
Most of the content is pretty interesting, regardless of your major.
Not a substantial amount of work, reflected by low variation in grades.
Not too much work
Not well taught, hopefully it will get better.  If you are taking it though, I probably can't dissuade you.  On the other hand, it is pretty easy.
Only take for finance certificate. Otherwise you are wasting your time. Too much "plug and chug".
Only take this course if you absolutely need the Finance certificate. Not really worth it at all. But it's better than ECO 362, at least.
Pretty straightforward course. Take it if your interested in finance/want to work in IBD.
Professor Shin is a great lecturer and presents the material very well. Workload is pretty manageable.
Professor Shin is a great professor who covers the material in-depth.  Just be wary of taking it as a 3-hour lecture starting at 7:30 PM.
Recommend if you're interested in finance - the course will help you understand financial concepts which it's good to be familiar with for life.

TAKE THIS COURSE. Especially if it is with professor Shin. The 3-hour lecture may seem tough, but professor shin is a fantastic lecturer, extremely intelligent, and explain all the concepts very clearly, and the 3-hour lecture really isn't bad at all. I can clearly see the real-life applications of the methods/materials that I learnt in the course. It is extremely useful, regardless if you want to work in finance or not. I think everyone should take this course, to get an understanding of basic accountancy, financial planning, and financial skills that will be useful in almost every industry/profession.
Also you don't need ECO 362/310,etc. to take this. I didn't, and did just fine on the course, and learnt a huge amount. Just enroll on SCORE. You won't regret it.
Take it if you have to, or if you want to be an IBanker
Take it if you like finance.
Take it if you need it for the finance certificate. If you want to learn accounting and can't force yourself to do it on your own, this is a good option as well.
Take it if you need to or if you think it will be helpful for work.
Take it only if it is taught in lectures twice a week. Tuesday night lectures are brutal.
Take the course if you are thinking of working in finance or its detailed practical implications. If not, there are other Econ courses that will give you a better overview of the industry.

Take the course if you want the finance certificate. Don't go out of your way to take this course. If you are going into banking, I would actually recommend taking this course after you've completed your summer internship.
Take the course!
Take this course if you need it for a requirement or if you want to learn how companies make financial decisions.
Take this course. Really helpful preparing you for stuff you need to know walking into the world of finance.
The class is good if not at night for 3 hours.
The class is useful and discusses some interesting material about finance.
The material is super practical but I learnt everything directly from the slides. I wouldn't go to lecture unless you learn better by hearing the material spoken out loud.
This class was a 3-hour long lecture--too long.
This course was very basic. It moved slowly, so it is an easy 5th/6th class.
We didn't learn too much this semester, but I assume with a different professor you would. Pretty interesting course.

We had one three-hour lecture with Shin on Tuesday nights.  That alone probably detracted significantly from the course, making it difficult to maintain focus.  The material itself was not incredibly interesting, but often fairly practical and made a good contribution to my understanding of how things work.

You do this because finance. Actually the material covered is quite important, all about how to value companies. Especially if I-Banking beckons, you need to get a good understanding of the material. I personally found it very boring. Didn't help that the class was at the worst time.
You have to take it if you want a finance cert. What can I say?
go to lectures and precepts as much as you can
it's a strugg but probably worth it for your future.
take if you're going to work at an ibank or need it for the certificate. Unfortunately, I don't have much to say because I knew the majority of the material prior to taking the class
take it if you want to go into finance, if not, you might be bored by some of the technicalities
prereqs: ECO 310 and ECO 362.
descrip: This course investigates the financing decisions of companies and financial institutions in the wider context of the workings of financial markets. Topics include capital budgeting, capital structure choice, risk management, liquidity, corporate governance, and the interactions between corporate finance and the workings of financial institutions and markets.

title: Moby-Dick Unbound
descrip: See website

title: Elementary Persian II
reviews: Amineh is always wonderful, and an excellent teacher. I don't think I can recommend this enough - take Persian! You'll love it.

Come to every class, be engaged while in class, and make sure to study vocab independently at home, since that really helps you participate effectively in class. I recommend the class with no reservations.
Highly reccomend - if you're considering a Near Eastern language, Persian is the way to go. It's rewarding, relatively easy, and Amineh is a phenomenal person and professor.
If you want to begin learning Persian, this is the course for you!

If you work hard, you will learn a lot (which is kind of common sense). However, as a graduate student, you have to be prepared to invest a lot of time and energy in this class. Doing this parallel to general exams might not be such a great idea, because it will inevitably collide with your other commitments.
Take this class asap. Spend enough time on the homeworks, and if you have nay questions, ask asap.
The sequence of Elementary Persian classes are extremely beneficial when taken with Professor Mahallati. I strongly recommend them!
prereqs: PER 101 or permission of instructor..
descrip: To develop the skills of understanding, speaking, reading and writing modern Persian. The classes are conducted mostly in Persian with emphasis on oral drills and conversations.

title: The Other Side of Rome
reviews: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS
Do the reading, and try to think of how to connect all the weeks together into one Roman culture.
Do the readings. Take notes on them and write little summaries of them b/c it will be hard to keep track of names and figures when studying for the tests.
Great distribution requirement

I would advise them not to take it. It has a lot of potential as a course, but the weekly quizzes were unnecessarily time consuming. If they restructure the quizzes to essays or something similar, then I would definitely recommend.
I would definitely recommend taking this course.
I'd recommend being interested in Rome. That would probably help you. Maybe.
If you want a roman history class, take something else since this only presents certain particular elements of roman life.
If you're looking for a relatively easy EM that doesn't require much work
If you've taken CLA classes before, you could probably find a better class on Rome, but if you just want an overview of Roman culture this is a decent choice.
Interesting "other side of Rome"! Really consider if you want to see some dirty things Romans were into!
Just don't. Worst class you can take to fulfill your EM.
Make sure you do the readings every week, not just for the quizzes but so that you have a good understanding of the materials covered when it comes to the midterm and the final.
Take it if you're looking for a relatively easy EM, but do the reading because there are weekly quizzes on it.
Take it with a different professor.
This class is good for fulfilling an EM but I would not take it otherwise.
This course is great if you have any interest in Rome. The professor and preceptors are wonderful and the work is rewarding in terms of the amount of effort you put in and what you get out of it.

This course is interesting and precepts are varied so that you do lots of learning sometimes and do fun stuff other times. I don't recommend taking this course for a grade unless you have enough time to commit towards the readings since they are pretty important for a good understanding of the materials. Nevertheless, the lectures are interesting and the course overall is great.

This is a good course if you're interested in the specifics of Ancient Roman culture and daily life. I would not recommend it if you're afraid of some technical details. The workload is never too oppressive.

This was the first year this teacher has taught this so I feel like I have to cut him a little slack, but overall I didn't like this course. If you do take this, make sure you really prepare for precept, and are super careful not to make mistakes on the online quizzes.
Yes, if you are really interested in Roman law and education.
dont take
fun class, good EM
descrip: An introduction to Roman culture designed to complicate the traditional images of Romans both as sober, unimaginative pragmatists and as unrestrained hedonists. We will begin by denaturalizing the idea of "being Roman" by examining Roman struggles to educate and socialize their own youth. Then we will look at a variety of topics in three broad areas (law, infrastructure, and systems of values), stressing the contradictions within the culture, even/especially as experienced by the Romans themselves. The internal diversity of Roman culture will be illustrated by reading a wide variety of primary and secondary sources.

title: Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics Simulation in Statistical Physics & Materials Science
reviews: If you are interested in MD and MC simulations and have a little bit of experience in QM and CM, than this course is  very good.
Recognize that this takes a lot of time, especially if you want to get out all that you can.
With a decent background in thermodynamics and coding you will love this course.
strongly recommend.
descrip: This course examines methods for simulating matter at the atomistic scale with emphasis on the concepts that underline modern computational methodologies for classical many-body systems at or near statistical equilibrium. The course covers Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics (from basics to advanced techniques).

title: Health Economics I
prereqs: Prerequisites: PhD-level microeconomics and econometrics..
descrip: Examines health issues in both developed and developing countries. Specific topics include the evolution of health over the life course; the fetal origins hypothesis; the two-way links between socioeconomic status and health; the impact of social safety nets on health outcomes; environmental threats to children's health and development; health insurance and its effects on health; the industrial organization of health care delivery; and the relationship between health and economic growth.

title: Regression and Applied Time Series
prereqs: ORF 245 and MAT 202.
descrip: Regression: linear, nonlinear, nonparametric. Quantile regression. Time series: classical linear models, univariate and multivariate; elements of spectral analysis; stochastic volatility models (ARCH, GARCH, ....); dynamic factor models

title: Neuroscience of Social Cognition and Emotion
reviews: Be engaged!! you will learn so much. It is a three hour class but if you immerse yourself into the material the time will fly by. do not go on facebook or youtube, really be present in the class and you will gain a deeper understanding (e.g. " increase your brain-to-brain coupling" with the professor) - take the course to figure out what this means and so much more!!

If you are looking for a course that will stimulate your mind at a leisurely pace AND help you meet your psych and neuro reqs, this is it. But you've got to do the readings to appreciate the class though.
Pay attention during lecture! Take notes. Also talk to the Professor regarding how weekly papers are going.

TAKE THIS. Taking this class with Prof. Hasson is like taking a course in quantum mechanics taught by Schrodinger. There's no better person to learn about the field of social neuroscience than from one of its leaders. This class will really change your perspective on neuroscience research and push you to approach the subject in a way that you've never encountered before. Take it, take it, take it.
Take it if you're interested and willing to get used to an accent.
Take it! Very interesting. Doesn't feel like it lasts 3 hours. Minimal work.
Take the course if you're interested in the subject.
This class will make you a better scientist and will teach you to really read science critically. If that's a skill you'd like to acquire, this course is for you.
This is an extremely interesting and intellectually stimulating class with a manageable amount of work. Take it!
prereqs: PSY 258.
descrip: This course explores the neural foundations of social cognition and social emotions. The objective is to provide a comprehensive overview of research topics relevant to the emerging field of social neuroscience. We will also discuss questions that cut across the specific topics that will be covered. Do neural systems exist that are specialized for social cognition or do the systems that participate in social cognition have more general cognitive functions? Can neuroscientific research shed new light on social cognition? How can different disciplines in neuroscience and the social sciences contribute to social neuroscience research?

title: Contemporary Issues in Spain and/or Latin America
reviews: Be ready to be engaged.
Go to office hours, discuss material outside of class before class begins.
Start the papers early and don't be afraid to ask help from German, he is extremely helpful.

The work can get heavy at times, but it is an enjoyable class and a decent opportunity to practice Spanish. You mostly watch movies and documentaries, which is by far the most fun way to learn about Spain, Franco's dictatorship, and the recent/current economic crisis (as well as its socio-political consequences).

This course is a fair amount of work; you watch at least one full length movie for every class and sometimes there are a lot of accompanying materials. However, if you put in the effort to understanding them, you can really learn a lot from the class discussions.
great introduction to the higher level spanish courses at princeton and helps to develop your ability with the language
prereqs: SPA 207 or 209, or instructor's permission.
descrip: What was happening in Spain during the last ten years of huge changes and quixotesque overdevelopment? What is happening today after the 2007 crisis and with the 15-M movement in the streets calling for "real democracy"? Using films and documentaries (and various materials: newspaper articles, YouTube clips, images, graffiti and hip-hop lyrics, reports, etc), we will study topics such as historical memory, emigration, multiculturalism, gender identities, traditions, urban struggles, urban cultures, social movements. Those who are planning to apply for the Princeton-in-Spain program will find this course to be a fantastic passport.

title: Religion and Culture Workshop
prereqs: REL 521.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop devoted to the critical discussion of research in progress in the ethnographic, historical, and normative study of religion and culture. Designed for dissertation writers receiving fellowships from the Center for the Study of Religion and post-doctoral fellows.

title: Introduction to Architectural Design
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of work on your own.

Be prepared to think creatively and explore the options available to you in the architecture building, like the modelling software and the woodworking shop. Come to each class with work you've done from the past couple days so you can get feedback from the instructors, as they are your best resource. I'd recommend this course if you're genuinely interested in architecture and are willing to work hard. You won't get much out of this course if you don't put the effort in.
Definitely take this if you're interested in architecture. Be prepared for some independent learning though and be sure to budget the time you spend on projects.
Don't get paranoid that you have to fully finish everything; drawings, model etc, just work on having a nice and clear presentation that represents your idea- and then stop and go to bed.
Don't take this course as a freshman. Take it only if you're sure you want to concentrate in Architecture, after having taken a couple of other courses in the department.
If you are in ARC or CEE, this is a course that you really need to take. You might not like it, but you should still take it.
If you like design and are actually considering architecture as a major take it, otherwise it would be too time consuming just to take for fun.

Take it if you're highly interested in architecture (ie. arch or civ-arc majors)! You get what you put into it. Expect to be challenged and to hit creative blocks. Also expect all-nighters, especially if you don't tend to focus and just get work done efficiently. Don't be afraid to experiment or to do something crazy. Also - your peers are your best resource. Ask them and the  arch juniors/seniors/grad students for feedback and software help. If you're reading this over summer, learn Rhino. And possibly Illustrator.
Take it if you're interested in architecture! It's a lot of work and a lot of late nights, but well worth it!
The projects take a lot of time, start early! Otherwise very fun and you get to do interesting projects
This class was VERY time-consuming, but FUN. I strongly recommend taking it if you are CivArc.

This is a challenging but rewarding course. Be prepared to put in a lot of hours - you can definitely skim by doing half-hearted projects, but it's so much more rewarding if you finish the class with work that you're proud of.
bro
only take this course if you are willing to devote a huge chunk of your time to it, otherwise it will not be fun/successful
prereqs: ARC 204 is a prerequisite for entry into the departmental concentration. Students will be expected to purchase materials in order to carry out various assignments..
descrip: The first in a series of design studios offered to students interested in majoring in architecture. The course will introduce architecture as an "impure'' plastic art, inseparable from a network of forces acting upon it. The student will be confronted with progressively complex exercises involving spatial relations in two dimensions, three dimensions, and time. The course will stress experimentation while providing an analytical and creative framework to develop an understanding of structure and materials as well as necessary skills in drawing and model making. Two three-hour studios with lectures included.

title: Topics in the Formal Analysis of the Urban Structure - American Urbanism
reviews: Good course if you are interested in urbanism and/or planning!
great seminar with project work
descrip: The American city has undergone a number of restructurings since colonial times. However, the mutations that occurred at the beginning and in the middle of the twentieth century not only restructured the city but also dramatically changed its configuration in a radical way. We might be living a similar situation today at the beginning of a new century, when changes as powerful as the sub-urbanization of the 1950's are generating new configurations of urban space and form that are expanding once more the definition of the city and urban culture.

title: Research Methods in Political Science
reviews: Prof is alright but the material sucks a fat one. Hope you like stats
Take it if you don't want to program in R and you're more interested in statistical research in a conceptual sense rather than an applied one.

This is not a particularly exciting course, but it is a good way to fulfill the analytical requirement for the Politics department. Kastellec explains the concepts very clearly, is patient, and answers questions helpfully. This is not a fun or exciting class, but it is a useful one, and is pretty well taught.
nothing
descrip: This is the introductory undergraduate course in research methods for Politics majors, designed to help prepare students for junior papers and the senior thesis. The material is chosen to convey an understanding of research design, choice of methods, and analysis. Both qualitative and quantitative methods will be taught, including some statistics. However, this is not primarily a statistics course, and the material is different from what a statistics class or qualitative research class would teach. Rather, it is an introduction to a range of research methodologies as they are applied to political science topics.

title: Comparative Ethnicity, Nationalism, and Race I (Half-Term)
descrip: The course is based on the assumption that ethnicity, race, and nation belong to a broad family of forms of cultural understanding, social organization, and political contestation, all related to perceived similarities and differences of cultural background, social belonging, and political destiny. We devote a week to each of five broad theoretical and empirical approaches, emphasizing (1) political modernization and state-building; (2) economic competition and uneven development; (3) the construction of boundaries, categories, and identities; (4) rational choice and micro-mechanisms; (5) sociobiological or psychological roots.

title: Advanced General Chemistry: Honors Course
reviews: Definitely take it!

Do the readings. Go to precept. Go to lecture. There's a large range of students there with differing abilities so know what works for you and where you are to maximize the benefits of the course. Don't suffer through early morning lectures if you've got a good handle on things, but don't entirely eschew lectures. Go to the ones on topics you have difficulty with but you'll be fine if you don't go for the ones you think you know. Also really nice to get Chemistry done with in one semester, especially if you have previous experience, definitely recommend over the two-semester sequence.
Don't take this course lightly. I made the mistake of overlooking it because I did so well in college. I think this class can be an easy A if you just stay on top of your work.
GO.TO.CLASS.
I would definitely find other students to do the problem sets with. And if Jim White is the preceptor, always go to him for help.
I would recommend reading the chapter, doing practice problems, and pay close attention in precept. Do NOT feel afraid to ask questions, all the chemistry 215 staff is uber friendly!
Not too bad. Better to take 1 semester of this rather than the year long gen chem if you have the prereqs.
Only take it if you are ready for a fast class where you often don't get too much help.
Only take this course if you are willing to put in A LOT of work and feel solid about your knowledge of chemistry from high school.

Only take this course if you know and remember AP Chem. The lecturer was awful, if it's Bernasek again, there's no point in going to lecture. You'll get good info from precept, but there's only 1 per week. So, essentially, you have to know already and review on your own with the book, and then be tested on it.

Take it. If you have any interest in chemistry then this is your class. It's structured nicely, everyone is super helpful because it is a small class and it's a great overview of chemistry. I would definitely recommend it.
Take this course if you want to fulfill a chemistry pre-req or pre-med requirement in one semester. Otherwise, seems like a better choice to go the 201/202 route.

Take this course over 201/202! It's fast, it's furious, and it's a great way to learn your general chemistry. The TA's, however, will not be the same in future semesters, and I found that James Pander and Jim White were the most fun parts of the course.
The class definitely assumes that you have previous exposure to chemistry. If you have had exposure to chemistry before, this is much better than the 201/202 sequence.

This class is very difficult, but do-able.  If you take this course, you will definitely need to do the problem sets and study a lot for the exams.  Also, going in to talk to Professor Bernasek is very useful.

This class is worth taking if you just want to get general chemistry over with and one semester. You should be very comfortable with the material beforehand if you want to do well in the class: i.e. you should have taken AP chem either Junior or Senior year in high school. If you have seen all of the material before it will be easy to keep up with the fast pace of the course. While the material is not more challenging then the CHM 201/202 sequence, there will be a LOT of material covered on all of the exams, especially the final, so leave time to study. Lectures were basically useless in my opinion, precept and and the problem sets were much more integral in teaching the material. Bernasek is not a fantastic lecturer, he just was not engaging and the lecture material did not really match the exam material. Also, we did not receive any practice problems or past exams before any of the exams, as per Bernasek's choice, so be sure to do a lot of self-prep, including attending the review sessions. All and all, if you are comfortable with gen chem you should take this course over the CHM 201/202 sequence because a) you get gen chem over with in one semester and b) the curve is pretty forgiving, so if you keep on top of your work you can very easily get an A-/B .
it doesn't get 'turbo' until the last half of the class, but it's definitely a fair class that moves at an appropriate pace for students who took ap chem in high school
read the textbook
prereqs: NOT open to students who have completed CHM 201 or CHM 207. Prerequisite consists of excellent high school preparation AND placement into the course by the Chemistry Department. Please contact Dr. Robert L'Esperance, rpl@princeton.edu, for all changes in class and lab sections after the completion of registration {OR} to add CHM 215 {OR} to be added to a waiting list for closed class or lab sections..
descrip: Selected topics from general chemistry are presented from an advanced point of view. Emphasis is on the conceptual development of electronic structure and bonding, on applications of thermodynamics to chemical equilibrium, and on kinetics. A unified approach to molecular science is developed. The course is intended for serious students of science or engineering.

title: Seminar in Italian Literature and Culture - Economic Politics and Organized Crime
reviews: Definitely take it.
I would definitely recommend this course to all students interested in learning about organized crime. The amount of reading was by no means overwhelming and the readings were quite interesting.
If this class ever comes back to Princeton, definitely take it. Saviano is a living legend and you don't want to miss this opportunity.
If you are looking to learn more about criminal organizations and their economics, there is no one better to teach you.

If you have the chance to take this class with Roberto Saviano do so. It will be the best class you will ever take. My only negative about this seminar was that it only met once a week for 3 hours. I could have listened to his stories for hours every day and never gotten bored.
Take it if you have very good Italian and any interest at all in the global economy / Italy.
Take it!
Take it! Read his books! Get to know him!
Take this course. Learn how mafia influences governments and private companies. You won't regret it.
prereqs: 200-level Italian course and permission of instructor. Application to be sent to marrone@Princeton.EDU.
descrip: This seminar explores how the media describes criminal organizations and their social and political role. Focus on topics such as journalism and mafia; mafia culture and the power of symbols; cocaine, the white gold; stories of writers sentenced to death by the cartels.

title: Intermediate Hindi II
reviews: I would recommend that students really try to keep up with the material and come prepared to class having read the material. If you come prepared, class is extremely interesting and discussion with Robert and your classmates is extremely stimulating and a great way to really improve your speaking skills!
Lots of fun! Great assignments, cool people!
prereqs: HIN105 or the equivalent level of proficiency.
descrip: Continuing from HIN 105, this course provides training in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Students will attain the ability to read and understand texts in Hindi on familiar topics, to speak with other Hindi speakers in a wide range of common situations, to write concise texts expressing thoughts and views, and acquire general familiarity with the cultural context(s) in which Hindi is used. Students will have exposure to the cultural contexts of South Asia through multimedia resources, and will engage in interactive and collaborative task-based activities in the classroom.

title: Physics of Nonneutral Plasmas
reviews: I would tell them to start reading Holm's book right away, perhaps even before taking the course. If you can stay on top of that material, the course makes a lot more sense.
It's a very good as well as very changeling course.

The value a student extracts from this course will be strongly dependent on their level of interest in this material. If a more mathematical approach to physics is interesting, this offers an insight which would otherwise take many more hours to gain from more basic references. If the student is primarily interested in immediately applicable plasma physics, they may lack the motivation to invest time in this course.
This is a really hard course. A lot of work must be put into it in order to really understand all the material. I definitely advise not to take the course before generals.
descrip: The course provides an introduction to the dynamics of nonneutral plasmas and charged particles with intense self fields. Topics include: nonlinear stability and confinement theorems, collective waves and instabilities, and nonlinear processes in high-intensity periodic-focussing accelerators. The modern geometric and field-theoretical methods for plasma and charged particle dynamics are introduced, including topics such as non-canonical Hamiltonian dynamics, symmetry group analysis, Lie perturbations, symplectic reduction, symplectic integrator, and the discrete exterior calculus algorithm for Maxwell's equations.

title: Law, Institutions and Public Policy
reviews:
1) Attend ALL the lectures. The test comes from them. 
2) Find a study group
Good course
Great class if you're interested in law and theory/practice! Professor Starr is awesome - super knowledgeable and nice.  Highly recommend!

I loved this course. It is reading intensive, but not work intensive. You will learn a great deal about many different things, but, more importantly, a framework which you could use to approach virtually anything in life. The lectures were great, insightful, and filled with brief historical anecdotes that I could not fathom acquiring another way.
I recommend the class. Hopefully Starr changes up his lectures a little bit to follow some sort of structure but overall it was a good class

I would definitely recommend taking the course, regardless of your department. Don't be intimidated if you feel that you do not have a substantial background in the topic---Prof. Starr was very available, and he will be more than happy to meet with you one-on-one

I would strongly recommend this course, as it really does present an opportunity to learn about nearly every single major issue of public policy in modern times and learn more about the institutions at work in each of those topics.
I would suggest printing out the Look-for-listen-for lists before doing each reading. These lists were very helpful.

If you don't have an interest in law and institutions, this class sounds dry but based on the amount of effort you put in, it can be very interesting. Go to every lecture because there are no powepoint slides to help during finals.
Take it! Especially if you have any vague interest in law.
Take this course! This is one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton -- it covers a ton of interesting and relevant topics. There's a lot of reading but it's worth it!

This course provides a unique perspective on the development of institutions of government. You will need to adjust your perspective in order to understand where the Professor is coming from, but you will be left with a view that you may not normally gain access to.
absolutely take it!
yes yes yes; if you're interested in how laws and institutions influence our society, definitely take it
descrip: This course will examine how institutions develop, vary in design, and shape public policy. Law will be a primary focus because it is central to the development of institutions in modern societies and provides the formal means for expressing and fixing policy. The course will cover a wide range of institutions- social, economic, and political- not only in an American context but also in comparative perspective.

title: The Psychology of Decision Making and Judgment
reviews: A good, solid course. Maybe not as mind-blowing as some of the other reviews will have you think. Requires a lot of time knowing the details of the reading, which is frustrating because each reading repeats the same concepts in slightly altered ways. While much of the course feels obvious, it is interesting to think about how little of it you knew before having it explicitly pointed out, and probably will allow for more educated and critical decision-making later in life.
A lot of reading, but an interesting course with a great professor.
A meh course to take. Midterm was too long and assignments are arbitrarily graded and economists are strawmanned, but it's worth taking for the knowledge.
An interesting class and you learn a lot of fun facts, but its difficult at times to find uniting threads between the material.

At the beginning of the semester, I was really excited about this class -- I'd never taken psychology before, but it seemed pretty interesting (and relevant if you're WWS). Unfortunately, this class made us read a LOT of manipulated lab studies that bore no resemblance to the real world. Does playing Family Feud really tell us anything about how poor people make daily spending decisions? Almost certainly not. The grading is also pretty tough (read: arbitrary), and the exams are very difficult -- you have to know a lot about obscure studies we read and then don't discuss in lecture/precept. Lectures were extremely repetitive -- he reuses slides and reexplains concepts way too much. Also, this class takes a ton of jabs at traditional economics. Some of the criticisms are legitimate and interesting. I actually really enjoyed learning about prospect theory. Others are, as noted before, based on really silly methodology. But most frustrating of all was the amount of straw-manning that occurred -- a lot of attacks on "economics" turned out to be attacks on poorly understood representations of economics that few economists hold. That being said, Peter was a fantastic preceptor -- he's the reason I came out with some respect for psych, since he was willing to be critical of BS studies while pushing back on standard rational agent model criticisms.
Be in a study group. It makes all the difference.
Best EC for the robotics certificate
Content is interesting...but the class could be structured much better. Would be a good PDF class.
Definitely take the course! While the readings may be a little excessive, the lectures are engaging and the material can be applied to a ton of real-world situations.
Demanding class, hard to follow, but interesting material.
Do the readings.
Easy class for finance certificate
Fair amount of work but definitely worth it. Most interesting class I took at Princeton.
Fascinating topic.
Fascinating. Take it!
Go in for the knowledge and for the great professor.

Great course! Very practical with realistic expectations from students and very applicable to our everyday life. Go to lecture and take good notes (they helped me a lot with exams). I think that this is the kind of class that many different majors can like because it is simply about how we think and make decisions individuals. I enjoyed it a lot.
Great psych/wws course! Good taste of applied psychology. Eldar Shafir REALLY knows his stuff and is constantly making research relevant. Not an "easy A".
I strongly recommend taking this course.
If you are "engaged" in the class, then the readings and concepts won't be that bad. The class is interesting, but an above average course load.

Interesting material on how humans actually make decisions and relate to things around them, though begins to feel a bit conceptually redundant after a while. It's worth knowing and thinking about, however, so it's worth taking. Also there's not very much work and it's easy.
Interesting.  A good class to take for general knowledge.
Its a good class, but it will be helpful if you know about public policy and economics before going in.
Lots of readings, tough assessments, and strict grading, but it could not possibly be more worth it. Hands down, my favorite class at Princeton.

New and interesting if you haven't taken a psych course before.  Most interesting parts are the applications to negotiations, decision making, procrastination, etc.  Unfortunately those parts were less emphasized in the course, but you can seek them in your readings
Not as good as I thought it was going to be but still interesting
Not super interesting overall
Not worth the time and hassle.  Mostly "fun facts" about why people are inconsistent.
Only take it if you're ready to feel like your very hard work has not paid off in the least.
