Pretty cool class. Sometimes a little obvious and terminology focused but you learn some very interesting stuff about how people make consistent mistakes.
Shafir is a good lecturer and gives fair assessments. The first half of the course can be a lot of review from introductory psych concepts, but the second half is very interesting.

Solid class.  Material is very applicable and definitely changes the way you think about things when you are aware of the cognitive biases exhibited by the human mind.   Class didn't seem very well organized, though - Shafir's lecture slides were all over the place and concepts were frequently repeated/regurgitated throughout the semester.  Overall, take it.
Sounds better than it is.
Take excellent notes in class - the lecture slides are not specific enough to understand what's going on without the aid of notes.
Take it for an EC--it will be interesting and you will learn.  Not the best class ever but a little above the mean.
Take it if you like psych a lot.  It's much more a psych course than a policy course.
Take it!
Take it, but know it's harder than it seems.
Take it. You will learn many things that will amaze you.
Take the psychology of social influence.
Take this class. Not THAT easy to do well, but it is super interesting and enjoyable. If you are looking for another class, definitely do it.
Take this course! One of the only psychology classes I've taken that I can DIRECTLY relate to my life.
Take this course! So interesting, important, and practical.
Take this course.
The course is a really interesting take on the decision-making that we make every day. Any student interested in going into management would greatly benefit from taking it.

This class completely changed the way I think about thinking. The subject matter is (in my opinion) some of the most inherently interesting stuff out there. Professor Shafir's lectures can get a little disorganized, but it's not hard to pay attention because all the experiments and examples he brings up are so fascinating. So much of what we learned about comes up in daily life. Take it!!
This class is more technical that you would expect.  You learn a lot about probability and modeling decisions rather than how to make decisions.  It is still a very interesting class nonetheless.
This course covers intriguing topics that are very applicable to everyday life. Think of it as a user's guide to decision making. Tends to be a lot of work, especially for senior spring.
This course will change how you think about the world (unless you know a lot of psychology already), and that's what college is about.
This course will teach you a lot on decision-making, but you've got to attend the lectures and do the readings. Take it!
This is a very interesting course that will teach you a good deal about the psychology behind decision making. I definitely recommend it, be sure to stay on top of the readings.

This is an interesting course, and potentially very insightful, although I perhaps expected it to rock my world a little more than it did. And don't be fooled before the midterm -- do study the readings and studies.
This was a really good course.
Very competitive course, but extremely interesting.
Very good course to take as an econ departmental. Easy and interesting.
Very interesting -- take it. Not much work but you need to know the readings very well for the exams
Very interesting stuff. Shafir is a great lecturer.
Wouldn't recommend
You learn a lot of interesting things in this course but at the same time it won't be the most engaging course you take at Princeton.
difficult exams but really intriguing material
take it!
take it, especially if you want to work in public policy!
prereqs: Introductory statistics for social science or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to the logic and research findings underlying decision-making and judgment under uncertainty. The focus is on the contrast between the rational theory of judgment and choice, and the psychological principles that guide decision behavior, often producing biases and errors. Among other topics, we will consider political, medical, and financial decision-making, poverty, negotiation, and the law, along with the implications of the findings for the rational agent model typically assumed in economics, throughout the social sciences, and in policy making.

title: Beginning Studies in Acting: Scene Study
reviews: ALL OF YOU CONSIDERING THIS COURSE--TAKE IT. I started this sentence with an "A" just so it would be near the top. Tracy is amazing. I'm not a "theater person," and I enjoyed this course so much. One of the courses to take before you graduate.
Go all out!!
I cannot speak to other professors, but if you are at all interested in acting and want an introductory course, you cannot go wrong with Prof. Vasen.
I would definitely recommend this course. It is not a light workload, but the work is not that intense and it is pretty fun. I enjoyed attending the class.
It's impossible to fake your way through a monologue you're supposed to have memorized. If you can, take this class from Tracy. You will not regret it.
Let go of your fear!
Really think about your character in terms of "How do I get what I want?"
TAKE IT!
Take it if you are eager to know what acting truly is about. It is not just being able to lose yourself in front of an audience!
Take this class whether you are interested in acting or not! It's a lot of fun and Tim is a really great instructor.
Take this course!  Especially with Tim.
Take this course! Even if you are shy it will allow you to come out of your comfort zone and meet new people.

Tracy is incredible. She's bursting with enthusiasm and absolutely engaging. and she's clear and supportive if you ever have any questions. This class is undoubtedly unlike any other class you would take at Princeton "just to fill a distribution requirement." It is very involved, and it does take more time than you might think, but it is all worth it. You get to know your classmates really well, and you get to know yourself even better. Take it if you can.

What I learned in the class will not evaporate away after the finals - unlike in so many other classes. Acting is a life skill just like cooking and swimming. This will be a quest into yourself - that is, if you are willing to allow yourself to do this. And Professor Bersley is a great guide in this journey. Take it.

With Tim, just be yourself and know that you will be forced to put yourself out there and being shy and trying to get out of doing things will not work. He is a great director and professor, you just have to be willing to be yourself and do things that you might be shy or embarrassed about otherwise.
really let yourself get into the class. you will get out why you put in and the class is worth investing into.
prereqs: This course is by Open Enrollment until the first day of class. Enrollment is by permission of instructors during the first two weeks of class. For enrollment in Section 1 (Mon/Wed), please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@). For enrollment in Section 2 (Tue/Thurs), please contact Professor Tracy Bersley (tberslex@)..
descrip: An introduction to the craft of acting through scene study monologues and, finally, a longer scene drawn from a play, to develop a method of working on a script. Emphasis will be placed on honesty, spontaneity, and establishing a personal connection with the scene's substance.

title: The Evolution of Human Language
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs/ay201314/

title: Diseases in Children: Causes, Costs, and Choices
prereqs: MOL 101, MOL 214 or MOL 215.
descrip: Within a broader context of historical, social, and ethical concerns, a survey of normal childhood development and selected disorders from the perspectives of the physician and the scientist. Emphasis on the complex relationship between genetic and acquired causes of disease, medical practice, social conditions, and cultural values. The course features visits from children with some of the conditions discussed, site visits, and readings from the original medical and scientific literature.

title: Climate Science and Communications
reviews: Don't take this class if you are not interested in journalism or film production. Or if you struggle with video editing soft ware.
Great course to take, not a heavy courseload, but you get into pretty interesting discussions with Mike and Heidi during class.

Take it if you're willing to be engaging and engaged in the class. The class is relatively easy, but if you're not willing to put the work in for the sake of your classmates, it will become boring. I never had this problem, so I had a blast. If you think you'd be interested in this kind of class, it's a must take.
Take this class and reach out to contacts for you video interviews early! Finding a time to meet with them can be time consuming.
The assignments teach valuable skills, and the seminars are fun discussions. Just know to take your own initiative, because the (great) teachers are really laid back.
phenomenal class, excellent teachers---take it
prereqs: Strong interest in science and communications; no previous coursework or experience necessary..
descrip: In order to address the risks of climate change, people need accurate information. Most of this information comes from the world of science and requires translation. The role of science communicators is crucial. The goal of this course is to give students the technical, narrative and critical-evaluation skills needed to communicate climate science in both print and video. The course begins with an overview of the state of climate science and communications. We then discuss critical elements of journalism, and apply those discussions in a series of writing assignments. The last weeks focus on video production using Final Cut Pro software.

title: Screenwriting: Creating Visual and Emotional Unity
reviews: I would recommend this course to anyone.  The course, structured through screenwriting workshops, is engaging, interesting, challenging, yet never brutal.  The only work written during the semester are 25-30 pages of our feature script (Act I) and an outline for the rest of the script, but you'd be amazed as to what can done with it in terms of tweaking.  Professor Lazaridi does a great job in preparing you for this work by pointing out tips in her own projects as well as through movies like the Sixth Sense.  The feedback itself is invaluable, from both her and the other students.  It's sincere and honest yet never cruel.  There were many times during workshop I found myself nodding my head, realizing how important the tweaks they suggested were to improving the stories I wanted to tell.  Even if you're only a halfway decent story-teller, take this course.  You won't be disappointed.
Please only take the course if you are seriously trying to learn about films/screenwriting. And try to have pages every week! It's really fun to do group work, but only if the group is working.
Take it
Take it!
Take it! It is a great introduction to screenwriting. Professor Lazaridi is amazing!
Take it, it's so worth it!
Take it.  This class is a gem.
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they want to take the course and, optionally, a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre..
descrip: This class will familiarize students with the complex use of metaphorical, emotional, and visual threads in screenplay writing. Analyzing examples of international, independent, and classical structures, students will be exposed to the rhythms and demands of the process of conceiving and writing a long form narrative film.

title: Intermediate Swahili II
prereqs: Intermediate Swahili I (SWA 105 ) or the equivalent level of proficiency..
descrip: This course emphasizes conversational fluency and increased facility in reading and writing skills while introducing students to Swahili literature. This literature forms the basis for a survey on cultural aspects and more advanced grammer. Students will be able to understand and analyze the main ideas and significant details of materials in Swahili such as media articles, short stories, poetry, short novels, films and plays illustrative of East African cultural issues. Covers advanced-level Swahili grammar, as well as the development of expository writing skills.

title: Transportation Systems Analysis
prereqs: ORF 245 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Studied is the transportation sector of the economy from a technology and policy planning perspective. The focus is on the methodologies and analytical tools that underpin policy formulation, capital and operations planning, and real-time operational decision making within the transportation industry. Case studies of innovative concepts such as "value" pricing, real-time fleet management and control, GPS-based route guidance systems, automated transit systems and autonomous vehicles will provide a practical focus for the methodologies. Class project in lieu of final exam focused on major issue in Transportation Systems Analysis.

title: Special Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering - Structural Dynamics and Earthquake Engineering
descrip: The course is designed to introduce students to the dynamics of structures. It covers a variety of topics in the theory of structural dynamics, and applications to earthquake analysis, response and design of structures.

title: Animal Behavior
reviews: A good STN to PDF for a distribution requirement! The funny pictures and videos of animals are a plus.
Alright class
Attend the lectures and study the slides/your notes for the test, and you should be fine!
Definitely consider this class if you are looking for an EEB departmental to take. Make sure that you don't fall too behind on the readings.

Definitely take this course! I took it out of genuine interest, and it was definitely worth it! It's not too difficult, and you should skim the readings because there are a lot and they're repetitive.
Do not cram for the exams it's near impossible. Stay on top of the readings!
Do the readings.  They help for remembering examples on tests.
Don't take this course if you are not interested in animals or their behavior.  If you are interested in it then it is an amazing class but it will be torture if you aren't.
Enjoyable if you like animals (making babies)! Professor Gould blazes through material though and there is a lot of material to memorize. He's got a wicked sense of humor.
Go to all of Professor Gould's lectures and take good notes!
Good survey course for people interested in evolution.
I recommend taking this if you are Mol and need a 300 level EEB course. This is probably the lowest commitment one. Watch out for blackboard discussion questions and precepts.
I think this class is great and is also a great STN for non-science majors because it does not require extensive biology background
I would advise them to take this class if an EEB major or if they are very very interested in animals but otherwise steer clear
If you are at all interested in animal behavior, definitely take the course! Professor Gould's lectures are informative and entertaining.
If you are interested in animal behavior, take this course. If not, then don't bother.
Interesting course but, in hindsight, would probably not have taken it as my STN.
It's a good class to take to get an STN credit for a non-major. You do have to study and do the readings, though, to do well!
TAKE THIS COURSE!! Professor Gould is a fantastic lecturer and really cares about animals. His lectures come off as improvised and smooth, and he just knows so much about animals.
Take it as a distribution requirement (PDF) or  if you're majoring in EEB. Gould is a good lecturer and probably retiring soon.
Take it if you need to.  This class could potentially be fun for someone generally interested in animal behavior, but I am not so I don't know
Take it with professor Gould and it will be one of the best you take at Princeton.
Take it!  You'll love the material if you have the slightest interest in biology and animals
Take it! Go to lecture and do the readings, they'll come in handy as examples on the exams.
Take it. Gould is great. Not too much work except for exams.
Take the course.
Take this class.  Awesome STL.  Gould is so dedicated.
Take this course if you are interested in how animals think.  It will help you evaluate what it means to be human.

This class does a good job of making you think about animals in a new way. Professor Gould is an expert in the field, and his perspective is quite interesting. Lectures are somewhat engaging if you sit close to the front but can be dry and boring at times. In addition, some of the material and the readings needed to be updated, as Prof. Gould has been teaching the course for a long time, and it seems that not much has changed while he has taught it. The exams are, on the whole, not too difficult and mainly test your memory of the information taught in class.
This class was a disappointment. It could be run so much better and be much more engaging. It's just another dull memorization of facts class.
This course will leave you in awe at all the neat things animals can do!
This is an interesting course with some fascinating material, but some of it can also be kind of dry and not particularly stimulating.
it's ok
learn more about animals and take this class
descrip: One of the fascinating challenges in biology is to understand the origins and organization of animal behavior. Ethology is the branch of biology concerned with the mechanisms and evolution of behavior, especially innate predispositions and programming, and their interaction with learning. The course begins by examining the discovery of early ethologists of behavioral units or "programs", and relates these to our understanding of the nervous system. We look at how complex behaviors such as navigation, learning, and planning are organized. We study the social behavior of several species and end with an ethological analysis of our own species.

title: Optimization
reviews: A really interesting course which gets better as the semester goes on, and you get to learn about the applications of optimization.

Attending lectures is not necessary. Problem sets were straightforward enough (go to precept; they usually go through the process of the problems), although can be somewhat tedious and time-consuming. I thought the material was pretty interesting, although most others don't. Lectures couldn't have been better.
Avoid if possible.
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!!
Decent course. I definitely learned the material and have a better idea of how to do linear programming now. Organization is not great, lectures are useless. Only take it if your are an ORFE major.
Ditch lecture except for that last one. That's where things get real.
Don't take it unless you have to or are super super interested in the material.
Don't take this. Unless you're an ORFE major. In which case it will make you hate your major.
Easy but very boring
Ehh boring

Gain a true understanding of how to formulate a linear program. Being able to solve an LP manually is not a really useful skill, but it pays to know the algorithms and their costs. LP in general is a very practical thing to know.
Go to class.
Got to take it. Not great, but not bad either.

Great course. Take it. Prof Vanderbei is engaging in lecture, the course has the perfect amount of work and difficulty (not overwhelming at all), and you learn a lot of things which you can definitely apply straight away to various areas. Optimization is very useful for everything! If you are going to take any one ORF course in your Princeton career, take this course!

I think they are changing the class next year.  If not, go ahead and take it but you will learn nothing.  The class is not optimization, it is the simplex method.  If you know what the simplex method is and how it works, then you are done.  It's linear optimization, which is mostly trivial compared to nonlinear optimization which I hope the class covers in the future.
If you take this, the material is very interesting, but make sure you like the material.
If you're not an ORFE major or comfortable with math I don't think this course would be a good choice.  But if you do feel comfortable I think it is a very useful and engaging course

Interesting material, but lectures can be very dry. Everyone knows how to do the material come exam time, so exams are more about not making stupid math mistakes rather than understanding concepts. If you know how to do the method, you can do well in this class.
It's an ORF departmental; don't take if not ORF or finance. However, it was relatively interesting given that it's a requirement for ORFE majors to take.
Its a distribution requirement for orfe majors, so take it only if you have to. It's pretty unorganized
Linear programming is pretty dry and lectures were not good. That said, you have to take it

Most likely if you're thinking of taking this, you have to take it. But if you do have a choice, I'd say look around a bit online and see if you think this interests you. 
As long as you stay on top of things, this is a breeze compared to 309 or 335.
Not the most interesting class.
Only take it if you have to. It's not too difficult, but can be dry.
Only take this if you have to.
Take it if you have to.

Take it only if you have to. Not a time-efficient way to learn how to optimize things. Read the book first, you'll understand that you don't learn much at all, only one thing repeatedly. Go to lectures selectively.
Take it. You will learn a lot and it is very interesting because it has so many applications
Terrible course. Boring. Tedious. Mostly easy. Don't take it unless you have to. If you have to, study algebra I because that's all the exams test. I cannot stress how bad this course is.
The course content is very good, but the lectures can sometimes get boring. The professor and TAs are very nice and take the class if you are interested in linear programming.

This class is a lot easier than ORF 309 and ORF 335 but is more theoretical than applications-based which can be frustrating. The lectures aren't essential to attend, especially if you read the book. I recommend starting the homeworks early, though, because some take less than an hour to do and others are very long and tedious.

This class was awful - coming from an ORFE students who expects an A. This is by far the worst class I have taken here. Ask ANY person and they will corroborate that - ANYONE. There is literally NO reason to go to lecture ever. Vanderbei reads straight from mediocre slides at a slow pace. It is inexcusable that he has not learned how to teach the class better in nearly two decades. This is case #1 in why tenure   professors must teach is a bad mixture. In precept, Haotian would say things like (word for word) "I already taught that", "Why don't you get it?", "Just look at the board", etc. The book is mediocre and not really a good enough crutch to fully understand without lecture or precept. Well that's the bad. The good is that there is not much content over the course of the semester and the homework is generally not that hard (the AMPL programming in hw is fairly easy). The midterms looked almost exactly like the practice midterms and you will know exactly what's coming and you can prepare accordingly. The final project was also reasonable. In short, terribly taught class in all respects but that wont be a detriment to your grade. It's not worth it. No non-ORFE should even think about it. Don't. No. Stop.
This could be a good course. But it isn't.
This is a pretty straightforward class. I wouldn't worry about it too much. Do the work and go to precept and you will be fine.

Though in theory optimization should be interesting, this wasn't an incredibly enjoyable course somehow. ORF majors don't have a choice, but if you're not an ORF major, surely there are better courses out there for this....
Unless it's a required class for you, I would not recommend taking it.
Unless it's a requirement, just buy the book and read it in you own time. Material is incredibly interesting and highly applicable, but is presented very poorly in lecture.
Unless this course is entirely revamped, I would not recommend taking it unless you are required.
Unless you absolutely need to (because you're ORF) don't take this course. (Don't do it, MAEs, there are better options!)
Vanderbei is ok, but not the best professor. If you can take it with someone else, do that. Also, Vanderbei will not teach Excel Macros.
You have to.  Don't make dumb mistakes on the tests, and if you're not a machine who only knows what he/she is taught in class, you should be able to get the few nuanced questions.
always read the book
only take as departmental
only take it if you need to.
prereqs: MAT 202 or 204. Basic computer programming knowledge suggested..
descrip: Many real-world problems involve maximizing a linear function subject to linear inequality constraints. Such problems are called Linear Programming (LP) problems. Examples include min-cost network flows, portfolio optimization, options pricing, assignment problems and two-person zero-sumgames to name but a few. The theory of linear programming will be developed with a special emphasis on duality theory. Attention will be devoted to efficient solution algorithms. These algorithms will be illustrated on real-world examples such as those mentioned.

title: Epidemiology
reviews: Absolutely take this class, whether you're in GHP or not!

Being able to think like an epidemiologist is a skill directly relevant to the real world.  Professor Amon really drives home issues like bias, confounding, and fair comparisons, thereby developing a critical and creative outlook useful to assess not only outbreak investigations but scientific claims in general.  The first part of the course is technical (some problem sets with math/statistics problems) and focuses on types of studies, but after the midterm, the second part explores things like policy and ethics--my favorite part of the course because Professor Amon and a couple guest lecturers share their many experiences.  Lectures are engaging, the reading load was very manageable, and case study assignments are spaced throughout the semester.  Don't be afraid to speak up in class and voice your opinions--even if you're wrong, you'll remember it better that way.
Don't think too much into the questions.
Get a study group together well in advance of the midterm. Professor Amon is cool, take the opportunity to get to speak with him.
Get ready.
Great course! Prof Amon is fantastic and you learn a lot about analyzing public health in a quantitative manner.

I highly, highly recommend this course. This is one of my favorite classes that I've ever taken at Princeton. It was a great combination of real-life applications and cool, meaningful topics. The professor and preceptors were awesome as well. They really cared about showing you how cool this field was, and they're also very reasonable in the work they ask you do.

I recommend this course for anyone interested in health defined broadly. But you have to be in the GHP program to take it. The first half is very technical, but the second half is really interesting and applies the basic epi concepts to a lot of different important health topics. I recommend reviewing early for the midterm, as a whopping 40% of students got Cs or below. Joe was great at providing extra credit opportunities to make up for this, though. Joe has a lot of connections in global health and was able to bring in 3-4 very engaging guest speakers.
I would certainly recommend this course to students interested in health who would like to take a course that teaches practical, applicable information.

I would really recommend this course and the GHP certificate in general.  It provides you with a lot of opportunities and teaches you a lot of really useful and valuable information for public health or medicine.  Professor Amon is really great- he and the preceptors are readily available to help you outside of class.  Although the first midterm was tough, you are provided with extra assignments to make up for it.  I would really take this class and pursue the GHP- such an amazing experience
Interesting course.
Make sure to understand the basics of every type of study very well- learn this from the Gordis textbook, since it is covered pretty quickly in class.
Pretty comprehensive course. You'll learn the core concepts behind epidemiology while engaging in contemporary problems. Amy is a great preceptor - try to get her :).

Prof. Amon is a great, knowledgeable, and thoughtful professor. This course places an emphasis on epidemiological methodology and critical analysis of the literature. And the guest speakers are very cool. Take it!
Start Case Studies early and get feedback, don't underestimate the midterm.
Take it if you're interested in public health (or getting the GHP certificate).  Professor Amon is great, but be prepared for unclear grading practices and expectations on assignments.
Take it, even if you're not GHP, but are looking to do any kind of policy or science work - it helps you understand and critique scientific papers!
Take this class!  Going into it I was questioning whether I still wanted to be premed and this gave me a window into a related field and has inspired me to consider pursuing a career in epidemiology.
Take this class! Professor Amon is amazing, and you will learn a ton about public health from both a science and policy perspective!
This class is straightforward and well-organized.
This is a good course, and taking it for GHP certificate is not an arduous task.
YES DO IT THIS IS GREAT
take it!  Don't be afraid of Professor Amon - he can seem super serious but is actually a very friendly and helpful guy.  Accessible even to those with limited math/stats background (like me).
the material can be a bit dry at times but if you get through that, it gets much more interesting later in the course
prereqs: Completion of an approved basic statistics course (e.g., ECO 202, EEB/MOL 355, ORF 245, POL 345, PSY 251 or SOC 301), or completion of an advanced statistics course (e.g., ECO 302, ECO 312, ORF 405, SOC 404, WWS 200, and WWS 332)..
descrip: This required course for GHP students focuses on the distribution and determinants of disease. Diverse methodological approaches for measuring health status, disease occurrence, and the association between risk factors and health outcomes will be presented via classic and contemporary studies of chronic and infectious illness and disease outbreaks. Emphasis on: causal inference, study design and sampling, bias and confounding, the generalizability of research, health policy and research ethics.

title: Financial Crises
reviews: Be prepared to read
Do go to every lecture. Participate actively. Do the reading well if you want to learn a lot from it and get a good grade.

I found the course interesting. However, note that the two halves of the course are completely unrelated. The first half (professor Janeway) has little to do with financial crises and should be called instead the "innovation economy". The second half (professor Gordy) has more to do with financial crises, but expect a very long coding assignment and an unnecessarily painful final take-home exam.
I recommend taking this course.

Janeway is an excellent lecturer and Gordy is an excellent professor.  

This class is definitely worth taking, but there are about ~3000 pages of reading to do!  (You need to read about ~1000 pages total to have papers to cite on the midterm and final) 

The class gets much harder and much more quantitative during the second half.  It is not as bad as Asset Pricing II or Econometrics, but Gordy thinks we're a little more capable than we really are.
Matthieu is the unfriendliest TA you'll ever meet.
The first half and second half is so different. The first half is all discussion and the second half is R coding and math. Think if you are good at these.

The first half of the course is like walking on the moon wondering what you are doing here. The second half is where you are walking on the surface of the sun, trying not to get burned. 

At the end of the course, I ask myself: what did I learn about financial crises? The only thing I find good is the coverage of securitization. Enough time was dedicated to this topic and it was covered in depth. The plethora of other topics and papers we only touched briefly, and students were just baffled by them.
Understand the requirements for both halves of the course if taught by 2 different professors.

You need to be strongly qualitative and quantitative to handle this course. Qualitative skills helped you understand the intuition of the course, which is crucial if you want to pursue a career in finance. Quantitative skills would help you pass the final exam.
prof. jane way was great, Gordy was not.
prereqs: ECO310 and ECO202 or equivalent.
descrip: This course will consider market bubbles and financial crises from two distinct angles. The first half will focus on bubbles and crashes in the public equity market, with particular emphasis on the productive role that financial speculation can play in the deployment of innovative technologies. We will take a broad conceptual view of historic episodes, so require a large amount of background reading. The second half will focus on the dynamics of the credit system, with particular emphasis on leverage cycles and systemic instabilities, including the global financial crisis of 2008. Recent theoretical literature will be explored in depth.

title: Junior Independent Work
prereqs: This course is open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty member.

title: Gardens in China and Japan
reviews: Amazing professors! Definitely take this course if you are interested at all in gardens, spirituality, or East Asian art and culture. The professors are incredibly friendly and engaging. They both are very knowledgeable, and want the best for the students. The trip to Kyoto is also a bonus -- you really look at gardens from a different perspective after having seen them in person.
Best course I have taken at Princeton, hands down. Dealt with beauty, culture, art, philosophy... If you're genuinely interested in Chinese and Japanese culture, it's absolutely fantastic.
Classes are a bit of a struggle, but the material is interesting and the trip is great so you should take it if it's ever offered again!
Come to class with specific questions; skim the readings.
I would strongly recommend taking this course - it was one of my favorite classes at Princeton!
Read, engage with the class, and you'll find it a rewarding experience.

Take it if you're genuinely interested in the subject matter. I know we all want a class with a trip, but this isn't a class you can just "take" if you're not interested besides going abroad. It'll be obvious that's all you want, and it'll be a very long semester for you...
Take it! The trip is fabulous! The seminar is easy but don't expect to learn much from the readings...
definitely take the course!
descrip: "Gardens in China and Japan," including a spring break class trip to Kyoto, studies gardens in a historical, religious, artistic, and literary framework so that students learn about their broad-ranging significance in traditional East Asia. In their underlying theory, siting, construction, and relations with architecture and agriculture, gardens offer rich areas for investigation and present insights about the view of nature, life of the imagination, articulation of religious and philosophical values, distribution of wealth, and human impact on the environment.

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Managing People and Organizations
descrip: This course enhances participants' understanding of their own motivation & behavior, & that of others. Students understand what environments make them most productive & satisfied, how to create most productive work environments for employees, how to manage different types of professional & interpersonal situations. The course uses cases & readings to explore topics of individual motivation, leadership, power & influence, managing conflict, organizational culture, working in teams, communicating effectively, decision making, fostering creativity/innovation, managing change.

title: Durer's World
reviews: Great course if you're interested in Northern Renaissance Art! Prof. Heuer is very knowledgeable. The class involves just one long final paper, and weekly reading responses, so be prepared for a lot of independent research. The readings are also quite dense.

If you are set on your interest in art history, absolutely take this course.  The material and Professor Heuer are amazing.  Otherwise, be wary of pushing yourself beyond your capacity; there is a lot to handle.
Professor Heuer's expertise on this subject is such that no matter what your knowledge of Durer is, this class will advance it.
prereqs: Some German reading knowledge is helpful but not required..
descrip: The course examines the staggering diversity of Albrecht Durer's pictorial experimentation, as well as his role as a collector, teacher, diarist, art theorist and intellectual in the German Reformation. Through reading, discussion, and object examination, the seminar will question traditional emphases upon the idea of Durer's "mastery" and probe the role his work has played in understandings of the Renaissance and various modernities.

title: The Origins of Japanese Culture and Civilization: A History of Japan until 1600
reviews: It's can be a lot of work, but you can decide on your own deadline for papers, which is nice. If you are interested in the topic, take this class. You won't regret it!
Read all the materials, listen in class, and talk to Professor Conlan about everything.
This is an interesting course on a part of history we don't often get much exposure to.
descrip: This course is designed to introduce the culture and history of Japan, and to examine how one understands and interprets the past. In addition to considering how a culture, a society, and a state develop, we will try to reconstruct the tenor of life in "ancient" and "medieval" Japan and chart how patterns of Japanese civilization shifted through time.

title: Contemporary Korean Language and Culture II
reviews: Be on top of your work. Don't get behind on assignments and readings. Make flashcards for Chinese characters.
Definitely take it! It's fun, not a ridiculous amount of work, and will improve your reading and writing skills a lot.
Professor Suh is the best lecturer ever! HANDS DOWN. TAKE THIS CLASS. YOU WON'T REGRET IT.
Take this course, and be brave! The great opportunity is wasted if you don't take the energy and courage to speak up in class.
prereqs: KOR 401 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Reading and discussion of Korean thoughts and issues in contemporary Korea. Readings drawn from a variety of cultural and historical topics. Class discussions will be conducted in Korean.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term): Sci & Engineering
prereqs: Course open to graduate students who have completed sufficient research to begin writing a research article in any area of science or engineering..
descrip: Writing workshop for students in any area of quantitative research, including science and engineering, who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.

title: Advanced Quantum Field Theory
reviews: Get a good understanding of Peskin until chapter 7 before taking the course!
I found the course rather challenging and it certainly took up alot of my time. If you are willing to commit I am sure you will get lots from the course.

If you want to take quantum field theory, Prof. Klebanov is proably one of the best professors that could teach it. It does not cover a great amount of material but it focuses a lot on important technical details.

Prof Klebanov's approach to QFT was very different from that given by Prof Verlinde. It takes some for people to get used to. In particular, he gets really technical, so it might be good to get the big idea first, and repeat the calculations twice in your own leisure.
Spend plenty of time thinking about the material beyond just finishing problems, and try to work in groups!
descrip: Relations between Quantum Field Theory and Statistical Mechanics, Renormalization Group, Non-Abelian Gauge Theories, Asymptotic Freedom, Quantum Chromodynamics, Chiral Lagrangians, General Constraints on RG Flows.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: Take it if required.
Worthwhile course.
You have to
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for graduate students and post-docs.

title: Media Arabic I
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or the equivalent..
descrip: In this course, students will develop their skills in reading and listening to Arabic news media, including newspapers, magazines, websites, radio and satellite TV broadcasts (including BBC and al-Jazeera, among others). Attention will also be given to informal discussion on these subjects, and we will also take a brief look at political cartoons.

title: Islamic Family Law
reviews: I would tell another student to listen attentively in class and write down everything the professor says!
It is an interesting topic and useful for understanding an important part of our societies but probably not the best course for someone who really wants to interact with the material.
Take this class if you are interested in the subject. Professor Modarressi is the best!
Very interesting class and Prof. Modarressi has a fascinating background.
descrip: This course examines the oulines of Islamic family law in gender issues, sexual ethics, family structure, family planning, marriage and divorce, parenthood, child guardianship and custody, etc. The course starts with a general survey of Islamic legal system: its history and developments, structure and spirit, and the attempts of the Muslim jurists to come to terms with the challenge of time.

title: Modern Physics I: Condensed-Matter Physics
reviews: A great departmental elective. Petta moves quickly in lecture but is clear. The problem sets often have you fill in the the calculations from lecture, which means that the results are interesting. Covers many important topics in condensed matter.

A great introduction to condensed matter physics. Professor Petta has an aggressively fast and very interactive lecture style. He is friendly and helpful and strives to teach his students as much as he can within the confines of our short semester.
Definitely take it! Make sure to follow through all the lectures; Professor Petta's teaching style is such that you will be sure to understand even the challenging material!
Great physics course. Interesting problems and good lectures.

I almost didn't take condensed because I heard it was impossibly difficult.  That is NOT TRUE.  The class is actually just the right level of challenge, Petta is very engaging, and overall the whole experience is rewarding.
Work hard and start early on the problem sets. Review the material each week so that you are prepared to respond in lecture.
prereqs: PHY 208, PHY 301 and PHY 305.
descrip: This survey course applies concepts from quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics to the properties of electrons in solids. Topics include phonons and lattice dynamics, electronic band structure, the tight-binding approximation, origin of exchange and magnetism, spin waves, Ginzburg Landau theory of phase transitions, and the BCS theory of superconductivity.

title: Introduction to Financial Mathematics
reviews: A great course, but one that's fast-paced and tough. Professor Sircar is an engaging and interesting lecturer, but make sure you're always tuned in!
Best ORFE class so far from the primary sequence
Definitely take it. Material gets tougher as the semester goes on, and it is very interesting and useful material. Take even if not orf or econ but have interest in finance.
Difficult but effective class.
Don't take it unless you took 309 and liked it a lot or you have to take it for ORF.

Financial math is really beautiful but also quite complex. I enjoyed applying 309 concepts to real-world problems. Beware that the final two problem sets are quite difficult, but other than that, this course isn't too bad.

Great course. Sircar is clear, and is the reason the course is good. Material is interesting, if a little challenging, but not impossible. Go to lectures. Read his notes to supplement the lectures, but not as a replacement. Textbook unnecessary; no one uses it.
I recommend! You learn a lot from this course and the math behind finance is quite fascinating.

I went in with no finance knowledge. I thought the material at the beginning was pretty difficult as I got used to all the finance jargon (shorting, no arbitrage, etc.), but it was actually doable with more time (pretty basic math). The second half of the class is a lot harder since it incorporates stochastic calculus, which was extremely difficult for me since I didn't do well in ORF 309. Overall, though, the curve was pretty nice. Work with others on the psets.
If ORFE you have no choice.  If you aren't ORFE you must really love finance and Math
It's a very good class (one of the best in the ORFE department). Prof. Sircar is great. However, it is a challenging class and psets can be very time-consuming.
It's time consuming and difficult, but well taught.

Most people have to take it, but if you like quanty-finance it is legitimately interesting and Sircar is a great prof. The problem sets start easy and get very hard at the end, so be aware and plan accordingly.
Only take it if you have to or are dying to know how to price options
Start your problem sets early -- you'll feel good.
Stay on top of things! It's interesting, but the material piles up, in the second half of the course especially
Take it! especially with sircar!!
Take it. It is hard, but you will learn a lot.
Take the course! Be prepared to work on assignments for a while in groups and understand concepts thoroughly.
Take this course if you need it or if you're very interested.
The material picks up substantially after the midterm, so be prepared.

The material's sometimes dry, but you get a lot of exposure to finance-related math and Sircar is a very knowledgeable (albeit sometimes dry) professor. Go to precepts, the Matlab code and some problems they solve will greatly help with homework. And go to class, the notes posted are very good but you don't want to miss anything.
This course is basically mathematics of derivatives, which are pretty cool. Take this if you've taken ORF 309 and liked it; don't take it if you really hate Matlab or doing tedious math.
This is a great course. Attend lecture, it's well worth it.
This was a great course taught well with a lot of interesting math and dynamic programming exercises.

Try to keep up with the material. I didn't and consequently did very poorly on the midterm and basically had a panic attack when preparing for the final. I also regret working alone on most of my p-sets (though they were a lot less stressful when I started early...). Overall, this is a very hard class, especially for someone like me who came in with absolutely no background in economics, but it is not impossible.

You have to probably take it as an ORFE major. Take the time to enjoy Sircar's clear and to the point teaching style (it's rare to get teachers like that), if you're a financy type of person read up the extra books they assign and yes- start work on MATLAB early and dont leave it till the end.

You're probably an ORF major and have to take this class anyways.  Gets a lot harder after the midterm so keep up with the assignments and notes.  If you don't like finance, you probably won't enjoy the material too much.
only take if required or if you have genuine interest in finance   stoch. calc.
the curve kills
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 104 and ORF 309 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Financial Mathematics is concerned with designing and analyzing products that improve the efficiency of markets and create mechanisms for reducing risk. This course introduces the basics of quantitative finance: the notions of arbitrage and risk-neutral probability measure are developed in the case of discrete models. Black-Scholes theory is introduced in continuous-time models, and credit derivatives and the term structure of interest rates are discussed, as well as lessons from the financial crisis.

title: Computer Graphics
reviews: Be prepared to work, and you will be rewarded with really cool working programs by the end :)

It is an amazing class but an insane amount of work. The assignments are very rewarding and the amount of material you cover is crazy. However it's by far the biggest workload I've ever had, especially the mesh processing and raytracing assignments. (I haven't taken OS yet so I can't compare to that.) You should take this class, but you should make sure all your other classes have low work loads. Don't bother getting the textbook, it's totally unnecessary.
Rewarding course but takes a lot of time.
Start ahead of time on your projects, and you will find that this class is not very hard.
TAKE IT especially if you're interested in it! Don't think about how much time it will take because in the end you will not regret it one single bit.
Take graphics! It's some work but worth it. A really good part of CS
Take it!

Take it! It's a ton of work (programming assignments take between 20 and 30 hours), but it was always really fun and the grading was always very reasonable. Plus you always end up with a very visually cool result and the final project in lieu of a final (you make a video game!) is great too.

This course has a reputation for being time consuming for a reason - assignments take easily 40-60 hours so say goodbye to every other one of your weekends. That being said, it is extremely rewarding, you'll have a strong grasp on modern computer graphics software. If you're looking for a course just to learn C  , this is not the course, but you will learn some of C   while taking this course.
This is a hard course. If you have only 217/226, this is a *very* hard course.

This is a lot of work and a lot coding in C  . Be prepared. Probably the most work of any COS class. Don't go in expecting it to be a fun easy class where you make video games every week. That doesn't happen till the week after classes end. I would recommend it for the experience in C  , some interesting content, and the final project.

when people say assignments take a long time, they mean it
other than that, this course is interesting and you will build some cool things
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226. Math 202 or equivalent recommended..
descrip: Introduction to computer graphics. Topics include image synthesis, 3D modeling, image processing and animation. Encourage hands-on experience.

title: Colloquium on the Biology of Populations
descrip: Discussion of the central problems of population biology and approaches that have proved fruitful. Topics ranging throughout ecology, evolution, biogeography, and population genetics are usually related to presentations by visiting speakers and students. (This is a core course.)

title: Post-colonial North Africa Before the Arab Spring
descrip: Since 2011, North Africa (or Maghrib) has been shaken by two revolutions in its Eastern part (Tunisia and Libya) and this area still contains strategic crossroads between Europe, sub-Saharan Africa and the Middle East. This graduate seminar addresses the social, economical and cultural issues in post-colonial North Africa before the Arab spring.

title: Human Rights and Human Dignity
descrip: See website

title: Architecture and the Visual Arts
reviews: Great theory class! Take it, you will learn a whole new side of architecture. Not too demanding if you show up to every lecture and precept.
If you are interested in the intersection of visual arts and architecture, take it.
If you are interested in this kind of thing, definitely take the course.
prereqs: ART/ARC 242 or other introductory courses on art and architectural history and theory are strongly recommended..
descrip: This course will explore the relationships between architectural discourse and the visual arts from the historical avant-garde to the present with an emphasis on a series of theoretical concepts, such as space, figure, frame, and empathy. Architectural discourse will be considered here as the intersection of diverse systems of representation: buildings, projects, drawings, as well as art and architectural theory and criticism, exhibitions, and photographs. The lectures are divided into six sections: theater, cinema, photography, painting, sculpture and multi-media installations.

title: Introduction to Machine Translation
reviews: Classes are pretty laid-back though 3-hour lectures are pretty hard to stay focused through. Take it if you want a general survey of natural language and machine translation techniques and are looking to apply them somewhere yourself.
Go to every class - otherwise you'll fall behind faster than you can spell "Chomsky normal form."
It can be a bit dry at times, but the material is very interesting if you like languages.
It's a great class if you are interested in the material.

Take this course if you like linguistics, computer science, or the link between them. The instructor (Srinivas Bangalore) was very good at offering it, and you would learn a lot from your semester. The course project is open ended and can be quite fun. I also suggest trying to follow along with the Jurafski and Martin book to get a better grip of what cannot be covered fully in class, but will be useful for homework.

This class isn't that great really. If you're fascinated by machine translation take it, otherwise don't bother it's not extremely interesting. It's also a 3 hour long lecture for all intents and purposes, and the professor did not respond to any emails I sent him (although he mentioned he received them in class, which is great). Meh.

This is a great course for someone interested in machine translation or natural language processing. The material's very interesting, and you get to make actual tools for natural language processing. The course description lists COS 126 as the minimum COS requirement, but I imagine that it would be very difficult for someone who has only taken that course. Additionally, given the different areas with Computer Science that natural language processing draws from, I would recommend waiting to take this class until junior or senior year.
take it to get a nice intro to NLP.
prereqs: Students are required to have programming experience or should have completed COS126 (Introduction to Computer Science). TRA 200 is recommended (may be taken simultaneously)..
descrip: This course will provide an in-depth study of the MT paradigms (direct, transfer, statistical/example, and interlingual) used in state-of-the-art speech-to-speech and text-based MT systems, from computational and linguistic perspectives. Machine-learning techniques for processing human languages (morphological analysis, tagging, syntactic and semantic parsing, and language generation) will be discussed in detail. Linguistic variation across languages and its impact on computational models will be presented. Projects will involve implementing speech/text translation components, identifying their limitations and suggesting improvements.

title: Proseminar in Anthropology
descrip: We build on the work of the first semester pushing the exploration of the notions of culture, structure, meaning, hermeneutics, interpretation, consensus & conflict. We try to map how these concepts have been applied to non-Western societies as well as western ones & what we can learn from these implementations regarding generation & elaboration of anthropological knowledge. Finally we examine the ongoing debate on transnational circulations & transnational reconfigurations with special references to their redefinings of self, identity, ethnicity, nation & power.

title: Pottery: Archaeology, Art, and Technology
descrip: See website

title: Fundamentals of the Geosciences II
reviews: Good
It is required.
descrip: A survey of fundamental papers in the Geosciences. Topics include present and future climate, biogeochemical processes in the ocean, geochemical cycles, orogenies, thermochronology, rock fracture and seismicity. This is the second of two core geosciences graduate courses.

title: East Asia since 1800
reviews: Focus on mastering the lecture material rather than trying to memorize all the events and people in the textbook reading.
Go to lectures. While they don't replace the textbook reading, they help your understanding a lot. Plus the midterm and final are based on them.

HIS 208 provides a standard overview of East Asian History. If you are an EAS or HIS major or simply have an interest in East Asian history I would recommend this course. Make sure you get Professor Chen as your preceptor as she was absolutely incredible. Avoid Professor Marcon if you can. He has a great personality and is very approachable and friendly but just not very skilled at communicating concepts clearly in English.

I would recommend that anyone interested in East Asian history take this course. However, the course does have a rather fast pace and broad scope, so make sure to stay on track and keep the various events and periods and themes organized throughout the course.
It's a very good history of East Asia class.
Such a good pdf history class
Take it, the reading materials are interesting, and the lectures are fun to go to.
Take it. It's a good course and it's very well taught.
This should give you a great foundation on modern/contemporary East Asia. If you have taken a lot of EAS classes previously, this might be more of a historical review.

Took this course because I knew virtually nothing about East Asian history (Chinese in particular), and I can say this course has definitely helped me to fix that and gain some much needed perspective on current issues in East Asia. Lectures were pretty fast-paced but not unmanageable. Workload was very reasonable as well -- I personally hate doing precept readings, but I was able to do (almost all) of the readings for this class without much trouble. Take this class is you want to know more about this subject! (It'll make you a better person!)
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the history of modern East Asia. We will examine the inter-related histories of China, Japan, and Korea since 1800 and their relationships with the wider world. Major topics include: trade and cultural exchanges, reform and revolutions, war, colonialism, imperialism, and Cold War geopolitics.

title: Introduction to Historiography of Science
reviews:
-Great course, led by a dynamic, kind, and awesomely competent professor.
-You'll get mostly HOS graduate students in this course, but also some from other fields, like architecture and classics, not to mention a few ambitious undergraduates! So many different opinions help to make the class discussions highly productive.
Again, more framing for students--what should we be looking for.  How does each week relate to one another?  what are current trends in the historiography.  This would have helped
Definitely take it to see a more academic aspect of history of science.
Definitely take it!
Great class, be prepared that the class size may be frustating and that there will be lots of readings.
Great course.
I highly recommend this course. Professor Creager is inspiring and delightful and class discussions are informative. A stimulating and worthwhile course that is well-structured and highly enjoyable.
Intense, and be ready for a lot of philosophical links, but a good introduction to the big questions.
descrip: This course is designed to introduce beginning graduate students to the central problems and principle literature of the history of science from the Enlightenment into the 20th century.

title: Translating Babel: Scripture and Translation in Near Eastern Religious Traditions
descrip: This seminar explores the relationship between translation and religion, paying close attention to the religious traditions of the Near East. We will address a broad variety of themes in the religious history of the Near East, ranging from the development of monotheism to the miraculous inimitability of the Qur'an to colonial attempts at translation and religion-making. We will examine themes in the comparative study of religion concerning canonization, scriptural hermeneutics, cosmopolitanism, and religious conversion. We will also bring theoretical perspectives to bear on topics such as semiotics, epistemology, and mysticism.

title: Opera Revealed: Imagining Its Future From The Inside Out
reviews: A straightforward and fun class. I took it as a fifth class, and the work load was no problem.
Gives cool access to behind-the-scenes stuff in the opera world, but poorly organized and you won't learn very much.
I do not have any advice.
Recommend if you're a music student, particularly a singer because you'll get the most out of it, particularly with the kinds of guests we had
Take this course if you are interested in opera. It was really incredible. You do need to be prepared to be work independently and be a bit confused about weekly assignments.
Take this course, but be flexible.
prereqs: Familiarity with opera useful..
descrip: This seminar explores the aesthetic, practical, and interdisciplinary aspects of opera. Featuring Anthony Roth Costanzo (countertenor with the Metropolitan Opera) as one of the instructors, this course includes guest lecturers and field trips to area opera houses, including The MET. Students will have the opportunity to meet the artists, critics, pedagogues, and administrators involved in opera and gain an in-depth understanding of all aspects of opera from conception to consumption, including directing, stage design, costuming, singing, acting, and arts administration. Students from all disciplines with interests in opera are welcome.

title: Survey of Selected Works of Twentieth-Century Architects
reviews: Amazing class, Jeff is just out of this world.
Class depends highly on Jeff's mood. You might be a little disappointed intellectually, but you'll end up having a great friend like Jeff.
It is my general understanding that other students felt frustration from the lack of organization and structure.
Jeff is smarter than you.
descrip: This course is intended to expose the students to a range of major works, built and unbuilt, of architecture from 1950 to the present. This course will focus on these particular buildings as they open themselves to a textual analysis. These analyses are intended to open up issues such as criticality, autonomy and singularity as they begin to evolve in architectural building (as opposed to texts) in the last half of the 20th century. This course will concentrate on individual buildings not architects. Each analysis will be accompanied by an illustrated presentation and selected readings.

title: Foundations of Political Economy
descrip: Course focuses on modeling the interaction of politics and economics, with applications to a variety of substantive areas. Topics include: poltics of taxation and redistribution; governmental structure, political economy of constitutional arrangements, development, and growth. Familiarity with microeconomic theory and POL 575 or the equivalent are prerequisites.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - ICT, Economic Development and Politicial Violence
descrip: Recent years have seen a boom in information communication technology (ICT) in the developing world: nearly two-thirds of the four billion people in Asia-Pacific and almost half of Africa?s one billion people are subscribers to cellular phone networks. This course examines the social, political, and economic consequences this modern communications revolution has had and what opportunities and challenges it presents for public policy. We explore the impact of ICT on economic development and inequality, existing social structures and cultural norms, democratization and democratic consolidation, as well as political violence and unrest.

title: Advanced German
reviews: BE WILLING TO MAKE MISTAKES
Don't take German, because it is 4 semesters
If you've gotten this far, you might as well take it.
It's a language class, be prepared to focus n it individually if you want to learn the language in a deeper level.

Perhaps because the class meets less frequently than 105, you should plan to do more work outside of class than you did last semester.  Work steadily on learning vocabulary - it will be too much to try to cram in one or two nights before a quiz.
Stay on top of the readings and vocab and grammar concepts!
Take if you're learning German.

Take the course, and take it with Professor Attanucci. The class is required for the distribution and you'll stay interested the entire time. Attanucci explains difficult concepts well and you'll learn a lot.
This course is not particularly grammar heavy,  so if you need a thorough revision of German grammar, this is going to be your responsibility.
This course really builds your vocabulary
This is a good course and the professor was great and very friendly and helpful.  I would recommend it,though at can at times be a bit slow.
don't put off vocab studying until the night before and never be afraid to voice your opinions in class (ie: grammarschmammar haha you have good ideas!!)
great course and good material just a bad teacher who ruined it for me and all my classmates
prereqs: GER 105 or permission of instructor. Classes conducted in German..
descrip: Continues improvement of proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing using film, digital media, and literary texts as a basis for class discussion. Grammar review is included.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: Be very careful in deciding which projects to pursue. Usually it is more difficult to work on a project that has been around for awhile because you will have to pick up other people's slack and work around previous decisions that have been made. Overall, though the class may be disorganized and time-intensive, the experience is invaluable. There is no other way at Princeton to get a hands-on engineering experience except through EPICS. I am very glad that I did EPICS.
Be vocal and motivate yourself intrinsically.
Definitely.
EPICS: Time Team is an excellent course that allows to work on cool, hands-on projects. Would definitely recommend!
Join the DDW team! We're designing a water pump for an Israeli-Palestinian NGO.

Take EPICS. You will get out of this class what you put into it. It is purely based on participation. If you have an interest in community service, engineering, or just a curiosity of science, take it. I am NOT an engineer and have enjoyed the past 2 years in the course. It is an all-around great learning experience.
Take it! It's a chilled out course and you learn a lot, particularly hands on things
prereqs: Completion of EGR 350.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Readings in American History: The Early Republic through Reconstruction, 1815-1877
reviews: Be prepared to read a lot and to learn everything you can about this period. Good for generals prep, as well as just knowing your stuff. Can sometimes feel like too much, but you'll walk away with a good handle on the major debates and questions of the period. Prof. Wilentz is a very engaging, knowledgeable, and approachable professor.
Don't start your reading the night before.  You'll never finish it in time.
Strongly recommend.

This course is a great primer for those seeking to research the nineteenth-century history of the United States. It will give you the ability to understand central conversations on the history of the country, and provide you with points of access for your research.
descrip: A comprehensive introduction to the literature and problems of American history from the Era of Good Feelings through Reconstruction.

title: Classical Japanese Prose
descrip: Reading of prose works from pre-Meiji Japan with an emphasis on the diversity of possible modes of inscription. Other topics include genre, commentary traditions, manuscript/print cultures, and bibliography.

title: Math Alive
reviews: Absolutely take Math Alive if you are looking to fulfill your QR requirement. Professor Griffiths is one of the best professors I have ever had in any subject, and he could not have been more helpful. Also, the lectures are engaging and enjoyable, and the problem sets are not very difficult. Still, the problem sets help deepen your understanding of the course topics that are all very relevant today! This class was just what I was looking for.

Anybody who is not mathematically-inclined, or who is but does not like hardcore math, should absolutely take this course. If you think math is useless and unrelatable, Ian will prove you wrong. Lectures are lively and he is so funny, problem sets are not too too bad, and my only complaint would be the essays. Make absolute sure you completely understand the expectations for the essay because that is what he uses to differentiate and break up the grades (since almost everyone does very well on the problem sets) and they count for a lot. Be open to learning and you will be very pleasantly-surprised and grateful.
Definitely a great class to take if you are a humanities person in need of a QR

Easiest course at Princeton.
If you're looking for QR, take this, NOT Astro. (which is uninteresting and harder than you'd expect)
Go to lecture! The lectures are REALLY interesting and totally worth your time. Figuring out the problem sets on your own isn't the easiest way to go about taking this course.
Great course
Griffiths is fantastic. Such a nice course, great way to fulfill a requirement.

I took this course because, as a humanities major, I was interested in finding a QR that could satisfy my distribution requirement. I have absolutely *no* regrets about selecting this course.  Professor Griffiths is a great lecturer, the material (the application of mathematics to everyday scenarios) is interesting, and the workload is not unbearable (10 problem sets throughout the semester, 1 6-8 page paper in lieu of a midterm and another 6-8 page paper in lieu of a final - both of these topics you can choose for yourself!) I could not recommend this course more highly. I found it much more enjoyable than the two English classes I selected, even as someone who was considering majoring in English! Professor Griffiths is such a great professor and makes himself easily accessible for any questions.  If you take this class, I guarantee you will not regret it.
If you're not a math person, this is the math class for you.
It is a very good option for humanities majors, but remember to do well on your papers.
Just do it.
Never expected I would enjoy a QR this much--Professor Griffiths is wonderful and you learn a ton.  Great course!

Really engage in the class. Go speak to Ian at office hours, if you have him, because he is so helpful and amazing. Also, don't hesitate to explore topics that interest you in light of material we learn in class. It is applicable to a variety of interests, which you can use as inspiration for midterm or final papers.
Still an easy QR.
TAKE IT BEST QR EVER
Take it if you are afraid of math. It doesn't take a lot of time; there are no readings and no tests, just weekly problem sets and midterm/final papers.
Take it if you don't like Maths
Take it! If you want to get your QR without pain but also want to learn, this is the class for you.
Take it! It's a great QR and actually relevant to real life.
Take the class if you want a fairly easy QR. Professor Griffiths is lovely!
Take this class to satisfy your QR! Ian is great and it's not difficult.
Take this class!
Take this class. Ian is great, material is interesting, and not too difficult.
Take this course, easiest class I took at Princeton
This is a great class to take with Professor Griffiths.  I would definitely recommend taking it.  You will get out of this class what you put into it.
This is a money course for satisfying the QR requirement and a GPA booster if you put in any effort

This is probably the best QR option for people who truly dislike math. The problem sets were pretty straightforward and never a pain, and there are no exams. It's not a particularly interesting class, but it gets the job done and was actually better than I initially expected, not to mention, very easy.
attend class and get to know Ian because he's so helpful
great for english majors
prereqs: This course is intended for non-science, non-engineering majors. When this course has closed, please email amainzer@princeton.edu to be placed on the waitlist..
descrip: Mathematics has profoundly changed our world, from the way we communicate with each other and listen to music, to banking and computers. This course is designed for those without college mathematics who want to understand the mathematical concepts behind important modern applications. The course consists of individual modules, each focusing on a particular application (e.g., digital music, sending secure emails, and using statistics to explain, or hide, facts). The emphasis is on ideas, not on sophisticated mathematical techniques, but there will be substantial problem-set requirements. Students will learn by doing simple examples.

title: Music of the Baroque
reviews: Definitely take this course if you're interested in music history. A music theory background is not required, but is a big asset for understanding the material. Also, it'd be good to know how to play an instrument, as performing makes the final project more fun.
If you enjoy the Baroque, you'll likely enjoy this class.
Solid Class, good overview of Baroque
Take this.
This course is pretty interesting and not much work.
contact professor lockey for extra questions you're too shy to ask in class; he tries to make himself available
prereqs: Some musical background helpful..
descrip: A survey of musical styles and performance traditions in European music from approximately 1600-1750, including the music of Monteverdi, Scarlatti, Handel, Rameau, and Bach. Topics to be considered include the role of music in the courts of Europe, the birth of opera, the rise of instrumental music, devotional music in the Catholic and Lutheran Church, performance practice, music and dance. Emphasis will be placed on music's cultural context in relation to the other humanistic disciplines.

title: Introduction to Monte Carlo Simulation
prereqs: ORF 245 and ORF 309..
descrip: An introduction to the uses of simulation and computation in analyzing stochastic models and interpreting real phenomena. Deals with generating discrete and continuous random variables, stochastic ordering, the statistical analysis of simulated data, variance reduction techniques, statistical validation techniques, nonstationary Markov chains, and Markov chain Monte Carlo methods. Applications are drawn from problems in finance, manufacturing, and communication networks. Students will be encouraged to program in Python. Help will be offered to help the students unfamiliar with the language.

title: Expanding British History 1700-1830: Nations, States and Empires
descrip: This reading course situates 18th and early 19th century British and Irish history in a broader European and global setting. It addresses issues of war and competing nationalisms; Britain's role as a European power, in an Atlantic community; as a constitutional model; and the changing domestic and international impact of the British Empire.

title: Modern Methods for Organic Synthesis
reviews: Be ready for a tough few weeks at the end, but overall the course is an excellent learning experience.
Prepare to haul for MOW, but this course is practical and helpful.
Synthesis is hard

This course is an incredible amount of work but is quite informative. This is a must take for synthetic grad students but I would caution any undergraduates that it relies on a graduate level understanding of synthesis (ie you have taken CHEM 530)
take it. you're going to hate the second part, but also learn more about critical thinking as it pertains to synthetic design.
prereqs: One full year of undergraduate organic chemistry.
descrip: This course exposes you to many types of carbon-based molecular structures, the transformations they undergo, and many kinds of chemical reactions and strategies that are important to the field of organic synthesis. Recent advances in asymmetric catalysis, cascade and other complexity-generating structural transformations, and powerful strategies for chemical synthesis that evolved from ideas about the structural origins of important, biologically active molecules such as steroid hormones, cofactors, and alkaloids are addressed.

title: Screenwriting for a Global Audience
reviews: Absolutely take this course. If you are an artist, you will learn to think in new ways that are current and relevant; and if you are an engineer or a scientist, you will learn to use your skills in creative ways.
Definitely take if you're interested in screenwriting! Christina is a great person - very kind, helpful, and fun.
Definitely take this class if you're interested or are looking for a fun creative writing class to take
Everyone should take a creative writing class at Princeton, and Christina's is one of the best. She is amazing and helpful and incredibly talented. It's inspiring to see a master work.
