Take this course!  Prof Lazaridi is incredible and will absolutely make you a better storyteller!  Also, the semester is really fun.
prereqs: By application only (no pre-requisites).
descrip: How can screenwriters create stories for global consumption? How can they remain grounded in an understanding of human nature, while working to innovate visual narrative forms? This course will analyze elements of storytelling techniques used across cultures and time, through an investigation of how the human brain processes narrative visual information. Using fairytales, films and new media, as well as scientific and technological breakthroughs in the understanding of brain function, the course will give students techniques for communicating a dramatic continuum to the human brain using traditional and cutting edge film/media platforms.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A formal report on research involving analysis, synthesis, and design, directed toward improved understanding and resolution of a significant problem. The research is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and the thesis is defended by the student at a public examination before a faculty committee. The senior thesis is equivalent to a year-long study and is recorded as a double course in the Spring.

title: Environmental Engineering Laboratory
reviews: Be sure to read the labs over prior to performing experiments; it will save a lot of time!
Enjoy the labs! There are not many lab opportunities for Environmental Engineers.

It's CEE environmental core lab. You will know if you need to take this class. It could be of interest to some CHM, GEO, MAE, ENV, or CHE students, especially ENV certificate students in non-science majors. Also, every WWS major who thinks they understand science should be forced to take this.
prereqs: CEE 303 and CEE 306 or Permission Of Instructor. CEE 306 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Designed to teach experimental measurement techniques in environmental engineering and their interpretations. Analytical techniques to assess biodegradation of wastes, lake eutrophication, non-point source pollution, and transport of contaminants in surface and groundwater, as well as hydrologic measurements to determine river and groundwater discharges, and soil-moisture dynamics in response to precipitation events will be conducted.

title: The Literature of Gastronomy
reviews: A great class to take senior spring. Interesting and not that much work.
Chill PDF or 5th class
Class time is minimal -- one lecture and one precept per week -- and it's easy to do well as the exams are based more on broader themes than details from the readings.
Cool/ interesting
Course really depends on the preceptor that you have. Use your discretion on taking this course.
DON'T TAKE IT
Definitely take it!
Do all the precept reading
Don't take it not worth your time.
Don't take unless you are PDFing it.
Don't take, not worth it.
Easy LA, very easy PDF.
Easy course to PDF and get an LA out of the way. But be warned, lectures and precepts are mandatory (they take attendance).
Go to class and participate in class because it makes it more enjoyable.
Good LA. Not a hard class.
Great class.
I really enjoyed taking it and it balanced out my very difficult schedule nicely.
I would advise another student considering taking this course to pay attention in lecture and to do all the readings and try to relate them to one another.
I would advise that they do all the readings in preparation for the midterm and final.

I would recommend taking this course if you're looking for a relatively low workload. The readings were not long and there was only a midterm and final, so it is great for taking PDF. The content was also pretty interesting.
I would tell students to take advantage of the lectures, because a lot of information is provided.
If you are willing to put in the work and get involved, this course can be rewarding. Definitely worth consideration, especially if you have any interest in Italy or Italian language.
If you have any interest in the material take it.
Interesting, and not terribly difficult.
It is an easier class but not extremely interesting.
It was a very interesting course and also not a lot of work besides weekly readings!

It's an easy pdf but an interesting course to learn a lot about the history of Italy through the lens of food. Do the readings so that precepts can be more interesting. Prof. Frassica is a nice elderly, Italian man with a thick accent and light sense of humor. Lectures are chill (if you behave!) but mandatory. Precepts engage you with the readings, give you a chance to present one of the works, and allows you to interact with the class. At the end, you get to cook a meal in groups, which is a plus!
It's easy but you don't learn much.
It's okay. Take if you want to learn a lot about the history of Italy.

JOKE OF A CLASS. I literally skipped every lecture but one, didn't do 90% of the readings, and still got a B+ (pdf'ed it). Take it for a class that will give you no real work and not teach you that much.
Light workload
Make sure to consider the overall themes of the course while doing the readings
PDF
Pretty easy course. Np papers required. However, exams are essay-based.
Recommend taking it to get away from some of the more Maths oriented courses.
Sometimes, easy isn't worth the boredom. Don't do it.
Take it
Take it any year of your Princeton career that your schedule would allow for it
Take it for fun
Take it if you are interested. And if you do take it, do the readings and you can get a really good grade.
Take it if you need a chill course. Not much work aside from readings and studying for the midterm/final.
Take it, it's pretty good.
Take it.

Take it. If you actually care to do the readings, or care at all about the class, you will learn a ton and even get a good grade. Your effort really shows, and the work/readings are not overwhelming. Please take this class but please actually do the do!
Take only if you absolutely need to fulfill LA with little time commitment. This course doesn't teach you much and often feels like a waste of valuable Princeton class time.
Take this class if you want something fun!

Take this course if you can get a good preceptor. I thought it was unfair that certain students had to complete weekly responses while others didn't, based on their preceptor. Exam grading was arbitrary.
Take this course if you want to learn about something new.
Take this course if you're looking for an easy class.
Take this for a fun and relaxed class, but you'll also learn a lot!
Took it for the same reasons
Very easy class especially if PDF selected.  A lot of the material is social and interactive, the readings are interesting and the professors in the italian department are some of the best.
Very easy course, and you'll hopefully learn a few things about Italian culture along the way. The readings are fascinating.
Yes take it very little work.

don't take it. everyone says it's such a great senior class. i do'nt think that's true because you need to do weekly responses and the stuff is boring unless you're into it. the food aspect is overblown as well.
great senior year class
it's a genuinely interesting and fun way of getting your LA. Do it
it's gastro? random AF but kinda interesting and super chill
take if interested in literary significance of food
take it but realize that it will be a lot of work.
take it for the easy class--unless u RLY work u will definately get a b or b  lots of ppl pdf it because its so easy
take this take this take this
prereqs: Prerequisite: 200-level course in Italian is only required for Italian precept(s)..
descrip: This course studies Italian novels and short stories in English translation, works of visual art, and films which thematize food as reality and metaphor, examining how eating functions within ideological and mythological structures of modern society. Topics will include 'Futurist' cuisine as an aesthetic experience and a prophetic vision, writing during the war, and sublime and erotic cuisine.

title: Field Ecohydrology
prereqs: MAT 201.
descrip: This three-week course, offered as part of a four-course study abroad semester, takes place at Princeton University's Mpala Research Centre in central Kenya. The course will provide an introduction to the principles of hydrological sciences through the development and application of instrumentation for characterizing surface/subsurface hydrological dynamics in field settings. Lectures and field activities will address the theory of operation, design, and implementation of methods used to quantify hydrological patterns and processes.

title: The Universe
reviews: Although colloquially called "stars for stoners," you likely would not pass this course if you were stoned the whole time.  It teaches real material and is very interesting, and requires thought in lecture to do problem sets later.

An excellent course for anyone interested in science or astronomy. If you have a math background it won't be overly challenging, but still certainly not a cake walk - i.e. this course is no longer "stars for stoners!" Fascinating material that really makes you think about our tiny role in the incredible expanse of the universe.
Do not wait to do problem sets 2 day before thy are due.
Don't skip the lectures if you can - all of the subject material is very interesting.
Don't take it!
Easy class. Curve is rough. Going to lecture seems like a waste of time, but it's hard to do that well on the exams without it
Go to all the problem sessions, they will help you even if you think you don't need help.
I absolutely loved this course. Take this course if you have any interest whatsoever in space.
I took this course PDF for my QR and enjoyed it.  The lectures provide a fun, interesting, and not-too-difficult introduction to basic concepts of astronomy.
I would consider taking the course - the professors really care about it and the pace is a good pace.
It isn't as light in workload as I thought it would be; the problem sets could take up a significant amount of time.  As an engineer, all the problems are doable; just be prepared to do some work.
It may be difficult if you're a humanities major who doesn't want to PDF the course. Otherwise it's quite enjoyable!
It's a very doable and interesting class for someone who wants to gain a broad introduction to contemporary astrophysics.
It's harder than you might expect.
Make sure you are not completely terrified by physics, because you use more than you would expect. Also, GO TO THE LECTURES!
Math is not hard. There will be a lot of BSE students taking it.  Material is interesting.
Pretty chill class.
Take it especially as a PDF and if you can do any math at all

Take it!  It's a great way to fulfill the QR distribution.  I chose the PDF option, but even with normal grading, the course does not require a ton of work, since problem sets are due every 2 weeks, as opposed to every week, like in most math/science courses.  The problem sets do require a significant amount of time, though, so make sure you don't procrastinate.  And don't hesitate to go to office hours - the professors are very helpful.

Take it!!!!!!! One of my favorite classes here. This is it if you're looking for something interesting but low maintenance. It might be better if you come in with an interest in astronomy or science because I also had friends in the class who were not interested in the material and did not enjoy it.
Take it.  Its interesting and not too hard, especially if you have some sort of math/science background

Take it. It's a good class for senior spring, although I kind of wish I took it earlier because I would have probably continued taking astro classes. If you don't have a science background, the assignments will take longer but there are a ton of office hours (5 instructors' worth!) and problem sessions the night before each pset is due. The instructors are genuinely excited about the course and are eager to answer students' questions. Probably one of the best courses I have taken at Princeton in terms of how it was structured and run. Also, go to the observing sessions! They're really cool.

Take this class if you're at all interested in the topics. Very interesting, minimal workload (biweekly problem sets with office hours), no reading. Attend lectures though, tests are based only on lectures.
Take this course!
Take this course.
The most interesting course I have taken at Princeton, and well within the abilities/time constraints of a non-physics/astrophysics major. One course in AST should be required of all students.
This class requires work but if you have a good TA it should be no problem.

This is a good overview class. The problem sets are not particularly hard and don't require you to pay that much attention in lecture or to the books. The math is pretty basic, but the problems you solve with them are interesting.

This is definitely a great course, it is incredibly interesting and engaging, and the material is at about a high-school-science level of difficulty. The grading curve is pretty harsh because of this, but it's still well worth it to see the cool material and learn about the universe in general.
To fulfill a distribution requirement, you will probably learn more by PDFing a harder class.
Yes! If you have an interest in astrophysics at all, I recommend this course.
if they want an easy class, take it
so well taught - really interesting intro course! the professors are all pretty invested and the material is interesting and straightforward if you put in the time!
prereqs: This course is intended for humanities and social science majors; however, familiarity with high school algebra and geometry will be assumed. An introductory high school physics course will also be useful..
descrip: This specially designed course targets the frontier of modern astrophysics. Subjects include the planets of our solar system, the birth, life, and death of stars; the search for extrasolar planets and extraterrestrial life; the zoo of galaxies from dwarfs to giants, from starbursts to quasars; dark matter and the large-scale structure of the universe; Einstein's special and general theory of relativity, black holes, neutron stars, and big bang cosmology. This course is designed for the non-science major and has no prerequisites past high school algebra and geometry. High school physics would be useful.

title: Workshop on Social Organization
descrip: A two-semester course for graduate students whose work is at the intersection of the fields of organization studies, economic sociology and social network analysis. In addition to covering foundational readings in these fields and addressing selected special topics (e.g. social organizational aspects of economic crisis), the workshop provides opportunities for students to develop research projects and presentation skills, and to read the work of and interact with scholars brought to campus by the Center for the Study of Social Organization.

title: American Evangelicalism
reviews: A real shame that Ryan's leaving after this year... he's one of the best professors I've ever had (what other professor gives you his cell phone number and tells you to call him at home if you ever have questions???). Amazing lecturer, great sense of humor, eminently fair, and also just a really good person to talk to (my paper conference with him turned into a personal conversation about life!). He's also one of the best preceptors I've ever had. The topic is fascinating as well, and the readings were great. My only complaint is that I wish that Ryan had actually assigned more readings. I felt that writing the paper was extremely difficult only because I really didn't know enough about each movement (for example, writing about the Enlightenment, which we touched on in class, was very difficult because we read almost no sources on the subject). That being said, it's probably a good sign that you're doing a good job teaching when the only feedback I can give is "tell us more!!!"

Hands down the BEST CLASS I've taken in my entire Princeton career! The material is super interesting and engaging, and Professor Harper does a wonderful job to get students start thinking about the key questions. He's very humble, approachable, and knowledgeable about the topic. I'm very sad that this was the first and last time this class was offered by him at Princeton.
I don't think that Ryan is staying next year, and it's clear that the course is "very Ryan" so I don't know how it will be in future years.
I would advise another student considering this course to prepare for an experience that alters prior understanding of what "American Evangelicalism" actually is
It's a great course and if you stay engaged it's easy to have fun with it.
Participate in class and precept discussions and attend office hours. There are a lot of topics that could be confusing so discussing them really helps to gain a better understanding.
Take it!
Take it! The material is interesting, even if you don't have any background before!
Take this if you're at all interested, but if it isn't with Ryan then you're missing out.
Whatever your major or your personal relationship to Evangelical Christianity in America, this class will be fascinating and a highlight of your week. Prof. Ryan Harper is amazing.
descrip: This course examines the history, practices, beliefs, and aesthetics of American evangelical Christians. Beginning in the eighteenth century and proceeding to the present day, we will explore the sermons, theological treatises, memoirs, and music of this vast, diverse, often hard-to-define group of Christians. Students will learn how to compare and contrast varieties of evangelical Christianities and how to assess the relationship between evangelicalism and American culture.

title: Intermediate Turkish II
reviews: Do it!

I would strongly recommend taking this course to anyone who is interested in learning Turkish. With continuous homework and clear explanations, this course in a very short time enables one to efectively communicate and read in Turkish.
Intermediate Turkish is a course that will deeply improve your proficiency in the language. I strongly recommend it!

Prof. Gilson is retiring, so I can't predict what next year's Turkish classes will be like, but TUR 107 has been a huge and positive part of my final year at Princeton.  Classes are fun, not too challenging, not too easy, and extremely rewarding if you're interested in foreign languages and cultures.  It was worth having class Friday morning.
Professor Gilson is the greatest.

Turkish is a beautiful language because you can basically create a word for any thought that you can think of. I strongly recommend taking it. Turkish culture is also fascinating and their food is delicious. Could also be valuable to learn considering recent events if you're into politics. Take Turkish!!!!
prereqs: TUR 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: To enable students to communicate in Modern Turkish, and to read Turkish (current events, editorials, literature and academic writings) with some speed and accuracy.

title: Senior Thesis with Design
descrip: Similar to 442 with the principle difference that the thesis must incorporate aspects and principles of design, whether for a system, product, vehicle, device, software, or apparatus. The year-long senior thesis with design may be used to satisfy a portion of the department's design requirement.

title: Utopias, Dystopias, and Manifestos
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Financial Management in the Corporate and Public Sectors
descrip: Designed to introduce graduate students in public and international affairs to certain principals and analytic tools widely used in the financial management of organizations, privately or publicly owned. Course is based on the premise that future civil servants should be familiar with this subject matter, either because they may be involved in the financial management of public agencies, or negotiate financial contracts with the private sector, or regulate financial management in the private sector.

title: Integrated Building Studios
descrip: Integrated design studios approach architecture from a synthetic perspective. Considerations of structure, environmental technology, building materials and systems, exterior envelope, and site design are integrated directly into the design process through the participation of technical faculty and outside advisors in critiques and reviews. Projects are developed to a high level of detail. At least one course is required for professional M.Arch. students.

title: Southeast Asia's Global History
reviews: I think the classes were great. I loved the lecture then open up style and I liked how it was based around a different theme each session. This helped us to tailor our ideas/thoughts when doing the readings. The discussion were open and fun and Professor Laffan was humorous and good at being available when needed! I enjoyed coming to class very much and I think I learned a lot about the region.
Make sure you review the handouts and look at the questions for the next sessions while doing the readings!!!!
Professor Laffan is great. If you have any interest in Southeast Asia then you should take this class.
Take it!
The course is very interesting and not stressful, so it is strongly recommended.
prereqs: PDF option not available to History concenrators..
descrip: This course aims to provide an introduction to Southeast Asia and its prominent place in global history through a series of encounters in time; from Marco Polo in Sumatra to the latest events in such buzzing cities as Bangkok, Jakarta and Hanoi. For the early modern period we will read various primary sources, before turning to consider a series of diverse colonial impacts across the region (European, American and Asian), and then the mechanisms underpinning the formation of some of the most vibrant, and sometimes turbulent, countries on the world stage.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
prereqs: Seniors only (except for juniors who have completed EGR 351)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Optimization Under Uncertainty
prereqs: ORF 307 or MAT 305, and ORF 309.
descrip: A survey of quantitative approaches for making optimal decisions under uncertainty, including decision trees, Monte Carlo simulation, and stochastic programs. Forecasting and planning systems are integrated with a focus on financial applications.

title: Advanced Topology
reviews: I would strongly recommend it, assuming he/she had a firm grasp of prerequisites.

Not sure if/when this class will be offered again, since Nemethi is a visiting prof. (Indeed the course may next be taught by a different professor and/or cover different material when it is.) 
If Professor Nemethi is teaching such a class again, definitely take it if it sounds interesting to you (or at least sit in the first couple of classes and see.) You'll see and learn about a lot of interesting things. 
It'll also be a very relaxed sort of class (maybe this would have changed by the time he teaches here again), in that there is very little homework and there aren't really any tests (our "midterm" and "final" were more like problem sets; collaboration was allowed.) This is good in a way, also because the lack of stress means you can concentrate on actually learning things, but also potentially bad if it reduces the incentive to keep up with what's happening in class. He also cites / mentions a lot of more difficult results without proving them, although he does supply references to where proofs could be found. I guess how much you get out of this class depends a lot on how much you put in. Although you'll still learn about a lot of interesting stuff without putting too much in---you just won't learn it as well or thoroughly.

Prof. Nemethi is visiting, so I don't know if he'll be teaching this course again. But if this course ever does happen again, I would highly recommend it, with the caveat that you should have some background in topology, especially algebraic topology, and at least know definitions from basic algebraic geometry. But that's exactly why the class is great: it brings together different fields in a fun and enlightening way.
prereqs: MAT365 or departmental permission..
descrip: The course will target the following topics: The definition of knots in the 3-sphere, first invariants; algebraic knots and links in the 3-sphere; classification of algebraic knots, Puiseux pairs, iterated torus knots; fibred links, monodromy, the case of algebraic links; higher dimensional algebraic knots, Milnor theory of complex isolated hypersurface singularities.

title: Intermediate Arabic II
reviews: Arabic takes a lot of time perhaps at least 2 hours a night during the week to review old material and learn the intricacies of the new lesson. I was unable to commit that much time to the course and that will be reflected in my grade. Nevertheless I enjoyed the experience.
Be prepared to put work in on your side to ensure that you are staying up to date with your knowledge of the language.
Do the homework, and don't study for quizzes only the night before.

Keep up with daily assignments and grammar - it is much easier to do well on the tests if you have been practicing vocabulary and concepts a bit each day and are not cramming at the end of each unit! And don't be afraid to speak, the speaking time is important and it's ok to make mistakes!
Make sure you are understanding things. Don't take this as an upperclassman unless you're prepared to put in some work.
Prof. Coffin is very funny and sometimes gets distracted but overall you learn a lot.
Take it if you're already committed to doing Arabic. That said, I would only go to 107 if you intend to keep up with Arabic and push for fluency, as otherwise the work is somewhat pointless.
Take it! Arabic is a huge time commitment, but during my oral interview at the end of the year I realized just how much I'd learned.
You get out as much as you put in.
prereqs: ARA 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Study of Arabic grammar and syntax, and use of the language in functional contexts. Reading of extra material from articles, newspapers, short stories. Discussions are held in the Arabic language to enhance the students' speaking skills.

title: Elementary Modern Greek II
prereqs: HLS 101 or equivalent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: To provide the basis for acquiring a command of written and spoken Modern Greek.

title: Intermediate Chinese II
reviews: Do not think twice--take it! You will not regret it. This class is super fun and very effective at teaching Chinese.
Do work daily, pay attention in class, and study, study, study....
Intense, but as always, good.

It is a little easier than first year Chinese, and more interesting. It is not a terrible amount of work once you get a hang of the language. If you are at all interested in Chinese culture, society or history, give these courses a try.
It is a lot of work, but worth it.
It's a lot of time, but it's also fun and very much worthwhile! Also, Chinese is going to be a dominant language in the future. Don't be left out ;)
Keep up with the material!
Make sure you are balancing your course load.
Practice the characters and don't skimp on the homework.
Prepare well. The more you put in, the more you'll get out.
Strongly recommend if you are interested in learning Mandarin and willing to work hard.
Take it
Take it if you actually want to learn Chinese.
Take it! Be prepared to work hard though if you want to do well. It's not hard material but it definitely requires a lot of time.

This course is time intensive, but it gives a thorough understanding of the language. This course also introduces different aspects of Chinese culture that adds flavor. If you put the time into it and apply yourself, this course is a great!
This may be obvious, but do the reading and practice writing the characters before class. This will make class time more productive, and will help prep you for the weekly quizzes.
You get it
You need to invest time in this class.
keep up and be confident!
prereqs: CHI 105 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Continuing the intensive study of modern spoken and written Chinese, this course shifts the emphasis to the reading of modern cultural and social issues.

title: Quantitative Analysis IV
descrip: An introduction to the basic analytical and computational tools of applied Bayesian statistics. Methods covered include multi-level models, mixture modeling, Bayesian model averaging, and models for missing data and causal inference; computational tools taught include the EM algorithm and the Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithms. Goal of the course is to enable students to build and implement their own model in order to answer a particular research question. Course may be of interest to those in disciplines outside of political science who need to learn the basics of applied Bayesian statistics.

title: Cultural Landscapes
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Macroeconomics
reviews: A horrible class. Do not take it unless you have to. Ezra Oberfield's lectures were incredibly boring and his only goal was to teach the textbook. Not once did we apply anything we talked about to the real world of economics. This class is horribly caught up in theory and you won't learn anything about the world by taking this class. If you do have to take the class with Ezra, I recommend putting most of your effort into learning through the textbook. Try to get Niklas Engbom as your preceptor.
Definitely take this over 311.
Do not take this unless it's required. If you are averse to math, this is the worst of all evils. If you enjoy math, take a more rigorous course
Don't take it with Ezra.  Well meaning but will make you want to enter a comatose state.
Don't take it.
Don't take this unless you have to. It is manageable and somewhat interesting but is a struggle unless you like the material or need the class.

Ezra's lectures are very boring,often difficult to follow, and among the worst I have ever experienced.  Nik Engbom was a great preceptor, however, so if you have to take this class, he can be super helpful.

Felt pretty disjoint -- homework is not super related to classwork, exam was a completely different take on the lecture material, and precepts didn't feel super useful. Lectures are very informative, though the 8.30 am lecture in the architecture building was brutal. Hearing Oberfield talk through things and then having the lecture notes to review are definitely a blessing.
Fine
Go to lecture!
Go to precept
Go to precept and office hours. It's much more helpful to review the material after having had a chance to absorb the subject matter after lecture.

I loved having So as my preceptor. He was always very available to answer questions. Problem sets could be confusing without knowing how to technically manipulated models, so definitely go to office hours for help. Exams were very simple, and very straightforward.

I thought this course was super boring, but if you're an ECO major, you have to take it anyway (I'd still prefer this to ECO 311). If you're not an ECO major, don't take it - it's really boring. I liked ECO 101 so much better.
I would absolutely not take this class if Professor Oberfield is teaching.  He is boring and you don't learn much.
I wouldn't recommend this class unless you need it for an Econ departmental.
If you are an economics major, you have to take this course.  If you're interested in macroeconomics but don't need the course, I think specific case studies would be a little more interesting.
If your in this coruse you probably dont have a choice so just do it.

In general, I found this class very theoretical and vague, with concepts and "effects of X on Y" shown vaguely on graphs. While not too interesting or engaging, as a required core class, it was still worth taking and taught me   theoretical macro tools that were useful.
Not a bad class to take for a required class.
Practical knowledge for the real world, would recommend for non-Econ majors.

Probably the worst taught course I've taken at Princeton. Lectures were often disorganized and inefficient. Ezra tends to write down literally everything he says on the board, so much of the class is us waiting for him to write in silence. The time could be filled with additional examples or explanations so that I didn't feel so unprepared come time for problem sets. Preceptors were minimally helpful, but thank God for the curve, which is ridiculously easy. Material itself is actually incredibly easy, it's just poorly taught
Take clear notes in class.
Take it if you are an econ major.
Take it with a different professor.
Take it with another professor
Take this class if you have to. Otherwise it's not really worth it. Intro macro has some pretty similar stuff.
Take this over 311 (I hear that course is brutal), but don't expect this to be exciting. If you get a chance to choose, definitely have Nik as your preceptor.
The course is manageable and the problem sets and exams are fair.  Take it if you are not so mathematically inclined.
This is a pretty easy course. You might not learn much more than in ECO 101 (at least that's what I've heard). But I heard 311 is pretty tough so I'd go with this course.
This is a solid but not great econ class
You are taking this because you are an Econ major. Go to office hours and read the textbook, because lectures will frustrate you and be inadequate to teach you the material.
You have to take it so there isn't much you can do to avoid it.
You have to take it. Just do it.
get through it
recommend, if you want to learn more than eco101
seriously the worst class I've taken in the economics department so far.
take only if you have to for major.
take over 311 if you have to take one
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101..
descrip: This course covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. We will focus on the determination of macroeconomic variables -- such as output, employment, price, and the interest rate -- in the short, medium, and long run, and we will address a number of policy issues. We will discuss several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth.

title: Studies in German Language and Style: Contemporary Society, Politics, and Culture
reviews: Take your time with the essays. Don't start the night before!

While the material covered in class was very interesting, class was sometimes very awkward and sometimes boring. Most classes we listened to prof Saman lecture for the entire class period. If there was better class discussion I think the class would have been much better.
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: The course offers an introduction to post-1945 German culture, society, and politics through a number of historical documents, literary works, and films. Topics include: the aftermath of WWII (Stunde Null); denazification; the founding of both German Republics; the economic miracle (Wirtschaftswunder); the legacy of National Socialism; attempts to define a new Germany; the student revolts; pop culture; reunification; and Germany's new role in Europe. Through the close study of the assigned material, this course aims at advancing the students' competence in both oral and written German.

title: Advanced Physical Chemistry: Chemical Dynamics and Thermodynamics
reviews: Attending the lecture and reading the book are interchangeable.
Get the other textbooks Professor Wang uses from the library (or buy your own copy), and do the problems from them.
I'm glad I took this over CHM 306, but pick whichever you think suits you best.
If you're taking it just for the departmental, take quantum instead. This class is mostly just a waste of your good time. Quantum will actually teach you interesting stuff.
Take it over 305 if you're comfortable with calculus.

This is semi-rigorous introduction to thermodynamics covering from partition functions through basic kinetics. It isn't interesting from a mathematica or chemical perspective, really just something many people have to take to understand why certain chemical reactions happen - its the nuts and bolts behind the -G<0 requirement. The work load isn't insane but the midterms are difficult. DO NOT take this class with professor Wang - she is very difficult to understand.
spend the time to make sure you understand the hw problems.
prereqs: MAT 201 or equivalent. Some knowledge of thermodynamics is useful. This course is open to freshmen and sophomores only with instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is an introduction to statistical thermodynamics, kinetics, and molecular reaction dynamics. Following a review of classical thermodynamics, the statistical mechanics of molecular systems is developed. Discussions of transport properties, chemical kinetics, and reaction dynamics form the rest of the course.

title: Religion in the Americas Workshop
prereqs: REL 523.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on the current research of visiting presenters, current students, and faculty in American religious history. Designed primarily for Ph.D. students in the field, but is open as well to undergraduate concentrators with a strong background in the study of American religion and culture. Note: REL 523 (fall) and REL 524 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Dissertation Seminar
descrip: Open to post-generals students actively working on their dissertations. The seminar aims at assisting students in their research and writing and at developing their teaching skills by improving their ability to present advanced material to less expert audiences. Students make presentations of work in progress, discuss each other's work, and share common pedagogical problems and solutions under the guidance of one or more faculty members. It meets for two hours each week throughout the academic year.

title: Policy Aspects of Federal and State Budgeting and Fiscal Decision-Making
reviews: I would advise you to take this class. The issues covered in the class, especially the fiscal issues the U.S. must act on (Social Security reform, tax reform, deficit reduction, etc.), are a must-know for all hoping to go into policy. The info on taxes/budget construction is also good to know.  Professor Keevey is a great discussion leader and ensures everyone understands the material.
Take It.
Take it, Professor Keevey is awesome. The subject matter is relevant and interesting, its a great class!
Take it. Great class, great professor.
descrip: The course will discuss key aspects of federal and state budgetary decision-making and its impact on policy. The course will examine budgeting, taxation, bond financing, pensions and long-term debt and its impact on future spending patterns. It will examine implications of the recent confrontation over budget in Washington and what it means for the future. While the federal government spends more money than any other enterprise, states and local governments in the aggregate spend just as much and thus the course will consider the significant financial differences between the two levels of government and the impact both have on our economy.

title: Poverty, Inequality and Health in the World
prereqs: WWS 507 and 511. Please see instructor to apply for enrollment..
descrip: About well-being throughout the world, with focus on income and health. Explores what happened to poverty, inequality, and health, in the US, and internationally. Discusses conceptual foundations of national and global measures of inequality, poverty, and health; construction of measures, and extent to which they can be trusted; relationship between globalization, poverty, and health, historically and currently. Examines links between health and income, why poor people are less healthy and live less long than rich people.

title: Topics in Geometric Analysis and General Relativity - Advanced Topics in General Relativity
prereqs: Undergrads must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will cover a selection of advanced topics in General Relativity, which could include the construction of dynamical black hole spacetimes, the formation of weak null singularities for the vacuum, and the stability of the Schwarzschild black hole.

title: Topics in History, Analysis, and Interpretation - Comparative Analysis
prereqs: Music 206 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Evaluation of competing methods of analysis through direct comparison of multiple analyses of the same compositions. Methods include Schenkerian, topical, motivic, set-theoretic and hermeneutical. Compositions by J.S. Bach, Beethoven, Stravinsky and Bartok. Weekly analytical exercises.

title: Cell Biology and Development
reviews:
-Read the recommended textbook and/or reviews pertaining to topics discussed to gain a better understanding of the overall concepts.
-Come to class with notes already written on the main approach, results, and conclusions of each figure to help with participation
-Write down questions as you think of them while reading papers and ask during class.

-its not the other students' fault but the incentive structure put into place to make us participate was ridiculous. So much time wasted with students asking questions that they didn't want the answer to. Could spend more time putting together an incentive structure that helps students catch up with the basics of development. undergraduate textbook readings with a nominal quiz grade to encourage reading.
Get a Development textbook if you do not have prior knowledge in this field.
Get an undergraduate text and read it before class. Ask a lot of questions. don't take it with genetics if you can help it.
Have access to a copy of a developmental textbook for references
It's most likely going to change, but overall it's a decent course. If you're willing to put in the work you really can learn a lot.
Read the Gilbert textbook.
Start thinking about proposal ideas early, and get as many people as possible to read it and give their input. Study as much as you can for all the exams because you won't know what to expect.
Take it.
Take undergrad development first or read a development textbook first.
The subject matter of the course is very interesting and I think with time it will become better structured.
They need to improve organization

This course assumes you have some developmental background already, so it can be difficult if you have never taken developmental bio before. But yes, it does help you learn how to muck through papers that are totally outside of your realm, which is a good skill to build.
Try to pay attention during Development even though the class is awful.
descrip: A continuation of MOL 504, with two modules, Cell Biology II and Development. Cell Biology II concerns how cells assemble into functional tissues, covering the molecular components and fundamental concepts in cell communication, adhesion, shape, division, and differentiation. Development covers the basics of developmental biology, focusing on important concepts and model systems. Primary literature is used to introduce seminal works and classic approaches, modern experimental techniques, and outstanding questions in the field. Students learn the basis of a good paper, to read critically, and to think beyond the reading.

title: Mathematics for Economics/Life Sciences
reviews: Be prepared to work hard - your grades won't be handed to you, but the effort will be worth it.

Both professors are great, but I had Professor Johnson in particular and she was awesome. Take it with her if you can. Also, if you are genuinely interested in math, you might be better off doing other more advanced math classes because this one shies away from complicated details.
Decent course
Do not take unless you need to, material is moderately difficult but material tested is very difficult
Don't get behind on the problem sets. If you do, sit down for a few hours to get caught up on the weekends.
Don't take this course with Vlaeminck. She doesn't teach and often can't answer problems or solve example problems/makes tons of mistakes
Go to all the classes, office hours and review sessions that you can as the teaching is very good and the instructors are always keen to clarify any topics that you don't understand very well.
Go to extra help sessions and office hours because Jennifer Johnson is very helpful.

I wouldn't particularly recommend this course as a general interest sort of course, but if you need to take a multivariable and linear course/courses for prerequisites, I'd definitely recommend this course as a great option for covering the important points in one semester.
If you are an econ/bio major, don't suffer through 104 and 201, 175 provides plenty of knowledge.
If you need it for a concentration requirement, take it but be prepared for a long, tedious process.
It's a challenge but if you have taken calculus before you will be fine.
It's not very hard unless you need to get an A.
Make sure you address problems early on.
Not as scary as other math classes here, take it if you have to.
Only take it if you have to for a departmental.
Prof. Johnson is great!! take it with her. Really caring about her course and very nice.
Professor Johnson is amazing. She is so willing to help her students. She is funny and kind. If you take this course, take it with her. She is wonderful. Go to her office hours.
Review all of the learned material every so often.
Start the psets earlier in the week so you have more context for lectures and can ask questions at office hours!
Stay on top of your work!

Stay on top of your work. Go to McGraw, get a tutor, go to office hours, do the homework, and you will be fine. Unlike MAT 103, the instructors are not trying to trick you. If you understand the material, though it is extremely demanding and difficult, you will do well in the course.
Structured, organized math course. Professors are helpful.

Take Johnson because she is a fantastic teacher.  She teaches the concepts very well and clears up anything by answering questions in a very helpful way.  Class is difficult but not impossible.  Pretty important to attend class and do readings
Take advantage of office hours and the sunday review sessions.  I wish that I had done this earlier on in the semester.
Take it for an quality math course if you don't need 201/202
Take it if you're entering Princeton having taken AP Calc BC but feel you weren't THAT solid in it.  It covers several to many of the topics in 201 without as much rigor.
Take it if you're generally interested in the material, or if you have to. Don't be afraid of it.
Take it with Professor Johnson!
Take it with Professor Johnson.
Take it!
Take this course
This course is fair, well-organized, and a great introduction to math at Princeton.
Try and start off strong, because the course gets gradually harder, although it won't be too hard if it is not your first math class at Princeton.
take it with Jennifer Johnson - she's the best
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Survey of topics in calculus and linear algebra as preparation for future course work in economics or life sciences. Topics include basic techniques of integration, average value, improper integrals and rates of growth, partial derivatives, gradient, Lagrange multipliers, linear systems, determinants, matrix inversion, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, as time permits.

title: The Great Recession: Causes, Consequences, and Remedies
reviews: 8:30 lectures are not fun. Honestly, Krugman is not a great lecturer

A good class for anyone who wants to better understand what happened (and is continuing to happen!) during the Recession.  Krugman definitely has a strong opinion on most topics covered in class but at least tries to show the other side... still left feeling a bit brainwashed though.  All in all, pretty decent ride.
A nice course, a bit cluttered but with a decent workload and a nice overview of the topic.
Absolutely take this course with Prof. Krugman. You will be an expert on the recession after you go through it and will understand the world around you and where we're going much, much better.
Definitely take it - even if it's 8:30 Monday morning. It's well worth it.
Definitely take it just for Krugman.
Don't bother - he's a big name, but the class is a dud.
Don't take it if you are looking to learn. Take it for a tiny workload. But then I don;t think Paul Krugman is teaching this ever again...
Don't think this will be offered again, but if it is, definitely take it! I've learned so much more about the financial crisis and about the world in general.
Easy class with a very tight grade distribution.
Great course. More influential to my understanding of current events than any other course I have taken. Too bad Professor Krugman is leaving, taking a class with him was an honor and a privilege.
Great course. You learn a ton about the economy, why recessions happen, and what has been done.

Highly recommend, especially if Professor Krugman is teaching (sad that he's leaving!). Very informative, very interesting. I feel that I have a much stronger grasp on the institutions involved in the Great Recession, and my own, very minimal role in the great machinery that is the global economy.
I really enjoyed the course. With no problem sets, you get the chance to learn about the concepts without it being a heavy workload class. If you're interested in the material, you should take it!

I would recommend this course to other students, but only if they're very interested in economics to begin with and enjoy Krugman's perspective. It might hurt your GPA a bit, but if you like Krugman it's worth it!

If you're interested in the recession and know nothing about economics, maybe take this course, but try to save on sleep by getting a circle of friends to record the lectures. Or who knows, maybe it will be better without Krugman. If you're an econ major, don't take this course unless you've been living under a rock, or want an easy good grade.

It's a pretty awesome class. I think Krugman is a generally unsociable professor though, so he'll talk about econ and answer questions, but he's not going to feel like the most approachable professor. Still, I really liked his lecture style??it was very VERY easy to understand.
It's good if you are highly interested in the material, but otherwise you'll probably wind up skipping a lot of lectures.
Krugman is very interesting.
Krugman.
Neel is a wonderful preceptor. Take this class if you would like to meet Professor Krugman. You get to hear his views on other economists.
No grading rubric. Very strict curve.
PDF it.

Paul Krugman is a great researcher and columnist, but definitely not the best lecturer you can find in the ECO department. I regret taking this class (PDFing despite having an A) because the time spent on this course was simply not worth it--could have learned the material on my own in a week. That being said, I'm glad that I took a course with a Nobel Laureate and learned it the hard way that Nobel Laureates != great professors.
Preceptors are good, but Krugman is terrible!
Prof. Krugman was a amazing - a must take.
Professor Krugman gives a great series of lectures, but the class is otherwise poorly structured and organized.
Stay on top of the readings.
Take it for the professor!
Take it if you are okay with an unstructured form of lecturing
Take it if you want to learn the economics about a hop topic in the news and thus be able to make your own judgments instead of relying on the media.

Take it if you're interested in hearing Prof Krugman's commentary -- I learned so much and really enjoyed the economic history rundown of the financial crisis. It's been one of my favorite courses at Princeton. But don't think that you'll get much, if any, personalized time with Prof Krugman. Take it just if you want to hear his commentary on different topics -- brilliant, but not necessarily aimed towards getting to know you, and not necessarily the best-prepared lectures either.
Take it!
Take it! Disorganized but interesting and doesn't require much work on a weekly basis. Break up readings in a study group before the exams.
Take it, but maybe p/d/f it.
Take it. It's really interesting and you learn a lot.
Take the class, esp if it's not at 8.30am
Take the course, I'd imagine it will be better structured next time
Take this class if you're interested in the material, and PDF it if you plan on not being able to do a lot of the readings during the week. Although, this is Krugman's last year here....
Take this course if you want to listen Professor Krugman talk about an interesting time in economic history with which he is familiar. But don't have any lofty expectations for it otherwise.
Take this course!! Next year is his last time teaching it :(
Take this course, though in the future it likely won't be Krugman teaching it.  The best part of the class is the readings; you'll learn a ton if you read them.
The material is great but it is definitely a class to take if you have PDFs available and just want to learn about the recession.

This class was pretty disorganized with Krugman (almost hilariously so), but I definitely enjoyed it.  Lots of practical information and not too much to do outside of class (other than readings, which weren't entirely necessary to keep up with what was going on)

This course wasn't great, but it's really important to understand the causes of the financial crisis and recession. The readings were very interesting and offered good insight into the current state of macro, and a basic understanding of these issues would serve anybody well.
With Krugman retiring, it's hard to say what the next offering of this course will look like. Take it if Krueger or Blinder is teaching.
You need to be very strongly motivated yourself and really remember to keep up with the readings.
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101 and ECO 202.
descrip: This course covers topics related to the current economy and current economic policy. The course will begin by reviewing the causes of the recession that began in December 2007. It will concentrate on consumer behavior, financial markets, unemployment, and the housing sector. The role of public policies in contributing to the economic crisis and in ending the crisis will be explored. The state of the recovery will be assessed and monitored. The course will also consider current economic policy priorities.

title: Grand Strategy
reviews: A lot of reading, but most of it is very interesting stuff. If you keep up with lectures and at least do some of the readings you'll learn a lot from this class.
Absolutely take this class!
Decent for an overview/survey of various aspects of theory and IR
Do the readings
Don't become complacent even if the material is familiar or you've already read some of the readings.  The class is not easy and the grading can be tough.
Great course, even if you have very little politics / international relations background. Do the simulations!
I really appreciated how the course covered the overlap between military and political/diplomatic strategy

I would really recommend taking this class, even if for general interest! The material covered is so so interesting, and lectures with Professor Friedberg are very insightful!  There is a lot of reading particularly as the semester progresses, so make sure you find someone in the class to split the reading with.

I would strongly recommend people take this course ? it is quite fantastic. I will warn that the course is a good deal of reading and that the topics covered are far from simple, but it is most certainly worth the work.
If you want to do well in the course you are going to have to invest a lot of time and effort into it, but it's a great PDF option
Interesting class, a lot of reading though.
Lots of interesting concepts; an ideal class to PDF. Grading on the exams was very nitpicky, bordering on unreasonable (ie: miss out one line that links idea A to B and lose a grade).
Split readings. Also this class is about military only, basically.

Split up the readings with friends - you won't be able to get through it all yourself. Precepts were educational but they weren't discussions - just about stuff from the readings. OK class, nothing special.
Stay on top of the readings.
TAKE IT. And even though there is so much reading, doing it will make the class a million times easier.
Take it! Professor Friedberg is a treasure.
Take this course if you are interested in history and general military strategy.
Take this course!

There's just too much reading to feel like you have a really good grasp of the material. Try to take this class with friends and designate readings. You need to be interested in this material to make it through this class, but if you are naturally interested in strategic thinking this is a great overview of grand strategies throughout history. You will learn something.

Too much reading to possibly do unless this is a departmental. Lecture is a bit hit and miss. 
Friedberg is interesting but (imho) attributes far too much coherence to all grand strategy.
You will learn a lot, the readings are a little scary, but as long as you go to lecture and are engaged you should be fine.
prereqs: Some knowledge of U.S. European, and/or Asian history is essential, through there are no prerequisite courses.
descrip: Grand strategy is the broad and encompassing policies and undertakings that political leaders pursue-financial, economic, military, diplomatic-to achieve their objectives inpeacetime and in war. This course will examine the theory and practice of grand strategy both to illuminate how relations among city-states, empires, kingdoms and nation states have evolved over the centuries and also to identify some common challenges that have confronted all who seek to make and execute grand strategy from Pericleses to Barack Obama.

title: Radical Political Thought
reviews: A great introduction to some very important theorists.
Be careful taking this course if you are not accustomed to philosophy classes.
Be prepared to read a lot, but to learn a lot too

Do you identify as a radical leftist? Take this course. Are you moderate Democrat who wants to better understand the left? Take this course. Are you a conservative who wants to see the truth? Take this course. Please, please, just take this course. It'll change your perspective on society forever.
Extremely dry and dense. Unless you really like political theory, take something else.

Good to take from a history perspective, but be prepared to read a lot of long, dry manifestos. Readings can be overwhelming (150  pages of primary sources a week) and lecture may be hard to follow without already having done the reading.
I would take it if you are interested in pol theory as it offers a good general overview of a lot of interesting figures, however, if not take another course.
If you aim to have any understanding of the political Left this is a truly incredible course; impressive in its range of ideas, enjoyable in its presentation of them.
If you're interested in these topics of political thought, Professor Muller does an excellent job presenting them. The material is rich and engaging. I would definitely suggest it.
If you've ever been intrigued by radical politics, take this class! The readings are great (please do them), and Prof Muller is a fantastic lecturer
It is a fine class but not super engaging.
It's one of the most informative classes you'll probably take but very dense and demanding, so I'd only recommend it to students who are up to the challenge.
Keep up with the readings and take good notes to pass the final.
Note: there is a LOT of reading, and if you don't do it you will be lost.
Only take this if you are willing to really dive into lots of awesome but challenging reading, and to really think about your papers.  Awesome class though.  It will make you think.

Prof. Muller is a really wonderful lecturer, and this material is really fascinating and important to know. I just wish some of the expectations for written work had been clearer, and that I had been able to do more of the reading (it's pretty extensive and dense).
Prof. Werner-Mueller is an excellent lecturer. If you are on the fence about taking this class, my advise is for you to do it!
Put a lot of effort in the essays. Do not fall behind.
Really engage with the readings and go to every lecture or else you will fall behind!
Really good if you're interested in the material.
Really interesting but not a class to take for fun - lots of readings and intense final projects.
Strongly recommended; do the readings though, as they help know whats going on in lecture. Warning: 200 pages per week is very common.
Take if it sounds interesting to you - lectures are great.
Take it its fun

Take it. Professor Mueller is an excellent lecturer and you'll learn a lot of interesting things. Unless you're allergic to reading (quite frankly, the reading load is kind of heavy); then you might want to think twice. But you should still consider take it.
Take the class! But be ready to work very hard; do NOT take it in the midst of an already heavy reading lad like I did, so that you can get the most out of it
Take this course - these are people you should read and the class is well run.
Take this course! Professor Muller's lectures are some of the best I've attended at Princeton. The course is great for non-politics majors who are interested in learning about political theory.
This course has quite a bit of reading, but for the most part, I enjoyed it.
Typical Princeton class that would be way better if the reading load was cut in half. Still, not too hard to get a B so long as you know how to write.
Yes.
You'd better really love opaque radical thinkers and want to spend a lot of time reading their stuff.
generally good, but there was too much reading to discuss all of it in a meaningful way
descrip: This course will examine traditions of political thought--mostly, but not only, on the Left--which challenge mainstream conceptions of liberal democracy and modern capitalist society. The main focus will be on Marxism, anarchism, feminism, religious radicalism, ecological thought, and critiques of alienation in everyday life. Particular attention is paid to the relationship between political and cultural criticism, and to the philosophical anthropologies underlying different theories as well as the mechanisms for social change they envisage. We also ask if liberal democratic thought can effectively respond to radical challenges.

title: Comparative Physiology
reviews: A LOT of work but so rewarding and interesting. Learned so much!!!
Be prepared to memorize a ton of stuff! Pay attention in lecture too!
Definitely do all of Professor Ben-Hamo's extra credit problem sets. The questions she asks are very thought-provoking and interesting!

Great course, very interesting material, absolutely recommend. Manageable and fun. Lab assistants and TA are fabulous. Great atmosphere. Trip to Six Flags to see African mammals. How can you go wrong?

If you are even slightly interested in the subject, definitely take it! Lectures are fascinating, and the labs give you a great hands-on look at some of the things you learn about. One of my favorite classes I've taken!
It was a good course to take if you are interested in physiology, anatomy and evolution
Keep up with the reading!
So much information. Great lab!
Study hard. This is probably the best lab you will take while at Princeton.
Take Comparative Physiology! You will learn a lot and actually love what you learn.
Take it, especially if you're pre-med. It really adds to your knowledge of anatomy/physiology.
Take the course if you are interested in physiology, it is really interested. Otherwise, it is a ton of work that you would not like.
The labs in this course were really cool and almost enough to make up for the rest of it, but if you aren't into the labs, I would not recommend.

This class is really difficult, but the instructors are fair and very accommodating to students. If you are taking the MCAT, this might be a good review of content you will need for the biology section.
Very good, interesting class. Worth the 9 am lectures, even if just to do the lab.

Very well-taught and very interesting. The hardest parts were midterm and final. They really tested whether we knew the material but it did feel like the tested material was above what we had learned, which was kind of frustrating. The professor and staff were all extremely helpful and friendly though, which made the class extremely enjoyable.
prereqs: EEB 211.
descrip: This course explores the mechanisms of animal function in the contexts of evolution, ecology and behavior. We will cover the physiological bases of osmoregulation, circulation, gas exchange, digestion, energetics, motility, and neural and hormonal control of these and other processes in a variety of vertebrate and invertebrate animals, thereby revealing general principles of animal physiology as well as specific physiological adaptations to differing environments.

title: Topics in Anthropology - Revisiting Sacrifice
prereqs: Open to juniors, seniors and graduate students in Anthropology. Other students can be accepted depending on instructor's permission..
descrip: The course brings back to discussion a concept and a set of practices central to the lives of millions of men and women across the world. While sacrifice is invoked in religious and political discourse and practice, it has been somewhat neglected by anthropologists in recent decades. Understanding sacrifice is understanding ritual and religion and their role in the globalizing world. Topics include theories of sacrifice, categories and comparison, genealogies and deconstruction, violence, power and religion, jihad, sacrifice and terror. We will study contemporary materials from public discourses and arts before going back to classical theory.

title: Philosophy of Language
descrip: Names and Descriptions: The seminar is organized around the close readings of two seminal books in the philosophy of language: by Saul Kripke and Stephen Neale. Background readings will include primary sources for Frege's distinction between sense and reference; Russell's theory of descriptions; Lewis's counterpart theory; Grice's theory of conversational implicature, and E-type Anaphora among others.

title: Iran Since the Revolution
descrip: This course examines the formation and development of the Islamic Republic of Iran in the aftermath of the 1979 revolution. It considers, in particular, how the Iranian regime has adapted to changing domestic and international economic, social and political conditions and sustained itself enface grave social and economic challenges and international isolation. Topics of discussion include: Social Movements and Political Reform, Clerical Opposition and Dissident Theology, Changing Interpretations of Religious Law, Missed Opportunities in US-Iran relations, Iran's role in the Middle East, the nuclear question.

title: Writing the History of Art
reviews: Go ahead and register!

I would recommend this class to any art history major, especially one trying to fulfill a distribution 2.  I love it! fascinating class.  It may seem like a lot of writing but it is actually extremely manageable because there is no term paper.  The class was interesting and no stress: a great way to really challenge your brain without the anxiety.
TAKE IT! It will change how you think about art for the rest of your life!
prereqs: ART 400 and four additional Art and Archaeology courses or instructor's consent..
descrip: Meant for students planning or beginning graduate work, this course examines assumptions that have troubled the writing of art history since the birth of our discipline, e.g., the teleological fallacy, which is deeply embedded in our ideas about styles and periods, and more recent notions that try to relate the history of art to some larger history by positing a metaphysical entity that shapes or directs the production of art. We want to find ways of thinking about the art of the past that give due attention to context without depriving artists and patrons of free will. Technical studies and perceptual psychology will also be introduced.

title: Studies in Ancient Judaism - The Study of Torah in Ancient Judaism
descrip: This course examines the representation of Torah study in ancient Jewish texts, focusing on historical developments in the construction of Torah, wisdom, and intellectual activity; on the relationship between these concepts and the structure of Jewish communities and texts; and on the extent to which the practice of and discourse on Torah study was informed by other intellectual traditions of the ancient world, such as the Greco-Roman tradition and its concept of paideia.

title: Theory of Games
reviews: Be prepared for math

If you're interested in the topic, then take this course. It covered a lot of different topics about the subject, and covered them pretty comprehensively. The grading's a bit tough, but start the problem sets early and you'll be fine.
Pay VERY close attention to the homework in this class and be alert and focused and you'll do fine.  This is weird to take as a Math major.  This feels like more of an Econ class, honestly.
There's a guest lecture by John Nash!
prereqs: MAT 202, 204, 217 or equivalent. MAT 215 or equivalent is recommended..
descrip: Games in extensive form, pure and behavioral strategies; normal form, mixed strategies, equilibrium points; coalitions, characteristic-function form, imputations, solution concepts; related topics and applications.

title: Philosophy of Science
descrip: There has recently been much interest in various "structuralist" views in the philosophy of science, the philosophy of math, and metaphysics. We discuss a range of literature on this topic, with particular attention to the role that symmetry plays in motivating and formulating these views.

title: The Civilization of the Early Middle Ages
reviews: Absolutely take it.

Go to every lecture and precept, and ask as many questions as you'd like. I would also recommend going to office hours, if you have further questions. Both Professor Reimitz and Ian were incredibly willing to help.
Helmut covers interesting material well
It's a very good choice if you need an HA. A lot of the class comes from outside majors and the workload is very manageable. The material is interesting as well.
Take it.
Take it. Do the readings.
The course is great, but I would definitely only recommend it to those with at least a minimum of an interest level in the topic at hand, otherwise the readings become overwhelming and boring.

This course is great so long as you stick with it and do the reading. The secondary sources are really important to be able to connect everything together. DO NOT NEGLECT THEM! Professor Reimitz is great and well worth taking a class from.
This course is very fun if you are interested in the time period.
Very interesting course on a less-than-well-known period of history. Take it is you need an HA, but be ready for lots of reading.
go to lecture, befriend Professor Reimitz, and read all of the primary sources - all of them !
if you love history you will love the course.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course will survey the "Dark Ages" from the end of the Roman Empire to the end of the first millennium (ca. 400-1000 AD), often seen as a time of cultural and political decline, recently even labelled as the "end of civilization". The complex political and social landscape of the Roman Empire, however, had more to offer than just to end. This course will outline how early medieval people(s) in the successor states of the Roman Empire used its resources to form new communities and will suggest to understand the "Dark Ages" as a time of lively social and cultural experimentation, that created the social and political frameworks of Europe.

title: Cultural Landscapes
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The History of Black Gospel Music
reviews: Definitely take this if you are interested in gospel music. It's not difficult. Do the readings for precept and for papers.
Do it, interesting class, great lectures not too much work
Easy LA. While it is 150-200 pages of reading some weeks it definitely varies and can be much lower. You also don't have to read everything to succeed.
I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in the topic area.
I would suggest it. It can get a little boring, but its a relatively low work class thats interesting.

It's worth it. Professor Best is amazing, cares about his students, and -- even if you know a lot about gospel music, you'll learn a lot about its history. Professor Best really isn't concerned with music made after 1999 anyway. Eh, who am I kidding: 1959, really.
TAKE THIS COURSE AS SOON AS YOU CAN! DO NOT MISS OUT!!! :D
Take this course if you have any interest. Wallace is totally chill and he is very very generous with grading. Try and get into his precept.
Take this!
This course is interesting, just be sure to take notes so you are prepared.
descrip: This course will trace the history of black gospel music from its origins in the American South to its modern origins in 1930s Chicago and into the 1990s mainstream. Critically analyzing various compositions and the artists that performed them, we will explore the ways the music has reflected and reproached the extant cultural climate. We will be particularly concerned with the four major historical eras from which black gospel music developed: the slave era; Reconstruction; the Great Migration, and the era of Civil Rights.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Economics of Latin American Populations
prereqs: The course will be taught in English..
descrip: This course will explore topics regarding "everyday life" from an economic perspective. Topics revolve around human behavior that arises at different ages and demographics from the perspective of Latin American cultural and institutional backgrounds. We study decisions of parents to have children and to "invest" in them, decisions of adolescents to use drugs and take other risks, the decision to marry (or not), and issues related to investing (or not) in one's health. We shall explore how economists think about, theorize and analyze these questions of great importance to Latin American populations from an economic perspective.

title: Art and Ideology in Medieval Iberia: Jews, Christians, and Moors
descrip: As a result of its unique racial, ethnic, and religious evolution, Medieval Spain offers a dynamic forum for the study of hegemonic structures (political, religious, gender) and of resistance. The dramatic interplay of these discourses which collectively define Medieval Iberian culture will be considered through discussions of art, architecture, and especially literature, from the militant epic mentality, to the dissident lyric voices of Shem Tov, to the figure of the romanticized Moor.

title: Revolutions, Constitutions and Re-configuring the Arab State
reviews: I would absolutely take it if you are interested in the topic!
Not sure if it will be offered again. Interesting material, but rather unstructured. Khouri's a very nice guy though and very knowledgeable.
The Professor is very well-connected and is able to set up really great speakers that were worth every bit of time spent on coursework and class. Very laid-back class. However, somewhat disorganized.
descrip: Revolutions, Constitutions and Re-configuring the Arab State will analyze events and transformations in Arab countries since December 2010 in Tunisia, in the historical and political context of the period since 1970. We will review the many causes that drive millions of ordinary Arab citizens to fight for their rights, the changes that have occurred in the process of adopting mechanisms to write new constitutions and create more legitimate and accountable governance systems in several Arab countries (Yemen, Tunisia, Egypt, Libya), and the counter-revolutions that continue to hinder the gains of citizen revolts across the region.

title: Holocaust Testimony
reviews: TAKE IT. One of the best courses I have taken at Princeton. Professor Trezise is very knowledgeable and super nice. You will have very rich discussions, especially if the class is small. Mine was five students - and it was excellent.
Take this class!  Professor Trezise is really nice and so knowledgeable about the subject.  Be ready to talk though.
take it!
prereqs: At least one 200-level literature course is strongly recommended..
descrip: This course focuses on major issues raised by but also extending beyond Holocaust survivor testimony, including the communication of trauma, genres of witnessing, the ethical implications of artistic representation, conflicts between history and memory, the fate of individuality in collective upheaval, the condition of survival itself, and the crucial role played by reception in enabling and transmitting survivors' speech.

title: Advanced Condensed Matter Physics II
reviews: Should take this course if you have solid background in QM, Solid State Physics and QFT
Take it.
descrip: Course introduces and present ongoing theoretical investigations of new research topics in condensed matter physics: topological insulators and Chern numbers, topological superconductors, the fractional quantum Hall effect and non-abelian statistics, as well as new high-temperature superconductors. The techniques needed to deal with such systems, such as Chern numbers, topological band theory, Berry phases, conformal field theory, Chern-Simons theory, t-J models, Gutzwiller wavefunctions, Hubbard models, are explained.

title: Topics in Nonlinear Analysis
prereqs: A good knowledge of Geometry and PDEs..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Nonlinear Analysis. More specific details will be provided when the course is offered.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy (Advanced)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Discusses the main tools of econometric analysis, and the way in which they are applied to a range of problems in social science. Emphasis is on using techniques, and on understanding and critically assessing others' use of them. There is a great deal of practical work on the computer using a range of data from around the world. Topics include regression analysis, with a focus on regression as a tool for analyzing non-experimental data, discrete choice, and an introduction to time-series analysis. There are applications from macroeconomics, policy evaluation, and economic development. Prerequisite: grounding in topics covered in 507c.
