title: South Asian Popular Culture
descrip: Provides an introduction to several South Asian popular culture forms and the different approaches, methods, debates and theory used in their study. Culture forms and practices include comics, film, music, visual culture (posters, calendar art, photography, etc.), clothing, and sport, with attention given to historical and contemporary social contexts. Through attention to aspects of their production, content, and consumption, we will discuss the ways in which these forms and practices are dynamic, contested and interconnected, and how they relate to various kinds of social identity formation.

title: Independent Study II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies. Usually taken in the Spring semester.

title: Second Language Acquisition Research and Language Teaching Methodology
descrip: Designed to provide future teaching assistants with the knowledge and conceptual tools needed to reflect critically on pedagogical practices in the second language classroom. Examines issues related to teaching language and culture in a university setting, highlighting the relationship between theory in Second Language Acquisition and language pedagogy and helping students understand the practical implications of theoretical frameworks in the field.

title: Topics of Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - International Migration and Public Policy
descrip: This course examines the historical and contemporary literature on international migration, the policies that enable or impede cross-national migration, and the consequences for the sending and receiving states as well as the migrants themselves. Drawing on contemporary international evidence, students will consider classical and contemporary theories of immigrant adaptation, language acculturation, and ethnic conflict from comparative international evidence.

title: Analysis in Several Variables
reviews: A great class for those who have a math proof background. Teaches the basic concepts necessary to do any higher level analysis class while also providing a foundation for classes in algebra or geometry.
Do it! It's a lot of fun, and Gunning is awesome. Find some people to problem set with though.
Expect to spend a lot of time, get a lot of help, and to be very nostalgic about the all nighters you will pull.
If you are interested in Math beyond simple calculus, definitely take it (it is being replaced from next year with 350). Take any Gunning class in general.
MAT215/218 serves as a good introduction to mathematics; I have a much firmer grasp and a new appreciation of concepts I learned in high school.

Please please please take the Gunning track if you are a potential Math Major. The MAT 215-218 sequence comes together as part of a while and really gives you a good foundation to any future math courses. The amount of work isn't anything to scoff at, but that's kinda true for all math classes. Make it a point to find a pset group though, you get to make friends on top of doing math (any group in this class is certainly good enough!)
Take it - it will literally make you smarter.
Take it if you like math.

Take it. I had little proof experience before coming here and therefore struggled in the beginning (it is a steep learning curve). But stick with it! Try to stay here and not drop down to the regular sections (MAT 215/217 for the 13-14 year). It is an extremely rewarding class (and Prof. Gunning is a professor that you will want to have at some point at Princeton).
Take the course with Professor Gunning! (and learn applications of analysis to French Literature)
This course is challenging but very rewarding. It will give you a sense of what real (and beautiful) mathematics is.
Very intense course in mathematics.
go to class, be ready to work a lot on your psets. nice curve
take it
prereqs: MAT 215 accelerated section..
descrip: Rigorous introduction to analysis in several variables.

title: Film Theory
reviews: if you can sit through silent films and black and white and want to learn about philosophy and some film ideas, why not?
descrip: A seminar centering on the film theories of philosopher Gilles Deleuze with screenings of the films and readings of the essays central to the formation of his thought.

title: Advanced Japanese II
reviews: Best (and most fun) semester of Japanese yet! Take it!
Don't cram on your vocabulary quizzes... keep reviewing that kanji!
More interesting than lower level courses.

Review vocabulary and grammar regularly; don't be afraid to ask for help, even (especially) if you need a lot; participate as much as possible in discussions--the speaking practice is for your own good.
Take it now! You won't regret it :)
Take it! Watching and discussing Spirited Away was great- my Japanese improved a lot because of it.
descrip: The course is designed to further students proficiency in four skills aiming at ACTFL-ETS advanced level. Reading materials include the Japanese anime "Sen to Chihiro no Kamikakushi (Spirited Away)" and selected readings from works in the original language.

title: Design of Large-Scale Structures: Buildings
descrip: This course will focus on the structural design of buildings and is open to students of engineering and of architecture who meet the prerequisites. The course will culminate in a major building design project incorporating knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work. Structural design is considered from concept development to the completion of detailed design while incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

title: Topics in International Relations - Protection Against Weapons of Mass Destruction
descrip: Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the only significant security threats to the U.S. and its allies have been from nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. Historically, the US focus has oscillated between protection via nonproliferation and disarmament agreements, and via civil and missile defense. The course assesses the threats, both approaches to protection, and linkages made between policies on WMD and perceptions of "conventional" military threats.

title: Experimental Methods I
reviews: General subject is really interesting
Very helpful if you wanna improve your ability of solving problems.
descrip: A laboratory course that focuses on basic electronics techniques, digital electronics, and data acquisition and analysis. Topics include introduction to digital and analog electronics, digital-to-analog and analog-to-digital conversion, microcomputer sampling, and data analysis. There are approximately four laboratory hours and two lecture hours per week. There is one project.

title: Introduction to Empirical Methodology in Finance
reviews: Definitely do take it! It is a great course.
If you want to learn the tools to working with data and are comfortable with a mathematical programming language, this course will be a great benefit.
One of the best classes in the econ department!

Really great course for those looking to get hands on experience with data and how actually empirical studies are performed. Not a high stress class and really useful. Yaxin is also incredibly nice and a wonderful professor!
Recommend for SAS/excel users, or who can use multiple software. Professor uses only SAS in her demonstration. Students have to do coding by yourself.

Solid course. Very interesting to analyze and replicate key empirical papers in the finance literature. Very fun and doable p-sets as well.

Also, no need to read the papers as the Professor does a great job in explaining them in lecture.
prereqs: Statistics/Econometrics: A solid understanding of econometrics is strongly recommended. ECO 302 and its prerequisites are prerequisites for this course. Programming language: The instructor recommends using a statistical programming language (e.g. Stata, SAS, Matlab, R) to complete the term project. Students might be able to perform some of the less data-intensive analysis in Excel but a statistical package is usually required to perform data-intensive analysis. Finance: ECO 362.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to empirical methods in finance research. The goal is to allow students to gain some experience in working with financial data and learn some empirical methodologies commonly used in finance literature. The goal is not to provide a complete survey of all methodologies used in empirical finance, but rather focus on a selection of topics and study them in depth. Topics covered include asset pricing models, momentum, and derivatives.

title: Pre-Columbian Maya Art: Elite and Popular Discourses
prereqs: The course will include a study trip to Guatemala to visit world-renown archaeological sites, national museums, and archaeological storage collections not available to the general public..
descrip: This course examines Pre-Columbian Maya art and archaeology from the perspective of intersecting aesthetic, ritual, and social traditions: official state art and popular representations and practices. Drawing on critical social theory as a basis for our analyses, we will examine the relationship between royal mural paintings and cave art, patronized art and graffiti, large-scale stone monuments and small-scale figurines, "readable" hieroglyphic texts and pseudo writing, and civic-ceremonial architecture and vernacular household architecture.

title: Gender and Sexuality in Modern America
reviews: A really fantastic course, even if you're not particularly interested in GSS. Professor Canaday is an engaging speaker and readings are interesting. It's a decent amount of work, but it is worth it!

Absolutely take this class!! Professor Canaday is one of the best lecturers I have ever had at Princeton - try to get her as your preceptor, she is amazing. The readings are also REALLY interesting. GREAT course!

Absolutely take this course - I think this is material everyone should be familiar with, and this course is so well organized. The lectures, readings, and precepts are all fascinating, and I found myself moved to tears at points (although it may have been sleep deprivation) because of the ideas and information presented to us.
Average to above average workload, incredibly interesting lectures.
Be prepared to dish out $130 for the course packets. Besides that, you'll learn a lot. If you're looking for an intriguing HA, I would definitely recommend taking this class.

Definitely take it if you're interested in the subject material! Professor Canaday is great and the readings are fascinating. The course doesn't really depart from the traditional white feminist narrative of the time period though, so it's not a course that will consistently and comprehensively explore the experiences of women of color. Don't buy "The Normal Heart" - you only use it for one precept, and it's not necessary for the exams or the papers if you don't want it to be.
Definitely take this class! It opened up my eyes to a part of history I did not know even existed.
Definitely take this course - it will give you a new perspective on America's history with gender and sexuality.
Definitely take this course before graduating Princeton! Canaday is an amazing lecturer, the material is interesting, and this is a piece of American history that everyone should know.
Definitely take this course with Professor Canaday! She is one of the best professor's I've had at Princeton and I loved her class.
Do the reading, but skim where necessary.
Highly recommend; a great way to look at a commonly discussed topic from an academic perspective
I would tell them that going to lecture is crucial  in this class.

I would tell them to read everything because everything is interesting and new; nothing is redundant. I would also tell them to work on their research paper early so that they have a very easy reading week.

If you think you know about women's rights, the AIDS epidemic, the suburban home of the 50s, the waves of feminism, take this class. If you know nothing about any of these things, take this class. You will learn so much, and you'll love the learning.
Seriously, take it. One of my favorite courses I've taken here. A good intro to GSS courses, if you've never taken one.
TAKE IT, TAKE IT, TAKE IT. It will change the way you look at the world.
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!
TAKE THIS COURSE!

TAKE THIS COURSE! Professor Canaday is awesome, and she is very understanding and informative in precepts too if you can get her for your preceptor. The information covered was not dull and very informative for present-day issues, as well as historical ones.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!! it'll make you think of the world in a whole new way. It is absolutely fascinating.

TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!!! Amazing lectures and super interesting readings. You will learn a lot and enjoy it the whole time. Try to do as much of the reading as possible, but accept the fact that it is nearly impossible to do it all.
TAKE THIS! You will not regret it. It was favorite class ever and I am not a gender studies major/ certificate!

Take advantage of all the time they give you to complete assignments! You can only do a good job if you spend a lot of time on the papers. Plus, you'll get more out of it.

Also, take the course!
Take it
Take it!
Take it! You will not regret it.
Take it!!!

Take it. Professor Canaday is awesome, the lectures are fascinating and give you a unique perspective on 20th century history. Even though there's a midterm paper, final paper and take home, which seems like a lot at times, the assignments are really well structured so they're lower stress.
Take the course. Professor Canaday is an excellent scholar and her lectures are great.
Take this course if you're interested in the topic and make sure you find a good preceptor!

Take this course! One of my favorites at Princeton so far. Professor Canaday is a wonderful lecturer and the readings for this course are absolutely fascinating. This class gave me an entirely new outlook on both American history and the present. Cannot recommend this class highly enough! Also, Caley Horan is a great preceptor.
Take this course!!
Take this course. Do it.
Talk to Margot Canaday. She is very knowledgable and helpful.

This class is so incredible!!! Professor Canaday is easily the best professor I've yet to have! Additionally, the material is so fascinating and relevant. It was such an enjoyable experience, and I'm so glad I took it!
This course is GREAT. If you're at all interested in gender and sexuality, take it!! It's definitely a serious history course but it's SUPER interesting and will change the way you think. DO it!
This is a fairly easy course and a good way to fulfill your HA.
This is a fantastic class, but not the best for senior spring.
This is an amazing and fun class, take it!
This is an excellent history class!!

This is one of the best classes you will take at Princeton. It is an essential component of 20th century US history, but few know nearly enough about it. Plus, Prof. Canaday is a goddess! You seriously will not find a nicer, more understanding, and more intelligent professor. Absolutely take this course!
This is one of the best courses I have ever taken. I highly recommend it to anyone who is interested in human rights.

This was a great class- I highly recommend it. Lectures were really interesting and well-presented, the material is very engaging (it gives you a totally different perspective on recent American history), precepts allow for high quality discussions, and the final paper is very fun to write and research, especially when you can reach out to Professor Canaday and ask for her help in your research process.
You must take this course! Just stay on top of the tons of reading, but it is all worth it.
amazing course; super relevant; be prepared to address tough questions and learn things you had never realized
definitely!
go to precept? I guess? Eh
this class rocks
descrip: This course examines the history of gender and sexuality across the 20th century, with emphasis on both regulation and resistance. Topics include early homosexual subcultures; the commercialization of sex; reproduction and its limitation; sex, gender, and war; cold war sexual containment; the feminist movement; conservative backlash; AIDS politics; same-sex marriage; Hillary; and many others.

title: Introductory Video and Film Production
reviews: Despite what the title says, this class is not a very good introduction to filmmaking. The only benefit that I felt I received from taking it was getting access to the software and equipment; beyond that, it seemed like everything I learned I had to teach myself. Prof. Sanborn is nice, but he is not a very engaging speaker, and he seems to have little interest in explaining the practicalities of moviemaking. Many of our classes consisted of a 3-hour Powerpoint on highly theoretical subjects which had little or nothing to do with film; maybe that would be fine for a more advanced class, it was unhelpful for those of us who were beginners and had no background in the technical aspects. Discussion of basic things like equipment, vocabulary, storyboarding and composition, and the industry as a whole were few and far between, and the short films we watched in class were overwhelmingly artsy, experimental pieces, rather than the narrative or documentary features that most of us were interested in making. Moreover, the department is trying to switch over from teaching Final Cut to Adobe Premiere, so many of our classes consisted of watching the professor for hours while he tried to figure out the software, rather than navigating it ourselves. The readings were never discussed in class, and overall I think it would have been helpful if more things had been committed to paper: I would have appreciated a list of basic vocabulary terms and concepts at the beginning of the year, for example, and having printed directions for the software would have allowed us to practice things like the special effects, color correction, and audio cleanup individually - a more efficient use of time than watching a three-hour demonstration. I would recommend this class only if you have a very strong interest and some background in film to begin with, and if your workload permits you to spend several hours per week in homework and teaching yourself the material.
Don't take this course.
Take the course if interested in learning both film history and some film production.
This class is not hard, and its kind of fun to do the stuff. I'd recommend it. Also, you can know literally nothing about filmmaking and be fine
prereqs: This course is now open enrollment ..
descrip: A film can be fictional or documentary, but there are also many other ways to tell a story. Through hands-on studio work, screenings, critical readings and group critiques, this course teaches the basic tools and approaches for film production with digital media including writing, camerawork, sound, editing, and postproduction. Technical instruction paired with conceptual frameworks will give you the means to find your visual storytelling voice and your filmmaker's point of view.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Mathematical Tecnhiques for Natural Algorithms
reviews: Chazelle is hands down the best professor I have had for a technical subject at Princeton. Yes, the lectures are sometimes a little scattered, yes points are not always made with the utmost thoroughness, and no, this isn't a math class, and doesn't have the attendant rigor of a math class. But if you are interested in intuition and what actually goes on in developing a big theory basically from scratch, Chazelle will gladly show you the world shining shimmering splendid etc. Do yourself a favor and take a class with him before you graduate.
It's not intense and is sometimes interesting
Not a very systematic course.
descrip: Reviews fundamental mathematical techniques used in the analysis of natural algorithms. In particular, spectral decomposition, Lyapunov functions, harmonic analysis, statistical and probabilistic techniques, Markov chains, ergodic coefficients, renormalization, and complexity theory.

title: Seminar in French Civilization - The Heroism of Modern Life
descrip: How can modern bourgeois life still claim to be, as Baudelaire suggested, worthy of heroic treatment, despite the rise of democratic values? While many post-revolutionary thinkers opposed heroism on political grounds, or judged it historically impossible, some fashioned new democratic heroes reconciling exemplarity and typicality. Meanwhile, reactionary thinkers revitalized an older heroic code to justify hierarchy and order. We examine the nineteenth-century crisis of heroism in a wide range of authors such as Balzac, Stendhal, Marx, Nietzsche, Carlyle, Emerson, Baudelaire, Comte, Michelet, Hugo, Rostand, Barres, and Bergson.

title: Religions of Late Antiquity Workshop
prereqs: REL 525.
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop providing students in the Religions of Late Antiquity with the opportunity to present their current research for discussion.

title: Advanced Korean II
reviews: Great class for improving your writing and reading abilities.
It is more difficult than KOR 301.
Lots of individual attention and will learn for sure.
prereqs: KOR 301 or placement test..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 301. Continued development of proficiency in speaking and reading through class discussion and short readings. Vocabulary learning and discourse skills are emphasized.

title: The McGraw Seminar in Writing - Writing with an Appetite
reviews: Absolutely take this course. Professor Bruni is extremely affable, and a great teacher.
Bruni is a fantastic, funny, thoughtful professor who really cares about his students. Fantastic class.
I doubt it would be offered again but if it is you must take it. You simply must.
Take it. If you're at all interested in writing or food, or writing and food, do it.

Take this class (please please offer it again for another class of food-obsessed writers!) or any by Prof Bruni if he teaches again (please please do!). You will laugh, think deeply, become a better writer, and be inspired to live boldly and experience more.

Take this class only if you really love food and want to learn how to write newspaper style articles. This is not a restaurant review course. It is a fun class to take if you have space in your schedule, but I would not recommend dropping another course to take this one.
Take this course for sure, and be sure to put time into your papers. Reading is kind of option since we don't spend that much time on it. Be prepared to learn a lot about writing.
Take this if Prof. Bruni returns.

This is one of the best classes I took at Princeton and I can't recommend it highly enough. Great if you're interested in food- and not just eating, but how our food habits change from culture to culture, how food is intimately linked to the vernacular, how the way we eat impacts national health and sustainably issues. But also great if you're just interested in being a better, more conscientious writer.
prereqs: Enrollment by application - see course web address.
descrip: In our food-obsessed culture, writers specializing in the world of food - cooking trends, sustainable farming, restaurant criticism, nutrition news - have found a niche both prominent and edifying. This course will introduce students to a wide range of food writing, with special emphases on how the way we eat mirrors so much about our lives and how the challenges of good food writing distill the challenges of all writing.

title: Topics in Literary and Cultural Theory - Alexander Kluge and the New Left
descrip: First emerging from the camp of German critical theory in the early 1960s, Alexander Kluge has become one of the most important figures in the New Left today. Indeed, the corpus of media theory, philosophy, fiction, film and television work that he has assembled over the last half-century has acquired new legibility and actuality since the financial crisis of 2008. Moving through the major stations in his body of work, this seminar focuses in particular on Kluge's renewal of the Frankfurt School's Freudo-Marxist paradigm as well as his relationship to other contemporaneous currents within the European (esp. French) Left generally.

title: Society and Politics in Pakistan
descrip: Nuclear weapons, radical Islam, military dictatorship, and war with India commonly come to mind when people think of Pakistan today. This course will examine the politics and economics of state-building in Pakistan, the impact of the cold war and hot wars, the role of militarism and nuclear weapons, the challenges of identity politics, the rise of Islamic fundamentalism, economic development and inequality, and the relationship with the United States.

title: Post-1945 African Photography
reviews: Definitely take this course. Prof. Okeke-Agulu is an engaging instructor and very knowledgable.
prereqs: For department majors, satisfies Group 3 distribution requirement..
descrip: This course examines the role and status of photography in different phases of Africa's political, cultural and art historical experience since 1945. We explore how African photographers used the photographic medium in the service of the state, society and their own artistic visions during the colonial and post-independence eras. Photography's relationship with art and its social function in Africa will underlie our discussion.

title: Trade Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Topics in Computational Complexity - Pseudorandomness
descrip: In many applications, it is desirable to construct combinatorial or algebraic structures that have "random looking" properties. Some examples include expander graphs, Ramsey graphs, Extractors, error correcting codes and subspace evasive sets. All of these properties are satisfied with high probability in a random object but finding an *explicit* constructions is quite difficult in many cases. We survey the state of the art on all of the above examples and others. The techniques we encounter are quite diverse and include additive combinatorics, exponential sums, algebraic geometry and graph theory.

title: Human Rights
reviews: A great course. Professor Bass is an engaging lecturer, and the issues covered are ones of which all Princetonians should at least have a cursory understanding before graduating. Highly recommended.
Absolutely take it! Certainly not an "easy" course, as there is a lot of reading, but it is super interesting, and I have learned a phenomenal amount.
Absolutely take this course if it is taught by Gary Bass
All students should take this class. This is one of those few life-changing classes that you can take at Princeton.
Be prepared to work hard, but this class will change your life.
Definitely take it! A must take course at Princeton. Professor Bass is inspiring, and will restore some idealism in your outlook.

Definitely take the course since it is an important and interesting class. And the lectures are great! But note it is more of a history class with its focus on case studies and discusses theory less. Also there is a lot of reading (though often repetitive to the lecture if you go to lecture), though the readings are fairly important for the midterm and final.
Definitely take this class if you are at all interested in human rights, or are a Politics or Woody Wu major!
Do all the reading and you will succeed.
Gary Bass is a great professor. This course was really informative and interesting. Take this class
Great topical overview. Bass knows his stuff and is a great storyteller.

I absolutely recommend this course to anyone who's remotely interested in it.  I took it as an EEB major and did just fine, and you learn so, so much.  However, be prepared for massive amounts of readings.  I took this class along with two other heavy reading courses and it was definitely a struggle to keep up.
I would strongly recommend this course to other students.

If you have any extra space in your schedule after depreqs, this class is seriously the one you need to take before leaving Princeton. Professor Bass is absolutely great, and the course material so heavily delves into how we have reached the place we are concerning human rights, the differing world views on what they are, and the steps we do and do not take to defend them.

It's a difficult course that demands a lot of attention to take properly, so don't take it on a whim. But if you have an interest in human rights issues, how they've played out in the past, and how they play out today, then this course will not disappoint.
Make sure you go to lectures.

Not the best class I've taken in the POL department, but not the worst either. Take if you think you're interested in learning more about the development of the human rights movement, but be prepared for somewhat politicized lectures.
Prepare yourself for the darkest, yet most engaging course of your undergrad experience. Bass' lectures are more than enough reason to hop on this ride.
Prof. Bass is incredible. Take a class with him before you graduate.
Professor Bass is funny, charismatic, and perhaps the best lecturer I've had at Princeton. This class has a LOT of reading but  a lot of it is actually pretty interesting. Take it for the lectures!
Solid course with phenomenal lectures. Be prepared for a good deal of reading.
Study for exams in detail. Enjoy the eye-opening experience.
TAKE IT! Gary Bass is the most intelligent, charismatic, moving professor you will ever have at Princeton. A course everyone should take while they are here.
TAKE IT!! Gary Bass is a fantastic lecturer, and probably my favorite lecturer at Princeton so far.  There is a lot of reading at times but it is worth it!

TAKE IT. It's worth it, especially for Americans to really reconsider U.S. engagement with the rest of the world. If you are at least a little bit interested in foreign policies, international aid, intervention, UN or other international institutions, politics, or ROTC, you should really take this course. It's both historical and practical and forces us to reflect on ethical grounds behind U.S. political engagement in rest of the world.
Take it and go to all the lectures
Take it! It will blow you away, one of the best courses there is at Princeton. Bass's lectures are legendary. Only thing is watch out, the work catches up on you fast right at the end.
Take this class! Professor Bass's lectures are amazing, my favorite class I've taken here.

Take this class! Should be mandatory for WWS students and perhaps politics and other departments as well. The information is crucial and this class will help you grow both in knowledge and in ability to form opinions on some of the greatest issues we face in the world today.
Take this course! Make a study group early so you can understand all the readings and go to your preceptor with any questions before precept/papers/exams.

Take this for a wonderfully engaging and thought-provoking experience. Especially for seniors, this is a fantastic way to end your Princeton experience on a note that reflects the goals of a Princeton education.
The course was one of my favorite classes so far.

The material is very interesting and Professor Bass is a good lecturer, but I feel like it could have been better organized in terms of expressing major themes and linking the reading material with the lectures.

This class is a lot of work and a lot of reading, but teaches you about human rights in a new way. Not my favorite POL class at Princeton, but I still recommend it because Bass is a very engaging, impressive lecturer.
This course is amazing - definitely take it if you can!

This is a fantastic course, and it will open up your eyes to all sorts of issues that you may know little to nothing about it. Professor Bass is one of the most engaging lecturers I've had at Princeton, and the material is fascinating. There's a lot of readings, and it's a lot of work, but it's very rewarding and fun.
This is an amazing course. Do the readings, take careful notes and try to apply what you've learned in class to current human rights related news.
This is an awesome course, a lot of work and reading and hard grading. Professor Bass is a bit intimidating and aloof in person.

This is by far my favorite class in Princeton (and I'm a BSE COS). Gary Bass is such an eloquent speaker and good at telling gruesome stories in an engaging way - you came out thinking about issues that were often overlooked and learn a ton. It taught me things greater than the historical facts and political intricacies; but a sense of responsibility we owe to each other, regardless of birth, race, religion. Take it, take it, and take it. Everyone in Princeton I believe is an idealist to some extent - and you should take this class if you believe in the kindness of human nature. Be prepared to get shocked by how depressing the human rights situations have been around the world, but also be prepared to transform,aspire and take up the beacon of democracy and the torch of humanity. You will be a different person coming out of this class. Take it.

This is one of the most challenging and rewarding courses I have taken at Princeton. It covers a tremendous amount of information, including both human rights theory and concrete, historical case studies such as Bosnia and Rwanda. The topic is fascinating and highly relevant to the modern world, and Prof. Bass is a very engaging lecturer.
Try to keep up on the readings, lecture is a must.

WONDERFUL! Gary Bass is a stimulating, engaging lecture. He keeps you on the edge of your seat for the whole 50 minutes. I really couldn't imagine better lectures. This was the highlight of the course. Gary Bass was also my preceptor. Great precepts, even though he sometimes seemed uninterested in what students were saying. He was rude on occasion. It was often clear that he thought he was much better than his students. Regardless, he did a good job of leading spirited debate and discussions. It was a pleasure going to precept every week. Most of the readings were wonderful. I was almost always excited to do the readings for this class. I was annoyed at myself when I did not find the time to do them. (Be warned that there is a ton of reading for this course.) You read a lot of very influential political thinkers in this class. I really loved Samantha Power's book "A Problem from Hell." I also loved Philip Gourevitch's book about Rwanda. THIS HAS BEEN MY FAVORITE CLASS AT PRINCETON SO FAR, even though it is hard and Gary Bass can be somewhat acerbic.
Yes! Absolutely!
asks important questions about human rights and how to answer them
take it!
this is the best course I've ever taken
descrip: A study of the politics and history of human rights. What are human rights? How can dictatorships be resisted from the inside and the outside? Can we prevent genocide? Is it morally acceptable and politically wise to launch humanitarian military interventions to prevent the slaughter of foreign civilians? What are the laws of war, and how can we punish the war criminals who violate them? Cases include the Ottoman Empire, Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union, Bosnia, and Rwanda.

title: Mechanical Design
reviews: Definitely take it if you're interested in more hands-on engineering, but be prepared to work hard at it.
Excellent, interesting, well-structured, and well-guided course. Very enjoyable, but be warned it will take a large, continuous time commitment to the SARR project.
Great design course if you need one.

I would recommend this course.  Building and manufacturing a robot may seem daunting - and it is at first - but the instructors provide great guidance and working on a team makes the process much more interesting.  In many ways the core of this course is learning how to complete large-scale engineering projects in a team setting, and the course definitely does its job in that area.  Some of the work may get rote and time-consuming - especially in the second half of the semester when manufacturing and troubleshooting becomes more prevalent - but if you have a good team, it makes up more it.

If you like robots and well-taught courses, take this class. In addition from learning to build a robot, you learn project management skills from an expert and work in a group to make something truly amazing. It's a lot of work, but it is very much worth it and was the highlight of my Princeton career.
It's really fun, if you get a good group.
Make sure you meet all the intermediate deadlines for the robot.
Take it. But stay ahead of schedule, because Nosenchuck really doesn't like missed deadlines.

The experience depends heavily on your group - try to sign up for a lab time with people you trust to do their share and prioritize the project. Expect to spend A LOT of time in the shop outside of class time.
You should start work early, because there is a lot of troubleshooting.

Your experience in this course will depend tremendously on who is in your group. Make sure that you are in a group that works well together and is willing to put in a lot of time.

If you are self motivated and somewhat capable, you will do fine. It will be frustrating, and you will have a lot of late nights in the shop, but at the end, you will have a functioning robot that you can be proud of.
prereqs: MAE 321 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course builds on the technical foundations established in MAE 321, and extends the scope to include a range of advanced mechanism design. Students, working in teams, will be challenged to design and fabricate a robotic system that will draw upon multidisciplinary engineering elements. The robot will be used to facilitate common daily tasks. The selected tasks vary each year. CAD, CAE, and CAM will be utilized in the design/simulation/prototype process. Labs are designed to reinforce and expand CAD and CAE skills. A final public competition will be held among the design teams. Judges from relevant industries will be present.

title: Ancient Judaism from Alexander to the Rise of Islam
reviews: Great class.
I took this as a PDF. While it is generally manageable to PDF, since it is such a small class in size, it is harder to slack off.
If you are interested and have prior knowledge of ancient Judaism than this is a great class.  Otherwise, don't take it.

If you are interested in the subject the readings and lectures are information packed.  Professor Himmelfarb is a tough grader, and most of the class ended up taking the course PDF. There was little work during the semester but a a dean's date assignment and take-home final, which were time consuming.
Take it if you are interested in a fairly easy survey course.

Take the course, do the reading and go to lectures. If you have a heavy semester, this is the perfect class to PDF but at the end of the semester you have a Dean's Date Paper and a take home final (which is another paper) which is pretty annoying.
Take this course! The readings are interesting and the papers aren't too long.
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the development of ancient Judaism during the eventful millennium from the establishment of the Torah as the constitution of the Jewish people in the fifth century BCE--an event that some have seen as marking the transition from biblical religion to Judaism--to the completion of the other great canonical Jewish document, the Babylonian Talmud, in perhaps the sixth century CE.

title: Computational Complexity
reviews: I definitely recommend it if you want to know more about complexity theory.
I would recommend this course to all students studying TCS.
It's tough, but the material is cool. Starts out very much like 487, but gets harder from there. Problem sets are difficult, so find someone to work with and start early.
Read before lectures, otherwise it's pretty chill.
This is a good course.
prereqs: COS 423.
descrip: Introduction to research in computational complexity theory. Computational models: nondeterministic, alternating, and probabilistic machines. Boolean circuits. Complexity classes associated with these models: NP, Polynomial hierarchy, BPP, P/poly, etc. Complete problems. Interactive proof systems and probabilistically checkable proofs: IP=PSPACE and NP=PCP (log n, l). Definitions of randomness. Pseudorandomness and derandomizations. Lower bounds for concrete models such as algebraic decision trees, bounded-depth circuits, and monotone circuits.

title: The Environmental Engineering of Buildings, Part II
reviews: Be creative when selecting what group project you would like to do. Mahadev likes to be pleasantly surprised.
Generally good
descrip: Study and evaluation of mechanical and electrical system applications for different building types, including air conditioning, electrical, plumbing and telecommunications. Emphasis on design integration with architecture and structure within the construction process including sustainable design and energy conservation. Introduction to vertical transportation, life safety systems, and intelligent buildings. Emphasis on a conceptual approach using case studies and field trips.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Challenges in State and Local Health Policy
prereqs: Interested students should email regina@princeton.edu for enrollment information..
descrip: This course will address state and local regulation of public health and health care. It will explore the opportunities and limits of government intervention to promote health and addressing health care deficits, with case examples drawn from New York City, New Jersey and other city and state experiences. The course combines in-depth reading, discussion, lectures, and written assignments; readings will be drawn from current health policy literature, state and local government primary sources, and news analysis.

title: Race in America
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Buddhism in Japan
reviews: Do your reading and ask a lot of questions.

Great reading material choices that covers from 6c to the present. Take if you're interested in Buddhism or Japan or both. Previous knowledge on Buddhism or Japanese history will help, but doesn't matter if you don't know much. The quality of the seminar hinges a lot on students' participation, so make sure to read the readings (at least skim) and think about the discussion questions before class. Professor Stone is very knowledgeable on the topic and leads great discussions.
Lots of readings to do, but it is a very rewarding class, and the discussions are very thought-provoking.

Take this course if you are very interested in the subject matter; otherwise, while it is very well run and Professor Stone works hard to make it interesting, you may find it difficult to keep engaged. Most other students are very involved in the material, and discussion is often very strong.
Take this course! Especially if you think Buddhism is a fascinating subject, and you want to find out more about Japan.
pretty interesting. take if interested stones pretty interested in what she teaches
descrip: This course will examine representative aspects of Buddhist thought and practice in Japan from the sixth century to the present. We will focus on the major Buddhist traditions--including Lotus, Pure Land, esoteric Buddhism, and Zen--as well as Buddhism and the literary arts, modern challenges to traditional Buddhism, and contemporary Buddhist movements. Readings will include scriptures, sermons, tales, and philosophical essays, as well as selected secondary sources. Some background in either Japan or Buddhism is strongly recommended.

title: Mechanistic and Physical Organic Chemistry
reviews: Exactly what you will expect.
Great course...definitely take it if you're interested in learning about mechanistic studies.
If you like hardcore organic chemistry you'll like this class.
Take this course, you will learn a ton from two of Princeton's best lecturers.
Take this course.
Take this if you want to learn how to do research.
This is a great course and covers very important information for chemistry students.

This was my favorite course the whole semester because it combines things from a lot of my favorite classes (quantum, kinetics, organic, inorganic), but it is very hard. There aren't that many problem sets, but they are challenging and worth a lot of your grade. Only take it if you're really enthusiastic for it.
take this
descrip: This course covers the fundamentals of physical organic chemistry to provide the students with a thorough understanding of chemical reactivity. Within the framework of organic reaction mechanisms, the class discusses a number of topics, including the essence of structure and bonding, the nature of reactive intermediates, and the use of kinetic measurements and isotopic labeling studies to decipher chemical mechanisms. Grades are based on problem sets, a mid-term, and a final exam.

title: Topics in Applied Economics - Urban Economics
descrip: This is a course in urban and regional economics. Course studies the main economic forces that lead to the emergence of cities and regional agglomeration, and the effects on worker productivity, urban amenities, and congestion. Course discusses the problems in measuring these urban characteristics, the methodologies to do it, as well as the design of optimal urban policy. Course also studies the economic theory and evidence on the internal structure of cities, as well as the policies that can enhance urban living. Finally, the course analyzes the role cities play in aggregate economic development.

title: Elementary Swahili II
reviews: Go in for help and practice ateast 30-60 minutes a day.
Take it!
prereqs: Only those who have taken Elementary Swahili I (SWA 101) should enroll..
descrip: This course is a continuation of Swahili 101. It enhances communicative skills with emphasis on writing, reading, comprehension and conversation. Class activities review and enhance already introduced skills in speaking, writing, listening and reading; all embedded in authentic and contemporary East African cultural content. Cultural themes include the basics of daily life such as relationships, food, physical features and other aspects of material culture of East Africa. Learners are expected to perform functions related to basic services, comprehension of basic spoken and written texts and writing of a 1-page essay in Kiswahili.

title: Problems of Philosophy - Topics in Population Ethics
descrip: This seminar examines ethical issues surrounding the creation of new persons. We look both at the individual choice to procreate as well as at social policies that influence the number, identity, and wellbeing of future persons. Among the questions we consider are: Can we harm or benefit a person by bringing her into existence? If we have a moral reason not to create a child whose life would forseeably be miserable, is there a corresponding moral reason to create a child whose life would be happy? What reasons, if any, are there for wanting the human species to continue for as long as possible?

title: The History of Russian Rock
prereqs: RUS105 or instructor's permission..
descrip: The course will examine cultural discourse in the late Soviet and post-Soviet periods through the lens of Russian rock lyrics, paying particular attention to musicians' divergent responses to authoritative Soviet discourse, and strategies for renewing language and recapturing meaning amidst that discourse's collapse. A variety of musical genres will be explored, from official Soviet music, to the "bards" and blatnaya pesnya, to the emergence of rock and punk music and its enduring importance in giving voice to political protest.

title: Beginner's Latin Continued: Basic Prose
reviews: Go to class everyday and always do the homework in advanced.
It's a fair bit of work, but you do end up knowing a substantial amount of Latin after a year. The amount of fun you get out of the class will probably depend on the instructor.
Keep up with the readings.
Melissa Haynes is very knowledgeable, fun, and energetic. Work is very fair.

Take Latin! It's SO interesting, and Princeton literally has the best Classics Department in the country, so if you're ever going to take Greek or Latin now is the time. It's hard, but it's easy to learn the vocabulary and you don't need to speak it, which makes it in many ways much easier than other language courses. Dawn is also amazing.
Wait till the end! Once you start reading prose and poetry, things get better!
it will take you more time than 101
prereqs: LAT 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continues Latin grammar from LAT 101. The second half of the semester will be devoted to reading continuous Latin poetry and prose.

title: The Musical Theatre of Stephen Sondheim: Process to Production
reviews: A lot of fun if you are at all interested in Sondheim or Musical Theater
I would highly recommend this course for Professor Wolf's unique perspective on education through active learning and discussion.
If you love Sondheim, TAKE THIS CLASS!
Must take this course.
Prepare well. Be familiar with the show you are discussing that week enough so that you can make a smart comment or raise a good question. Do as much of the readings as you can.

Professor Wolf is an incredible teacher. I highly recommend this course for anyone who is remotely interested in musical theater, and wants to be challenged to participate in new and creative ways, especially through performance.
Take it. Do the readings. Don't be afraid to participate in class.
Take this course if you want to be fully engaged and learn something every week.

Take this course!  It's a really amazing way to understand musical theater.  Spend plenty of time with the texts, including rereading/re-viewing the shows you think you're already familiar with.  Understand that the creative aspects of this class are themselves analytical, rather than some extra fun/creative thing.  There's a slight danger of class discussion spending time on "I like this" or "I feel this way", so make sure you take the time to ground your impressions and observations in evidence, and challenge your peers to do the same.
Take this course!!!
This is a fun way to delve into Sondheim's work. Start listening early in the week so you actually get to hear it.
descrip: This seminar examines the musicals of Stephen Sondheim, from page to stage. Focusing on a different musical each week from Gypsy (1959) to Road Show (2009), we will ask, How do musical theatre's elements of music, lyrics, script, dance, and design cohere in Sondheim's musicals? We will explore influences on his art, both personal and cultural, his collaborators, and the historical and theatrical milieu. We'll study the musicals themselves by reading libretti, listening to music, seeing taped and live performances, researching production histories, and analyzing popular, critical, and scholarly reception.

title: Advanced Arabic I
prereqs: ARA 107 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Study of Modern Standard Arabic at the advanced level. Attention given to speaking, listening, reading and writing, with special emphasis on grammar.

title: Advanced Arabic Skills Workshop II
reviews: Preparing all readings before class is very helpful and lets you get much more out of classroom. Particularly, putting case markers on the texts can be a valuable exercise.
Take the course if you're interested in Classical Arabic and Arabic literature.
This course was highly enjoyable and fascinating with Ustadh Nizar.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 401 or the instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of ARA 401, focusing on readings in classical Arabic literature. Conducted primarily in Arabic.

title: Ocean, Atmosphere, and Climate
reviews: I loved this course a lot.  Professor Sarmiento is absolutely fabulous.  This course is by no means an easy course if you don't put any time into it, but if you're even remotely interested and are willing to attend all lectures and weekly office hours it is completely manageable with a good curve and interesting material.
Loved this class.  Might not be your cup of tea if you aren't interested in oceanography but I really enjoyed every second of this class.
Overall a great intro course. Problem sets were challenging but not too hard. Professors and TAs provided a lot of office hours and are really helpful.

Study the lectures frequently, consult the manual on a regular basis, and get help from any of the instructors whenever you need it. They're always willing to help, and they are all very friendly. A great course for anyone who wants to try out an introductory science course.
Take it! This is a great course taught by a really great professor!
The problem sets illustrate most of what you need to know, but be sure to pay attention in lab.

This class gives you a really good introduction to oceanography and geosciences. You will learn a lot. It requires work and effort to do well on problem sets and labs, but problem sets usually help you understand the material better, and office hours are an easy way to get help. Prof. Sarmiento is super interesting and wants to make sure you understand the material. Definitely good to help you figure out if you want to be a geo major

This class is what made me decide to be a geo major and was probably one of my favorite classes here thus far. It's not easy, but if you're interested in the material, it won't feel like you are overworking yourself and you'll learn a lot!

This course will take up a decent amount of time, especially because it has a lab, but it is well worth it.  The professor and TA's make their expectations very clear. If you're thinking about Geosciences, this is a great introductory course to take.
This is a great way to ease into the geosciences and experience what a science class is like. The workload isn't bad and the professor/lab tas are very willing to give extra help.
take it
prereqs: High School biology, chemistry and calculus..
descrip: An introduction to the ocean, atmosphere, and climate from the perspective of oceanography. Covers coastal processes including waves, beaches, tides and ecosystems; open ocean processes including atmospheric circulation and its impact on the surface ocean, the wind driven circulation, and surface ocean ecosystems; and the abyssal ocean including circulation, the cycling of chemicals, and ocean sediments and what they tell us about the climate history of the earth. The final part of the course will cover humans and the earth system, including a discussion of ocean resources and climate change.

title: Order and Chaos in Eighteenth-Century European Art
descrip: This seminar considers order and chaos as organizing principles in exploring the art of the long 18th century (1700-1830) in Britain, France, and Italy. Drawing on primary texts (artist's treatises, memoirs, poetry, etc.), we will seek to understand the relationship of works of art to fundamental Enlightenment discourses on the ordering of knowledge and society at a time of dramatic social, economic, and political change. Even as we examine this wider context, we will look closely at original works of art, including paintings, prints, and drawings in Princeton's collections.

title: Elementary Hebrew II
reviews: Considering that this was the instructors last semester teaching, I would say to wait and see who the next teacher will be. If it's Tzach, then definitely take the course. He was a great instructor, and way better than the one that I had this past semester. If the people in charge of Hebrew for the upcoming semester are smart, they'll choose him to teach the class. He deserves it.
If you want to learn Hebrew, take it!
Take it!
Take it! It is so much fun!
The materials in the class are good, and since there will be a new teacher in the fall, I'd recommend shopping it.
Wait for a better professor to come in. Do not take this course from Professor Robbins.
prereqs: HEB 101 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of HEB 101 focusing on the structure, the grammar and vocabulary of the Hebrew language. We'll be reading easy texts from Israeli newspapers, from our textbooks. We'll be writing more compositions and be giving presentations about various topics in Hebrew.

title: Capitalism, Utopia, and Social Justice
descrip: See website

title: War in the Modern Western World
reviews: A very interesting course if you're interested in wars and history in general. Take it! The midterm is very reasonable, though be sure to do all the readings and go to all the lectures.
Be careful on the exams as there are many history majors. It's not a course that you should take for general interest.
Be prepared to pull your weight as far as going to lecture and taking notes goes, as well as staying up to speed on the readings.
Definitely take this class. The readings are heavy, but they're interesting, and the class as a whole is very enjoyable.
Do all the readings, just because they're great readings. You won't find it hard to pay attention.
Do the readings, attend lectures, ask questions during precepts and think critically.
Fabulous course. Not too much of a work load.  Definitely take it!

Fun 2nd semester senior course to PDF. Interesting topics, LOTS of reading though. 

Lectures, for the most part, were extremely intriguing. If you like battles, warfare, technology, tactics, etc. this will be entertaining.
GO TO LECTURE. Do the readings as you can, but lectures cover the bulk of the material.

Great departmental, interesting course material (particularly when you get into the 20th Century). Strong overlap though with Intro to International Relations, which usually had more interesting lectures.

I think this course is ideally an interesting course, and the material we covered was certainly interesting. However in practice it was difficult to follow and oftentimes confusing. There was really a lot of information and it was not always in order and so studying for the exams was very difficult. As was trying to take good notes during lecture. Sometimes overwhelming. Do not take this course as a pdf!
I will highly recommend this class to other students.
I would highly recommend this course for any student, especially one with a specific interest in military history.

I would not recommend this course unless you are specifically interested in military history. I love history and have done well in other history courses here but I really did not enjoy this course. Whether you're a history major, someone who loves history, or someone who just wants to get their HA, there are better history courses out there. This course just tries to cover too much in too little time, and it didn't go into enough depth for my liking. Lectures always felt rushed and barely scratched the surface of the wars and battles we were covering. The readings are also going to be boring unless you have a burning passion for military history.
I would recommend but note that grading is relatively difficult.

If you are going to take this course, you MUST go to lecture. Professor Bell presents myriad information that is not covered in the readings but is necessary to do well on the tests. If you go to lecture, you won't be disappointed because Bell is an incredibly gifted lecturer. Also, make sure to do the readings each week because it is difficult to follow the precept discussions if you don't have the necessary background information.
If you are interested in the material, take it! If not, still not a hard course, but the reading might become dull if you are not interested in the material.
If you are looking to take a History course just to take a History course, maybe there's a more interesting option.
If you don't have much of a history background, it's a good HA or general interest course.
If you have any interest at all in war or history, this is a great course which brings together a multitude of themes against the backdrop of war and battle throughout modern history.
It is an excellent military history class

It's a solid course and an interesting way to cover some key points in modern history writ large. There's a fair amount of material covered, as one might expect in something of a survey course, and for that reason lecture attendance is crucial. Prep a lot for the midterm/final, and don't stress as much over getting all the readings done in detail.
Make sure to go to lecture and precept.
Must do the readings!
Only take it if you like military history-battles, weapons, strategy. This is not a typical history course.

SOC 250: Western Way of War is a bit more interesting. This class is a historical run through of wars, but doesn't really go that much into the details. You get both the soc approach and the history in SOC 250.
So interesting. Take it if you want to learn about war, or are interested in foreign policy

Superbly taught course. Bell is an amazing lecturer and very down-to-earth, and he's very approachable and easy to talk to. I never felt sleepy in this class and I learned a ton about military history. Do take it if you're interested in wars.
Take detailed notes of your readings as you read, instead of waiting to midterm and finals weeks to do so.
Take it
Take it!
Take it- it's great!
Take it.  It's relatively easy, interesting, and not a typical large, easy history class.
Take this class if you have any interest in history
Take this course whether your a history major or not!

Take this if you need a history distribution requirement or if you're interested in military history at all.  You will learn a lot about not just individual battles but how military engagements have affected history as a whole.  The workload is pretty light, and most of the readings are interesting.
Take this if you're interested at all.
The class is both fair in terms of both grading and workload with interesting lectures and precepts. Take it if you can!
There is a lot of reading and it requires a lot of work but I was always interested in the course material, never got bored in lecture.
This class is pretty much what you'd expect, you learn about war in the western world.
To only take it if they have a lot of time to dedicate to it.
Use the questions Bell provides each week to narrow down your focus in the readings, otherwise they can be overwhelming.
Very interesting course and I recommend if any interest in European war history.
WAR WHAT IS IT GOOD FOR AMIRITE. TAKE THIS CLASS
Well structured class. One who is interested in war history should absolutely take this course.
go to lecture and precept and do readings. in order to do well must be completely engaged
descrip: A survey of the history of war in the Western world since the late middle ages. Will cover both "operational" military history (strategy, tactics, logistics, mobilization, etc.), and also the relationship of war to broad changes in politics, society and culture.

title: Light, Camera, Action
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs/ay201314/

title: Intermediate Polish
prereqs: PLS105.
descrip: The class will continue to improve students' knowledge of Polish through conversation and review of grammar, and it will enhance their reading skills through the analysis and translation of some Polish poetry and fragments of prose. There will be also short written assignments.

title: Narrative Filmmaking
reviews: Be aware that you and your peers make this course successful or unsuccessful. You get out as much as you put in.

Be prepared for a lot of hard work. I have never pulled as many all nighters or worked as hard for a course. It is intense, but worth it if you care about film. If you are not passionate about this and don't want to put in the work, don't take this class, period.
Take it if you're interested in learning about video production from a storytelling, feature film perspective.
Take it, but be prepared to do a LOT of work.

There is a huge discrepancy in how much work you will have to do for this course based on what position you have in the two films that are made. The writer/director will by far have the most work to do, while everyone else can get away with not doing much at all.

This course will demand a lot of time and energy on your part, but I feel that it is worth it. This is really a class that reflects the amount of work you put into it. It is self-driven; Professor Abt will show you the way to create good films, and it is up to you to apply it to real life. Go for it, but as she always says, "step humble to the craft."
descrip: This studio course will be equal parts directing and screenwriting, with a special emphasis on social issue-driven material. Students will learn how to bring a script to life in collaboration with actors, production crews, and their fellow students. The course will also critically examine a selection of powerful narrative films and analyze their different approaches to visual storytelling. Specific topics covered will be: the basic tenets of film direction, writing for the screen, effective ways to work with actors, the post-production process, and how journalistic research methods can inform the early stages of the filmmaking process.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Economics
reviews: Ask questions! The lectures are very intersting.
Nah. Rather some Philosophy course to get you thinking.
You have to go, so don't miss too many classes...
good
descrip: This seminar is designed to help graduate students in economics cultivate ethical research practices they may apply in future work at or beyond the University. Students are encouraged to discuss concerns that may arise during the conduct of their research with experienced faculty and devise solutions for dealing with these concerns. The course provides necessary training for newly mandated RCR training for graduate students supported by government grants, and is required for successful completion of the program.

title: Biophysics
reviews: If you really want to learn biophysics, you're going to need to supplement materials. But this course is great to get good biological intuition
THE TRUTH: You can always take the class and drop it later if you lost interests.
Take it because it's required
descrip: The course presents a broader view of biological physics. While the course starts with an overview of the fundamentals of biological physics, using Frauenfelder's text book as a guide, the course will move on to higher levels of biological systems, using evolution and ecology as our primary organizing principles. The course will have a section on the Physics of Cancer at the end.

title: Hydrology
reviews: DO the readings!
Do the work and stay caught up on readings. It will make exams easier.
If you think you're interested, take it. Be warned that lectures can be dull and just a bunch of equations, but the precept discussions are interesting, and Prof. Smith is a great guy.
descrip: Analysis of fundamental processes in the hydrologic cycle, including precipitation, evapotranspiration, infiltration, streamflow and groundwater flow.

title: Science and Technology of Nuclear Energy: Fission and Fusion
reviews: As a chem major, the problem sets were tough, but it's an incredible class. Goldston is an awesome lecturer. Take it.
Definitely go to office hours and don't be afraid to ask either the professor or TA for help when you need it. Start the problem sets early.

Definitely take this course. I hadn't done physics since freshman year, but this was awesome (and thermo was totally not required - don't know why it was a prereq). Get a good group for the problem sets, since hunting down all the relevant equations in the lecture slides can be annoying if you're doing it by yourself. This course will really give you a solid sense of what nuclear fission is, how it works, and what the policy implications are. The fusion half is a little less well-organized, but that's probably because nobody actually knows how to make fusion work yet. Take it, take it, take it.
Even if you should not need this course for your Research interest, there are many things beyond the scope that you will learn. Do not hesitate, take it !!!

Not a very good introduction to the actual science of nuclear energy and plasma physics. The problem sets are time consuming but not very satisfying intellectually. As a physics student, I would recommend taking another elective that goes a little deeper.
Not recommended for senior spring. Otherwise a great course.
Prof. Goldston is amazing, but the problem sets may be an exercise in finding the right formula in the lecture slides more than anything else.

The course can get quite heavy on the math and physics aspects, and this is speaking from an engineering major's point of view. You might be more comfortable with the material if you're a physics major though.
Fortunately, Prof. Goldston is very friendly and helpful. Go to his office hours, and he will take the time to go through the derivations with you and explain everything that you want to know.
prereqs: PHY 101-102 or 103-104 or 107-109, MAT 201 or 203, or EGR 191-194. CBE 246, CHM 306, MAE 221, PHY 301 prior or concurrent, or permission of instructor..
descrip: Concern about climate change has driven some to support the growth of nuclear fission power. The events at Fukushima Daichi and the fear of nuclear terrorism have driven others away. New experiments in fusion energy are moving towards the realization of an alternative approach to nuclear power, with fewer dangers but not yet commercializable. In this course we will study the science and technology of both fission and fusion. You will gain a good physical understanding of how both approaches work, including their benefits and risks, through applying and expanding your scientific and mathematical skills.

title: Dramaturgy Workshop: Hoodwinked
reviews: First of all, Jill Dolan is a gem. I'd go so far as to recommend you take ANY course she's teaching (or for a bonus, a course joint-taught by Prof. Dolan and Stacy Wolf). That being said, this dramaturgy workshop (which I believe is the first of its kind) was such a refreshing course, offering an overview of an  aspect of theatre often overlooked on Princeton's campus. The practical application on the Hoodwinked project was interesting and took up the vast majority of the course. One drawback though was that it did feel at times like we were doing the same thing every week.
I definitely recommend this class, particularly since I expect the plays being developed in the future will provide better opportunities for dramaturgy.

I hope that next time it is offered, the class works on a different text (and I know Professor Dolan had some issues with the text we worked on this semester as well). But the meat and bones of it were so great; definitely worth taking!
If you are thinking of pursuing a career in theater, you should definitely take this class!
Jill Dolan is an amazing teacher.  Don't hesitate to take a course with her (or several)!

Jill Dolan really is the warmest, most encouraging prof around. Any class with her would be great, and while Hoodwinked itself wasn't the best piece, I would recommend another dramaturgy collective in the future.

Prof. Dolan is an incredible professor and project facilitator who sets reasonable goals and provides valuable learning opportunities. She is incredibly knowledgable about the current theater scene and this course allowed me to be exposed to new work that changed my perspective on theater today. Take this thought-provoking course and learn about a new way to be involved in theater!
Really depends on the text you're working on. But Jill Dolan is an absolutely wonderful professor and everyone should take a class with her.
YOU MUST TAKE IT!
descrip: This workshop explores the basic precepts of American theatre dramaturgy, using playwright/director Emily Mann's play-in-progress, Hoodwinked, as its example. We'll review the literature about dramaturgy as a production and literary method in American theatre, and apply those strategies to help develop the Hoodwinked text. The play addresses the massacre at Ft. Hood Army base in Killeen, Texas, in 2009, and investigates the political complications of terrorism and jihad. The course culminates in a staged reading of Hoodwinked and a one-day public symposium about its issues with invited guests.

title: Introduction to Sanskrit II
prereqs: CLA 475/LIN 475 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course builds on the grammatical foundations acquired in the previous semester (CLA475/LIN475) by engaging with the original Sanskrit language as found in Epic-period literature. Our readings include excerpts from the Bhagavad Gita and the story of Nala and Damayanti as narrated in the Mahabharata.

title: Master of Engineering Independent Project II
descrip: Continuation of MAE 513. Directed study for Master of Engineering students. The topic is proposed by the student and must be approved by the student's research advisor and have received approval from the MAE Graduate Committee.

title: Intensive Portuguese
reviews: Take this class if you are interested! Very fun--just be prepared to keep up with the work because it moves so quickly!
Take this class if you're interested in learning a new language, and already have knowledge of Spanish!

There's a steady stream of assignments for this class, which is essential to retaining a language taught from scratch at a pace as fast as this. If you're pretty competent in Spanish, this'd be a good class to take if you want another language under your belt in a relatively short time. Probably wouldn't recommend it if you're not very comfortable in Spanish; definitely not if you have not had any Spanish.
Very fun way to get started with Portuguese!

E preciso que voce estude portugues com Nicola! Seriously, this class is amazing. In just 24 sessions, you will reach an astonishingly high level of Portuguese, both spoken and written. There is a significant amount of work: five two-page compositions, five small quizzes, a midterm, final, final paper, and an oral presentation. Don't let that deter you from taking this class, though! With good time management and a bit of enthusiasm, it's extremely manageable. Take this class with Nicola if you can; she is so lively and engaging that you will look forward to going to class every day (or twice a week, as it were). This course is best taken by those who have studied Spanish and are comfortable with their oral proficiency in that language; French speakers seemed to have a bit more trouble in this area than the other students. 
      Simplesmente dito, esta aula foi a melhor aula de lingua que eu tinha durante meus quatro anos em Princeton. Uma oportunidade muito legal para todos!
descrip: An intensive course designed for students who have fulfilled the language requirement in Spanish or another Romance language. Knowledge of one of these languages provides the basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. This one-semester 'crash' course teaches fundamental communication skills--comprehension, speaking, reading and writing--and some exposure to cultural aspects of the Portuguese-speaking world, but does not offer an in-depth study of grammar.

title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
descrip: This seminar is an introduction to contemporary sociological theory from the mid-twentieth century onwards with the work of some earlier theorists included. The seminar is organized around several clusters of enduring questions that have been of principal interest in sociology. Throughout, the emphasis will be on ideas that can guide fruitful empirical research rather than on abstract perspectives.

title: Ethics and Economics
reviews: A fair course as far as less mathy departmentals go. Go to lectures and the reading is unnecessary. Lectures are great but problem set are long and sometimes feel randomly graded. No-midterm, no-final is a plus.

A really good class that combines economic thought with ethical theory. A familiarity with basic ethics will help you understand this class, but to do well on the problem sets you only need to take really really good notes in lecture. Write everything down that he says. The problem sets ask you to regurgitate his arguments, and the more notes you have the better. Grading on the problem sets was difficult. Having the right answer often only earns you 8/10 points on a question.
Be prepared for super arbitrary grading. Seems like everyone is getting a flat B.
Professor Leonard is a great lecturer. But be prepared for extremely subjective grading on the homework assignments, midterm, and final.
TAKE IT. The assignments take long but the class is so worth it. I learnt so much about econ and philosophy. Professor Leonard is amazing.

TAKE THIS CLASS!! professor leonard is amazing, the work is not quantitive, and it's an incredibly engaging and thought provoking course - so happy i took this my senior spring, since it was one of the best classes i took during all 4 years at princeton

Take impeccable notes and don't miss class. Leonard is a great lecturer although the material can sometimes be dry.  Really time consuming problem sets, but there are only three of them and they are offset by no work the rest of the time besides attending class (the readings are completely unnecessary); overall a low time commitment and interesting if you aren't that into other EMs.  If you took Law and Econ I would say this class is even better and less time consuming.

Take this class if you want an economics class with interesting and thought-provoking material that is less math-based. Don't be put off by comments about the assignments. Go to office hours for clarification and you should be fine.
Take this course because the material is interesting and the lectures are some of the best around.

Take very good notes on the lectures as most material on the problem sets can be answered by things covered explicitly in class. If you are interested at all in the intersections between philosophy and economics, I would recommend the course.
This course is similar to Law and Economics, but it is a bit more demanding in terms of both content and assignments.
prereqs: ECO 100.
descrip: Introduction to ethical issues in market exchange, and in laws that regulate it. How ethical commitments evolve, and influence cooperation. The moral dimension of low wages, price discrimination, income inequality, trade in inalienable property, and the separation of choice and consequence.

title: Ottoman Diplomatics: Paleography and Diplomatic Documents
descrip: An introduction to Ottoman paleography and diplomatics. The documents will be in divani and rika scripts.

title: Knowledge and Travel
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Techniques of Conducting
