reviews: As a non-music major, I recommend this course regardless. Michael Pratt is a fantastic conduction and teacher, and just a great person to know. If you're interested in the subject, you'll learn a lot.
Definitely take it if you are at all interested in musical conducting! The more work you put in outside of class the more rewarding it will be for you.

It's a great course to take if you have any interest in conducting. Professor Pratt does a great job. Note that you learn only the baton-waving part of conducting, though, and little of transpositions and other theory-based material.
Take it if you have any remote interest in conducting. Pratt is very good at what he does and makes you literate in leading an orchestra.
Take it!
Take it. Do yourself a favor and take it.
This class is amazingly interesting and useful. Highly recommend taking it. Small workload, and very enjoyable.
YES.
prereqs: MUS 105 or permission of instructor. Some background in music theory..
descrip: This course will focus on: 1) the building of a vocabulary, verbal and non-verbal, that will enable competent conducting 2) learning effective rehearsal technique and 3) developing an overview of stylistic concerns, as related to orchestral repertoire.

title: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities - Exemplary Stories, Case Histories
reviews: This course changes every year but the semester with Brooks and Doherty was quite relaxed and enjoyable. Learned a lot.
This course was a great capstone to the certificate.
descrip: In studying the humanities, we often encounter stories - of figures past or present, real or fictional, historical or hypothetical - that offer their own exemplarity as a promise of some broader application or lesson. This seminar will reflect on the roles such exemplary stories play, in fiction and non-fiction. We will give particular attention to one subcategory of stories: the case history, which has a special status in law and in psychoanalysis. What do authors intend when writing factual or fictional "case histories"? What are we supposed to learn from them? What is at stake for the subjects of such stories, as well as for the readers?

title: Contemporary Experimental American Literature and Visual Culture
reviews: Definitely not for everyone. You'll get as much as you put in. Expect to work really hard. If you put in a lot of work, you'll learn a lot and probably do well. But if you don't want to put in the work, definitely don't take the class. Professor Ball really makes sure that you're invested in this class. But if you are, you'll be rewarded.
Definitely take this class no matter who you are and what you are interested in.
Take it if you can!!

Take it! So much fun - not just for English majors, art historians, and visual artists, but for anyone. We read comics, played a video game, visited the art museum, and so much more. Prof. Ball is a wonderful teacher and will match your level of engagement - so do not take this class if you do not plan to do the readings, put work into the experiments, or be immersed in class discussions. There is no reason not to do any of those things and you will lessen the experience for everyone else in seminar if you don't. It is not an "easy" LA, because these texts are experimental so they can be difficult and Prof. Ball won't hesitate to call you out on bad writing, but it is definitely a FUN LA, and has the potential to improve your writing and enrich your approach to material in other courses.

This class is a great one, but be warned that Professor Ball has extremely high expectations.  If you think you can take this class on the side and turn in half-assed work, expect some harsh comments and somewhat condescending feedback.  HOWEVER, if you put in work, it's totally worth it.  There's so much to be interested in here that you can find yourself hooked to a topic and discover some interesting things.
Watch out for precisely what work will be required. Enjoying the readings doesn't matter as much when you're too stressed out about the assignments.
descrip: This course will study contemporary writers and artists at the intersection of the fine art exhibition, the artist's book, and graphic narrative who seek to overturn the traditions, formal devices, and audience expectations of literary fiction. Do such experiments in image and text radically alter our previous conceptions of literature or do they reassert notions of innovation, authenticity, and originality that undergird conventional ideals of the literary? How do these works respond to the turbulent changes in visual culture and publishing in the digital age and force us to read and see differently at the outset of the 21st century?

title: Judicial Politics
descrip: Topics typically include: design of judiciaries and legal systems, doctrinal struggles within judicial hierarchies, bargaining on collegial courts, judicial selection, judicial independence and the rule of law, judicial-legislative relations, interest group activism and rights creation, judicial federalism, politics of administrative law, civil liberties in war time, social consequences of judicial activism.

title: Introductory Painting
reviews: A lot of extra time other than class but very amazing if youre willing to put in the time. Prof cameron was very helpful and insightful

I would recommend this course to a student who is strongly interested in painting and visual art. Be prepared to spend several hours in the studio each week outside of class. Do not expect this to be an easy class. Painting can be quite challenging, but you will learn a lot in this class if you put in the effort.
It is a large time commitment, so make sure that you are prepared for significant work outside of class.

Super fun, you'll learn a lot if you know nothing about painting. Knew nothing about painting in the beginning (think stick figure) and learned more I ever thought I could. 

Doesn't emphasize on technique though, know that.

Takes up LOTS of time, though, be prepared. A painting a week is the average.

If the class fills up before you can sign up, still show up to the first two weeks of classes. People will drop out as they realize how much work the class will be, and you can take their spot given you've done all the work so far.
Take extra time outside of class to work on your paintings.
Take the course for the LA, and be surprised at how good you get at painting throughout the weeks.

This is a great course if you want to experiment with painting. However, this class requires a significant amount of dedication and involvement if you really want to improve or learn. Prepare to spend quite a bit of time outside the regular painting sessions to paint.

Very good introductory course to a more traditional painting method, focusing on under painting and over painting. All paintings are in acrylics and are representational. I would recommend taking this class regardless of if you have a lot of prior painting experience or not. The time commitment is reasonable, and it is a great change of pace from other course work :)
its a good class but know that it takes time outside of the classroom.  it also isn't very easy grade-wise but it is a nice break from books and problem sets.
descrip: An introduction to the materials and methods of painting. The areas to be covered are color and its interaction, the use of form and scale, painting from a model, painting objects with a concern for their mass and interaction with light.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: For those who want to know about Asian culture and society, you should take it.
See above. I would recommend that students push for a text/discussions/presentations to supplement desk crits and public presentations.
That the studio is what you make of it and that you are mostly alone, free to work on your own terms.
prereqs: Two vertical studios are required for all M.Arch. students. Three-year M.Arch. students are required to complete Digital Media Workshops before entering the Vertical Studio sequence..
descrip: Vertical Design Studios examine architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. Projects include a broad range of project types, including individual buildings, urban districts and landscapes.

title: The Origins of Rome: Livy and Vergil
reviews: DO THE HOMEWORK! and then participate in class.  It is the best way to really learn the grammar and what is going on.  Studying for the exams and quizzes becomes a lot more easy.
Do the translation ahead of time, it makes class a lot more enjoyable
Haynes is a goddess. Take a class with her. Now.
Keep up with the translating, always.

Livy and Vergil are great. If you can, definitely take this course with Professor Haynes. She's awesome. It is a good amount of work (~25 lines of poetry a day, check the syllabus for more details), but not unrealistic.
Take it if you are interested in Latin/ancient culture and need to fulfill a language requirement. Or take it anyways.
Take this course! Professor Haynes is a thoughtful, caring professor who is amazing at what she does. I feel so lucky to have had her as a teacher.

The only reason you're taking this, probably, is to fulfill the Latin language requirement, but be relaxed and enjoy it. Make sure you are prepared each day, and just have fun with the texts because Professor Haynes will always have fun with them.
This is a fun class - the translations are pretty manageable, and Professor Haynes is very engaging.
Work together!
great course - keep up with translations
prereqs: LAT 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: We will read selections from Livy and Vergil, the masters of prose and poetry respectively in the period of Augustus. Our objectives are: to develop the ability to read Latin with greater ease and enjoyment; to improve sight-reading skills; to experience the artistry of Latin prose and poetry; and to examine some of the questions associated with the Romans' interpretation of their history.

title: Probability Theory
descrip: Graduate introduction to probability theory beginning with a review of measure and integration. Topics include random variables, expectation, characteristic functions, law of large numbers, central limit theorem, conditioning, martingales, Markov chains, and Poisson processes

title: Major Author(s) - Mourning America: Emerson and Douglass
reviews: Take it! Emerson and Douglass are incredible writers and Cadava is a great person to learn from

Take this course if you are interested in gaining a truly insightful, intellectually stimulating, and inspiring experience. Professor Cadava cares very much about this material as well as his students.
Take this if you have an interest in the material or need to satisfy a departmental.

This is an incredible course that I would recommend to all students, no matter your major or interest. This course taught me a lot about what I wanted to learn at Princeton but didn't get a chance to until senior spring. Professor Cadava is probably my favorite professor at Princeton.
take it!
descrip: This course focuses on the literary and political writings of these two "representative men" of the 19th century. Suggesting that the promise of America has yet to be realized, they argue that democracy can be furthered through acts of writing. The course stages an encounter that may revise our understanding of both of these writers, especially in relation to issues of slavery, racism, and capital. Demonstrating that Douglass' strategies of writing have relays with Emerson's points to the political and historical character of Emerson's writings but also to the profoundly literary elements of Douglass' political writings.

title: Transformation of the Ancient World: Byzantium 500-1200
reviews: Do the reading.  You will be thankful that you did.
This is definitely a good course to take if you are interested in Medieval European history.
take it. Everyone should learn about the Byzantines
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course introduces the history and culture of Byzantium, with some material on the medieval European world to the West and the Islamic states to the East. We will focus on the development of Byzantine society and economy, on how the state worked, and how Byzantium related to its neighbors to both the West and the East. Why did the eastern Roman empire survive the barbarian invasions of the fifth and sixth centuries? How was the state ruled and by whom? How did it deal with the powerful Islamic states to the East? How and why did the Byzantines arouse the hostility and suspicion of the medieval West and the papacy?

title: Seminar in Modern Spanish Literature - Seminar in Spanish Film
reviews: I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who speaks Spanish and is interested in cinema. I thought the course itself was great. However, I would caution people that, as a graduate seminar, it's quite fast-paced, and I had difficulty contributing to the discussion.

Students with either a high or a low familiarity with Spanish culture will benefit with this course. With a comparative approach, it recalls the main topics of 20th century culture in Spain through movies. Definitely a very worthy experience.
Take it!
prereqs: NO AUDITS.
descrip: An examination of Spanish film since the 50s in the context of international cinema (Ozu, Casssavetes, Fassbinder, Godard, Dardenne, Jia Zhan Ke, Lee Chang Dong, etc). Attention to history and memory, trauma, melancholia, subjectivity and representation, untranslatables, empathy and violence, melodrama, post-theological worlds.

title: Energy Storage Systems
prereqs: Knowledge of ODE/PDE.
descrip: This is a survey course on energy storage systems with a focus on electrochemical energy storage. Fundamentals of thermodynamics will be reviewed and fundamentals of electrochemistry introduced. These fundamentals will then be applied to devices such as batteries, flywheels and compressed air storage. Device optimization with respect to energy density, power density, cycle life and capital cost will be considered.

title: Physical Chemistry: Chemical Thermodynamics and Kinetics
reviews: A very good course; thermodynamics is a difficult subject to learn but Professor Kelly teaches it very well.  Because of the format of the class, where you do reading summaries for each chapter before the corresponding lecture, the lectures can begin to feel somewhat repetitive, but I think I learned the material really well as a result.
A whole lot of work as a senior, so it's tough to keep up since it's honestly unrealistic in terms of work; and I'm not sure it's too rewarding since it's so far removed from your day to day.
Go to office hours. You'll learn most of the concepts there.  Discuss the conceptual questions if you have nothing better to do.
It might be a lot of work but the grading is pretty fair and the information is pretty useful.
This course is hard. It's challenging but not in a ridiculous way. You have to put the work in but if you do, the subject material is doable. Professor Kelly (and Maor) are absolutely amazing.
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 and MAT 104, or CHM 215, or permission of instructor. Course is open to freshmen who have completed CHM 215..
descrip: At the center of this course is the recognition of Gibbs Free Energy as a fundamental quantity describing physical processes. From this, we will develop concepts of thermodynamics and kinetics, and illustrate them with examples from chemistry.

title: Topics in Social Theory and East Asia
descrip: An introduction to classical social theory of modernity and an exploration of new directions in social theory in contemporary social science. Course examines the ways in which Western scholarship on East Asia has engaged with theories of modernity, at times generating new bodies of thought on social exchange, capitalism, feminism, the state and civil society, and agency and subjectivity. Texts on Japan, China, and elsewhere, moving between theoretical, ethnographic, and historical contexts, are used.

title: Studies in the Religions of the Americas - Religion, Race, & Gender in Latin America
descrip: This course explores the intersections of religion, race, and gender in the history and historiography of Latin America. It consists of three chronological units looking at: the formative and "baroque" eras of the colonial period, (1500-1720); late colonial Bourbon reforms through the early national period, (1750-1865); and the triumph of liberalism through the first half of the 20th century, (1870-1950). Seminar participants choose to write either a historiographic paper focusing on the scholarly literature surrounding a particular theme, topic, or time period or a research paper.

title: Topics in Inorganic Chemistry - Catalysis
reviews: Come and learn!
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in getting a flavor for the field of heterogeneous catalysis.  Very little prior knowledge is required to engage in the course and learn something.
If you're interested in surfaces, this is a good course to take.
Take this course if you are interested in catalyst
Take this if interested in catalysis/your research concerns surface science in general.
Try to combine what learned from all the professors so that you can take the most from this course.
Yes, if you're interested in surface catalysis (and if it's offered again in this particular incarnation)
descrip: This is a survey course which includes study of the kinetics of catalytic systems, analytic techniques to identify key species, and the exploration of well-established catalytic processes. Both heterogeneous and homogeneous catalyst systems are covered. The importance of surface morphology in heterogeneous systems is investigated along with an introduction to electrocatalysis.

title: Seminar in Central European Art
descrip: This seminar considers the idea of the "Netherlandish Model", the impact of the Low Countries on cultural exchange with Central Europe (and the world) ca. 1400-1750.

title: Special Topics in Environmental Engineering and Water Resources - Geochemistry
descrip: Studies in selected areas of geochemistry and biogeochemistry. Special topics vary according to the instructor's and the students' interests.

title: Selected Topics in Russian Literature and Culture - Translating Russian Poetry
reviews: Take this only as a pdf.
prereqs: RUS105 (or beyond) or permission of instructor. No previous knowledge of poetry (Russian or otherwise) will be assumed..
descrip: This course will serve three functions; it will introduce students to some of the superb Russian poetry of the last three decades and thus offer a window on recent Russian culture; it will allow students the opportunity, through translation, to improve their practical language skills; and it will serve to raise important questions about translation as an art. Class will be conducted in English, but texts will be read in the original Russian.

title: Empire and International Relations
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: Austen, Bronte, Eliot: Abandoning the Marriage Plot
reviews: Beware the Janeites! There will probably always be a couple people in this class who have loved Austen and/or the Brontes for years and address the texts solely on the level of pathos. It gets old, but luckily Nord is a really sharp prof and a great discussion leader (and not above the occasional reproving word regarding the quality of discussion) and you move to George Eliot eventually. I loved it.

Don't take this course. Professor Nord is just not a very good teacher, and her seminar falls flat. Even though I loved the books, I dreaded going to class and suffering through three hours of boredom. She shoots down interesting or unorthodox ideas (even if they're just in play for discussion purposes), seriously dislikes being disagreed with (an constantly makes it clear that she disagrees with student ideas), plays favorites, and too frequently makes no effort to elevate the level of conversation. People often spoke about characters as if they were real people, referred frequently to what they "wanted" from the endings of the novels, and were occasionally hostile to other students. Professor Nord did not seem to really care about the discussion at all. Professor Nunokawa's 19th Century British Fiction is a much better alternative. Read the books on your own, but find another course to take.

I would advise that students really take advantage of the class discussions to bring up any questions or points they would like to make. This seminar is a great way to really talk through your opinions and questions regarding the materials.
If the reading list interests you, then you'll enjoy the course.

If you're interested in these authors, definitely take this course. Even if you've read some of the books before, reading them in an academic setting and under Professor Nord's guidance really bring a lot of new and unexpected things to the table.

It was an OK class. It's a 3-hour seminar though so make sure you have the attention span for it and the novels are incredibly long. Luckily, there's no exams which is good if you prefer writing papers to taking a midterm and final (my main reasoning for taking the course).
Just be engaged and you will learn a lot!
Take it!

Take it! Wonderful, wonderful course.  Try to do the reading ahead of time if you can, particularly Villette and Daniel Deronda are long and challenging but so well worth the effort to understand them closely!
This was my first ever English course as a senior in the engineering school, and while I struggled a bit with the papers (multiple visits to the writing center helped!), I never felt out of place in class discussion.
descrip: This course will consider the demands, opportunities, and constraints of the marriage plot in nineteenth-century fiction. We will read early and late novels by Jane Austen, Charlotte Bronte, and George Eliot with an eye to the evolution of the plot of courtship and marriage in the literary careers of each. How does each novelist deploy and yet rebel against literary and sexual convention? What kinds of experiments and departures from tradition does each novelist attempt in her later works and especially in what turns out to be her final novel?

title: Electronic Circuits for Biomedical Application
reviews: Definitely recommend it. Mainly for Naveen Verma. He's awesome. But don't take it if you're looking for an easy course.
Don't take this unless you have to. It causes lots of stress and pain, as it's basically a class on MOSFETs and amplifier configurations that doesn't really address biomedical applications.
ELE and similar majors should definitely take
Has a basic concepts of circuits and systems and fundamental behaviors of MOSFETs.
If you aren't afraid of a little work, this is a great course in which you'll learn a ton.

If you know you want to design circuits at some point, then you should absolutely take this course. Otherwise, I would take something else. 

Also, the first ~two weeks of lecture are nothing like the rest of the course. Read ahead in the book to check that the material interests you.
It's a course that will give insight into circuit design for biomedical application. I will recommand for students with interest in analog integrated circuit design.

More of an advanced course in analog circuits with occasional case studies in biomedical electronics. Also, this course takes a lot of work- I probably spent about 20 hours on the average pset. That said, if you're interested in circuits and you can spare the time, absolutely take it. Verma's lectures are amazing. 404 will change the way you look at circuits. One of my favorite departmentals so far.

This course will give you an intuitive grasp of analog MOSFET-based circuit design.  Professor Verma is both an excellent lecturer and an excellent teacher.  However, be advised that the material is extremely challenging, the exams are difficult, and the problem sets are long.  To get the most out of this course will require a lot of time and engagement.
This is a great course. Verma is very understanding and fair. Had fun with it. One of the better ELE courses for sure.
prereqs: ELE 203, ELE 208, ELE341 (recommended, exceptions by instructor's permission).
descrip: Start by analyzing biological systems to understand the origins of some of the signals that they present. Develop circuit models of these systems to determine what instrumentation circuits are required at the interface so that the signals can be reliably acquired. Study analog circuit topologies based on MOSFETs for low-noise instrumentation and processing of the signals. Study digital topologies based on MOSFETs for extensive computations on the biological signals. Analyze the trade-offs between the analog and digital topologies. Emphasis is on design and analysis using circuit simulators.

title: Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: A really excellent class for anyone with an interest in writing fiction.  The quality of the class is highly dependent on the student effort, since a large portion of the class consists of reviewing student works, so make sure you put a good effort into writing your stories.  The workload is fairly relaxed but extremely enjoyable and engaging.
Are you kidding me? It's so much fun, and it's a rare opportunity to learn something creative in this way.

As someone who's never taken a creative writing class of any sort, I found this class to be a supportive environment for receiving an introduction to the "tools of the trade." It is helpful to have an idea of the stories that you want to write for the workshops early on.
CRL is very friendly and helpful, not to mention talented.

Chang-rae Lee is amazing. He gives great advice and really emphasizes the professional short stories that we read each week. The only (HUGE) downside about this class is that students are allowed to send out their stories the night before class meets, which means that often it was hard to spend enough time reading and commenting on the stories. If you don't have time to edit the morning before class this may make you very, VERY frustrated. Other professors have slightly different formats for when you have to turn in your story.

Chang-rae is a good instructor to take this with if you're an experienced writer. He'll make you feel good, support you, etc. He's incredibly nice and the class was pretty structured. If you're looking to really grow, I'd recommend it with someone else who will really challenge you to improve. Because the class was so chill, I didn't feel much motivation to get better. This class was incredibly fun though and had a light workload. Definitely take one of these in your Princeton career.
Definitely put in the effort and try to do the same for other's stories.

Definitely take this class. Although it's P/D/F (so you can slack off if you want), you can get a ton out of this class if you put in the time to try and write quality stories. Also, definitely recommend A.M. Homes' class! She's the best.
Definitely! You don't necessarily need a big name to enjoy the class!
Fantastic course. Everyone should take a CWR course at some point.
Fantastic course. Take it!
Fun and a nice change of pace from any technical classes you might be taking. Much lighter workload.
How well the course goes well for you really, truly depends on how much you put in. It is a good class for fulfilling a distribution requirement, as it is also p/d/f.
I would definitely recommend this course.
I would recommend taking a creative writing course with Professor Whitehead.

I would strongly recommend Professor Steinke to other students - she's not only successful but also takes the time to structure her classes in a fun and engaging way. An excellent writer and advisor in one!
I would take this class; it is incredibly fun, engaging and a great balance to the rigors of engineering. Professor Lee is also great.
If you have an interest in creative writing, definitely take an introductory class. The work load is very low and the class time is short. But you get proportionally more out of the class.
If you have any inkling about taking a creative writing course, you should take it, because it's awesome.
If you like creative writing and/or improving as a writer in general, take it!
If you like writing at all this class is fun and you will learn and there's no need to be intimidated by writing for an audience.
It's a really fun course, just make sure you have time to write the stories and spend time revising them.

Prof Lee is awesome! Note that he structures his classes with reviewing a short story the first hour and the next hour critiquing student's stories. You'll learn a lot from the professionals but won't have as in depth criticism on your stories, but I think it's a fair trade!
Prof. Lee is great ? he's super chill and nice but also offers great constructive feedback. Listen when he offers it because it's valuable! I'd highly recommend taking Intro Fiction with him.
Put some thought into the pieces you do so you can get the most out of the class. The value of this class is dependent on whether you work for it.
Spend a lot of time on your stories! You get out of this class as much as you put into it. And you can always arrange to meet with the professor privately if you ask for it/set up appointments.
TAKE. TAKE AGAIN. TAKE MULTIPLE TIMES.
Take advance of the opportunity that is this class to learn as much about writing as possible and write bravely.
Take it or you're missing out.
Take it with Professor Watkins.
Take it! Chang-Rae is great, very perceptive and constructive with his critiques and insights.
Take it! Professor Watkins is a great professor and you'll learn a lot from the other students in the class.
Take it.
Take this course, and take it with professor Homes. She is amazing.
This class is excellent! It is a ton of fun, and Chang-rae Lee is a fantastic teacher. The work load is pretty light and manageable.

This class is fun and the amount of work that you do is up to how involved you want to be. If you're taking it just to pass a PDF, then so be it. If you're taking it because you genuinely like creative writing, then even better - so worth it.
This course is enjoyable and Chang-rae Lee is an extremely nice instructor, but you will not be pushed particularly hard or necessarily improve your writing unless you put the work in yourself
This course was a terrific addition to an otherwise math/physics courseload.  It was relaxing, interesting, and genuinely engaging.  I wish I could take more CWR, but alas... the real world beckons.
Write.

You should absolutely take a creative writing course. It's a nice way to break up the grind of your schedule, and you might end up writing more than you ever had before (I certainly did). I had a terrific experience, Chang-Rae Lee is absolutely phenomenal, both insightful and down to earth.

Your experience in this course is largely determined by how much effort you put into it -- how much you invest into your growth as a writer and reader. This course will allow you to discover new things about your writing style while also introducing you to the necessary skills for being a resourceful reader and effective participant in workshops.
definitely take it! one of my favorites at princeton!
take it!
prereqs: Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers a perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Visions of Transformation: Religious and Secular
reviews: Every student ought to take at least one religion course during their time at Princeton. The professor (and in my case also the preceptor) will not disappoint here. What it even means to speak of a "religion" discipline in the modern academy will be given valuable attention. Given the degree to which religion continues to figure in the contemporary political and cultural landscape, along with the realization that "it" isn't going anywhere anytime soon, I would strongly recommend this interdisciplinary approach from a very passionate pedagogue. The film component of the course is also deeply interesting, particularly concerning the means by which the modern medium serves to represent (and re-write) the discourse of religion.
If not a required course for your major, understand this course is equal parts religion and film. the emphasis is heavy for both, so it is good to be interested in both.
If you are interested in Film or Religious studies it's a great great class.
Kinda changed my life, actually though. Take it, regardless of your major. It is important for life in the most fundamental way.
Lots of class time, but interesting material.
My advice would be to read as many of the texts as possible because they are fantastics. The films are also incredibly enriching.
Prof. Stout is a genius in the field of religion. He also knows his movies. Admittedly, the movies were old and decidedly non-Hollywood, but I enjoyed them nonetheless.
Take it if you're interested in a broad overview of religious topics - origin, historical debates, secularization, etc. The films were all excellent - many in (rare) 35mm.
Take this.
The film selection alone makes the course worth taking. Combined with the readings, the course can be an eye-opening experience.
The films are great. A good EC, and there's not a lot of coursework aside from two papers of moderate length.
don't.

if you like big ideas - take this course.  it is really great it terms of learning about the different ways people think about themselves and society.  but i'm more historically inclined so it was a challenge for me to get through the denisty of the matieral.  prof stout is great though
prereqs: Required for Religion Department majors..
descrip: An examination of thinkers (e.g. Pascal, Marx, Freud) and filmmakers (e.g. Hitchcock, Kurosawa, Friedrich) who distinguish between a way of life they regard as sinful, oppressive, and/or deluded and a process of change in which the alleged defects are overcome. An introduction to modern debates over religion and to film as a vehicle for social criticism.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Advanced Topics in Financial Inclusion
descrip: Access to finance has been the most prominent development intervention of the last 20 years. Yet half the world's population remains unbanked, and the evidence of microfinance's impact is limited at best. This seminar explores obstacles and policy solutions to providing the world's poor with appropriate financial services. Focus is on current and policy-relevant topics, with guest presenters from the microfinance industry.

title: The Politics of Nature
reviews: Definitely take this course if you are interested in politics, anthropology, and/or the environment. Professor Ellison is very knowledgeable and an incredibly engaging professor. You will learn a lot and probably be convinced to become an anthropology major.
Take it.
This class is fine. If you're taking it just for distribution requirements its nice because its not that much work but anthropology is frustrating for many hard science majors
This course will change how you think about nature and environmental protection. A course that fundamentally changes how you think about a topic is worth taking!
This is a great class to get you thinking more critically about issues you care about.  I walked out of this class with a new perspective that I will carry with me beyond the bubble.
only take if interested in the material. Ellison is nice but not a have-to-take professor and there are a lot of readings.
descrip: In this course we will consider the social and political life of nature from an anthropological perspective. How are our ideas about nature historically and culturally produced? What is the relationship between resource control and the consolidation of power? From the work of conservation NGOs (nonprofit organizations) to laboratory-produced GMOs (genetically modified organisms), we will explore how notions of pristine wilderness, polluting people, and ethical business are produced and contested. Course themes range from the lived effects of extractive industries to nature as both a commodity and the grounds for claiming political rights.

title: Ohms, Environments: Architecture, Resistance and Media Technology
descrip: The seminar explores articulations of environment in post war architecture through new technologies of communication, production and reception. It tracks media and environment as they intersect through a broad range of practices, pedagogies, technologies and social theories. It considers environmental design as a response to perceived complexity, as the site of liberatory expansiveness and as resistance to architectural conventions. It assesses environmental failures from urban violence to ecological distress and examine the extent to which contemporary architecture has tuned in to or resisted postwar environmental strategies.

title: Behavioral Economics Workshop
reviews: Sign up if you do behavioral or theory.
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Behavioral Economics

title: Luso-Brazilian Seminar - Rethinking the Enlightenment
reviews: Although I had a great experience taking this course, I must confess that it is not an introductory course to Brazilian culture. I would advise only people seriously committed to the study of History, and particularly 18th century History, to take it.
descrip: What are the legacies of the Enlightenment? How do 18th-century developments resurface, or are resignified, in later debates? In this course we study major events, texts, and turning points of the period, as well as their repercussions or reception in the 20th and 21st centuries. With the Luso-Brazilian world at its center, the seminar focuses on three interrelated and overarching themes: transatlantic circulation of knowledge; slavery and the emerging science of race; literature (esp. poetry) and urban imaginaries.

title: Multilevel Models (Half-Term)
reviews: An excellent advanced statistics class. We are so lucky to have this professor at Princeton!
If one believes multi-level modelling is relevant to his/her future work, this is definitely a very helpful class.
Take if interested in using MLM.
Take this course! If not for multilevel models, for a basic understanding of Bayesian inference . . .
take it but you have to be accountable for making sure you internalize the material with time out of class working through it, even without assignments
prereqs: WWS 509 or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to statistical methods for the analysis of multilevel data, such as data on children, families, and neighborhoods. Reviews fixed- and random-effects models for clustered and longitudinal data. Presents multilevel random-intercept and random-slopes models, discussing model fitting and interpretation, centering and estimation of cross-level interactions, and extensions to binary and count data using maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods. Course emphasizes practical applications using the multilevel package MLwiN. Half-term course, offered second half of spring term.

title: Policy Seminars
prereqs: Enrollment is limited to WWS concentrators and certificate students. The course is required for concentrators, for whom it is considered Junior Independent Work. Junior concentrators are automatically signed up for the policy seminar as Junior Independent Work, not as WWS 402. WWS juniors who are certificate students must enroll. Seniors serving as commissioners and graduate students serving as consultants may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: In policy seminars students work in groups first formulating the general problem, then engaging in individual research on subtopics, and finally presenting their inferences for discussion and debate and producing a collective policy report.

title: Theory of Detection and Estimation
reviews: Difficult but rewarding.

Estimation and Detection is ubiquitous. Definitely take this class. It would be very helpful to have a good background in probability, statistics, and information theory as the course was mostly based on information measures.
I would suggest students to have rather solid mathematical background, at least some basic understanding of real analysis, before attending this course.
descrip: An introduction to the fundamental theoretical principles of signal processing related to detection and estimation. The level of this course is suitable for research students in communications, control, signal processing, and related areas.

title: Turkish Literature in Translation: From Omer Seyfettin to Orhan Pamuk
reviews: I would advise any student wanting an not only an introduction to Turkish literature, but also history and society, to take this course. I would also recommend not falling behind on the responses, and doing them before class.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!
This course will offer an excellent introduction to the literature of modern Turkey and should be recommended to students with an interest in literature and Turkish Studies.
This is a rewarding course; If you are interested in Near Eastern literature and culture, take this course. Professor Hatemi is amazing!
descrip: This course introduces a concise look on modern Turkish literature predominantly through short stories. It aims to provide a sample of Turkish literary writing and basic knowledge of its actors and works. The reading list is naturally shaped by the limited number of English translations available, nevertheless it will offer a colorful picture of diverse authors, their works, literary themes and styles, as well as social, political and cultural issues in Turkey during the last century.

title: Topics in Modern Astronomy
reviews: A fairly interesting choice for an STN. Exams much harder than HW.
I would recommend keeping up with readings in the textbook and going to the weekly problem review session to reinforce ideas.
If you like astrophysics and physics, this course will be fun.
It's an intro class in astrophysics, which is cool. If you're good with calculus, this class isn't the hardest science course you could take.
Make sure to talk to the TAs if you have questions.
Office hours are extremely helpful, go to them!
Pay attention in lectures, read the textbook, review weekly, and really understand the problem sets.
Read the textbook and do a lot of practice problems.
The course is not very engaging, unless you really like the material.
The textbook is very helpful so be sure to read it

This class is great! I took this course because I needed to take a physics-related class to apply to medical school. I wasn't expecting to be very interested in the subject matter, but it turned out to be one of the more interesting classes I've taken.

This class was really easy but lectures were kind of boring. They were full of information but the interesting stuff was interspersed with tons of really dull basics that almost everybody already knew. If you're an astro major, I see no reason not to just skip it at take Cosmology or something.

This was a pretty cool class.  The homeworks were intriguing and (relatively) not too time-consuming (although the exams were relatively hard).  If you are considering astrophysics even a little bit as a major, it's a wonderful course to take.
You should absolutely take this class if you want to get a broad, physical and mathematical introduction to astrophysics, but it isn't stars for stoners.
take this if you enjoyed physics 103
prereqs: PHY 103 or 105 and MAT 103 or 104 or permission of instructor.
descrip: A broad overview of modern astronomy and astrophysics for students in the sciences. Emphasis is on the application of basic physics to understanding of astronomical systems. Topics include the birth, life, and death of stars; planetary systems and exoplanets; supernovae, neutron stars, and black holes; the formation, structure, and evolution of galaxies; cosmology, dark matter and dark energy, and the history of the Universe.

title: Religion in American Society
reviews: A nice overview of religion in America. Not too difficult, interesting readings, and Prof. Weisenfeld is very organized which is nice!

Do the readings, come to class, enjoy the videos, and talk with the professor about the parts of the class that interest you! She knows something about everything and is more than willing to talk more about anything after class.
Focus on lectures and larger themes rather than smaller points. it is highly thematic
I really recommend this class! I thought the material was super interesting, relevant, and accessible! The class wasn't too hard and I had a great time!
Judith is amazing, this class is a great 5th (a bit soft as a 4th) - really fun and will enrich your looking at America and religion in general
Take this course if you are at all interested in the topic.  Also a good 5th course -- not too much work.
descrip: This course explores the dynamics of religion in contemporary America. We consider such themes as religious encounter and conflict; patterns of tradition and change; the relation of religion to broader political currents and debates (including race, sexuality, gender, science, economics); "secular" spiritualties, the challenges of religious pluralism; and religion and popular culture.

title: Music and European Jewry
reviews: I would definitely recommend other students to take this course.
I wouldn't take this course unless you consider yourself fluent in music and/or Judaism. I also wouldn't take this course unless you are an auditory learner. Otherwise, PDF it.
If you are interested in music of Judaism at all, take this course.

Prof. Heller was a wonderful professor who really engaged with the students and made us laugh and have interesting discussions. There was very little lecturing, but a lot of questions raised and class discussion. I really enjoyed the discussions had in this class and the pieces and composers we covered.
Stay on top of the readings and give this your all. It's very interesting material and Wendy Heller is amazing.

Unfortunately Professor Heller will be taking a sabbatical next year, but after that - if you need a music course (or just an LA), i would recommend a class with her. You will certainly learn a lot and enjoy yourself on the way.
if you have a vague knowledge about music, or just enjoy classical music (or yiddish theatre), take! lots of fun, interesting, but not a redundant or too easy class
prereqs: The class is open to all students with interest in European history, music and art, Judaism, and Holocaust studies. Background in music helpful, but not required..
descrip: This course examines the experience of the Jewish musician in Europe from the 17th-century through World War II. We will explore how Jewish music; which had so long isolated Jews from mainstream Christian society; would ultimately provide a path to inclusion; how anti-Semitism shaped the careers of Jewish musicians; and how notions about Jewish music fostered anti-Semitism. Topics include: Jewish musicians in early modern Italy; Sephardic Jews in 18th-century Amsterdam; Mendelssohn and the "sincere conversion"; Victorian London and her Jews; operetta, opera, and symphony in fin-de-siecle Vienna; music during and after the Holocaust.

title: Options, Futures and Financial Derivatives
reviews: Assuming that Haddad and Gordy are still teaching it, I would recommend taking this class. The first half (Haddad) feels like an undergraduate level extension of 362 (aka it's a pretty standard derivatives introduction). The second half (Gordy) was taught closer to the graduate level than the undergraduate level. I did not feel that the first half entirely prepared me for the second half, but I felt that the jump would not be as difficult for math track ECO or ORF majors. The second half had a lot of statistics that I was not prepared for, but had to pick up on the fly.
Don't take this class unless you're really really interested. It's challenging and frustrating at times.
I think it's overall not a bad class. There are better derivative classes out there (ORF 335 for example) however.

The exams are a bit challenging, but they are doable. Try your best. This class will probably be more challenging than many ORF courses, but I learned a LOT. If you are considering between this and ORF 335, definitely take this or take ORF 335 then take this. This class covers a lot more of the "real" stuff (things that actually happen in the market these days) and review over papers that were written in the 21c.
The first half was interesting and while not a walk in the park, understandable. The second half escalates quickly. Good luck if you choose to take this course. Also, 8am isn't as bad as you think.
prereqs: ECO 362, ECO 202, or equivalent statistics course, and calculus..
descrip: The course offers an introduction to financial derivatives and the models used to price them. Pricing techniques include the Black-Scholes formula (awarded 1997 Nobel Prize in economics), as well as extensions to accommodate time-varying volatility. We also consider counterparty credit risk in derivatives trading and the market mechanisms that have arisen to mitigate this risk. This course is technical by nature, and requires extensive use of calculus, statistics, and spreadsheet programming.

title: Art as Interaction
reviews: Fia is the best. She basically changed my life. And this is the perfect class for you if you want to do anything related to social change in a critical way. It'll help you see things in a new light, I promise. TAKE THIS CLASS!

Push yourself and take this course--you won't regret it. Fia said something in class that stuck with me for a long time: "If something about your art makes you scared, that's what you should be pursuing." That space of discomfort is a rewarding place to be, for an artist. Push your limits, go interact and make art!
TAKE THIS COURSE. Especially if you're not an art student! Soc, anthro, woody woo, politics, etc would be great in this kind of class.
You will learn a lot! It's worth taking this class for the opportunity to do the group project. Expect A TON OF OUTSIDE WORK though...
prereqs: Any 200-level course offered by ART, CWR, DAN, MUS, THR, or VIS.
descrip: With roots in political art and community activism, art as interaction inserts itself into public contexts and directly engages its communities and its audience - often with the hope for social change. It endeavors to make social structures as art rather than objects. This class will investigate public art today through readings, case studies, and creating projects that engage the spaces on and around campus. What kinds of societal questions can art pose while still being art? In what ways can forms of collaboration and audience participation be part of artistic practice? Can art provoke social change?

title: Readings in Classical Japanese
prereqs: JPN 403 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Selections from outstanding works of Classical Japanese prose and verse from Nara to early Showa period, particularly in the genres of history, philosophy, and poetry.

title: Intensive Intermediate and Advanced Italian
reviews: Definitely take this if you really want to improve in Italian. Even if you are unsure, at least try it out and I'm sure you'll like it.
Don't try to be too creative with the written assignments. You are really just doing them to improve grammar, not your story telling skills.
If you're comfortable with learning a new language fast or you have a background in a romance language then it is definitely worth taking the accelerated track.
It's not that much work, but it really helps you understand the language. If you're shy though, don't take it.
Take it!
prereqs: ITA 101 and Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Italian 102-7 is an intensive double credit course designed to help students develop an active command of the language. Reading comprehension and oral proficiency as well as reading skills and grammatical accuracy will be developed through various activities. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Students will be familiarized with various cultural aspects of Italy through readings, cultural videos, and films.

title: Topics in German Literature - Poetry and Philosophy
descrip: This course explores the relationship between poetry and philosophy within the context of the German tradition. We read works of philosophy inspired by poets, works of poetry inspired by philosophers, and works whose status lies bizarrely in between, in addition to some of the theories and commentaries that seek to pinpoint the epistemic contribution of such hybrids. In the process, we ask ourselves all the most basic questions about the possibility of a specifically literary truth, but we do so on the presumption that even these basics will turn out to be historically conditioned.

title: Advanced Chinese: Contemporary Literature and Film
reviews: A great way to read move your Chinese to the next level. You will be reading and writing a fair amount each week.
Definitely take it if you're interested and have the Chinese language skills required for this class.
Start the assignment early!
The homework for this class I do when I don't want to do hw from another class... enough said
This course is really interesting. It will really help you improve your writing skills in Chinese.
This is a good course if you have studied Chinese at Princeton before and wish to maintain your proficiency, or if you are a native speaker.
prereqs: Students should have already taken at least 3 years of Chinese or have equivalent language proficiency..
descrip: This course is designed for students who have learned Chinese for three or more years. The goal is not only to improve student's ability to listen, speak, read and write in Chinese, but also to introduce them to the intellectual and literary development of China after 1949 by sampling literary masterpieces and representative movies. Genres covered in this course include critical essays, short stories, poetry, and visual arts such as posters and film. Through class discussion and writing assignments of formal essays with more advanced vocabulary, students will increase their Chinese skill to a new level.

title: Advanced Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: 202 will be easier, but this is more interesting.
Be prepared to put work in, but if you like math and want to challenge yourself, this class is worth it.
DO ALL PROBLEM SETS.

Do the readings before lectures; they are short and very helpful for grasping the material covered in class. The first two weeks are the most difficult; it is hard to grasp the abstract concepts of subspaces/nullspaces/column spaces and the seemingly arbitrary rules of row reducing and echelon form matrices at first, but things becomes much smoother afterward. Preparing for tests requires devoting time to practice problems from past exams. A very useful and different "kind" of math that you may be used to; particularly, very different from multivar calc. Material is very logical and well-connected.
Fascinating topic, take this course if you are considering it

If you are interested in learning a bit about proofs and don't mind a bit of a challenge, you should definitely take 204 over 202. The class avoids many of the tedious calculations that 202 has to do, and instead we get to do fun proofs (but not too challenging).
If you are not a Math Major taking 217 or 218, but you want a little more than the rote computation of 202, than this course is for you.

If you aren't interested in pure mathematics and are just taking linear algebra as an engineering, economics, etc. requirement, I would warn you to think carefully before taking this course. Professor Taylor moves very fast during lecture (it often went over my head), and the supplementary problems on the problem sets are very time consuming without being really interesting or rewarding. Each problem set took me at least 10 hours to complete, often more, with a lot of help from other students. While I learned more in this course than I would have in 202, I don't know how necessary it really was, and my grade certainly wasn't as good as it could have been. One the other hand, the curve is much more generous than in 202 (average test score is usually just above 50%, and this is about a B+). If you do decide to take this course, here are my suggestions to do well (which I admittedly didn't usually heed myself): 1) read the textbook section before lecture. Professor Taylor moves so fast that it's good to have a basic understanding going into lecture. If you don't read it before lecture, definitely read it afterward. 2) start the problem sets early in the week. Ideally, do each book section after lecture, then do the supplementary problems over the weekend (starting saturday, not sunday). 3) find a study group! don't try to do the problem sets by yourself, even if you can manage it in the beginning, because they get more difficult as the semester progresses, and you will likely need help later on. also, working together makes the problem sets more fun

If you feel good about your math abilities, if you have had some exposure to linear algebra before, or if you want to learn a lot more about linear algebra than you would in MAT 202, do it. If you're worried about having a ton of work or if you're just doing linear algebra for a distribution requirement, you may not want to take it.

If you have never done proofs before, make sure you try and do homework with someone who has in the first couple of weeks. Don't be afraid to ask about concepts, as everything builds off of everything else.
It is a hard class but it is worth taking
It is a very challenging course if Christine is teaching it but worthwhile. Prepare for hard exams.

It is realllly well-organized, everything was returned in a timely manner, and Taylor was always available to help out. The course is difficult, but the material more than makes up for it and it was really cool to see how linear algebra applies to the world around us.
It takes a lot of time, but is very rewarding afterwards. You will learn matlab and lots of applications of linear algebra, and you'll actually learn them well.

It's a very good class, take it even if you didn't like 203. It will increase your interest in Math for sure. But be ready for a time commitment. Don't take it along with other difficult classes, and don't take five in the semester ifyou want to do justice to this course.
Start the problem sets at the beginning of the week and try to work ahead. Attend lectures. Do lots of problems to prepare for exams.
Stay away if the course hasn't been redesigned. Extremely interesting/powerful material, but covered horribly.
Study for all quizzes and exams. Start early on problem sets. Don't be afraid to ask questions either to students or instructors. Many people are equally lost, just like you.
Take 202 unless you're a maths person

Take it and take it with Prof. Taylor! Go to her office hours because she's super friendly and helpful. I wasn't sure about math/linear algebra before I took this class, but this class sparked my interest in them.
Take it if you're willing to really put in the time and effort to adjusting to all of the different manners in which the material is taught and used.
Take the course if you want to learn linear algebra deeply but keep in mind it is a lot of work.

Take this course if you are willing to put in the extra time and really learn linear algebra. The course is very proof heavy, but there are also many very useful applications that are considered. It is worth the challenge, and you will grow a lot by taking it.
Take this course if you want to learn linear algebra and don't have too tight of a schedule.
The P sets were killer; about 10 to 15 hours. The exams were hard too; average always around 55%. It breaks boys, but makes men. Take it, and you will become a man.
This class is a real challenge. You will learn a lot, but it wont be easy.
This class is fascinating and very well-organized. In addition to being quite thorough in the subject, it also explores many interesting uses for the concepts taught in the class.

This class is much less frustrating than MAT 203. The material is actually very fun, and Christine Taylor is simply amazing. The course is very organized, which is always helpful! Towards the end of the semester, the material becomes a bit too technical and perhaps boring but be careful to always stay on top of it, because you will need everything for the finals

This course is difficult (especially if you don't have much experience with proofs) but definitely learnable if you put the time into it.  Practice the proofs in the book as they will help you get used to common patterns and ideas used in the proofs you'll have to do on your own.

This course is very challenging and moves rapidly through the material. Make sure you read the textbook before coming to the lecture, and do not be afraid to attend office hours to clarify any confusion that arises.

This course will give you a deep understanding of linear algebra, but not purely for its own sake like 217.  If you want to learn why the theorems of linear algebra are true, rather than just how to apply them to problems, take this course instead of 202.  Problem sets are take some time to complete, but they are totally worth it for the deeper understanding of the subject.

This course will teach you a lot of applications of linear algebra, and a lot of lot of proofs. I took it without previous linear algebra experiences, and do wish I had known more about matrices and things to start out with. I had not taken any Princeton math before this class, and I did feel at a slight disadvantage because I didn't know what to expect unlike people who took 203. Other than that however, it is definitely possible to take this before multi. Do put in a lot of studying. Realize that problem sets will take several hours (for me, upwards of 10 hrs each week). Realize you will need help for the supplementary problems, and do go to the study sessions on the weekends! Try to start the psets early. I highly recommend Professor Taylor! She is very interesting, and interested in helping you succeed. Take practice tests before quizzes and exams!! 
This course is extremely challenging, but even though I've not done as well as I'd hope I think it has been extremely rewarding in everything I've learned. This is much less computation than 202, but has a lot of proofs and theoretical difficult ideas.

This is a fairly difficult course that will occupy most of your weekends. Definitely keep up with the material by reading Professor Taylor's lecture notes and preferably reading the textbook before class. This will help you understand what is going on, as Taylor's lectures are extremely fast-paced. (Switch into her section if you can; Professor van Zwam goes too slow to cover all the material.) The problem sets will take you at least 10-12 hours, so start them early. If you keep up, the quizzes and exams will be difficult but doable. (Know magic squares; they appeared on all four of our exams.) Professor Taylor is very dedicated to the course and will be happy to help you if you need it. Overall, the class definitely has a strong theoretical component, though there is lots of computation as well. Take it if you want to be challenged and if you have the time.

This is a good course and it challenged me and expanded my capabilities for mathematical thinking. However, the applications side of the course really isn't up to scratch and the MATLAB component is a joke. If you are truly interested in learning linear algebra, I would take 217 instead (which reputedly has less work than 204, because they go through less material with more rigour).

This is a great course to take!  You also learn a little bit about how to use MATLAB, which is cool and kind of interesting.  I enjoyed the course and liked how it went into a little more detail than (from what I heard) MAT 202.

This is a very difficult course. The Psets will eat up a significant amount of time - they are difficult and time-consuming even in a collabroative setting. The examinations are brutal. However, you will learn much more material here than the 202 classes learn. Furthermore, some of the applications covered exclusively in this course (e.g. Principal Component Analysis) have a wealth of practical applications in several industries. I would adivse you to take this course but be prepared for the course to eat up more and more of your life as the material gets more and more complicated.
Yes, the course is informative and applicable to many important things.
great course.
i think 217 would be better in general if you want proofs. it's probably good for physics people though.
make time to really understand the concepts involved
descrip: Companion course to MAT203. Linear systems of equations, linear independence and dimension, linear transforms, determinants, (real and complex) eigenvectors and eigenvalues, orthogonality, spectral theorem, singular value decomposition, Jordan forms, other topics as time permits. More abstract than MAT202 but more concrete than MAT217. Recommended for prospective physics majors and others with a strong interest in applied mathematics. Prerequisite: MAT104 or MAT215 or equivalent.

title: Reading Freud's Great Case Histories as Short Stories
descrip: See website

title: From Molecules to Systems to Behavior
prereqs: Successful completion of NEU 501 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This lab course complements NEU 502A and introduces students to the variety of techniques and concepts used in modern neuroscience, from the point of view of experimental and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include electrophysiological recording, functional magnetic resonance imaging, psychophysics, and computational modeling. In-lab lectures give students the background necessary to understand the scientific content of the labs, but the emphasis is on the labs themselves. Second half of a double-credit core course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: Quantitative Methods
reviews: AVOID THIS COURSE IF YOU CAN. poorly taught, boring, and the professor is very unprofessional.
Attend the lectures and pay attention.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. I took it thinking it was the "easy stats class" and the material was fairly easy, but the midterm and final were extremely unfair and tested us on material we were never taught. There is no book so you can only rely on his sub-par class powerpoints, which he directly read from during lecture. If you want to learn stats, take a different course. If you want to get a good grade, take a different stats course. Only take this class if you want short problem sets that really don't help much come midterm or final.
DO NOT TAKE. TAKE SOC STATS

Do not take this class. Absolutely horrible. The fact that Andrew Conway has a job at this university is truly insulting because he is incredibly incompetent and literally the worst teacher that I've ever had. I taught everything myself and if there was a dog teaching the class I probably would have learned just as much in lecture.
Don't listen to students who talk about his last lecture. He's a very calm guy and does a great job with the class.

Don't take it this course unless you need to. It is boring and the professor does not teach. If you have to take it, take really good notes when watching the videos and still learn the material that he tells you will not be tested on, because he will test you on it!
Don't take unless you have to.
Go to Laura if you need help. Also rewatch lecture videos.
Go to lab. Homeworks are pretty straightforward. Pay attention in lecture and memorize everything on the slides.
Go to lecture and lab! If you do, life will be good :)
Good if you want to learn how to do research and how you should use stats when doing research. Not so great if you're looking for something quantitative.
Good stats to take.  Basis of R

If interested in psych or neuro, this class will help you understand the stats you see in journal articles much better. The course was more conceptual than math based, but it was still good overall and not very difficult. Weekly quizzes and short psets.
If you need to take it, do it but go to office hours with the professor.
Its an easy stats course, though the lecture leaves much to desire.
Just "suit up and show up" for labs and lectures. It make be dry and boring at times, but it's worth it for that Psych. major!
Know the terms (and how to distinct them), and look into any resource outside of class (e.g. Google, Khan Academy, etc.)
Lecture will be worthless, the lab is unrelated but useful in learning R. Take as a fairly easy QR or for the major, but it won't really help your life.
Not an extremely interesting lecture, but relatively easy and if you pay attention in class and lab it's very informative and clear. Pay attention though-- quizzes can come back to bite you.
Not bad for a QR I guess

One of the easier stats classes offered, but probably one of the most poorly taught classes at Princeton. If you can't make sense of what Conway is saying in lecture, just watch his videos, or google everything. Little to no math required on exams, really just theory, so if you suck at math take this one.
Only if necessary.

Prepare for quizzes and do homework attentively. Organize your notes. Goes without saying, but keeping up each week will help your midterms/ finals life considerably, and this class gives you ways to do just that.

Pretty easy stats course. There are better, more rigorous courses if you want to learn the material in depth. The only issue is the exams, which are deceptively simple (25 multiple choice and short answer questions). Losing a couple points on them can disproportionately impact your grade.

Professor Conway seems easy and this may make it seem like it is okay to disengage from lectures, but he notices and gets upset.  He made our final extra-challenging because of the tension created by this issue.
Stay on top of everything, because the midterm and final are 25 points each and 25 percent of your grade each.
Take it, it's a good stats course to take.
Take this class if you're looking for an easy stats class. Don't take it if you really want to learn statistics and think you may need to use it in your independent work, or future research.

Take this course if you must, but don't expect to learn too much. Although this course is among the easiest courses I have taken at Princeton, I felt that the course was largely a waste of my time. The lectures were dull, repetitive and boring. The lectures were quite disorganized, as were precepts. Although tests were quite easy, some questions were completely unfair and were clearly not addressed in class.
The class isn't too hard as long as you pay attention in lecture and lab.
This class is inexcusably bad. Do research and see if you can find a better Stats option. If you have to take it, start teaching yourself EARLY on Kahn Academy!

This is a terrible course. I know there aren't many other options for stats, but only take this if you have to. It's so frustrating to be in a class and feel like you're not learning anything over the course of the entire semester. Don't take it unless they make some drastic changes.

This is a very difficult situation. Ask any previous student who has taken this class, they will tell you that it's not a difficult class but the professor is horrible every single semester he has taught and doesn't care because he has a tenure. Only take this class if you need it for your major, otherwise take another stats course. This is not worth it.

This is a waste of a course. If you don't need it for a requirement, don't take it. If you need stats as a requirement, this might be one of the better choices. The material is "easy" in a sense, but I didn't feel like I learned much. The stuff that I learned I probably could have just looked up the equations for because basically that's what we did. We memorized equations, traced through them (as in "if N increases what happens to F?"), and spit back the information on exams. There was little to no math involved. We were just tracing through a bunch of statistics equations and giving them all these names/acronyms that are used in psychology. Grading was not based on a curve which was a blessing until we found out that exams are 25 questions only and also 25% of your grade; that means one question wrong and you lose a whole percent on your final grade. The professor is very awkward teaching and is not inspiring at all. He also completely lost it and blew up at us the last lecture, not very professional or patient.

Very poorly organized. Conway skips lectures as he pleases, often because he goes on tangents during lecture and the class falls behind. There is a painfully obvious lack of communication between the TAs and Conway because the homework and and quizzes, which are distributed by the TAs, often had material that the professor did not teach. That being said, the class is still really easy if you independently study. Save yourself the time - skip lecture and watch his online Coursera videos instead. You'll learn twice the amount of material in half the time.
Watch the online lectures to go over what is taught in class, but also go to in class lectures.
You basically have to teach yourself the majority of the course. Lectures were repetitive and it was very hard to tell what material was relevant.
easy class; if you need a stat class, this one is okay.
great class.
take if needed
descrip: The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the basic techniques of statistical analysis used in psychological research. Students will learn the logic underlying the statistical techniques and learn how to perform statistical analyses and interpret the results.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A full year study of an important problem or topic in chemical and biological engineering culminating in a senior thesis. Projects may be experimental, computational, or theoretical. Topics selected by the students from suggestions by the faculty. Written thesis, poster presentation, and oral defense required. The senior thesis is recorded as a double course in the spring. Departmental permission required.

title: Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: A new way of thinking about math. Much more theory than 201, and True/ False will be the end of you. But you learn a lot, and I think overall the course is easier than 201. It is very easy to get behind on the material, which is very bad due to the fast pace of this course.

Aaaaaa. Get a good preceptor. Like Sheridan. That will make/break you in 202. Because this shit isn't easy, and you need a good teacher to help you guide it through. Oh yeah, and take all the practice examinations. PSET's are not like the quizzes/tests.
All math is harder than it seems at Princeton
Attend the classes and dedicate time to the assignments.
Be prepared to work, and don't be worried if you get really bad grades because the curve will save you.

Definitely to go to office hours and finish the assignments early.

Go to office hours whenever you have a question, conceptually or on the homework, and make sure you have an understanding not only of the processes in calculating things, but also of the conceptual and geometric meaning behind what you learn. Keep up with the material, and everything should be fine. Do practice quizzes and exams decently ahead of time; they're very helpful. If you don't understand a topic, read the book section, it usually helps.
