I don't advise taking this course unless it's a requirement.  While it's a decent introduction to Linear Algebra, we never explored the material deeply enough for it to be interesting.  The exams are unnecessarily difficult (with averages running around 60%) and the homework is tedious.  On a positive note, it's still manageable even if you aren't the best at math.
I found it harder than 201, though I was one of the few.

I think this is a solid course overall. I liked it better than MAT 201. It's the most clearcut way to learn the linear algebra you need for your course requirements, but be prepared to put in a decent amount of work and effort into it.

I would advise students to take MAT 204 / MAT 217 if they would like more of a challenge in mathematics. This course is not very rigorous and not very abstract. It is very concrete and all about using the methods they teach you. While you get a good understanding of the basic concepts, all of the theorems and tools are pretty much derived for you. Yet, there are not very many applications that we did. But I guess if you are looking for a chill and easy class, this would be it.
I would highly recommend doing the reading before each class. Once I stopped doing the reading, I stopped understanding the material, and problem sets necessitated a weekly all-nighter.
I would highly recommend trying to get into Niels Moller's class and make use of his office hours and strong desire to help his students learn.
I would not recommend this course to anyone unless they need it as a requirement.
I would really advise paying attention to your professor and asking as many questions as you can. MAT 202 is a worthwhile class, and if you work hard I am sure that you will succeed.
I would recommend looking at the past exams to help prepare you and understand the material.
I would recommend reviewing material frequently to prevent confusion on future material.
I would recommend taking this course. It's hard at first, especially the proofs, but you'll get used to it.
I would recommend this before MAT 201 as an entry into math, it seems much more like an actual math class than the cutthroat trickery that was MAT 201.

I would say it's very helpful to work with other students when studying for exams and doing homework, because every teacher probably taught slightly differently, and different students are going to have different levels of knowledge on certain topics, so talking through them with each other will let everyone understand more.
I would say to try to be in Nick's precept; he was instrumental in learning the material.
I would tell them to be sure to do problems sets diligently.
I wouldn't take it just out of interest, but it's good for engineers.

I'm assuming that most students taking this course are required to. Make sure that you understand the material from the first three chapters, because the course builds off of previous chapters. Work in the first few weeks to understand the relationship between the algebraic and geometric meanings of linear transformations.

I'm just being a baby. 202 isn't that bad if you pay attention, but it's taught in a very abstract sense and isn't dumbed down very much for us less-math-minded children. So watching Adrian Banner's videos on 2x speed after a lecture will make life so much better.

If I took this course again, I would make a sheet of the theorems as I moved through the course, and I would try to review the sheet at least a few nights a week before going to bed to form a solid web of concepts in my mind.

If Nate is teaching again, GET HIM. He's the best preceptor by far, explains things in a way that will almost convince you to be a math major. He holds office hours frequently, and they're actually helpful. He walks you through the homework so you actually learn it. He teaches class so you know exactly what's going on at all times. He is incredible. Otherwise, this course is really hard.

If you don't have to take this course, don't do it. That being said, the topic is actually relevant to several other majors and topics so if you have the type of math mind that I don't, it may not be too bad.

If you have to take it there's not much you could do about it except try to stay ahead and start your problem sets 3 days before they're due. If you're not required to take this, it's better than MAT 201 but you're still crazy if you opt to take this...
If you like more computation-based math, take this course. Otherwise take MAT204 or MAT217 for more rigorous theory.

If you need 202, take it. Get Javier as your preceptor, he was awesome. Many of your classmates will have taken it before, don't get frustrated if you don't know what's going on the first couple of weeks.

Linear algebra is very very fascinating, largely because it shows you some really cool relations in mathematics and geometry. Take it if you have to, but complain about it after in a vain attempt to convince the powers that be to make the class more exciting and more interesting to the people who want it to be interesting.

Take it! I went from 203 to 202 and was worried I'd be bored, but 202 with McConnell is awesome. He's a genuinely nice person who cares about the material and wants you to succeed. The material is interesting, slightly computation heavy ? but that is balanced out by interesting things like the true/false questions on tests. Take it with McConnell as your instructor and go to his office hours ? he's great! The class is consistent throughout and the topics are well covered. Definitely recommend it.

The course is fair in grading and has a decent workload, but is useful for learning the necessary mathematics for future classes.
The course is highly conceptual (there's no way to visualize an orthogonal basis in 5 dimensions, after all), so be prepared!

The course is not super interesting, but if you take it, take it with McConnel, Bellittini, or Javier. I think all the profs teaching it are good, but the material is fairly dry. The exams are very hard, and the homework is boring and repetitive.

The tests are difficult. Linear algebra is not a computational subject. It's heavy on the concepts and you need to constantly review the theorems and definitions before the tests and quizzes. I recommend doing plenty of practice midterms and quizzes and keep track of the topics you need to review. The true false section of the exam seems menacing, but with practice and an understanding of the concepts, you will be fine. It's an interesting course, very different than MAT 201 and the math courses you took in the last few years of high school. It can be very intuitive. It's cool to think in higher dimensions than what you can physically visualize.

The textbook wasn't very clear to me so I definitely relied on lectures. When I missed a detail in lecture I often found that the Blackboard files entitled "Handouts from Mihai Fulger" were very useful (these were also useful when studying). By far the best way to study for exams is to go through the Fulger notes and then do practice exams. The exams were usually pretty straightforward and the practice exams will give you a good idea of what to expect.

The way that exams are graded is absolutely ridiculous. There is almost no partial credit, so even if you understand most of a question, but make one tiny mistake, you get almost no credit. If you take this class, get ready to be very frustrated each time you take a test. Oftentimes you will understand much more material than your grade reflects. Make sure you try to get Nate as a preceptor as well. He will spend as much time as you want or need at review sessions and office hours.

The way the class is set up, most of the really important stuff happens in the first 9 weeks, so near the end of your semester you might feel like your understanding is slipping. But if you have a really solid understanding of the concepts from the beginning of the semester you should be fine.
This class is actually very difficult. If you have been taking calculus classes for a long time, it's definitely a change of pace and a challenge.
This class is very challenging, and more theory-based than you would think. Be prepared to work hard.
This course is MURDER!  Only take if you have to or you like pain.

This course is a requirement for many people and therefore hard to get around. However, if you invest yourself (i.e. use old quizzes and tests and go to office hours) it shouldn't be too difficult and you will be able to succeed.
This course is necessary for learning linear algebra for people interested in different types of applications of math. However, it isn't all that interesting and the curve is very tough.
This course is pretty well-taught and it's a prerequisite for other courses.

This course is quite valuable but only if you are willing to keep on top of your work and work hard on all the homework assignments.  A lot of times harder concepts won't be fully grasped until you utilize them in homework problems.  Also UTILIZE office hours, they are incredibly helpful.

This course is very different from MAT 201. If you want to learn a more theoretical view of math that has many applications (this class helped me understand quantum physics much better), then it's a good idea.
This course is very useful if you are planning on doing science or engineering, but don't take it unless you need to. It isn't worth all the work for just a QR credit.

This is a course you could do well in even if you skip classes--although I'm not necessarily recommending that you do. However, it's easier than a lot of other BSE engineering classes, and the tests are very fair. The material is interesting and the textbook is great. McConnell's lectures can be dry sometimes, but he's really helpful during office hours.
This is a difficult class, and the problem sets alone won't prepare you for exams. Take lots of practice tests, don't procrastinate!
This is a tough class and you probably have to take it. Don't try to understand the material a week before the exam, just keep up with readings
This is a very study-able class. Although it requires a little intuition, studying is really all you need to do well unlike other classes in which you either get it or you don't.
This is not the most interesting course, but is necessary. If you're looking for something more intellectually stimulating, consider MAT 204.

Try going to different precepts to test which kind of teaching style you like. Your lecture experience in the course will depend highly on your instructor's ability to present the material. The class is given at a very comfortable pace--- one chapter section in the textbook per lecture. Definitely go to office hours to get help on homework.
Try to read the textbook before going to class.  Stay on top of all the concepts learned.  The material builds quickly, and it is very dependent on what was taught before.
Understand change of coordinates, since it makes up the majority of the second semester.
Unless you have to take this course as an engineer or have taken the material before, I highly recommend not taking MAT 202 because I don't see how it will help you at all.
Unless you're really interested in math or it's a requirement I don't recommend.
Work AS MANY problems as you can!!!!
Yes
Yes, but I suggest 204 which is firmer in terms of mathematical grounding.
You probably have o take the class always, but I really enjoyed it. Material is very interesting but harder to visualize than that in 201. A lot of material is covered, so don't fall behind.
You probably have to take it, so take it
You'll probably be required to take it so be happy that it's not as bad as multivariable calc.

You're going to have to take linear algebra. I took 203 last semester and really struggled with it, and was much happier with my choice of 202 this semester. You might learn more in 204, but I also heard friends saying they felt that they weren't sure if studying would improve their grade. Doing the problem sets in 202, reading the textbook, and doing practice exams (of which there are many and which help immensely in preparation) is almost guaranteed to pay off. I liked that I got a good basic grounding and some ways to think about it I might need if I use linear algebra again, but it never felt impossible or pointless. If you're on the fence, you might try 204 first, but I think 202 is an excellent and well-organized course. McConnell gives good lectures, although sometimes it can be a bit slow.

do the practice exams basically..no one goes to class

prereqs: MAT104 equivalent..
descrip: Companion course to MAT201. Matrices, linear transformations, linear independence and dimension, bases and coordinates, determinants, orthogonal projection, least squares, eigenvectors and their applications to quadratic forms and dynamical systems.

title: Communism and Beyond: China and Russia
reviews: A very nice and informative course, that manages to condense quite a lot of information in just 12 sessions. The lectures were mostly engaging, and the material interesting. The workload is decent.
Do all the readings. You'll get a lot out of class if you do.
Don't take this course as if it were an area studies course or a sociology course. For what it's worth, though, you will learn a lot about both Russia and China.
Take this class if you really want to learn about communism in Russia and China. Very approachable and nothing too esoteric.

Try to form your own opinions when you do the readings and see if the information that is presented supports those opinions. I think that the Professor is not just looking to give an overview of the two countries and how they are connected, but is also trying to make students analyze these connections and draw their own conclusions. She likes this to be reflected in the written work.
descrip: This course focuses on the communist experiment in the Soviet Union and China. The first half of the course presents the political, social and economic histories that characterize the USSR's and China's particular path to communism. The second half of the course focuses on the consequences of communism by examining each country's demographics, environment, social structures and so on.

title: Methodology of Spanish Language Teaching: Seminar and Practicum
reviews: Be forewarned that printing out each reading would take a lot of paper, so it may be better to just read them on the computer and take notes.
Definitely take this course and dedicate time to it, it's more worth it than many others you can take. It is probably the most helpful course for your further life as a university professor.
descrip: This course is an introduction to key terms and ideas in the field of second-language acquisition and core issues in teaching modern foreign languages, with special attention to Spanish and Portuguese. Students will develop and practice skills and techniques of teaching foreign languages, selection of content and materials, evaluation of student performance, and self-assessment of their own pedagogical practices. The theoretical foundation will be applied to the teaching of the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing). The teaching of culture and the use of new technologies will be also considered.

title: Comparative Environmental History
reviews: great philosophical questions about history, the environment, and ecology. Prof. Kreike is an amazing teacher. TAKE THIS COURSE
descrip: The course examines the processes, causes, and effects of environmental change. Drawing on different historical periods and world regions, including Africa, the Americas, and Asia, class readings expose participants to different models and approaches to the study of environmental change. The course focuses on such themes as environmental determinism, ethno-ecology, biological imperialism, deforestation and desertification, the history of famine and food, and the impact of war, technology, population growth, market forces, and globalization on earth's ecosystem.

title: Welfare, Economics and Climate Change Mitigation Policy
reviews: Definitely take this course!  It provides a fascinating application of both economic and philosophical principles to climate change - if you are interested in climate change and have a background in economics or philosophy (or neither) this is a great way to learn about the other side and how they intersect.
It might not be offered again, but if care about climate change and the ethical issues that arise when we consider it, definitely take this class.
Take it. The course is well-taught and interesting, and the topic will be relevant for your life no matter what career path you choose.
descrip: Climate changes poses a variety of important policy questions. How much carbon to emit into the atmosphere, who should have the right to emit it, when should it be emitted, by what means should emissions be restricted or reduced, who wins and who gains from such policies. In this course we will attempt to answer these and other questions by considering economics of climate change and the welfare implications of the policy options.

title: Labor Economics/Industrial Relations Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences II
reviews: A great class where you will be challenged and meet great people.

Choosing whether or not to stick with ISC is a really hard decision that I think all of us had a hard time dealing with, but I am so happy I chose to stay. Shaevitz is a great teacher, and being able to say that you made it through an entire year of ISC is an amazing feeling. I honestly can't imagine learning all of this material in a different setting.

Don't take this course. It is a cool concept, but the execution makes it not worth it. The first semester is really interesting, and while it is a challenge, it is both reasonable and rewarding intellectually. The second semester is run at a much faster pace, however, and the problem sets and the final required knowledge that we weren't given in class. I am not one to shy from hard work, but this is hard work with little reward on a level different than I have experienced in other classes.

ISC is a very intense course that involves a lot of time commitments. However, it is also very rewarding and instructive. Taking ISC has definitely taught me a lot more than if i had taken all of the science intro classes combined. If you are genuinely interested in learning about science and committing your freshman year to it then definitely take it!
ISC is wonderful, albeit difficult. Do it if you want to learn science.
If you have survived first semester, don't back out now.  Although there are still some issues, second semester is much better and its a waste if you work so hard to give up now

Integrated Science is a good class overall, but be aware that the workload is very heavy (compared to other classes) and the material taught might not be what you expect. It's truly a mix of biology, chemistry, physics, and computer science, but it doesn't necessarily cover everything you might learn in the equivalent introductory level science classes. I'd recommend this class for those who truly want a holistic approach and integrated view of the sciences.

It's a fun, engaging course! You meet a lot of people who you'll know for the rest of your life. This course shows how science connects together. Just be prepared to spend a lot of nights with your ISC buddies doing problem sets and preparing for midterms and finals. I especially enjoy lab!
Take it if you are excited to learn about science, but its definitely something that you have to dedicate your semester to.

Take it if you're very interested in scientific investigation. You''ll learn a lot, and gain great friends in both your peers and the professors. I challenge you to complete the course and not want to engage in scientific investigation. It's tougher than the first semester though, especially in the second half. So take it with two easy classes.
Take the course if you're not entirely sure what sort of science you want to pursue or if you want to be MD PhD.

Take this class if you are really interested in majoring in the sciences, and you are willing to work really hard. Because this class requires a lot of work, you might find yourself with less time to spend on other things than you would like, so keep that in mind.
In addition, take Multivariable Calculus and Linear Algebra concurrently, if you can. Though these are not prerequisites for the class, they will be extremely helpful in understanding the material. From my observations of my classmates, those who had already taken more math had a much easier time doing the problem sets and understanding the material in general.
This class may be called "integrated" but it is VERY physics-heavy, so be prepared. Even if physics scares you, take it. It's an awesome class, and you'll learn how to do science.

This course is a very intensive course, more so than the first semester, and deals with very abstract and not-very-intuitive topics. The faculty, lectures, and labs are awesome, though, and the course is very much worth it.

This course is not for everyone but is worth considering. It can drive you insane, make you question how you got into Princeton, and can dominate your life if you let it. It a also gives you lasting friendships, gives you the opportunity to do awesome labs, get a paid summer internship, and work with professors that excel in their respective fields. However, a great skill to learn is when to stop working. You can always study more, work another hour, or two, or ten on a lab or problem set. But most likely, it isn't worth it. Get to the core of the concepts and project, and don't stress. There is always more work to do, so don't lock yourself away in the library for a year. You will regret it. This class teachers you a lot of life and academic lessons. It is not for everyone, it is not for the faint of heart, but it is for people looking for a unique Princeton experience.

This course is not for the faint of heart. You really need the desire to delve into the sciences. However, you can do it! If you're motivated and determined, you will succeed. Take this course for the incredible lectures and wonderful professors.

This semester is more structured than the last, but be prepared to learn some really hard material. Seek help when you need it, and everything that you learn can be found in an actual textbook rather than the lecture notes if you're looking for additional resources. If you found that the pain of the first semester is worth it, then by all means keep going. Taking multivariable, if you haven't already, is recommended and you'll find that the two classes compliment each other surprisingly well.
You will be challenged in this course and you will become very close to your fellow ISC classmates.
prereqs: Familiarity with calculus at the level of MAT 103/104 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses. Students must have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231 and 232 in the Fall..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year long, four course sequence is a multidisciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: W. Bialek, T. Gregor, J. Shaevitz (PHY); P. Debenedetti (CBE); H. Yang(CHM); O. Troyanskaya (COS); E. Wieschaus (MOL); C. Broedersz, J. Gadd, A. Leifer, B. Machta (LSI). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session each week.

title: Science, Technology & Culture
reviews: A cool blend of anthropology, science, ethics, philosophy, and sociology. Pretty theoretical and abstract, but very stimulating and interesting.
Look around you for how this course relates to current events, and other things you come across. This shouldn't be hard if you're already interested in the subject matter.
Take it! But you gotta dig in.
Take it, but just be prepared to do a lot of (interesting) reading.
descrip: Scientific and technological ventures have challenged, even redefined, some previously stable and important ontological categories, in the West as well as around the world: categories such as life, death, nature, human, self, animate and inanimate. Using ethnographies, theoretical readings and overviews of several fields, whilst examining diverse sites of scientific production and dissemination - from test tubes to outer space, from indigenous knowledge to genetics labs - we will look at how science and technology are changing perceptions and experiences of these categories and examine the social and political consequences.

title: Analysis of Big Data
reviews: Any interest in data, big data? Economics major? TAKE THIS COURSE. Han Liu is the best professor I've ever had as he's SO clear, organized and teaches the class like he's telling a story. The material is useful if you want to be a data scientist. It's considered "hard" material but if you just pay attention and ask questions you'll love the class.
Attend all lectures.  Material is presented primarily there.

Don't be afraid to ask questions.  Professor Liu appreciates them, and given the difficulty of the class, they are essential.  You'd be surprised how many students would have the same question but would be too bashful to be the first ones to admit it.

Favorite class at Princeton so far, just edging out 309.  Perfect combination of code/application and theory, so you really know what's happening.  Tons of material, though, so it doesn't go as in depth as I would have liked.  Start problem sets early (that data is pretty big and can really slow you down).  Also, more math than you probably would expect (e.g. if you're COS and not very theoretical or don't have a strong probability background, stick with 424).
Go to lectures. Ask questions. He wants you to understand and do well.
Great statistics and machine-learning class, though the problem sets can be tough and time-consuming.  Start them well in advance.

I would not recommend this class unless if you're very interested in big data and are willing to put up with Professor Liu's strange and sometimes ineffective classroom methods. One thing that still bothers my conscience is how Prof. Liu actively convinced certain people to drop out of the course right at the beginning (week 1!) so that he can presumably get a lighter teaching load. (To achieve this, he claimed the class would be "super difficult" and that the material will be "very dry". This didn't turn out to be true at the end.) We started with 80 students and ended up with 41. I just thought these tactics were against the spirit of academic integrity.   N.B. For those of you thinking "if half the people dropped out, then the curve must have been awesome", this was not true. It was only fair of him to curve the class as if 41 people started out or else it would've been ridiculous. The average course letter grade given out is probably around B/B , depending on your class attendance sheets.

IGNORE THE PREREQS. YOU NEED WAY MORE THAN JUST ORF 245. Also, everyone in the class seemed to know the material already, as most were seniors who had taken many ORF classes before. Only take if you're confident in your programming ability and linear algebra

If Professor Liu is teaching the course again, I would highly recommend this class. It covers a lot of interesting material, and few professors care more about their students than Professor Liu. Very happy with having taken this
If you have any interest in statistics and machine learning, this is a MUST take. Even though it's a lot of work, your ratio of learning/work is still extremely high.
It is one of the best ORF courses.

It's a great course if you're interested in it, but it was tough this year. This was only the second year it has been offered and it changed a lot since last year, so it might not be the same next year. However, Han Liu will continue to be amazing, and the subject matter will continue to be relatively difficult, so expect to love it if you're interested in the material but resent it a little if you aren't.

It's a lot of work, but an awesome class.  I finally feel like I know how to USE statistics (after taking ORF 245 and 405, neither of which taught me how to do anything). Be warned, it is a huge time suck though, do the problem sets in groups.

One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton, better than COS424 for sure. Prof. Liu is really dedicated to making sure the students do well, and clearly has a good grasp on how to explain the material he is teaching. The lectures try to give you a sense of the fundamentals behind a number of statistical concepts and algorithms, and after finishing the class I really felt that I thoroughly understood things. The HW nicely complements this by looking at applications (e.g. spam filtering, image classification). You're given a piece of R-code to start with that essentially solves a simpler version of the HW problem, which you then have to 'tweak'. This way, you can really get in depth on the applications, and after this course I also felt confident I could deal with more complicated applications. Workload for HWs is very doable though, so don't worry about that. Beyond the homework, we only had a final, on which the open questions contained some curveballs, so beware. Finally, the TA's (especially Kevin Lin) are very helpful, respond quickly, and are clearly enthusiastic about the material. Overall, would very strongly recommend taking this class; you'll get a good understanding of some fundamental statistical concepts and algorithms, and will also work on some really cool applications.
One of the best courses on data analysis at Princeton. A must take if you want to learn the principles behind statistics and data analysis in general.

Probably the best ORF class I've taken, along with 309 and 335. Prof. Liu's lectures are really good -- he highly encourages students to ask questions, which makes the class seem more like a seminar than a traditional lecture. Problem sets take a while, but there aren't a lot of them, and they're designed well to illuminate concepts from lecture.

TAKE IT! Prof. Liu genuinely cares about what his students learn and the class is very well structured and clear. The hws take a really long amount of time and by really long I mean, you better start early and plan to spend 2-3 nights of the week on the hw. But the hws are very fulfilling and you apply the theory you learn to the code you write almost line by line. So, if you want to see real applications of statistics and big data you should definitely take this class
Take COS 424 instead
Take it if you want to learn about statistics and machine learning.

This course will give a good overview of statistics and machine learning, with an emphasis on the frequentist approach. Take this if you are interested in how statistics and machine learning is used to approach big data sets in academia and  industry. The course is structured into four parts: inferential analysis, predictive analysis, and exploratory analysis.
Tremendous course, very difficult, but the reward is well worth the work.
Very useful and informative course
prereqs: ORF 245.
descrip: The amount of data in our world has been exploding, and analyzing large data sets is becoming a central problem in our society. This course introduces the statistical principles and computational tools for analyzing big data: the process of exploring and predicting large datasets to find hidden patterns and gain deeper understanding, and of communicating the obtained results for maximal impact. Topics include massively parallel data management and data processing, model selection and regularization, statistical modeling and inference, scalable computational algorithms, descriptive and predictive analysis, and exploratory analysis.

title: Drug Discovery: From Snake Venoms to Medicines
descrip: See website

title: Master's Project II
descrip: Under the direction of a Bendheim affiliated faculty member, students carry out a master's project, write a report, and present the results in the form of a poster or an oral presentation in front of an examining committee.

title: Advanced Optimization
reviews: Be ready for lengthy derivations, but realize that much of the material is self-similar, so you have five chances to get everything. It's not as hard as it seems.
Bubeck is a great professor.
Convex optimization is ubiquitous. You must take this class if Seb Bubeck is teaching it.
Don't take unless you're interested and have a solid background in math

Enjoy the course! The course is full of passion and beauty like a wonderful epic poetry. You will see how graduate-level mathematics such as real analysis become very useful for large-scale optimization. You will also learn lots of genius ideas to tackle with big data. Princeton university should use all approaches to keep prof. Bubeck stay here so that he can teach this course every year!
Excellent
If interested in optimization, definitely take it.
Take it.
This course is worth taking. You can learn a lot about optimization in this course.
take it if you have already taken optimization before and are comfortable with proofs
prereqs: Prerequisite: linear optimization.
descrip: A mathematical introduction to large-scale optimization and stochastic optimization. Topics covered include the analysis of diverse gradient-descent algorithms such as sub-gradient descent, Nesterov's accelerated gradient descent, FISTA and mirror descent, as well as a discussion of complexity lower bounds a la Nemirovski. These methods will be compared to the semi-definite programming approach and applications to high-dimensional statistics and machine learning will also be discussed.

title: 20th-Century Japanese Literature
descrip: Readings in selected texts in modern Japanese literature.

title: Elementary Arabic II
reviews: 102 is where Arabic starts to get interesting and complicated. The difficulty jump can catch you off-guard if you slack off, so don't. Try to take it with Ustaadha Eva or Ustaadh Greg, both are fantastic.

Arabic is by far the most useful NES language, but the first two years are spent learning Formal, which can be helpful in learning a dialect but is focused much more on never-utilized rules and structures. Be sure you can commit A LOT of time out of class to this language and try to find someone to speak it with because otherwise it will remain a language you can only read and write.
Be prepared for a ton of memorization. You also need to have a good motivation for taking it in order to get through. I really enjoyed it because I took it with my goals in mind.
Be prepared to put in a lot of work on the course, because although its extremely interesting and rewarding, you do have a lot of homework every night.

Definitely take this course, especially with Professor Bell! Prof. Bell has been one of the kindest, more understanding, and most helpful professors I have had a Princeton. All the students in the course enjoyed learning, and the classroom felt like a real community. The material is not incredibly difficult; all you need to do is stay on top of the vocabulary because there are small quizzes weekly. But putting in the effort is really worth it in the end! I highly recommend taking this course!

Do it. Take Arabic with Professor Bell. He's exceedingly helpful and will answer any questions you have, and he's always willing to meet outside of class to help you with anything. Arabic is a difficult language, but Professor Bell makes it as painless as possible.
Enjoy it!
I would definitely recommend it!
I would definitely recommend taking this class. Be prepared to put in a lot of work in order to be proficient in the language.

I would recommend that you enroll in the earliest section (9:00), for a few reasons: 1. The class size is smaller, so you get more attention, you're forced to participate more, there's enough space for everyone to write at the board as large as they please, there are enough chalk erasers to go around, etc. 2. It makes you get up early, and then you get out of class at 9:50, and the whole fresh day unfurls before you, redolent with possibility and promise. Glorious. 3. If you sleep through class, you can always sit in on one of the later sections.

I would recommend this class to students who want to continue their Arabic study. If they have Professor Slowinska, I would tell them to be prepared for a fast pace class but to learn a lot. I would also tell them to not worry about grades much since they do not properly reflect their work and to just focus on learning the language.
I would simply advise to show up the classes and to not fall behind on the homework, which can be very time consuming. Also, always take advantage of office hours.
If you are even remotely interested in Arabic, take this class with Greg!

If you have an interest in the Middle East and/or need to take a language for your language requirement, I would highly recommend taking Arabic. It is not the easiest language, and you must put in a good amount of time with it, but you learn a lot very quickly.

If you need really detailed explanations of grammar concepts, go with Greg. However, if you want to actually have to activate the language (particularly writing and understanding), and you're fine with grammar concepts sometimes being not-as-well explained, definitely take Eva.
It's a lot of homework, but it helps get one aptly started in Arabic.
It's much easier than 101. It's a fun class, kind of weird vocab, but it keeps things interesting.
Its a consistent one or two hours of work per night, but very doable and very rewarding

Keep up with the daily homework and prepare for the weekly quizzes. If you dutifully study every week the language will be more fun to learn than if you put off the work. I strongly recommend taking this course and will be pursing further Arabic study. All the Arabic teachers are warm, highly competent, and truly care about their students.
Know what you are getting into in terms of workload
Take it with Bell!!
Take the course if you want to learn a beautiful language. Take the class with Eva if you want a challenge and want to learn it really well.
Take this course if you want to learn arabic; but it definitely is a lot of work and you have to be willing to put in time.
To study.
You learn a lot in a short time! It's amazing to see how far I've come.
prereqs: ARA 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course continues the study of Modern Standard Arabic and spoken colloquial Arabic commenced in Arabic 101. Emphasis in class is placed on active use of grammatical points introduced in the book; reading and writing increasingly longer texts; further vocabulary acquisition, and continued practice in listening and speaking Modern Standard and spoken colloquial Arabic.

title: The Age of Discoveries: Early Modern Europe, 1450-1789
reviews: HIS347 easily places in the top 3 of courses I've taken at Princeton, which means quite a lot given that I've now taken 32 of them. Adam Beaver is enthusiastic, knowledgable and really managed to engage the class. He genuinely cared about our academic experience and his classes just made me want to become a history nerd. Work load was very manageable and the readings were actually fun!

If you are worried that this course is simply a rehash of AP Euro, don't fret. This course focuses on some of the more nuanced aspects of the early modern period and makes you understand just how progress was made.

Not the best class. Prof. Beaver seems scatterbrained, and tries to fish for answers most of the time. The reading list is good, but it's out of order, and doesn't seem very coherent throughout the semester. It is primarily an intellectual history course, and grossly disregards the actual historical events of the time period.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: The early modern period in European history is often referred to as the "Age of Discovery" because of European encounters with the New World. In fact, the period witnessed multiple discoveries: not just of different parts of the globe, but of ancient texts and learning; of the laws of the physical universe; of the science of politics; of nations (as objects of knowledge and as political actors); and of the idea of secular progress. This course will provide an introduction to the period, from the Renaissance to the eve of the French Revolution, introducing students to key texts and themes of the period.

title: Messiahs, Mystics and Rebels in the Islamic World
prereqs: This seminar assumes no prior knowledge of Islamic history although some familiarity with the study of religion may be helpful..
descrip: This course surveys a representative selection of messianic movements and millenarian visionaries from the Islamic world (7th-19th centuries). Some emphasis will be placed on syncretic movements, common throughout early modern Eurasia, that sought to synthesize or reunite one or more of the monotheistic religions in preparation for the end of history. Revolution will be a dominant theme of the course. We will study the religious outlook of the members of such movements and the intellectual commitments of individual millenarian thinkers while also situating them in their social, political and cultural contexts.

title: The Making of Modern India and Pakistan
reviews:
A lot of the kids in the class were Indian themselves, of Indian descent, or had done Bridge-Year India. While this could have added insight and perspective, I think it put those of us who didn't have that familiarity background at a disadvantage because there was a lot of assumed knowledge that we just didn't have. 

Because it's called the history of "modern Indian AND PAKISTAN" I assumed that we'd be starting at Partition in 1947, with maybe a lecture or two of British rule at the beginning. I was surprised to find out that we only got to partition around the middle of the semester, and was pretty disappointed about that. We also entirely skipped the 1960s...

There's not a lot of work--reading amount is decent--but there are both a Dean's Date paper/project and a (take-home) final exam, which is really annoying.
A must take course for History concentrates or anybody else interested in India- Pakistan history
Definitely take it.

Do you like Bollywood music? Do you like understanding important historical questions surrounding South Asia? Are you confused about the British Empire and the effects of colonialism on India/Pakistan? BEST CLASS EVER SERIOUSLY TAKE THIS CLASS IT WILL CHANGE YOUR LIFE
Especially if you are taking this class for a grade, do the readings... they're really interesting!
Go to every lecture. Prepare well for precept and make the most of this class, because what you get out of it depends heavily on how invested you are.
Good class. Even though the midterm and final is take-home, be aware of the grading expectations. Secondly, the creative paper is a little cumbersome.
I would recommend this class, I think it is a fairly good survey class. Not too much reading and if you are into South Asia you will definitely enjoy it. Gyan is a terrific storyteller!
If you want to know about subaltern history, Professor Prakash is the man. Plus, the Bollywood clips in lecture are a treat
It's a great course, but be ready to read a lot if you want to get everything out of the course. Definitely take it if you can.
Its great
Many students in this choose have background knowledge about India.   It might be hard to keep up in the course without prior experience.
Professor Prakash is great, but I would not recommend taking this course as a second semester senior. There is a final paper and a take-home final.
Take it if you are interested at all in the subject. There is a lot of reading, but you will get a lot out of the class. Also, Professor Prakash is really cool.
Take this class - you definitely won't regret it!

This was a good enough class. I was very interested in South Asia beforehand, which inspired me to take it. I have to say that I was disappointed by the instruction. My preceptor was decent-- nothing spectacular. Professor Prakash was generally an engaging lecturer, but I would imagine there are better in the history department. It's a fun enough way to fulfill your history requirement if that's what your looking to do. I love South Asia so I generally liked the class, but I talked to other people who were doing it for their requirements for their History major and they didn't like it too much. I'd give it a 3 out of 5 -- good enough.

This was a great course -- not too difficult, but very insightful and interesting. Take it if you have any interest in South Asia or if you are interested in exploring history from a 'non-Western' standpoint.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: An exploration of three major themes in the history of India's and Pakistan's emergence as nation-states: colonial socio-economic and cultural transformations, the growth of modern collective identities and conflicts, and nationalism. Topics covered include: trade, empire, and capitalism; class, gender and religion; Gandhi, national independence, and partition; and post-colonial state and society.

title: Race, Nation and the Citizen in Latin America
descrip: This seminar course traces the tide of racial discourse and Enlightenment-spurred scientific empiricism and explores the materialization of these anxieties in popular culture as it related to the development of notions of race and nationalizing projects at the dawn of independence in Latin America.

title: Sex in Ancient Judaism and Christianity
reviews: Incredibly informative and interesting. Vidas is a great professor--he lectures excellently, leads discussion well, and is incredibly approachable. Highly recommended.
One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. DO ITTT.

The course is a rigorous introduction to sexuality in this time period. It is beneficial to have some background knowledge but not necessary. The professor is a great teacher and very energetic but could be more organized.
descrip: Contemporary discussions about sexuality are filled with Jewish and Christian texts from antiquity. Quotations from the Bible and its ancient interpretations are continuously used to make claims about sexual behavior and sexual desire. Yet these texts themselves come from a very different world, with values, facts and passions of its own. This course examines the classical Jewish and Christian texts on sexuality within their own ancient historical context. Throughout the course, we will emphasize the diversity of positions in antiquity and the broad cultural conversations in which these positions were staked.

title: Stochastic Analysis Seminar
descrip: Recent developments in the theory and applications of the analysis of random processes and random fields. Applications include financial engineering, transport by stochastic flows, and statistical imaging.

title: The Life Cycle of Behaviors
reviews: Get to know Assif. And take this course
Good course if you haven't taken much neuro, psych, or mol. If you have already taken any science upper-level courses though, this class might feel a little pointless.
Good for an easy class if you're interested in the subject material. Not very intellectually stimulating.
Great easy psych course if you think you might be interested in learning a little about psych but are not sure. Really manageable and informative, with interesting lectures.
I would recommend this course.
Interesting class, good for requirements.
It's a very doable intro to psychology and neuroscience! Ghazanfar is a good lecturer, and the course has been solid.
Not too difficult and very interesting, if you want a good neuro course, take it!
Pay attention in lecture. If you want a relatively easy course that is taught well and exposes you to some of the neuroscience behind development, then this is a great option.
Pay close attention during lectures. Study the experiments really well. Be genuinely interested!
Pretty low workload, and interesting material. Very different from every other psych course you're going to take at this course, as it felt much more EEBish than PSYish. A cool new experience though.
Pretty relaxed class - you get to learn about recently published papers and development/behaviors at the same time.
Really straightforward neuro class, just go to lecture and pay attention and you'll do fine. The exams and assignments expect pretty little of you intellectually.
Solid, easygoing class.
Super interesting class for anyone interested at all in neuroscience. Great professor!
TAKE THIS COURSE, you will not regret it!
There isn't too much material and it is all fairly easy to understand. But since it's easy for everyone else, it can get competitive.
This class is a very accessible science course.  Take if you are interested in neuroscience and behavior.  The workload is very manageable and the exams are fair.
This was the most interesting class I have had at Princeton. The tests are super fair and Asif is an amazing professor.
good course to take if looking for a science w/o lab. exams are fair and the lectures are interesting and professor ghazanfar is great
really interesting course and good for someone with no background in the subject matter. it's NOT PDFable-make sure you're aware!
take it! ghazanfar is the best
take this course!! such interesting material, not a lot of work at all.
prereqs: Any 200-level (or higher) PSY, NEU, MOL, or EEB course..
descrip: The goal of this course is to illuminate the interactions between the brain, body and behavior over the course of development and how this shapes a species' evolution. We will first explore developmental events at the cellular level that are shaped by parental behavior. We will then see how these events influence the developing circuits of the brain. Finally, we will learn about influences at the level of niche or culture, where the changes that organisms make to their environments and to themselves influence and modify the patterns of behaviors exhibited in the next generation.

title: Problems in Roman History - Republican Political Culture in Rome
descrip: This seminar focuses on political culture (very broadly defined) in republican Rome, in the third, second, and first centuries B.C. After an initial consideration of the role of periodization, the course is arranged by topics that cut across the time-periods. Which is more important in defining republicanism in Rome: the functioning of the political institutions themselves or the culture of spectacle refined by Rome's political elite (the nobiles)? The emphasis is on current research and new methodologies, as well as on how to approach our extant ancient sources, whether literary, epigraphical, numismatic, or archaeological.

title: Graphic Design: Typography
reviews: Definitely take it if you have an interest in typography! You learn a lot and presents a very different style from other Princeton courses. I really enjoyed it, and it's a great option for seniors looking for something different.
Great class to take as a distribution requirement or just for fun!
Only take the course if you know you can make yourself interested enough to honestly attempt the assignments.

TAKE IT. If you're at all interested in design or typography, this is a great intro course. Not only do you learn a lot, but the assignments are really engaging and challenge you on a completely different level than you are used it. It's a great intro to design class and the workload is minimal outside of the studios on Monday. This class teaches you the skill set to become a good designer, something that can be applied in all your classes, especially with something as ubiquitous as typography. You will not regret it.
Take it if you want to learn about typography. It is a lot of time, but its a very relaxed class with no homework.
This was a very rewarding class for a beginner to typography.  It was really cool to see the progression from letter press to the computer.
descrip: This studio course introduces students to graphic design with a particular emphasis on typography. Students learn typographic history through lectures that highlight major shifts in print technologies and through their engagement in studio design projects. Class readings provide the raw material for hot metal typesetting in the letterpress print shop, photo-typesetting in the mechanical paste-up studio, and state of the art typesetting and design software in the digital computer lab. Overall, the workshop synthesizes hands-on graphic design skills with aesthetic awareness and a critical vocabulary.

title: Computer and Electronic Music Composition
prereqs: MUS/COS 314 or Permission of the Instructor.
descrip: A composition workshop class, with a focus on synthesis techniques. Emphasis will be on the students creative work, composing both "fixed media" works, and live electronic/laptop music.

title: Topics in Paleoecology, Paleoclimatology, and Paleoceanography - Environmental and Biotic Effects of Volcanism
descrip: This course investigates biological and environmental effects of Deccan volcanism 66 m.y. ago in India that led to the KT mass extinction and delayed biotic recovery. Investigations include climate and environmental changes, weathering, ocean acidification and its effects on calcareous marine microplankton and the observed high-stress marine assemblages. The timing of major volcanic eruptions and the time elapsed between individual lava flows will be investigated based on red bole layers.

title: What is Freedom?
descrip: We examine major theories of freedom, especially as they developed in the course of the twentieth century. Particular emphasis is placed on three questions: first, the question whether, ultimately, there is only concept of freedom; second, the question how freedom relates to institutional arrangements such as democracy and the rule of law; and, third, the question whether there is such a thing as ?collective freedom.? Contemporary debates about freedom ? particularly among liberals, neoliberals, and republicans ? are treated towards the end of the course, as are more recent psychological approaches to freedom.

title: A Nation of Immigrants
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Research Seminars
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; fourth-year students for 596; and fifth-year students for 597. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Masterworks of European Literature
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of reading. honestly you don't have to do it all, but the more you do the better the course will be. If you want to get a lot out of the course do as much as you can.

COM 206 is one of the best classes you'll take at Princeton. Not only is the reading list important for your personal growth as a human, but it will make you understand what "Masterworks" means. This, in conjunction with 205, should be the cornerstone of any humanities education at Princeton. I'd recommend it particularly for freshmen & sophomores.
Do all the readings, not for the course but for life.
Do it.
Do the readings!
Great lecturer, boring precepts.
I would recommend this course to those considering comparative literature as a major and to those who are generally interested in global literature.

If you're reading this evaluation, you are probably interested in the reading list. In that case, stop worrying about the workload and just register. You don't have to read everything so it's really up to you how much you learn. You will cover some absolutely fascinating topics (I was blown away during some lectures/precepts--stayed after precept for 20 minutes once to finish hearing an argument) and hopefully come out with a new favorite book
Last occasion to take 206 with Sitney :/
Professor P. Adams Sitney is amazing and the reading load is heavy but they are truly the masterworks. Highly recommended!
Take it if you love literature and want to see how great ideas persist through time and are reflected in different books!
Take it, you should read the books anyways and it's great to hear what professor Sitney has to say about them
Take it. its fun and not to challenging.
Take this if you value art, culture, and literature.
Talk this course if you're at all interested in Literature!

you'll still get a lot out of it if you drop a few books, but try to keep a schedule open enough to allow you to do all the reading. do your precept-mates a favor and don't BS through precept--prepare a few points to make beforehand.
descrip: In this course we will examine the major forms and themes of Western Literature since the Renaissance: the drama, essay, lyric and novel. We shall read major works by British, Spanish, French, German, Russian and American authors, considering the unique contributions of specific nations and languages and the transformations of themes and genres over a span of five hundred years.

title: America Then and Now
reviews: Do not take it. This is a terrible way to learn about American History. It is difficult, with no perceived rewards. There are many good individual qualities to the course, but taken as a whole, it is a huge waste of your time. Look elsewhere if you're interested in American History or interdisciplinary studies.
Do the readings
Don't buy all the books, but do the readings that are on blackboard.
Don't take it unless you're getting the certificate.

Don't take it. Yes it looks like an easy A for your EC requirement, but it's so boring you'll inevitably give up on trying to pay attention and perform less well than you should, which is weirdly frustrating but unavoidable. It has the feel of a PDF class without actually being able to PDF it. I feel like I literally learned almost nothing at all after a whole semester of this class. It's not particularly difficult or time consuming, which is nice if you really need that (as I did), but its just SO boring.
Done take it unless you need it for a requirement or it becomes PDF
Eh. I wouldn't take this course knowing what I know now. It's easy but the grading is pretty wack.
Enjoy the readings and only take it if you are interested in the materials.
Get an easier preceptor.

Go ahead and take it if you need an EC or are considering the certificate.  I would even say take it if you are not.  It is just an interesting and insightful way to think about and try to understand America.
I recommend taking this course. Stay on top of your readings. Make sure you get a good preceptor -- they are a big part of the course. The three essays are doable but the final is hard.

I recommend this class, especially for anyone considering the American Studies certificate (the Program in American Studies has really good classes, and it's not hard to do the certificate). I definitely learned more about our nation, especially some specific aspects of it (i.e. the African-American experience in America), and enjoyed learning how to analyze American tv shows, music, and art. Overall, it's a decent class (you will learn something- not necessarily a lot because America is pretty familiar to most of us already, but something), and it's a pretty fun class as well. I also highly recommend Elizabeth as a preceptor- she was great, especially about offering students feedback on paper ideas.
I think that this is a good course overall for an EC. However, it does feel disjointed due the fact that there are three professors and many different types of readings.
I think this is a great course for everyone to take regardless of academic interests.
I would recommend taking this class.  Lectures are interesting and important to attend.  This class will transform the way you approach American history.
I would say that this course is more than just and exploration of American culture. It really makes the student think about their role in society and the future of America.
I would take this course as a fifth course because the work load is manageable.  The course is very interesting and relies on individual thought more than excessive research and readings.

I would take this course if you are looking for an EC without too much work, or you need it for the American Studies program. Outside of that, I don't think it really enriches the curriculum of the average student, as much of the material presented has been presented before in high school.
If you are taking this because you think it is just an easy class, be prepared to work hard. It is not an easy A, and will challenge you to learn how to write in new ways.

If you are thinking about taking the course because of a general interest in the material, DON'T.  However, if you want probably the easiest possible way to fulfill an EC distribution requirement, go for it.  As of now, it is extremely disorganized, but perhaps that is because it is still a new course.  The precepts were pretty much the only good aspect of the course.
If you need an EC, or you have any interest in the concept of America, this class is a great choice
If your interested in American studies take this class.
It is a fairly easy class. The papers are very straightforward and simple and there isn't a lot of reading.
It's a good EC and you should take it if you're interested in America!
It's not that much work or that hard of a class. Papers are short. But it's super boring.
It's what you expect.
Kinda complex and nebulous motives but nonetheless gives a good introduction to AMS.
Make sure you do the readings.
Make sure you get into a precept with one of the professors--I imagine that would make the course that much more engaging.
Make sure you go to lecture and keep up on the readings. It's a lot of material that's covered on the final, but if you go to lecture and pay attention, you'll be fine
Overall an alright class, take it if like me the other AMS classes sound interesting and are thinking about a certificate. But not that great of a class.
Read with other students, so you are able to talk about it and formulate ideas, prior to precept.

Seriously, listen to the masses. I took this class to fulfill the AMS certificate requirement, and if you're taking it for that purpose (after all, the certificate is pretty easy to get), fair enough. But otherwise, seriously, seriously don't take this class. You will learn 0 new things, you will be frustrated by the constant discussion of Sarah Palin, you will not understand the purpose of writing a 3 page paper on Miley Cyrus for a significant assignment, and you will not understand the point of the class. It's a totally scattered mess without a real common thread.
Take - work hard on papers
Take if plan on getting AMS certificate or need an EC- not too difficult of a class.
Take it
Take it for an EC.

Take it for the AMS Certificate, or even for an EC if you need one. A bit expansive, but generally fun. The papers are all multi-media based, so they are definitely a break (in some ways) from regular essays. For example, we had to write on a TV show, a song, and a painting for our three essays.
Take it for the certificate, otherwise I wouldn't really bother.
Take it take it take it!
Take it!
Take it! Great assignments
Take it!!
Take it.
Take it. You will learn a lot. It is a great EC.
Take this class if you want to look at American history in a way that high school didn't allow you to!
Take this course! Go to lecture and you will be fine.
Take this! It is fun, interesting, and a great time.
This class is relatively interesting, and I would recommend it if you need a filler class.

This is a good class to fulfill a distribution requirement, but don't take it out of general interest. It waffles between boring and incredibly interesting, and the lack of time spent in class contrasts the amount of time you'll spend reading for this class

Three professors, so three very different approaches to learning about America--this is a pro and a con. If you appreciate the diversity of perspectives and don't mind feeling a bit lost/disconnected from week to week, go for it.
Use your preceptors and don't be afraid to reach out to them if you want to talk with them about your papers or if you have a question
You'll get out what you put in.
do the readings so you can participate in precept
its a fine course for a core.
only take it if you have to and do not get marko as a preceptor
take it
descrip: This course introduces a selection of signature ideas and debates that made the nation what it is today and what it is becoming. Objects of study range across multiple media, including texts, images, works of art, music, performance, and film, and draw from the diverse fields of literature, history, political science, art history, economics, law, cultural studies, and the history of science. The course attends to how knowledge about America has and continues to be produced, disseminated, and consumed, emphasizing the cognitive processes associated with the invention and delineation of America.

title: The Psychology of Scarcity
descrip: See website

title: Intermediate/Advanced French
reviews: Definitely plan to devote more time to the course after class. It determines how much you get out of the course.
Do the homework.
Don't expect to learn any French, but instead, except a deep hatred for your classmates and the French language.

Gauge the amount of work you personally need to do to feel comfortable in this class as the range of individuals at varying places in their language learning cannot be addressed by the broad assignments and activities.

I would recommend this course. I hated French when I took it in high school and this class made me enjoy the language again. I also learned a lot more than I thought I would in not a very long amount of time.
It is a very interesting course.
Just stay on top of the assignments and you'll be fine. Push yourself to participate vocally in the class; speaking the language is a very important part of learning it.

Keep up with the daily work as much as you can--it makes preparing for writing and tests very simple. An hour a day and a little extra on the weekend is very manageable and obviously pays off. Participate in class as much as possible no matter how poor you think your speaking skills are; the more you participate and the harder you try, the easier it gets, and because you speak basically everyday you can see your progress very quickly.
Participate in class! It'll help you learn.
Take it with Professor Hart! She's terrific and loves to engage with students.
Take it!
don't slack! a second language is important to have!
prereqs: FRE 102 or FRE 103, or special permission..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to develop your listening, speaking and writing skills, while giving you a foundation for understanding and appreciation of French-speaking cultures. There is a thorough review of French grammar and a selection of communicative activities chosen to improve proficiency and give practice of newly acquired linguistic material.

title: Water in the Atmosphere
prereqs: Background in atmospheric/oceanic sciences..
descrip: Despite the paramount importance of atmospheric water vapour for climate, our understanding of the processes that regulate its distribution and changes within a changing climate remains incomplete. This course analyses observations and discusses theoretical approaches, both basic concepts and novel ideas, to the problem. Course is for graduate students with a background in atmospheric and/or oceanic sciences, and students are encouraged to provide contributions from their own research experiences that are related to the course topic.

title: Poetry and the Arts
reviews: ACTIVELY read all the readings and take advantage of office hours.
Definitely take this course !

Effie is probably the best French professor at Princeton.  That being said, even if you love her, don't take this course unless you legitimately have an interest in poetry, especially modern poetry.  The art aspect is really a teeny side component of what is essentially a poetry class.  Effie is not afraid to tell you if you are wrong so you can't bullshit your way through it - you really have to learn to understand the poetry which is not as easy as it sounds.

If you like poetry and art, and want a course that is very rewarding for not that much work, take this class! Prof Rentzou is absolutely amazing.  This was by far the best language course I have taken at Princeton.

If you're interested in literature but also as a parallel phenomenon to the complex and rich artistic movements of France, take the course. Also take the course if you're interested in curatorial work, though only if there's an exhibition project involved.
This was a really interesting and different class!
take detailed notes and put in a lot of time and effort for the final project
prereqs: FRE 207 or permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course examines the connections between modern French poetry and the Arts. The period under investigation is the 19th and 20th centuries, starting with the Romantics and ending with recent developments in visual arts, poetry, and poetics. The class will be taught at the Princeton Art Museum and each week will focus on one work, style, or art movement and poetry's interaction with them. Readings include poets like Bertrand, Baudelaire, Rimbaud, Mallarme, Apollinaire, Cendrars, and Breton. The thematic topics that will structure the course are the poem as ekphrasis, the poet as art critic, collaborations between poets and artists, etc.

title: Women and Gender in Islamic Societies
reviews: Marmon is really kind of scary. The reading is a lot but the topic is really cool.
Take it!
The class has a LOT of weekly readings, but it is really worth it. If you're interested in the topic, this class would be perfect for you.
The reading load is heavy - but they are really good.
descrip: This seminar focuses on issues of gender and sexuality in Islamic societies, past and present. Readings are drawn from the fields of history, religious studies, anthropology and sociology. Readings also include a wide range of texts in translation, including novels and poetry. Films are an integral part of the course. Topics include: women's lives; women's writings; female piety; marriage and divorce; sexuality and the body; and women and Islamic fundamentalism.

title: Topics in the History of Sex and Gender - History of Sexuality
descrip: A survey of important work in the history of sexuality, seeking to understand sexuality not only as a topic of historical inquiry but as a category of analysis. Seminar focuses on U.S. history (from colonial period to the present), but some of the readings address contexts outside of the United States, as well as interdisciplinary and/or theoretical approaches to questions of gender/sexuality.

title: Portuguese Cultural Themes
reviews: I would highly recommend taking this course. I really enjoyed myself and learned a lot. I feel strongly that this course will be further improved in the coming years. If you have an interest in Portuguese and want to improve/keep up your language skills, I would highly recommend this course.
Take it! Very different language class than the others that are offered at Princeton - in a good way. The kinks with the CBLI will undoubtedly be worked out for next semester.
prereqs: POR 208.
descrip: This course will examine the experience of Portuguese-speaking immigrants and communities in the United States, both through broad themes of exile and displacement, ethnicity, identity, economics, tradition, saudade and cultural production and the specific experiences of residents of the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. In addition to weekly readings and occasional films depicting the immigration experience, we will be working with the Community Based Learning Initiative (CBLI) and local partners to engage the local Portuguese-speaking community and increase our understanding through hands-on research and inquiry.

title: Seminar on Education-Theory and Practice
prereqs: Prerequisites: See Teacher Preparation Program requirements. Course requires admission into the Teacher Preparation Program. Enrollment limited to students doing their practice teaching (TPP 402) except by special permission from the program director..
descrip: Seminar taken concurrently with Practice Teaching (TPP402). Students investigate the processes of curriculum development and implementation, develop learning goals and rubrics for assessment, study national and local issues in education and their impact on schools, examine current philosophies and effective practices, reflect on their work and evaluate their performance as practice teachers.

title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate French
reviews: Be prepared for an onslaught of grammar.

Be prepared to work with grammar.
Enjoy the teacher attention and experience.
Even though there aren't many assignments you have to hand in, it's still a good idea to review the material as often as possible. Don't fall behind!
I would say that this is a great course to take if you already have some experience in French.
Take it with Madame Hart if you can!
Take the course!!!! Especially with this professor!!!
prereqs: Prerequisites include approximately two years of high school French and an appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test..
descrip: FRE 103 is an intensive beginning and intermediate language course designed for students who have already studied French (typically no more than 2-3 years). Covering in one semester the material presented in FRE 101 and FRE 102, this course prepares students to take FRE 107 the following semester. Classroom activities include comprehension and grammar exercises, conversation, skits, and working with a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: Readings in Ancient and Medieval Japanese History
descrip: This course is designed to introduce fundamental themes and debates about ancient and medieval Japanese history, and how conceptualizations of Japan have changed from the third century CE through 1600. Approximately two books, or a comparable number of articles, are required each week, and wherever possible, a brief passage of Japanese scholarship will be presented as well. Reading knowledge of modern Japanese is desirable.

title: Approaches to Ballet: Technique and Repertory
reviews: Definitely take it if you have had serious training in dance. It is challenging but so rewarding and you learn so much about ballet history. Being able to take classes from guest choreographers who have made it in the ballet world and to listen to their experience is really a privilege.
Enjoy ballet.

I absolutely love this class. If you've had ballet training in the past, this is the perfect opportunity to develop as a dancer and interact with incredible professionals from around the world. There's a low enrollment cap, so make sure to ask Tina to reserve a spot early before it fills up!
I will always recommend this course. Great way to stay in shape and expand one's ballet repertoire!
I would advise a student who has a love for ballet -- even if they aren't planning to pursue it seriously -- to take this class. It's a beautiful way to indulge in your love of the art.
If you are an advanced ballet student, you should absolutely take this course! Wonderful professor and subject!

If you love ballet take this course. It is physically rigorous and will keep/get you shape, but is generally a supportive environment. The class discussion is a nice complement to the dancing, but it is definitely more movement focused than reading/writing.
If you love ballet, this is a truly great course that will not only keep you in shape but also expose you to incredible teachers and different choreographic styles. Take it!
Really pay attention to the guest teachers brought in for the course; they have very worthwhile things to say.
Really take advantage of the classes taught by guest teachers and watch all the videos because you cannot always get easy access to them outside of the class.
Tina is wonderful and you get to learn some really fun rep from fantastic guest artists - highly highly recommend!!! Enjoy it!
prereqs: Application by Interview/Audition only. Please email Professor Fehlandt (fehlandt@) for an appointment..
descrip: This course will be divided into three units; each focusing on a different ballet choreographer: Michel Fokine, Agnes de Mille, Kenneth MacMillan. Students will be coached by internationally known guest artists, including Susan Jones, Kathleen Moore Tovar and Hilary Cartwright, to master and understand the diverse styles of each piece of repertory learned.

title: How Not to Go to Africa: Alternative Voices on the (East) African Narrative
descrip: See website

title: America and the Melting Pot
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Senior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified juniors if they have already taken COS 398. BSE candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Utopias, Dystopias, and Manifestos
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Analysis of Environmental Systems
reviews: Big hydrology emphasis. All major problem sets require coding. They're team projects but you'll get the most out of doing the hw having taken at least COS 126. Exams are fair. Celia is a GREAT teacher, especially with explaining math stuff. Hedin is less structured, but is also great and talks about really interesting things! Readings are short. Projects take quite a bit of time but there will be entire weeks when all you have to do is read an article here or there. Don't miss lecture though.
If at all interested in environmental science and modeling systems take this course. Lectures are very interesting and the workload is very manageable
Take good notes in class - you'll really need them for the test.

Take it! Both professors and Ryan are great and you will learn a lot. The only part that is tough is matlab if you've never used it before, but if you get a partner with experience or just get Ryan to walk you through how to code stuff, you'll be fine.

The course I took doesn't really match the course description (mostly about water, with some material on climate change / general modeling concepts / vegetation), but I would still recommend it.
