Celia and Hedin are great.  It is probably useful to have some exposure to coding before, but not absolutely necessary.

This course doesn't actually cover the material stated in the course description. In Spring 2014, the course began with box models, moved into the dynamics of groundwater flow (google 'Darcy's tube' and see if you want to spend three weeks on it), and ultimately into an assortment of modern topics relating to climate change.
Tough class gradewise but take it if you're interested in environmental modeling.

You aren't clearly told this, but you NEED Matlab, linear, and multi if you hope to really  understand anything Celia does. If you aren't an engineer (or an AB who takes engineering courses) then hold on to your hats, folks.
prereqs: Prerequisites: Mathematics equivalent to MAT 104 or instructor's permission; and Chemistry equivalent to CHM 202 or instructor's permission; and Biology equivalent to EEB 211 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Humans are increasingly affecting environmental systems throughout the world. This course uses quantitative analysis to examine three of today's most pressing issues: energy, water, and food. Each issue is examined from perspectives of natural and engineered ecosystems that depend on complex interactions among physical, chemical, and biological processes. The course is an introduction for students in the natural sciences and engineering pursuing an advanced program in environmental studies. We emphasize quantitative analyses with applications to a wide range of systems, and the design of engineered solutions to major environmental problems.

title: Seminar in Global Health and Health Policy
reviews: Absolutely take this class. It is an invaluable opportunity to gain experience presenting in front of a group of peers, to discuss science and policy issues with a widely talented group of people, and to hear the perspectives of guest speakers and the three amazing professors. A rare, wonderful class.

Be aware that this class is heavily reliant on student presentations, and you "learn" from students who have researched a topic for a few hours prior to presenting to the class. When the class includes expert presentations or discussions among the 3 professors, it is great and exactly what I wanted. But this is rare.
Come to class prepared to ask questions and really delve into the topics.
Do the readings - it helps you stay more engaged and appreciate the presentations more. Generally the discussions are great - I was always impressed by how thoughtful my classmates were.

Great class! This is an incredibly opportunity to take a seminar with three of Princeton's top professors. Very worth it. I was somewhat skeptical of the emphasis on student-led presentations as these have often been the worst part of previous classes. But for the most part, the presentations in this seminar were really worthwhile. Students put a lot of effort in to presentations, interesting questions are asked, the professors chime in, etc.

If you're interested in Global Health (and aren't afraid to participate in class), TAKE this course.  There's no other course I would willingly take, and enjoy taking, from 7:30-10:30 on Thursday nights, but the professors and the other students make it worthwhile and rewarding.
Take it. Great course. Great opportunity. Fun and engaging. Expect to participate.
Take it. Without a doubt.
Take this course. Just take it. Ask questions, think and read. I looked forward to this class every week.
Take this! It's a great class.

This class allows for experience in presenting for a longer amount of time than most classes at Princeton. Be prepared for a class mainly derived of student presentations, with occasional guest lecturers.

This class is amazing, I recommend it to everyone, especially seniors.
Be engaged in the conversation and you'll be fine. Having the three professors together is such a treat. 
That being said you do spend the majority of time listening to other students present so be aware that it's not just the professors speaking. When they do speak though, especially when they debate amongst each other, it's one of those Princeton moments where you can't believe you're getting the chance to witness such a conversation.
When participating, don't be afraid to push back against what others say, even in the large class size. It raises the quality of the discussion.
take it! super fun, super interesting, great all around!
prereqs: GHP 350 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This seminar will examine three major topics in global health. Potential topics include: the importance of patents in healthcare; AIDS in America; synthetic biology and biosafety; vaccine safety; the business of biology; the state of US healthcare; healthcare in emerging economies; and drug discovery and development.

title: Seminar in Comparative Politics - Military, State and Society
reviews: I think all students did well.
Professor Shah is the shit!!!
The same advice I would give for any class, but in particular any seminar: think hard about what you want to learn, and take seminars seriously.
it's very theoretical and abstract at times - only take it if you're interested in military politics. that said it covers all the bases.
prereqs: At least one Politics course in comparative or international relations is highly recommended..
descrip: This seminar is concerned with the puzzles and problems of civil-military relations. What role does the professional military play in modern state and society? Are professional militaries more or less likely to intervene in politics? How do democracies control the military? Why do those with guns obey those without them? We will explore these and other important questions in the study of civil-military relations across a variety of political contexts: consolidated democracies, transitional democracies, and authoritarian regimes in different regions of the world, including the U.S., Europe, Latin America, the Middle East and South Asia.

title: Research Program in Development Studies
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Beginner's German II
reviews: Go to class.
Good class, really depends on which teacher you get.
I hear the language pedagogy in the Japanese department is much better?maybe try that.
I would recommend that they constantly refresh themselves on old grammar so that larger grammar lessons don't seem too cumbersome.
I would take this course if you are interested in German.
I'd generally recommend trying to take the section that's taught by a professor as opposed to a grad student, but the grad students are usually excellent as well.
If you took GER101, take it. It's a language class.
Practice every day and use Quizlet to make flashcards of the vocabulary of the different sections.
Practice everyday, even if you're just reviewing vocabulary.
Put in the work to learn the vocab and grammar as you go.  This is not a course to cram for before tests.
Take German! The courses are fun, the teaching staff is great, and the students are awesome!
This class is good. The assignments are a little juvenile, but you will come out speaking very good German.
This is a wonderful class in which you will learn a lot!
Typical language class and you sort of have to take it, if you took 101 and want to get credit.
prereqs: GER 101 or permission of instructor. About 12 students per section. Normally no credit is given for GER 101 unless followed by 102..
descrip: Continues the goals of GER 101, focusing on increased communicative proficiency (oral and written), effective reading strategies, and listening skills. Emphasis on functional language tasks: learning to request, persuade, ask for help, express opinions, agree and disagree, negotiate conversations, and gain perspective on German culture through readings, discussion, and film. Participants are eligible to apply for Princeton-in-Munich, GER 105-G, June, 2014. The afternoon section, restricted to graduate students, follows the basic syllabus with added emphasis on reading skills.

title: Culture of Individualism, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Ecology and Conservation of African Landscapes
reviews: Any course with Rob is definitely a course to take, and the chance to travel more around Kenya with Paula was so worth it.
I would advise other students to be prepared for two distinctly different teaching styles (Paula and Rob).
Pringle is amazing. Greatly enjoyed his class.
Take this course!!! You get to travel, do fun projects of your own design, and also work with great professors. I can't recommend it highly enough.

This course was the most student-driven by far. The professors had very realistic expectations. Ask lots of questions, don't get frustrated when problems arise, and make sure you're clear on what the expectations are throughout the project. The professors will be willing to guide you.
This is a great opportunity to look in-depth at ecology (in the first half) and the social/cultural factors that interact with conservation (in the second half).
prereqs: Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya.
descrip: Only six percent of Africa's land area (containing a fraction of its biodiversity) is protected, and these areas are rarely large enough to sustain wildlife populations. Mostly, wildlife must share land with people also facing survival challenges. This course will explore how wildlife and people interact in Kenya, where new approaches to conservation are being developed. Lectures will cover the ecology of tropical grasslands and first principles underlying conservation and management of these landscapes. Field trips and projects will examine the dynamics between human actions and biodiversity conservation.

title: Global Change and the Impact of Human Activities on the Biosphere: The Everglades Today and Tomorrow
descrip: See website

title: Environmental Economics
reviews: A good option for fulfilling a departmental requirement. This class was okay, but not great. Even though I am very interested in the environment, I found the lectures to be incredibly boring. Smita is wonderfully intelligent, but didn't do a good job of presenting the material in an interesting fashion. The problem sets for this course are easy, and the overall workload is light. However, the tests were very difficult. It was hard to know what to study. I was disappointed in this class.

A great course for anyone interested in the relationship between the environment and economics. Make sure though that your fulfill the necessary pre-reqs because the math concepts can be tough without them.
Go to lecture, take notes, participate so you get more out of lectures. No need to read the book. Go to office hours if you have trouble with the psets. Easy departmental.

Lectures discussed interesting issues and research/research methods in environmental economics. Professor Brunnermeier's lectures were mostly clear, but it was difficult to know what to expect on psets and exams, based on the issues discussed in lecture. Rachel was a very helpful preceptor!
Not a bad econ course -- take it if you're interested in the subject. Professor Brunnermeier is a good lecturer, if slightly fast. Fairly light workload and overall not terribly difficult.
Take 310 before the course.

Take it. Especially if you are "science- oriented" It will help you understand that not everything that is technically feasible is economically realistic. This course helps you see climate change & other issues in a new way
Take this if it interests you. It is neither the best nor the worst class that I have taken here.
This class is mostly qualitative after the first couple of weeks.
This is an interesting course with relatively low work demand.
prereqs: MAT 103 or equivalent and ECO 300 OR equivalent..
descrip: Course introduces use of economics in understanding both the sources of and the remedies to environmental and resource allocation problems. It emphasizes the reoccurrence of economic phenomena like public goods, externalities, market failure and imperfect information. Students learn about the design and evaluation of environmental policy instruments, the political economy of environmental policy, and the valuation of environmental and natural resource services. The concepts are illustrated in a variety of applications from domestic pollution of air, water and land to international issues such as global warming and sustainable development.

title: Numerical Methods
reviews: A good introduction to numerical methods and it is an useful class if you need it, but not one to take out of curiosity. Problem sets can be very long and it's easy to fall behind.

A very good course for those outside the math department looking for an applied math course. Assignments are split between proofs and computational implementations of algorithms. Strong programming skills help.
I think this course is worth taking for anyone interested in a nice introductory background in numerical methods.
Interesting course. I would recommend it if you have an interest in physical sciences and applied math. Easy enough for a sophomore/junior.
Review the material as much as you can, go to lecture, and start the problem sets early.
Take if you want a hybrid math and computer science course.
This is quite different from a regular math class. For those who are interested in seeing theoretical math being used in an applied setting (at a very fundamental level) this is a great class.

This was definitely an interesting course. However, before signing up, keep in mind that the prereq courses won't adequately prepare you for the material. Some experience with COS classes and proof-based math is definitely necessary
prereqs: MAT201 and 202, or MAT203 and 204, or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to numerical methods with emphasis on algorithms, applications and numerical analysis. Topics covered include solution of nonlinear equations; numerical differentiation, integration, and interpolation; direct and iterative methods for solving linear systems; numerical solutions of differential equations; two-point boundary value problems; and approximation theory. Lectures are supplemented with numerical examples using MATLAB.

title: International Security Studies
descrip: Central topics in security studies, including the causes and nature of war, deterrence, alliance formation, military doctrine, civil-military relations, arms competition, and arms control.

I would say don't, but you probably have to. Ask a lot of questions in class to force the preceptor to slow down. And skip lectures if you want to catch up on sleep or do readings; the iClicker points don't count for that much anyway and you can probably spend your time better in other ways.

Homework problems and prelabs are written with no regard to grammar or clarity, and quizzes are made with no regard to the amount of time they might take (they range from ridiculously short to ridiculously long, given the same amount of time). Whoever writes these things does not seem to have a good grasp of course expectations. If you are taking this class, find a good preceptor that actually explains the material and doesn't just give more problem sets in class. Mine was great but he won't be teaching at Princeton anymore.

NEVER TAKE THIS COURSE or physics 103. Unless they restructure the course you will be in a constant struggle in which you will end up with a mediocre grade and only a knowledge of  what you need to know for the test.

It's an introductory physics' course, so it won't be spectacular, but it's pretty good.
Study regularly. Do extra homework than the required problem sets. Take 105-106 instead of 103-104 if considering the physics major. I wish I had.

Take 106 if you have the time.

Take it for a solid physics grounding. Be organised about it - there are many things to do to keep track, and try not to fall behind with learning and reading the textbook.

Take it if you have to!
Take it if you have to, if not there is really no reason to consider it.
Take it if you have to.

The class is annoying at times, but overall it's manageable.

The course is interesting and enriching.

This class is incredibly challenging. Probably just as hard if not harder than PHY 103. The labs are better because they are shorter, but are still just as boring.

This course (or an equivalent advanced course) is a requirement for engineers, and I don't think I would take it otherwise.  Unless you are a physics major and see this as a class for you.

This course is a lot of class hours given that it has 3 precepts, 1 lecture, and 1 lab per week, but you should always try to go to class.  A large part of your grade is the lab, so DO NOT miss lab, even though you can do make-ups it is better to do the labs while you are learning the material because they serve as reinforcement.  Also precepts are were the majority of the teaching goes on, so make sure you attend precept and find a preceptor whose teaching style matches the way you learn.  Also GO to office hours!  One final piece of advice is that this course requires a lot of memorization of formulas but if you read the textbook and learn at least the concepts behind the formulas they will be much easier to remember and use in problems.
This course is challenging, and more difficult to understand than PHY 103. Once again, prepare to work hard. There is a fairly heavy workload.

This course is disorganized and uninteresting. The material is usually just plugging and chugging with formulas, without the kind of interesting depth that you would find in PHY 105 or 106. As a result, the time commitment required for the class is very low outside of completing the laughably short problem sets. Lectures were extraordinarily unhelpful, except for some cool demonstrations. Make sure you get a good preceptor, as you will do all of your learning in precept. Don't expect any homework or exam solutions to be posted on Blackboard. Overall, only take this course if you need it as a requirement and don't have the time or physics interest for 106.
This course is fine to fulfill the requirement, but if you have already taken multi and would like thorough understanding of the material, it might be in your best interest to go up to 106

This course is not too interesting and I would recommend that you take it only if you have to. The labs are very boring and long. That being said, if you understand physics, the class wont be hard at all, as the pre-labs are short, and so are the assignments. The quizzes were really hard sometimes, but the final was very simple, so the difficulty level kept varying. Also, the lectures were not too great, as the prof just did cool experiments but didn't really teach any of the theory.

This course was not the greatest physics class and it's not the worst. The grading is fair and with multiple little quizzes, online and written homework, no one assignment will be make or break with your grade. That being said there is a lot of focus on minutia and memorizing foolish formulas about light which shouldn't be as big as a priority in the class but still seems to be. Lectures are somewhat foolish but Labs tended to be pretty interesting which I found relatively surprising. If you're taking this course, you most likely have to take it and as far as required classes go, it is very neutral (not great, like Cos 126, but not bad, like Mat 201).
This course will teach you physics.

This is a really simplistic approach to E&M. Take it if physics has given you trouble in the past. Otherwise, don't waste your time, take 106 instead. It is much harder, but also much more insteresting.
Try to get La porta.

Tully is a terrible lecturer, and the class is horribly organized. The problem sets are not written in discernible English. The only good part about the homework is that it's extremely short, but that just means that if you want to learn the material you will have to do it on your own. Textbook is awful as well. I absolutely love physics, and the only way I got through this class was through watching MIT lecture videos and reading Giancoli, which is a pretty good intro physics textbook. The one this class uses is Tipler and Mosca, and it is nonsensical and a pain to read. Avoid taking this class if you can, but if you have to take it just understand that you'll be learning everything by yourself. It's not impossible because there are lot of good physics resources out there ? it's just sad that the physics department doesn't care about getting people interested in the subject. If possible, take intro math or computer science classes instead.

Understand the problem sets, do practice quizzes when they're posted on blackboard. You'll probably have to do a lot of additional work if you really want to succeed in the class. Don't bother reading the textbook; its not particularly helpful. It's probably more worth your time finding a better source or using another University's lecture notes.
Very hard.  much harder than 103. Take it seriously or you will fall behind

When taking this course be sure to stay on top of everything. It's fast paced and not something you can afford to fall behind in. Meeting with your teachers is very beneficial and study groups will definitely make it a lot easier. Independent success if commendable and all but 5 brains is better than one--make use of your peers and all of your resources. Do this sooner rather than later so you don't have to play catch up at any point.

Worst course I've taken at Princeton. Don't take unless you have to, and if you do, go to MIT open courseware and look at Walter Lewin's lectures. There are a lot of them, but they will teach you the entire course a thousand times better than this course, and actually inspire some interest in a subject that this course will otherwise snuff out.
Wouldn't recommend it if it's not required; if it is, go for it, put in the work, get Vikram as your preceptor, and you'll be fine

You have to take this course because it's a BSE requirement. In its current state, attending lectures and precepts are a waste of time. Watch the MIT OpenCourseware version of the course (8.02), and you'll learn so so so much more in 45 minutes than you will in the entire 8 hours of class a week. It's a terrible course, which is a shame because Electricity and Magnetism is such an awesome field. As I said, you have to take it. If you can get Juan Uson as your preceptor, DO IT. He's great, and the only positive contribution to my experience in the course. He goes out of his way to help students, and holds review sessions frequently (with pizza)!
You need to teach most of the material to yourself; there's really no way around it

You're going to have to take it, and it's not going to be fun. First, hope you get a good preceptor. Second, if Tully is still teaching, you won't get any quiz averages, he won't answer your emails (or do what he says he will if he does answer them), and you'll feel that lecture is pointless. If you can, watch Walter Lewin's OCW videos out of class and zone out or do other things during lecture, which you will have to attend, because of iClickers. Do your problem sets with other people so they don't take up the time they're not worth in your week. Third, maybe if you all try hard you can inspire a little organization in this course, because we had none. We never knew how well we were doing in the course, problem sets, exams, and labs were all extremely hit or miss, and by the end it's evident that neither the instructors or the students care much. The instructors don't know what the other instructors are teaching and many are basically guessing about what the exam will be like and what you need to know due to lack of centralization. Unfortunately, you may not have a better alternative, because I have heard the same problems in 106 (although you will probably learn more there, they have apparently not put up practice finals yet. Their exam is a week away). For some reason, the physics department likes to see 103/104 as a service they're forced to provide for the university as opposed to a way to introduce non-majors to how interesting and useful physics is, and 105/106 as a way to weed out the potential physics majors they don't want to have. I think E&M is actually kind of cool and would be worth really learning about, but I was not inspired to do that whatsoever by this course. Get through it, study for quizzes and exams but don't be too put out if it doesn't pay off--it may not really have been your fault. Hope your upper level courses are better than this.

Your only hope is to have a good preceptor, so make sure you find one and take full advantage. If you don't understand something, go to office hours until you do.

Use Tully's slides to determine what's fair game on the test, then use your problem sets, quizzes, old tests, the Internet, and Tipler to actually study. Those slides are just a syllabus: at the surface.
attempt to knock out this requirement in highschool.
dont take it if you dont need it

The goal of the course is to develop an understanding of the fundamental laws of physics, in particular, electricity and magnetism, with applications to electronics, optics, and new challenges in renewable energy sources.

I would take it as a chill class.

If you are interested in entrepreneurship this is a great course. You have the opportunity to hear from great guest speakers and work on a entrepreneurship project of your own choice. In Spring 2014 though, the course suffered from a lack of organization and feedback on the instructor side though which often lead to repetitive, general non-guest lectures- so just be aware of that.
If you are interested, take it because you will learn a ton. It's probably a good idea if you have a team and an idea as you begin the class.
It's a good low-workload course and to hear the occasional good guest speaker.
Only take this course if you're very interested in the guest speakers and want to learn the general subject matter. Course itself is poorly run and the TAs are very disorganized.
PDF this class. The lectures are interesting in general, but the busywork in memos and pointless assignments makes for dead work.
Start reading the books -- they aren't good things to Sparknote, and you'll get a lot out of them.

Stephen Lin is the man. Course overall was pretty disorganized. I guess the guest lectures make it worth it. Reading responses for every class lecture. The final project was very open-ended and an own-you-own type of thing.

TAKE IT! This class is what business school should be for people considering startups. You get to interact with some amazingly successful startup people (Peter Fenton, Fred Wilson, Sam Altmann, Meraki founders etc), work on your own startup and reflect on what you're learning in the class by reading three books through the semester and writing reviews for all the lectures and books. Absolutely must take!
Take it for the guest lectures and the opportunity to do a project, but don't expect too much coherence otherwise.
Take it for the guest lectures. Everything else is meh.
Take it if you want to create something! It's not really worth it if you're taking it just to hear Meg Whitman or Jack Dorsey speak.

Take this course for the guest speakers...not the work you have to do for the class.  In that case you might as well take high tech entrepreneurship.  Speakers are awesome, Professor Singh is super knowledgable, but he doesn't seem to care very much about the class, which is unfortunate because it actually has an incredible syllabus and covers really awesome, relevant stuff to people interested in tech and business.

The class is pretty unorganized, but there's a lot of interesting material. The project is great, it's like 333 but you also have to think about the business side. I've talked to people who took ELE 491 and they're very similar in subject, although this class is less organized but you focus a lot more on your own ideas (the big project vs 491's case studies)
The guest lectures are awesome. Take this class!

This class gives you some great exposure to the business side of tech. The guest lectures were awesome. However, beware that this class is extremely disorganized and JP is impossible to get in touch with.  For the first month of the class we had no assignments and no syllabus. Perhaps to make up for this, they decided to make us write a 500 word response for every subsequent lecture (thats 2 per week), the grading of which were almost completely arbitrary.

This is a good course. The guest lecturers are amazing. However, it is clear that there's very little concern about the students and the course from the part of the TAs, which was a very negative experience. If this is fixed, I would highly recommend the course.
don't take it
easy way to finish up your COS certificate, might be more interesting/valuable to someone actively engaged in the startup world
go over everything with the TAs/JP before you turn it in
good class but somewhat unorganized. if you're going to invest in the product you choose, it can still be pretty fulfilling and you learn a lot about overall business model
pretty lame class don't take it unless you want free time to work on a business idea. lectures are terrible and having to write memos about the same repetitive concepts is quite annoying
take this if you need a departmental. otherwise it's just JP Singh talking about himself.
this class is best to pdf because the guest lectures can be very good, but JP is super disorganized and doesn't have much to contribute as a lecturer.
you would think this is the first time they offered this course. terrible organization BUT great people and material. find good partners and it's a definite take.
prereqs: COS 217 or COS 226 or equivalent..
descrip: Course teaches engineering students about issues tackled by leading Chief Technology Officers: the technical visionaries and/or managers who innovate at the boundaries of technology and business by understanding both deeply, and who are true partners to the CEO, not just implementers of business goals. Focus will be on thinking like a CTO (of a startup and a large company) from technology and business perspectives, and on software and Internet-based businesses. Industry-leading guest speakers provide perspectives too.

title: Materials in Civil Engineering
reviews: Ask plenty of questions and take good notes in lecture because not everything you need to know is explicitly in the slides and notes. Claire is pretty good; sometimes she'll breeze through stuff but she'll slow down if you ask. (f)
Focus on the lab reports and grasping general concepts.
Give yourself enough time for the lab reports and make use of the discussion board to ask questions.
I had a great time mixing and breaking concrete in the labs for this class.
It's a decent amount of work, though a change of pace from other civil classes in that you'll be examining materials in depth instead of mechanics.
Only take the class if you have to because the labs are a huge time commitment.
Only take this if it's required for you. Start early on lab reports (they can take up to 8ish hours). It gets easier to manage throughout the year.
This course could have been very interesting, but it was very poorly organized and taught.
take if youre interested. the class isn't very engaging if you're not.
prereqs: CEE 205.
descrip: Lectures on structure and properties of building materials including concrete (conventional and low CO2), steel, asphalt and wood; fracture mechanics; strength testing; mechanisms of deterioration (corrosion; freeze-thaw cycles, pollution). Labs on brittle fracture, heat treatment of steel, strength of concrete, mechanical properties of wood.

title: Advanced Hebrew Language and Style II
reviews: It's too bad Esther is leaving. I hope whoever teaches this course next is even half as good.
Take it with Esther!
Take the course!

Take this class if you want to keep developing your Hebrew beyond the basics.  My Hebrew was already really strong and I still enjoyed this class and gained a lot from it.  The work is not so bad and you will develop your Hebrew if you put in the effort.
Take this class!!! Morah Esther is the best!
Too bad she left :'(
interesting, exciting, fun. take it.
descrip: Readings in Hebrew culture, exploring the underlying tensions in identity among Israeli Jews: tensions in religious identity (ie. Ashkenazim versus Sephardim/Ultra Orthodox (Chareidim) versus Secularists), political identity, age/generational identity, and personal identity. We will analyze these issues within the context of contemporary short stories, modern poetry, newspaper articles, and cinema/theater.

title: Observing the World
descrip: In this seminar we will consider the different modalities of observation in the pre- and early modern world, including artistic, literary, philosophical, and scientific. A central problem will be the ways in which the world was transformed into concrete representations through language, visual art, and mathematics. Among the topics of interest to us will be perspective, early modern technologies of vision, observation and experiment, cosmology, travel narrative, and the rise of the scientific academy. Among those whose works we will consider are Alberti, Bacon, Berkeley, Descartes, Dante, Donne, Galileo, Leonardo, Milton, and Shakespeare.

title: Venice and the Mediterranean World
reviews: Amazing class - you'll learn a lot about Venice and its empire! Not a huge amount of reading but be prepared to spend time working on the final paper as well as any written responses - we seemed to have some kind of assignment due every week. But the chance to go to Greece is phenomenal and you shouldn't miss it!! Prof Shawcross is very kind and extremely knowledgeable about the subject material, so don't be afraid to approach her for help.

As crazy as this sounds for a course with included international travel, I would not recommend this class.  The work load is heavy, the material is often dry and the expectations are impossibly vague.  If you have an otherwise easy semester, it might be worth it, but if you take this class on top of other demands, prepare for a lot of frustration.
If you're slightly interested in the course, take it! Make sure that you do the readings and think about how the course might apply to your final paper.
Space out the readings.
make enough time in schedule to do the readings.
prereqs: Previous work in either History, Hellenic Studies, Art and Archaeology, Religion, Medieval Studies, or Italian Studies..
descrip: Venice, from unpromising beginnings on a marshy lagoon, succeeded in becoming a major commercial and territorial power that by the late Middle Ages and early Renaissance sought to rival the Byzantine and Ottoman Empires and dominate much of the Mediterranean world. This seminar will look at the development of both the city itself and its empire - the stato da mar stretching from the Adriatic to the Aegean and Libyan Seas - against a backdrop of conflict and exchange between Christians, Muslims and Jews. We shall learn about political, social and economic history, but also about art, architecture and literature.

title: Philosophy of Mathematics
reviews: Focus on writing clear, focused philosophy papers.
I strongly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in either the history of mathematics, logic, or metaphysics,

If you're good at maths and/or logic and are interested in how mathematics came to be what it is today and the controversies in maths, take this course. The readings can be hard for someone without a background in advanced maths though.
Take it as an upperclassman if you have a strong quantitative background.
This was a great class.  Burgess and Halvorson are good lecturers.  However, sometimes the material can be difficult if you are not a math major.
Worth taking!
prereqs: One previous course in philosophy or logic, or instructor's permission..
descrip: If we have any clear and distinct knowledge, then it's knowledge about mathematical facts such as that 2+2=4. What is it about the practice of mathematics that enables it to produce such apparently certain knowledge? We investigate the evolution of mathematical thought, and in particular, the development of the notion of mathematical rigor. This development culminates in the 19th century rigorization of mathematical analysis , and the ensuing early 20th century debates about the foundations of mathematics. We then turn to recent discussions about the notion of structure in mathematics, and its relation to the notion of rigor.

title: Macroeconomic Theory II
reviews: Definitely.
I would recommend the course. My advise to another student taking the class would be to stay on top of the material from lecture as much as possible.

My comments are targeted towards undergrads, since this class is required for econ grad students: take this if you are interested in demonstrating ability for a grad school application, or if you are interested in an overview of some important academic models in macroeconomics - bu be warned, it will probably not be very similar to an undergrad macro class.
Try to study Kaplan's material as the class goes along - he covers a lot, and it's hard to cram it all in at the end.
descrip: This course is the second term of a two-term sequence in macroeconomics. Topics include classical and Keynesian theories of cyclical fluctuations; the determination of employment and real wages; credit markets and financial stability; and stabilization policy.

title: Language of Love, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Information Retrieval, Discovery, and Delivery
reviews: A good, straightforward departmental with a very reasonable, balanced workload.  LaPaugh's lectures are very boring but she is very helpful in office hours to discuss either course content or the project.  The project is a good, open-ended way to do an exploratory but more academically oriented CS project.  Go to lecture and multi-task; pace yourself on the project.  I'm very glad I took this class - strongly recommend for anyone particularly interested in the data structures and machine learning behind search engines and database systems, neutral otherwise.
Definitely take it, especially if you need an applications credit for the computer science department.
Do the required readings. They are much more informative than the lecture notes/slides.
Easy, but definitely interesting and worth spending time on.
Go to office hours, go to lecture, and think through your final project.
Take it to learn about information retrieval in a relaxed setting.
Take it!
Take this course if you need an easy applications course or are interested in the material.
The workload was light and fairly straightforward. However, I felt uninspired by the course.
painfully boring
prereqs: COS 226 and some familiarity with linear algebra..
descrip: This course examines the methods used to gather, organize and search for information in large digital collections (e.g. web search engines). We study classic techniques of indexing documents and searching text and also new algorithms that exploit properties of the Web (e.g. links) social networks and other digital collections, including multimedia collections. Techniques include those for relevance and ranking of documents, exploiting user history, and information clustering. We also examine systems aspects of search technology: how distributed computing and storage are used to make information delivery efficient.

title: The Ethnographer's Craft
reviews: Even if you're not an anthropology major, this course is extremely helpful if you're interested in doing any field work. Do the readings and think through the issues that they bring up.

If you're an anthropology major you need to take it, and it could probably give you useful skills even if you aren't. But I wouldn't recommend using this course to gauge the department as a whole or to decide if you should major in anthropology or not.
Only take this if you are planning on being an anthro major.
Take it, especially if you're considering anthro!
Take this class if you're interested in ethnography and think it's useful!
the amount of work is not bad. just go to class, try to participate, and do the work, which isn't that much considering its a requirment
prereqs: ANT 301A and ANT 301B will meet together. ANT 301A/B is open to all students who would like to have the opportunity to prepare for cross-cultural engagements or ethnographic human subjects research. ANT 301B is reserved for Anthropology majors; all other students should enroll in ANT 301A..
descrip: What are social and cultural facts? And how do we identify these facts using anthropological research methods? This field methods course is for students interested in learning how to work with complex and often contradictory qualitative data. Students will examine how biases and beliefs affect the questions we ask, the data we collect, and our interpretations. Key topics include objectivism, interpretation, reflexivity, participant-observation, translation, and comparison. In addition to reading ethnographies, this class will use ethnographic films as a lens through which to explore the extraordinary power and limits of qualitative research.

title: Laboratory in Molecular Biology
reviews: Anyone who takes this course is required to take it...
Better taken in junior year than sophomore year.

Beware. 
There are pop quizzes, so make sure you know what's going on at all times.
Experiments will go wrong. A lot. Don't count on getting good data.
Definitely a good class to take if required - if not, then perhaps not worth your time, given the double block lab sessions.
Do the draft workshops, it saves time later. Try to turn in a full draft if you can later. Read the lab manual before class!
Don't take it but if you have to, fight against it. Don't just suck it up. You shouldn't have to take this class. It is absolutely useless.
Don't take it if possible. The class itself is good, but the lab reports are painful and don't seem to reward understanding or insight.
Good and well-structured course that helps to write laboratory reports.
Great class-just need to balance out your schedule since a lot of time will need to be put in if students wish to do well.

I would say this course is fairly well run, even if the experiments themselves can be plagued with unforeseen complications.  Professor Snyder's lecture explains the theory and technical background to the experiments you'll do that week, so it is worthwhile to pay attention.  Keep up with writing for the draft workshops, and your life will be easier down the road.  The toughest part about the course is growing accustomed to the conventions.  This is especially apparent when writing the first lab report, as the second report seemed to come together much easier, in my opinion.  Take advantage of the professors' FAQs and especially their offers to read and discuss drafts (TAs are less helpful in this respect).  Even if the particular experiments are not relevant to your future, you will learn a great deal about writing and reading scientific manuscripts.  Be willing to work consistently throughout the semester, but know that you'll still have to put a lot of time into the reports.
I'm sorry you have to take this, but just do it. You'll learn lab techniques
If you are interested in working in a lab ever, this class would be extremely beneficial.
If you have to take it, take it. It won't kill you but it will make you work hard.

If you're MOL, you're going to have to take it... so yeah. This was my least favorite departmental, mostly because the teaching staff really didn't act like they cared, were incredibly rude, and were not willing to provide help and assistance. I actually cannot express enough how disappointed I was in the teaching staff for this course. I have never had teachers at Princeton who were so rude and so unwilling to help me and guide me. Not even huge lecture courses, like orgo, were this bad.

If you're a MOL major, you'll need to take this class. I don't know how this compares relative to other core labs, but it seems less intensive than the rest. Honestly, while the 6 hours in lab a week (and you will definitely go overtime, so keep that in mind) might seem horrible, I think anyone who is in MOL for the right reasons has no legitimate excuse for taking this class because all of the research and work should be up your alley to begin with. 

One concern I have with this class is that while this course is in theory like freshman writing sem in that it tries to get everyone on the same level for their JPs and senior thesis, there is a huge disparity between students' experiments in research. I don't think this is something that the professors can control, but outside of the typical lab course prereqs students needed to take to get here, if you have done research before and written up manuscripts on your results and such for an internship or whatever, you have a huge advantage over students who have not. That is not to say that you will not do well without experience, it's just that the overall methodology of doing a lit review for your intro, understanding how to present results and figures, and writing up a pertinent discussion, etc. are all things that are relatively novel (unfortunately due to the fact that our prereq lab courses have really inane and pointless lab write ups) for most students at this point. 

General advice for doing well in this class:

1. Go to every lecture. Take thorough notes.

2. Do lab write ups in your book before each session. The book is only 5% of your grade but honestly the benefits of staying on track with it are much greater and will help you on reports and such in the long run. Print out figures and put them in, too.

3. Ask the TAs and professors questions while waiting for gels to run, digests to incubate, etc. You should ask them questions about your drafts, especially as deadlines come up, so that your rough
It's a really great course. I learned a lot and actually enjoyed doing it.
Not too bad until lab report time comes around...be prepared to spend a significant chunk of time dedicated to each lab report, and make sure you get your draft reviewed by a course instructor.
Only take this class if you have to do so. It takes a lot of time and isn't really necessary unless you are considering doing lab work in the future.

Prepare the actual writing of the report at least two weeks ahead of the deadline because it is so taxing and so time-consuming and definitely cannot be accomplished in one or two nights from scratch. Be warned.

So the class itself is really enjoyable and having to write two 25 page lab reports makes me feel like I really have a solid grasp on research but JESUS all the pop quizzes made me feel like the professors were out to get us. Some of my saddest moments this semester was when I stared down at a pop quiz asking the most esoteric, specific details and I could only draw a blank. 
Hint: if the powerpoint has less than 20 slides, you're probably getting a pop quiz at the end of lecture.

Standards are very high and grading is harsh. Make sure you find a lab partner who knows what she/he is doing. Finish as much of the lab reports as you can early and submit it for review by one of the instructors.
Start on lab reports early.
Stay on top of the workshops!

The course isn't hard, per se, but if you can't ask the right questions early and ask the right person, you're going to have a bad time. It's a lot of work and be sure to take the Draft workshops seriously. If you do all the Draft Workshops and work hard on them, you'll be fine.

There are two lab reports in total and in the last two weeks before their due dates, they will eat up all of your time. I still learned a lot and there was so much guidance through draft workshops and one-on-one conferences. Recommend over chem core lab.
Turn in a rough draft of the reports for the professors to read, otherwise it's really hard to know what they want.
Very time-consuming course but a course that will teach you so much.
When it comes time to write the lab report, make sure you talk to a lot of people to gain perspective on what is expected.

You have to take this class so there's no point for feedback.

Don't discouraged from how terrible this class is though, its not an accurate representation of what research is like in my opinion. Take a summer and intern somewhere to get a better feel, a more organic way to get into research I feel.
You kind of have to if you're Mol.

You probably have to take this class, but I really enjoyed it anyway.  Make sure you understand the lab manual before class, shouldn't take long to read through and really helps you know what you're doing in lab.
buckle down. you got this! labwork is fun! lab reports not so much
you must have draft quality drafts in the workshops... or else you will fall behind...
prereqs: MOL 342 (or permission). This course is required for Molecular Biology Majors..
descrip: The major objective of the course is to introduce students to a variety of tools required to conduct independent research in the field of molecular biology. While completing original research, students will employ a number of techniques that are used by molecular biologists, molecular geneticists, and biochemists. Upon completion of the course, students should have gained an understanding of how, when and why certain techniques and skills are used in a research setting. In addition, students will learn to write a research report modeled on the scientific literature.

title: Introduction to Quantum Computing
reviews: A lot of expectation to pay attention to things that were barely covered in order to do okay on the final. It would be nice if the professor did a more aggressive job of preparing students.
Consider waiting for Houck to teach it.
Excellent course. Take it. It can be hard if you haven't done quantum before but you can do it.
If you're interested in quantum computing at all, it's a good course to take.
Interesting course, but Lyon's lectures and notes didn't help me much.  The subject is cool though.  Take it with Houck if you can.
Not an easy class, but definitely rewarding and fascinating material.
Not at all. Perhaps sit in on a few lectures for general interest.

Take it if you are very interested; the grading curve is harsh but the material is not too difficult. Be on top of your game (sleep, feel healthy, make sure you understand random facts) on the tests because choking on the tests is the fastest and least satisfying way to get a poor grade (and it will happen even if you know the material well, if you're not prepared).
Take it if you want to figure out what quantum computing is about from the algorithm side.
Take it, but beware that it is not an easy course.

The class is really good! Take it if you want to learn quantum algorithms (like Shor's factoring algorithm and Grover's searching algorithm etc.) and if you are interested in quantum computing in general.
This course is very poorly organized. I would recommend against taking it.
prereqs: A previous quantum mechanics course will not be required. Requires sophomore linear algebra at the level of MAT 202, 204, 217 or the equivalent..
descrip: This course will introduce the matrix form of quantum mechanics and discuss the concepts underlying the theory of quantum information. Some of the important algorithms will be discussed, as well as physical systems which have been suggested for quantum computing.

title: Early China - Early Chinese Historiography
descrip: Early Chinese Historiography: Zuo Zhuan, Shiji, Hanshu. Readings in the major historiographic texts of early China. Close comparison between Shiji and Hanshu. Analysis of the defining features of early Chinese historiography in relation to contemporaneous literary thought.

title: Readings in American Legal History, 1607-1977
reviews: I would strongly recommend taking this course. The reading is certainly intensive, and the texts are not always easy, but it is extremely rewarding. The atmosphere in class is really welcoming and allows you to try out different ideas related to your own research.
Stay on top of your reading journals!
Take it. You won't regret it.
descrip: This course addresses the issues and methods in the study and interpretation of American legal history. Students may elect to take this as a research seminar.

title: Seminar in Medieval French Literature - Living Texts, Live Performances
descrip: We often treat medieval texts as dead artifacts by dead authors in a dead language, preserved in "best-text" print editions. This course aims to recover medieval experiences and practices of literature that depended on the living bodies that read, recited, performed, recopied and repurposed it. With attention to the fluidity of the French vernacular and the mediated nature of its early literature, this course covers a range of medieval texts and critical-theoretical approaches to their study, while also giving students hands-on experience with manuscripts and basic reading knowledge of Old/Middle French.

title: Decision Theory
descrip: Could it be rationally required to do something you are (rationally) quite confident is irrational? How should disagreement about how to respond to disagreement inform one's view of disagreement? What is it to have inconsistent beliefs or desires, and what actions are rational given such beliefs or desires? Need it count against a belief or desire that it reflects the influence of irrelevant factors? Can causal decision theory be reconciled with compatibilism about free will? We tackle these and other questions, focusing on ways that decision theory and epistemology inform each other.

title: Integrated Engineering Science Laboratory
reviews: Be ready to write reports. While they were short this year, they were not easy unless you'd had experience writing scientific papers in the past.
Don't be afraid of the reports. It'll all feel worth it in the end.
Don't be afraid to be creative! Take theory into account, and then let your imagination go wild!
Don't leave the lab reports for the last minute.
Don't start lab reports at the last second

Fun labs, you get to build turbines for the final project. It's basically a class about how turbines work.
MAKE SURE YOU LIKE YOUR LAB PARTNER at the first day of classes. They'll stick with you. And HAVING A GOOD LAB PARTNER IS SUPER IMPORTANT. For your own sanity.
Fun labs. Not fun lab reports, but it's nice that they limit length to 5 pages single space.
I enjoyed taking it, it allows you hands-on learning and building.
If you're MAE you'll be taking it. It isn't bad, have fun!

It is very interesting and very useful if your are in 222, but be warned the lab reports will take forever and sometimes you will stay up all night but still fail on them because the grading in unpredictably.
Its a much better lab than freshman year labs.
Lab reports 4 and 5 take forever. Start them very early. In fact, start ALL your labs very very early or you'll be spending nights and mornings working on them. Enjoy!
Make sure you know what your Lab TA expects out of reports!
Never take this.
Start the lab reports early, and they will be much less painful.

The first half of the new labs is pretty cool. Careful for the second half, might get a little boring. We got to build an engine that used newspaper as fuel for the first half! Almost none worked, though, but it was a lot of fun!
have fun
pretty cool lab because of the technology you get to use but also they throw coding/solid modeling at you. highly improved from last years mae sophomore lab
prereqs: MAT 104, MAT 202 (may be taken concurrently), MAE 222 (must be taken concurrently). Laboratory report grades from MAE 221 fall semester will be incorporated into final grade of MAE 224.
descrip: Students will conduct a series of prepared experiments throughout the year that will culminate in an independent project of the students' design involving fluid mechanics, thermodynamics and data acquisition tools. Preliminary experiments focus on pressure and Bernoulli's equation. Concepts learned will be applied in subsequent labs involving expanding flows and lift and drag measurements. Experiments will include internal and external flows.

title: Photonics and Light Wave Communications
reviews: Be sure to attend and pay attention in lecture!
Definitely take this class. Prof. Prucnal is the best and you will learn alot as well.
Despite the 400 level number, this course is very easy and minimal work. You will learn plenty though.
Great course and great professor! Definitely take it!
I really liked this course. I'd recommend it to anybody who wants to learn something about optical communications, and who doesn't mind a little lab section.
Take this class! It is a fantastic class and balances out well with Carlab in terms of work load and topic diversity.
This is a very good course for people who are interested in optical systems. In some ways, it is more of a general introduction to optics than some of the lower level ELE classes.
take it even if you aren't interested in fiber optics
descrip: This course provides a working knowledge of the components comprising fiber-optic networks, which form the backbone of today's communication networks, including the global internet, 4G wireless, home access (e.g., FiOS), and data center networks. The operation of lasers, fiber optics and optical routers will be discussed, as will current applications such as fiber to the home, the broadband wireless-optical interface, all-optical switching, signal processing and computing, and security in fibers. The course provides hands-on lab experience with fiber measurements and splicing, and frequent visits to the fiber optics lab and demonstrations.

title: Special Topics in Computer Science - Modeling the Past: Digital Tech, and Excavations in Polis Cyprus
reviews: Definitely take a course with Professor Smith and Szymon--I know that they really care about their students; and that they really want their students to get as much as they can out of the experience.
Fun, laid back course that teaches you a bit about archaeology and computer graphics. Final projects were websites, but not everyone in the group needs programming knowledge.
Go for it. It'll be a lot of work and probably a little outside your comfort zone, but a very rewarding experience and you produce something really meaningful in the end.
I would definitely recommend this class, it was very cool!
If this course is offered again, take it! It's fun and you'll get a lot out of it.

It is not a "Special topics in CS" at all; it's basically art and archeology (although if they want to do more 3D interaction, knowing how to build a website is not only useful but necessary because they won't teach you how). Whatever you do in 3D you learn through tutorials, the focus is entirely on the art and archeology aspect of the ancient buildings in Marion (Cyprus). I did not enjoy it very much, but if you are interested in that, Professor Smith would be a great source of information.

This course is really cool, but make sure you have an interest in both aspects -- otherwise you will get bored very easily. Also plan to spend a lot of time on the course project, but it is definitely a rewarding experience! (I found it to be more like guided independent work than normal course work)
descrip: This course will bring together students in Computer Science and Art & Archaeology to explore how digital technologies assist in the analysis and exhibition of ancient artifacts. Students will use 3D modeling tools to reconstruct virtual buildings based on excavations at Polis, Cyprus, and will populate the buildings with scanned 3D models. The course project will be to prepare website materials for the excavation project.

title: Intermediate Portuguese
reviews:
Be aware of the department grading scale! 

99-100 A  
95-98 A 
90-94 A- 
87-89 B  
84-86 B 
80-83 B- 
77-79 C  
74-76 C 
70-73 C-

An A is 95-98 which translates to almost impossible (!!) given all the small assignments you have to complete and the fact that a small accent mistake will cost you ~0.5 on the quizzes and the tests. Also, the course has 3 primary oral components (2 video surveys and a final presentation) and there are native speakers and near-native speakers in the class. I felt like no matter how much effort I put into this course, it was made impossible for me to receive an A and this made me want to give up and I felt unappreciated.

Definitely take this course if you want to learn Portuguese! Andrea Melloni is a fantastic professor and her classes are really enjoyable. Just one heads up: only take this class if you know Spanish. Otherwise it will be quite challenging.
Definitely would recommend it to those who wish to learn Portuguese.
Do not expect to have as much fun as 108, but worth it
Expect to do a lot of work, but you will get a lot of benefit from it. Like all other language classes, you need to want to learn the language, not just want to pass the test.
I highly recommend this course. Andrea is a fantastic professor, and you're Portuguese will improve greatly over the semester.

If you really want to reach a level of commendable proficiency in reading, writing and speaking Portuguese, you should take this class. It is significantly more work than POR 108 because you are going to be learning what is (or at least feels like) a lot more grammar on top of reading a book to analyze for your final paper. Also, Megwen is great ? she keeps the class fun and is always willing to help! She does grade pretty strictly though, forcing you to pay attention to detail when writing and speaking.
If you're interested in taking Portuguese, take it with Professor Melloni!
It gives you a good grammatical foundation. Great for freshman/sophomore year. I felt like at times, I was back in high school.
It's a lot of grammar; if you've taken Spanish in a highschool or college setting, you should be fine, the structures are very similar. So, do the homework - it'll make the tests/quizzes much easier.
Keep up with the outside of class work as well as the grammar lessons in the text book.
More work than 108, but rewarding and fun. Really proofread your papers and engage in the class!
Much more work than 108, but you learn a lot! Actually spend time reading the novel. It was quite good. Get Andrea!
Stay up on the work and you'll do well.
TAKE IT! The Portuguese department is the best
Take it if you've taken 108 because otherwise that will have been useless, but expect more work and harder grading.  Still a solid class though.

Take it! Portuguese is worth learning in this day and age if you want to work internationally. It's also very easy for an English and Spanish speaker. Pay attention to grammar. Vocab is not stressed whatsoever in this course. Do some of the Azul Corvo reading, but you don't have to do all to be able to do fine in discussion.
Take it! You learn so much and it is extremely fun
Take it. Andrea is the best. Seriously.

Take this course pass/fail if possible. Be prepared to waste your time doing busywork because of Megwen's obsession with film critiques (largely unproductive time in regards to actually learning of the language taking place) and reading a poorly-written and unimaginative novel.
Take this course!! Andrea is amazing!!!
Warning: this course is a lot more work than 108, and it moves at a faster pace at the beginning. Be prepared.

You should know that this class is infinitely more work than 108. And it's more work all the time. If you don't have a 45-minute take-home quiz for the weekend, you have either a composition or a video-critique based on a movie. You'll also be reading 20 pages of a Portuguese novel every week, which doesn't sound like a lot, but takes a while since you're not completely familiar with the language. It wouldn't have been so bad, had the book been more interesting. (I personally was not a fan in the slightest.) If you're taking this class with Megwen, know that she grades fairly harshly. The numbers themselves aren't always terrible, but your paper/test/quiz will come back looking like a crime scene. This class will really expand your knowledge of Portuguese - soooo many tenses - but it will also test your love of Portuguese.
prereqs: POR 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Students will further develop their language skills, especially those of comprehension and oral proficiency, through grammar review, readings, film and other activities. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to give in only one year of study a command of the Portuguese language sufficient for travel in Brazil, Portugal and beyond.

title: Music and the Spoken Word
descrip: A number of great composers (Mozart, Stravinsky, and Ravel among them) have worked with the spoken word in a wide variety of ways (as timbral or rhythmic counterpoint, programmatic narrative, poetic elaboration, found artifact, ironic, sentimental, or didactic counterpoint). In addition to examining older work (Stravinsky's L'Histoire du Soldat and Berio's Sinfonia, for instance), "we mean to acquaint ourselves with significant work by modern composers, (i.e. Lansky, Mackey, Currier, Wolff, Goebbels, Ashley, Dresher, Galas, et al.) and also run some experiments of our own with text and music."

title: Junior Seminars
descrip: A special section of HIS 400 for sophomores intending to major in History and who intend to spend Junior year fall term or the year abroad. Normally required of all juniors in the fall term, the seminar serves to introduce majors to the tools, methods and interpretations employed in historical research and writing. This seminar will concentrate on the history of property: cultures, practices and institutions of ownership in Europe, United States and Asia, from Early Modern time to the 1990s.

title: Christian Ethics and Modern Society
reviews: A great class that can be enjoyed without putting in too too much effort. Doing all the readings makes the class WAY better, but it isn't necessary to learn stuff or pass.
A lot of reading. Thought the class would be more interesting. I think it all depends on how much debate the preceptor encourages.
A pretty easy PDF option, if you go to lectures or do the readings. Go to precept and engage in discussions.
Always pay attention during lecture. Once you're lost, you have no idea how he got to where he is
Amazing!

An absolutely incredible course. The best academic experience I have had to date. Lectures are fantastic, readings are intriguing, precepts are insightful once you get the discussion going. Taking Christian Ethics is the best decision I've made thus far at Princeton-- I am now considering a major in religion thanks to the doors this class has opened. Take it. It may just change your life. More importantly, it may change the kind of life you want to lead.
Barely talks about ethics
Be open minded
Be prepared to read a lot.

Best class at Princeton. If you are do the readings and allow your ideas and opinions to be challenged, it will be life-changing. But if you are apathetic, you will likely come away having learned nothing. You will get out of this course what you put into it.
Boring if you're PDFing like me, but the readings I did do were good. I would try to take the course and do all the readings. If you do this, you will almost certainly get an A.
Break up the readings well or with friends because there are a lot.
Christians- take this course. You'll have a leg up already knowing the biblical text, but you'll be challenged to look at it in a new light.

Definitely take it if you're looking to fulfill a requirement (like WWS) or are interested in learning more about Christian ethics (whether or not you're Christian) -- not super hard, and you get to talk about interesting & relevant issues.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take this class as an easy distribution class. Not even worth taking pass-fail.

Definitely take this class. Whether you're a Christian who's interested in learning how to use your faith to reason about complex issues or you just want to understand common biblical arguments on both sides of these issues, there's something for you to get out of this class. As a cautionary note, though, the readings in the second half of the class can be very, very long.
Definitely take this course if you have the opportunity to. Although the papers are challenging
Definitely try to keep up with at least half the readings each week, so you don't scramble at exam time!
Definitely worth taking whether you're Christian or not. Good survey through important topics in ethics and the readings are generally worthwhile.
Definitely would say that effort needs to be put in to really understand and digest all the information.
Do all the readings and don't miss lecture
Do all the readings! They are super interesting and you learn a lot.
Do the readings -- they'll make you think (which is what this class is all about)!
Do the readings and try to participate in precept, but going to the lectures is not necessary and a waste of time.
Do the readings thoroughly. The more you think about them, the better you'll do on the papers and exams.

Do the readings! There are a lot and you might get behind at times, but doing the readings really makes you think critically about the issues. By the end of the course, I realized how much I had learned.
Do the readings.  The class is much harder to follow without them.

Don't come in thinking this class will give you a cookie-cutter answer to all the major ethical questions facing our culture today. That is Gregory's goal. Instead, he seeks to expose you to the richness of Christian text and perspectives on these issues that really makes you think for yourself where you stand. This was one of the best classes I've ever taken at Princeton and truly recommend it to every student.
Don't take it. Terrible. Not fun.

Don't take this class unless you want a relatively easy distribution out of the way and you SERIOUSLY do not care about being bored to tears in lecture. They stop being necessary to go to early on in the semester if you do the readings yourself. Professor Gregory's lectures just ask you questions the entire time and you can't tell if he's giving his own thoughts in between only regurgitating others' ideas. Just prepared to give this class little attention.
Easy EM to PDF. I never did the readings or went to precept. Studied the night before the midterm exam and did really well on it. So it is definitely very doable!
Get in Adam Eitel's precept. Lectures are always interesting.
Go to lecture. Take notes. This will clarify which materials are most important.
Good amount of readings, some tricky papers, but a great course.

Great class to fulfill your EM requirement. Interesting readings and not too much work. The final was a lot of writing and a little difficult, but overall I enjoyed the lectures and precepts and readings.
Great class to take even for non-Christians.
Great class to take, precept can be awesome if you have Alda, lectures are a good summary of readings, readings are super interesting

Gregory is the man, Adam Eitel is the man, the readings are fantastic though numerous. Whether you're Christian or not, there's lotsa Christians out there, and it's good to know how to engage with them, with all kinds of Christians. just take this class already. Oh, and here's some padding to make this review longer and therefore get sorted to the top in my algorithm that you're using to view these: lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol lol - Love, Senior CS Major
Highly recommend; presented a very wide spectrum of viewpoints concerning Christianity and its (great) impact on the world over the course of history and especially today.
I highly recommend taking this course.

I really enjoyed the lectures, readings, and precepts for this course. However, as someone who came into the course knowing very little about Christianity, I didn't feel like I had enough knowledge about the religion to put all of the readings in context.

I recommend this course for all students, no matter what their background may be. It offers diverse perspectives on very controversial issues, and could quite possibly change the way you look at ethics as a whole.
I think this course would be weird if you weren't Christian, but a lot of non-Christians take it and disagree. You don't need to do all the readings super thoroughly, but you do need to do them.

I would definitely recommend this course. It really challenges your thinking, whether you are a Christian or not, and is personally fulfilling. The class is not only intellectually fulfilling but personally fulfilling as well. Professor Gregory is awesome.
I would highly recommend this class to other students. It is a fair bit of reading, but all of the readings are definitely worth doing. This was definitely my favorite class of Spring semester.
I would only take this class if you are interested in Christian Ethics.  Many people PDF the course, which could be helpful because you could chose what readings you want to do.
I would recommend against it
I would recommend it to fulfill as an EM requirement.
I would recommend them to make sure to take copies or print out professor Gregory's lecture outline sheets because they provide a lot of information about the topics discussed.
I would recommend this course to anybody that was remotely interested in philosophy.

I would say if you are really intrigued by these issues, then take the class. If you don't really care about the issues, than don't, because it becomes very boring. Those people who tell you they love the class are the people who have passionate opinions about the topics, those, like me, who tell you they were disappointed are the people who don't.
I would strongly recommend this as a distribution requirement, general interest or even as a stepping stone towards possibly majoring in religion.
I would strongly recommend this course.
I would strongly suggest taking this course. While the course is reading heavy, one does not need to do all readings in order to get a good grasp of the material and the scope of the field of study.
If you are looking for a PDF EM, this would be the course to take.
If you do not know the Bible, you will struggle a bit with this course, even though they say you don't need knowledge of the Bible at the beginning.
If you're a Woody Woo major looking for an Ethics requirement, take this over anything else. It's super engaging (although it gets sort of boring towards the end) and also adequately interesting.
If you're looking for an EM that is engaging, take something else. There is a lot of reading, and the lectures are pretty dry.

If you're looking for something to challenge your views on Christian Ethics, this might not be the class for you. Maybe it's because I am a Christian so I heard a lot of this before, but also probably because Gregory shies away from too much controversy, I wasn't too provoked (and I wanted to be). But I think maybe if you're not a Christian you might find it interesting (though one of my non Christian friends also said he thought Gregory was trying to be too politically correct). A good overview in general on the ways Christians might approach certain topics though, and on Christianity and liberalism.

If you've ever heard anyone say to not take this class because it shoves Christian ethics down your throat, then let me tell you that this is blatantly not true.  The ethical questions are approached from a Christian perspective, yes (honestly, what else were you expecting?), but even in the Christian community, there is a lot of disagreement.  There is not a single perspective in this class that is elevated above all the others - it's more about the dialogue (or lack thereof) between these perspectives.
Interesting material, but quite a lot of work.
It is a class that gives you perspective. You may enjoy it if you are the type who likes thought-provoking readings.
It is a good way to fulfill an EM!
It really opened my eyes to the complexity of Christian ethics and shook up my preconceived notions. I encourage everyone to take it.

It's a class everyone should take, but only because the subject matter is interesting. The teaching is not what it could be, especially considering Gregory's qualifications. It's a ton of work, so if you're on the fence, maybe wait a semester.
It's a fairly easy class that does not require a lot of work. It would be a very easy P/D/F.
It's interesting, but a lot of work for pdf course.

It's not a theology class, so there isn't as much study of the Bible as I expected. You'll mostly study what various other Christian authors have written. Very good class though - you'll learn a lot, especially if you do all the readings.

(Although he grades easily enough that you may not have to do all the readings to get a solid A- ).
Its an easy and good class, there's no reason not to take it.
Its not as amazing as people claim it is.
Keep up with the readings.

Know that despite its reputation as a distribution-requirement-fulfilling class, it can be both 1) very interesting, and 2) difficult. Do the readings, pay attention in lecture, and you will do fine. Also, choose Adam Eitel as your preceptor.
Make sure to do all the readings before precept and lectures. You will take a lot more out of the class.
Make sure you do the readings and understand that this is a good P/D/F class but not a blow off class.
OK distribution requirement. Keep up with reading. Lectures aren't the most entertaining.
One of my favorite classes at Princeton.
One of the best classes I have taken at Princeton! Strongly recommend

People love this class - I didn't love it, but I thought it was worth it to take. It's much less interesting to take if you have very little Christian background, because the second half of the course deals primarily with how Christians could/should engage in society, which I didn't find particularly interesting or relevant.
