If you're interested in religion and its relevance in the context of society, this is a great class for you. If you're newer to religion and want to learn more about its foundation, this probably isn't the class for you.
Pretty easy PDF.  I found lectures more boring than others have said
Probably better to take it for a grade than PDF it.

Relatively easy, especially for Christians with some theological/ethical training. Professor Gregory is great, and really seeks to make students develop a deeper understanding of ethics than the vague, simple liberal tendencies typical of this institution.
Should be a necessary class to take in order to graduate.

So if you're low on time, consider this for the final/midterm (worked very well for me): get together a group of friends, and you each do ONE WEEK of reading really thoroughly. Take notes, summarize the main concepts and thoughts, vocabulary the people are using, everything that will be helpful for the midterm/final. Then trade your notes with each other, meet up and talk about it. That way you all have all the knowledge and can talk about all the readings on the exams, without having to have put in the time to read all of them. Huge time saver.

So some of the reviews I read coming in said that even if you were an atheist or didn't have a lot of background/knowledge regarding Christianity or religion in general, it would still be a riveting class.  I did not find this to be the case.  I thought some subjects and arguments were very engaging and interesting, but those turned out to be the non-religious parts of the argument.  And even if not having a Christian background technically doesn't hurt you on exams or papers, soooooooo many people in precept just pull Bible verses out of their pockets and are throwing them around and I'm just sitting there like...ok.  This doesn't mean you'll suck in precept, you just won't be able to engage as much if your preceptor doesn't make sure to bring it back to an ethics, rather than religious discussion.  I would take it, but it doesn't deserve its high rating.
Strongly recommend! I have gained so much perspective in a lot of different social issues. Reading work is heavy, so divide it with a friend.
TAKE THIS CLASS!
TAKE THIS COURSE AND DO THE READINGS!
THERE IS A LOT OF READING.
Take a different EM if you just need to take this course for a distribution requirement. Especially if you're PDFing. Too much work is required.
Take it and try your best in it. It doesn't take that much effort, and it's definitely something worth taking in Princeton.
Take it but be prepared to work
Take it for an EM or just for fun. It isn't that much work and the readings are pretty interesting. It's nice to see the opposite side sometimes.
Take it if it interests you - I enjoyed it a lot.
Take it if you want an introduction to Christian ethics and many of the bases for Christian beliefs.
Take it if you want to engage in some interesting questions, no answers will be had, only new tougher questions than those you had before.
Take it if you want to learn a new perspective.
Take it if you're interested, whether or not you're Christian.
Take it!
Take it!  It's fun.
Take it! Christian or not, REL major or not, there's a lot to learn from it. Also, keep up with the readings.
Take it! It was a great experience. Do the readings if you can, won't be a waste of time.
Take it! The lectures are interesting and it is a thought-provoking class
Take it, lots of fun!

Take it. Get Melanie Webb as your preceptor cause she is awesome! It is a good class because it exposes your to Christian and non-Christian perspectives on big issues, forcing you to really understand where you stand and why you stand there. It's not doctrinal, so if you're not Christian, it is a nice intro to what Christianity is about. The papers are excellent because they force you to create really strong arguments. The exams are very straightforward and dare-I-say easy if you go to lectures and do ~70% or more of the readings.
Take it. It's interesting.
Take it. The best class I have taken hands down.

Take it. This is a phenomenal class between the readings and the teaching. If you approach it the right way (which shouldn't be about getting a good grade or fulfilling a requirement) you can get a lot out of it.
Take the course as an EM- not too bad
Take the course if you are interested in gaining perspective on relevant social issues.
Take the course if you're interested in the subject area.
Take the course if you're looking for a class to really make you reconsider your own morals.
Take the course! Coming from someone who is not Christian, it was a very valuable look at an important ethical framework.
Take the course, particularly if you come from a Christian background or have an interest in religion/Christianity.

Take this class!  It was so interesting and it challenges many assumptions about and even interpretations within Christianity.  It really makes you think about our current society and what it will become with or without religion.

Take this class! I just took it because it sounded interesting, even though I already fulfilled the distribution requirement and I didn't need it for a departmental. It turned out to be pretty great like everyone said.
Take this class. This opens your eyes to so many different issues regarding Christian views on almost every controversial issue. Helps us understand what it means to be a Christian.
Take this course for an interesting, PDF distribution requirement.
Take this course if you need to PDF an EM
Take this course!
Take this course!!! it is my favorite class I have taken at Princeton so far! Great way to fulfill a EM requirement.
Take this if you need it for a requirement. Know all the main points of the readings for the exams. Talk to your preceptors about the papers if you don't know how to write a philosophy paper.

The course is fair to all perspectives; you don't have to be a Christian or well-trained in ethics to do well in the course (though I suppose it might help). If you want to explore current topics along with general ethics from a perspective that includes Christianity, this is a great course.
The material is very interesting; the lectures are a tad dry sometimes.

This class is fairly enjoyable. If you're looking for solid answers, you might be disappointed, but it's helpful to be exposed to many different ideas surrounding these complex and controversial issues.

This class is kind of like going to church.  Gregory is preachy, although he has some funny stories to tell (e.g., midget tossing).  Also there are SO many authors you are responsible for on the midterm and final it makes it really difficult to PDF.  You still have to do the readings and at that point you might as well take the class for a grade, since your workload will not be reduced all that much.

This course is excellent for both Christians and non-Christians. There is much to learn concerning the debates on these modern ethical issues. Dr. Gregory does a great job in "unpacking" all of the related arguments.
This course is really stimulating, ESPECIALLY if you have a good preceptor. If your preceptor's not great it'll still be fine, but really helps if you have that.

This course meshes well with Michael Smith's introductory class on Moral Philosophy.  The readings are great, but there are a lot of them and a few are somewhat dense.  It might be helpful to form a study group.  Also, be cognizant of the fact that the final exam is cumulative and that you are required to memorize the names of the authors of the readings for both the midterm and final exam.
This is a fun course that is not too much work.  It makes you think about a lot of current issues in different ways.
This is a good course, but be prepared to keep up with the readings -- they get increasingly longer and more difficult towards the end of the semester.  Be sure to find a precept that suits you.

This is another one of those classes you take to get the EM out of the way. The material has the potential to be interesting but the way it is treated results in it becoming exactly how you'd expect a Christian Ethics course to go, which makes the material trite and boring.
This is not at all what I expected the course to be. It was too theoretical for my liking and had way too much reading.
This is probably hypocritical of me, but do the required readings! They are really interesting and varied and will teach you a lot.

This is probably my favourite course at Princeton. The only thing that seemed to ruin it for people, in my mind, is that too many people went in with a ton of preconceived notions. The point of the class is to hear and understand both sides of the debate on a lot of the issues that get talked about, and the course is cheapened a lot if you don't go in with an open mind. Professor Gregory is extremely good at staying impartial on (almost) every topic covered, to the point that I still don't know what most of his opinions are. As long as you go into the class prepared to do the readings (which are the primary thing tested) and can try to understand the actual arguments in the debate, you're going to both enjoy and do very well in this class without a ton of effort.

This isn't going to be the most in depth class, but it's going to hit on most of the major contemporary thinkers. Make sure you get a solid conceptual understanding of the different philosophies. 

Professor Gregory can talk at you a little too much in lectures but is pretty good and has some interesting things to say, and he's a nice guy too.

This was a great course. It challenged the way I think and we got into really deep discussions in precept. Not much outside work besides reading (just 2 short papers). Should definitely take a class like this while at Princeton. Also understanding the perspective of one of the most common religions is really helpful in understanding why people believe the things they do, and how it affects our democracy.
This was a very meaningful class. Lectures, readings, and precepts were all very well connected and got us thinking about interesting and relevant issues.
Try to keep up with the readings. It's hard, but worth it.
Well worth it just for the lectures, but should really do all the readings to make the most of it.
What you get out of this course will be determined by the effort you put into the readings and discussions.  If you are genuinely interested though, I would recommend taking it.
You get out what you put in
You need to take it.  Best class at Princeton.
You should take this course as early in your Princeton career as possible. It is set up so that, if you are diligent, you can really do well and learn a lot about yourself and morality.
good pdf
keep up with the readings

super easy class...dont even need to go to lecture although you'd be missing the best part because Professor Gregory is AWESOME! Papers are easy and midterm and final were manageable if you are familiar with concepts and readings
take it if you are interested in it
take it, but it's still a busy workload
descrip: An introduction to Christian ideals of conduct, character, & community, & to modern disputes over their interpretation & application. Are Christian virtues & principles fundamentally at odds with the ethos of liberal democracy oriented toward rights, equality, & freedom? What do Christian beliefs & moral concepts imply about issues related to feminism, racism, & pluralism? What is the relationship between religious convictions, morality, & law? Special emphasis on selected political & economic problems, sexuality & marriage, bioethics, capital punishment, the environment, war, terrorism & torture, & the role of religion in public life.

title: Eastern Europe: Culture and History
reviews: I would recommend this course to anyone who has a background of interest in the history of Russian or any Eastern European country, but lacks knowledge of the culture.
Participate in the discussion.
The course is interesting and well-organized.
descrip: The course will discuss the main trends in East European history and culture, concentrating mostly on 20th and 21st centuries. Each week will be devoted to one aspect of East European studies and the classes will combine theme-plus-methodology approach. There will be several invited speakers. The course is part of the track in East European Cultures and Societies (EECS), one of the two tracks for Certificate in Russian, East European and Eurasian Studies.

title: Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology
reviews: A great intro to molecular biology. It is a large amount of information to learn in a short period of time so stay on top of lectures as reading material.
A very fair class. Feels like high school in a good way. AP Bio prepares you well for this course; if you didn't take it don't let that discourage you.
Always stay on top of the readings.
As long as you can stay awake at 8:30 this is a good class.
Attend lectures, especially Notterman's because it's really hard to understand his materials just from reading the lectures.
Be prepared to go over a lot of information, and be on top of teaching yourself a lot of it in order to get a good understanding.

Be sure that you want to take this class if you are not pre-med or interested in majoring in molecular biology. The material is well prepared, but the culture and attitudes of the other students really determine how you will feel about it.
Best and most manageable of the premed courses. Try and keep up, it'll make studying for the final much easier.
Beware of pre-meds everywhere. And gels everywhere.
Create a study guide as you go. Do the p.sets. Go to office hours with questions
Definitely take if considering majoring in science. Otherwise it might not be worth it.
Do not take it unless you really love mol bio or have to take it. 8:30 lectures are a killer, especially in this topic.
Do the psets!! It will force you to review the material, and figure out what you do and don't know.
Do the readings and review the lecture slides for the tests.
Do the weekly problem sets.
Don't do this with ORGO!
Don't take it unless you NEED to. Don't take it freshman year.
Don't take the course unless necessary. Lab was good and fun but it wouldn't be worth it to obtain an STL. Prepare for a lot of tedious memorization.
Don't take this just to get your STL out of the way. Only take if needed. 830 lecture is brutal (it's as bad as it seems) so don't subject yourself to it unless necessary.
Don't think that it's easy because it's biology. The tests aren't actually just about memorization.

Eh. If you're not premed or required to take THIS specific course, I don't know. It felt very similar to AP Biology to me, and it wasn't a walk in the park, but the labs aren't hard. take it if it interest you!
Final was absolutely terrible, but everything else was fine.
Fine.

Get ready to put a lot of effort into this course if you want a decent grade. Do the textbook readings. Don't get bogged down on details but rather applications of the material, which is what most of the questions will be on on the test. This is a very hard course to do well in.
Go over the lecture notes after each lecture.
Go to bed early. ALWAYS go to lecture; that's where you learn the bulk of the information for the exams.
Go to class! the power points help but taking notes during the presentations make it that much better.
Go to every single lecture - EVERY single one, you'll need it - and go to the review sessions !
Go to lecture and take good notes (so that reading the textbook is not as needed)
Go to office hours.
Good luck learning at 830am!
Great course!  Not too challenging and a good intro to mol
Helped me decided whether I do or do not want to pursue a major in MOL. Difficult if you are not good at conceptual thinking.
Helpful for getting a good mol bio base, just a lot of work
I approached this course in the wrong way, too nonchalantly because I did not realize how intensive science classes are.  Just know before going into this class that it is a real science class.

I think most people who take this course have to take it, but if you are taking it just because of a general interest, prepare to stay very organized throughout the course and do a lot of studying outside the class.
I think this was a really interesting science class.  I hadn't taken AP Bio like many in the course did, but I still found it a really well taught introductory course - definitely recommend!
I unexpectedly really enjoyed this course. I suggest taking it; you might find out you like it.
I would definitely recommend you take this class. You have to if you want to major in MOL or EEB.
I would recommend doing readings in the event that lectures begin to make less sense. Falling behind is fairly easy to do, and necessary to avoid.
I would recommend taking it if you are interested in biology and want to know a bit about
I would recommend the class to anyone possibly considering being a science major.
I wouldn't take unless you need it for a requirement, but nevertheless it is an enjoyable course. Make sure you write an outline after every lecture to keep the material organized in your head.
If you are interested in MOL, please take it!
If you are pre-med or MOL you have to take this class. Don't be afraid, just stay on top of the material and start studying for the exams early.
If you like biology, you'll like this class. If you're doing it for a distribution requirement, there are probably better choices.

If you love biology (like I do), you'll love this course. Preparing for exams can be a lot of work, but this class will teach you a LOT in a relatively short amount of time. MOL 214 is an awesome course!
If you need it, go ahead - it's a pretty good course.

If you take this class, a word of advice about the text book: don't worry about the activation code for the online site - it isn't worth buying, so go ahead and get the book used. The book is helpful, but there isn't too much required reading. I found that most people were taking the class for some requirement or another. The lectures are okay - long and early - and the material doesn't appear to be so detailed in lecture when it is explained, but details are important for the tests, so start studying in advance so that you can memorize/learn everything. The class is interesting, but I didn't love it as much as I expected to.
If you want an intro to biology this is great!!

If you're taking it, it's probably for a requirement.  I'm not gonna lie, 8:30am is brutal.  I read the textbook for the second exam, and my grade was significantly higher.  It's not too difficult to learn the information based on Dr. Gavis's lecture slides.  But Prof. Notterman does not make good lecture slides. I'd have enjoyed it more if it were later.  I put the least amount of time into this class compared to my other classes, and I expect to receive a B.  But you have to study really hard for the exams.
Interesting and engaging. See teacher outside of office hours.
It is way too early in the morning to learn anything.
It's VERY early in the morning.

It's a great course. As most people are surely going to say, it is pretty much just pure memorization and then some application of the material. If you've taken bio classes before, most of the material will not be new (replication, transcription, lac operon, cancer, etc.), but the modules at the end of the semester are really cool! Overall it's a great and very interesting course (but as a MOL major, how can I not have loved it?)
It's a lot of work and requires time and diligence. You do learn important biology concepts and from an experimental standpoint.
It's fine. It's very exasperating if you are actually interested in learning more after high school biology.
It's not inherently boring, it can just get really into detail at some parts. Just keep up with the lectures, even if you miss a couple make sure to learn the powerpoint.
Its a pretty uninspiring course, but it doesnt ask too much of you so its ok
Just stay on top of the material.
Keep up on material: lots to memorize.
Keep up with the material week by week.
Labs are easy. Not like the physics death of hell. Late meal every day. Do your readings, do your shit.

Learn stuff as you go over it in lecture and make study guides weekly, otherwise the details become very overwhelming at the end of the term. But it's still a worthwhile class if you have the interest. Especially the Neuroscience module, definitely opt for that one if it's an option.
Lots of information, but if you like learning about molecular processes, it's super interesting! Really felt like I learned a lot.

Lots of specific information to memorize, especially for the final, but manageable as long as you keep up. MOL majors will have to take this anyways. Overall a good class; would recommend to anyone with an interest in the subject.
MOL 214 has been my favorite pre-med class at Princeton. Very interesting material, well-organized class, and wonderful teachers.

MOL 214 is hands down the worst introductory biology course, pre-med required course, and introductory level course at Princeton University. Memorization is the name of the game, and the course currently has no resources to help any of its students. There are no precepts, which greatly contributes to the mass confusion of those students who did not take AP/AP-level biology in high school and which deemphasize the priority of this course in the minds of its students. Every single preceptor (lab TA) is equally unapproachable from my experience for extra help, seeing as they are all 2nd year or so grad students who are out of touch with the machinations of actually going about understanding this material. The review sessions led by the arrogant Anthony Ambrosini were equally awful, as he did nothing actually to review the material, but rather he just went over the answer key for the weekly optional problem set and stared at our blank faces as he ended every single session more than hour early. Unbelievable. Even in his office hours he scoffed at half the questions he received. Do not bother with his review sessions. If you want help, approach Dr. Thieringer. Go to office hours every week. Lectures are important to go to simply because you want to copy down verbatim what the lecturers are saying, because none of it will make sense to you at the time, at 8:30. Find a friend with whom you can exchange notes when one of you misses lecture. Perhaps even record lecture. They are Tuesday and Thursday, so at some point from Friday-Sunday, sit down for 2-3 hours RELIGIOUSLY and review each slide. Trust me, just reviewing the slides will take that long. Then, do the problem set. Then on Sunday-Monday, work on the almost-weekly lab report AND do the textbook reading for the coming week, which should not be too long. If you have not had AP/AP-level bio in high school, I highly suggest studying basic genetics over the summer (DNA replication, transcription, translation, gene expres
Make sure you're very awake before each lecture.
Material is actually fairly interesting if you like biology. Exams are really detail oriented. I would only take this if it's required for you.
Memorize a lot.
Memorize everything.
Mol is not as bad as everyone makes it out to be.
Next year should be more organized class, should be better than this year, but was still pretty good this year
No one took it because they wanted to. just something we had to grind our teeth a get through. People like Heather and Chris made the class a lot more bearable.
Not as bad as I thought it would be. Make sure to attend lecture!
Not very hard, super interesting, well-run. Take it if you have to, or if you're interested.
Obviously pre-med students have to take it, but if you do not enjoy biology do not take the course. For those who decide to take, make sure to stay current on the readings.
Only take if you have to
Only take if you have to. If generally interested in bio, take Mol 101.
Only take it if it is a requirement. I imagine this course is not representative of the entire MOL department as it is generally a less than stellar intro class.
Only take it if you are genuinely interested in the material, or have to. And if you do take it, go to lecture.
Only take it if you have to. It's well taught, just not always very interesting
Only take this class if you absolutely have to.
Pay attention in class and study  the slides....don't read the textbook if you don't have to. Time will be more efficiently spent if you just study the slides.
Practice exams from previous years are a big help. Go to lecture and pay the fifteen dollars for LectureTools, just for the Q&A feature if nothing else.
Pre-meds: ya gotta do what ya gotta do. Enjoy the labs. They're a lot of fun and you get to go to late meal when you run gels.
Prepare to be bored out of your mind all semester.
Provides a strong foundation for mol bio

Put in the work and you can do well, but it is a lot of work so if you can, avoid taking it alongside another STL (especially orgo). Keep up with the material every week, because it is a lot to cram in a few days. Attend every lecture.
Read the book! Go to lecture!
Read the chapters and don't miss the lecturers.
Review the slides ahead of time.
Stay on top of memorization
Stay on top of the material.
Study
Study well in advance of the exams. They is a lot of material which needs to be studied multiple times to achieve full comprehension.
Super interesting material! Make sure you study from week to week, otherwise it is really hard to understand and memorize everything for midterms.
Take it for the major or to decide if you are interested in medicine. It is time-consuming, and so you will have to dedicate a lot to the class in order to derive a lot from it.
Take it if necessary.
Take it if you have taken bio in high school. If not it is very hard to learn all the material
Take it if you want to have a good basis of molecular function and heritability.
Take it if you're really into bio and want to learn to think like a scientist
Take it, but go to lecture and do the problem sets.  Maybe don't do the readings.
Take the course because it's a departmental, and don't buy the textbook.
Take this class if you like bio! The "pre-med" nature of the course shouldn't scare you.  I learned a lot!
Take this course! (Unless you have AP credit-- then take a more advanced MOL class)
Take this course.
Take this to see if you're interested in mol, though be prepared that it is a lot of work.
Take this! even just out of interest.
The course material is definitely interesting
The lecture slides are the most important. Don't try to memorize everything - it won't help because we are not tested on specific enzymes. Pay attention the mechanistic details.
The wall of memorization that an intro MOL class presents isn't always fun, but this one is pretty well done. Labs are sometimes fun sometimes boring.
This class is a premed requirement. Don't expect much.

This class is really rewarding if you put in the effort. There is a lot of work that goes along with it, but the material is really interesting, whether you are going to end up as a MOL major or not. That being said, there a lot of very intense MOL people in the course, and the atmosphere is kind of intense (esp. will all the premeds). So, be prepared to stay on top of your work.
This class was a lot more work than I intended it to be and it was straight memorization. The material was interesting, I just wish that some of it was more clearly explained.

This class was a requirement for pre-med and I would not have stuck with it if I did not have to.The 8:30 start was painful and I tended to fall asleep in the long lectures. Therefore, I got very little out of the class. The best part of the whole semester was the last two weeks when we broke into specific modules.

This class will be very hard for you if you don't have AP Bio experience. Try your hardest to clear out the rest of your schedule if you've never taken AP, or else the odds are extremely against you. Don't take this class unless you absolutely have to, there are better things to do with your time/effort/tears.
This course is very well run and is definitely interesting since it doesn't focus as much on memorization as people think.
This course will teach you molBio. It isn't all that hard, all that much work, or all that stressful. It is, however, very early.
This is a great class and I would definitely recommend it to anyone interested in the basics of biology.
This is a great course for anyone interested in biology or medicine. It is however a time consuming course but in the long run not that difficult.
This is an interesting course, and I would recommend it if for those interested in genetics and cellular biology. Be prepared for lots of cramming and memorization, though.
To study a little after every lecture.
VERY HARD
While this course was certainly competitive due to the large number of pre-med students taking it, I found the information enjoyable and learned a lot.
Wouldn't recommend it unless you need to take it as a departmental or prerequisite for pre-med.
You really learn the molecular biology in this course.

You will learn a lot and understand a lot of the advancements in medicine in the real world, but it is a difficult class and requires a lot of time and effort.  And even then, you still might not do well because the tests aren't straight forward.
don't take this unless you have to. if you can take MOL Bio elsewhere, do it.
if you like biology, take it, but be prepared - you can't coast.

it's pretty interesting - i like how they split the class at the very end depending on interest. for me, the hardest thing about this class was waking up at 8:30... Gavis' lecture slides are self explanatory so you didn't have to really go to lecture... Notterman's lecture slides are vague, so u actually have to go to class to know what's going on.
keep up with the readings and go to review sessions. Always try to get some help from your TAs
only take this course if you absolutely need to.
stay on top of lectures and memorize them as you go.  very hard to memorize 8 lectures the week of the exam.
take it if you're premed, want more of ap bio
descrip: Important concepts and elements of molecular biology, biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology, are examined in an experimental context. During the last two weeks of the semester, topics-based sections will be taught by different faculty members in the following areas: Neuroscience, proteomics, and human disease. This course fulfills the requirement for students majoring in the biological sciences and satisfies the biology requirement for entrance into medical school.

title: Genius
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Image Processing
reviews: Highly recommended as the instructor was wonderful at presenting the material in a clear and understandable format.
prereqs: ELE 301 or equivalent.
descrip: Introduction to the basic theory and techniques of image processing. Topics include image perception, acquisition, display, enhancement, restoration, compression, transformation, tomography, medical imaging, video coding and content analysis. Applications to HDTV, machine vision, medical imaging, etc.

title: Fourth-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: If you took 3rd year (which you probably did, unless you're switching in from a different school), this class is pretty much just a repeat of last year. Be prepared to spend a lot of time (2-3 hours for several readings) on extensive vocab lists that don't seem to stick. Unfortunately, it's one of the only options if you want to keep up your fluency though.
It doesn't seem like it, but it will improve your Chinese.
Its a good introduction to Chinese literature. Challenging but worthwhile!
You'll be required to constantly attend to the coursework, but the reading toward the end is pretty interesting. Worth taking!
prereqs: CHI 403 or instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of 403. Reading and discussion of scholarly writings in the fields of Chinese literature and modern Chinese intellectual history. A weekly written assignment will be required.

title: Theory and Practice of Arabic to English Translation
prereqs: Minimum of two years of study of Modern Standard Arabic (equivalent to completion of ARA 107), or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course trains students in the practice of translating Arabic texts from a wide variety of genres into English. Attention will be given to both theoretical and practical problems of translation for research and professional ends.

title: Hindu Scriptures
reviews: Do it. It's fun and you'll learn a ton from it.
If you're interested in Hinduism, take it! (It's an EM!)
If you're interested in the origins of Hinduism and comfortable unpacking the complexities of primary sources, this will be a very rewarding course.
It's worth taking -- the readings are fascinating, Prof Gold is incredibly knowledgeable, and you really leave feeling like you've learned something.
Take it! You'll learn a lot!
Take this course its great!
Take this course only if you are interested in academic study of Hindu scriptures. Do not take it if you are looking for a survey course on Hinduism.
This class was very interesting if you want to learn more about Hindu scriptures.  The readings were fun to read.
descrip: This course is an introduction to classic scriptural sources for Hinduism: Vedas, Upanishads, Bhagavad Gita, The Laws of Manu, Mahabharata, and Ramayana. These texts present a complex, interconnected set of stories, rituals, concepts, roles, and philosophies that evolved over two millennia. We will spend most of our time looking closely at source texts (in English translations), dipping occasionally into theoretical work on ritual and myth. We will seek, in Hindu scriptures, their historical contexts, their mirroring and questioning of social structures and norms, and their nuanced, localized expressions of general human yearnings.

title: Advanced French
reviews: 108 is an excellent course! Some of it may feel redundant to 105 but you will learn many more nuances that make your command of French less stilted and more natural. If you get the right teacher (I loved Eloy if he's still teaching, and I hear to avoid Harriet) classes will always be fun, even when you're tired. Make an effort to improve by doing all the coursework and you will see a marked improvement in your French.
Absolutely take this course, and make sure to engage during class!
Come with an open mind, and make sure you do all your work to the best of your ability!

Definitely take the 105-108 sequence if you're interested in becoming a better French speaker.  The class is a very reasonable amount of work and you get a lot out of it.  Make sure you get a good instructor though.
Do everything you can to make sure your instructor is a professor and not an adjunct.
Do not be afraid to speak up in class and ask questions!

FRE 108 is a great course, and I found it to be the right next step after having taken FRE 105.  The format of the class is very similar to FRE 105. If you can, take the course with Professor LaBrada! His class was super popular, and he is a great professor.
For a language class, the workload is relatively light. Some of the readings are dense and boring, but you can get by the course just by skimming them.
Go to all the lectures even though you can miss 3. They are crucial.
Good course, not too much work. Get Eloy if you can he's the best
I would recommend that a student take this course if they want to maintain their French ability. It also can often be very fun way to learn about French culture.
I would strongly recommend against taking French 108 with Professor Jackson.
I'm sorry you won't be able to have Eloy as your professor!
It is great to learn another language and if you are at all interested in French I would recommend this class.
It's a bit more work than I had expected, but it's definitely worth taking over 107 if you want to improve your speaking ability.
Make sure you get a good instructor.
Recommend the class if you're interested in learning French, but do not take the class with Harriet Jackson!
Set aside time to do the readings because this class is a significant step up in difficulty from French 105.
Solid introduction to more advanced French courses.
Spend time on the Quia stuff, it's a great way to incrementally learn the tough parts of French (grammar).
Stay on top of grammar excercises.
Take it - but with another professor.

Take it if you need to fulfill your requirement.  It is fun,, especially if you get placed with a good group of students who like to participate.  If you don't talk in class it will be awkward and you'll hate being put on the spot.

Take it if you want to keep developing your French! Also take it with Eloy if you can.  I had him all year (105 ad 108) and he is amazing!!! There is much more emphasis on reading and understanding than in 105, and it is more challenging than 108.  But if you put the work in, you'll improve your language skills tremendously!  Also talk in class as much as possible - it really helps.
Take it with Eloy
Take it with Eloy but all other professors may not be as good!
Take it, and do everything that it says on the syllabus, and your French will improve dramatically.
Take it.
Take this class! It is not an unreasonable amount of work and take it with Katie Chenoweth!
Take your time when doing the readings because all the discussions and the test are based on them.
The workload isn't that light but class is very fun and your speaking will improve a lot!

This class is a good amount of work - not difficult necessarily but time-consuming. Keep up with the class readings - not only will it save you time preparing for exams, you can get the most out of class time.

This is a great course! Coming from 103 which is pretty much a lot of grammar, this course was very refreshing. Of course you do grammar (review some stuff and learn some new stuff), but the emphasis is on reading, writing, and discussing aspects of French history and culture. This is a great course because it allows you to put your French skills to the test, and the material is really interesting!!!!!
Try to get into Prof. Chenoweth's section.
Try to get the course head as your teacher. They are always more reliable than other teachers. Admittedly, Eloy is fantastic as well.
Work hard, you'll get the improvement you're looking for.
Would be fine with a good instructor.
prereqs: Placement through the University's Placement Test, completion of FRE 105, or permission of the Director of French Language Program..
descrip: FRE 108 is an intermediate advanced course, with a brand new syllabus. We'll take you on a journey through various periods of French history and culture and offer an opportunity to reflect on important questions at the center of controversial debates: national identity, immigration, relationships with the Francophone world and former colonies, the role of the State in the shaping of the nation, etc. We have selected a variety of authentic materials (films, videos, music, newspapers articles and literary texts) and carefully incorporated them into our curriculum so you'll develop your ability to communicate in French.

title: Introduction to the History of Art: Renaissance to Contemporary
reviews: A key part to any Princeton liberal arts education.

ART 101 is a really interesting class to fulfill your LA distribution requirement. It's a lot of fun looking at works of art in class and learning about art in different time periods. You should PDF though in case because the midterm grades were really harsh this year. I also heard they might be changing the format of the class next year.
Attend all the lectures, don't do all the readings. The memorization will seem tedious but overall you will learn a lot. Definitely great things to know coming out of a liberal arts college
Fine as a distribution requirement, but barely skims the surface. If you want to get really in depth into understanding an art movement, pick a different class.
Go to lecture.
Go to lecture. If you pay attention in lecture, chances are you'll do well on exams and papers. Readings are not necessary.

Go to lectures; they're pretty awesome and you get to hear a wide range of art historian voices.  The workload is really light, just a few papers and weekly blackboard posts outside of exams. You don't really have to do all the readings in depth, but you'll probably get more from the course if you do. Have fun, it's a really great overview!
Great PDF for senior year.
Great course to PDF if you have a general interest in the topic, but rather not spend a lot of time memorizing information
I didn't like it.  not a good intro course

I took this course because several people outside of Princeton had told me that they might have majored in art history if they had taken it earlier in their college careers, and I was curious about the field, having had no exposure to it before. I guess I'm happy to have taken this class because I see the world differently and feel that I can actually appreciate art now, but I often found this course frustrating because I felt the readings were often excessive and the exams unfair. I really loved writing the papers for this class, and I've discovered that I really like art history as a discipline and want to take upper-level courses in it, but I'm not 100% sure I would recommend ART 101. Keep in mind that it's hard to get an A, and that even if you do I don't think it's necessarily deserved, since the exams test for arbitrary things in my opinion. (But also keep in mind that the department is changing the course so that it's organized by theme rather than chronology, so it might be better in future semesters.)
I would advise that they always attend lecture and precept.
I would take this course to get an overall feel for art history, but it is not a comprehensive view.

If you are interested in art history, take this course. I would even recommend taking this course over ART 100, as working from the Renaissance forward deals with some really incredible artwork. That said, the material overlaps a good deal with works covered in AP Art History, so if you have background there and do not need to take this course, a more specific/advanced course might be of more interest. However, I didn't find the overlap to be a detriment; as a lot of the actual testing is pure memorization, having encountered the works previously helped reduce a lot of the stress there. This was a fairly easy course.
If you are really interested in the Art field, this is an amazing class to take. If it is just to fulfill and distribution requirement and you do not have general interest, do not take this course.

It's not so much for learning to say something intellectual when you go to an art museum but it's super interesting nevertheless and it's a great way to get an LA out of the way if English isn't your thing.
It's what you expect - a general survey class. Pretty good.
Its a relatively easy course
Make sure to take good lecture notes for the exams.
Make sure you go to all of the lectures. As a BSE student, this course was a nice counterbalance to all the other courses with problem sets. Loved precepts in the art museum!
Start papers early.
Take it - it's a fun taste of art history!
Take it -- great general knowledge!
Take it if you are interested in any sort of art.  The modern art isn't terribly fun but most of the class is spent on real artists anyhow.
Take it if you have no art history background and want a brief overview.  Workload very manageable.
Take it if you have no exposure but want a bit of knowledge about Art History. Easy PDF, hard A.
Take it, but do the readings.
Take this course only if you have a very limited familiarity with art. I would not recommend this course to an intended art history major.

Take this course! It is a great way to get to know one of Princeton's greatest resources: the art museum. Every precept meets inside and getting to engage with art in front of you to complement lecture is awesome. Also a great way to get to know the department. You can tell each professor is passionate about his or her subject matter.

The reading volume is fairly high compared to what I was used to from other classes, but a large portion is due to the textbook, which largely repeats the material in lecture.  Make sure to keep up with the supplementary readings, though, and begin your papers as early as possible so you can meet with your preceptor.

This course is a difficult introductory course, and I would not recommend it. Although subjective, the course grades against a rubric that is not shared with students, making it impossible to know whether or not you are meeting the expectations until after you get back your exams.
This course is enjoyable and the workload is totally manageable.

This was a great distribution requirement to take, as the lecturers were pretty enjoyable, it wasn't too much work, and having precepts in the museum was really interesting.  I didn't really know anything about art history before this class, but I'm glad that I've been exposed to the material in this class.
go to class, write a lot for the exams
it's not hard until the midterm and the final exam
unless you really are into art take it PDF
yes
descrip: An introduction to selected periods and works of art and architecture from the Renaissance to the present as well as an introduction to the discipline of art history. Two lectures, one preceptorial.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Race and Public Policy
reviews: Absolutely take this course. Professor Massey is brilliant, and it is just crazy to learn just a completely different perspective on history you learn your entire life. I loved this class and had such a great experience!
Be super invested in Race and Public Policy to make this worthwhile

DEFINITELY TAKE! This has been one of my favorite classes at Princeton. Has opened my eyes up to the issue and the class is fantastic. You will learn so much. For the final paper pick a topic you are really interested in so you won't hate writing the very long paper. Also, do all the readings- the reading list is fantastic.
Do not be afraid of the difficult end of the year assignments -- this class is absolutely worth it!

Do not take this course if you want to learn more about racial oppression and policy in the U.S. If you're in Woody Woo and need to fulfill a core requirement, this may be less miserable in terms of workload for most of the year than the other courses, like International Relations. The course is very little work for the first 8 weeks, but then you have a 30-page paper and a very hard final.
Doing well on the exams is a simple matter of coving the lectures, but make sure you get on a paper topic early; don't let Dean's Date ambush you.
I really loved it! It's a lot of reading, but I thought it was totally worth it. No one else is teaching this kind of material.
If possible, I would consider taking this course in the first semester. Since the only writing assignment is a 20 page paper it would help to have those three weeks of winter break to help.
Take something else if you can.
Take this course if you are interested in racial policy in American history. The 25 paper at the end is a lot. However, the rest of the class is pretty chill and the tests are straightforward.
The paper is not to be trifled with
This class is excellent, but be prepared for the final 20 page paper AND the final; it eats up your reading period time.

This is mostly a history course about African Americans in the U.S.  We learn a little bit about racism in other countries as part of the introduction, but it is a very specific subject and you are tested on dates and historical events.  It seems like it may be the most interesting of the sociology departmentals but I wouldn't suggest taking it if you don't have to.

This is the best class I've ever taken at Princeton. Professor Massey is so knowledgeable and each lecture was not only engaging but also mind blowing. Every single student at Princeton (and in the country) NEEDS to take this class. Also, don't buy the books. Not necessary. Do not be deterred because of the 25-30 page paper - it's daunting but totally doable. I did it junior year with a JP and it's manageable - so worth it!
descrip: Analyzes the historical construction of race as a concept in American society, how and why this concept was institutionalized publicly and privately in various arenas of U.S. public life at different historical junctures, and the progress that has been made in dismantling racialized institutions since the civil rights era.

title: Autobiography and Identity
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Managing the Transition to a Clean Energy Economy: Renewable Power in the US
reviews: I would highly recommend the course for anyone who is interested in this industrial sector.
If Schwartz is there, take the course.

It depends whether you want a class that is theoretical like many offered in Princeton or if you want a class that discusses practical issues.  If you are interested in the latter, I recommend you take this course.
Take it!

This course is worth it just for the guest speakers alone.  He brings in many, many industry experts to co-lecture.  These guest speakers are energy industry Presidents, CEOs, etc.  His ability to bring in these experts tells you his knowledge and reputation in the energy industry!

This course provides a very useful perspective in the energy-environment space in that it draws upon Prof. Schwartz's extensive private sector experience. As mentioned above, the course was at times disorganized, but I feel that the material made it worth it to anyone interested in issues of clean energy.
Worth taking if offered again
descrip: This course is designed to provide students with an understanding of the structure of US energy markets and how renewable power integrates into this market and explores the underlying technology, policy and commercial dynamic that will shape the industry for the next decade. The goal of course is to use this knowledge base to identify new policy constructs or revisions to existing policies that have the potential for driving sustainable investment and thereby realizing the potential of renewable power to transform the US power sector.

title: Race and Medicine
reviews: Don't take this class.
Good for anyone interested in medicine, even non pre-meds.

Take it if you're interested in public health, race, medicine, good discussions in a small seminar class.  I learned so much, and this course changed the way I view life and health and communities and people.  I plan on going into public health, so this class was very good in that it helped me shape my interests better.  I also became more self-aware of how I perceived other people.
Take it! Keep up with readings, try and leave behind preconceived notions about the topic, because you will get schooled.
Take this class if you are interested in medicine and inequalities in medical treatment.
Take this course!
The class is as interesting as you make it
This course was pretty interesting and low-key. Super accessible, even for people who have not taken an anthropology course before. Great class for senior spring!
descrip: In 1998, then-President Clinton set a national goal that by the year 2010 race, ethnic, and gender disparities in six disease categories would be eliminated. While the agenda, called Healthy People 2010, was a noble effort, many of the goals were not met. This course examines what went wrong. For a final project, students will be asked to propose their own solutions for eliminating health disparities.

title: Pre-Columbian Peoples of Tropical America and Their Environments
reviews: Be prepared to be confused during the second half of the course if Dr. Cooke is teaching. Pay attention to lectures and review your notes for the exam.
Great course! Wonderful to be able to learn about Panamanian culture.
I liked the other courses in Panama more than this one, but it's definitely worth coming to Panama anyway.
I strongly recommend taking one of the field semesters to all EEB majors.  Course was an interesting intro to archaeology/anthropology field research
Worth Taking.
it's funnn! just ask cooke a ton of questions so you know what on earth he's talking about.
prereqs: Prerequisites: 211, and 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring Semester in tropical ecology program in Panama..
descrip: The pre-European history of Amerind cultures and their associated environments in the New World tropics will be studied. Topics to be covered include the peopling of tropical America; development of hunting/gathering and agricultural economies; neotropical climate and vegetation history; and the art, symbolism, and social organization of native Americans. Field and laboratory experiences will incorporate methods and problems in field archaeology, paleoenthnobotany and paleoecology, and archaeozoology.

title: Roberto Bolano: Adventures in Cultureland
reviews: Bolano's work is amazing, and this is a good way to go through it.  Make sure to participate in discussion, though, or the seminar will go painfully slowly.
Definitely take this course if you want to improve your ability to read/write in Spanish while exploring the Hispanic literary world
Susana is great, take it.
Too long. Avoid it unless you like Bola?o.
prereqs: At least one LA distribution area course in Spanish.
descrip: Forty years after the emergence of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the narrative works of the Chilean Roberto Bolano have once again put Latin American literature at the center of the world's cultural mainstream. Quiet poet, public storyteller, and heir of Borges' most intricate speculations and the beatniks' nomadism, Bolano broke with the recipes of magical realism and opened a fresh literary horizon by combining anti-intellecutal vitalism and erudite conceptualism. This course explores the artistic strategies of an author who made Jim Morrison dialogue with James Joyce, and went from being an anonymous eccentric to a New York Times bestseller.

title: Introduction to Metaphysics and Epistemology
reviews: A lot more work than you've probably heard it is. Go to lectures because the readings are very hard to follow. Don't take this class unless absolutely necessary though. Dasgupta is a fun, interesting professor but that's about the only plus.
A perfect class to balance in whatever else you are taking
A very accessible and interesting introduction to philosophy. A great EC departmental if you're still looking for one, especially if you can pdf it.
An excellent course. Prof. Dasgupta is a phenomenal lecturer, the readings are fascinating, and the material is profound.
Attend every lecture and take notes.
Attend lectures because they are interesting. Put in extra effort to figure out how to write the papers. Nice class to get a taste for philosophy.
Definitely take this course if you haven't done any philosophy before. The course load is manageable and as long as you attend lectures the assignments and exams are very doable.
Definitely take this if you are interested in philosophy, or if you just need to fill a requirement. It is very interesting and is not very demanding.
Do take it!!!
Do the readings and come to lecture. The readings are interesting, and Shamik's lectures are extremely clear.
Do the readings so that precept isn't so darn awkward.
Don't take it. It is boring and I don't feel like I learned anything. Take if you want a guaranteed P, but still too many assignments.
Go to every lecture and ACTIVELY read every reading.
Go to lecture
Go to lecture and takes notes because it definitely helps you understand what was going on in the readings
Go to precept and lecture, give yourself time to finish levels assignments
Good intro to philosophy
Highly recommend this class! Not too much work and it will expose you to a lot of important topics in philosophy.

I absolutely loved the class and might want to major in philosophy because of it. The lectures were great, the readings were interesting, the precepts (with Professor Dasgupta) were thought-provoking, and the assignments taught me to think and write philosophically at a good pace, especially as someone with no prior exposure to philosophy. Take it!!
I quickly found out philosophy wasn't something I was interested in, but I was PDFing it so the work was completely manageable.
I would definitely recommend this course.

I would highly recommend this course. I think that every student should take a philosophy course before graduating at Princeton, and this course is interesting, engaging, and not too heavy of a workload. You will have the opportunity to grapple with issues you may never have previously thought about, which is always great. Also, Professor Dasgupta's lectures are fantastic.
I would really recommend this as a fifth course. Philosophical background is not required.
I would say that you should be prepared to explore a wide variety of philosophical concepts and be intellectually stimulated in a way that you may not have been stimulated before.
If at all interested, go for it

If you are interested in philosophy, I would recommend this as a great intro class. The subject material is fascinating and the lectures are worth attending. The Levels System is good for first time philosophy students and builds up to the final assignment. Not necessarily an easy class but definitely a lighter workload.
If you want a super interesting philosophy course, this might not be your best bet. Still, it's not bad and worthy of the fact that you need an EC.
Interrogate the preceptors about the requirements for the assignments. Do the readings and attend lecture. Talk to the professor after class in order to have a real discussion.

Philosophy, as it turns out, can be absolutely fascinating. This was one of my favorite classes at Princeton. Shamik Dasgupta is a truly outstanding professor, quite possibly the best I have had here at Princeton. Philosophy is sometimes tricky, and some of the readings were difficult to grasp at first, but when he taught them he made them all make so much more sense. He has an amazing way of getting at and conveying the core of the material. I was nervous about taking this class because I didn't know if I'd really like philosophy, but Prof. Dasgupta made it seem fascinating and fun to engage with.
Pretty solid; philosophy majors should take this fairly early.
Take as much advantage of this course as you possibly can, the professor and the preceptors are very helpful.
Take it even if you have no exposure to philosophy
Take it, it will be hard and challenge how you begin to understand a mental problem.
Take it.  It's awesome!
Take it.  The homework isn't too demanding and it feels very rewarding
Take the course. It requires work, but it is an interesting class.
Take this class, especially with Professor Dasgupta.
Take this course because its not overtly challenging, and incredibly interesting. I am very happy that I have taken a philosophy course at Princeton.
Take this course if you're interested in the bigger questions in life.  Don't expect the class to give you answers though.  All it does it make you think for yourself.

The material is very abstract - it's something you either really like or really dislike. Be prepared for lots of philosophical questions and discussions with no set conclusions, but very interesting material. Good way to fill a distribution requirement. The professor is very engaging and brings abstract and complicated ideas down to an understandable, intuitive level.

This is an excellent course that has fascinating material about very important questions that all ought to seriously contemplate such as the existence of God, the way we know things, who we are, whether there is more than just material to our beings, and whether we are free and responsible. Professor Dasgupta is a very clear and engaging instructor and you will do well to go to his lectures.

This was one of my favorite courses at Princeton. Although the topics are difficult at times, I can think of no better philosophy intro course than this. The levels system (for papers) caters to new philosophy students and is a godsend.
USE THIS COURSE TO FULFILL EC!
Write your levels assignments very carefully.
You get out of it what you put in
definitly makes you look at the world a different way.
descrip: An introduction to central questions in philosophy, including: (1) Why is there something rather than nothing? Why do we exist? In particular, is there a scientific explanation of our existence? (2) How can we know anything about the external world? (3) Is there a ready-made world out there for us to know about? (4) What, most fundamentally, am I? My body? My mind? Something else? (5) What is the relation between one's body and one's mind? (6) Are we free to act as we choose or are our actions determined by factors beyond our control, like the laws of physics?

title: American Political Institutions
descrip: This seminar is part of the two-course sequence of the core curriculum in American politics and provides an introductory survey of American political institutions. Provides an overview of the various problems for which institutional solutions are sought (e.g., problems involving collective action, delegation, and social choice) as well as a detailed assessment of some of the scholarly literature that investigates political institutions.

title: God of Many Faces: Comparative Perspectives on Migration and Religion
reviews: Definitely take it!!!!
Do the readings
Do the readings!
Good course take it!
It's easy but you don't learn much. She often takes attendance in lectures.

Make sure to do the readings and listen avidly in precept. This course covers the broad range of religion in migration, and you will enjoy the course if you attend lectures and precepts and see the teachers if you need additional help.

PFK has a very passionate and compelling lecture style, but it seems like she is not really dedicated to the class. The entire class was not very well structured, and because of this, the precept discussions were usually not fruitful. I learned much about different phenomena of religion and migration, but I still don't understand what the thesis of this course was. Good course to PDF, sit in lectures, and hear about a bunch of random things.
PFK's teaching style is not for everyone, but precepts can make the class worthwhile.
Stay in the loop with your preceptor.
TAKE THIS COURSE! You will learn so much
Take if want to learn more about religion and immigration
Take it if a soc major or just interested in other religions! More intriguing than difficult!
Take it if you want a class that won't overwhelm you with work, but that is interesting and probably quite different from other things you'll be exposed to in Princeton University courses.
Take it!
Take it.
Take this class
Take this class, you will learn a lot but make sure you are willing to really put in work to gain from the class.
Take this.

This class was perfect as a distribution requirement! The work load was pretty light, but at the same time, the course wasn't a joke. The material was incredibly interesting, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. PFK is also incredible- take the time to get to know her outside of class, and sit up front so she knows you! One of my favorite courses at Princeton.

This course was disappointing. The material is interesting, and it seems a tempting course to take P/D/F, as I did. However, the lectures are so disorganized and hard to follow that it would take far more dedication and focus than I had to be able to take a lot from them.

This is a thought provoking and chill course. Attend lectures because they're actually quite interesting, but also because she randomly takes attendance. Try to do the readings because they're interesting and not too long, but if you fall behind, it's nothing to stress over. Also do CBLI if it is offered again, you won't regret it!
Yes, it's a great informative course with a reasonable course load that will have you thinking and wanting more by the end.
take it
this is an easy course to take, dont expect to learn much because the lectures are off topic and unrelated, but it is definitely a course that you wont have to stress about
waste of a course
descrip: Immigrants often experience discrimination in areas of destination. Religion can strengthen their sense of worth, particularly when the circumstances surrounding departure from the country of origin are traumatic, as with exiles and refugees. We take a comparative approach and use examples from the United States, Asia, Europe, and Latin America. The course broaches questions such as: how does religion transform (and how is it transformed by) the immigrant experience? When is religion used to combat stereotypes? Are there differences between the way men and women or dominant groups and racial minorities understand religion?

title: Special Topics in Statistics and Operations Research - Optimization Seminar
descrip: Algorithms for approximate dynamic programming/reinforcement learning come in a number of styles. This seminar will survey the literature on the theory supporting the convergence of different algorithms on different classes of problems drawing from computer science, engineering, economics and operations research. Each week will consist of a presentation by one of the students that offers a convergence proof for a particular algorithm/problem class.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Social Entrepreneurship for Policymakers
descrip: Over the last 20 years, the emerging field of social entrepreneurship has taken new approaches to problems in education, waste management and global public health. This course focuses on types and stages of different social enterprises (non-profits/hybrid organizations/for-profits), will evaluate nature of capital available from grants to patient capital to market-return investments. Course seeks to equip students with a framework for understanding how: 1) social enterprise can complement traditional provision of public services and 2) new markets are being created that deliver clear social benefits while generating returns to investors.

title: The Brain: A User's Guide
reviews: A little worried since you can't PDF the course, but everyone is taking it out of interest instead of credit so people are pretty passionate about the topic/course.
Although Professor Jacobs says not to pay attention to specifics, DO! The midterm covered a lot of specific information from the book.

Barry will tell you that the lecture provides the level of detail that you need to do well on the test. The textbook is much more detailed. Still, you SHOULD read the textbook. You wont do well if you dont.
Definitely take it if interested in neuroscience- however, if you're pursuing the neuroscience certificate it would most likely be better to take a more advanced course.
Definitely take it!
Good class if interested in brain psych, but watch out for tough in-class quizzes and exams

I hated this class. The content was super interesting and the lectures were really good, but I felt very strongly about the exams and the grading that it ruined the whole course for me. I wouldn't consider it introductory, you should have taken another Princeton psych class, not just AP Psych. I can't even tell you how to prepare for the exam because it was so hit or miss.
I highly recommend this course, it is by far the best and most interesting course I have taken at Princeton.
If having to take a neuroscience course I recommend it, but just be prepared that the exams are extremely specific. Pay attention in lecture and read the textbook
Importance of the textbook cannot be stressed enough, decent departmental requirement for those less neuro savvy
Its more difficult than advertised but still worthwhile
Precepts with Michelle are great.  Course is a bit more difficult than expected.  If you have a real interest go for it, otherwise steer clear.
Study for the quizzes even though he says you don't have to. They are tough!
Take as an easy 6th class.
Take it!
The course proved to be quite interesting - take it if you are genuinely interested in the workings of the brain.

The good news is it's fine. The bad news is that it's fine. The material is fairly interesting (especially the precept readings -- definitely do those for pleasure), and Jacobs is a decent lecturer. But the way he runs his class is extremely frustrating. The weekly quizzes feel like high school and make me think he doesn't have confidence that we'd pay attention without them. The weekly precept grades are just silly. And as others have said over and over, he'll tell you all semester long, "Just learn critical concepts. You don't need to know the details." This is simply a lie. The exams are just a series of "which details can you remember" questions, which makes the class pretty frustrating. If you learn details well, take the class. Otherwise, you're going to be pretty frustrated by how misled you are all semester long.
The workload is very minimal; as long as you prepare adequately for tests then you will be fine. There are weekly quizzes, but as long as you go to lecture they are a breeze.
This class is very disorganized and nothing you can do will prepare you for everything that shows up on the exam. Don't take it if you can avoid it, there must be better neuro classes
take this course if you are interested in neuro but don't want to take NEU258
descrip: The course provides a basic introduction to neuroscience, especially as it impacts upon practical issues: mental disease, drugs, neurological disorders, development, learning, memory, etc. It is intended for students who are not planning to concentrate in the life sciences. It is hoped that some students may get stimulated by this course and decide to concentrate in aspects of psychology, biology, philosophy, or engineering as they relate to mind and brain.

title: Growing Up Global: Novels and Memoirs of Transnational Childhoods
reviews:
-Lectures can be boring depending on your interests, and she'll take attendance and penalize you if she sees you on your phone!
-That being said, this is a relatively light course. I was not able to keep up with all the readings, though, but you can still survive with a good grade.
-Great for an EC!
100% take it!!! It will change your life and your Princeton experience.

Absolutely take the course! It was well worth it. Not difficult at all, but it fosters much more introspection than Princeton courses usually do. Sometimes the precept ended up feeling like a support group, and you really get to know other Princeton students in a different light.

Attend every lecture and precept (it affects your grade heavily). Do the readings, they're not very difficult intellectually and are pretty interesting. Have fun with the creative portions! Go to office hours if you need help with formulating arguments, but make sure you have some sort of idea or topic to work with first.
Attendance is important. Do not wait until the last minute to start readings, papers, or your creative narrative. Meet with Professor Belcher or your preceptor.
Be prepared for a lot of reading about the same material, but fun writing assignments.

Chill class. The reading is readable (interesting.) For those non-ABs that are apprehensive about having to write, this class is safe. There are 2 papers (5pgs) and a memoir (10). They give you feedback, and then you can write them again. How nice, yeah? Precept is really interesting (when someone is presenting their memoir). It's fun to hear about other people's lives/experiences on earth. You don't have to be trans-national to take the class. You can take it if you just feel like you don't fit in the world.
Class attendance is an absolute must, but are largely a formality.  Be active in precept and take pride in writing the papers (especially your creative memoir), and you will do well in the course.
Definitely do all of the readings, they are very interesting.
Definitely recommend to anyone wishing to reflect on their transnational experiences or looking for an easy but interesting EM
Definitely take it. Awesome course.

Definitely take the course. It is fun, the readings are great, and you actually look forward to going to classes. Use the chance to rewrite your papers. As long as you do this and don't skip classes, you're sure to come away with a good grade.
Definitely take this class if you are a transnational person, living between borders. The books that you get to read are great - doesn't feel like classwork but more like reading a book for fun.
Definitely take this class, and do all readings
Definitely take this course! Great readings, great preceptors, fun discussions!

Do it if you are very interested in the topic of a global identity. You will have some useful conversations that will apply to you in a way that goes beyond the classroom. At the same time, be prepared to not feel connected to every aspect of the course.
Do the readings and go to lecture.
Do your second drafts of papers, complete the reading and participate in class. It's pretty straightforward
Don't take this course. If you do, just keep up with the readings.
Easy class, engaging readings. You might need some sort of transnational identity crisis in order to write the creative narrative. I didn't leave the class feeling like I learned much though.
Get Aia as your preceptor!
Get help on papers and participate in precept. Also, go to lectures because they're very strict about attendance!
Good course. Creative wriitng component is fun. It's also great to be in a class with a lot of people with multinational backgrounds.

Great class and perhaps the easiest EM. The workload includes easy weekly readings (the reading list is amazing, and if you have a ton of work one week, it's not completely necessary to do the reading if you're not writing a paper that week) and optional weekly viewing, two papers on two of the weekly readings that you select in precept at the start of the course, and a creative memoir for the final due on Dean's Date. No midterm or exams. Overall, very manageable. The class is probably the most racially colorful at Princeton (see the title and listing of the course), so you get to meet a lot of diverse, cool people. Even if you do not think of yourself as transnational, you will learn and contribute to the class and perhaps find that the definition of transnational is broader than you think. Lectures are not good, but note of warning: Prof. Belcher takes lecture attendance seriously. Precepts are wonderful. Taylor Eggan is a wonderful preceptor, but most of them seem to be great, as well. I'd highly recommend this class to people looking for an easy EM and everyone else, too.
Great course to take! Writing the memoir is fun and the papers are not too strenuous.

Hands down the easiest class I've taken at Princeton. Really enjoyable-- the readings are great. Pretty optional, but it's a good idea to read them so you can participate in precept. Assignments are really interesting. Belcher is a great lecturer, though she can be incredibly biased at times.

I took this course for the reading list, and it was worth it. Note that attendance is very important - don't think that because it's a large class you can skip. Professor Belcher will notice and it will affect your grade. Overall I enjoyed the class and the final assignment was fun to work on. Try to get Taylor Eggan as a preceptor if you can!
I would definitely recommend this class to everyone. Very interesting and very insightful.

I would recommend only if you are looking for an easy EM. I often found myself dreading lecture and feeling like I was wasting my time, but only went because they take attendance. It got better when I realized I could do work for other classes in lecture. There are far better classes out there. Precepts were equally boring.
I would take this, but beware that the critical papers become annoying. Good PDF
I would tell them that they should read the assigned reading before the first lecture so they don't get spoilers.
I wouldn't recommend it unless the structure is changed to two precepts and one lecture. Then I would say to consider it if you need an EM, but still not a ringing endorsement.
If you do what you're supposed to do, you will get an A. Don't bother reading everything - it might seem impossible at times. Show up to lecture. Low work load.

If you want an easy class, you should take it. Be warned though there are no computers allowed and Belcher is very strict about attendance. If the class changes to be a seminar style, I encourage people to take it because the book list is great and so is the premise. However, if you want to learn anything at all and not just fulfill a requirement, I would suggest finding another EM

Interesting, engaging readings-- you also don't have a midterm or a final. 2 critical papers and 1 personal narrative-- the perfect class for senior spring! Lectures are a little annoying because you have to go and listen to her talk about concepts that are pretty irrelevant to your overall class experience but I would strongly suggest going because they take attendance pretty seriously.
It's a good way to get the EM if you want to do something literary. Not a hard class, just attend lectures.
It's a great class! Take it if you are interested in the topic.
It's a great way to meet other transnational students, but the course itself is pretty fluffy.

It's a very easy course, but I don't think I've ever disliked a teacher as much as Wendy Belcher. She's not malicious, but I have no respect for her. A girl had a seizure in class, and the only thing she said was she wished she could get a teaching moment out of it. She is just one of the most unprofessional professors I have ever encountered. 

Take the class because it's easy, but it's not going to blow your mind about being transnational.
It's cool. Keep up with it and you'll be fine.
It's easy. Just do your readings, especially when you have to write an essay (only 2 per semester, plus a dean's date assignment).

Meet with your professor/preceptor to chat about the readings, papers, etc. Attending lectures would really not be necessary if attendance weren't taken, but do all of the readings and think about your creative memoir early on!
READ THE BOOKS they're all genuinely worth reading for your own sake, if not for the class itself.
TAKE IT if you're looking for an easy EM. Best EM out there.

TAKE IT! Make sure you can relate to the subject of feeling "in between," though. It doesn't have to be in between cultures necessarily, but that would help. If you think you can write a memoir about your in betweenness and are interested in learning more about transcultural people, this is a great class. It's a lot of fun, and really chill as well.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!!!
TAKE THIS COURSE.
Take it - great readings for the most part, very manageable workload. Attendance mandatory.
Take it for an EM, you won't regret it!

Take it if you can! It has been one of my most enjoyable classes at Princeton. Go to class...she takes attendance through small class assignments.
