If you feel you are in between two or more cultures, backgrounds etc, you should definitely take this class. This will probably one of the most fun midterm/final you will take at Princeton.
Take it!
Take it! Lectures are awful but overall it's worth it.

Take it! This class is a great chance to examine the global influences in your life and write about it. All of the readings are interesting and varied, so there is no chance to get bored halfway through the semester. The final writing assignment (writing a memoir)  is also a great stress reliever during Dean's Date.
Take it, easiest A.

Take it, especially if you are an international students or had a transnational background. Ask yourself if there is something "in-between" about your cultural upbringing, and if the answer is yes, take it.

Take the class if you want to get better at writing papers!! Try to get the professor as your preceptor or make sure you like that preceptor. It's got the feeling of both a lecture and a seminar so it's pretty unique. Readings are also fantastic.
Take the course! It's fun and pretty laid back but you'll get to read some very interesting stories! It's also a time for unexpected self reflection. Ask for Jill as a preceptor!
Take this class for the readings, not for the lectures.

Take this class or you will regret not doing so! It is one of my favorite classes ever. I learned so much about myself and the world around me. The final project is great for coming to terms with life in general.
Take this class! If you're interested in what it's like to live in different countries, speak different language, and be different, this is the class for you.
Take this class! It is an easy EM and you get to meet so many interesting students you probably wouldn't have met otherwise.
Take this class!!!
Take this course! Space out the reading so that you are able to finish the readings and don't be afraid to explore more about yourself.
Take this course, especially if you want to learn more about yourself in serious self-reflective writing.
The readings are very interesting and the course is pretty fun. If they're offered, take advantage of re-writes! They're very helpful for improving your writing (and your grade).

This class is actually low-stress. It helps if you schedule your papers beforehand so they don't conflict with other assignments. One thing is that the class is very "close." Even during lectures, we are encouraged to talk with other students about our personal experiences relating to culture, etc. If you are averse to group work or discussing race/culture (if that is a sensitive topic for you), you probably shouldn't take the class.

This class is so easy. The grading is super lenient and you never have to read anything for precept. At the same time the lectures are some of the most unprofessional biased things i have attended on campus. But, its super easy.
This class is super interesting and intriguing. It makes you question what it means to be multicultural and helps you work through your own story.
This course is not a lot of work, but if you want to get anything out of it, you should do the readings and try to participate.
This course is the kind you would want to take in a liberal arts education.  It allows you to learn about yourself and others from different backgrounds.
This course requires individual interest in the topic- make sure you're actually interested in learning about yourself or individuals who are transnational (or have an interest in people in general).

This course was the a complete and utter joke. I learned nothing. Some choice quotes from lecture to show you how much of a joke this was: "let's read this passage four-five times and I want you to 'notice what you notice'." "Let's listen to this clip of a man speaking in a foreign language and I want you to tell me how it makes you feel." Literally I learned deeper stuff in my ninth grade English class. Don't take this. Unless you want an A. In which case, this is perfect for you.
This is a good course! The demands of the quality of writing might seem rather intimidating, but the instructors are always there to work with you. And the topics we covered were quite interesting.

This is a great course, especially if you have transnational background. It made me learn a lot about myself as well as my peers. If you want a class where readings are fun and that focuses on self-exploration, this is definitely a class for you.

This is a really good EM course if you like reading stories.  The memoirs we read are all wonderful and engaging.  The work is not bad at all.  But it's important to get a good preceptor because I think the grading among different preceptors is pretty varied.

This is an amazing course. It will take you around the world and give you an amazing perspective about what it means to be a global student. The reading list is great and you can tell how much passion Professor Belcher puts in the class.
This is an easy and fun way to fulfill your EM requirement. The readings are engaging and entertaining.
Unfortunately lecture attendance  is mandatory but otherwise it's a great PDF and EM.
Very easy class. And the creative narrative is a fun paper to write. It was my favorite paper I've written at Princeton
You should absolutely take this course if you've ever felt dislocated. There are lots of thought-provoking readings, and the writing task is amazing!

You'll particularly enjoy this class if you have a transnational/transcultural background; I know many of its ideas and readings resonated deeply with my own experiences. Reading for this class was basically a chance to pleasure-read each week. The creative narrative assignment (it's your mid-term and final) was really special. Professor Belcher is slightly crazy about lecture attendance and attention, so go and enjoy them. Grading was surprisingly harsh on the first round of critical papers, but you get to do re-writes, and if you try hard and talk to your preceptor, you should be fine. Fun, light class, also a really easy way to do your EM!
for students who want THE WORLD's EASIEST A, this is the perfect class. otherwise, you will not get anything out of it, I promise!
take it but go to lecture for attendance purposes, it's part of your grade
take it!  every student should take this class - you learn a lot about yourself and gain some invaluable perspectives
descrip: What if you grew up with a passport from one country, a face from another continent, an accent from yet another, and live somewhere related to none of them? What if the real answer to the question "Where are you from?" or "Where did you grow up?" is so complicated that you tend to give a convenient rather than honest answer? In this course, we will explore narratives of youthful cultural and linguistic adaptation by those who have spent their childhood crossing national boundaries. Among the topics of discussion will be how the narrators construct meaningful identities and produce a sense of belonging or alienation through narrative.

title: Topics in Organic Chemistry - Organic Chemistry and Catalysis
reviews: Do not take this class.
If possible: audit this course rather than enroll in it. Some of the material is helpful, but the amount of work is not worth it.
Sit back and enjoy the ride. Hold on tight, the fun will make it pass by in the blink of an eye.
Take notes.

This was the worst class I have ever taken. Even if you love organometallic chemistry you will find yourself constantly frustrated by the obtuseness of the evaluation and general poor quality of the lectures. The one saving grace is the guest industrial speakers (two lectures in the term) but one can simply sit in on these without taking the course. I would not recommend this course to anyone without a major overhaul.
Very similar to other organometallics courses here, but more of a lit survey approach.
take it. youll learn a lot, and then youll learn a lot about hartwig.
descrip: An in-depth discussion of transition metal-catalyzed reactions commonly used in modern organic synthesis (e.g. cross coupling, olefin metathesis, asymmetric hydrogenation, etc.). Emphasis is placed on the topic of selectivity (chemo-, regio-, and stereo-) and its mechanistic basis. The historical development, scope, and limitations of the methods are discussed. A prior course in organometallic chemistry (CHM 521) is recommended.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - The Aztecs: An Introduction
prereqs: The course will be taught in English..
descrip: An introduction to Aztec Civilization before and after the Conquest. Topics to be explored include mestizaje, transculturation, and the destiny of these people in a globalized world (the Iberian Empire extended from Africa to Asia). Special focus on images and visual culture.

title: Community-Based Performance
prereqs: Enrollment in this course is by permission of the instructor. Please email Professor Erica Nagel to state your interest in the course at: enagel@mccarter.org.
descrip: This hands-on seminar will explore contemporary theories and practices of community-based performance, investigating contemporary theatre, dance, and music groups that use these methods. The course will also interrogate the sometimes fraught politics of community-based performance, including questions of authorship, authority, authenticity, and artistry. Offered in partnership with the Community-Based Learning Initiative, this course will offer hands-on experience in the process of creating community-based performance projects, and facilitate opportunities to build artistic relationships with local community organizations.

title: Macroeconomic Analysis (Advanced)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Course offers a broad treatment of macroeconomic theory and policy issues, using the formal methods of modern macroeconomics. Topics will include long-run growth and development, labor, consumption, savings and investment decisions, the role of expectations, short-run fluctuations and stabilization policy, inflation and unemployment, trade and exchange rates. The course is advanced, so that: (i) having had some introductory course in macroeconomics is a prerequisite, and an intermediate-level one is best; (ii) the course requires a solid command of microeconomic theory (511 c or d) and good comfort with algebra and calculus.

title: Introduction to Mathematical Physics
descrip: An introduction to mathematically rigorous methods in physics. Topics to be covered include classical and quantum statistical mechanic, quantum many-body problem, group theory, Schroedinger operators, and quantum information theory.

title: Philosophy of Law
prereqs: Open to grad students and qualified undergrads (with permission)..
descrip: A systematic study of the salient features of legal systems, standards of legal reasoning, and the relation between law and morals.

title: Independent Work
descrip: Student selects subject and advisor - defines problem to be studied and proposes work plan. A list of possible subjects of particular interest to faculty and staff members is provided. Written report and poster session at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339 Fall Term project; 340 Spring Term project.

title: From Molecules to Systems to Behavior
reviews: I recommend the course.
Take it, especially for the RL, DDM, and backprop assignments - very helpful and well made units.
prereqs: Successful completion of NEU 501 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: A survey of modern neuroscience in lecture format combining theoretical, experimental, and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include systems and cognitive neuroscience, perception and attention, learning and behavior, memory, executive function/decision-making, motor control and sequential actions. Diseases of the nervous system are considered. This is one-half of a double-credit core course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: Colonial Latin America to 1810
descrip: An introduction to the scholarship on Latin America's colonial past, ranging from "central" areas in Mexico and the Andes to "marginal" regions. New concepts and topics have emgerged. What are these new trends and what do they mean? Why do some types of questions now seem more urgent than others? To explore these questions and find out what problems of past historiographical traditions remain unsolved and deserve a new look, both classic texts and more recent works that display new approaches will be read, often in counterpoint.

title: International Trade II
descrip: A continuation of ECO 551, with emphasis on current research issues. Topics vary from year to year.

title: France Today: Culture, Politics, and Society
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of work, plenty of readings and preparation for class!  You will not be allowed to sit back during this class, Professor Sagnier likes to encourage debate and discussion.  You will learn a lot.

Definitely take this course if you are interested in learning more about French society. If you put time and efforts into learning the vocabulary and paying attention to the skill-building exercises in class, your language skills will improve immensely.
Do the readings and come prepared.
Hands down best class I've ever taken at Princeton. Sagnier is a French god among men. Seriously, I love her. Take this course!!
I really enjoyed this course.  It was quite a bit of work because there was some homework for each class meeting, but it was well worth it.
I would reccomend this course to anyone serious about improving their French and who doesn't mind nit-picky corrections to grammar in writings (it will help you lots) and who is willing to discuss.
I would take this course if you want to get better at French or if you are curious to learn more about France.

Sagnier is great and this course provides an interesting historical and contemporary view of France. If you're interested in improving your French skills, definitely take this course or any course with Sagnier!

possibly the best class in the French department. Small but steady dose of work. 1.5 hours for each class I'd say, with some short papers interspersed. You will need to keep up with the work and prepare/bring energy to each class, it's all about discussion. Professor Sagnier is a wonderful teacher (many profs don't care about teaching...she is the opposite, master teacher). All the other FRE courses above 207 (other than 211, 311, and 307) are on really boring abstract stuff like 12th century poetry, this class is not. It's legit, practical, and great for your written and spoken French.
prereqs: FRE 108 or equivalent; FRE 207 recommended..
descrip: This course is designed to develop students' linguistic skills and broaden their knowledge of contemporary French society. Discussions and essays will cover a wide range of topics drawn from economic, political, social and cultural aspects of France and the francophone world. Current affairs will be discussed in class on a regular basis. The course will provide intensive language practice and students will improve their communication skills by completing a research project, to be presented orally and in writing, on a topic of their choice. Course material include readings, videos, films, francophone television and web-based activities.

title: Senior Project
descrip: Students conduct a one-semester project. Topics chosen by students with approval of the faculty. A written report is required at the end of the term.

title: Topics in Analysis - Nonlinear PDE
prereqs: Undergraduates require permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course addresses questions of existence of strong and weak solutions for nonlinear evolutionary PDE including Euler, Navier-Stokes, SQG and related models. Weak-strong uniqueness and regularity theory are covered. Methods include Littlewood-Paley decomposition, Bony paraproduct, as well as de Giorgi local iteration. Singular limits, long time dynamics and statistical solutions are also discussed.

title: Readings in Classical Arabic Literature
descrip: Topics vary according to students' interest. Some possible topics: poety, narrative prose, "adab."

title: Global History: The Modern Middle East
descrip: Although the Middle East is often seen as exceptional, it is part of our globe: through connections and in being part of worldwide processes. This seminar's double goal is to study the Middle East from this perspective, and thereby also to explore how the modern world emerged. We will use Irye, Osterhammel, and Rosenberg, ed., A History of the World, 2 vols., covering 1870 to the present, as the backbone of the course; and in parallel read case studies on the Middle East in the world, including global cultural patterns, social webs, economic ties, imperial action, state building and international system, and the spread of political ideas.

title: Religion and Law
reviews: Definitely take it if you have any interest in the topic. Interesting material and fantastic professor who makes the material even more interesting than it would otherwise be.
I would advise another student taking this course to make sure that they thoroughly read the assigned readings so that they can fully participate in the seminar discussions.
If you have any interests in this subject matter ....this class is for you. It will expose you to a lot of varied and interesting material. Also, Professor Kaye is awesome!
Prof Kaye is wonderful, but it depends a lot on the class dynamic.

Professor Kaye is leaving, so I don't know who will be teaching this course, but the material is super interesting and incredibly relevant to anyone, because any place you live or come from will have some interplay of religion and law that affects your life.
This course is incredible if you are willing to do the readings. You will learn a lot. Absolutely take it.
This course will greatly help you think about issues of law and religion from historical and theoretical perspectives.
Took with Kaye; awesome professor and interesting material.
descrip: A critical examination of the relation between concepts of "religion" and "law," as they figure in the modern state. The course will survey theoretical tools for thinking about these issues and their historical development before applying them to case studies in Europe and the Middle East. With the benefit of these comparative studies, and a new historical and philosophical insights, we will then address religion, politics and law in contemporary America.

title: Natural Disasters
reviews: A good way to get a lab; interesting superficial geology
Be prepared to do a bit more work into it than you want to. Other than that, it's a pretty good STL and/or pdf class.
Definitely take it. Great STL. Easy.
Do the readings and go to lecture.
Do your lab reports early and well. Do the readings early and well. For those of you with the early lecture (should it continue at that time), rise early and well.

Don't take this class if you PDF, because although its relatively easy, you have no choice but to put in the work. You might as well take it for a grade if you are going to have so many labs and assignments.

Eh. If you're not a science person at all, then I guess this is one of the classes you're thinking of taking for the dreaded STL requirement. It's more boring than it sounds but if taken on pass/d/fail basis, you ought to be fine.
Go to lecture.
If you are taking it for an STL, no. There are other STLs that are less time consuming and more interesting.
If you have an interest in natural disasters and are looking for a good course to fulfill the STL requirement, then I highly recommend taking this course.
It's a good way to fill the STL requirement.
It's an easy lab, so I'd take it if you need a STL
Not as hard as you think
PDF
Take it for your STL requirement.
Take it if you are interested in the science behind natural disasters. Very rewarding.

Take the course, but take it seriously.  It's easy enough, but it is completely worth putting effort into the course because the lessons will stay with you if you are at all interested in the way the world works and how we deal with it.
Take the course, it was an interesting class even though I have no interest in studying geology.

The lectures take attendance using iClickers and worksheets. Very easy relative to most classes I have taken (it was easier than I had expected). Material includes some useful knowledge about stuff that I should have known more about already.
This is a fun class without too much work.  It is a good PDF course.

This is one of the best STLs and as a course I took for that requirement, it was very interesting and worthwhile. Definitely take it if you're not very science-inclined, but if you're deciding between this class and, say, a Physics class because you're interested in it, it's a choice between an easy class and one that is harder but with labs that are much more engaging (most likely).
Try to get as much out of the laboratories as possible, because they will help so much for understanding the material for the class in general.
work hard in lab
descrip: An introduction to natural (and some society-induced) hazards and the importance of public understanding of the issues related to them. Emphasis is on the geological processes that underlie the hazards, with discussion of relevant policy issues tied to reading recent newspaper/popular science articles. Principal topics: Earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, tsunami, hurricanes, floods, meteorite impacts, global warming. Intended primarily for non-science majors.

title: Designing Sustainable Systems - Applying the Science of Sustainability to Address Global Change
reviews: DON'T.

Forrest is a great guy, even if the course can be a bit disorganized and vague at times, and I'm sure it's going to be a lot more streamlined next year, so take it for a pretty easy exploration of solutions to big environmental issues!
Good distributional requirement but only interesting if you are really interested in environmental sustainability.
Have an open mind.
I would definitely recommend taking this course as an STN.

I would not recommend the course to anyone in its current form but hope that it will improve if offered again. Professor Meggers is a great person and clearly cared about the class and teaching but was not able to create a meaningful or stimulating class.

I would recommend this course but let them know that the first half of the semester is a bit boring, but it's worth it for the second semester, if your final group project is a fun and interesting one

Just turn everything in on time and you'll be fine. Be creative, and engage with the book you're assigned in the second half of the course (they're all good, and will help stimulate some good environmental thinking).
Not a bad class for an STN requirement! Take it if you really are interested in architecture and/or environmental science.
Take it!
Take it. It's a good STN, and Professor Meggers is cool.
The class will probably be better once it is taught for a second time.
This is great class. Not too much work, and very interactive!

You don't have to put much effort into this class, but then you won't get much out of it. I would recommend this class more for self-motivated students who are willing to do some independent research.
descrip: The course presents anthropogenic global changes and their impact on sustainable design. The course focuses on the mechanistic understanding of the underlying principles based in simple concepts from natural and applied sciences. Based on a reflection of successes and failures, it indicates the feasibility of the necessary changes and critically discusses alternatives. The material is presented in 2 parts: 1) Global Change and Environmental Impacts: studying our influences on basic natural systems and cycles, and 2) Designing Sustainable Systems: studying potential solutions to these challenges through an applied design project.

title: Topics in Applied Economics - Growth, International Finance & Crises
descrip: This is a macro, international finance-oriented development course, which will focus on the political economy of policy decisions. It will cover the following themes: 1. GDP growth and volatility; 2. the size, composition, and influence of international capital flows; 3. sudden stops in capital flows and financial crises; 4. the domestic and multilateral response to crises, including the role of fiscal adjustment, external financing, and debt restructuring; 5. We will draw on several country case-studies and students will be encouraged to undertake short research assignments to deepen their own policy interests.

title: Combustion
reviews: Take it.  But only with Professor Law, because I fear it would not be the same course otherwise.
descrip: Chemical thermodynamics and kinetics, oxidation of hydrogen, hydrocarbons and alternate fuels, pollutant chemistry and control, transport phenomena, laminar premixed and nonpremixed flames, turbulent flames, ignition, extinction, and flammability phenomena, flame stabilization and blowoff, detonation and blast waves, droplet, spray and coal particle combustion, principles of engine operation.

title: Complex Organization (Half-Term)
descrip: Introduction to the study of complex organizations. Course goals are (1) to familiarize students with classic and recent organizational scholarship; (2) to enable students to apply critical insights from this research to empirical analyses involving organizations; (3) to provide a start on key readings for students planning to take a comprehensive examination in this field. Topics covered include: bureaucracy/pre-bureaucratic forms; contributions of the Carnegie School; economics of organizations & organizational networks; environments and organizational ecology; institutional theory; organizations/inequality; corporations/social change.

title: Advanced Economic Theory II
reviews: Take the course.
descrip: Topics vary from year to year. See 511.

title: Milton
reviews: I would recommend it, IF you like Milton and Paradise Lost.
If at all interested in Milton/Paradise Lost, definitely take it
If you are interested in Milton and 17th century England then you should take this course! It's not too much reading but it's not worth taking if you don't intend to do all the reading.
If you don't like Milton, then this class might not be for you, but it goes at a relatively easy pace. Professor Smith is much better one-on-one than in lecture.

If you're at all interested in Milton take this class. Professor Smith is fantastic and loves to teach this course. It's not too much work for those thinking of using it for a distribution requirement
Nigel Smith is a great professor to get to know and there is a lot to be mined from Milton's works. A good opportunity for literary analysis too.
Professor Smith is lovely and does a great job of communicating his enthusiasm for Milton.  It's a lot of fairly difficult reading, but it's so cool!
Seek help on papers if you feel your analysis may be off!
descrip: We will explore John Milton's entire career, largely as poet, but also as prose writer and thinker: a lifelong effort to unite the aims of intellectual, political and literary experimentation. In doing so Milton made himself the most influential non-dramatic poet in the English language. We will spend much time with Paradise Lost, regarded by many as the greatest non-dramatic poem in English or any modern language; we will encounter Milton's profound, extensive learning and his startling innovations with words, and in ideas of personal, domestic and communal liberty.

title: Econometric Theory II
reviews: If interested in Metrics, definitely take it.
The course is interesting but can be quite challenging. The best advice I could give is to read on your outside of class.
strongly recommend
descrip: This course begins with extensions of the linear model in several directions: (1) pre-determined but not exogenous regressors; (2) heteroskedasticity and serial correlation; (3) classical GLS; (4) instrumental variables and generalized method of movements estimators. Applications include simultaneous equation models, VARS and panel data. Estimation and inference in non-linear models are discussed. Applications include nonlinear least squares, discrete dependent variables (probit, logit, etc.), problems of censoring, truncation and sample selection, and models for duration data.

title: Medical Spanish
reviews: If you are at all interested in medicine and spanish, TAKE THIS COURSE. Low workload but you gain a lot. You will love Paloma and she will love you. Happiness all around.

Participate as much as possible, and be interested in the material presented as it focuses on important aspects of our health care system that will surely impact us as we proceed in the journey of becoming medical doctors.
Take Medical Spanish! It is hands down the best class I have ever taken at Princeton University.
This class is amazing!! Paloma is a wonderful person and I loved this class. Take it!!
prereqs: SPA 107 (with instructor's permission); or SPA 108; or SPA 207.
descrip: An advanced level Spanish course on health and medical topics. Its main purpose is to provide the students with vocabulary and linguistic skills to discuss medical issues, and to prepare them to interact with Spanish speakers in a healthcare environment in the U.S. or Latin America. The course is focused on both oral and written skills. It will also explore some aspects of the Spanish-speaking culture in the fields of health and medicine through authentic documents and the contribution of guest speakers.

title: Documentary Filmmaking
reviews: Great professor. However, because the class meets for five hours a week (a two hour evening class followed by a three hour afternoon class the next day), it's deceptively demanding for a pdfonly class. If you're in a busy semester and want a pdfonly class, I would look elsewhere unless the classes are shortened.
Plan on doing editing outside of class, come prepared with questions about how to use the program.
Put in the full effort. Even though people think they need to put in less effort for a PDF- you are missing out on a great experience if you don't put the full effort.
Take it early (freshman or sophomore year). I wish I had been able to do the certificate after taking this class. Lots of work for seniors who also have theses.
YES take it! Very fun and you just make your own doc on whatever you want. Also get to watch many great documentaries.
descrip: This course introduces students to documentary film production using digital video, with an emphasis on the practical challenges of working in the real world. While students learn the traditional methods of production, they are also encouraged to range widely in their thinking about how to document daily life. Production of videos will be augmented by screenings, readings, and visiting filmmakers.

title: Public Policy and the American Racial State
reviews: AMAZING CLASS. Murakawa is a genius and will change the way that you think.
I would recommend any student remotely interested in American politics.

If you are interested in race and public policy or anything related to AAS, I would highly recommend the course. Professor Murakawa is an amazing and articulate instructor and the class is very engaging overall. There is a good amount of reading, but most of it is thoroughly enjoyable. Take this class!

It's not an easy course. There's a lot of reading and the midterm and final paper is tough. If you're interested in African American studies though or race relations in America at all, this class is an absolute must take.
Read the material!

Take it!!! Prof. Murakawa is a very creative thinker and great at running seminars. The class will change the way you view American politics. But just be warned, despite the lack of weekly reading responses, this is not an easy course. You will get out as much as you put in to the readings and discussions.

Take this course!  It's a chance to read an amazing list of books, have eye opening discussions and interact with a phenomenal professor.  Professor Murakawa is a fantastic--she's a brilliant academic, great at stimulating discussion, very approachable and makes herself available for meetings outside of class.  At first, I was skeptical about the in class midterm.  We wrote the questions as a class and then had time to prepare outside of class before writing two essays during our seminar time.  In hindsight, however, it really helped me synthesize a what we'd been talking about all semester and the format allowed all of us to prepare beforehand and do our best.  There's a lot of reading and the midterm and final paper are both challenging, but it's all worth doing.  Read as much as you can and come to class with an open mind, ready to discuss.  I highly recommend this course.
Take this course. It will change how you think in a necessary way.
You will get the most out of this course if you put a lot of work in. Do all of the readings, participate in class discussions,  attend office hours and have an open mind.
descrip: In the context of de facto equality but persistent racial inequality, how do we identify race's role in public policy? This course addresses this question by drawing on a range of interdisciplinary texts. We begin by exploring different theoretical perspectives of race, seeking to define "the racial state" in historical and comparative terms. We then consider how race interacts with a variety of American political institutions, including the welfare state, immigration regulation, and the criminal justice state. We give particular attention to the complexities of racial construction and race's intersection with other forms of hierarchy.

title: Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications
reviews: This course is worth taking
descrip: As our society transitions towards an information-driven paradigm, concerns about security and privacy of computing and communication have come to a forefront. This course exposes students to foundational principles and mechanisms that enable security and privacy in computing and communications. In addition, we study the interdisciplinary dimension of security and privacy by exploring its intersections with machine learning, information theory, computer architecture and formal methods.

title: The Philosophy of Plato
descrip: This is a seminar on metaphysics in Plato's later dialogues. We focus on Parmenides and Sophist with reference also to Philebus and Theaetetus.

title: Macroeconomics: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: An excellent course! Much more challenging than 310, and much more rewarding.
Be prepared to work very hard.
Definitely take if Kaplan is teaching again.
Don't take this class.
Go to every lecture and ask questions.
Go to lecture. Go to lecture. Go to lecture.

Greg Kaplan teaching ECO311? You HAVE TO take it. He is SO clear and you will come away from the class understanding how economists model real business cycles (recessions and booms), models for understanding cross country income differences (why is the US GDP so much higher than Nigeria). 

For the final and midterm, make sure to go over the derivations that he does in class again. Take good notes because they are SO helpful for homework and exams.

Greg Kaplan is the best economics professor I've ever taken a course with. So organized, clear and energetic
I would take this course for an excellent and serious overview of the macroeconomy.
If Prof. Kaplan is teaching, take this course; it's one not to be missed.
It's not as math intensive as you may think.
Look at the supplementary precept materials each week as if they were required readings.
Professor Kaplan's approach seems pedantically micro-foundational at the beginning, but provides a solid understanding of how to derive macroeconomic models.

Sometimes it seems like Prof. Kaplan teaches to the highest level/grad level in the class, not explaining terms that some students may not have ever heard before. But he's very encouraging of questions in lecture, which can help. Also, problem sets often require going to office hours, and there were times that each preceptor and the professor would advise differently on a pset problem, which was confusing. It's also hard to predict what the exams will be like/prepare for them in this course.
Take if you have to for your major.  Get to class early and SIT IN THE FRONT ROW! Kaplan's handwriting is small and horrendous, so you want to make sure you can see.
This is a very fun, interesting class to take if your math background is strong enough. Prof. Kaplan is a very clear lecturer, and you should definitely take the class with him if you can!
Very challenging course. But a good intro to theoretical macroeconomics at grad school level
it's like ECO 310 but more about economics than math. It is cool because you get smarter, but know what you are getting in to.
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101 and MAT175 or MAT 201..
descrip: This course examines the determinants of long-run economic growth, short-run business cycle fluctuations, and the conduct of monetary and fiscal policy. The first part of the course develops a framework for the analysis of households' consumption and savings behavior and firms' production decisions, and uses that to analyze long-run growth and financial crises. The second part of the course extends that analysis to examine business cycle fluctuations, including inflation, unemployment. Current issues in macroeconomic and financial policy are discussed throughout.

title: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
reviews: Attend as many lectures as possible, active feedback in precepts is necessary.
Do all of the reading. The lectures are more important but the reading helps for sure. Make sure if you are confused about something to ask about it in precept.

Don't feel intimidated and participate in discussions as often as possible. Make sure to have a firm grasp of concepts taught earlier on in the course as they recursively appear throughout the semester.
I STRONGLY recommend this course. It was very engaging, and you will retain the knowledge learned for a very long time.
If you need an LA or are interested in the field of linguistics, this is the course for you.
Interesting material and good course!
Interesting material, not too time consuming.

It is a basic, introductory linguistics course. Feels a lot like an AP class. The material is quite eclectic. There are mechanics of language, developmental psychology, and anthropological aspects. The psychology sections were largely covered in intro to psych so I did not find them interesting or useful.
Just take the course.
Only take it if it is of interest to you or you have a compelling reason (besides, say an easy EC requirement).  I can see how the course may seem quite dull to people not interested in Linguistics.
Pay attention during lecture. It'll make it a lot easier later when youre studying for exams.
Read.
Take it only if interested in linguistics.
Take it!
Take notes in lecture to make sure you stay focussed as it is easy to drift away in lecture
Take this course! Not stressful and interesting!
Take this course, it is very eye-opening about how people speak the way they do.

This course is amazing as a survey course, and it's really great for anyone interested in language! I think it's very easy for any professor to make this material engaging, so even if the course isn't with Professor Teodorescu, it'll still be fun and exciting! You should take it!!!
This is a good intro course for linguistics!
This is a good introductory course to Linguistics.
This is a great introductory course to linguistics, and you will learn a lot. Be prepared to do all the readings and attend all of the lectures.
Very good 5th (maybe even 6th) class - light workload   interesting and intuitive material
really great course- definitely take it if alexandra teodorescu is teaching. she's awesome- very approachable, and presents the material in a very effective way
descrip: This course is designed to give you an overview of linguistics, the scientific study of language. We will explore many of the major subfields of linguistics and learn some of the techniques used by linguists to describe and analyze language. Topics include the architecture and diversity of human languages, how children acquire language, and how language is stored in the brain, the relationship between language and society, language change and death.

title: Theory of Algorithms
reviews: Find a partner and spend some time going over the lecture slides with them, working through Tarjan's reasoning. It's pretty much impossible to understand all of the material otherwise!
If you are interested in algorithms, you should probably take it.
If you're interested in math and theory of algorithms, this course may be ok for you. However, be aware that the materials and grading can sometimes be badly organized.
Important topics for any COS major.
Start problem sets early and go to office hours.
Take it if you are looking for a Theory requirement. The problem sets shouldn't take more time than the 340 ones.
Take it if youer' interested in theory.
Take it with Wayne. Tarjan is amazing (and great in office hours) but he isn't particularly good at explaining the material...probably because he knows it too well!
Take it!! Believe me if you put in the time you CAN succeed. Go to office hours and put the work in. I found 340 challenging and I'm no math genius and I could do it so you can too!

Take this class!  Professor Tarjan is an incredibly thoughtful professor who really cares about his students' learning.  If you like theory and want to learn more (and don't mind a substantial workload along the way), I think you'll really enjoy this class!
Take this course if you are interested in algorithms.  There is not much work for the course, but the work that is given is fairly difficult.
Take this course. You ll get a very good understanding of algorithms.

Tarjan is really helpful in office hours, but his lectures are confusing.  I would recommend studying the slides on your own and then asking him about difficult concepts in person. The problem sets are easy, relative to COS 340.
This class under Tarjan is pretty unorganized, with largely unnecessary lectures. You can learn pretty much everything necessary from the slides and online resources.

This course could aptly be named "Bob Tarjan's Greatest Hits," as Prof. Tarjan essentially taught algorithms through the lens of his personal contributions to the field.  Thankfully, he invented or co-invented nearly everything that we consider to be core algorithms knowledge today (and then some), so the class covered all of the important topics in algorithms.  Seriously, go read the CLRS textbook - you'll see his name every couple of pages (on OCW, the MIT professor asks students to guess who new algorithms were invented by, and the answer is always Tarjan).

Tarjan is one of the greatest living theoreticians in computer science, and his expertise shines through the course.  Lectures drag, but he is a fantastic teacher in office hours.

The course will require all the work in the world, but it'll be worth it.  I'd do it again.  Don't pass up the chance to learn from Tarjan.
not entirely worth it; difficult and not very enlightening. also very disorganized
prereqs: COS 226 and 340, or permission of instructor.
descrip: Design and analysis of efficient data structures and algorithms. General techniques for building and analyzing algorithms. Introduction to NP-completeness.

title: International News - Foreign Policy, Public Opinion, and the Press
reviews: Absolutely take this class if you're at all interested in journalism or international relations! I loved it!
Awesome course. Professor Richburg was engaging and very knowledgeable.  Helped me stay up to date with foreign news. Great guest speakers.
I would really recommend taking this course. Professor Richburg is a fascinating teacher and great journalist. I really learned a lot.
If Keith comes back you should definitely take a class with him!

It's a good class. Just be aware there are a lot of little assignments throughout the way (5 articles  that require interviews with specialists--kind of hard to get in touch with these people). If this doesn't deter you, take it.
Read the news critically, and come to class armed with questions.
Start your assignments early so informants have time to get back to you and you have time to review your work with Keith.
Take a journalism class! Even if it can't be with Professor Richburg, you will learn a lot and enjoy it.
Take it!! But don't expect a lot of structured readings and seminars. But you'll probably come out with a bunch of assignments you're proud of and also being very knowledgeable about current events.
Take this class!
Take this course!
This is a great course to learn not only about current affairs, but also about writing in general. It is a lot of fun!!
prereqs: Enrollment by application - see course web address.
descrip: From the Vietnam War to Afghanistan, from perceptions of Africa to the rise of China, Americans' views of the world are driven largely by foreign reporting and the dispatches of a relatively small number of foreign correspondents. Foreign policy decision-making is thus often impacted by, or in reaction to, these news reports from abroad. This course will explore that nexus between foreign reporting, foreign policy, and public opinion, using case studies from Africa, Iraq, Afghanistan, China, and Southeast Asia.

title: Neuroeconomics
prereqs: Students must have knowledge in at least one of: economics, neuroscience or psychology. We will also assume basic quantitative or technical background (e.g., introductory statistics), as one of our primary goals will be to develop a familiarity and facility with formal approaches to neuroeconomics..
descrip: This seminar focuses on the recent explosion of interest in understanding the neural basis of valuation and decision making, and the resulting marriage between the formal rigor of economics and the empirical basis of psychology and neuroscience, termed "neuroeconomics". We will approach the question of how the brain makes economic decisions from multiple perspectives, drawing on theoretical, behavioral, and neural data from economics, psychology, and neurobiology. Major topics include: decision under risk and uncertainty; the role of learning in evaluating options; choice mechanisms; and multiplayer interactions and social decision making.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences IV
reviews: Definitely take it. Be prepared for a lot of really interesting material, but also for testing and problem sets that are unconventional (and not always well organized).

Honestly, if you've gotten this far you might as well go all the way if you are interested in the QCB certificate and/or a career in mathematical biology or biophysics. You know by now that the course is disorganized but you should try it for a few weeks and see how it goes. I highly recommend against for those not interested in mathematical biology or ISC for ISC's sake. But it is much, much better than taking MOL 214 or real genetics. If this is the biochem portion next time, ignore what I said and take it because Rabinowitz is FANTASTIC.
It needs some growth and serious reorganization, but if that happens, it's a wonderful class. Stay in integrated!
Just take it.
Make sure you understanding everything on the psets.

This course is very interesting, and it will teach you a lot about genetics and basic developmental biology.  True to ISC form, it has a heavier computational component than the analogous course in MOL.  Don't worry if you have a weak biology background; I had only one week of Punnet Squares for earlier genetics information, and this was my favorite semester of ISC yet.
This past year was an exception because Botstein took a sudden leave of absence, but it was pretty disorganized. Interesting stuff, though.
prereqs: Students are expected to have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 235..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics, genomics, evolution and neuroscience. This is the second course in the year-long multidisciplinary integrated science sequence. Multiple faculty will be involved over the year: J. Lieb, M. Murthy, E. Wieschaus (MOL), J. Rabinowitz (CHM). 2 hrs and 40 min of lecture, one precept (1 hr 50 min), one evening problem session.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: A good experience
I would say that you should expect to do a lot of the work off of your own motivation. You get what you put into it.
If you are an engineer, then this class is for you. Out of all of my freshman classes, this course provided the most context, the most hands-on work, and the most actual engineering.
Take it as an additional course, if you are looking to be involved in a hands on engineering project.

The Piano Team in Team Time is a low commitment class that is fun. We took stuff apart and put it back together, I learned about how instruments work and how to work with my hands to fix them and I enjoyed it.
This course is good if you are looking for more practical applications instead of book work or reading about possible solutions.
Yes, but be self motivated so that you inspire others to work hard.
much more difficult than expected
prereqs: EGR 250.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of freshmen through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Risk Analysis
descrip: This course aims to develop the ability to use analytic frameworks in the formulation and assessment of public policy. We consider many different analytical techniques with an emphasis on decision-making under uncertainty. The emphasis is on how to apply the models to different public policies rather than on how to derive the theoretical underpinnings of the models. Most of these models are solved in Excel or other software packages. Techniques include: Probabilistic risk analysis (event trees, Bayesian decision theory); Decision Analysis; Monte Carlo simulation; Linear programming; and Markov chain models.

title: International Theatre: Plays and Politics
reviews: Great Professors. Material you've probably never encountered before. Really interesting.

I would definitely recommend taking this course! Professors Isaacs and Wolff offer incredible insight into political theater, and the energy that they bring to class makes each seminar very enjoyable. You will gain a much better appreciation for world politics and the role of theater in making political issues more visible and catalyzing change.

I would say this is a course called plays and politics, but be ware that this is in my opinion a theater heavy course, with politics complementing it. If you love politics and only kind of like plays, and theater, this may not be the course for you. If you love theater, and only kind of like politics, you could really enjoy this seminar.
Take this class!!
This is a really good class, even for people who have never taken a theater or English class before!

Those without some minimum level of political knowledge/engagement may feel occasionally left out in discussion. However, with graded assignments, be prepared to think in a much more dramatic/lit crit sort of mindset, as that's Tamsen's thing and she can be picky. A fascinating topic with a great pair of professors, though. Discussions were brilliant.
descrip: This course addresses when and why producing political theatre matters. We will look specifically at contemporary and canonical plays from around the globe that take on various political crises (e.g., the Israeli/Palestinian conflict, Chile under Pinochet, the Liberian Civil War, the Arab Spring). In order to consider the challenges of producing highly charged political theatre, students will also attend professional productions and hear directly from artists who are engaged in making this kind of theatre around the world.

title: Homer
reviews: I would recommend this course with Professor Katz, but I would warn that it is quite difficult..
Professor Katz says it's much easier than it's going to be--expect a lot of work and reading, but it's very enjoyable over all.

You must take this course. Reading Homer in the original is completely different from any literary experience I've ever had, and the payoff is well worth the difficulties at the beginning. If Prof. Katz is teaching the course, then you absolutely must take it, but I think it would be wonderful when taught by anyone because the source material is so good.
You need to take this course to get better at Greek, but you also need to identify support and resources ahead of time so that you don't get overwhelmed.
prereqs: CLG 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: To learn to read Homer with pleasure, both the Iliad and the Odyssey. In addition to providing an introduction to Homeric dialect, oral poetry, and meter, we will discuss literary technique, epic's historical backbround, and Homer's role in the development of Greek thought.

title: Colonialism, Post-Colonialism and Islam: North Africa (1830-2011)
descrip: This course explores the history of North Africa, an area undergoing radical political turmoil since the beginning of the Arab spring in January 2011. The course explores the colonial and postcolonial transformations of the Maghrib from the 19th to the first decade of the 21st century. Through a range of secondary and primary sources, the purpose of the course is to give an overview of the colonial effects and legacies on and in North African societies, but also to start questioning the colonial period as a framework of analysis.

title: Writing Cultures: Ethnographic Facts and Fictions
prereqs: This course presumes prior familiarity with sociocultural anthropology. It is particularly appropriate for junior and senior anthropology majors writing JPs and Senior Theses and for anthropology graduate students writing up field research (dissertation-related and otherwise). Non-anthropology students with some anthropology coursework are also welcome: this course is most appropriate for students with a special interest in ethnography and/or in one or more of the other genres we will be discussing (e.g., history, memoirs, journalism, and fiction)..
descrip: Comparing ethnography (anthropologists' signature form) with related nonfiction genres (history, journalism, memoir), we focus on questions about truth and "truthiness": about evidence, expertise, credibility, and authority and about literary form (e.g., voice, metaphor, and technical jargon). We consider how different genres are recognized as such in acts of evaluation by expert and lay readers; and what their distinctive evaluative standards allow or disallow. Throughout, we seek fresh ways of thinking about the ethical dilemmas of ethnography and related genres by juxtaposing them to the ethical dilemmas of fiction-writing.

title: Atmospheric and Oceanic Wave Dynamics
descrip: Observational evidence of atmospheric and oceanic waves; laboratory simulation. Surface and internal gravity waves; dispersion characteristics; kinetic energy spectrum; critical layer; forced resonance; instabilities. Planetary waves: scale analysis; physical description of planetary wave propagation; reflections; normal modes in a closed basin. Large-scale barclinic and barotropic instabilities. Eady and Charney models for barclinic instability, and energy transfer.

title: Motor Control and Learning
reviews: If you're a NEU student looking for an elective, this one's a must. Prof. Taylor creates a relaxed but super informative classroom environment which you'll definitely enjoy.
Not much work, fairly interesting readings, and good lectures. Professor Taylor is really good.
very interesting class
prereqs: No Prerequisite Required.
descrip: In this course, we will examine how the nervous system controls movements, how the brain handles enormous computational complexities of movement, how motor skills are learned and consolidated, and how the motor system influences cognition.

title: Politics and Society in the Arabic Novel and Film
reviews: Definitely take this class. It's very engaging and offers an expansive portion of the Middle East and North African history and culture.

TAKE IT if you're interested in Middle East history.  I truly believe that especially if you're in another department and want to focus on NES (like POL, WWS, or HIS) that a course like this deepens understanding of the issues facing the region in an important way.  It will humanize the political, economic, and cultural issues you study in other classes about the region.
Take this course! Prof. Levy is great at stimulating discussion and you'll read so many awesome books you probably wouldn't be exposed to outside of this context.
Take this course! The professor is very passionate and always helpful outside of class. The readings are great!
The COM crosslisting is misleading. Don't take it and expect the kind of textual analysis you would find in a comp lit course.

This is a great class if you are interested in anything related to Arabic culture, this is an important class to take. Having a cultural understanding is imperative to seeing the political affects on the social people.
take this class!!!!
descrip: This course examines how Arab writers have used fiction and film to address major social and political issues such as displacement, labor migration, war, social repression, and dictatorship. The course covers novels from Egypt, the Sudan, Lebanon, Palestine, Morocco, and Iraq. Topics covered include the Lebanese Civil War, the Palestinian struggle, Islamic fundamentalism, Iraq under the Baathist regime, and the Arab Spring. The course will also look more broadly at experiences of exile and migration and the postcolonial world as reflected in modern Arabic writing. All readings are in English translation.

title: Advanced Heat and Mass Transfer
reviews: Don't be tired beforehand.
NA
Read Deen
Study and memorize equations for midterm more than practice problems.
Study the text and the notes handouts; these will tell you exactly what you need for the problem sets and exams.
Taking the time to meet with Prof. Brangwynne outside of the course will definitely help with understanding the course material.  It is a pretty average core course in chemical engineering.
To read the textbook and follow-up on concepts that are not clear.
descrip: A survey of modeling and solutions methods for processes involving heat and mass transfer. Topics will include convective and diffusive transport, conservation equations, scaling principles and approximation techniques, forced convection, multi-component energy and mass transfer as well as buoyancy and turbulent driven transport.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: Do the readings and show up.
N/A
Try to participate in discussion, as it makes the class more interesting.
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students & post-docs.

title: Asian Capital Markets
reviews: Awesome course?definitely try to take this as a senior!
Definitely take this course in your senior spring. I would recommend the PDF option for no stress and yet very engaging class, but even if you do not pdf, it is well worth the work you put into it.
Definitely take this course! You will learn a lot, not just how to structure a profitable trade!
Definitely worth taking as long as the subject interests you.
Good course with an amazing professor. Sometimes feels like a hedge fund class than a ACM class

Highly recommend this class if you're interested at all in markets and investing. You'll learn a lot about Asia, macroeconomics, and investing in general from Prof. de Swaan, who has a unique background as a partner at a hedge fund.
Participate and enjoy.
Take if you are interested in finance in Asia.
Take it if youre interesting in finance, especially the hedge fund side of the buy side/ asian markets.
Take this class if you're interested in financial markets.
take this class, you wont regret it
prereqs: For those who are unable to register because the course is full, please contact Professor De Swaan directly (jdeswaan@princeton.edu). Juniors need special permission from instructor to enroll..
descrip: Course explores the increasing weight of Asia in global financial markets and its implications. It frames the discussion in the context of the globalization of financial markets, with emphasis on concepts of economic development, institutional reform of markets, and public and private market investments. Discussions combine analysis of historical trends and recent data and events with insights from practical experience in Asian markets. Course explicitly considers China's gradual shift toward a capital market-based financial system and the policy decisions faced by the Chinese and US governments relative to existing global imbalances.

title: An Introduction to Engineering
reviews: Approach with an open mind
Enjoy it, pay attention in the labs, they can be fun
Good course to take if you're unsure about which engineering department you want to join.
If you have an interest in engineering, but only a vague impression of what kind, it is a great class to take. It isn't really a must-take class, but it is a lot of fun and worth the time.

If you're looking for something deeply interesting and engaging, this isn't what it may seem from the description. If you're just looking to peek into the world of engineering while not really having anything matter and fill out a schedule; it's perfect.
Take if you are not sure about the engineering majors, as they should help you. However, if you are choosing from ORFE or COS, the course doesn't really touch on these.

The course was a good stress-free course for a freshman engineer who wanted to a chance to look at what each type of engineer does. If you come into Princeton already knowing which type of engineer you want to be, I would suggest taking courses in your major instead of this course.
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the various disciplines of engineering. It is a project-based sequence (Energy Conversion and the Environment, Robotic Remote Sensing, and Wireless Image & Video Transmission) that covers engineering disciplines and their relationship to the principles of physics and mathematics.

title: Tragedy
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Dangerous Music
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Geometry and Architectural Representation
reviews: Be prepared to spend a few nights really making this a priority, but you'll be proud of the work in the end.
Take it if you are interested in architecture.
its very time consuming, but fun at the same time. don't leave your projects to do last minute.
prereqs: This course is designed primarily for freshman and sophomores who are interested in gaining introductory experience in design and drawing. This course will help prepare students for ARC 204 and upper-level studios..
descrip: This course sets out two goals: the first is to understand the theories and techniques of geometry in architectural representation; the second is to develop the student's drawing sensibilities through 5 thematic drawing projects engaging both digital and manual techniques. Each new theme will be introduced through a lecture, tutorial, and discussion including a number of specific readings related to the topic at hand. The second class will be an individual desk crit to discuss the development of each drawing project. The third class will consist of a group pin-up review of each drawing experiment.

title: Seminar in Musicology - Cultural Fusion, Exoticism and Music Analysis
descrip: Exam selected forms of cultural fusions, absorption, translations, articulations, and circulations in Western art music. Many gestures used to express exotic music have acquired new meaning, become absorbed into modern musical idioms or system, some shedding any association they once had with the exotic. We ask what analytical frameworks and approaches are most germane to the analysis of particular forms of cultural fusion. The music repertoire studied ranges from late 19th century 21st century.

title: Molecular Basis of Cancer
reviews: A great introduction to many important aspects of cancer biology, covering not only the history of the field but also current areas of research.  Excellent course for anyone interested in learning more about the field!

Good class. Not too much work, and really good & broad coverage of how cancer works. I signed up despite a few negative reviews, and I'm not sure why those exist - maybe he changed up the class format or something.
Great course if you want to learn about cancer in a paper-discussion-based environment.

I would advice them that this is a very hands-on course. Do not expect to be able to merely observe, you will participate in the discussion as this is a primary mode of learning utilized in this course.
It is a lot of reading but if you don't take the time to do it then you won't get anything out of the class.
Read the papers and engage in discussion.

TAKE THIS COURSE!! You will not regret it. You will leave the class with a completely new and deep understanding of cancer. This class not only teaches how science is done and criticized, but also critical ways of thinking about problems. I HIGHLY recommend this course!
Take it. No questions about it. THE BEST COURSE I HAVE TAKEN AT PRINCETON!!!

This course would be great for those interested in cancer research. The invited speakers included important scientists and medical doctors that provided a variety of perspectives on cancer research and treatment.
it is a good idea to take it, and more time you put in, the more you will get out of it.
take it!
descrip: We explore the molecular events leading to the onset and progression of human cancer. We review the central genetic and biochemical elements that make up the cell cycle, followed by a survey of the signal transduction pathways and checkpoints that regulate it. We discuss oncogenes, tumor suppressor and mutator genes that act in these pathways and review the role of viral oncogenes and their action on cells. We investigate the role of cancer stem cells and the interaction between tumor and the host environment. We explore specific clinical case studies in light of the molecular events underlying different cancers.

title: Financial Econometrics
reviews: Attend the lectures, as they cover material not in the notes.
Be prepared to devote a lot of time to this class, especially the homework. This class would have benefited a lot from a precept, doing examples and R code
Definitely take it. Worth it. Do make sure to read ahead before lectures though
Don't go to lectures but read everything on your own.
Great course taught by Prof. Fan.
Have a finance and/or time series background before taking the course - I did not and struggled because of it, but that's to be expected.
It is a good course
Mfins have to take it otherwise I recommend to find another statistical class
Prepared to be able to do R coding and math!
Programming background highly required. Do previous midterm and final exam that he post online as it is a very good guidance.
Start working on the problem sets early.
This course requires students to know how to use R (or any software that has basic time series and statistical packages)
Topic is very interested. Be prepared for long homeworks.
We have to take the course. The subject matter is very interesting. The work I quite enjoyed.
talk to the professor. he is very nice
you can learn a lot from it.
descrip: Econometric and statistical methods as applied to finance. Topics include: Overview of Statistical Methods; Predictability of asset returns; Discrete time volatility models; Efficient Portfolio and CAPM; Multifactor Pricing Models; Intertemporal Equilibrium and Stochastic Discount Models; Expectation and present value relation; Simulation methods for financial derivatives; Econometrics of financial derivatives; Forecast and Management of Market Risks; Multivariate time series in finance; Nonparametric methods in financial econometrics

title: Current Issues in Neuroscience and Behavior
reviews: Should attend the talks if you are in general interested in neuroscience.
descrip: Advanced seminar that reflects current research on brain and behavior.

title: Roman Historians of the Empire
reviews: Be bold in your interpretation of the text and don't be afraid to challenge existing understandings. Great course with a great professor.
Extremely interesting class, but Tacitus is a difficult author.
Highly highly recommended! Great professor, great text selection.
I highly recommend this course; Professor Shaw is one of the nicest professors at Princeton.
It's a great class if you like Latin. Tacitus is a challenging author, but definitely worth reading. Professor Shaw is awesome.
It's a pretty good upper level Latin translation course.
Take Tacitus.  Shaw rocks.
Take it.

This course will expose you to a very different style of Latin than other classical courses and gives you a taste of Roman history as the Romans saw it. Great course, great professor, very manageable workload.
prereqs: LAT 203 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: We will read two 'biographical' accounts in the historical writings of Tacitus: One on the life of his father-in-law Agricola and the other on the death of the crown prince Gemanicus.

title: Computer and Electronic Music through Programming, Performance, and Composition
reviews: Based on talking to people from previous classes, this year's class was a little less organized. But it was still lots of fun! Max/MSP is a little frustrating sometimes...

Don't take this class if you don't know anything about music or programming/using software. You'll feel bad if you do. If you make it to the second week and you're not feeling it, definitely drop. There isn't anything in particular about second week, it's just the fact that I don't think this is a good course to take if you're not actually engaged (really engaged)

Don't take this class unless you have already taken a computer science class. You will be schooled by the other students because most people in the class were COS people and this seemed like their "fun" class.

If you still think of this course as "PLOrk", be aware that it has changed; some of the instructors have left over the past years and the course is no longer integrated with the Laptop Orchestra. As a result, the course now has more time available in class, which is used to cover a lot of computer music history / theory as well as a wide variety of software tools. COS majors might think of it as the musical equivalent of COS 333, complete with a big open-ended final project. This is a must-take (and a reasonably easy class) for anyone who's interested in both programming and music. For people who are interested in only one of these, I'd still recommend it, but be aware that parts of it will be unfamiliar / difficult and other parts may be a little boring.

It is extremely helpful to have programming experience, but later on in the course you can choose to use the graphical software to do your assignments rather than ChucK. However, there is a steep learning curve so you will have to put in the effort to learn the software. Definitely take this class if you're interested in interfacing technology and music - final project was a blast.

It's a cool class, but you should only take it if you've completed 126. Music knowledge is not necessary at all. Grading seems a little arbitrary, and most students just reused cool projects from their other classes which was unfair to the younger students who hadn't taken those classes. Kind of stupid. Lecture was also pretty much useless and the professor didn't care if you didn't show up.
One of the best classes I've taken here. Do it if you love music and want to try to do cool things with it.
Take it -- you learn a lot about things you wouldn't anywhere else!
Take it only if you have experience coding.
Take it. It changed my life.
Take this. It's awesome and you'll learn a lot. Note that it's by far easiest for COS students to pick up.

This class is the best and you should definitely take it. If you're reading this and thinking that they won't accept your application, you should definitely apply because it is just the best. You'll be surrounded by really creative and talented people and you'll get to see a bunch of cool stuff and make cool stuff yourself, too. What more could you ask for? Also, the lectures are really great. Do it.
This class was phenomenal. Be prepared to work hard, but you will learn so much, and take so much away from it.

This course will expose you to a really, really awesome field. Make sure you're willing to put in the time to try some creative things. It's hard, but it can be rewarding, if you like this sort of thing.
This course, as it stands this year, is where you learn to code to make music. The making music part is up to your musical background, largely.
prereqs: Instructor's permission. Application available in the Music Dept. office..
descrip: An introduction to the fundamentals of computer and electronic music. The music and sound programming language ChucK, developed here at Princeton, will be used in conjunction with Max/MSP, another digital audio language, to study procedural programming, digital signal processing and synthesis, networking, and human-computer interfacing.

title: Cities and Suburbs in American History
reviews: As a very STEM person, this class did a great job of introducing me to history as a discipline. Prof. Isenberg did a phenomenal job of working students through their research papers, particularly if they had never done anything like it in the past (which was the case for me). Prof. Isenberg was especially responsive to students, and created a very personal feel in her lectures, despite the larger size of them. The readings are very interesting, though can sometimes be a little long. Very valuable course, provides great insight into urban studies from a historical perspective.
Impossible to do all the readings.  Lectures and readings have nothing to do with one another.

It's an interesting topic, but the course is average in terms of presentation (professor reading from lecture slides). Not the best or the worst, so think about the pros and cons in terms of why you need this course / what interests you about it before signing up.
Take it if at all interested in urban planning and American history.

This class actually involves a fair amount of work, but leads to really interesting facts about cities and suburbs that you wouldn't know from normal readings and life experience. I recommend as a science major if you want to fulfill a distribution requirement and have a free pdf.

This course isn't incredible well-organized, and Professor Isenberg is not always well-organized either. The information is pretty interesting, but there's often a total disconnect between lectures and readings.

This is a very interesting and informative course. However, the reading can be a bit overwhelming. A book a week can be anything from 150 pages to over 250. Probably not the best course to take if you're a senior with a thesis to write.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: From the colonial era to the present, this course weaves together a comprehensive history of American cities and suburbs, cutting across social life, politics, economics, culture, and the built environment. Topics include urban planning and design, public and private spaces, social experience, urban investment and disinvestment, the metropolitan economy, politics and policy, arts and culture, city leadership, and the participation of ordinary people in shaping urban and suburban life.

title: Independent Research Project
prereqs: Students MUST sign up in room 121 during course selection period..
descrip: Independent research or investigation resulting in a report in the student's area of interest under the supervision of a faculty member. Open to sophomores and juniors.

title: The Politics of Seeing: The Films of the French New Wave
descrip: See website

title: America and the Melting Pot
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Statistics and Data Analysis for Economics
reviews: A great introductory statistics course. Clear and approachable.
As far as econ stats go, people think it's quite dry, and it is... but Professor Mueller makes it go quite quickly. He makes it pretty fun.
Best stats course at Princeton by far. Actually very well-taught - you'll learn a lot! It's not too challenging, and the curve is great.
Do not fall behind
Do the problem sets, go to precept as necessary
Do the problem sets, go to the lectures, or you will be lost.
Don't lose steam even though it starts to get boring during the second half
Don't take it if you don't have to
Don't take it if you don't have to. Its not that interesting, has nothing to do with economics - just statistics.
Don't take unless you're a mathy person.
Easy class. just read the notes and come to lecture every once in a while.
Easy way to get the stat requirement out of the way. Basically AP Stat...
GO TO MCGRAW

Gives you a good understanding of stats. It's not particularly challenging, so you could learn the material in a couple days leading up to the exam. But it's much easier if you just keep up i.e. go to lecture, skim the textbook before, and pay active attention. Make sure you allot yourself enough time to go over practice tests before the exam since questions repeat in style and content.
Go over the book in addition to the lectures. Go through practice exams before any test or final.
Go to office hours because even if you understand the concepts in lecture, the problems you are expected to do on exams will be a lot more difficult
Good overall stats course

Good stat course to take if you are an Econ or WWS major and pretty good at math. Lectures are interesting and problem sets aren't terribly time-consuming. Tests are pretty difficult but fair with a pretty good curve.
