I loved this course! It's definitely one of the best introductory statistics courses offered at Princeton.
I think this is a good course to take.
I would advise them to learn the material conceptually, instead of just learning formulas, or else the tests will throw you off.
I would recommend taking a different stats course. Lectures were too long, there wasn't sufficient help in preparing for exams, and derivations were stressed in this class.
I would recommend that students attend all lectures and do a careful job on problem sets.
I would suggest going over proofs and to not fall behind in the class.

IF YOU HAVE TO TAKE STATS, seriously consider ECO 202. I was struggling to decide between orph and this one to fulfill my econ stuff, and wanted to choose one that I could handle better without a strong math background. This is the best stats class offered.
If you have to take a stats course, I would definitely take this one! Professor Mueller is very engaging and the workload is very fair.
If you have to take it, read the book and never go to lecture or class.

If you need a statistics course, this is a pretty good option. It's very manageable, but it's definitely important to go over problem sets and practice finals as these questions are very much similar to the midterms and finals.
It is an interesting course. It is required for econ majors unless you can place out using AP or IB credits.

It is ridiculously hard, especially if you're woody wu and not econ math track. However, you can escape with a B especially if you make it priority and take advantage of your resources. If you are debating between ECO 202 and other stats for woody wu, definitely take ECO 202. It is the best of the worst by far.
It's a good course. I loved the professor. I only regret not going to office hours to actually get to know him. McGraw is super helpful. Take it if you wanna learn stats, good course.

It's a pre-req for a lot of majors so know that there is a large diversity of students who come from many different departments and interests. The questions posed are not always applicable to the real world unless it's finance.
It's a very good statistics course that is not heavy on math.
It's good for a stats class but not one of the greatest courses you will take at Princeton.
It's not that hard or that interesting. Take it if you need to.
Make sure you stay on top of the material!
Not bad stats course. Take it if you have to, not very interesting nor difficult.
Only take this course if necessary to become an econ major.
PRACTICE PROBLEMS.
Practice tests are key for midterms and exam studying
Pretty chill class
Pretty standard introductory statistics course, I learned a lot about stats in this class! Definitely very math-y and quite difficult but it's definitely doable
Read the book before class
Second midterm is a killer.  Otherwise, not too bad.
Still sounds less bad than any other stats course offered at princeton
Study in groups
Take PSY 251 if you're looking for a stats distribution requirement or a certificate requirement.
Take detailed lecture notes.
Take if you have to, it's introductory stats so pretty straightforward.  Muller is a really good professor.
Take it
Take it if you are required to or want a straightforward, not very challenging introduction to statistics.
Take it if you have a statistics background from high school, but maybe look around at the other statistics courses if you just need to fulfill the distribution requirement
Take it if you have a strong math background.
Take it if you have to.
Take it over ORF 245 if majoring in econ.
Take it!
Take this class
Take this class if you have too. It's pretty boring but if you've never taken statistics before you learn a lot. Professor Mueller made it as good as he could. Exams were tough though.
Take this class with Prof. Mueller and go to lecture.
Take this class! It is my favorite math/econ class that I have taken thus far at Princeton!

Take this course if you need a medium-difficulty course to fulfill your statistics requirement, or if you have an interest in learning about stats. Coming from an engineering major, this is about as easy of a quantitative class as you're gonna find. It's really easy compared to the other math/science/engineering courses I've taken at Princeton.
Take this course if you need statistics as a prerequisite for your major. It is not easy, but is probably the best option for the subject.
Take this course,

The concept are very important to understand. Exams are not that difficult, though the final may be a bit challenging compared to the midterms. Good lectures and great problem sets. Definitely take it but don't get Stata. We only needed it once this semester.

The consensus is that, of the classes available to fulfill the stats requirement for WWS, this would be the least painful. Of course, 80 minutes of stats twice a week can be boring & taxing, but Mueller's a great professor. He's got good energy, an engaging sense of humor, and is pretty aware of how responsive students are being to the material (there's honestly nothing better than a professor who can sense the vibe the students are putting out and respond accordingly - think 10 minute breaks and candy). My only warning would be that the class can seem deceptively easy. Problem sets look short, but can take quite a bit of time (though sometimes they actually are pretty quick). You'll also feel like the class doesn't require a lot of work, so you won't give it too much energy from week to week. But then you'll realize that it's time for one of the 2 midterms or the final and you're more unprepared than you anticipated. If you're mindful of that ahead of time - I feel like it's the one thing no one tells you - then your experience with the class will be positive. So to echo the general sentiment, if you have to take a stats class, might as well make it this one.
The course is a bit theoretical, and more proof-based than I'd hoped.
The course was pretty doable, just make sure to stay up to date on the material. Otherwise it was a pretty straightforward course.
There is absolutely no reason to go to lectures and the class isn't that hard.
This class is HARD. Professor Mueller is a great lecturer, but at the end of the day the content, midterms and problem sets are stressful and very difficult.
This is a really good course but if you like doing math, maybe try ORF245 instead since it is a little more legit.
This was a pretty good stats class to take.  I had taken AP Statistics in high school, so some of this stuff wasn't new to me, but I still learned a lot.
Understanding the material is more important than memorizing formulas.
While the material might be slightly easier than orfe stats, the psets are pretty challenging. Not an easy class. But manageable.
You're not going to enjoy this course, but you need to know statistics, so just take it. You will complain throughout, though.
bascially, all the learning is from doing previous practice tests. going to lecture doesn't help THAT much.
don't fail
not easy
recommend if you need to take it. watch out to do all the practice exams before the finals and midterms
study hard, do all practice exams, read textbook, find good group to work on for psets
prereqs: MAT 103.
descrip: An introduction to probability and statistical methods for empirical work in economics. Probability, random variables, sampling, descriptive statistics, probability distributions, estimation and hypotheses testing, introduction to the regression model.

title: Linguistic Semantics
reviews: If you're not into linguistics, I think inevitably a class like semantics will seem a little bit dry, since it can get a little bit technical at times, so it would be better to take a more accessible course. If you ARE into linguistics, then it's a 'must'!
Take it only if you already have a strong interest in the subject.
prereqs: LIN 201.
descrip: An introduction to central issues and leading theories of linguistic semantics for natural languages. Analysis of specific linguistic phenomena (including: anaphora, quantification, and tenses) will be used to illustrate the interaction of syntax and semantics, the relation between language and the world, and the role of linguistic meaning in communication and understanding.

title: Islam Across the Indian Ocean
descrip: This seminar will consider Islam and mobility across the Indian Ocean, discussing ways that Southeast Asians, Africans, and Indians have created their distinct communities while nonetheless declaring themselves to be of one discrete entity: the Umma. Alongside discussions of knowledge creation, orientalism and nationalism, the seminar will also explore issues relating to global projects for religious and political reform, using Indonesia as a primary example.

title: Analysis I: Fourier Series and Partial Differential Equations
reviews: I would recommend waiting until Professor Stein teaches this again.
prereqs: MAT215, 218, or consent of instructor..
descrip: Basic facts about Fourier Series, Fourier Transformations, and applications to the classical partial differential equations will be covered. Also Fast Fourier Transforms, Finite Fourier Series, Dirichlet Characters, and applications to properties of primes.

title: High-Energy Physics
descrip: An overview of modern elementary particle physics and the Standard Model. Specific topics include: weak decays, W and Z physics, deep inelastic scattering, CP violation, neutrino oscillations, Higgs searches, with an emphasis on areas of current interest. Course also covers concepts in experimental tools and techniques.

title: Materials Science and Engineering
reviews: Go to class. Understand the concepts. Don't mess up the calculations.
Good intro-level class if you like materials.
I fell into the trap of believing that since the notes were online I could afford to miss class. Not the case. Go to class

I've heard excellent things about the course when it is taught by Craig Arnold so I would strongly recommend that you take it with him. That being said if you need to take this course in the spring then professor Loo is an acceptable substitute. I would not have taken this course if it was not required.
If interested in Chemistry and material science
If you are looking to do future work in materials or inorganic chemistry, this course may be useful.
If you think you are interested in materials science, then this is the course for you. The workload is not bad, and you definitely get a sense for what materials science is like.
It's a good course. Solid intro to materials, from a chemical and mechanical perspective. The math isn't difficult, but there's a lot of it, so I hope you like plugging numbers into equations.
It's a requirement. Fulfill it and move on! You might learn something cool, but yeah.
Keep up to date with material from week to week, as the topics don't necessarily build upon each other, and by the end it's a lot of conceptual topics and equations to know.
Lynn Loo's great. The material doesn't not go incredibly in depth, but it still fairly interesting for someone interested in materials.
Not a bad course. Not too much workload.
Overall, this is a great introduction to materials science.  Most people taking this course will have covered a lot of the material before but not in a materials context.
Read the book and pay attention in lecture!  It helps to prepare ahead and do the readings before lecture if possible.
Take it if you are at all interested in materials science.
This class was fair and I would recommend really studying for the midterms.
prereqs: Calculus, physics, and chemistry. Course will expect some level of organic chemistry; students to carry out some basic derivation of equations. Freshmen should speak with course instructor for approval to enroll..
descrip: An introduction to the structure and properties of important current and future materials, including metals, semiconductors, and polymers. Emphasis will be placed on the phase behavior and processing of materials, and how structure in these materials impact their macroscopic physical, electrical, and thermal properties.

title: Greek Prose Authors - Readings in Greek Historiography
prereqs: CLG105 or CLG108.
descrip: This course is an introduction to Greek Historiography. By reading selections from the Greek historian Xenophon, we will try to answer the following questions: Was the ancient Greek conception of writing history essentially different from ours? How did history relate to rhetoric and other literary genres? What were the main methods of writing history? The emphasis will be on reading passages in the original, followed by discussion of issues.

title: Topics in Geometry - Introductory Course in Contact Geometry
prereqs: Departmental approval..
descrip: Topics in geometry selected from areas such as differentiable and Riemannian manifolds, point set and algebraic topology, integral geometry. Prerequisite: departmental permission.

title: Life on Mars - or Maybe Not
descrip: See website

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: If you want an A by just giving up two hours of your week, take it.  If not, find something more interesting.  I regret taking this class, even though Ill leave with an A
Take this class if you want to learn hands on engineering design. There aren't that many opportunities to get your hands dirty in Princeton Engineering.
take it
prereqs: Completion of EGR 450.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Introduction to German Philosophy
reviews: Do the readings before the lectures instead of the other way around. Stay on top of them.
Don't be deterred by the fact that this is a GER course instead of a PHI course. It's worth taking.
Don't take it lightly, but certainly take it if you want to know more about the material.
Make sure to do the readings and attend lecture for enhanced understanding.
Take it for the EC, small class, easy PDF
Take it! Even though the concepts are difficult, lectures are great and grading is nice. You'll come out of it gaining more than you put in.

Take this class if you have an interest in philosophy - you will learn a lot about various influential thinkers and see how their thought has affected the way we think today. It's a huge amount of material in a short period of time so there's a lot more breadth than depth, but it's still good for understanding the philosophy of big names like Kant, Hegel, Nietzsche, Heidegger. Prof Pourciau is an amazing lecturer and very efficiently digests the primary material and presents it to the class in a palatable way. Eduardo is a great preceptor - funny and constructive - which made my 8am precepts a lot less painful. A good EC in which you'll learn a lot, but don't expect to get by easily or without some kind of angst/headache about the complex ideas you're grappling with.
Take this course if you are remotely interested in german philosophy. It's thought provoking and not an unbearable amount of work.

The material is challenging and it takes a while to get to grips with the philosophical concepts, but once you do it's really rewarding and Professor Pourciau is a great lecturer and is extremely knowledgeable, so you should go to lectures. Take it to learn about major trends in Western intellectual history.

Was originally going to PDF course but ended up not. It's possible to get a great deal out of it without doing the reading (which takes a lot of time and effort to make sense of), but doing the reading, even just parts of it, definitely gives you a more in-depth understanding and is really rewarding.
it's probably a pretty good EC.
descrip: An introduction to the German philosophical tradition from the Enlightenment to the present through the study of its major figures (Kant, Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, Wittgenstein, Heidegger, Adorno, Luhmann). This course offers a survey of German intellectual history, which engages directly and closely with the original texts. Domains to be explored include metaphysics, aesthetics, the theory of knowledge, political philosophy and philosophy of language.

title: Junior Independent Work
descrip: Subjects chosen by the student with the approval of the faculty for independent study. A written report, examination, or other evidence of accomplishment will be required. Students generally spend 15-20 hours per week on the independent project.

title: Studies in the English Novel - The Great Good Place: Modern Utopias
descrip: Utopias literally exist nowhere, but their moral and social hopes for an improved, ideally perfected Life congregate and are realized in a specific site: the Great Good Place. The phrase comes from the title of Henry James's only utopian fiction, in which "The Great Good Place" is equated with having "The Great Want Met." Our seminar explores the Great Wants that Utopian fictions at once acknowledge and hope to satisfy through their imaginative reclamation or transformation of place.

title: Topics in Automorphic Forms - Moduli Spaces of Vector Bundles
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: The goal of this course is to explain the proof V. Lafforgue's recent results on the global Langlands correspondence for reductive groups over functions fields. I also review some background material such as the affine Grassmannian, the geometric Satake correspondence and moduli spaces of G-bundles, G-bundles with modifications and G-shtukas. I assume that the audience is familiar with the material in Hartshorne's "Algebraic geometry" and Milne's "Etale cohomology".

title: The Classical Age
reviews: Good french class, attentive professor, fairly graded.
Take it if you like French plays... a lot!

This course facilitated a lot of interesting conversation and gave me a lot of insight into the literature's history as well as its cultural significance. Professor Schroeder did a very good job of engaging us and applying fresh teaching approaches to some very old pieces of literature, using blog posts, movie clips, visiting speakers etc., as well as good, old-fashioned group discussions.
prereqs: Prerequisite: a 200-level French course or permission of instructor..
descrip: A literary exploration of the 17th century, known in France as "l'age classique" or "le grand siecle." Readings include examples from various genres (comedy, tragedy, novel, poetry) with an emphasis on the dramatic masterpieces of Corneille, Moliere, and Racine. Through close textual analysis, we'll examine how these works give artistic expression to moral, social and religious tensions and conflicts which are both characteristic of their era and still unresolved today: passion and duty, self and society, conformism and heroism, truth and illusion, worldliness and transcendence.

title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory II
descrip: Macro implications of micro imperfections. The "cleansing" effect of recessions and the impact of allocative versus aggregate shocks. Recent models of consumption and empirical tests of risk-sharing. How the distribution of income or wealth affects aggregate growth and fluctuations. Role of imperfect credit markets, distributional conflict and political economy. Endogenous, skill-biased, technological change and human capital accumulation; implications for growth and social mobility.

title: Neuroeconomics
reviews: Absolutely take this course, especially if taught by Professor Niv, an icon in the field of Neuroeconomics.
Oral presentations are very important in this class.  I would not suggest this course to those who are better writers than they are speakers.
Prof Niv is easy-going, smart, and cuts away the extraneous and tedious tasks sometimes required in a class.
TAKE THIS CLASS!!! super awesome   super fun.  it doesn't entail a lot of work, but the work that it does is super interesting. prof niv is also great
Take it if you have the pre-requisites!
Take it!
Take it, absolutely excellent.
Take this course only if you have a background in neuroscience, or maybe economics--otherwise it is going to be very boring/over your head.

You can get as much out of this course as you put into it. It is not highly structured, so it is easy to lose focus at times, but if you are interested in the crossover between economics and neuroscience it is really the only course here that bridges that divide. Relatively neuroscience heavy, so do make sure you have some background in that. Also, Professor Niv is one of the up and coming greats, and this is an amazing opportunity to get one-on-one time and attention!
definitely take this class if you have a neuro background, would recommend but not strongly if you have an economics background.
prereqs: Students may come from different backgrounds, so we will not assume knowledge in economics, or a biological or psychological background. We will assume basic quantitative background (e.g., introductory statistics), and knowledge in either neuroscience or economics. Prerequisites: one of NEU/PSY259 (Cognitive Neuroscience), ECO310 (Microeconomic Theory) or ECO317 (Economics of Uncertainty) as well as one of PSY251/MOL355 (Quantitative Methods) or ECO202 (Statistics and Data Analysis) or equivalent..
descrip: This seminar focuses on the recent explosion of interest in understanding the neural basis of valuation and decision making, and the resulting marriage between the formal rigor of economics and the empirical basis of psychology and neuroscience, termed "neuroeconomics". We will approach the question of how the brain makes economic decisions from multiple perspectives, drawing on theoretical, behavioral, and neural data from economics, psychology, and neurobiology. Major topics include: decision under risk and uncertainty; the role of learning in evaluating options; choice mechanisms; and multiplayer interactions and social decision making.

title: Casting: History, Theory, Practice
reviews: take it
descrip: Casting - the process whereby actors are assigned to particular roles - has largely eluded scholarly investigation. This course enacts just such an inquiry through a survey of the history, theory and practice of casting within U.S. entertainment industries since the later nineteenth century. Course participants will trace the emergence of "casting" and the "audition" as discrete modes of performance-making practice through review of dramatic literature, "how to" guides and documentary films, as well as relevant scholarly and popular literatures.

title: Close Relationships
reviews: Always ask questions.
Attend all of the lectures because if you don't you will miss out on the most important and relevant information to your life.
Definitely take it! Professor Shelton is awesome and I'm sure most people will find the material relevant and interesting.
Definitely take it. You don't need Social Psychology at all (I didn't take it and felt very comfortable with the material). It's really fun and pretty chill.
Easy enough psych course but beware that you'll be in a class with a ton of pretty intense psych majors so it's not quite as chill as you may initially think.
I had to take this course because there was nothing else left for departmentals. If you tend to bore easily, this may not be the best fit for you.

I was a science major who needed an SA my senior year and was hesitant to take this class, but I'm so happy I took it!! It is so interesting, you'll find yourself talking about the class material all the time, especially with students who are not in this class.  You should take it!
Make sure to go over precept readings before the midterm exam! Professor Shelton loves to pull from them for key concepts and a lot of people didn't study them as well as they should have.
Super fun material and also really interesting! Good review of important social psych concepts you might have seen in 252. Also a lot of new stuff. All around good class!
Take it if you're interested in psych. If not, maybe avoid.

Take it! It is a very interesting course and is so applicable to everyday life that a person with any major can like it. Professor Shelton is a great lecturer, very clear, and her lectures are well organized.
Take it! Learn a lot and really interesting material!
Take it! The exams, assignments, and grading are fair and the material is really interesting.
Take it!!! This class is so interesting but not very hard
Take it. Super interesting and novel material in psych, although if you're used to taking advanced psych classes this one covers less material and isn't very hard.
Take this course! It is fun and useful information.
Take this course! It's a lot of fun and interesting material, and the exams are very straightforward

The course is fine. Lecture are sometimes interesting, sometimes boring. It's not a huge amount of work, and the work that is required is fairly interesting, so that might be the course's most attractive aspect.

The final paper can be a little overwhelming but this class is super interesting and totally applicable!!! The textbook readings are meant more for in-depth information, but I would recommend you read it because it is engaging! Also, go to lecture because it is one of those classes where you don't want to miss lecture!
This class was really fun and relevant to life. Grading is hard and nit-picky, though.
This is a good course, though Shelton's exams tend to be a bit harshly graded. Still, there's a lot of good stuff here and the lectures are very enjoyable.
This is a must take class!
Very fun and practical class. Not very hard either.
take it, not too hard and it's interesting
descrip: Close relationships are at the core of the human experience. You already have extensive experience with relationships of many sorts--family bonds, friendships, and probably romantic partnerships as well. The objective of this course is to introduce you to the scientific perspective on close relationships. You will learn how research psychologists apply the scientific method of data collection and analysis to investigate how people experience and think about relationships in general, and romantic relationships in particular.

title: Topics in 19th- and Early 20th-Century Music - Shostokovich
descrip: An exploration of the music of Dmitriy Shostakovich, taking into account English-and Russian-language publications of the past decade and newly available archival materials. The seminar addresses Shostakovich's political context, with an aim to unpacking reductive assessments of his relationship to Soviet cultural power-brokers, from Lenin's time to Brezhnev's. Class discussion had both a technical and aesthetic focus.

title: Qing History - Readings in Cultural History
descrip: Course explores the cultural, economic and social roots of Manchu political power in Northeast Asia on the eve of the conquest of China, roughly 1550-1644.

title: Vergil's Aeneid
reviews: If you're interested in world literature, take this course
Take it!!!
The workload is very manageable--only ~100 lines per class.

This class was excellent, especially with Emily Gowers as a professor, visiting from Cambridge. She was a pleasant presence in the classroom, with a sagely perspective on the machinations of Vergil's poetic mind. 
I highly recommend taking this class, with the caveat that you should expect to do all of the translation to do well. The quizzes test whether you remember how best to translate a passage you already read, not always your objective grasp of Latin in general. When you have 15 minutes to translate roughly 15 lines of Vergil, and you haven't done and reviewed the translation, you will undoubtedly make many mistakes in hastily analyzing the grammar and struggling to remember vocab that ends up being crucial to a correct translation. Nonetheless, never pass up the chance to study Vergil.
prereqs: LAT 203 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Books 1, 7 and 12 will be read in Latin; the entire work in English.

title: Readings in Chinese Literature - The Discourse of Nature
descrip: The discourse of nature constitutes an appealing aspect of Chinese poetry. However, questions such as how nature is defined and depicted, whose nature poets concern themselves with, and to what extent the discourse comes to be shaped by a literary trend remain unanswered. This course is designed to treat these questions in the broad historical and political context of the Disunion Period, i.e., third through sixth centuries, by delving into critical as well as poetic writings in the primary language. Traditional narratives on the representation of nature and the evolution of nature poetry are also examined.

title: Introduction to Asian American Studies: "Too Cute!" and the New Asiamania
reviews: A class in Asian American studies is generally worth taking because of the unique perspectives it uncovers on racial and ethnic dialogue in the United States. I would recommend having had taken a class on critical race/gender/queer studies, aesthetics, or literary theory beforehand, though.
Attend all of the extra-credit opportunities.

BEWARE OF THE COURSE TITLE. It seems interesting yes, but I have studied Japanese cultures and subcultures and actively participate in some of them and I would strongly advise against the course in its current state. This is not a good representation of many Japanese subcultures that exist and some "facts" are plain wrong. I would refrain from taking this course until a more qualified professor who is actually proficient in East Asian studies teaches it or it has improved dramatically in quality. Attendance dropped so much due to the quality of lectures that the professor was forced to implement pop quizzes in order to get people to show up. Not the best.
Best class I've ever had. If it is offered again you are very lucky and should definitely take it!

Definitely recommend. Very interesting topics thought about in an interesting way, will change your perceptions on cuteness and Asian Americaness in general. Very low workload but lots of stimulating material!
Do all the readings because they're pretty interesting.
Do it! Try to do the readings way before hand and ask your preceptor how they are relevant so you don't misinterpret things too far.

Do not get scammed by the cute sounding name of the course. It has surprisingly little to do with cuteness or Asian American studies. Most lectures just involve Prof Cheng throwing big nebulous concepts around without much attempt at clarification. Towards the end of the semester about a third of the people showed up for lecture - the prof had to resort to giving graded pop quizzes during lectures to get people to turn up. All in all, not much work, but a complete waste of time.
Don't take it if you want a course about Asian Cuteness. If you want to hurt your brain with the intricate details of aesthetics, objects, objectification, and affect, then go for it.
Don't take it unless you have to or are super interested in the topic.
Excellent intro to Asian American studies, for those interested!
Expect it to be harder than an introductory course.  Grading is a bit tougher than expected.
Fairly easy course. Just a precept response every week and a few short papers. The midterm paper also allows you to use a "creative non-fiction" prompt, which makes it a pretty good PDF.

Go to office hours.  Ask questions in lecture/precept.  Also, I would ask more about methodology in the course.  Start papers early and really challenge yourself, but make sure you are also organized in your presentation.  This is actually at times a demanding/challenging class.  The course does often suffer from disorganization.
How much you put into it is how much you get out of it; that said you can probably get by with doing little on a pdf. it's one of the few classes that's 'asian american'
I recommend this course.
I would recommend going to the preceptors more often for help on clarifying things because lectures and readings aren't always easy to understand.

I would recommend taking the class, especially if it's for a distribution requirement. It's definitely interesting, and writing the two papers isn't too bad. Definitely try to get into Professor Cheng's precept!

If interested at all, take it. If in doubt, take it anyway. There's so much interdisciplinary richness and real-life relevance to the course that it would be truly a shame for anyone even vaguely interested in the course not to take it.
If this is offered again, TAKE IT!
If you are interested in talking a lot and reading a lot
If you have an interest in Asian American studies, race relations, gender studies, or East Asian pop culture, take this class!
If you're at all interested in the subject material, take it. The professor is excellent. There's also a fair amount of African-American studies material.

Interesting course covering topics that aren't well-covered at Princeton. Wasn't as specifically focused on cuteness and Asian-Americans as I expected it to be -- the material from week to week sometimes seemed disparate and harder to connect to broader themes -- we but there were a lot of great readings and fascinating material in general.
It's a great SA that is interesting and unique!  Go in with an open mind and enjoy it!
Meh. It wasn't really worth it. It's not a bad choice, but there are better courses out there.

Not a very good class. If Professor Cheng is teaching it, don't take it. She is one of the worst lecturers I've ever had, and the course is not very well run/organized under her.

Shame, too, since this class could be so much better: there's definitely a "there" there in terms of interesting things to talk about, and cuteness is a great springboard for talking about them.
Not sure if this course will be offered again but I would recommend. Fairly light on work and interesting material.
Spend time on the papers.
Take it if you want a low-key, fun, not-too-substantial course.
Take it! It's great and it'll only get better.
Take it! and you will never look at pop culture the same way again.  I think it is courses like these that really represent what Princeton is trying to teach you (to have an open mind).
Take only if extremely interested! Keep up with the readings!
Take this course and go to lectures!

Take this course if you want to learn about aesthetics and endure a lot of technical readings. Otherwise, skip it. The Asian American experience isn't really talked about much, which was disappointing.

Take this for a fun perspective into pop culture, especially that coming from Asia, and even just things that you would find cute. This is a great class to PDF because the readings and videos are a treat from other work you might be doing. The discussions and lectures will help you think more critically about cultural products and even give you a nice introduction into film and art critique.
This class is more like an LA than an SA.
This was an interesting introduction course with great readings and movies. I'm not sure I would recommend it, though, since the format of the course was really problematic in my opinion.
Way harder than expected
easy class, not necessarily super interesting
i guess take this class Dowon Dan Kim
its a fairly easy course and it starts out interesting.
descrip: What does a minute and shallow category like "cuteness" have to do with a serious subject like race? This course offers an introduction to key terms in Asian American Studies through the lens of the seemingly insatiable American appetite for "Asian cuteness." How do we reconcile this craving with the history of anti-Asian sentiments in this country? Are other races or racial styles cute? If not, why not? We will explore cuteness as commodity, globalization, aesthetics, affect, and politics. Above all, we want to understand the relationship between race and style.

title: Projects in Instrumental Performance - Chamber Music
reviews: Chamber music is fun. Just make sure that your group members are all equally serious about it.
If you care about playing, do it with people who care as much as you. It's a great program.
If you want to keep up your chamber music chops, do it. But beware: getting others to rehearse and cooperate is a huge timesink and difficulty.
It will be quite different now that the Brentano are leaving, so it's pretty impossible to provide any meaningful advice.
MUS 213 is a really fun and amazing class, and it will be a bonding experience for all involved.
Not sure what MUS 213 will be like now that Brentano Strings leave.
So sad Brentano is leaving!

Take it for sure!
But don't think that just because it's a PDF it will be no work.
Take it if you love chamber music, and find great people and people you get along with to play with since you will be rehearsing for quite a bit.
Take it! The Brentano is leaving, yes, but next year's instructors will be great.
Take this course if you want to have fun playing chamber music with your friends!
The course will be different now since Brentano is leaving. But chamber music is definitely a must at Princeton!
This is such a wonderful course that challenges you to grow as a musician!
You get out what you put in. And you'll want to put in a lot. But it's fun!
idk what's happening to this class now that Brentano's gone.
if youre a serious musician take it - you also need to rehearse quite a bit considering you have to learn the entire piece in one semester

make sure your group members will be prepared and willing to make time in their schedule to rehearse, and stick to it, otherwise it gets to be a pain- but nothing at fault in the course or professors. it is a time commitment.
prereqs: Enrollment by application and audition. Auditions will be held on Tuesday, November 19, 2013, 6:00 - 9:00 p.m. in Room 102, Woolworth Center. Only complete groups may audition. No exceptions will be made for students abroad or absent for any other reason. Students will be allowed to receive credit for the course twice and to audit the course only once. (Signup sheet is on the Bulletin Board near Room 101 Woolworth.) Contact Gregory D. Smith (609) 258-6078 or gsmith@princeton.edu for further details..
descrip: Instrumental chamber music class of the standard repertory of the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries. Preparation for performance of ensembles. Each ensemble's repertoire will be determined in consultation with the instructors during the first week of classes.

title: Fundamentals of Nanophotonics
reviews: Even for the experimental guy, it's a great course, just take it
The exams are tough. Prepare yourself.

This course covers really cool material, but it's NOT for the non-mathematically inclined. This is a very hard math/physics class that is oriented for those interested in the field. If you are into to that, though (or are a graduate student in physics/ELE), I'd recommend it!
prereqs: Knowledge of basic linear algebra and differential equations at the undergraduate level is assumed. Prior knowledge of quantum mechanics is not required, but helpful..
descrip: Introduction to theoretical techniques for understanding and modeling nanophotonic systems, emphasizing important algebraic properties of Maxwell's equations. Topics covered include Hermitian eigensystems, photonic crystals, Bloch's theorem, symmetry, band gaps, omnidirectional reflection, localization and mode confinement of guided and leaky modes. Techniques covered include Green's functions, density of states, numerical eigensolvers, finite-difference and boundary-element methods, coupled-mode theory, scattering formalism, and perturbation theory. The course explores application of these techniques to current research problems.

title: Survival Analysis (Half-Term)
reviews: Do not be afraid! Do the work!
I would tell them NOT to audit it - you learn the most in this class by actually DOING the problems
Only take it if you are going to do demography or have specific plans to use the method.  Do not take as a general interest stats course.
complex but worth it.
prereqs: WWS 509 or equivalent.
descrip: Course focuses on statistical analysis of time-to-event or survival data, introduces hazard & survival functions, censoring mechanisms, parametric & non-parametric estimation, and comparison of survival curves. Covers continuous and discrete-time regression models, with emphasis on Cox's proportional hazards model and partial likelihood estimation. Discusses competing risk models, unobserved heterogeneity, and multivariate survival models including event history analysis. Course emphasizes basic concepts and techniques as well as social science applications. Half-course offered in first half of spring term.

title: Optics and Lasers
reviews: "Principles of Optics" is a very useful book to accompany this course.
This course is a necessary foundation for research in the fields of optics and lasers.
This course was not hard, and Julia is a very nice lady, but it was largely a waste of my time. She may improve with time.
descrip: An introduction to principles of lasers. Topics include propagation theory, interaction of light and matter, Fourier optics, and a description of operational characteristics of lasers, light scattering, and nonlinear optics.

title: Graphic Design: Circulation
reviews: Fun course, lots of InDesign.  It will take more time than you think it will if you haven't used InDesign before, but there were a variety of students at different levels in the class, so it wasn't too bad even if it's your first time designing anything.
Take this course if you have a chance and if you're interested in graphic design!!

This is definitely an interesting course to take if you have any interest in graphic design at all. You gain a basic sense of how to use InDesign. The projects can be somewhat time intensive depending on how engaged and detailed you decide to get with them.
prereqs: This course serves as a complement to VIS 214 Graphic Design: Visual Form and VIS 215 Graphic Design: Typography, but can be taken independently..
descrip: The practice of graphic design relies on the existence of networks for distributing multiple copies of identical things. Students in this course will consider the ways in which a graphic design object's characteristics are affected by its ability to be copied and shared, and by the environment in which it is intended to circulate. Through hands-on design projects, readings, and discussions, students will delve into different material forms of distribution - the public newspaper, the community newsletter, the course packet, the PDF - and investigate the particular attributes of each.

title: Born in the U.S.A.: Culture and Reproduction in Modern America
reviews: A great course! Do the readings, but class participation is the most critical way to get a lot out of the class. I also regret not going to more office hours. Professor Armstrong is very easy to talk to and receptive.

Absolutely worth it!  The readings are extensive and excellent; don't let the amount of reading be a burden.  The overall work level (papers, etc.) is quite manageable, and Prof. Armstrong really cares about each student.  We always got thorough feedback on all our written work.  If you're a male, please especially consider signing up--this class is not just for females!  I learned so much.
DEFINITELY take this class if you can! And do the readings - they're fascinating!
Definitely take this class if you are at all interested in the subject. Professor Armstrong is so nice and interesting!

I recommend that any student from any discipline or background take this course. All of us have unique relationships to reproduction, and I believe Princeton students could learn a lot about their existing misconceptions surrounding women's bodies and pregnancy/childbirth/motherhood by taking this course.

Just take it. (Even if you're a guy!) Professor Armstrong is beyond awesome! The multiple papers look like a lot of work but they're actually pretty short and a lot of fun to research and write. The readings are all really interesting and it's the only 3 hour seminar I've never once been bored in. Completely worth every hour of work you put in. It really challenged a lot of my world views and made me think about things I otherwise would have taken for granted-- and this is coming from someone seeking a GSS certificate who'd already thought a lot about issues around reproduction.

Make sure you are interested in the topic. If you are, its a great class! Participate in seminar. Go to office hours. Do the readings. It's not difficult to do well.

Boys should take this class too.
Take it!

Take this course! Professor Armstrong is so interesting and kind. Even if you think you know absolutely nothing about the subject matter (I didn't), you will do a lot of thought-provoking readings and learn a lot. Professor Armstrong is really knowledgable on reproductive issues in the U.S.
descrip: Reproduction is a basic biological process, as well as a fundamental one for all societies. While the biology of human reproduction is universal across time and place, cultural norms and social institutions powerfully inflect and shape the experience of pregnancy and childbirth in every society. This course investigates the history and sociology of reproduction, focusing on the contemporary United States, but with an eye toward other societies for comparison. How, why, and for whom does birth matter? How do reproductive practices reflect gender, race, and class? The course examines the culture, politics, and economics of reproduction.

title: The World of Late Antiquity
reviews: Be engaged and interested in the material, you'll get more out of it that way. Don't just read to gain knowledge for the exam. Read because you genuinely want to learn more about the late antique world. It's not a hard class. You'll enjoy it if you love to learn.
Definitely go to lecture - its worth it.
Definitely take it. It'll be one of the most interesting and fun classes you'll take.
Definitely take it. Tannous is the man. Not very difficult and extremely rewarding. Go to lecture!
Definitely take this class, even if you don't think you have an interest in it, you will be the end.
Definitely, DEFINITELY take it. Very good, manageable (i.e. easy) course. Try to get Tannous as your preceptor...
Do the readings (or at least a good portion of them) they are very interesting!
Do the readings for precept and show up to lecture.
Do the readings, they do supplement the lectures and precepts really well.
Don't skip a lecture if you can, and go to Professor Tannous' office hours as much as and whenever you can beyond the mandatory one.

Fantastic course for an HA - this course is a uniquely Princeton perspective on the late Roman era, and you read things that you'd probably never have the chance to look at elsewhere. Make sure that you go to Dr. Tannous's office hours early in the semester - not just once - he's so helpful and kind and willing to talk with you about anything from grad school to history to even compsci.
Go to Professor Tannous's office hours as frequently as possible. You will learn more in one hour with him than you will from most books.
Good stuff. Lectures are a bit of an information dump -- record them. Tannous is very clear about what's important information. Also, he's a boss in general.
Great class
Great course! Well worth taking just to have Professor Tannous.
I would definitely recommend that other students take this course!!!

I'd recommend taking this course unreservedly. I'm not a history major, nor was I especially interesting in Late Antiquity prior to entering, but that didn't matter--Jack Tannous is brilliant and a fantastic professor, and it is worth taking the class to interact with him. He's also probably going to be at the top of this field in 15 years, so that's cool too.
If you are a student that is not very into history but need an HA, take this class as Professor Tannous will show you how applicable history is to every facet of life.

If you are at all interested in this time period, definitely take this course. Personally, I did not find it to be the most interesting material, but Professor Tannous' lectures made it very engaging. This is a great, low-stress elective. There is a lot of religious history, so be aware that you will be learning a lot about early Christianity and Islam.
If you are interested in this topic, especially the historical foundations of Christianity/Islam, take it. Prof Tannous is amazing and one of a kind.
Jack is a really interesting professor and the tests are really fair and chill.

Late Antiquity is a good course, although I think it has been hyped up quite a bit. Tannous' lectures are good, and the grading is very easy. That said, Champlin's Roman Empire course overlaps quite a bit with the first half of the course. Also, prepare to read a lot of primary sources about early Christianity, especially saints' lives, which personally were not my thing.
TAKE IT! Tannous is a great lecturer and professor! you will love the class and it is not that hard either!!!
TAKE THIS COURSE

TAKE THIS COURSE!! this class is awesome, super interesting, and a minimal amount of work. you can get by by just doing precept readings and going to all the lectures/precepts. that being said, totally can go all out if you want. Go to office hours!
Take it
Take it if you are at all interested in the time period.
Take it no matter who you are
Take it!
Take it.  If you're interested in history, take it.  If you just need an HA, take it.  Such a good class.
Take the course. It's easy, even if you're not interested. This class is great for a pre-modern (or non-western) History requirement.
Take this class if you want an engaging and not absurdly time-consuming history class.
Take this class. Awesome HA with an awesome professor. The workload is very manageable.

Take this course! Tannous's is a truly amazing professor - engaging, funny, brilliant - and people in all departments love his courses! He refers to this course as the "No Stress Express," so you can be sure it won't be all that difficult, but will be very enjoyable!
Tannous is the man. He gives you the outline of the test beforehand, so if you don't do well, it's all on you. Super chill.
This course is great, especially if you are looking for an overview of a less well studied period. Tannous is great and is definitely worth taking a class with!
This is a good course. You're exposed to a new area of history. It isn't too difficult, but it is challenging enough to make sure you learn the material.
take it--it is great and very clear. if you work hard you can get a very good grade.
very fun class, does take some work though
descrip: This course will focus on the history of the later Roman Empire, a period which historians often refer to as "Late Antiquity." We will begin our class in pagan Rome at the start of the third century and end it in Baghdad in the ninth century: in between these two points, the Mediterranean world experienced a series of cultural and political revolutions whose reverberations can still be felt today. We will witness civil wars, barbarian invasions, the triumph of Christianity over paganism, the fall of the Western Empire, the rise of Islam, the Greco-Arabic translation movement and much more.

title: The Ethics of Reading V: Criminal Law and Criminal Literature
descrip: The seminar, the fifth in a series under the rubric the "Ethics of Reading," will inquire into the reading and interpretation of major documents from criminal justice in relation to literary texts and films that speak to similar questions. The course looks at stories in the law and about the law: court cases that turn on competing versions of a story, and how narrative "conviction" comes about, as well as fictional and non-fiction accounts of mystery, crime, investigation, and detection. The seminar introduces students to some issues in criminal law and procedure as well as to the analysis of narrative.

title: Musical Theory from the 18th Century to the Present - Music Writing by Nonspecialists
descrip: A seminar to explore the ways in which non-specialists may offer illuminating (or un-illuminating) commentary about music. Examples include diverse writings by Roland Barthes, Catherine Clement, Edward Said, George Sand, and others.

title: Desire and Detachment: Japanese Literature, 700-1700
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the Japanese literary tradition, with a focus on narratives of passion and renunciation. Love poems are found among the earliest Japanese writings, but they stand side-by-side with Buddhist-influenced works that stress the suffering inherent in emotional attachment. We will trace this binary of longing and denial through early folksongs, palace gossip, pious sermons, and ghostly pantomimes, against the changing backdrop of Japan's social and intellectual history. No knowledge of Japanese required.

title: Journeys in Portuguese: Studies in Language and Culture
prereqs: POR 109 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Designed as a journey through the Lusophone world this course seeks to present the Portuguese language in context by exploring historical, social, political and cultural aspects of Brasil, Portugal, and Lusophone Africa through the media, literature, film, music and other realia. Students will increase their fluency and accuracy in both written and spoken Portuguese, broadening their vocabulary and mastery of syntax through textual analysis, discussions, oral presentations and grammar review. An advanced language course and overview of the Lusophone world, POR 208 seeks to prepare students for further study of literature and culture.

title: German Intellectual History - Cultural Theory of the Frankfurt School
reviews: An excellent course to take if you are interested in twentieth-century cultural thought.

Anyone who skips over the Frankfurt School before graduation is missing a huge opportunity, particularly given the two professors teaching it. They are two of Princeton's finest pedagogues. As for the material, it by necessity extremely demanding of the reader. If you wish to be critical of the means by which your subjectivity is mediated by the modern political and cultural landscape, along with considering possibilities of preserving such subjectivity, which is relatively essential to the living of a meaningful life, then you ought to take this course.
Take it!
Take this class--it will teach you to think critically. And if you already think you know how to do that, that's the best sign you have that you need to take the class.
Take this course.

This course is one of those rare opportunities to go really in depth with difficult texts. If you want to really start to understand what these authors are saying, you should take it.
It will be a lot of work though.
This course is really niche, abstruse and the material is excessively hard to wrap one's mind around if one does not put in the hours...
descrip: This seminar will undertake an examination of the work of the "Frankfurt School" of critical social theory on questions of modern mass culture. We will focus on the textual debates between Theodor Adorno, Walter Benjamin, Max Horkheimer and Siegfried Kracauer on the complex relationship of aesthetics and politics. These often polemical socio-philosophical texts attempt to map a contemporary cultural landscape reconfigured by "culture industry," transformations in perception, the emergence of the mass, and new technologies such as the gramophone, radio, cinema, and television.

title: Principles of Quantum Mechanics
reviews: A great intro class in quantum. If for no other reason, take it for Sondhi's beautifully presented lectures!
Buy a book called "A modern approach to quantum mechanics" by Townsend to supplement the course. This book is very helpful in filling the gaps in Griffiths.
Do a lot of practice problems.
Doing the weekly readings before the lecture really helps.
Harder than 205, I thought, though interesting in its own right
I would not recommend this course unless it is a departmental requirement for your major.

I would recommend taking this class if you have an interest in quantum mechanics! Beware that it does require a lot of work, and the exams are difficult. Be sure to read the textbook before coming to lecture and to get your questions answered instead of letting the uncertainties build up.

If you are at all interested in quantum mechanics, I would highly recommend this course.  The only thing is to note that you will not gain a very deep foundational understanding of the subject.  The algebra can get obnoxious at times, but it is not otherwise very difficult.
If you're considering this course, you're probably a physics major with no other choice. Have fun!
If you're thinking about taking it, you probably have to. You'll spend maybe 15 hours a week on it, so be prepared to work.
It is pretty good
It's a very difficult course and I wouldn't recommend it unless you are genuinely interested in the material and have the proper time to devote to it (about 12 hours a week).
It's tough, but super interesting. Some people got it very quickly while others took a bit/much longer, but that's just physics.

QM is unlike any course I've ever taken, physics classes included.  It's different from pretty much everything I've ever tried to learn, and that alone makes it pretty challenging.  The math involved can also be quite challenging, if not for sheer difficulty than for sheer tedium.  Sondhi also teaches at lightning speed (to wit: most undergrad QM I courses teach roughly half the material we covered).  That being said, I'm glad I took the course (even if my sanity was a little compromised by it at times) and I definitely think I've gotten better at learning unfamiliar things in general after being thrown in the deep end with quantum.  Still, I wouldn't take it just for the hell of it--it's a pretty major time commitment, and not for the quantitatively faint of heart.
Sondhi is a very good lecturer. Psets are heavy on algebra.
Study hard, go to help sessions and spare enough time for psets.
Take it only if you have a lot of time to spend on this class. It takes a lot of time and effort.
Take it under Prof Sondhi. He is an amazing lecturer!
Take it!
Take this Physics class. It is not the easiest,but not the hardest either
The Psets take a long time so get into a group and start early if you can. Probably easier than Death Mech but similar feeling as far as workload goes.
prereqs: MAT 204 or MAT 217 and PHY 205 or PHY 207. If PHY 104, PHY 106, or ISC 234 have not been completed, one of them must be taken concurrently..
descrip: This is the Physics Department's introductory quantum mechanics course. Its intent is to present the subject in a fashion that will allow both mastery of its conceptual basis and techniques and appreciation of the excitement inherent in looking at the world in a profoundly new way. Topics to be covered include: state functions and the probability interpretation, the Schroedinger equation, uncertainty principle, the eigenvalue problem, angular momentum, perturbation theory, and the hydrogen atom.

title: Neuroscience and Everyday Life
reviews: Don't take this class if you think you want a neuroscience certificate because it does not count towards it. It is a perfect class if you need a lab credit.
Don't take this unless you want to take a fairly easy STL.

I'd recommend taking this course to anyone with even a passing interest in neuroscience. Just make sure to keep on top of the topics being discussed and stay organized, as there're a lot of things to learn.
There are better STL's. If you are interest in neuroscience, take a different NEU class.
descrip: This lecture and laboratory course will acquaint non-science majors with classical and modern neuroscience. Lectures will give an overview at levels ranging from molecular signaling to cognitive science with a focus on the neuroscience of everyday life, from the general (love, memory, and personality) to the particular (jet lag, autism, and near death experiences). The laboratory will offer hands-on experience in recording signals from single neurons, examining neural structures, and analysis of whole-brain functional brain imaging data.

title: Music and Power
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Economic Experience in Cultural Context
reviews: Be prepared to ask Prof. Lederman to clarify some assignments or readings, but everything is fairly straightforward or explains itself in due time. Take this seminar though! Lots of interesting discussions and a totally manageable workload
Kind of tough, but really rewarding discussions if you're engaged.  Workload isn't too heavy, its more of the concepts that can be tough to grapple with initially
Please do the readings and participate actively in class.

Take if you're interested in a different perspective from econ and finance classes. You have to be ready to see the world through an entirely different lens. Enjoyable class, relatively light workload, and a lot of cool info
Take this course. It will change the way you think about EVERYTHING in life. Seriously.
Unless you have a background in anthropology, the grading may seem a bit arbitrary. The "casual" assignments are not as casual as she claims, so put in a lot of care!
prereqs: No economics background is expected; a previous anthropology course is helpful but not required..
descrip: This course explores the social and cultural contexts of economic experience in the US and around the world. It considers how the consumption, production, and circulation of goods--today and in times past--become invested with personal and collective meanings. It pays special attention to symbolic and political dimensions of work, property (material, intellectual, and cultural), wealth, and "taste" (i.e., needs and wants). Additionally, course participants do a bit of anthropological fieldwork by learning to draw everyday experiences systematically into conversation with more familiar academic sources.

title: European Politics and Society in the 20th Century
reviews: A lot of reading, and be prepared to be put on the spot.
Be ready to read a ton
Concentrate more on the lectures and content given in class and pinpoint which readings are most relevant.
I wound up not going for the EPS certificate so I sort of regret taking the course. It's not a bad class, but nothing makes it stand out either.
None
Only take this course if you're interested in European politics and history. There is a lot of reading involved. If you have no background in European history, be prepared to work especially hard.
Take this class! Great thematic overview of European politics, not too much work, good grading structure for the class.

This course assumes a general understanding of European history and introductory political concepts (even if it says there are no prerequisites). Taught by knowledgeable professors and worth it if you're interesting in the topic, but be prepared for lots of reading.
take it!
descrip: The course aims to cover the critical developments of twentieth-century Europe and the consolidation of democracy in European countries. It will deal with the legacy of the two world wars, Nazism, Stalinism, the Cold War, the legacy of colonialism and decolonization, the birth and development of the European Community, the development of the welfare state, the problems confronting the European Union (immigration, enlargement, political institutions, military role, and the single currency), and the varieties of democratic institutions in Europe.

title: Advanced Programming Techniques
reviews: A good, practical course, but be prepared to figure a lot out on your own. It's probably good practice for the real world, in that way.
A great way to fulfill systems, and a great way to take a lecture with the man himself (assuming Kernighan is still teaching it).
Assignments can take a lot more time than expected
Be aware that assignments take longer than they say it will - especially using AWK. He might think it takes 5 hours, but that's because he wrote the entire language.
Be efficient
Be ready to work - the project always takes longer than you think it will.

Because you spend your own time reflecting and building a software course, the class is rather self-guided and self-taught, with potentially minimal teacher intervention. If you don't make good use of the professors and TAs, there's really no strong point in taking this class as opposed to going to hackathons.
Definitely take it. You'll learn loads of practical knowledge about actually building a real system, you'll hear great lectures by an amazing professor, and you'll make a great product in the end.
Definitely take this class! Make sure you choose your group wisely.
Definitely take this class, regardless of your major. Find a group early, decide on a project early.

Definitely take this course if you can. I wish I could take it again with a different project and thereby learn a lot more. 

Make sure that you have a firm project idea and a group in mind when you start - this will be really helpful in the long run. It's not a good idea to come up with the project idea during the course.
Definitely take this course! Best if taken with a group of friends who you want to work with and you have a basic level of programming skill in whichever language you're developing in.

Definitely take this course. Professor Kernighan is an amazing lecturer and very down-to-earth. He makes a point to learn everyone in the course's name and will greet you by name if you see him on campus. The software project has been the most rewarding project I have ever worked on. Through it, I learned many practical, real-world lessons, and I have also built something that I am proud of and will show to potential employers. If you can, try to enter the course with a group you'd like to work on the project with. That way you can get started earlier.
Definitely take this course; you'll learn some invaluable skills and have a great time. Prof. Kernighan is a great teacher.

Do this class for the project, not the lectures. I LOVED my group (we met through this class) and had an amazing time working on our final website. The first assignments really take a lot of time though. Highly recommended but don't expect much from lectures.
Essentially 100% of the learning you do in this class will be outside of the class, with no guidance.
Exciting class to take for the opportunity to make your own app/etc. Lectures are essentially irrelevant though.
Extra motivation to work on an outside projct

For someone who had no experience working on a group project in COS and making a product from scratch, this was a very time-consuming class. However, you have the opportunity to learn a lot, meet really great people and hang out with them ALL THE TIME under the guise of doing work, and create something you can be proud of. It's such a great class, if you're even considering it, try going to the first lecture and then deciding. Dang, so good.
Get started early on the final project

Good course, worth taking in order to complete a big project you can show your friends and employers. And to gain the skills to do that kind of thing, which is certainly useful nowadays. Take it if you want.
Good partners and time management is key.
Great course, very informative.
Have a bigger picture of your application. It'll help later.
Have the second half of your semester open for a lot of late nights. Find a group you can coordinate schedules with easily. Plan ahead. Modularize.

Highly recommend taking this class - Prof. Kernighan is great to learn from. Make sure to devote a lot of time to your project, and think about what your users will want to make your design decisions. Learned a huge amount from this class.

Huge time commit. Put a lot in and you'll get a lot out. 
Through this course, I've produced a project I'm not going to stop bragging about.
Will definitely improve your coding skills
I strongly recommend this course for people who are looking to build something substantive for the first time.

If you think you could be interested in creating web apps / work in a start-up in the future, this course is a must. Otherwise, it's a great choice (it was for me! I plan to go to grad school but I thoroughly enjoyed the course)

If you want to use computer science after college you really need to take this course. The project really gives you experience that you would not get anywhere else.  Kernighan is also a legend.  Must take for those majoring and those getting the certificate.
It's a good class, but not for the class. Helps you get both feet into the programming world.
It's only worth it for the final project. If you have enough motivation to do a project on your own, then don't take the class.
Know who you want to work with coming in. Ask for advice in dividing work and plan early.

Of course the project provides useful experience. The lectures aren't that helpful. You'll learn mostly by teaching yourself how to do things. It's really the whole point of college isn't it, paying lots of money to have people force you to learn on your own. Prof. Kernighan has many interesting stories to tell, as do the guest speakers. Start the project early, find a good idea early. Also the fifth assignment is a competition where you get graded against everyone else; don't even think about meeting the minimum requirements and calling it a day there, you will get obliterated by your classmates.
Only if you are sure you can pull of the project and have group members in mind. Otherwise it may be a bit of a struggle near the end.
Only take if if you have too. Learning python and some web development stuff was the only useful take-away. Then again, it is one of the better systems courses in COS, which are generally BAD
Pick project groups early. It's a very rewarding course.
Spend some of spring break on the project, and don't set goals that are too ambitious! Getting everything implemented is only a small portion of the project.
Start assignments early, the usual stuff.
Start the project early or you will regret it. Be sure to think about what you want to do early as well and find a good group of people to work with it on.
TAKE IT best COS class I've taken at princeton. It's an applications class disguised as a systems.
Take classes because of the instructor, not the title. Kernighan is an incredible professor, and you owe it to yourself to take this class if you think you have the programming ability.
Take it if you want to come out of Princeton having built an actual product using your COS skills.
Take it!

Take it! A good group is crucial -- use Piazza to find likeminded partners if you don't know many people in the course. Be wary of working with seniors who have thesis deadlines and don't contribute much to the project. :-/
Take it. It will be time-consuming when working on your project, but you will want to spend that time, so you know it's a great class.
Take this class if you meet all the pre reqs and have time to spend on a project--it's a great experience if you plan on using coding in your life after college.

Take this class, but it isn't that necessary. Probably the most valuable thing you'll learn is how to program in a new environment (for example, I learned web app development), see how apps are developed in a team, and get to know Brian Kernighan, but all in all it's not a bad course. The assignments in the beginning before the project begins are all pretty interesting (though some are a pain to figure out), but it's not anything that you wouldn't learn by building an app by your own or at a hackathon. The class is a decent amount of work (more than average, I'd say), so don't underestimate the amount of time you're willing to put in. However, if you want to learn a survey about all of the different languages and concepts out there (and not work on your 333 project in lecture instead), Brian Kernighan does a good job of explaining what they all are--you just won't necessarily get practice with them all on a weekly basis. Good class, but it's not necessary.

Take this course if you are confident about your COS skills. There is no hand-holding in this course; if there is a problem, you have to figure it out. That said, you learn in this course what you will never learn in other COS classes.
Take this course if you have any interest at all in programming. You'll know really fast if software engineering is right for you
Take this course! And get a good group for the project, and start early!

Take this course! It gives you great practical programming experience, you get to experience Brian Kernighan, and you come out of the class with a really cool final project that you can show off to your family/friends/potential employers.

Two caveats: I wouldn't recommend coming in right off of 217/226--get a little bit more programming experience under your belt before you attempt this course, because if you go into the project with absolutely no practical programming experience it will likely be painful. The other caveat is that you should probably have a group ahead of time, though you definitely don't need an idea of time.
Take this if you want to learn real-world programming.
The content of the course is essential for any cos major. Kernighan is a great lecturer. The first-half of the course consists of pointless and time-consuming assignments though.

The course was rewarding overall, but only because of the effort I put into it on my own. I got little from lectures, and the assignments in the first half of the course only taught me how to pound out Python/Java to meet the weekly deadlines. Also, the weekly TA meetings were not incredibly helpful. I feel that the course could be greatly improved by actually teaching us some web-dev, or having web-dev based projects in the first half of the course. Right now, 333 breaks down into two types of groups: people who come in knowing how to do web-development and who make a stellar looking project; and people without a ton of web-dev experience who are frustrated the class doesn't really teach you anything about web-dev. Take if: 1. you have a really strong idea for a cool project going in; or 2. you already know a lot about web-dev or are willing to teach yourself all about it.
The final project was one of the most rewarding things I have done as a COS major. Find a good team early and take it!!

The group project is by far some of the best COS work you can do at Princeton. The lectures aren't always relevant to anything, but are still generally interesting. Budget more time than you would expect for the early assignments, though.

The information in the course is good to know, but a lot of it isn't, and the lectures are mandatory...  Be prepared to spend a ton of time on the final project in the second half of the semester (start early).

This class is great. If you are interested in learning a very specific topic in depth, it may not be for you. However, this course is a very interesting survey of current topics in computer science. I learned many interesting tools for putting together practical, working projects. The final project was a highlight of my time in the computer science department.
This course is legendary. Take it. The programming assignments are meh but the final project is a fantastic experience if and only if you have the proper team so take this class with friends!

This is a must-take class for any student who is interested in building a rather complex project. Find a good group and pace yourself throughout the semester. Really start earlier. And don't take it if you have a senior thesis.
This is the closest you'll get to real-world software engineering here at Princeton.  Be prepared to work hard but have fun working on a project of your own design.
This is the course COS majors have to take. Building a product from the grounds up is a very rewarding process; plus, you get to learn about interpersonal dynamics, too.
This was one of my favorite courses I've taken so far at Princeton. Very informative, as well as a lot of fun.
This was such an incredible course! The semester project was one of the most rewarding things I've ever done, and it felt great to own a project...I learned more than I ever thought I would!
Though the lectures, assignments, and final projects are all disparate portions of the course, it's one of the best courses at  Princeton. The final project is a great experience.

Wonderful course, wonderful professor. Highly recommended! However, be prepared to spend a *lot* of time on the project. If you want your project to be polished, you pretty much have to start immediately, and by the end, you'll probably be meeting every day to get it done. That being said, it's a great and extremely rewarding experience, and you'll have a great project to show for it by the end, maybe even the next ICE!
Work in a small group on a project you're passionate about it. It's a great opportunity to pursue in-depth something you're interested in and is a major component of your final grade.

You get what you put in to the course.  The first five assignments re kind of boring and tedious, but you still learn a lot.  The project is an amazing learning experience.  Take it and work hard.  You will be rewarded.
You will get as much out of it as you put into it.

You will learn a lot when working on the final project.  Lectures during this time weren't very relevant so many students either slept during lecture or worked on their project during lecture.  Most people went to lecture during the second half of the semester because you might be randomly called to give an elevator pitch.  Overall, this was a great course!
You will work a lot.  You will learn a lot.  Take this class.
decent course. definitely do not feel like i learned much outside of the project, which is a disappointment. you get out what you put into the project.

definitely take this course if you're at all interested in building and coding something from scratch. there's so much more to be learned working on a full project than just doing cos assignments for a class - so worth it, so fun! try to come in with a group of 4-5 in mind.
great class with real development experience, although I found through this class that I don't want to be an engineer
learned a lot of real-world knowledge and approaches to problems
take it! but its a lot of werk :(
take it, it's awesome.
work hard on your project!  it's fun!
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: This is a course about the practice of programming. Programming is more than just writing code. Programmers must also assess tradeoffs, choose among design alternatives, debug and test, improve performance, and maintain software written by themselves & others. At the same time, they must be concerned with compatibility, robustness, and reliability, while meeting specifications. Students will have the opportunity to develop these skills by working on their own code and in group projects.

title: Gender and Development in the Americas
descrip: This course examines gender as an integral component of socio-economic development in the United States and areas of Latin America.
