We give attention to processes of industrial restructuring on a global scale that have increased the participation of women in the labor force and transformed men's employment alternatives. The relationship between gender inequality and social order is a central focus. We give special attention to liberal and Marxian approaches in economics.

title: Problems in Latin Literature - Maecenas and the Poets
descrip: We explore the cultural contradictions of the Augustan age through the textual traces of one of its most controversial and anomalous figures, the patron and statesman C. Maecenas. Reading Virgil, Horace, and Propertius, as well as Maecenas' own poetic fragments, we ask: how does Maecenas leave his stamp on Augustan poetry? how does he become the focus of contemporary ideas about masculinity, luxury, power, patronage, and freedom? how do imperial writers like Velleius, Martial, Juvenal, and Tacitus assess his influence? and what is Maecenas' legacy in later Western culture?

title: Vergil - Eclogues
descrip: After an introductory session on the pastoral, we will read the entire collection, reading each poem closely with attention to its relation to both earlier and later pastoral tradition. We will also explore issues of arrangement within the collection.

title: Environmental Law and Moot Court
reviews: Great course, great professor. A new angle on environmental studies, and a thought-provoking and interesting class. Be ready to defend your ideas, and come to class well-prepared.

I would definitely recommend this class. The workload is definitely manageable and evenly split throughout the semester, providing ample time to prepare for the large assignments, such as the moot courts and the final paper. I very much enjoyed working in a group for the moot court, while being able to show my personal point of view in the brief. This course provided a perfect balance. Finally, I would recommend this class to anyone considering studying law after graduation, as it truly introduces the basic skills and notions required for the legal profession.

If you're nervous about public speaking, don't let it deter you from taking this class. The moot courts aren't that bad. This class helped me realize that I really do want to become a lawyer--I enjoy writing briefs, preparing arguments, writing memos of law... really practical class to take if you're thinking of law school. Only downside, the people who take this class are pre-laws too, so the grading curve is hard.
One of the best classes on the subject at Princeton. Those with any interest should definitely consider it.
Take it if you're interested, but be prepared to work!

Take this class if you are:
1). Interested in going to law school
2). Interested in environmental policy

This class is fun in its structure but also really encourages one to think in legal terms, and engages one with writing and argumentation styles that would be present in the legal field.  Professor Hawkins is also very approachable and through the sharing of his experiences also gives students useful insights into what it means to practice environmental law and law more generally.
This is one of the best courses I took in Environmental Studies. Readings are doable and the material is really interesting! Also, George Hawkins is an awesome and experienced leader.

Very great introduction to thinking like a lawyer. Professor Hawkins does a great job presenting the course materials, and his extensive experience as the General Manager of DC Waters puts him in an unique position to bring unparalleled insights into the classroom. The mootcourts are also good practice for those considering law school.

You will succeed much more if you have a background in law then if you have a background in environmental science. That having been said, the course is accessible to all and is the right level of challenge. This should be a mandatory course for anyone interested in law school, and is one of the best elective classes I've taken at Princeton.
descrip: Examining the relationship between law and environmental policy, this course focuses on cases that have established policy principles. The first half of the seminar will be conducted using the Socratic method. The second half will allow students to reargue either the plaintiff or defendant position in a key case, which will be decided by the classroom jury.

title: Romanticism - Mil Huit Cent Trente
prereqs: Advanced reading knowledge of French. Open to Juniors and Seniors..
descrip: An Interdisciplinary approach to the cultural production of France in a year of revolutionary change. The focus is on the many important works of fiction produced in that year, seen in relation to each other and to the theater, poetry, painting, music and politics of one of the most significant years in French history.

title: Current Topics in Theory and Analysis - Composition in--The Academy?
descrip: In this "think tank," participants take turns as leaders and learners. Each student invents an ideal teaching environment designed to nurture the creative and intellectual practice of sophisticated graduate composers. Designers take turns as faculty, practicing what they preach by leading substantive inquiry in areas that concern and entice them. The beta testers are charged with impersonating real-life graduate students and creating situations that challenge their colleagues.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: This seminar is a continuation of CEE 509. Each student carries out research, writes a report and presents the research results. Doctoral candidates must complete this course one semester prior to taking the general examination. The total grading of the course will be 25% oral presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: 20th-Century French Poetry or Theater - Surrealism
descrip: This course examines the development of surrealism from its birth in Dada-infused Paris through its years of exile in New York to its decline after the Second World War. Materials considered will include literary and theoretical texts, visual works (including film), and magazines. The course will treat the topic at a variety of inter-related levels, exploring surrealism as part of the broad historical phenomenon of the avant-garde, examining its specific ways of (re)conceiving literature and art, and investigating the epistemological ramifications of surrealism's aesthetic, political, and moral positions. (In English)

title: Econometric Applications
reviews: Absolutely take this class! It's a lot of work but it's worthy to put in the effort. You will be a lot ahead when doing Senior thesis. Pauline is a great preceptor, I would not survive the course with her help!

Although the fact that I have not liked my experience in most economics classes might mitigate the impact of the following statement, I have this to say: This class is the most engaging economics class I have taken, and I felt throughout the course that what I was learning was actually applicable both in academic settings and in more general industry/public policy settings.
Decent class. Go to office hours and STATA sessions for extra guidance. This class will really teach you some great techniques for your JP/Thesis work.
Don't take it unless you're really interested in the material, otherwise it will be a slog.
Farber is great. Highly recommended.
Get ready to invest a lot of time into the homeworks.
Good. Take it.
Highly recommended

I recommend this course if you are working on an empirical econ JP/thesis. However, the lectures are not that great, and you will have to invest a lot of time in understanding the material outside of class.

I would recommend this course to any econ major as it is extremely helpful for independent work and you will get a lot out of it. Problem sets every week can be time consuming, but considering that's all the course requires (and no midterm; just a take-home final), the workload isn't too bad.

If you are planning on doing anything empirically related in economics (most econ majors do) make sure to take this class.  It is very helpful and you will leave feeling much more confident about STATA.
If you enjoy the data side of policy/economics, this is the best course to take at princeton. Completely hands-on.
If you liked 312, don't take this class. Otherwise, maybe still don't take this class.

If you're very interested in applied stata, take the class. I'd assume this is good for a JP or thesis or so. If you're interested in probability models and data analysis fundamentally, take a machine learning or at least a little more theoretical class.
It's a hard class

Junior or a sophomore majoring in economics? You HAVE to take this class. You are probably going to be doing an applied econometrics paper and this class gives you the tools to write a JP. Highly recommend sophomores to take it so you start your JP junior year knowing what's going on. Best part of this class? You'll be able to read an economics paper by say Alan Krueger and understand step by step what he's doing. Amazing MUST take course though the lectures can be quite unorganized.
Lots of panel data and labor. Very few theoretical extensions beyond 310/312.
Problem sets are very long; go to help sessions and you'll be fine. Course didn't live up to my expectations, but STATA skills are certainly valuable in preparation for thesis.
Start problem sets early. Pay attention in class. STATA help hours are very helpful, take advantage of them.

TAKE THIS COURSE if you are an econ major. Independent work will be SO much easier. I can't even imagine not having taken this course, because I've learned so much about the empirical methods of Economics research.
Take it if you want to learn how to really use Stata, but there really isn't much econometrics to the course.

Take this class if you want to gain a better understanding of Stata and how to perform good economic research. The case studies were really interesting and I definitely feel more prepared for my thesis after taking the class. Don't be put off by the time commitment for the problem sets, they're only once a week and you're allowed to work in groups and ask for help. There is also no midterm and just a take-home final, so the workload isn't terrible overall.
Take this class. Best Econ class I have taken in Princeton this far. The problem sets are not really that time comsuming.

This was one of the most useful classes I have taken at Princeton.  Absolutely take it if you are interested in econometrics at all or if you are an econ major.  It helps a TON with your  JP and Thesis!

You need to know a lot of statistics, as well as a lot of Stata knowledge. Because the class doesn't go over too much, if you don't really know how to use Stata, be prepared to figure that out on your own.

You'll learn a lot of econometric techniques. If you want to do well on the problem sets plan on a solid 6-8 hours a week on them, but they're doable especially if you get help when necessary from the preceptor.
prereqs: ECO 302 or ECO 312; Calculus..
descrip: This course provides hands-on experience in the art and science of econometric analysis designed to help students to acquire and master the skills necessary to carry out their own empirical research in economics. Various aspects of empirical research in economics will be covered including 1) development of testable economic models, 2) appropriate use of data, 3) specification and estimation of econometric models. A range of applications will be presented and discussed in class and on problem sets.

title: Introduction to Relativity
reviews: For AMO or CM people, good luck.  There is no good alternative for you in this class block.  I understand the department wants to expand what the students learn, but after talking with the 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 5th years in my lab, they all agree that they can't remember anything from this course, that is, it was a waste of time.
General relativity is a great topic and Prof. Pretorius teaches everything you need to know from an introductory  GR course. I recommend this class over the undergraduate version (AST 301).
I would recommend this course if you want a well presented basic introduction. I would say  that the first half of this course will be very slow to anyone who is familiar with vectors and tensors.
Take GR, but be prepared to work through problems in other books as well.
Take it because it's required
Take notes in class and you're good to go.
Why not dive into Einstein's mind to find that he had divined a structure meriting a century of study?
i hope you like gr
learn as much differential geometry as you can early.
read as much literature as you can along the class
take it.
descrip: This course gives an introduction to Einstein's theory of general relativity. No prior knowledge of general relativity will be assumed, and an overview of the differential geometry needed to understand the field equations and spacetime geometries will be given. Beyond this, topics covered will include black holes, gravitational waves, and cosmological spacetimes.

title: Interacting with Data
reviews: A solid introduction to machine learning, but not as glamorous as it sounds.
Although Blei isn't teaching this anymore, the course itself is very instructive. There's a bunch of overlap with other classes (such as AI), but Bleis' attempts to make it more unique succeeded.

Amazing course when taught by David Blei. It really is a shame that Professor Blei is leaving. I don't know anyone who could ever replace him and his masterful lectures.

Also, just a warning: the upside and downside of the course was that it was highly unstructured, in the sense that most of the marks came from open-ended problems.  If you don't like this sort of format, then you might take something like ORF 350 (big data) instead.
As taught by Blei this year, it was one of the worst classes I've taken at Princeton.

Avoid this class and probably any others where Xiaoyan Li designs the assignments.  The one real reason in favor of taking it, Dave Blei, is leaving the university.  Of course, that means that this course will change enormously the next time it is offered.
Be aware that some of the problem sets can be very time-consuming.
Be prepared for a lot of work.
Be prepared for some hard maths and stats, but it's a good class!
Be prepared to be creative; there are super open-ended problems, sometimes as general as "find some data and analyze it using methods from class."
Big time investment - lots of math and very little coding. If you take, fit your open ended set to the week and not to what you think you will actually work on for the final.
Blei abandoned us.
Blei is a great lecturer but he's leaving. Class is much more intense than first seems first few weeks. Possible to slide by with a better grade than deserved due to all graded assignments partnered.
Blei is an entertaining lecturer, but this class is boring. Also beware that you will have to submit something in 75% of the lectures.

Blei is an excellent lecturer, but he's leaving this year. Be careful: Just make sure that if you decide to take this class, the professor is actually coordinating with the person writing the problem sets.

Blei is leaving after this year, so take this review with a grain of salt - I expect that most of the problems with the course were a reflection of the professor.

This was a terrible mess of a course. The lectures were entertaining but entirely uninformative; I always left with the realization that I actually hadn't learned anything in the preceding 80 minutes. The readings helped to stay afloat, but the only way to do well on the problem sets was to have had previous experience with statistics and data analysis.
The problem sets were disjointed and used multiple different notations that we hadn't seen in lecture. When the problems were ambiguously phrased (which was often), instructors would give conflicting answers on Piazza as to which interpretation was correct. The problem sets were universally handed back way too late, and there was essentially 0 feedback on the open-ended section (50% of the grade). This was especially problematic because there was also essentially 0 instruction on what we should do for the open-ended section.
I had hoped that I would get a solid introduction to data analysis and machine learning. I had hoped that I would understand the algorithms we were taught. Instead, I learned the names of different functions in Sci-Kit Learn and got a vague sense of what type of data each technique is usually applied to.

Blei is leaving so not even sure if this will be offered. Regardless, one of the preceptors is really good (either sachin or rajesh, don't remember), material is definitely overwhelming if you have no probability experience. One little thing that I think can ruin your life is notation. Make sure you internalize it!!! A semester is too short to be wondering what all the letters stand for again? or is that a scalar or a vector?
Blei won't be teaching it next so it really depends on the professor... But this is cool stuff and every CS student should know about it.

COS 424 has been my favorite class at Princeton.  Machine learning is *so cool*.  Blei is a fantastic (and hilarious) lecturer, although he's leaving.  Lectures consisted almost entirely of derivations of basic machine learning algorithms on the blackboard, which I didn't really care much for.  At other schools, I think the machine learning courses are more applied.  Assignments consisted of a set of tough theory problems, plus an "open-ended" problem of the form, "take something we learned in class and apply it to a data set."  These were *really* fun to do.  (I'm biased, though, because my partner did all of the theory problems.)
Can't recommend this course unless it changes significantly (which it might since Blei is leaving). My year, it was extremely unorganized and lectures were terrible.
David is leaving, you don't have a chance learning it from him. Therefore this evaluation is not valuable at all.

Disappointing class, essentially all you end up learning is probability theory with a touch of machine learning. You do very little actual data analysis except for on your own in the problem sets, which offer next to nothing as guidance. There is also zero feedback on the open-ended part of the problem sets besides the actual grade you get on them. Unless you're looking for a class on probability, look elsewhere.
Do the readings early and try to understand them as much as possible. It's hard and slow!
Do your readings. Material is much easier to understand if you spend fair time going through the assigned reading.

Don't bother looking at previous versions.  If the class uses this format again, it's not as applied as previous versions.  Also, this class didn't have a webpage like previous versions.  No scribe, no PPTs, no handouts.  Everything was done over Piazza unfortunately.  I'd recommend taking something else in the AI requirement if this class keeps the same format.
Don't take it unless you want to do a lot of the work yourself.
Don't take this course unless you already know machine learning

Don't take this unless you really know what you are getting into. The Math is really hard at points. Interacting with data is unfortunately not as fun as it sounds on first hearing it. Everyone was so pumped about this class, but everyone was disappointed. IF you like the material, then I'm sure you will love it though. Just personal opinion.
Good course but fairly difficult especially if you are not a COS major and do not have strong math skills.

Good general data science course, but this class requires a lot of math (derivations). In terms of work, problem sets are entirely about probability theory with the exception of one "open ended" part where you apply a model to analyze real world data. Final project is an opportunity for working with real world data too, but you only get about 2 weeks to do it.
Great survey of a lot of practical topics in big data. Heavy in theory so if thats not your thing it might be tough.  More work than I expected.

I am a big fan of Blei, but not so much of the course.  Also, he is leaving after this semester, so it's hard to say how the course will be in the future.  Try it out and see how you like it.  There are probably better ways to learn machine learning.
I didn't really like how the class was run. I would have liked more structured precepts.
I don't think Dave Blei is returning, but it's a solid departmental class. Moderate-to-high amount of work.
I hear Professor Blei's leaving, but if he comes back you have to take this class.

I really liked the class. The huge size of the class this year maybe overwhelmed the teaching staff a little bit this year, and they were a little slow to get stuff back and whatever, which might be what contributed to what I'm sure other people will talk about as the disorganization of the class, but I thought the class was structured pretty well. The professor is very good at lecturing, the material covered is useful (as far as I can tell), it's not very much work (compared to other COS classes). It probably won't be your favorite class of all time, but it's pretty solid.

I would only take it if you had prior data analysis experience and were prepared to deal with a lot of uncertainty and confusion. You should have ideas for the final project or be the type of person who has a lot of ideas or really enjoys forging your own path, because you're not going to get much help. The homework problems are often extremely confusing and require good math skills.

I personally did not like Blei's lecturing at all, from his tangents about his personal life that had nothing to do with the material, to sometimes getting confused in lectures, to saying things to the effect of, "oh, it doesn't really matter, just do what seems right."
I would recommend making sure you understand the readings.
I'm not sure how the class will evolve without Blei.
If you are interested in the material, just get the textbooks and read them yourself. Coursera has courses that cover the same material better.

If you like statistics/machine learning, sure. I actually took this after taking ORF 350. Covers some similar topics, but keep in mind that a frequentist teaches ORF 350, whereas a Bayesian (though prof Blei is leaving for Columbia) teaches COS 424. 350 has frequentist stuff like asymptotic properties of estimators, 424 has Bayesian stuff like graphical models. Things might have changed, but some specific algorithm differences are: Discriminant Analysis in 350, HMMs and PCA in 424. I think it's worth taking both, especially if you enjoy this kind of stuff.

It is advertised as a COS class, but really it's about the math behind machine learning -- expect mostly numbers and symbols. I personally went in knowing I would hate the material, learned a whole lot, came out thinking "Ok that's done, no regrets (in retrospect, during was other matter), never again." The problem sets took time and were annoying, but I don't know if they will be characteristic of future courses.
It might be worth it to learn the theory, but I'd stay away until you see evidence that the grading policy has been improved.
It was a fun class! Prof Blei will no longer be teaching it next year, but I hope that the experience will be similar :) I'd recommend!
It's an ORF class disguised as a COS class. Take COS402 if you're looking for machine learning techniques instead.

It's not going to be with David Blei anymore, so most of these reviews are useless.  I had no interest in machine learning, so I didn't like the course.  R is horrible to use, the assignments were stupid, and the end of the year project was really annoying.  Hopefully a different professor can save this class
N/A

Over-hyped. Problem sets are challenging but also 50% of the hw is an open ended question where you make a model that relates to any topic in past week. I now know that there is an R package for everything.
Pretty dense course. Kind of interesting.
Put a lot of thought into your project and open-ended assignments to get the most out of this course.
Reasonable workload for a COS class (which is still a lot of work, BTW!!!) and what you learn in incredibly useful
Should take it. Will learn a lot
Since this is Blei's last year teaching this course, I can't really recommend for or against taking this class. If the next professor to teach it has good reviews, take it.
Start early on your final projects. Lectures are good, but readings are technical and difficult, as are the problem sets.  Not a good class if you have no background in statistics.
Start early on your projects. Be creative in your open ended problems (creativity and difficulty appear to be heavily correlated as far as grading goes).
Take ORF 350 instead, it's a much better course.
Take it. Too bad Prof. Blei is leaving this year.
Take this course, but it is advised to be prepared to do a lot of individual reading and studies to fully understand the materials.
Terrible, terrible course. I can't believe I wasted one of my senior spring classes by taking this. Blei's lectures suck, and you'll end up teaching yourself from the book/Google.
The course has very interesting material, but is poorly administered.  ORF 350 is probably a better choice.

The course was great through the covered material  - for each homework we had an open questions that forces you to come up with something innovative each week. Unfortunately the readings and the lectures were not the best mix.

The problem sets and readings were challenging and time consuming, but the material was interesting and useful. Part of the reason I enjoyed the course was Professor Blei and unfortunately he will not be teaching this again.

The reviews for this class in previous semesters have been fantastic.  I wonder what happened this time around that made things so much worse than previous offerings.

Blei is hilarious and makes lectures a lot of fun.  He's also incredibly bright.  That alone might get him good reviews this time around, as it has in the past.  However, the organization of the course this time around was terrible, and absolutely must be improved.

Problem sets were roughly biweekly, and had to be handed in in class just like the annoyingly trivial reading responses (most of which are not read by the course staff) since apparently none of the TAs have mastered email submission of assignments.  

The restrictiveness of having to be physically in class to submit homework is somewhat eased by "late days."  However, this highlights another problem with the class.  The material required to complete the problem sets was frequently not taught until near, or even after, the due date.  When emailed about these situations, Blei responded by asking not to be emailed about these situations.  He frequently had no idea what material was being covered in the problem sets at any given time, and explicitly said in class that his relationship to the homework was "fast and loose" as though that somehow makes everything ok.  This was only made worse by his frequent (still entertaining) tangents in class that delayed covering necessary material even more. (Also, as a courtesy to anyone who takes this class in the future, please save questions that are obviously outside the scope of what we need to know for after class - some students *frequently* asked esoteric questions on which Blei spent a great deal of time at the expense of examinable material.  Some students were so notorious that I heard people were actually playing drinking games in class, one drink per question from a particular student.) Consequently, students were often left with no choice but to use late days just to give the staff time
There really aren't that many overviews of machine learning offered here so if you're interested, definitely take the class. It's a fair amount of work, but you do learn a lot.
This class is JP/thesis in disguise.

This course has a structural issue: students come to the material from a wide range of mathematical backgrounds and computer science accumen. This course should require stronger probability background, or split into two or three subcourses that cater more to students abilities.
This course provides a really interesting opportunity to learn about machine learning!  However, since Professor Blei is leaving, the course might be different next year.

This course was a huge letdown--one of the most overhyped courses I've taken. The material felt like it overlapped in weird ways with so many other COS courses I've taken and Blei's lectures were quite poor. The assignments were disorganized and the expectations were simply never made clear.

This course when I took it was pretty terrible, largely because of the course organization. The assignments were vague and arbitrarily graded, the problem sets used confusing and conflicting notation, and the TAs were pretty unhelpful. However, if this class is taught by a different professor in a much more organized fashion, the material might be interesting.
This is a good course for learning basic machine learning algorithms and also a good practice for using them in real world problems.
This is a good course if you have a background in programming and want to get a general overview of machine learning theory and techniques.

This is one of the worst classes I have been in at Princeton. I have no idea why it got such good reviews before. What could have been a really interesting class was ruined by an utter lack of care for teaching on the Professor's part. Professor Blei doesn't pay any attention to what is on the problem sets, so we are often assigned difficult homework on material that has not been taught in class. No feedback is given on ope-ended assignments and the TAs can't even answer basic questions about the course material.
This was an enjoyable class, but the math definitely picks up on the 3rd and 4th assignments. Brush up on your linear algebra and be sure to find a good partner to work with!
This was an okay class.  It felt like towards the end, David Blei gave up.  The assignments are super vague.  It would have been better if there was more structure to the assignments.
Useful and fundamental. Everyone major in science should take it.
Useful topics, not so well taught
Very useful to learn modern approaches to analyzing big data sets and as a first step to building your own models for data exploration / prediction / classification.
Was a great course but Blei is leaving so no idea what will happen in future years.
You need fairly in-depth knowledge of multivariable calculus, linear algebra, and statistics.

You should have a strong math and probability background before taking this course. Lectures can be tough to follow and readings aren't very helpful. Take good notes during class, otherwise you'll fall behind. If you're interested in the subject material, it's worth taking.
You're too late, suckers.
did not live up to the reviews
go back in time and take this with blei
good class
open-ended questions are the best. spend time on them.
pretty good class
prereqs: MAT 202 and COS 126 or equivalent or permission of instructor..
descrip: Computers have made it possible, even easy, to collect vast amounts of data from a wide variety of sources. It is not always clear, however, how to use that data, and how to extract useful information from it. This problem is faced in a tremendous range of business and scientific applications. This course will focus on some of the most useful approaches to this broad problem, exploring both theoretical foundations and practical applications. Students will gain experience analyzing several kinds of data, including text, images and biological data. Topics will include classification, clustering, prediction, and dimensionality reduction.

title: Integrated Building Systems
reviews: TAKE THIS CLASS if you can.
descrip: An introduction to building systems and the methods of construction used to realize design in built form. First half of the course will be an overview of the primary systems, materials and principals used in construction of buildings and the fabrication of elements, through lectures and accompanying lab sessions. The second half will be an explanation of the means by which information is communicated from designers to fabricators, current standards in the practice of architecture, and practice's relation to changes in methods of fabrication and project delivery.

title: Intermediate Urdu II
reviews: Fauzia-ji is a huge sweetheart. The classes are often quite informal, but she is really a wonderful person with whom it is a pleasure to have class four times a week.
If you want to learn Urdu this is your only option, but thats OK, because its a great class.
TAKE IT! Fauzia is the best. She made my year so much better. The class itself is fun and interesting. You get out of it what you put in.
Take it!
prereqs: URD 105 or equivalent proficiency. See instructor..
descrip: This is a continuing proficiency-based course which refines and expands previously acquired linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Focus is on expanding vocabulary, mastering more complex grammatical structures, and acquiring idiomatic expressions. Use of authentic Urdu materials from print and electronic media, literature, and films. Equal emphasis on all skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing). Various aspects of the target language culture will be integrated with instruction. Activities will be conducted in Urdu and classes will be interactive.

title: Intensive Fourth-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews:
DO IT. This is the most fun I've had in a Chinese course. I feel like my Chinese level has increased so I can actually have FUN with Chinese. I also really loved the readings, and many of them resonated with me. Also, it was slightly less work than other Chinese classes. 

** However, Chinese 406 is designed differently every year, so I don't know if this class next year will still be a Theatre class.

I would give my highest recommendation to take CHI 406. It is one of the highest quality language classes at Princeton that you will ever take and reflects the excellence of the Chinese department. The teachers are dedicated, the homework is entirely worthwhile, the content (this semester it was plays, but it probably will change next year) was of the best quality and extremely interesting to study. If your goal is to continue to improve your language skills, communicate clearly and effectively using more advanced and varied vocabulary this is certainly the class to take. It is a commitment (probably not as much memorization as 405 was last semester), but you will not regret it if you have a passion for the Chinese language like I do.
prereqs: CHI 405 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Continued reading and discussion of scholarly writings on modern Chinese literature. This course also exposes students to the social issues China has faced in recent years, while discussing various aspects of contemporary Chinese society.

title: Oil to Ozone: Chemistry of the Environment
reviews: Do the Spiro reading--it is quite helpful. And go to precept.

For those with a good chemical background but little exposure to environmental subjects, it is a must. For non-scientists, also an OK choice as Morel is very good at clarifying complex subjects. For those in GEO or CEE, likely good as a bsaic class only.
If you are interested in the material, take it. It's a good class.

If you're looking for a doable science course, you've looked at the right one. Lectures are not helpful, but do attend because participation counts. Homework is straight forward. Do reading extensively for the midterm, but the final is entirely based upon the problem sets.

Not a GEO departmental, there are better EEB departmentals out there, and CHM majors find this too easy. The only reason you should take this is if you're pre-med or CBE and need a 300-level CHM class that's not orgo or p-chem, but even then, you may get more out of those classes.
Pretty easy, and the material can be interesting.
Should take this class
Take it! A very chill class and interesting material if you're interested in the environment.
Take the class if you are interested in the environment or if you are CBE looking for an upper level CHM
This class does not require a lot of work. My advice would be to go to all of the lectures. If you go to all of the lectures you will do well in the class, even if you don't do any of the readings.

This course is a haphazard and barely-rigorous treatment of many disconnected topics that may tangentially relate to environmental chemistry. The geophysical and societal components of the course are severely lacking; the chemical component is rigorous and redeeming but is disorganized and, I think, delves insufficiently into first principles and equations. Prof. Morel is a good lecturer and very funny, though his chalkboard writing can be hard to follow. His wife, Anne, who co-taught the course this semester, has none of the lecturing talent of Prof. Morel. I would not recommend this course as a first exposure to the topics covered, though it will be easy for those who have encountered the topics elsewhere.
You can learn about a lot of different subjects, but this class doesn't go very in depth into any particular one, which people actually liked.
You will be called on randomly in class; make sure to keep up with the readings.
take it
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 or equivalent. (Consult instructor.).
descrip: The chemical background of environmental issues. Topics include energy and fuels, global change, ozone, air pollution, chemistry of natural waters, pesticides, and heavy metals.

title: Science and Global Security: From Nuclear Weapons to Cyberwarfare
reviews: A lot of work! But you can get quite a bit out of it.
Ask preceptors about the homework if you're confused. Question the grading if you're not sure.
Definitely take it. Initially it appears as more math/science than I expected but it is very doable.
Equations are important. Memorize basic conversions: there's a lot of math and units in the class.
I PDFed, and it required a good amount work, but the course content was interesting. Good for people looking for a PDF-able STN.

I felt that the class was filled with students who were using the class to get rid of a WWS requirement or STN. There was a lot of apathy. The material is really interesting if you're willing to teach yourself.
If you have a friend who's good at math/science, get them to take it with you. Problem sets all on your own are hard.
Interesting course. The first half is definitely more math and physics based than I expected. Not as much policy based stuff
It's a good course to fulfill your Woody Woo STN.
It's a great overview of the major scientific issues relating to global security! The class has a nice mixture of quantitative and qualitative aspects.

It's a lot more boring than you think it would be.  Also, it's filled with Woody Woo majors which makes the class insufferable.  On the very first day, Glaser asked "does anyone know the speed of light?" to which no one raised their hand.  When someone finally did answer 20 seconds later, they got the answer INCREDIBLY wrong.  I can't believe there exist Princeton students that don't know the speed of light.

Lectures / material cover the science in more depth than the policy. I as a WWS major expecting a course on policy-related science got what I signed up for. A engineer friend of mine expected a course on science-related policy and was very disappointed. People with extensive science background will find the science simplistic as the course glosses over so much. The readings go into material in greater depth than the class (lecture, precepts, etc.) do, so they are rewarding on an intellectual level.

Lot of work. Be prepared to pull an all-nighter every week for the problem sets. It's inhumane that there are 100+ pages of dense, uninteresting readings each week on top of these problem sets. This course needs to be more organized (it was much more organized in the first half than in the second half.) There's a lot of math (although it's not too demanding) but the amount of creativity and outside-of-box thinking that they expect from you once they teach you the basics is kind of unrealistic. They just assume that since they taught you some basic concept about nuclear projectiles, you should then be able to apply them to solving creative problems that you've never really seen before. Some of the p-sets were so unnecessarily ambiguous (like the one on some Iranian nuclear plant where they gave us a document to go searching for details that they could've just given us straight up...Why were they even quizzing us on our ability to read and find details? Calculations should be the focus..) At least for consistency's sake, this course shouldn't be too different from what it was last year, but from talking to people who took this class last year, it seems like WWS353 became much harder this year. There are more p-sets, for example, than last year.  Anyway, this class is 80%+ woody woo majors who are taking the class for their departmental credit, so expect to put in a lot of work if you want to do well. Preceptors weren't too willing to help on p-sets (or at least one of them thought it was a good idea to tell us at the end of lecture to not expect help from preceptors the day before psets were due), and they (or at least one of them) became visibly annoyed when too many of us started asking for help. That shoudl've been indication that they were making the problem sets too ambiguous and time-consuming--really, they have only themselves to blame for us asking that many questions. The office hours for preceptors were pretty much useless because they were, for example, on

Take it if you can start the problem sets early and see where/when you need to ask for help. If you're a WWS interested in environmental stuff and only doing this because it sounds like a more interesting WWS STN than those other ones, I would say it's not worth it because this class draws more physics/math people than those environmental/disease courses and can make those more technical problem sets tough. However, it was harder earlier in the semester, so if you can handle reading period, stick it through.
Take it no matter what your academic background is. You'll find it a very rewarding decision.
Take this course! It's a great STN and the material is very interesting.
The course was very interesting and clearly organized.  If you are willing to do some basic math and critical thinking on science policy issues, it is very worthwhile.
This class is really interesting, but it focuses mostly on nuclear weapons, so the title is a bit deceiving.
This class requires a lot of work. Physics is also important, especially for the first half.

This is a great way to fulfill a STN but keep in mind THIS IS A SCIENCE CLASS. It's crosslisted WWS/MAE and the problem sets fit that mold: half quantitative and half free response. There were some epic moments in this class, mostly when it deviated from lecture format. For example, there was a climate change game one day and the last week was a MUN simulation of the Iranian Nuclear Negotiations. If you are not good at quantitative reasoning, you can PDF the class, but I do highly recommend it.

While the course requires you to do quite a bit of math, all of it is manageable, since the  focus is on knowing how to manipulate a given equation rather than on knowing how to derive that equation. Still, make sure to take advantage of office hours if you are able to do so. Also be aware that the majority of the class is focused on nuclear weapons and technology with less time spent on the other subjects. The members of the course staff were friendly and interactive components during lecture made it easy to stay engaged.

course covers a lot of interesting topics (about a half is spent on nuclear) that are relevant to society today. a lot of work every week though-a weekly blog post and pset. and midterm and final but no papers
this class sucks don't take unless you need the departmental/distribution requirement
descrip: This course will provide students with a basic technical understanding of some of the critical technologies that are relevant to national and global security and will equip students with the skills to better assess the challenge of developing effective policies to manage such technologies. Case studies will inter alia include nuclear weapons and their proliferation, nuclear and radiological terrorism, space weapons, biosecurity and cyberware.

title: Macroeconomic Analysis (Basic)
prereqs: Non WWS Graduate students should contact the instructor directly for enrollment..
descrip: Covers the theory of modern macroeconomics in detail. Focus is on the determination of macroeconomic variables - such as output, employment, prices, and the interest rate - in the short, medium, and long run, and addresses a number of policy issues. Discusses several examples of macroeconomic phenomena in the real world. A central theme will be to understand the powers and limitations of macroeconomic policy in stabilizing the business cycle and promoting growth.

title: Introduction to Kanbun
descrip: Introduction to the basics of reading Chinese-style Classical Japanese and its related forms. Texts: Literary and historical texts from both China and Japan.

title: Human Rights in an Age of Terror
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Design and Interpretation of Social Psychological Research
prereqs: Psychology graduate students only, or Instructor's Permission..
descrip: An advanced seminar that considers current research in social psychology. Contemporary research conducted by the seminar participants is discussed.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: An interesting course, mult choice exams require a good amount of memorization.
Definitely take it if you are interested in neuroscience!

Definitely take this class if you're interested in neuroscience! NEU 258 and this course provides a solid grounding in neuroscience (the first in physical neuroscience and the second in cognitive processes). However, be prepared to pay attention intensely during lectures as Professor Botvinick speaks very rapidly! Also, the readings are not really necessary, though there will be questions on the exams related to the readings.
Definitely take this course if you're interested in neuroscience in a more serious way!
Don't forget to keep up with the textbook readings. A broad array of information is covered in this class.
Don't take this class unless you have to.
Don't take this course unless you're deeply interested in neuroscience or have to to get a certificate.
Even if you're not Neuro/Psych, this course is really interesting and not a ton of work.
Go to lecture and just skim the textbook readings.
I enjoyed the course. Make sure you go to lectures, or get someone else to take good notes and share them with you for exams -- they are predominantly based on the lectures.
I liked 258 better. This was a decent course, but after taking it I decided I am not interested enough to get a neuro certificate.
I would recommend 258 over this class, unless you are getting neuro certificate. Lots of memorization and info

If you are interested in psychology, this is a better course than NEU 258.  Also more straightforward and organized (compared to Graziano).  Make sure you go to all the lectures and I would also recommend recording them and listening to them again prior to the exams - it helps a lot in studying.

If you have to take it, you have to; it's not that bad but in no way as exciting and interesting as NEU 258 taught by Graziano. If you're not pursuing a neuro certificate but just want to take a neuro class for fun, choose a different class!
If you like neuroscience, you should absolutely take this course!

If you take this class you will either decide that you love neuroscience and want to get the certificate, so you may do well, or you will be completely turned off from the subject and decide to PDF the course/flush you dreams of studying neuroscience down the john.  Botvinick was a horrible lecturer. I hated going to lecture, and precepts were not really interesting unless you liked the material. You will only do well in this course if you find the material interesting. If you don't, hey, that's okay! It just means that you neuroscience isn't what you want to study, and that's totally cool. If you do find the class material interesting and do well, you still might find the class setup to be poor, because it is; hopefully the other neuroscience courses in the certificate are more interesting.
Lectures are great, precepts are kinda useless.
Lectures are obviously the most important. The lectures follow the text pretty closely so if you miss something in lecture you can usually find the relevant information in the text.
Make sure to attend lecture! This is where all the info. is given.

NEU 259 is VERY different than NEU 258. It has a cog psych perspective (in part because neuroscience is a recent field), so just be aware of that. Also, precepts are not so great, and I've heard that labs are pretty cool, so choose the lab option instead!
Neuro is interesting. Not a ton of work, pretty cool topics. I found Botvinik less engaging than Graziano (from neu 258), but the material was still pretty interesting.

Only take if you are very interested in technical neuroscience or plan on getting the neuro certificate. Otherwise, there are other neuroscience courses to take that will be more engaging for a general audience.
Only take it as a requirement for the neuro certificate. There are more interesting STNs out there.
Pay attention in lecture.
Read the book
Read the textbook. Memorize lectures.
Take it for the certificate. There's not a lot of outside work or reading, but pay attention in lecture because that is the most important part of the exams.
Take it if interested. Botvinick covers a lot of material and does well to present it in lectures.
Take it if you are interested in Neuroscience and enjoy the journal articles.
Take it is you like neuroscience
Take it!
Take it! Neuro is super interesting and Botvinick teaches it well!
Take the class but its a little boring and not as magical as you might think in enlightening you.
Take this course. if you take good notes, it will go well :)
The course is incredibly interesting but keep in mind that it may feel repetitive at times if you've taken 258.
The topics are fascinating, and have a wide breadth, but the lectures can be a bit disorganized. Definitely worth it and necessary if you're interested in neuroscience.

This course is very interesting but it's a lot of memorization. You either know it or you don't on the exams. And there are only 2 exams: the midterm and final. Precept is worth 30% of your grade though and the preceptors grade the written responses fairly.
This is not a joke class.
Yea it's pretty good! Only if you're interested in continuing with neuro, because it gets into specifics that aren't really applicable to other departments

cog neuro is pretty bad...too much psych. bleh. not a rigorous treatment of the brain, but then it's the best we have. best to learn the material and learn it well, because neuroscience at the end of the day is a very young field.
do it if you're going for the certificate, but don't expect anything like NEU 258
nothing
prereqs: NEU/PSY 258 or permission of instructor.
descrip: An introduction to cognitive brain functions, including higher perceptual functions, attention and selective perception, systems for short- and long-term memory, language, cerebral lateralization, motor control, executive functions of the frontal lobe, cognitive development and plasticity. Major neuropsychological syndromes (e.g., agnosia, amnesia) will be discussed.

title: Imagining Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Comparative Politics
reviews: Do the readings, and remember that it's one of the most important parts of the course.
Get Marcus as a Preceptor

I loved this class because my level of engagement with it was very high. Do the readings and find things that are relevant to you so you can get as much out of the class as possible. I'm sure it is possible to not do the readings, but I learned so much from the readings that it would have been a shame if I didn't read them.
If they're interested in subject matter.
It's a great class and you'll learn a lot. I strongly encourage going to lecture because it makes a difference when studying and try to keep up with the readings because they are very relevant.

Make sure you do the readings and all of them. Take your time, do not just skim or even read, but actively engage with the material throughout the reading process to make sure you are comfortable with each of the academic debates implied by political scientist's papers.

Pretty easy intro politics class. Professor Pop-Eleches is awesome! Get in his precept if you can. As long as you do at least some of the readings and have a general concept of what a democracy is you'll really be fine. The Take home exam and a 10 page paper are a bit much though for the end of the semester
Stay on top of your reading and ask questions! Go to office hours too!
Take it
Take this course if you have a general interest in politics
descrip: This course surveys institutions of government and explores the role of government in economic and social affairs in developing as well as advanced industrial countries. The overarching theme is the relationship between capitalism, democracy, and economic development. The course also provides an introduction to the comparative method: using some major books in Comparative Politics as examples, we will explore how different scholars use cross-national comparison to gain insight into political dynamics.

title: Nietzsche
reviews: Fantastic intro to Nietzsche.  Leaves you wanting more.
If you can take only one course from the philosophy department, take it with Nehamas. It will change you life.
If you like Nietzsche, it's worth it. Can be hard to focus in lecture (because philosophy in general requires lots of concentration) but a good course.
If you want to free yourself from the human herd and learn how to develop your own style of doing things, take this class.

If you're even slightly interested, take it. This course was life changing and it opened my mind to new ways of thinking about the world we live in. Nietzsche is a phenomenal philosopher and everyone can learn something from him. Just take it, it's simply amazing.
If you're interested in reading Nietzsche and trying to work out and understand some of his arguments, take this class!

If you're used to a more analytic mindset like me, this class will definitely challenge you. Personally, I think Nietzsche himself, both substance and style, are shit. But the class was worth it because 1) Nehamas is clear and kind, 2) my preceptor Yoaav was energetic and approachable, 3) I was pushed beyond my comfort zone, and 4) the class had a generally good system of papers and readings.
Make sure to do the readings--you won't be tested over them but you'll get more out of the class.
Nietzsche's stuff is incredibly. Will make you see the world a different way

One of the worst classes I've taken at Princeton; certainly the worst in the philosophy department. Nehamas' lectures were boring and were even more confusing than the readings. There were a couple students in my precept who were both stupid and talkative (the worst kind, as I'm sure you know). It was a disaster every week. Also, this class feels a lot less like a philosophy class and a lot more like a literature class.
Philosophy majors should definitely take this course.
Read and think!
TAKE IT. Prof. Nehamas is awesome, and is definitely one of the premiere scholars of Nietzsche today. I'm sad I didn't take this class sooner.

Take it! Nehamas is an amazing lecturer. Even if you don't do the readings, go to lecture and you will get a pretty good understanding of the material. This also isn't as analytical as your typical philosophy class so even non-majors can enjoy this thoroughly.

Take it!!  The workload isn't crazy (three papers) and you can get a lot of help from preceptors (get Yoaav!).  Readings are interesting, Nehamas is friendly, approachable, and a great lecturer.  If needed, you can get away with not doing all the readings because Nehamas does such a wonderful job explaining it in class.
Take it, no matter who you are, you should take it.
Take it.
Take it?

Take this course with Professor Nehamas if you are interested in learning about Nietzsche. Nehamas is an extremely dynamic lecturer, and a wonderful and interesting man. He is always willing to help, and is so excited about the material. Nehamas' book, "Nietzsche: Life as Literature," was excellent. If you take the course, definitely read that as you go along because it's the most accessible of any of the material. Nehamas is the person from whom you want to be learning about Nietzsche. Get to know the professor!

The style of thinking that Nietzsche (and this course) prompts students to do is unconventional, sometimes frustrating, and not for everyone. I would recommend that students come to this class from an existing philosophy background OR an existing literary background.

This course was highly recommended, but I was disappointed. I am glad to have read a significant amount of Nietzsche, but I feel like the particular merit of this class is as captured by a reading of Nehamas' book, Nietzsche: Life as Literature.
This is a great course, if you are willing to do the reading and maintain an interest in the material.

You should definitely be open to reading and the grading distribution of the course is very similar to writing seminar, which I also took this semester with evenly weighted essays. Also, I would take advantage of office hours more to simply discuss the oftentimes complicated readings.
if you have any interest in Nitzsche takes this course. Nehamas is a great lecturer.
take this course! It's also not analytic philosophy, so even if you've never taken a philosophy course it's still amazing.
prereqs: At least one Philosophy course-not elementary logic. Freshmen admitted only after interview. Please contact Prof. Nehamas for an appointment..
descrip: An examination of Nietzsche's central views, including the role of tragedy, the place of science, the eternal recurrence, the will to power, and the primacy of the individual. We will also examine Nietzsche's ambiguous attitude toward philosophy and his influence on literature and criticism.

title: Theoretical Ecology
reviews: Be warned that there is a great deal of work - the course requires both an original group research project (with an in-class presentation plus a paper) as well as a three-hour final. Worth it, but a lot of work.

I took this course because it fulfills the Ecology requirement for EEB and I wanted to learn more about mathematical modeling. It was a pretty good class, but if you're just interested in disease modeling, you're better off taking Disease Ecology with Professor Grenfell. Sometimes Professor Levin is too smart to explain some of the more challenging concepts - it just seems obvious to him. The guest lectures are good - it's neat to see what other people in the department are doing with modeling. The precepts are really great. Overall, I learned a lot. If you are doing a modeling thesis for EEB, this is a good class to take.

Levin is an expert in this field and a good lecturer. This course a way to get a broad introduction to a large field and it's most useful if you're ready to do the readings and think a lot about the subject.

The best and most worthwhile EEB class I have taken. 
Take it even if you are intimidated by the math.
You need to go to lecture since this is where all the material for the course comes from. Math is not intense or anything, but there's a lot of it throughout the course.
prereqs: There is no limit on graduate enrollment..
descrip: Current and classical theoretical issues in ecology and evolutionary biology. Emphasis will be on theories and concepts and on mathematical approaches. Topics will include population and community ecology, immunology and epidemiology, population genetics and evolutionary theory.

title: Comparative History of Literary Theory
reviews: Incredible course, classmate, readings, discussions, and professor. Confirmed my decision to be a COM major. Sometimes I felt like there is nothing in the world of humanities that Professor Bermann doesn't know about. Take it if you are any sort of literature major, if you are interested in intellectual history, or continental philosophy. The readings in this course are fundamental to all three, and Professor Bermann was by far the best professor I have had at Princeton so far.

Professor Bermann is very interested in and knowledgeable about everything she's teaching! The class covers a lot in terms of moving through centuries, so you get a little bit of everything from ancient to modern. Take this class if you want to think and talk about poetry and writing and its purpose in civilization.

Stay on top of the readings, because this course is most rewarding when you can put the arguments of the various thinkers you will study in conversation with one another. If you're an English or Comp. Lit. major, this course is also great preparation for senior comps.
Take it as a sophomore if you're interested in Comp Lit--it might help guide your course selection throughout the major.
There's quite a bit of philosophy
This is a great course, providing a comprehensive overview of major Western literary theorists. The reading is not overwhelming.

This is a really amazing course and a great experience to have in a class-- the three hours were extremely enjoyable and the material fascinating. Do all the readings, read everyone's weekly blog post, and definitely take advantage of the class discussion. Just make sure you are interested in theory as it is not for everyone. But it is a very rewarding class to take.

This is one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton--Professor Bermann is amazing.  The amount of reading is generally manageable.  If you're at all interested in thinking critically about literature, take this course!
descrip: A historical introduction to literary theory, primarily in the European tradition, from Plato to the present. In our readings of philosophers, critics and creative writers, we will consider issues such as mimesis, imagination, religious belief, sexuality and ethics. Past terms and current problems are related to an inquiry into the nature-and the power-of literature through the centuries. Critical works from Plato and Aristotle, through Nietzsche, Beauvoir, Benjamin, Derrida, Said, Ngugi, and Butler will be read. Also poetry and plays by Sophocles, Shakespeare, Eliot and Brecht.

title: History of the Balkans
reviews: Highly recommend it!

Not only does this course go into great depth about one specific region of the world, but it also equips you with a knowledge about the broader study of history. You'll learn about the many ways in which historians "do" history -- through primary source analyses, book reviews, and original research. I recommend this course to anyone who is interested in the Balkans or the study of history in general.
Take it!
Take it. It's a small, engaging class.

The lectures were really interesting, as was discussion. Professor Greene is very insightful, although she is a little intimidating because of how much she knows and her critical and skeptical approach to "common knowledge" history. At times it was difficult to participate because I felt my comments were not insightful/"deep" enough. However, the class is fantastic, the readings are great, and she's a very personable professor.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: Southeastern Europe has always possessed a distinct regional identity. To say "the Balkans" is to conjure up a place that, while part of Europe, seems somehow apart from European history. What is it that has given southeastern Europe its distinctiveness? In this course we will answer that question by exploring the historical experience of the area stretching from Hungary to Crete, and from the Adriatic to Istanbul. We will start in the medieval period and take the story up until the twentieth century.

title: Integrative Advanced Japanese II
descrip: Four skills approach to advanced Japanese with a focus on reading, writing, speaking and listening.

title: Sociological Theory
reviews: Departmental, but PFK makes it chill.
Do the readings and go to lecture. It's a pretty stimulating course that covers a lot of interesting sociological topics.
Do you have a choice? I'm honestly not sure why you'd take this if you're not a SOC major -- but if you want to take this or SOC 101, I'm not really sure you can lose.
Don't be scared of Prof. Fernandez Kelly! She cares a lot about her student's investment and interest in her courses.
Go to all lectures and precepts.
If you take this class, do the readings and appreciate the lectures for their own value, rather than complete guidance for the course.
If you're a soc major, you have to take this. It's not a great class, it's not a terrible one.

If you're interested in being a soc major, absolutely take it! 
I would more likely recommend the professor than this specific course.
It's pretty easy but not exactly exciting.
It's very so-so. PFK is awesome but doesn't really teach the material.
Its required for SOC majors so take it.  PFK is hilarious and really cares about her students.  She gets a bad rap from some but I think she is pretty great.
Only really take this if you are a sociology major or really like PFK's teaching style. Otherwise, it is not really worth your time.
Only take this class if you are a Sociology student and have to as long as PFK is still the professor.
PFK is a lovely lady (she invited us to her house for dinner multiple times) and the opportunity to get to know her is a great one.  Her class, though, is one to avoid if you can.

PFK, who is a wonderful woman once you get to know her, said that she will not be teaching this course again next year. You will be missing off-topic lectures and quotes such as "I am not against the pleasures of the flesh, au contraire."
Read the material
TAKE IT! Even if you are not a sociology major, this class will help you understand what exactly are the main theories and theorists behind the field.
Take advantage of the resources PFK provides. Lecture is also quite helpful for main concepts!
Take this class!
Take this course! PFK is awesome and there is minimal work.
Take this course, go to lectures, and do the readings.  You will not regret it.
Try do the readings each week.
While the content is interesting and important to understand and know as a sociology major, it is frustrating to cover it in such a superficial, unorganized, confusing, convoluted way.
do not take this unless you have to because you're a soc major
i wouldn't recommend taking it unless you need to for the department or you are like really into sociological theory
prereqs: SOC 101.
descrip: This course invites you to systematically review foundational texts in sociology. Attention is given to the formulation of concepts, hypotheses, and research methods. We explore social structure and action; change and conflict; norms and roles; social class and stratification; deviance; and the link between micro- and macro-sociology. We also consider phenomena such as modernization, urbanization, migration, industrialization, and global capitalism. Why does theory matter to contemporary politics and policy? These are among the questions we ask.

title: Topics in Evolution (Half-Term)
descrip: This seminar explores the genetic and functional basis of pigmentation, exploring primary literature to understand the molecular pathways and phenotype impacts upon genetic and regulatory perturbations. Further, it expands to explore how this phenotype functions in an ecological framework (e.g. natural and sexual selection) alongside of biomedical implications of these same pigmentation genes (e.g. immunity). Students read and present papers central to pigmentation genetics and ecology. Class meets once a week to present and discuss the selected readings.

title: The Undead
reviews: Have fun.
Not what you think it is. Very metaphorical take on definition of undead.
Really fun class! Even as a non-English major I could still keep up with the work load and enjoyed our class discussions. Professor Chihaya is really engaging and thoughtful.

TAKE THIS COURSE!!! Especially if you're like me and normally are not very interested in reading Shakespeare or Victorian stuff or other traditional English class books. GREAT professor, and the readings are very interesting. DEFINITELY TAKE IT if you're at all interested in vampires, ghosts, or zombies.
Take it!
Take it.

Take this course (caveat below)! Professor Chihaya is easily one of the best professors I've had at Princeton! She's amazing, and the readings and discussion topics are really interesting. The grading is definitely fair. Probably not a class to take if you can't write a pretty good paper since that's most of the overall grade (fair grading is not easy grading). And maybe not a class to take if you don't have a background in or enjoy real literature, don't be fooled by the cool name. It's not all just Night of the Living Dead and Dracula- the readings are highly varied, with different kinds of poetry, novels, and movies. And this class WILL be mostly filled with English majors, so if you're not up to holding your own in conversation for three hours, pick another class. But if you're up to it, go for it! You won't be disappointed.
This course is definitely worth taking. Even though I'm not like particularly into the Undead in my personal life, like I dont watch those kinds of TV shows or movies, I enjoyed this course a lot.

This was not as focused on the undead as I would have liked, but for all my misgivings on the material, the course was well-taught and engaging. Chihaya is a very personable professor, and grades fairly.
descrip: The Undead are everywhere: on movie and television screens, in books, even in the academy. This seminar will explore the literature of the undead beyond commercially successful franchises like True Blood or The Walking Dead, from the 19th C. to the present day. Many questions are raised by these literary revenants: What do the undead do for us? What can they express or represent? How do these texts use the supernatural to address very human (political, historical, social) issues and desires, particularly in regards to postcolonial and minority discourses? Why are the undead so compelling to contemporary writers and readers?

title: Introduction to World Literature: Leaving Home Throughout the Ages
descrip: This course takes a cross-cultural and cross-temporal approach to the questions of exile and migration, following their depiction across centuries and continents in novels, stories, poems, and essays from both East and West. We will read classic works alongside contemporary novels, and narratives of homecoming alongside narratives of no return, always looking closely at the concepts of home, identity, language, and memory. As exile is a major theme of literature throughout the ages, this course serves as an excellent introduction to comparative literature and world literature more generally.

title: Tibetan Buddhism
reviews: Attend lecture and precept more, your teachers are your best resource.
Do the readings and ask questions!
Do the readings because they will help you in understanding the lectures better.
Do the readings, they will pay off for the take home midterm and final
Easy distribution
Engage with the readings by always asking questions, and bring those questions to lecture and precept.
If you do not the readings or attend lecture, the material can be a little confusing and difficult to keep straight. Definitely utilize precept as a chance to ask all your questions.
If you're interested, go for it -- it's pretty fun if you're into the readings and precept discussions. :)
It is an interesting EM. Definitely take if interested in Tibetan Buddhism
It's a very interesting topic and the course is fairly relaxed. A great EM.
It's an easy EM--take it
Its around a 1 hour time commitment outside of class and the papers don't take that long. Good fifth class!
Just make sure you understand the overarching topics and key terms.
Nice and interesting class, not too  difficult. Good way to get your EM distribution
Relatively straightforward EM, fairly interesting too.
Stay on top of the reading and read everything, making notes, and go to every lecture.
Take it for an EM for sure.
Take it if you're interested in Buddhism or Eastern thought in general.
Take it if you're interested in religion or East Asian cultures. We also talked about the Tibet-China conflict which was pretty interesting. I enjoyed it!
Take it! Great class and Gold is a great lecturer!
Take it!!!! Interesting subject to think about.
Take it.
Take this course. It taught me a lot. It's not wicked hard. You get out of it what you put into it.
This is a good class to take for distribution requirements. You get out what you put in.
This is great for exposure to other religions.

Try to immerse yourself in the material. Find topics that interest you and analyze them a little deeper. I did not do that very often, which limited my appreciation for the course as a whole. In the end, it's what you make of it.
easy. don't take for the lecture.
it's an easy PDF, but i was disappointed in the quality of the course.  may be more interesting to someone with no previous exposure to eastern religions.
take it if u need a farily easy religion or EM class.
descrip: This course is a survey of the Buddhist traditions of Tibet, focusing on the doctrines and practices associated with the main schools of tantric ritual and meditation. Topics covered will include: the origins of the distinct forms of Buddhism in Tibet; Buddhist responses to historical challenges; the special relationship between politics and religion in Tibet; the role of Tibetan Buddhist scholars and scholasticism; Tibet through the lenses of the Chinese, and the West; and Tibetan Buddhist art.

title: Chinese Intellectual History
descrip: Methods, sources, and problems of research in Chinese thought, including examination of some broad interpretations of intellectual development of China. A reading knowledge of Chinese or Japanese is required for the study of selected problems areas through seminar discussion, oral reports, and research papers.

title: Poetics - Towards a Prosody of Subjects: A Rhythm Party
descrip: In this seminar we will seek an alternative history of rhythm, approaching historical & disciplinary transformations in the meaning of this word in linguistics, philosophy, cultural criticism & the history of medicine, in order to open questions around the relationship of poetics to a politics of subjectivity & embodiment. Focus will be on the work of Emile Benveniste, extending backwards to Saussure and Marx, and forwards to Henri Meschonnic. Finally, we will look at some of Benveniste's late work from 1968-69Dernieres Lecons, and notes on Baudelaire, which extend his thinking on semantics, enunciation & subjectivity into poetry and poetics.

title: Risk Analysis
reviews: A lot of material is covered in a short amount of time, so brace yourselves to stay on top of your work all the time or you will get lost.
Be active and do the work. Its useful information.
Easy for ORFE

I highly recommend this course for all CEE majors. While it is theoretical, it's theory that adds a lot of realism to your course of study. All of our other classes tend to treat all structural parameters as constants, while in reality there is lots and lots of uncertainty in our world. This course will definitely greatly expand the way you think about structures and failure.
prereqs: Basic probability and statistics course..
descrip: Fundamentals of probabilistic risk analysis. Stochastic modeling of hazards. Estimation of extremes. Vulnerability modeling of natural and built environment. Evaluation of failure chances and consequences. Reliability analysis. Decision analysis and risk management. Case studies involving natural hazards, including earthquakes, extreme winds, rainfall flooding, storm surges, hurricanes, and climate change, and their induced damage and economic losses.

title: Physics of the Universe - Introduction to Theoretical Cosmology
reviews: A great class taught by two of the greatest figures in the field. If you're an undergrad but you have the background (say, AST 401), then you'll be in fine shape to take this course.

A great class to take with Spergel/Steinhardt, two really brilliant professors. However, beware that the class goes very quickly, and you will want both a background in cosmology and (as much as they may deny it) field theory if you really want to understand the material.
A must take if you are interested in cosmology.
I highly recommend it to students interested in cosmology. It can help to have some prior knowledge of the topic (AST 401 for instance).
If you already have some basic knowledge of cosmology this is a great course and I would strongly recommend it.

Put some time in with a few reference texts, since presentation matters more here than in many other subjects. Being on the cutting edge can make the learning curve rather steep, but both professors emphasized their willingness to discuss more fundamental things if necessary. Take it if you have any inkling of a future in cosmology for yourself.
Take the class only if you are going into theoretical physics or experimental/theoretical cosmology. It would be hard to follow otherwise.
The grading may prove to be harsh, but the lectures are fascinating and memorable.

You should really have taken a cosmology course (or have some other background in cosmology) before you take this, or else you might not get much out of it. That said, Steinhard and Spergel are amazing.
take it if you have a strong background in observational cosmology or a sincere interest in the subject.
descrip: The second semester of a survey of fundamental concepts in cosmology, designed for students who have taken a basic introduction (PHY 563, AST 522, AST 401 or equivalent). Course spans the leading issues in contemporary cosmology including inflation, the cyclic universe, baryogenesis, dark matter and dark energy, emphasizes the connections between cosmology and particle/string physics, and discusses the origin and evolution of inhomogeneities, their effects on the cosmic microwave background and large scale structure.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: Definitely take it. There's no reason not to. You get to write fictional stories about whatever your imagination can conjure up, you get good feedback from the professor and other students, and it's just a lot of fun.
Excellent. CVW is a gem.

I understand that they're changing the sign-up process for the creative writing classes, but I didn't look into what the changes are. If it's still some kind of line-based, waiting-based system, though, get in line extremely early, because this class is the first to go. I mean 4:00 AM, 5:00 AM.
