Bring an umbrella and a book and something to sit on (pad, collapsable chair) and others will be jealous of your prescience. The fainting-prone should bring a granola bar. You can probably also coerce others into buying you beverages from Wawa. Of course, if the line has been abolished, none of this advice is useful. Sorry!
Invest your time in this course if you want to get the most out of it.
Make sure you have enough time to devote to the creative endeavors so that you feel like you really made the class worth it for yourself. Also, do the short story readings, you won't regret it!

My recommendation would be to take at least one creative writing workshop during your time at Princeton, if only for the experience of discussing your writing critically with other students. It's hard to listen to people tear apart something you created, but it is also a useful process with results in both writing quality and writing process.

Prof. McGrath is excellent--gives really thorough feedback and is clearly passionate about the art of telling stories and spinning yarns! He's my favorite fiction instructor that I've had--I highly recommend taking this class with him.
Professor Eugenides is an attentive and insightful professor, and is otherwise a very laidback and funny guy. Don't be intimidated!
Take fiction at Princeton. It will change now just how you write, but also the ways that you read and think about your real-life interactions.
Take it if you're serious about improving your creative writing skills.
Take it.
Take it. Creative writing courses here are amazing and will help you in every subject.
Take risks in your writing. The feedback will be more beneficial if you put a lot of time and energy into your stories.
Take this class !!!!!!!
take it
yes
prereqs: Admission by application only and must have completed two 200-level fiction courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of fiction for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: The Dreamkeepers: Education Reform and the Urban Teaching Experience
descrip: See website

title: The Study of Comparative Politics
descrip: A general introduction to the field of comparative politics, with an emphasis on principal theoretical approaches and major problems and theories.

title: Queer Citizenship: Merging Theory and Activism
reviews: Do the readings and take the time to write a thoughtful journal response each week. Even though it seems long and even though the comments back aren't always what you expect, if you put something personal in your writing you will succeed regardless.
descrip: Is there a particularly "queer" way to be a world citizen? Does a queer perspective mitigate for certain forms of social, interpersonal or political action? Is a university education necessary, or even useful, for these endeavors? Does academic queer theory have any relevance to "real-world" LGBTQ activism? In this course, students will examine the connections and disconnects between academic work in gender and sexuality studies and the ways feminist and LGBTQ politics are imagined and lived within contemporary activist communities.

title: Intellectual History of China from the Ninth to the 19th Century
reviews: Absolutely take this course - I almost didn't because it seemed pretty esoteric and impractical, but it is actually SUPER relevant to all the big questions we ask about ourselves and the world. Made me rethink a lot of things about my life. Professor is amazing, readings are interesting, and classroom environment is very comfortable.
Excellent Course.
I would recommend this course to anyone with an interest in Chinese political and philosophical thought.

If you're interested in intellectual thought about governance, social conscience, and learning, this is a great course!!  Although China is the setting, the things we discuss are so applicable to anything in life.
This course presents a very good picture of the role for Chinese intellectuals in the ancient time. Professor Peterson provide very good guidance in both writing papers and methodological issues.
prereqs: A prior course in East Asian Studies is desirable but not required..
descrip: The course centers on the changing role of the intellectual elite -- how they were recruited, their relationship to holders of powers, their attitudes toward the past and their cultural heritage. The aim of the course is to provide a clearer understanding of the burdens and privileges of intellectuals in Chinese society.

title: Beginner's Greek: Attic Prose
reviews: Great way to get a lot out of an interesting, hard language
It might be more work than with other instructors, but you will learn more Greek than with anybody else. And you will enjoy it.
It's a lot of work, and requires a lot of review. But it is very rewarding.

Make flashcards and take notes on each lesson, on Thursdays after each week is over. It only takes around an hour to an hour and a half to sit down and consolidate each week's lesson, and you will thank yourself immensely.
Make sure to stay on top of grammar topics and vocab.
Take this course with Professor Haynes! She is a wonderful teacher who brings even Hansen and Quinn to life.
prereqs: CLG 101 or Permission Of Instructor. Greek 101-102 are a unit. Greek 102 must be taken to receive credit for 101. Greek 101 must be passed to qualify for 102..
descrip: Designed to enable the student to read classical Attic Greek with facility; at the end of the year short selections of Attic prose will be read. Equal emphasis on acquiring a vocabulary and an understanding of the structure of the language.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
reviews:
A lot depends on which group you choose to work with. In fact, everything depends on it, since each group is, in practice, run as its own separate course. Therefore, in reading these student evaluations, pay careful attention to what group the student is from, since you can essentially regard them as reviews of three different courses.

I joined the time team. It was a bit too easygoing - there wasn't much to do most of the time, and there wasn't much guidance on what to do. I personally prefer something a little more tangible and difficult, something that pertains to my ELE major. I would take it again in the future, but after seeing the end-of-the-year presentations from all the groups, I would join another team. (One of the group was designing motor control circuitry, which is something that pertains to my major and is a good practical experience!)
TAKE IT. Perfect as a 5th or 6th course. You will not regret it. Really fun and don't take up a lot of time at all.
Take it.
Take this as a great study break and time outside the classroom! It's fun to get to know other students in a hands-on project context and you work on very cool projects.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: The Soviet Empire and Successor States
descrip: This seminar covers the history of the Soviet Union from inception until dissolution and slightly beyond. The readings are exhaustive and comprehensive, with particular attention paid to institutions, empire, the cultural foundations of politics, and the world context.

title: Financial Modelling
reviews: A very good course for those who are interested in financial econometrics.
Even if you are interested in Finance and not Econometrics this class is worth taking (or at least auditing).
prereqs: ECO 525/FIN 525 and ECO 526/FIN 526 (526 may be taken concurrently)..
descrip: Advanced asset pricing and corporate finance including a selection from: models of financial crises and bubbles; interaction between finance and macroeconomics, derivative pricing in incomplete markets; tests of asset pricing models and associated anomalies; models of investor behavior; financial econometrics, including tests of asset pricing models and methods for high frequency data. Pre-requisites: ECO 525 and 526 (526 may be taken concurrently).

title: Modern Political Theory
reviews: Excellent course; interesting readings. Go to Professor Stilz Office hours if you have any questions. The readings can be dense sometimes, but they are also really thought provoking and applicable.

If you are a politics major, take this class. I can imagine it being one of the easier politics classes since there are only 3 assignments. Two 6-8 page papers and a final. The final is pretty lengthy. My year it was 5 short answer questions, 2-3 paragraphs each, and 2 essays, 4 pages each. Also, if you are interested in the many theories of why governments are formed, you should take this class. Professor Stilz does a great job explaining prominent thinkers like Locke, Rousseau, Mill, and Rawls. Also, if you have taken The Just Society take this class. The readings are almost the same and you will get pretty far if you paid attention in that class. This would be a pretty easy pdf class as well, except for the final since it was lengthy.
If you want an overview of the past centuries of thought on questions that are still important today, take the course.
Make sure to do the readings.
Stay ahead on your reading!

Take this course if you want to read really classic texts in political theory and especially the social contract tradition. The course spent quite a lot of time on each author so your knowledge about the texts and the author's philosophy will be more extensive than in a survey class. And Professor Stilz explained things very clearly and graded essays fairly as well.

This is a great course to take. You learn a lot about central political theory texts, you have engaging conversations about them, and the essays are graded at an appropriate level of difficulty. Challenging, yet engaging and educational.
This is an excellent course.  Essential for anybody who is interested in the social contract or an understanding of rights.
descrip: This course offers an overview of classic texts in modern political theory, focusing on the social contract tradition. Readings include selections from Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Mill, Marx, and Rawls.

title: Children's Literature
reviews: 100% take it.

A fantastic course. Definitely take it if you have the chance. I was at first a bit skeptical about what I would actually learn from discussing Children's Literature...but now having been through it I am very glad I took the class. Gleason's lectures are very good and you are foolish not to go to them (although you could still pass without going). You don't have to do all of the readings. Just pick a book from each half of the semester to read and really know well. Everyone likes this class for a reason. One of the best classes at Princeton.
A fun class that isn't a horrible amount of work. I highly recommend this to anyone.
A great course for someone who wants to pdf or for someone who is really interested and an English major! Great readings, such a trip down memory lane :)
A pretty good PDF class. The final was easy.
A very manageable PDF with moderate but fun reading.  Not a big step up to taking the class for a grade - the final was easy enough that I wished I hadn't PDFed.
Absolutely necessary to take before graduating.
Absolutely take it. No qualifications.
Appreciate it!
Awesome course. Be prepared for precept and spend some time on the papers, and you'll really enjoy this course. Professor Gleason gives great lectures.
Best course I've taken at Princeton-- definitely take it.

Children's Literature is a very interesting course. As someone who is not an English major, I learned a lot of interesting and novel concepts about stories written for children. It's changed the way I look at not only books but movies. Gleason is also a FANTASTIC lecturer. The way he speaks captures your interest; you need to make an active effort to get distracted during lecture. I was very pleased with the quality of this course.

DEFINITELY take this class. It's not hard, and the reading is light and fun. It is extra helpful if you have read some of the longer books before/read them ahead of time, since it can be a lot to do in a week on top of other work. The picture book unit tends to coincide with thesis deadlines, which is also really nice for seniors. Also depending on preceptor, you might have additional weekly assignments (like blog posts) but it varies.
DEFINITELY take this course!!! Everything about it was amazing.
DO IT
Definitely take it! an easy and engaging class
Definitely take it-- great lectures, fun reading, and not much work.
Definitely take it. Such a light work load and you get to write papers on Harry Potter and The Hunger Games.
Definitely take the course if you're interested in children's literature but keep in mind the essays are actually quite difficult.
Definitely take this class! It's a lot of fun and Professor Gleason is a great lecturer. You get to read awesome children's books and the work load is definitely manageable.
Do it! There is a reason for all the hype around it.

Don't be afraid of the "200 pages of reading", because those 200 pages will go by in a flash, and sometimes it won't even be that many. This class is really fun, and the professor is an amazing lecturer. Take it!
Don't dare miss lecture or surf Facebook during it - Gleason is one of the best lecturers here at Princeton and you'd have really dislike learning to skip his lectures for no reason.
Don't write it off as a joke class, not because it isn't easy (it is) but because there's so much you can learn if you just pay attention!
Easy and interesting. Take it.
Enjoyable reading and great lectures!
Fantastic class to PDF. Great lectures, great readings and a very manageable workload. You must take it!
Fun reading, great lectures, pdf it though
Gleason is a great lecturer and the readings are fun - great to read the Hunger Games for class instead of dry readings! A nice break, but still intellectual.
Go to lecture and actually listen
Go to lecture! Most of the learning is done there.
Good class! Great for semesters where the workload will be intensely high. This was a really nice class to just relax with and enjoy. I used my readings in this class to procrastinate on others.
Great P/D/F for senior spring. Would happily take it again. (FYI, the standards to get an A are exceptionally high, at least compared to every other course I've taken at Princeton)
Great PDF, interesting material.
Great class for seniors, careful of preceptor, make sure they're engaging
Great class to PDF.
Great class to take: fun, interesting, but not too hard.
Great course, particularly if you're a second semester senior looking to PDF or just take a fun and engaging course
Guys, it's kiddie lit.  If you have the opportunity to take this and don't, you're wrong.
Hands down best course I've taken at Princeton.
Have fun with it but also don't be afraid to think about these classic children's books in new and even critical ways.
Highly recommend it if you have any interest in children's literature.

Honestly, don't take this class if you actually care about children's literature or want to learn much. The precepts will occasionally be interesting, if you're lucky, and the readings are wonderful, but the lectures devolve over the course of the term until you're just watching YouTube clips for 80% of the lecture. And your fellow students won't care at all, which is demoralizing.
I PDF the class, so if you are looking for a good PDF this is one. Readings are very enjoyable, essays are very fair, and the final....we will see on Friday.
I didn't PDF it and they aren't the easiest graders on papers but definitely a must-take.

I didn't enjoy it as much as I thought I would. Some people were craaaazy about the lectures, but I just didn't dig them that much. They were entertaining, but not that insightful. Good class to pdf though.
I enjoyed this class.  Not an unreasonable amount of work and reading kids books is relatively fun for homework.

I highly recommend taking this course to anyone with an interest in children's literature. My advice is to put your best effort into the precepts. The more you discuss and develop your arguments in class, the more you'll get out of the course and the better your papers will be.

I loved this class! This knowledge may not necessarily be "useful" in a sense, but it gives you a completely new way to look at some of the books you may have read growing up. I loved taking a break from my other classes and reading Alice in Wonderland or A Little Princess or re-reading Harry Potter. There are two papers and a final exam. We also did two small short "papers" in the middle for the a digital archive of ABC books, but that might not be there next time the course is offered because we were kind of "testing" the site.
I would advise them to take the course and do the readings because the final is more difficult than anticipated
I would strongly recommend, but try to switch precept if possible early on if you don't like it.

I'm not sure if this semester was an anomaly, but the grading of the first essay was harsh, in my opinion.  Don't know about grades for the second paper which haven't been released yet, but maybe they'll smooth out the grades when they don't have to give comments and things are more "behind-closed-doors."
If you can get Gleason, I'm sure he would make as good a preceptor as he is a lecturer. If not, it's probably not worth your time.
If you love to read, are a bit nostalgic about your childhood, and want a great professor who can share fascinating perspectives, absolutely take it!!!
If you want to take this course, pdf it and enjoy the lectures (which are awesome) and read the books for pleasure!
It is an enjoyable class, but not for intellectual reasons. If you are looking for an easy class to with fun reading and fun lectures (although not that instructive) I recommend this class.

It really depends on what the student is looking for when choosing a course. If you're looking for an easy class to P then this is probably a good choice. That being said, I often felt that my time was being wasted in this course (even though I only wanted the P) and wish that I had chosen something more intellectually stimulating and useful.
It's Children's Literature.  It's lots of fun, not too much work (2 papers   final exam), and the readings are great.  It seems pretty difficult to get an A, but getting a B is pretty simple.

It's a big class, so you won't get much attention. However, the lectures reveal adult perspectives on children's literature, which juxtaposes the students' experiences of reading the kids' books in their childhood - which I found intriguing.
It's more work than you would imagine if you do not intend to PDF the class. Nonetheless, interesting material and great professor--lectures were always interesting!
Lots of fun, well worth taking.
Make sure you get a good preceptor and come to lecture! The lectures are seriously the best part of the class!
One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. TAKE IT! Try to get Matthew Harrison as a preceptor too. He is incredible!
PDF this course? Take it. Gleason is SO clear and the material is so interesting (analyzing harry potter as an adult is VERY interesting)
Please take before leaving Princeton.
Professor Gleason is a gem and lectures make these readings that you've all read before all a child so much more interesting than you could ever imagine. Meagan Wilson was a FANTASTIC preceptor.
Professor Gleason is great. For those not used to writing English papers, keep them focused, grading is harsh.
Read everything! It's worth your time.
Recommended.
Select your precept carefully!
Start early on the papers.
TAKE IT

TAKE IT! Even if you end up PDF-ing it, go to lectures, read the books! Definitely something where putting in a little effort goes a long way. So rewarding/exciting to think about what the changes in kiddie lit/YA fiction mean in re: to our changing views of childhood. I want to write kiddie lit now!

TAKE IT!! It is a very interesting class and not too difficult. It is a great supplemental course especially for seniors also working on their thesis. Professor Gleason is very interesting to listen to in lecture. He was also great in a sense that he scheduled the non-intensive reading materials at a time that the seniors were working on finishing their thesis. Again, I say take it!

TAKE IT.  It is interesting.  Do the readings and put in the time to really glean something from the material.  It's very easy to pass this class without appreciating it.  Don't do that!  Take it all in.
TAKE IT. Professor Gleason is best lecturer I've had here at Princeton. And the course itself is amazing.
TAKE IT. Seriously. Take it.

TAKE THIS CLASS!  Seriously.  If you enjoyed reading as a child, and are willing to listen to analyses of the books you've read before, you will love this class.  Professor Gleason is awesome and is always excited about what he is teaching.  The homework (readings) feel like a study break rather than homework.  Go to lecture - they are interesting and you learn a lot more from them than you could from just the minimal slides Professor Gleason posts.  Great class!
TAKE THIS CLASS. It's a great class and worthy of everyone's time.
TAKE THIS CLASS. so great

TAKE THIS. I had a ton of fun and actually learned some things too. Relatively easy way to get an LA out of the way. Advice: do the readings, keep runnings lists of important concepts, characters, etc.-- the final had IDs and concept definitions.
TAKE THIS. SO FUN. it's just so chill and really fun.
Take Kiddie Lit! It's one of the best courses at Princeton, regardless of your major.

Take class if you want a pretty interesting course on children literature theory but also not have to put a ton of time in to do the readings. A little difficult if you try and take it for a grade but P/D/F is really easy option.
Take it
Take it and go to lecture!
Take it and write.
Take it as a PDF for LA
Take it for an easy PDF
Take it if it is offered! The class gives you a different perspective on the books that you read as a child.
Take it take it take it

Take it take it take it. Professor Gleason is an amazing lecturer, and it's really fascinating to study the development of children's literature as well as critically re-examine many of your own favorite childhood books. Readings were always fun and assignments not too difficult and well-explained in advance.
Take it when you can!
Take it!
Take it!  Definitely one of those classes that every Princetonian should take.
Take it! And ask Prof. Gleason which precept he's teaching. Go to all the lectures. You won't get what you need to know just from the slides.
Take it! Don't half-ass it though, even if you're PDFing. It's an amazing course if you take it seriously!
Take it! I didn't PDF and still had a lot of fun and learned a lot.

Take it! If PDFing, you'll basically just be reading easy and fun texts and thinking critically about them, and the final exam won't be hard to prepare for. If you aren't PDFing, quite a bit of review and preparation is required.
Take it! It's so chill! Professor Gleason is an amazing lecturer - take it for him.
Take it! So fun.
Take it! Though a little more work than you might expect
Take it!!
Take it!!!
Take it!!! Also, go to lecture because they are very interesting and stimulating.
Take it, but be warned it is very hard to excel on the papers and exam without a look of work and studying (unless you are an ENG major and know exactly what they are looking for).
Take it.
Take it.  It's awesome.
Take it. Seriously.
Take this - super easy PDF and not too difficult to get a good grade in otherwise. The final is minimally stressful.
Take this class if you need another. Perfect PDF course

Take this class! It is so much fun and Prof. Gleason is clearly passionate about the subject. Lectures are really engaging and entertaining while still presenting interesting ways to look at the readings. If you need a literature class or just want to take something fun, this is a great option for you!
Take this class!!! One of my favorites at Princeton, and Professor Gleason had a lot to do with that.
Take this class. Not too hard, the readings and assignments are fun, the lectures are really engaging
Take this course - it's a lot of fun and Professor Gleason is an amazing lecturer.
Take this course and go to lecture for sure.
Take this course before you graduate!
Take this course! A lot of fun.

Take this course! It is not only a lot of fun, but also incredibly challenging and insightful. Prof. Gleason is brilliant, and his level of enthusiasm and respect for his students make this class one of the best that I've taken in my four years here.
Take this course!!!!
Take this course, but keep in mind that that grading is rough
Take this course. One of my favorites at Princeton
Take this course...there's a reason that the course has over 400 students.  The reading is fun to do, and lecture is captivating.
Take this if you can!!

Take this with Professor Gleason - he truly makes this course amazing. It's definitely an excellent course to take senior or junior year when you have a lot of independent work. It's not easy and trivial, though, it's just so entertaining and interesting you'll want to do the work.
Take. Very interesting ride down memory lane.

The lectures are so entertaining and fun; in my opinion the lectures make the class worth taking. If you're taking the class just to PDF it and not go to any lectures, you're missing out on the best aspect of the course. That being said, a pretty easy course to PDF.
The readings and lectures are great. Papers are pretty standard and the exam is fine. Not too much work overall, so why not?

The readings are very fun. Early lectures provide a lot of useful insight, though later lectures tend to be more about just plot summary with a few observations thrown in. A pretty easy English course if you need one.
This class is a lot of fun, and not too much work.
This class is fun, but hard to find the so what factor

This course is a lot of fun! I was worried that looking at my favorite children's books critically might ruin them, but it doesn't at all! Looking at the craft and writing style that made these books so successful just made me appreciate the magic of them even more.
This course is a must take in Princeton. The readings are fun, Professor Gleason is one of the most passionate and enthusiastic lecturers, and the preceptors are great. Definitely do it!
This course is an excellent one if you're looking to PDF it; the readings are not very heavy at all and the papers are relatively short.
This course is awesome. Take it.

This course is is cool and easy and lacks depth. I didn't learn much, but I had some fun reading novels and writing about them. I also learned some tiny insights about children's literature in general. That's about it.
This course is worth it for the lectures alone, but I think I would have had an even better experience had I been placed in a different (and more organized) precept.
This is a great PDF course. Otherwise, it has lots of topics that are fun to learn about, but difficult to write about. If you want an easy LA for a grade, take another class.

This is a great class I would recommend to anyone. It's kind of a Princeton staple. Be warned, though, it's definitely not an easy class, especially if you are not PDFing. The work is held to very high standards and requires real engagement with the text. While the reading is easy (because it is meant for children, for the most part, after all), the work required of you is not quite so simple.
This is a great course. The work load isn't terrible, and the readings are interesting. Would definitely recommend if you need an LA.

This is a really fun class. You will get to read books which are inherently enjoyable through a new lens which will give you new insight into them. Do all of the readings, because this will make writing the papers and studying for the exams more manageable.
This is an incredible course. If you have the chance, do not pass it up, particularly with Professor Gleason teaching.

This is an interesting, easy class.  Not every single lecture/ book is super duper fascinating, but overall a solid class with easy papers.  There are great overarching themes to the course - I learned a lot about what children's literature is in general, and how the genre as a whole changes over time.  Good choice for senior spring and PDFing.
Very serious topic.  Will require 100% attention at all times.  Not for the faint of heart.  Definitely not something that you can just PDF as a joke to free up time for a thesis or JP.
Why are you reading this? You know it's great. Take it! :)
Worth taking as long as you are ok with an easy, enjoyable class where you learn, but what you learn isn't necessarily relevant to anything you will do after Princeton.
YOU MUST TAKE THIS COURSE! IT IS ONE OF THE BEST, IF NOT THE BEST, COURSE AT PRINCETON! TAKE IT--WHETHER YOU'RE A FRESHMAN OR A SENIOR! TAKE IT!
You can slide in this class, but you'll enjoy the lectures more if you keep up with the readings.
You get to read children's literature for homework! (And gain interesting perspectives on it.) Take it!
You read Harry Potter.  That's all that matters.
Your experience in this class is dependent on your preceptor-- choose wisely
sure.
take it
take it for fun!
take it, p/d/f it
the only class worth buying books for at Princeton because you can hand them off to your children.
typical eng class. (a joke)
descrip: A survey of classic texts written for children from the past 200 years in (primarily) England and America. We will examine the development and range of the genre from early alphabet books to recent young adult fiction. We'll try to put ourselves in the position of young readers while also studying the works as adult interpreters, asking such questions as: How do stories written for children reflect and shape the lives of their readers? What can children's literature tell us about the history of reading, or of growing up, or of the imagination itself? In the process we will consider psychological and social questions as well as literary ones.

title: Econometrics and Public Policy: Applications: Basic (Half-Term)
prereqs: WWS 507b.
descrip: Provides hands-on experience in the application of econometric methods to policy issues. Various aspects of empirical research in economics will be covered including 1) development of testable hypotheses, 2) appropriate use of data, 3) specification and estimation of econometric models. The course will be taught using a set of cases in which students apply quantitative methods covered in WWS 507b to data in order to answer specific policy questions. Emphasis will be placed on interpreting and writing about results.

title: Elementary Korean II
reviews: Go to office hours.

I recommend Korean if you are looking for an easier alternative to Chinese or Japanese here. The only issue is that if you need lots of thought-provoking work to keep you motivated, you might need to find those qualities yourself?
I would definitely recommend taking this course. Make sure to use the language outside of class!
If you are interested in Korea/Korean culture/the Korean language, take this course! It's a lot of work, but it's so interesting (Korean is a fascinating language) and you get so much out of it.

If you are looking for a fun language course to take, consider Korean! The workload is easily manageable if you do a little bit of work every day, which is something you'll have to do anyways for learning a new language.

Probably the most fun introductory East Asian language course. Classes are often supplemented with clips from K-dramas and shows. Instructors are extremely helpful in and outside class. Regular (and frequent) homework but work load should be no more than any other introductory language courses.
Take it if you're interested at all in Korean!
Take it if you're interested in Korean!
Take it! The material is incredibly interesting and fun. It's a really reasonable workload with a great payoff.
Take it!!! It's so much fun! :) The homework, quizzes, assignments, and exams aren't that difficult. Both professors are amazing! Plus, spring term you get to make a music video for fun.

The curve might be a little hard, but that's totally in line with other Princeton Intro language courses. You should definitely take this class if you're any bit interested in Korean language/culture/history!
The professors are great people and teachers, but be sure you're ready to make the one-year commitment before enrolling in the 101/102 sequence.
prereqs: KOR 101 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 101. Continued development of proficiency in basic communication.

title: Introduction to English Literature: 14th to 18th Century
reviews: As an English major, I can happily say take this course, but in all honesty, the people who will take this course and be excited about it are the people who are required to take it- English majors. If you're not considering an English major, there are probably more interesting English courses out there for you. That said, Sophie Gee is incredible, so I think it's worth it just for that.
Be prepared to engage with the reading, because some of it is difficult but getting through it makes the class much more interesting

Best way to be exposed to some of the most important books in English history (even if difficult and boring at times). Prof. Gee is a great lecturer and when else will you get a chance to read Paradise Lost cover to cover.

DON'T take it if your only reason is to get the requirement out of the way. The material is dry and you might not get an exciting precept, and it might discourage you from pursuing English as a major.
Definitely take it if you are into being creative and literature.

Do not take this unless its a requirement for the english major. There are far more inspiring and interesting courses on this material if you are looking at this out of general interest, and the course is not easy.
Do some readings over the summer to get a head start!
Do your readings!
Don't take it unless you have to.
Go to lecture, you'll enjoy it.
Go to lecture-- though you don't necessarily need to know lecture material to write your papers, it can definitely help guide your thinking and you absolutely do for the final.

Go to lectures!! Professor Gee is hilarious and snarky, definitely knows her stuff, and is able to present insights into the text and their literary context in ways you won't get elsewhere. Also, she has an Australian accent, and that's really cool. Some of the texts themselves can be a bit difficult to get through, but lecture and precept are so much more worth it if you do, so try your best to stay on top of it. And have fun! There's a lot more humor in the reading than I expected, and Professor Gee highlights that really well.

I can only speak from an English Majors prospective but nonetheless it's a great course. If Sophie Gee is teaching it, do not fear ENG 200 as it has become of the best classes I've taken here at Princeton.
I would definitely recommend this lecture course. I would advise people try to get into Sophie Gee's precept, though.
I would really recommend this class actually for anyone interested in English whatsoever.
I would recommend this course to anyone with an interest in English literature.

I wouldn't recommend taking ENG 200 as a first English class. While lectures are interesting, an English seminar gives students a better idea of what sorts of interesting discussion can take place in literary studies.
I wouldn't take class to satisfy your LA unless you're genuinely interested in English. However, if you are interested in English, take this class! Sophie is wonderful and it's a great class.
If you are interested in a liberal arts major, this class definitely teaches you about close-reading and other important skills.
If you have to take it, take it. If you don't, probably don't take it.

If you're an English major, you have to take this class, but for non-majors, I recommend choosing a more engaging literature class. If you want to get really deep into dense material like "Paradise Lost" and "The Faerie Queene", go for it, but if you don't, stay away.
If/when you take this class take it with Prof. Gee.
It's a fine prereq, might be too much for a casual course or LA
It's definitely a class that challenges you, even as a prospective english major.
It's hard, and a lot of reading-- recommended for English majors.
It's really interesting and Sophie Gee is AWESOME, just tough if you are not an English major.
Keep up with the readings and start your assignments early!

No, do not take unless you are committed to be an english major. If you want to be an english major, take it your senior year. This course amy deter you from majoring in a wonderful subject with a wonderful department.
Obviously make sure you do the readings, and practice analytic reading before the lecture on the readings if you can.

Obviously, you'll be reading a lot in the course, but take the time to really enjoy the texts you encounter. Who knows when you'll have an opportunity to revisit them. Actually GO TO LECTURE, because they're pretty good and Professor Gee will bring very interesting insights to the readings.

Only take it if you're willing to do a lot of dull readings. This is a class you should take because of the subject matter, but you will be bored at times. Not a bad class, but not the best English class I've taken.

Professor Gee is charming and the readings are great for understanding the history of English literature, but the workload is distributed pretty unevenly throughout this semester and grading varies a lot depending on the preceptor. Don't do it if you're not an English major.
Push through the beginning. You'll be glad you took the course by the end!

Standard advice: Do all the reading. Start the papers ahead of time.
Even if you're not an English major, the reading for this class is wonderful and it is literature that everyone should read! And Professor Gee's lectures are amazing.
The readings are good, but only take it if you have to for the major. Get Sophie Gee for your preceptor.

This was my first English course at Princeton, and I loved it. I think it's also great if you're considering an English major because you talk a lot about literature, narrative, storytelling, and representation as topics in themselves. (I personally am leaning more and more toward English after taking this class.) Melanie is a great preceptor.
do reading
prereqs: First-year students welcome. English 200 is a prerequisite for entrance into the Department of English..
descrip: An introduction to the leading figures of earlier English Literature, including Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, Milton, Pope, and Swift; to literary history as a mode of inquiry; and to some of the questions that preoccupy English poetry, prose, and drama across four centuries: art, beauty, romance, desire, the will, the mind, God, sex, and death.

title: African Vampires, Zombies, and Other Political Phantoms
reviews: Come with an open mind and if you are really interested in the subject.
Concentrate on finding an argument for your papers because that's what Prof. Belcher looks most critically at.
Definitely take this course if you are at all interested in African literature or film!
Maybe the class was not as good because this was the first year the course was taught. Perhaps it will improve in the future.
Take it take it!

This class is great if you want to read books and films about a topic that is completely different. The discussion style of this class was great and allowed for many different ideas to flow. The papers are not too demanding, make sure that you take advantage of Professor Belcher's office hours and run your ideas by her beforehand so you can find out what she thinks. There is not really a dull moment in the class and Wendy Belcher is amazing!
descrip: In this class, we will explore literature and films about African vampires, witches, zombies, mermaids, and ghosts as a way of thinking about how Africa is constructed in the global imagination as well as how African and African diasporic artists use magic to analyze the dynamics of power. In this interdisciplinary anthropology, political science, literature and history course, students will be introduced to several bodies of literature (twentieth-century African American and Francophone fiction; twenty-first century African science fiction; West African popular film); as well as the latest in theorizing about magic, culture, and the state.

title: Organic Chemistry II: Foundations of Chemical Reactivity and Synthesis
reviews: Always read the lecture notes.

Amazing course overall. Sorensen is one of the best lecturers at Princeton. The only gripe I had was that we didn't get detailed grade distributions like in 303, so it was a bit more difficult to tell how you were doing in the class.
Attend all the lectures and precepts because they are really good.
Definitely read Professor Sorensen's notes!

Definitely take Sorenson over Semmelhack. Sorenson is truly one of the greatest professors, he is very inspiring and engaging. Lectures were a pleasure to go to. Orgo is a very challenging topic but put in the time and you will do great

Definitely take this course. Second semester Orgo is much more interesting than first semester, and Sorenson is amazing!!!! If you can, choose this course over 304B. Semmelhack is a great guy and an amazing chemist, but Sorenson has this enthusiasm and energy that is contagious and very much appreciated. Don't be scared off by the title if you are looking into biology rather than chemistry. Just take this class because it is definitely worth it, trust me. And don't worry if you were not happy with your performance in 303; you can definitely work harder this seamster and come out with a better grade. But, you're going to have to work for it, but the work you end up putting into the class makes it that much more rewarding. Guys, I honestly loved this class, and I am not a CHM major. Final note, be prepared for a lot of mechanisms and synthesis, which can be really interesting and fun (when you know what you're doing). TAKE IT
Do not take it unless you have to, but it is surprisingly interesting, and Sorensen is the best!
Do practice problems.
Do problems everyday.
Don't take it if you don't have to.

Don't take this class in conjunction with other difficult classes if you can possibly avoid it. The workload is overwhelming, and if you don't stay current you fall behind quickly. That being said, Sorensen is a FANTASTIC professor, and if GPA is not a prime consideration and you have an interest in the subject matter, you should definitely take this class.
Expect to work extremely hard but enjoy it along the way. Be smart about balancing the course with your other classes.

Here is the thing about orgo: A lot of people who have no natural inclination toward chemistry are forced to take it as a premed prereq. They do not enjoy it. This probably shouldn't be surprising. Here is the surprising part: organic chemistry is actually loads of fun if you like chemistry! You pretty much get to spend all your time figuring out how to build stuff and solve puzzles. The workload is pretty light, except around exam time, and labs are straight-forward. I really, really liked this class.

I enjoyed being in this class a lot and learning about the wonders in the world of organic chemistry.  That being said, I did not do so well on the course and can't be much help in offering advise.  I guess the best thing to do is to study everyday rather than cram.  You can't cram for this course.

I would say to keep up with the material by doing practice problems daily. I would also say that going to precept is a great way to solidify the material that you already learned, especially since the preceptors do relevant problems with you.

If Semmelhack didn't work for you last semester, I urge you to try Sorensen's class. His class isn't any easier, but he is one of the most well-meaning, patient, and friendly professors I've ever had. His board-work and lectures are fantastic. His notes are wonderful in their way of speaking to you.
If you like chemistry at all, TAKE IT. Sorensen is a lot of fun and I loved the class and learned a lot. I really like the way it taught me to think about chemical problems.

If you're taking this course, it's likely for premed or for a departmental. TAKE SORENSON (not Semmelhack). Sorenson is incredibly engaging and posts his notes after each lecture, which are super helpful (better than any notes you'll take on your own). Sorenson loves the material and really conveys that in lecture and allows you to actually enjoy organic chemistry. Also get Tracy Liu as your preceptor - she makes the course infinitely better!
It is not as scary as everyone says it is.
It's taught very well, and if you go to lectures, precepts, and read the notes, you'll learn a lot about organic chemistry. The tests can be really hard and not so straight forward.
Its a great course
Just stay engaged in the class and take all of the practice tests.
Lot of interesting material, but a huge time commitment.  Only take if (1) required or (2) if you genuinely are interested in the subject matter.
Many students must take CHM 304 as a requirement, and I think it was not as bad as I thought it would be, and even enjoyable.
More difficult than an average class
Only take if you absolutely have to (that premed life...)
Only take the course if you have to. However, once you do, you will definitely enjoy it.

Organic Chemistry is difficult, but with dedication it can be done. You cannot expect to get a good grade without putting in most of your time and effort. That being said, this class is a very great course! Sorensen is engaging and is always excited to teach new material to the class! Take this version of the course if you can!
Organic chemistry makes sense when Professor Sorensen teaches it!

Orgo can be stressful. But you have so many resources open to you: your preceptors, Professor Sorensen, Henry, McGraw staff... Don't be afraid to ask questions, and see some mechanisms drawn out again. Play with the modeling kit. 

Also, to lighten the subject... think about what you're learning about... you're learning about inner workings of nature at a scale so much smaller than the eye could see. If you take on the excited perspective that Professor Sorensen and the rest of the faculty have for this dense subject, I assure you, you will have a better experience with the course.

Orgo needs time, I can't emphasize this enough. If you're taking this class you're pre-med or a chem major or someone who just needs to take this class anyways so you might as well give it the time it deserves because there is no escape. Definitely 304 over 304B though.
Practice, practice, practice.

Prof. Sorensen is an absolutely wonderful lecturer. He is very engaging, and I felt like I remembered what what taught after each lecture, which was definitely not the case for me during the first semester. Prof. Sorensen makes the material interesting and involves the class in the learning process. In addition, the preceptors and Frick staff are extremely receptive to any questions you have and are quick to answer questions. Although the material was challenging, it is key to keep up-to-pace with the information and make sure you prepare for each exam.
SORENSEN IS AMAZING. If you have to take orgo 2, take it with him! He's hilarious.

Sorenson is an absolutely fantastic professor!! I may be a little biased as I absolutely loved this class, but his lectures were the high points of my day. Definitely go to lecture, and definitely read the notes. And don't be afraid to go to the preceptors or Professor Sorenson himself with questions, they really  do want to help. 
Make sure to take practice tests before taking the midterms, take them under timed conditions. And study more than you think you need to for the second midterm. When you get to carbonyl chemistry, think simply in terms of steps, don't let yourself get overwhelmed with the many possibilities.
Study every week!
TAKE IT
TAKE ORGO SOMEWHERE ELSE! It is very difficult at Princeton. Unless you were a general chemistry genius, consider taking it at a different school.
Take Sorensen over Semmelhack if you can

Take Sorensen! This class is excellent, as long as you stay on top of your material, as with any class. Lectures are Tuesday and Thursday. Everyday after lecture, spend 15 minutes over lunch reviewing what was just thrown at without you. You won't be confused. Problem sets are due Thursday so work on them after Tuesday, at which point you should know what to do for the problem sets. Do a more in-depth review sometime on Friday-Sunday, for 1-2 hours on the material you learned for the week. Start studying for exams 5-7 days in advance -- first by reviewing the 7-8 lectures that will be tested, and then by doing all the practice exams that are available. Save the last day for going over mistakes, redoing problems, finalizing your cheat sheets, and quickly skimming through the lectures again. Make sure to understand the examples he puts in the notes, especially those ones that seem complex and just "challenge problems." Cognates of those will find their way onto the exams. You can do it! 304 is a lot more fun than 303. I imagine 304B with Semmelhack is too.
Take Sorenson's class in the second semester. He is awesome! (But if you don't have to take it, don't take orgo. Your GPA will thank you)
Take it if necessary.

Take it if you are an enthusiastic student and find solace in putting in hours at the library. Organic Chemistry really teaches you how to learn and develops study habits like none other. It is also very rewarding and the subject itself is interesting.

Take it. I mean if you care about your grades a lot then that might be rough because it's not like I got an A but if you think chemistry is interesting take 304. The worst part about orgo is the 8:30 time for 303. I could not immerse myself in the class like i did for 304 and that is definitely a shame.
Take organic chemistry. It is worth it.

Take the class with Professor Sorensen!!! He genuinely loves teaching, loves orgo, and it makes you love orgo too (or at least like it more than before). I was frustrated, and afraid of orgo after the first semester because I didn't understand the point of organic chemistry and worked and still didn't do well. Prof. Sorensen completely changed that though. Although I still struggled in the course, I can am fascinated by the subject and its complexities and possibilities.
Take the course. Even if you don't need to, it was just a joy to learn about chem from so many passionate people.
Take this and not 304B.

Take this course if you liked 303 even a little bit! This course really gets at the crux of organic synthesis, and you'll be able to conceptualize so many more reactions afterwards. Have fun drawing the arrows. Professor Sorensen is a great lecturer. When preparing for exams, do all the previous exams and you should be set (there aren't that many).
Take this course with Sorrensen. And study a lot.
Take this course! It's not as hard as its reputation makes it seem. Sorenson is an amazing lecturer and his staff works hard to make sure everyone understands.
Take this. Don't take Semmelhack.

This course is more challenging than first semester organic chemistry, but the concepts are explained much better, and the class is much more engaging.  I would recommend this class for anyone who is remotely interested in organic chemistry.

This is a great class, and Sorensen is a wonderful lecturer. The pacing of the class is unusual, it starts very slowly and ends very quickly. If you're fine with memorizing a lot at the end of the semester, and really care about the quality of lecture, take this course. Otherwise, Semmelhack might be better (but I wouldn't know, I don't know what Semmelhack is like second semester).
This was a fun course, but most people who take it are required to do so.  Some parts are less interesting than others, but the material is definitely useful/important for anything chemistry related.

You have to go with Sorensen! This was the best class I've taken at Princeton so far and the best teaching experience I've had here too. Sorensen gets at the fundamental principles of organic chemistry so that you will be prepared to tackle a seemingly-strange problem. Continue taking orgo as well! The labs are a lot more fun this semester!!
great lectures but insanely hard exams. 10/10 will make you want to cry more than once. do not take for fun.
take it with Sorenson!!!!
this sucks Dowon
prereqs: Prerequisite: CHM 301 or CHM 303..
descrip: This course begins by discussing the chemical consequences of conjugation and the Diels-Alder reaction. After a coverage of aromaticity and the chemistry of benzene, we then move into the heart of the course: the nature and reactivity of the carbonyl group, a subject that is central to both mainstream organic chemistry and biochemistry. Throughout this course, an effort will be made to demystify the art of chemical synthesis. This course is appropriate for chemistry majors, premedical students, and other students with an interest in organic chemistry and its central position in the life sciences.

title: Advanced Studies in Acting: Scene Study and Style
prereqs: THR 201 or THR 301 or THR 311 OR any class in Dance. THR 401 can be taken up to two times, with the permission of the Program Director, as long as the instructor or the subject matter is different. Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for more information..
descrip: This class will focus on the works of internationally renowned German playwrights Bertolt Brecht and Heiner Mueller. Living through the events of World War II, both men at times focused on how to take texts from the canon and update them to address modern concerns. Students will prepare scenes from Euripedes, Sophocles, Brecht and Mueller in an effort to understand how these two great writers adapted classics and used them as a metaphor for the specific concerns of their times.

title: Music and Madness
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Boundary Layer Meteorlogy
reviews: I will definitely recommend it.

I would advise that students spend a significant amount of time on the fundamentals of the core. This is a very hard class to take when you are involved with significant research work and other courses at the same time. If this course is important to your research work then you should make it your primary course and focus on it. Others who are simply taking it for general interest may not do well.
If you deal at all with the surface layer, take it
If you want to know something about boundary layer or micrometeorology, this course is the best choice.
Pay attention to the time limit during the mid-term exam! Well, at least bring a watch:)
This course is difficult without previous knowledge, particularly knowledge of fluid mechanics.
read Stull
descrip: This course covers the basic dynamics of the Atmospheric Boundary Layer (ABL) and how it interacts with other environmental and geophysical flows. Topics to be covered include: mean, turbulence, and higher order flow equations, turbulence closure models for the ABL, similarity theories, surface exchanges and their impact on the stability of the atmosphere, the different ABL flow regimes, its role in the hydrologic cycle, the fundamentals of scalar (pollutant, water vapor, etc) transport, modeling and measurement approaches for the ABL, and the role and representation of the ABL in large-scale atmospheric flows and models.

title: 19th-Century Master Novelists - Tolstoy
descrip: A close reading of War and Peace (in Russian) along side short fictions, classics in Russian criticism, a sampling of diaries and letters, and ideological - philosophical context. Good reading knowledge of Russian required. Coordinated with COM 415.

title: Communities and Natural Ecosystems (Half-Term)
descrip: This course presents an overview of ecological theory and research in the social sciences with emphasis on the interactions among communities and ecosystems. Each of the six class sessions is devoted to consideration of a body of representative literature from ecology and environmental sociology.

title: Intensive Intermediate Chinese
reviews: Definitely take into consideration how much time is required for this class
Definitely take this course if you are dedicated and want to learn Chinese.
It is definitely worth taking.
It's a lot of work, but you will learn.
Review lessons before class.
Strongly recommend any class in the Chinese department. Teachers are easily reachable, and class sizes are always small.

Take the class. Minimal effort will get you the B still, but you'll still learn a lot. You'll most likely never get the chance at a class like this after you leave princeton, especially considering how esteemed the chinese language program is here.
Take this if you want to better your Chinese. It will help A LOT.
This is a fine course if you have background in Chinese and are interested in strengthening that. Depending on the amount of experience you have, it might even be easy.

This is a great class for heritage speakers, whether you want to jump into the Princeton Chinese program or just want to knock your language requirement out of the way. Keep in mind that you'll have to meticulously try to earn every single point possible?this is not an exaggeration? if you want an A-range grade.

This is a great class to take, especially if you are a heritage speaker (i.e. speak Chinese at home, etc.). I would definitely recommend it to anyone who is qualified to take it... it's well worth it.
prereqs: CHI 103 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: An intensive course covering 105 and 107 in one semester for students who have finished 103 which covers 101 and 102. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills and the analysis of grammar. After 108, students are ready for third year courses.

title: Introduction to Classical Chinese II
prereqs: CHI 301 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Reading and discussion in Chinese traditional philosophical thoughts and historical issues. Texts and essays written from Tang to Qing dynasty. Class discussions will be conducted in Mandarin Chinese.

title: Re:Staging the Greeks
reviews: Absolutely take it !
An excellent course for anyone who wants to expand as an artist and scholar of theater.

Best class I have taken at Princeton. The combination of the gorgeous texts, Tim, the trip to Greece, and the other students who are drawn to the class makes for an incredible semester. Take it! Also, do as much of the reading as you can before break because there is a lot for the first few weeks, and you won't want to miss a page!
DO ITTTT
TAKE IT IT WILL MAKE FOR ONE OF THE BEST PARTS OF YOUR PRINCETON EXPERIENCE
TAKE IT! Greece is amazing, as is its culture, people, and theater. Learning about it has made me a better person, and I look forward to taking what I have learned and using it in the future.
Take it.
prereqs: THR 201, 205, 301, 311, or 317 OR significant theatrical experience. By application and audition. Students interested in auditioning for THR 365 should contact professor Tim Vasen directly. During the spring break registered students will take a required study trip to Athens..
descrip: Re:Staging the Greeks, a collaboration between the Theater Program of the Lewis Center for the Arts and the Program in Hellenic Studies, will begin with this acting/directing workshop investigating how to stage ancient Greek plays on the contemporary stage. On Tuesdays, we will study some of the plays, the contexts in which they were first performed, and approaches taken by theater directors over the last few decades. On Fridays, we'll be on our feet, exploring the play's performative possibilities for ourselves.

title: Readings in Japanese Academic Style II
descrip: The second half of the two-semester course, which trains students in reading the particular style of Japanese academic writing. The second semester particularly focuses on academic writings from Meiji to the 1950s, including brief introduction of necessary Classical Japanese Grammar for this purpose. Course conducted in English.

title: Representing American Slavery
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Divided We Stand: Economic Inequality and Its Discontents
descrip: See website

title: The Emergence of the Modern Middle East: Arabic Sources
descrip: The end of the Ottoman Empire ushered in a key transitional period in Middle East history. This seminar uses Arabic monographs, memoirs, newspapers and novels to study life in Syria, Lebanon, Palestine, and Jordan from the end of the Ottoman era to early independence, and to practice formulating textually based research questions. Throughout paying attention to underlying questions of gender, culture, and space, the class focuses on the transition from the Empire, ideologies, the position of women, generational and social class changes, and political issues from the 1930s to the 1940s, including the Palestine Question.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Economics of the Welfare State
descrip: All advanced countries have extensive "welfare state" programs that provide insurance against economic losses, support people with low incomes, etc.. But these programs vary widely in extent from the relatively small US welfare state, to the larger welfare states of much of Europe, to the generous programs of Scandinavia. At the same time, there is heated controversy about the effects of such programs. This course surveys welfare state programs, including health care systems, across various countries, analyzes the debates over their economic effects, and looks at the political economy of reform in the US and countries such as France.

title: Religion and State Relations in Comparative Perspective
descrip: In this comparative seminar we examine models of secularism in contemporary Europe, North America, South Asia and the Middle East, and explore the implications of religion-state relations for the quality of democratic citizenship. We start with an overview of the relationship between religion, democracy and secularism and ask what role religion should and should not play in democratic public discourses. We then compare the institutional models of secularism. In a final section, we study the relationship between religious freedom and human rights, and the challenges religious laws may create for democratic and democratizing polities.

title: Microeconomic Policy
descrip: oh, dear

title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu II
prereqs: HIN 301 / URD 301 or equivalent proficiency..
descrip: This course provides continuing advanced level training in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Reading and writing exercises will be provided in both Hindi and Urdu, and students are free to choose their preferred format for assignments. Readings are supplemented by films and documentaries on relevant topics. Assignments will consist of short essays or other exercises. In-class discussion will help develop oral competency in idiomatic spoken Hindi-Urdu and the expression of ideas and opinions in a culturally and linguistically authentic and accurate manner.

title: Applied Quantitative Analysis
reviews: If you are interested in statistics but are hesitant because of the math, go for it anyway. This class will beef up your R skills and reasonably equip you to conduct original research in political science or at least give you enough knowledge to figure out more complicated concepts. Professor Wasow isn't a great professor yet, but once he has more experience, his enthusiasm for the subject and his students is hard to beat.
If you are new to statistics, or if you have a solid understanding, this is a good course to take. Go to the lectures for interesting statistics applications in Politics.
If you're interested in R and don't mind putting in some independent effort to figure it out, then go for it!
It's a chance to teach yourself a lot of R, but otherwise not too great. Recommend a COS or ORF class instead if you want to learn stats.
Not as good as POL 345. Still learned something though.
Professor Wasow could make this class great, but it needs work.

Professor Wasow is a great stats teacher who really wants you to succeed. His lectures attempt to paint broad strokes to give you the concepts, and you'll have to nail down the details in completing the problem sets. He's one of the most accessible professors I've ever had- responded to several email questions past 11pm within minutes.
TAKE THIS CLASS Professor Wasow is SO COOL and it's really really interesting. He makes everything seem so relevant and he's always willing to meet and help his students out.
Take it with Prof. Wasow, he's great!
Take it.

The concepts in the course are important, but the lectures are all over the place, the problem sets are extremely basic, and you could probably learn all of this from a good book. Professor Wasow is, however, extremely knowledgeable and energetic.

This course will teach you statistical techniques and programs that go a step beyond 345. I would recommend it because it will help you understand data in your daily life and for future independent work.

This is truly an applied stats class, so if you're looking to understand statistical theory a lot better this might not be for you. If you're looking to learn how to apply the stats you already know, this will be very helpful for you.
prereqs: POL 345 or equivalent.
descrip: In a world awash in data, how can we identify signals amid the noise? This course focuses on developing an intuition for statistics and applying it through data analysis, regression models and a final project. We will wrestle with what makes a good research question, play with data to see how statistical methods can help us make sense of real world concerns, and work at communicating quantitative findings clearly to broad audiences. Particular attention will be paid to applying these techniques in Junior Papers and Senior Theses. Coursework involves using the R statistical platform.

title: Music of Africa
descrip: Introduction to the vocal and instrumental music of Africa, south of the Sahara. Topics include the place of music in society, the influence of language on musical composition, principles of rhythmic organization, urban popular music, and "art" music as a response to colonialism.

title: Princeton Atelier - Creating Musical Comedies by Baby Wants Candy
reviews: Holy @#$% it's amazing. Interesting take on creating a musical -- it's very improv based.
If you have any interest in improv comedy, this is a fantastic class to take. Be aware that you will have to perform though.
It's not a difficult class, though a little more work than one might expect - useful for all walks of life, I think.
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT
Take it! I'd recommend it especially if you have improv experience. Just make sure you are OK with sexual / crass stuff in what you will be working on and presenting.
Take this class! It's so much fun and you learn a ton about improv!
prereqs: This course is for students who are eager to study and create comedic musical theater. Writers and musical theater performers are encouraged to apply. No experience is required, however, just a great force of will and enthusiasm for the art form. Applications are required; for applications and more information, see the Princeton Atelier course webpage..
descrip: This course, led by critically-acclaimed comedy writer/performer/director Al Samuels and his cutting-edge improvisation group, Baby Wants Candy, will explore and create original comedic musicals. Students will participate in BWC's early-in-process concept as well as work in groups to develop their own original one-act musical comedies, which they will perform at the end of the semester. Students will experiment with musical theatre story structure, song-writing, and the nature of comic performance in fresh and challenging ways. BWC has extensive experience working collaboratively with students in the U.S. and at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.

title: Contemporary Chinese Society and Culture
reviews: Be ready to understand difficult but fascinating material and also don't be afraid to open up your minds and learn new perspectives/world views.
Don't be afraid to ask clarification questions if something Professor Zhang is confusing at first.
Don't take it unless you have to or are extremely interested in the subject matter.

If you are interested at all in Contemporary Chinese Society and Culture, this is an excellent class to take. Despite what some will probably say in their reviews, Professor Zhang's lectures were chock-full of information, and very organized. He used slides which contained content in outline format very conducive to writing notes. He is approachable and willing to discuss relevant topics to this course. He gave the best final exam review session that I have ever had. In the course of an hour and a half, he refreshed my memory on nearly every topic that the course had covered. It was amazing!

If you want to take one course to "understand" China, this very well could be it.

Some students in the class said that Woodrow Wilson School majors who wish to focus on China should be required to take this course... I agree. Zhang's course offers an incredibly comprehensive and, most importantly, non-essentialist approach to Modern China. Zhang is an INCREDIBLE scholar and educator, and it was an absolute joy and privilege to learn from him.
It helps make a well understanding of contemporary Chinese society and culture.
Professor Zhang is great. If you like China and a relatively low workload, this course is for you

Take it if you're interested in the material and want to have a better understanding of China. Midterm war fair and Zhang is a good teacher. Readings could be a little long and lectures sometimes a little dry but for a midterm, paper, final class really not hard.
Take this class! Great prof, interesting material.

Take this course if:

a) If you are interested in EAS
b) Want to fufill a distribution requirement 
c) Want to learn more about modern Chinese society and culture
Very solid contemporary China class

Well organized and administered course. The precepts were a little boring but the lectures were interesting and the readings were very informative and compelling. 20th Century Chinese history and culture is a fascinating topic.
descrip: This course surveys "contemporary China." It begins with Maoist socialism between 1949 and 1978, and focuses on the tremendous changes of Chinese society and culture from 1978 to the present. Using ethnographies along with documentaries, this course seeks to demonstrate major trends and contradictions through people's lived experiences: decentralized social life under the state power, overall life improvement along with increasing inequality of consumer society, the rise of individual desire amidst conflicting memories of socialism, reinvention of traditions under transnational influences are some examples.

title: Animal Behavior
prereqs: Note that labs are very time consuming..
descrip: The course focuses on the mechanisms and evolution of behavior, especially innate predispositions and programming, and their interaction with learning. Topics include the sensory bases of behavior, how complex behavior such as navigation communication, and learning is organized, social behavior, behavioral ecology, mate choice, cognition, and human behavior. Labs emphasize hypothesis formation and testing, using mammals, birds, fish, and insects. Students taking the lab are excused from precepts.

title: The Bible as Literature
reviews: Could not recommend this class strongly enough.

Go to lecture. Soak up as much of the reading s and insight as you can. There is an infinite amount of interesting stuff to learn from this, and obviously a semester isn't enough for the entire Bible, but it's a good start. I'd never read the Bible before this class and it was fascinating.

I would recommend this course to any Princeton student, whether or not you are familiar with the Bible. You will learn a lot of really valuable material. The workload and expectations are reasonable, even if you are not a humanities major.
Take it if you want to learn what you don't know about the Bible from just going to church.
Take this class, it is very interesting and explores so many interesting things about the Bible and the message of hope it offers.
This course is essential to an understanding of world literature, at the core of which the Bible sits
You should take this course if you've had any exposure to Christendom.
descrip: This course will study what it means to read the Bible in a literary way: what literary devices does it contain, and how has it influenced the way we read literature today? What new patterns and meanings emerge? This course will examine the structures and modes of the Biblical books; the formation of the canon and the history of the apocryphal or deuterocanonical books; questions authorship; its literary genres; histories of exegesis, interpretation, and commentary; the redaction, division, and ordering of biblical texts; the cultural, political, and intellectual worlds within which these texts were written.

title: Advanced Video and Film Production
reviews: Film early in the semester, so you can save editing for the end.

I would recommend it to students with a strong interest in film production. I would not recommend it if someone is just looking for an arts credit or a fifth class though, as it is a pretty big time commitment.

If you don't have an idea of the film you want to make going into this it may be more difficult, but if you have a concept and people willing to help you make it then the course will be much more enjoyable.
Su is the best film/art/life professor at Princeton. Do yourself a favor and learn from this woman while you can.
Take it if you love making films. Not for the "generally interested." Su is great.
prereqs: VIS 261/262, VIS 263/264 and self-sufficiency in film editing software such as Premiere or Final Cut Pro..
descrip: This course builds on a student's prior experience in writing, shooting and editing. Work develops from their ideas; a student can make one term-long project or numerous short ones, and in any genre. The idea is to refine one's technical skills and expand one's approach to storytelling.

title: Global Air Pollution
reviews: DEFINITELY TAKE IT BUT ONLY IF INTERESTED!

Good course. Interesting material. Challenging without being really hard. Lecture is interesting but can get dull when he just shows you powerpoints of distributions of gases.
Start homeworks early as office hours can save you a LOT of time.

If you are bothering to read the course recs, you are ahead of the game. I commend you for being proactive in your academic decision making process. This class is very informative and teaches you the chemistry of pollution in the atmosphere. I came in interested in Climate Change, and I learned that all pollution problems are connected and how they are too.
Take advantage of the time with Professor Zondlo.

Take it if you are interested in air pollution from a chemical and geophysical perspective. You will come away with a comprehensive body of knowledge on the subject. Prof. Zondlo is articulate and rigorous. Those looking for a technological or political treatment of air pollution should look elsewhere.

Take this course if you have any interest in the topic.  I did very well with none of the prereqs (although orgo wouldn't have hurt).  It was reasonable difficulty, but you're always learning something new.  It's great and applies to anyone interested in air quality.
This class is great for a departmental credit and is very interesting for anyone interested in the atmosphere or environmental chemistry.
overall good course-practical applications relevant to everyday life. readings aren't particularly necessary for the exams, but will help you understand the material better and more thoroughly
take it if you are interested in topic but need some chemistry and some calculus
prereqs: CEE 303 or CHM 303/304 or Instructor's Permission.
descrip: Students will study the chemical and physical processes involved in the sources, transformation, transport, and sinks of air pollutants on local to global scales. Societal problems such as photochemical smog, particulate matter, greenhouse gases, and stratospheric ozone depletion will be investigated using fundamental concepts in chemistry, physics, and engineering. For the class project, students will select a trace gas species or family of gases and analyze recent field and remote sensing data based upon material covered in the course. Environments to be studied include very clean, remote portions of the globe to urban air quality.

title: Philosophy of Language
reviews: Great course, TAKE IT IF you are a linguist / philosopher. DO NOT take class if you are a freshman or if it would be your first philosophy class. I made both of those mistakes and they are both the things that are keeping me behind.

If you're really into metaphysics or linguistics, give it a whirl; if not, I wouldn't do it. It's pretty boring and not as applicable to other branches of philosophy as you would expect for a metaphysics class to be
Take it if you really want to engage with readings.
This was a fun class if you are interested in the philosophy of language.
prereqs: Course open to freshmen..
descrip: An introduction to selected topics in the philosophy of language, including the semantics of names, formal semantics, conditionals, necessity and possibility, and pragmatics.

title: Translation Workshop: Spanish to English
reviews: Definitely take this course! Especially if you've never taken a translation theory class before.
Do the readings, they're fascinating!
Highly recommended for anyone interested in linguistics, or in learning multiple languages.

If you are interested in translating Spanish works into English, take it! Professor Wimmer is an amazing instructor, really sweet, flexible, and accommodating. Ask plenty of questions and have fun with your translation project!
If you have any interest in translation at all, take this class!
Take it! It's easily the most fun class in the spanish department. It's like a creative writing class.
