Take it! Pretty low-stress and a very rewarding and enriching way to work with translation!
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission. Reading knowledge of Spanish..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the practical act of literary translation and an exploration of the questions that the practice of translation inspires. Subjects of discussion will include style, context, the conventions of contemporary translation, and the retranslation of classics. We will begin with a series of translation exercises. Each student will then select an author and work to be translated as the central project for the class, and embark on the process of researching, contextualizing, and revising successive drafts.

title: International Monetary Theory and Policy II
descrip: Advanced topics in monetary economics, with an emphasis on open economies. Money demand and currency substitution; price-level and exchange-rate determination under alternative monetary policy rules; real effects of monetary disturbances; exchange-rate policy and macroeconomic stability; welfare consequences of inflation and exchange-rate stabilization; advantages and disadvantages of monetary union.

title: Topics in Mathematical Modeling - Mathematical Neuroscience
reviews: Do it. But be prepared for it to be challenging. The material moves very quickly and is not easy, but you will come out of the course stronger.
Holmes is retiring, so I don't know if this is relevant. But ask if you can get a PDF of the notes ahead of time.
I would highly recommend it, since mathematical modelling in biology is really interesting, but be prepared for a lot of work
More math than you're probably thinking there is in this course, so think about that first. I think this course is fantastic, but for a specific type of person.
prereqs: This interdisciplinary course in collaboration with Molecular Biology, Psychology and the Program in Neuroscience is directed toward upper class undergraduate students and first-year graduate students with knowledge of linear algebra and differential equations..
descrip: Draws problems from the sciences & engineering for which mathematical models have been developed and analyzed to describe, understand and predict natural and man-made phenomena. Emphasizes model building strategies, analytical and computational methods, and how scientific problems motivate new mathematics.

title: Leo Tolstoy, War and Peace, and the Tasks of Literature
reviews: Be ready for a ton of reading when you're reading War and Peace! This course actually requires a lot of time to do the readings thoroughly.

Definitely take this class or any class with Professor Emerson. Cate and Denis as preceptors were also wonderful. Tolstoy's writings are really thought-provoking but could be challenging at times. However, the instructors spent time to clarify things, connect the texts with historical background, etc. Highly recommended!
I don't think this course is being offered in the future, but Tolstoy is a fascinating thinker to study. He spans literature, philosophy, history, art, religion....
I really wish they could... but I think this was the last time this course was offered. Unfortunately. Otherwise I would strongly encourage everyone to take it.

I would recommend this course to any student who either loves or hates Tolstoy. The latter simply because even if one hates a work, they should be able to articulate why and should be able to understand why the author is appreciated by others.
If Caryl Emerson is teaching this course, you have to take it. She is a magnificent lecturer, and she will make you love the course, even if you occasionally get angry at Tolstoy (which you will).
If ever Emerson lectures: go.

If only to have a chance to take a class with Prof. Emerson and experience the wonder of having Denis Zhernokleyev (super intelligent/chill preceptor) lead precept, try to take. Just be warned that the 300  pages is nothing to sneeze at

It's a shame Professor Emerson won't be teaching it again because she is phenomenal. Still, if you're looking for some big literature that addresses some of the biggest questions of life, take this course.
It's too bad this is the course's last offering; otherwise, I would encourage you to take it.
Life-changing!
Please take it! Tolstoy is a character that you can love and hate at once, but you will always learn from him. Professor Emerson is amazing!
Sorry you missed the chance to take this amazing class.
TAKE THIS CLASS...i don't know who will teach after emerson retires, but it is a really incredible class
Take it.

Take this class. Tolstoy is a fascinating author, Prof. Emerson is phenomenal. I had never taken a literature class or a comparative literature class here, and I didn't know anything about Russia or Tolstoy going in, but I loved it.

Take this course, do the readings, and stay engaged. Professor Emerson says at the beginning of the class that this class requires your engagement and this is so true! This class will probably be your favorite class at Princeton if you put in the effort.
This course is amazing and Caryl is a profoundly engaging lecturer.  There is a heavy reading load and if you don't plan on reading it, don't take the course, because the point is to read Tolstoy.

This is a phenomenal class. The best one of my semester, and I took it just for fun. Yes, it's a LOT of reading, but I took it as a 6th class and managed to get it all done without skimming. You can too. You'll have such an odd relationship with Tolstoy by the end.
You should take the course if you are interested in Russian literature.
prereqs: Knowledge of Russian not expected or required for 415. Graduate students (and qualified undergraduates) taking Tolstoy under SLA 511 must have an excellent reading knowledge of Russian. SLA 511 meets Tuesday afternoons with its own syllabus, loosely coordinated with 415, but all 511 students are invited to sit in on undergraduate discussions Mon and Wed..
descrip: An introduction to Tolstoy through his select short fiction and/or drama, critical essays, and all of [War and Peace] in the context of various theories of the novel. Our thesis--which is open to debate--is that Tolstoy's radical ideas on narrative have their counterpart in his radical ideas on history and the self, which, taken together, offer a coherent view of the human condition at odds with most Russian writers and philosophers of his time.

title: Science and Democracy
reviews: Do all the readings and think about how the discussions relate to your life today!
Expect to work hard!  Best politics class I've taken at Princeton.

If you are interested in science or politics, you should take this course. I entered wondering what the connection between science and democracy could be, thinking primarily that "democracy doesn't belong in science because that's not how it's done." Coming out of the course, I now have a much greater appreciation for science and the difficulties involved in communicating under uncertainty, even under ideal circumstances. For science majors who might still be skeptical, I'm a physics major and this was definitely one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton.

Take this class. Professor Lane is incredibly dedicated and leads stimulating discussions. This class's focus on the connection between science and democracy will help you rethink how you understand government and its role within society.

There is a lot of interesting material here, made kind of unpleasant ultimately by (a) some very unengaged students, (b) some other very self-absorbed students who do not have much patience for perspectives besides their own, and (c) a professor who is reluctant to really lecture and who is a little obsessed with splitting up into groups for discussion, outlining and guiding each class precisely thus and so, and so forth. Don't expect class discussions to feel organic, and don't expect anything radically interesting to come up. That said, once again, material is quite good, and there is a kind of guaranteed baseline understanding that Prof. Lane will bend over backwards to make sure everybody obtains by the end of each meeting. But if you're looking for a real humanistic challenge, look elsewhere.
take it!!!!!!
descrip: Are science and democracy mutually supporting communities of inquiry, or are they antithetical in their rival commitments to expertise and equality respectively? This question illustrates the questions to be pursued, about the fundamental principles and models of science and democracy; the relations between them; and the roles and responsibilities of scientists, policymakers, and citizens. This is a course in political theory and normative reasoning that will integrate perspectives from the philosophy of science, science and technology studies, and case studies, accessible to students with backgrounds both inside and outside natural science.

title: Mexican American History
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of reading, but you will learn a lot and realize how much more there is to learn in this field.
Hands down one of the best courses I've ever taken and you should absolutely take it if you have the chance! If you're interested in Mexican American history, or even just US history, take this!!!!

I was totally blown away by this class! The material is fascinating and you'll learn a lot about a part of US history that is not often covered in the mainstream. As expected, a lot of discussion of race/ethnicity comes up, as do questions of class and gender. Prof Lozano is extremely kind and approachable, and makes an effort to get to know all her students personally. There is a substantial amount of reading, but a lot of it is extremely interesting, and the emphasis is on broad themes rather than nitty-gritty details. A great class!
I would strongly recommend this course to other students.
Take it. It is worth your time. Prof is great. Content is unexpected.
This is a really great course, definitely do all the readings, you will get the most out of the course and lectures if you really take the time to do readings and precept assignments.
descrip: The course follows the major themes and issues surrounding the history of Mexican Americans in the United States. It seeks to explain the historical origins of the continuing debates over land ownership, assimilation expectations, discrimination, immigration regulation, and labor disputes. The course focuses primarily on the US citizens created after the Mexican American War and Mexican immigrants to the US. It looks transnationally at Mexico's history to explain US shifts in public opinion and domestic policies. While the course examines the impact of Mexican Americans in many regions of the country, it will focus on those in the Southwest.

title: English Constitutional History
reviews: A bit of a change of pace, and definitely not an easy A or anything. However, if you want to try something new and attend lectures with one of the legendary history professors at Princeton (or in the nation), this is worth a shot.
A very interesting course- Prof. Jordan's lectures are actually fun to go to.  Work is not excessive, especially if you're engaged in the subject matter.
Actually do the reading. You'll get so much more out of it.
Ask other students who have taken this course how they were successful, and consider P/D/F'ing if you don't do well on the first exam.
Definitely take a class from Prof. Jordan before you graduate.
Definitely take it! If you work hard, you'll be rewarded and learn a lot!
Don't take this unless you're a big history buff.
Get ready to think in this history class!
Great PDF class.  Lectures are awesome.  Reading is enjoyable if you can keep up.  Long live King Bill Jordan, the 'Animate Law' himself!
Hard class, a lot of work, but take it if you have the time.

I don't regret taking this course, but I'm not sure I'd do it again. I liked the classes themselves, but the evaluations were difficult and didn't seem very effective as a true measure of learning, and I wish we had pulled things together a bit more at the end.

I would definitely recommend this course.  Professor Jordan is one of the best lecturers in the university and the course is really interesting.  As far as history lecture courses go, it can be a bit tougher since it covers over 600 years of history, but if you put a little bit of effort into keeping dates and monarchs straight, it is definitely manageable.  Definitely take it!
Lectures are fantastic, precepts/assignments less so. I PDFed and had a great time, but bring your A-game if you want to do well. A lot of Pre-Law and History people take the class.
Must Take.
TAKE IT. Professor Jordan is amazing and the content is incredibly interesting for anyone with the slightest interest in English history and Law! I LOVED this class.
Take it

Take it! Seriously, take this class. I know it's at ten, and I know it's about English constitutional history. But take it, it's great! Professor Jordan is a FANTASTIC, HILARIOUS lecture. The preceptors when I took it were really cool and helpful. You'll actually learn really interesting stuff about parliament and common law and whatnot that you'd normally think would be boring, but isn't, because Professor Jordan rocks. Also, the English kings are batsh*t crazy, and they're super fun to read about. And I felt totally fine in the course even though I'm not a history major. Do it do it do it you won't regret it.
Take this class! The material is great if you are remotely interested in law and/or England, and the lectures are incredible.

Take this course. Professor Jordan is the best lecturer I've had and although the title of the course sounds dull, it actually is really interesting and looks at the development of the concept of law in Western society.
This course is fascinating but extremely difficult. Be ready to PDF if necessary.

This is a really tough course, but fulfilling if you're willing to put in the effort. Grading is harsh (I PDFd) but the lectures are awesome. Might be worthwhile just to hear Prof. Jordan's lectures. He's the man.

This is, if I remember correctly, one of the only undergraduate courses on English constitutional history offered in the entire country, and Professor Jordan is a really engaging professor. I'd highly recommend taking this class.
Try not to get Brianna as your preceptor.
Very interesting course, but you definitely need to do the readings and be attentive during lecture.
Very interesting. Jordan is a great lecturer, the foremost scholar in his field. Take if you want an interesting course, but it's definitely not easy or straightforward.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: To explore the development of institutions and theories of government in England from the Norman Conquest to about 1700.

title: Vladimir Nabokov
reviews: Absolutely take this - even if you are not a huge English person. Nabokov is an incredible writer and you will find yourself very influenced by his language. Professor Hasty is wonderful!
Absolutely take. One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton
Definitely take this if you are interested in Nabokov, it's a great class even if you have never read anything he's written before.
Don't assume you're going to enjoy all the reading just because you liked Lolita. It is definitely easy to do well, though.
I would always advise the student to begin the readings on Saturday. I found myself too often crunched for time on Mondays.

If you enjoy reading, then you must take this class. Nabokov is a magnificent writer, and the act of reading his novels is a completely different experience from reading anything else. The lectures were also very good, but this almost doesn't matter, given how good the texts are.

If you like literature for its aestheticism, Nabokov is the author for you. But if you're looking for more "deep" novels with social commentary, you might want to try a different Lit course first. That said, fun course overall, and reading Nabokov teaches you a lot about what it means to be a skillful writer.

Nabokov is SUCH a fascinating writer. It's definitely worth taking this opportunity to learn how much more there is to him than Lolita and Professor Hasty does an excellent job of breaking down his work. I took the class on a PDF basis because I just couldn't keep up with all the readings, but even then, I feel like I gained so much just from sitting in on these lectures.
TAKE IT. Reading Nabokov will change your life. And reading Nabokov under Prof. Hasty's brilliant guidance is utterly amazing.
Take it! Professor Hasty is amazing and Nabokov is incredible.
Take the course if you like literature, but be prepared to do a lot of readings.
Taking a serious literature course was a new and eye-opening experience for me. Totally ignoring the quality of teaching, the literature is just so good.

This is a great course if you really want to get a feel for the oeuvre of Nabokov. I will warn you, however, that you may become tired of his characteristic style. But you will definitely learn a lot about this brilliant and influential writer.
descrip: In 1919, at the age of twenty, Vladimir Nabokov fled "the bloated octopus of state" of his native Russia and embarked on a dazzling bilingual literary career in emigration. This course focuses on Nabokov's masterly writing, which reflects a modernist preoccupation with narrative, temporality, and memory. The Russian and American novels are at the center of our attention, but readings include also a sampling of his shorter fiction, poetry, essays on literature, and the memoir Speak, Memory.

title: Topics in Early Chinese Art and Archaeology - Early Writing in Comparative Perspective
descrip: The topic is early writing in comparative perspective. We begin with the origin and early uses of writing in Mesopotamia, Egypt, and China, and end with close study of the display inscriptions in the tomb of Zeng Hou Yi (d. 433 BC) and their implications for ancient music theory.

title: Special Topics in Operations Research and Financial Engineering - Stochastic Methods for Quantitative Finance
prereqs: ORF 309.
descrip: This course is an introduction to stochastic calculus at the undergraduate level with applications to financial models. The emphasis is on computational and practical techniques. Topics include: Brownian motion; Ito's formula; stochastic differential equations; partial differential equations; Girsanov's theorem; simulation and finite difference numerical methods; implementation in Matlab; applications in finance.

title: Monstrosity in Film and Literature
descrip: See website

title: Genetics of Eukaryotic Organisms
reviews:
-Write notes on the main question/techniques/results/conclusions of each figure for the papers. It might jog your memory or help you think on the spot with the "index card" system of participation.
-Get as much feedback and critique from friends/colleagues as possible when working on grant writing.
Be ready to learn a lot of cool genetic methods.
Check your status in participation as much as possible, and ask for a clear description of the participation scoring. Don't be nervous about answering questions.

Don't stress too much about having a solid understanding of the material that you read for each class, because the instructors explain the background you are most liekly confused about and are great at fielding any type of question.
I highly recommend this course.  You will come out will a good understanding of genetics.
It is a "must" course for students who do research in molecular biology.
It was a great course. It'll likely change over the next year but I enjoyed it.

Reading a textbook helps if you have never been exposed to some of these concepts.  Don't be surprised when you finally start learning more about proposal writing or yeast genetics as you are doing the assignments.  It can be a struggle at times, but it definitely pays off.
Seek help from lectures outside form class when subject matter is hard to understand.
Simply read the papers before class and be prepared to participate.
This course takes considerable amount of time, but is completely worth taking.
do the reading. Pay attention in class. and ask lots of questions regarding assignments.
good
prereqs: Undergraduates need permission of instructor.
descrip: This course presents the genetic tools and logical framework used in the study of eukaryotic organisms, from the major model organisms (yeast, Drosophila, C. elegans, mouse and zebrafish) to humans. Discussion and readings from the primary literature focuses on basic cell, developmental, and quantitative biology. Material emphasizes genetic approaches building from classical methods to modern molecular genetics and genomics. Topics include suppression, synthetic lethality, epistasis, mutagenesis, mosaics, transgenics, ES cells, knock-in technologies and cell-type specific gene expression.

title: Class Field Theory
descrip: This course will describes abelian extensions of number fields and function fields of curves over finite fields. One example is the celebrated Kronecker-Weber theorem stating that any abelain extension of Q is contained in a field generated by roots of unity. Another example is Kronecker's Jugendtraum stating that all abelian extensions of imaginary quadratic fields can be obtained analogously using torsion points of elliptic curves with complex multiplications. Prerequisites: Galois Theory (such as MAT 322) and MAT 419.

title: Global Justice
reviews: Consult your preceptor about your essay beforehand and afterward for more feedback.

Do the readings: the work load is manageable and the course material greatly improve your understanding of the important debates in political philosophy. You will derive the greatest benefit from the course if you try to engage with the material rather than comment as an outsider.
Does not have a lot of grades, so make sure to do the reading so when essays come about you are well oriented. Talk to the preceptor prior to starting your essays. Beitz is a very kind and wise dude.
Final exam is easy but the essays are graded harshly so do stay on top of those! Go to every lecture and pay attention as they move fast. The class presents some fascinating material.
Go to office hours with both your preceptor and Beitz.  Good course for an EM but definitely challenging.
Great course! Be analytical in your writing. Don't fall behind too much.

Highly recommend. Gives a very strong overview of the challenges, both logistical and philosophical, that face peoples and their governments in the near future (and a fantastic overview of the recent history of those same issues). In my opinion, will make you a stronger and more informed citizen of the world.

I would recommend this course with Professor Beitz. He is absolutely wonderful, the class is really well-taught, and you learn so much throughout the semester! The topics and readings can be challenging at times, but you will get a lot out of it. Definitely take it!
I would tell them to make sure they pay attention to all the lectures, because that is where the bulk of the information is from.
If you are really interested in political theory, you will enjoy the class. If not, it'll be a very hard class.

If you want to learn how to think about pressing global issues - humanitarian intervention, drones, and extreme poverty, to name a few - from a moral standpoint, definitely take this course. Prof. Beitz is not only one of the leading scholars in the field of global political philosophy, but also happens to be a fantastic lecturer. Previous exposure to political/moral philosophy might help, but it is definitely not necessary as long as you are engaged with the course material.
If you're into this kind of thing.
It is a good course to take.
Make sure you take close notes on the readings!
Take it if you like philosophy. Professor Beitz is a fantastic teacher!

Take it!  An excellent introduction to contemporary issues in political theory.  Professor Beitz is an excellent preceptor - get his precept if you can.  Readings are quite manageable. Start the papers early.

Take the course! Be ready to do a good bit of reading but also to think about moral concerns that you often may think of but are too busy to actually consider. Beitz is a great guiding hand to walk you through this process.
Take this course! It's very well organized and I got a lot out of it. The readings are extremely doable and you feel like you've learned something at the end of the semester.
Take this if you are interested in political theory; do all the readings and go to all the lectures, and make sure you keep track of it all.

This course can be frustrating in terms of its pie in the skyness, but if you enjoy thinking about moral philosophy and are not unreasonably jaded, you will get a lot out of this class from Professor Beitz, whose crisp lectures sketch the major arguments of international moral philosophy in a thought provoking way.
Whether or not you're interesting in political theory, this is a great course.  The assignments and readings are all very manageable, and the ideas are interesting.
do it. go to the lectures and actually pay attention and the you will learn a lot and feel like you're ready to have a talk on international justice with Obama.
take this course!
descrip: What, if any, norms of justice apply to the institutions and practice of world politics? Topics include "political realism" and skepticism about global morality; just wars and justice in warfare; ethics of humanitarian intervention; the nature and basis of human rights; world poverty and global distributive justice; democracy and accountability in global institutions. Readings chosen from recent works in political philosophy.

title: Introduction to African-American Intellectual Tradition
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar introduces graduate students from many departments to the African-American intellectual tradition. The perspective concentrates on African-America and the African Diaspora, with attention to issues of class and gender as well as race. A broad set of topics, including race, racism, religion, and slavery are discussed. The course presupposes a familiarity with issues in African-American studies.

title: Seminar in Golden-Age Literature - Inquisition and Literature
descrip: A study of the workings and cultural impact of the Spanish Inquisition from its establishment to its final abolition. Readings include trials for heresy, witchcraft, and sexual deviation, in addition to literary texts, both Golden Age and modern, involving or inspired by the institution.

title: Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: A pretty interesting class; definitely take if you're into econ!

As an ORFE major, I was disappointed with this course. The description and most reviews indicated that it was fairly mathematical, which it was not. I think that the treatment of the subject was not as interesting or rigorous as I hoped for. A main focus of the course is optimizing subject to constraints. Despite this, LaGrange multipliers are never mentioned and all problems are doctored in such a way that the math always works out simply without corner cases or any real thought necessary. I don't recommend this for ORFE majors despite its presence as an elective.

Awesome class. Learned a bunch, incredibly interesting. Well taught, well supported. Curve %-age wise is easy (40% A/A-), but the class is full of ORFE majors. Psets were super engaging. Highly recommended if you have Pesendorfer. Not too math-ey.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE unless you HAVE to (i.e. for the Finance certificate). I felt like I had to teach everything to myself, and felt extremely lost 90% of the time. I have a difficult time understanding what was expected of me from this course. I did not feel as though I had been taught well: office hours were too disorganized.
Definitely a good class to take and not too difficult.
Definitely take this if you are interested in economics.
Don't take if you're not good at math/logic.
Don't take this course unless you have to or really want an introduction to college-level econ. It is not very interesting.

Don't take unless you have to.  This was my least favorite class at Princeton thus far, it treated me brutally but it also isn't the beast some make it out to be.  It is the class I might have the most regrets about: regrets about taking, regrets about my study procedure, and regrets about how cut out I am for the finance world.
Dont take ECO300 take this one
Go to all classes and study extremely hard for the tests.
Go to class, do the psets, ask for clarification when you don't understand something and you should do fine.
Go to precept.

Good broad-based micro-economic theory course with above average usage of mathematics, which makes it more interesting. Clearly taught. It is actually not that abstract and difficult in terms of mathematical rigor, so just make sure you follow each step of the logic in the derivation/proofs/heuristic and you'll be fine.
I would only take this course if you need it for a distribution/certificate requirement.
I would recommend this class to students with a stronger Math background who want/need to take an intermediate micro class.

I would strongly recommend future students to take it with Wolfgang. Wolfgang is a very nice professor who is not at all snobbish, but actually very humble for a European professor. His slides are immensely clear and logical. I would really recommend students print them out and annotate them. The problem sets are fun. If Mariano is precepting, request him! He has a sexy italian accent, but in general does a lot of general cases for problems so he is quite helpful!

If Wolfgang is teaching it, it is quite easy if you are good at math and (hence necessarily) have a clear mind. Can give lower priority to homework of this class because they only count 10% and legend has it that the minimum grade for each homework is 8/10 (if you turn it in). By the way, I never opened the book. Overall, it is very fun and interesting!!!
If you are interested in economics with a quantitative focus, this is a good class. Hopefully the lectures are better in the future.

If you have any interest in econ or using math to look at real-world problems/society, take this class. It will sharpen your skills and the section on game theory is particularly engaging and really interesting to think about.
If you have to take this class, be prepared for seemingly endless lectures. But the class does teach you many important microeconomic concepts.

If you're deciding between ECO 300 and ECO 310, definitely give this one a shot first. All the concepts are pretty easy to grasp if you have a strong foundation in ECO 100. Professor Pesendorfer does a good job presenting the material, and his slides are very thorough which helps for studying.
If you're interested in optimization and game theory, take this class. It's a rite of passage.
If you've taken ECO 100 and thought, "What the hell? Where are they getting this stuff from?", take this course. But it's not fascinating material.
In all, a fine course. Not poorly run at all, but not necessarily interesting.
It is a requirement for finance and econ, but it is interesting regardless.
It's a good course for a mathematical. foundation in mircoeconomics.
It's not as bad as ECO 310's reputation makes it out to be. Still not the most engaging class, however.
It's really good, I'd recommend it

Just don't go into this class with the expectation that you're going to love the subject matter. The matter isn't inherently interesting, but it is useful and you'll definitely learn. It won't be the most exciting class, but it's clear why this class is necessary for a bunch of majors and certificates. Pesendorfer is great.
Lectures are okay, if you can learn on your own then power to you. Do the p-sets, collaboration makes the very manageable. Precepts are helpful.
Make sure you go to lecture and really study the material.
Not a very interesting course, but a necessary one.
Not hard. Work on problem sets with other people.
Not too much math involved--getting the economic intuition is more important. Make sure to do the weekly assignments diligently and read over the lecture slides!!
Only take it if you must.

Pesendorfer is a great lecturer, but don't go to lecture except to turn in homework. That 1 hour 20 minutes is better spent on reading the slides and using the remaining 50 minutes for other work/leisure.

Pesendorfer teaches a very organized course.  Material isn't hard, partially because there's so many resources available.
Actual material isn't very practical/fascinating, so don't expect this to be 'eye-opening' in any way.
Pretty well taught but I feel like it is pretty broad for someone who doesn't need it as a requirement.

Probably half the class didn't go to lectures because Psendorfer has very clear and thorough lecture slides. If you did go, you were likely to fall asleep or get distracted. That being said, although the lectures were a bit dry, Psendorfer repeated important points multiple times in case you happened to be zoning out the first time around. I would definitely go to precept, though, which help with pset problems. The material isn't too hard, but this semester's final was harder than the practice ones (and worth 55% of your grade!!).
Problem sets should've been worth more
Read through the lecture slides and go to office hours!
Reviewing lecture slides is very important for full understanding of the material.
Take good notes during lecture.
Take it if you have to
Take it if you have to, or if you really enjoy math. Otherwise go for ECO300.
Take it if you want a finance certificate or really like math.
Take it with Pesendorfer
Take it with Pesendorfer.
Take it with Wolfgang and get Brian as your preceptor!

Take it! I like it a lot better than ECO 100 because this is more hands on and mathematical, rather than abstract. You can physically see the results of optimization and taking into account multiple factors to come up with a final conclusion.
Take it. I learned a lot though the lecture is a little dry.
Take this course.
Take this if econ major and okay with math.  Math was not very difficult.  Course is very well organized and is also very interesting.
Take this if you like calculus or microecon!
The material is interesting and lectures are solid, but this class really emphasizes the midterm and final.
The material is very challenging and the exams are hard (in the sense that the curve is tough). Only take it if you are comfortable with math.
The math is fun though often overwrought. The lectures are pretty useless - all the material is online. Precepts were extremely helpful in really teaching you how to do the problems.

This course is worth taking with Pesendorfer. While he is not the best lecturer, his slides and homework are very good and the class is nowhere near overwhelming. It's not a super easy class, but it is not difficult.
Try to take it with Professor Pesendorfer!
Very difficult. If your preceptor's teaching style does not work for you, don't be afraid to attend another preceptor's class.
Well taught course, reasonable psets and exams. Not super exciting though and material doesn't scream interesting.
YESSSS! With Pesendorfer! He made the class so much better
Yes, for Econ majors
You learn by doing psets, so do them well and do them early so you can ask relevant questions during precept
get alex as your preceptor.
get through it
not a bad course to take
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT175 or MAT 201. Not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course presents the economic theory of individual and firm behavior using mathematical tools including calculus. The course will emphasize applications of microeconomic theory to consumer choices, output and production of firms, market interaction and equilibrium.

title: The Art of Deception
descrip: See website

title: Introductory Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
reviews: Ask Luis for help if you need it. Also, if you're having trouble turning in an assignment, Luis is generally pretty flexible (although this doesn't hold for the end of the semester because there are a lot of assignments and material packed in at the end). I'd say that the last composition should have more structure in terms of the directions.

Chill pace, Luis is a great instructor. Stay on top of the online exercises and the grammar readings in the book and you'll be gucci. You learn a lot in a really short period of time without killing yourself. Great introduction to the language.

Definitely start taking Portuguese if you have any interest. It's a super useful language, and the classes here are really fun. Make sure you have a strong Spanish background though. Everyone else does.

Definitely take it if you're leaning at all towards it as you learn a lot and it is a very engaging learning environment.  I've already recommended it to several of my friends who are planning on taking it!
Do all of the homework, it will only come as a benefit to you.
Do the homework every night, and take active notes while reading the textbook.
Go to the language tables!
I think Portuguese is a great language to learn and that this course will really give you a strong foundation in the language especially if you already speak another romance language like Spanish.
Luis is awesome.
Make sure you can put the time and energy into studying the grammar and vocabulary in this course on a regular basis. You get out of it what you put it.
Portuguese is a beautiful language
This class is fun, but sometimes so fun that even the professor doesn't take the coursework seriously. You might not end up learning a lot of Portuguese.
This is a fun course that's really easy. Take it
prereqs: SPA 107 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Normally open to students already proficient in Spanish, this course uses that knowledge as a basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. Emphasis on the concurrent development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to provide in only one year of study a command of the language sufficient for travel and research in Brazil and Portugal.

title: Autobiographical Storytelling
reviews: A very cool niche for a class on this campus. More useful for learning storytelling than other  creative writing classes I have taken on this campus. Occasionally classes can be wasted due to lack of organization.
Enjoy this class. It is lovely.

I think this course can be as challenging as you want it to be-- you are telling your own stories-- and those who engage the deepest will feel most rewarded.  A really amazing way to get to know a group of people; Herrera did great work putting together a fascinating class. I felt lucky to be a part.
Take it! Great class
Take it! Super fun and you will improve in the art of storytelling, stage presence, etc.

Take it, it's fun to hear other people's stories, and you're sure to uncover some things about yourself that you might have forgotten or not thought story-worthy. People wanna hear your stories, and this is a great opportunity to learn how to tell them!
Take this class!!!!!
prereqs: Enrollment is permission by instructor -- please contact Professor Brian Herrera at: bherrera@princeton.edu for enrollment interest..
descrip: Every life delivers a story (or three) worth telling well. This workshop course rehearses the writing and performance skills necessary to remake the raw material drawn from lived experience into compelling autobiographical storytelling. Course participants will work in an array of storytelling modes (including stand-up comedy, testimonio, first-person media, slam poetics, etcetera) and will draw from those techniques to devise, document and perform an original work of autobiographical storytelling at semester's end.

title: Latina/o Performance
reviews: Definitely take this. Vazquez is amazing.
I strongly strongly recommend this class to everyone. Vazquez is an amazing teacher, and I would recommend any of her classes, especially this one.
I would strongly recommend someone to take this course.
Prof. Vazquez is hard to get in contact with, but other than that she's one of the most engaging and intellectually stimulating professor's I've had at Princeton.
Speak your mind, and don't feel like you have to speak in traditional "academic" ways to discuss topics in this course.
Take every course you can with Prof. Vazquez.

Though the readings may sometimes be a bit difficult, they are nonetheless interesting and should definitely be done to get the most out of the course. Also don't be afraid to speak up and participate!
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar examines U.S. Latina/o performance from the 1960s to the present. Students will engage the creative traditions that have emerged from the U.S.-Mexico borderlands, the post-colonial aesthetic concerns shaped by Caribbean migration, and the social preoccupations that have defined urban and suburban life. The class will learn to put formal motifs in conversation with a set of conceptual terms, including mestisaje, borderlands, transculturation, choteo, and disidentification. We will alternate between plays, critical readings, live performances, videos, and music.

title: Race and Religion in America
reviews: Take this class! Professor Weisenfeld is awesome! You have to work hard, but it is worth it!
This is a heavy reading course, but definitely worth taking if you are interested int eh topic.
descrip: This seminar examines the tangled and changing relationship between religion and constructions of race in American history. We will consider such topics as American interpretations of race in the Bible, religion and racial slavery, race and missions, religious resistance to the idea of race, and popular culture representations of racialized religion.

title: Physical Hydrology
reviews: Good primer to large scale land-surface modeling.
I would advise them to be sure to read the books on his/her own to ensure that they learn the material well as the class really serves as a brief introduction to a wide range of topics.
This course is a comprehensive overview of land surface hydrology. I would recommend it for students interested in working with land surface hydrologic models.
descrip: The course develops model parameterization for land surface water and energy models based on the underlying physics and mechanisms of surface and subsurface runoff generation, evapotranspiration, infiltration, and snow accumulation and melt. A goal of the course will be the development of a land surface model. Numerical issues related to land surface modeling will be discussed.

title: Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: Absolutely take this class. It was incredibly enjoyable and fulfilling in a way that Princeton classes often are not. Don't be scared off if you aren't a humanities person - I'm a math major and I loved it! Take it with Professor O'Rourke if you can.
Actually put time into your poetry or you won't get anything out of this class!
Coach is great, and he works well with people who have never done poetry before and people who have more experience. He makes you open to new things. Embrace the shoves!
Definitely take it, and I recommend with professor Richardson.  It's all about what you put into the class, because that's exactly what you'll get out of it.
Definitely take this course. It's not a lot of work, though you can certainly get a lot out of it if you put in effort. Monica is wonderful and really encouraged us to flesh out our poetic minds.
Enjoy :)
Fun class! Good readings and fun and easy assignments. Quality of class depends on who's in it, so it's totally a crap shoot.
Have fun with it
I liked having an excuse to write every single week, and it was really cool to listen to Paul Muldoon take your work seriously. Good chill class
I would definitely recommend that other students take CWR 202 with Michael Dickman. The creative writing classes are wonderful and unique.
I would definitely recommend this class to all students needing to fulfill their LA requirement and want to take a relaxing, but fun and engaging course.
It's a good time if you take it seriously and do the work
It's a very easy pass/fail course, so it makes for a good 5th class. That said, you get out of it what you put in.
Make sure you are prepared to commit, as you will be required to generate a lot of new work, and you will want to give yourself enough "creative time" to produce something you are proud of.
Michael Dickman is one of the best professors I have ever had at Princeton because he is just such a fun, quirky presence. If you have any chance at all to take this class - go for it!
Michael Dickman is such a chill guy. Go for this class!
PLEASEPLEASEPLEASE do yourself a favor and take this class! It will make you a more awesome poet and person! Favorite class by far, especially with Michael Dickman!
Please do take this class, even if you think you hate poetry. It's so worth it.
Please.
Prof. Richardson is a good poetry professor, especially for beginners.
Professor O'Rourke's awesome.

Professor Richardson gives great feedback, so you'll get a lot if you put in a lot. That is, your writing will improve. Class chemistry is also important since this is a seminar, but that doesn't mean you can't still focus on your own writing!
Put time into your work. Students can tell who did not spend time on their poems. You don't want to be that kid with lazy and trite poetry.
Read the suggested poems each week as they will help you to come up with your own ideas and style.

Strongly recommend. It's good to create things and see what other create. You get insights into yourself and others that you never would've gotten otherwise. Also, try to get into one of the classes that's more difficult to get into, since it's unfortunately true that many people taking the class are seniors looking for a PDF. Since you spend so much time in class reading others' poems, it matters how much effort they put into it. Professor Youn is a great instructor.
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT! Michael Dickman is dazzling.
Take CWR!  This class is interesting, and it's PDF only, so you can't go wrong.
Take a poetry course. It doesn't matter so much with whom, because each teacher is very good at teaching their particular style of course. Just do it.
Take advantage of the readings and attend every lecture; you'll learn a lot.
Take creative writing! Coach Dickman is awesome!
Take if you have sincere interest/love for poetry, otherwise you will bored.  Classes can feel long sometimes.
Take it if you have not taken a poetry course before.
Take it with Michael Dickman! He's really cool and the class is generally laid-back. The chapbook project at the end is really fun too.
Take it with Professor Dickman!
Take it!
Take it! It's a lot of fun
Take it! Take at least one CWR course before you graduate.
Take it.
Take this class if you want to write a poem a week, discuss it with your peers, talk about their work, have a few laughs, and hang with Michael Dickman.
Take this course if you want to write poetry.

The introductory poetry classes have been the best classes I've taken at Princeton ever. Highly recommend. Professor Richardson takes the class really seriously, so sign up with him only if you are too.

This course tries to teach you how to write a specific type of poem that a lot of American writers write. If you're truly passionate about writing poetry I wouldn't take a creative writing course here, since creativity can become smothered when turned into an assignment. If you just like the idea of writing poetry, then this course may be helpful.

This course was very fun and informative for students with a variety of experience levels in poetry and writing in general.  Also, this was a comfortable, respectful environment to get feedback from peers on your creative work.
This is a fabulous course. The workload is not heavy, and it's really fun work at that. Highly recommend to anyone that has ever put pen to paper.
This is a great class!  Professor Smith is wonderful, and you'll really grow as a writer!
You don't have to be good at poetry to take this class, you can go in with no experience and do equally as well.
You get out as much as you put in.
You get out of it what you put in, and I ended up putting in much more than I expected, because it was fun! Good low pressure, high reward class.
You learn a lot and walk away from the class knowing that.
take it
yup
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing Program application (please visit the program website) by attaching four pages of original poetry or (optionally) a paragraph explaining their interest in the course..
descrip: Practice in the original composition of poetry supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. This class is open to beginning and intermediate students by application.

title: Introduction to Later Sufism (ca. AD 1200 to present)
reviews: An excellent choice.
Be prepared to think outside the box and have to deal with problems you've never dealt with before.
Listen.

Professor Barry is truly amazing, and you should definitely try to take a course with him - you really can't go wrong with any of his classes. That being said, I took both NES 323 (Introduction to Early Sufism) and this course, and if you're only going to take one, I would recommend NES 323 over NES 324. Early Sufism was more oriented toward stories and Sufi art, while Later Sufism focused primarily on philosophy as presented in one book (the section on Ibn 'Arabi's philosophy from Sufism and Taoism by Toshihiko Izutsu), which we read line by line in class. Both courses were great, but I think NES 323 had more variety and therefore was more engaging.
Take it if you can!
Take it. Michael Barry is a fantastic professor, and cares more about you learning and understanding then differentiating students for grading purposes.
descrip: Popularized through translations of world famous poets like the 13th century Rumi, the Sufi mystical strain pervaded Islamic culture for a thousand years and played a major historic role in furthering friendly relations between Muslims and other religious communities through endorsement of spiritual tolerance. The Spring session of this two-term course addresses the overwhelming influence of the Spanish-Muslim Ibn `Arabi (d. 1240 AD) on all subsequent higher Islamic mystical speculation and poetical literature - as far as India.

title: Latinos in American Life and Culture
reviews: Take this course if you're at all interested in Latino studies.
descrip: This course will consider how Latinos are transforming the United States socially, politically, and culturally even as they themselves change in the process. Topics to be examined include the social and cultural significance of "Latino" or "Hispanic" as an ethnic or racial category, how Latinos fit into the American social system, ethnic and cultural identities, their educational and health outcomes, the implications of the unprecedented geographic dispersal of Latinos, and their growing contribution and impact on mainstream and other types of culture including music, literature, and language.

title: Useful Fictions: How and Why Mathematics is Developed and Then Changes the World
reviews: I would recommend students to take this course if they need their QR requirement and if they want to gain a better appreciation for math. I cannot say that I became better in math, but I now find it more interesting than I did before. A student wanting to learn how to do math may become frustrated by the course though, but it is good for a student to understand the complexity of mathematics.
descrip: Provides a view of mathematics as a living, creative endeavor that classifies as both a science and art, giving a feeling for, and some mastery of, the mathematical way of thinking and an awareness of some of the many applications of mathematics. Starting from a broadly historical approach we will move to investigate several important areas of contemporary mathematics.

title: Health Psychology
reviews: Attend lectures, because the information you need for the exams is from lecture.
Definitely take this class
Go to all lectures -- this is the kind of course where it is hard to get good quality notes unless you have taken them yourself. The book/lecture slides will not substitute.
Go to lecture and do the readings and you will really enjoy/ do well in the class.

I thought this course was pretty interesting without being too much work. If you are interested in health or a health care profession, you should definitely take the class. Grading seemed to be fair and tests were relatively straight forward.
I would say take it, and go to lecture.
Just read the textbook if you find the material interesting-- the lecture is a waste of time.
Low workload and pretty easy.

Make sure you memorize all the studies mentioned in lecture, because you might have to write about them in an essay or recall details to answer a multiple choice question on the exam. Always take detailed notes in lecture and precept!
Precepts with Kaite are really awesome. Lectures can get stressful sometimes with note taking, but I highly recommend taking this class. Material is really interesting.
Pretty standard class. Show up to lecture. Read the book when they tell you (from the study guides). Show up to precept, doing the precept assignments. You'll do well.
Read the textbook, pay attention to studies mentioned in class, and do the precept readings so you can contribute in class
Take it if you are interested in the topic. I learned some cool things without struggling at all
Take it!
Take this course!
The class is very interesting if you are interested in the psychological side of medicine. I think it is an important class to take if you are considering going into the medical field.
There are better courses, but it is useful if you are interested in public health or medicine.

This class covers a wide range of topics ranging from stress to health behaviors to getting treatment.  For a given topic, Professor Brynildsen presents the findings from several studies and then synthesizes them into the major models and hypotheses in the field.  Some of it is almost common sense (like "pain impairs cognitive ability"), but sometimes it is neat to see the actual data.  The two exams spaced throughout the semester keep the content from becoming overbearing, and the paper is a fun way to explore your personal interest.
This class is relevant to all and taught well. The readings can be dry, but lectures make up for it.
This course will teach you a lot about the mechanisms behind health and health behaviors. You'll also gain unique insight into healthcare and medicine, along with a view of the future of medicine.

This is a course that teaches a lot of fascinating and eye-opening material about your physical and mental health. Just be prepared to pay close attention in class. The lecture slides are no help and the lectures aren't all that interesting by themselves, but tests ask about very specific questions.
This is a great course for pre med students.
This is a pretty low-effort class with interesting content if you want to go into medicine. No need for any psychology background, but if you have it, this should be an easy class.
This is a solid class--not too much work, fairly straightforward, and I learned some things.  Follow the study guide for tests and review the studies discussed in lecture and you'll be fine.
Very interesting subject matter, but at times can get a little stale. Not too difficult if you stay on top of things and take good notes in lecture.
Yes. Take it. It's awesome.
go to lecture!
great class.  Learned a lot, was pretty easy.
not too much work and is interesting
prereqs: One prior psychology course..
descrip: The objectives of this course are to understand the psychosocial processes that influence health and health care delivery. Topics to be examined are the psychophysiological and sociocultural bases of health and illness; pain; adaptation to chronic illness; stress; personality and illness; death, dying, and grief; substance use; health promoting behaviors; patient adherence; physician-patient communication; health care; and medical ethics and utilization.

title: Tropical Biology
reviews: Definitely take it! Get as much help as you need from Professor Basset and the TAs - they're very helpful!!
Great course, as is the whole semester in Panama! Yves Basset is very approachable and friendly.
I strongly recommend the field sequence in either Panama or Kenya to all EEB Majors.
Take good lecture notes and don't be afraid to ask Professor Basset questions!
Take it! It was a great time walking though tropical forests and experiencing what field work was really like.

While the textbook is very interesting and informative, I don't think it was very necessary for the course. Take advantage of being in the field and Yves very wide range of knowledge. Don't be afraid to get to know him - he's great!
take it take it take it go to panama it's amazing.
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester tropical biology program in Panama..
descrip: "Tropical Biology" is an intensive, three-week field course given at four sites in Panama, examining the origins, maintenance and major interactions among terrestrial plants and animals. The course provides the opportunity to appreciate (1) floral and faunal turnover among four rainforest sites (beta-diversity); and (2) floral and faunal turnover along vertical gradients, from ground to upper canopy, at two rainforest sites (vertical stratification). Students carry out individual projects at the sites. Fieldwork is supported by six orientation walks that introduce participants to common orders and families of plants and arthropods.

Course will also include a visit to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to study additional works.

I don't know much about Professor Stone, but I was never in want of a better professor for the entire semester so even though I've heard great things about Stone, Yannis was good too. He did teach pretty straight out of the book for most lectures - however, I felt as though this helped you understand the concepts even more so since you could go back to the book and remember what happened in lecture. When a percentage of people started skipping class once spring came, he adapted the course. He posted extra practice problems and answers online, he tried to use different examples from the book in lecture, and reformed review sessions (optional-type precepts). He also has a very unique sense of humor, which would perk up the class every so often. For the first time at Princeton, I thought the problems sets for a class were fair (based on what you learned) and took a reasonable amount of time to complete. And then the tests were open-book and questions similar to the homework. At no point in lecture, hw, or tests were you wondering what was going on. However, there is a LOT of content compared to other classes so this was the first class that waiting till the day before to study wasn't sufficient.
