title: Democratic Theory and Practice
descrip: Course examines policy-making in the contemporary American political system, focusing on two broad models--one emphasizing majoritarian aggregation of public preferences and the other emphasizing power, preference intensity, and bargaining. We consider the normative foundations, logical coherence, and empirical veracity of each of these models and assess their utility as theories of democratic policy-making.

title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
reviews: Although it was not quite as bad as others said it would be, it is very frustrating that most of the points you will get off will be from picky things on figures that could have been fixed if the professors or AIs would just tell you in your draft.
Be sure to start writing reports early!
Do data analysis as you're doing the lab - there's a lot of it. Don't concentrate on the minute details - get the big picture.
Don't if you don't have to.

Don't take. Unless you're CBE, at which point think really hard about the fact that you have to take the course. We learned nothing apart from 'make clear graphs', 'write legibly', or 'speak up with confidence'.
Get through it.
Good luck guys. You will suffer but you will get through it.
I don't understand why anyone will take this course of their own free will.

If you are reading this, you are probably required to take this class at some point as a CBE major. If you are not a CBE major, please don't take this class--it is a huge time commitment and you won't get much out of it.

CBE majors--START EARLY! As soon as you get some data, analyze it to the best of your ability. That way, if you have any questions (and you will have a lot of questions because the lab manuals are terrible), you can ask your TA early on and then you can do the subsequent data analysis in a more painless manner. Start error analysis early as well. Ask a professor if you are confused. Don't forget error bars, and don't forget uncertainty intervals. If lab reports are due Monday (or Tuesday), I would suggest having all of your data analysis, including error analysis, done at latest by Thursday (or Friday) so you can spend the weekend pounding out your lab report. 

Be super efficient during your lab sessions. 3 hours isn't a lot of time, and for some labs, you will have to wait around for certain things so you may stay later than 3 hours.

Lab reports--they might be graded arbitrarily. If it seems like you put in a lot of effort but you grade doesn't reflect that, don't worry too much. You can't do anything about that and everyone's pretty much in the same boat. 

Oral presentations--practice a lot and try to anticipate any sort of curveball question the professors will throw at you. Brainstorm with your partner possible questions. If you are confused about a concept, you'll probably be asked to explain that concept, so get that cleared up before your presentation.

Partners--if you are allowed to pick partners (which you probably will be doing), pick someone you know you will work well with. Make sure that person has a similar schedule to you and has a similar work ethic. For example, if you are someone who likes to start early but your partner likes to do things last-minute, this probably won't work out, even if the two of you are best fri
If you're CBE you don't have a choice.

If you're a CBE, you're going to have to take it anyway. It's a lot of time in lab, but the most painful parts are right before reports are due. Just so you know what to expect, you have 4 experiment cycles. You do 2 written reports, one oral report per partner, and one poster presentation. You can choose your partner, so choose someone you can work with well! Don't procrastinate - do your data analysis as you go. Don't worry, you'll get through it and survive just like the rest of us. :)

It is so great! You'll learn to write lab reports like a pro, give American Idol-like power point presentations, and have a grand finale pizza and poster presentation session. Pick your partner wisely, because working that closely with one other can bring up some issues. Before going into lab, really read the lab manuals so you can be efficient in lab. Start writing the reports up early so the professors can help you with analysis. The professors really care about the presentation quality of your reports and power point, so focus a lot on how "pretty" it is. They really want the data to be reported in the best way, and that goes a lot towards the "prettiness" I'm talking about.
It's required.

Process data immediately. Start working on analysis right away. Also talk to the professor in charge of your experiment because they'll usually have something they want that they didn't tell you in the lab manual.

Run away fast from CBE if you still have a chance (really should not have taken you this long to realize your mistake though). This course will literally make you hate your life. The professors grade arbitrarily and their expectations of you are at times totally unreasonable. There was never a clear idea of what one was expected to gain from each experiment and report back to the professors. Just generally a terrible experience. Felt like climbing Mt. Everest while carrying a boulder on your shoulders and slowly being deprived of oxygen and life. When things start to look sort of bright, they quickly disappear and you realize that you will never reach the top and that there will always be three overlooking Gods laughing at you every step of the way on this fruitless ascent.

So this is it.  You've bs'ed your way through CBE 245.  You still don't know what fugacity is after thermo.  You still aren't sure what the point of sep was, and you suffered dearly though pipes.  Now, it's time for the granddaddy of them all: core lab.  Ever since you were a clueless freshman considering chemical engineering, you heard upperclassmen about core lab...usually under their breaths.  "(To you) Yes, you should totally become a CBE!  (whispered, usually to a friend) Heh heh, wait until they get to core lab..."  Even other course reviews tend to talk about how terrible this class is.  To be honest, though, CORE LAB ISN'T THAT BAD.  The truth is, it takes up a lot of time, there's no getting around that.  With six hours in lab per week, you'll be putting a lot of time into it.  Although this already seems like a lot to do, make sure to analyze your data that you collect in each lab before the next one.  This will help you make more informed measurements as labs go on.  Also, get as much feedback as you can on your written work and data before it is due.  Your TA should be willing and able to help with this.  If you do core lab right, it can be one of the most worthwhile experiences of Princeton.  If you don't, you'll end up hating every minute of your life.  So, buckle in, put on your big boy (or girl) pants, and get ready to do some science.
Talk to your professors (and not your TA's) for your reports, since they're the ones that end up grading it.
Think of something creative to do on the last day of each cycle that shows your understanding of the lab.

This course isn't that bad if you START EARLY and ASK QUESTIONS. After every lab period, make sure you've analyzed your data before the next period. Make sure your data is in line with what you expect - if it's not, bring up the discrepancy to your TA or Prof in the next period so that you can either a) understand what went wrong or b) understand why the data's ok and why your expectation was wrong. With your reports, it's really important to figure out what each professor wants emphasized - the way you do this is to ask lots of questions during lab. If you're having trouble analyzing your data, your TA and professor can be really helpful, but you have to analyze it early enough to be able to ask about it. Your TA will also have a good idea about what each professor wants - ask them if there's anything in particular that's important to focus on in the report. The reports will take a lot of time - plan on spending the four  days before the report's due working on core lab a lot.
Well, you have to take it. People will complain constantly, BUT report writing is a skill you need. Though Core Lab isn't always fun, I got way more out of it than many CBE courses (coughcough Sep)
Work early.
You have to take this. It sucks. deal with it.
take only if need to
your TAs will never be as good as mine.
prereqs: CBE 246, CBE 250, and CBE 341 or equivalents..
descrip: An intensive hands-on practice of engineering. Experimental work in the areas of separations, heat transfer, fluid mechanics, process dynamics and control, materials processing and characterization, chemical reactors. Development of written and oral technical communication skills.

title: Intermediate Hebrew II
reviews: New teacher
do not take this class.  Hebrew is an amazing language but Esther cannot teach
prereqs: HEB 105 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Completion of two-year textbook, Ha-Yesod, and reading and discussion of selected additional texts (newspaper, stories, poems, etc.) Extensive practice in conversation, writing and reading and tasting Hebrew literature.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Contemporary Challenges in Electric Power
reviews: Amazing lectures. A very informative and engaging course.
Definitely take it.
Definitely worth it!
Fun and current.

Great class. No work, but got to listen to a bunch of fascinating lectures over a wide range of topics. Small class, so very easy to ask questions and dictate conversation. Loved going to class even though it was at night twice a week.

Great survey class. Doesn't take much effort to attend, and you learn a good deal about important topics in the power industry. Highly recommend if you are in any sort of field related to energy issues.
Take this course and listen carefully to each lecture, try to contact with speakers whose presentation attracted you.
This course, if again organized by Prof. Wagner
This was a great class. Very educational and interesting!
descrip: The goal of this readings-and-presentations course is to introduce students to recent and anticipated technical developments in the electric power industry. Increasing electrification of advanced economies, network coordination over ever larger geographic areas, power generation by distributed wind and photovoltaics, lack of broadly usable electricity storage, and electrification of automotive transportation are posing many new challenges to the generation, transmission, distribution, and use of electric power. Lecturers and students present specific topics. Students choose topics on their own or from the syllabus.

title: Jesus of Nazareth: Ancient Controversies, New Interpretations
reviews: A wonderful course, Professor Pagels is a great professor who ably directs the discussion and encourages everyone's questions, and the material was fascinating.
Absolutely! I loved it.
An incredible seminar. An incredible professor.

Definitely take this course. Professor Pagels is a world expert and you'll learn a ton. Also, try really hard to get into the seminar if it's application-only. Many of my seminars and precepts here have had worse-than-expected quality of discussion (lots of people P/D/Fing, people are trying out some discipline for the first time and don't have much of a gift for it, etc.) but the other students in the class were really bright and brought a lot to the table. I highly recommend the course. Professor Pagels leads discussion well, picks good people for the seminar and puts together a good set of readings. This was really good.

Elaine Pagels brings a lot of energy to the seminars.  She is always interested in your interpretations of the passages and is incredibly knowledgeable.  Even if you were raised in a Christian household you will learn about much more interesting aspects of Christianity than you could in a church.

Prof. Pagels is a superstar, if you have a chance to take a seminar with her, you should jump at it.  she is also really kind and understanding, which makes her a great person to interact with in a small setting.  The subject matter is the stuff I love, but i think it would be interesting to anyone who ever wondered about jesus/the bible
Take it! It is a great opportunity to read the Bible and learn about Jesus!
Take this course! No matter what background you come from, this information will change your perspective on the world.

This was the last class I took at Princeton, and perhaps the best. Professor Pagels is a treasure for this school. The topics is fascinating -- big and consequential but narrow enough to really sink your teeth in. Could not recommend enough.
Wonderful course. You'd be lucky to take it.
descrip: In this seminar we will first investigate the earliest known sources--both gospels in the New Testament and "gnostic gospels" outside the NT, including the Gospels of Thomas, Mary Magdalene, and Philip. Second, we will explore a range of attempts to place Jesus in historical context. And third, we will look at interpretations of Jesus in poetry, theology, fiction, and film.

title: Spanish Language and Culture through Cinema
reviews: DEFINITELY TAKE THIS WITH GORKA -- I haven't taken a Spanish class in four years, and this was the best part of my day every day even though it was at 11am.

Definitely take it! Gorka is wonderful and there is not as much pressure as in other language classes since you are watching films. Make sure that when you come to class you are ready to give it your all because it really is a class where you get out of it what you put in.
I would advise that they put lots of time into the course, because if you are always prepared for class and for presentations the course is much more enjoyable.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student and I would advise them to watch all the films, to do their blackboard posts as early in the week as possible, and to practice their spoken spanish as often as they can.

I would highly recommend this course for any student who wants to improve Spanish speaking skills. If you are genuinely interested in Spanish culture this is a great class. There is not a lot of grammar so if you are looking for a more structure, writing based class this is not it. Gorka is a great, engaging professor. You'll have a lot of fun.
If you're looking for a class to improve your linguistic knowledge, this probably isn't the best option. If you're looking for a class to increase your conversational ability, then take it.
It's a fun course in that you get to watch a lot of great movies and simultaneously improve your spanish, but the grading is harsh at times.
Make sure you pay very, very close attention to grammar in all of your assignments. It counts a lot more than you might think.

Speak-a the Spanish. Practice the Spanish. Love the Spanish.
Good luck. I have a feeling you'll enjoy yourself.

Such a great class. It's a lot of fun and the content is really interesting and varied. If you're already comfortable speaking and writing Spanish, you'll be surprised by how much this class will add to what you already know. If you're not particularly comfortable with those things, then you should definitely take this class. I think everyone in the class saw notable progress in their speaking and writing. And all while getting to watch really good movies. Also, Gorka's the best. Basically, take this class!!!

TAKE IT. Such a good class!! Work load is decent - watch a weekly film and write 250 words on it, plus a few bigger assignments in between. Don't let the 4 presentations daunt you, they became easier throughout the year. Good films, good discussion, good prof, good class.
Take it! You won't regret it
Take it, it's awesome. The grade might be frustrating but everything is fun and worthwhile.
Take it. Gork's amazing!

Take this class!! It's so much more productive and enjoyable than another class that focuses on grammar. It forces you to put grammar into practice with (surprisingly difficult/harshly graded) weekly responses to movies. And class discussions are also pretty complex and interesting. Overall, despite or perhaps due to the difficulty of the course, I've learned so much from it.
Take this course! A great way to continue to improve spoken Spanish, but not a huge time commitment. Gorka is a wonderful professor to work with.

This class is a great way to see some Spanish movies, and it's fairly laid-back. Be warned that it does still focus a fair amount on learning the language (as opposed to just analyzing the films), but it's still a fine class to take.
Try your hardest to speak in class.
prereqs: SPA 107 (with instructor's permission) or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or a satisfactory AP/SAT score (AP5/SP SAT ST 760)..
descrip: A course designed mainly to improve your speaking abilities while learning about Hispanic cultures and cinema. Moreover, throughout the semester there will be several writing exercises that will help you to improve your writing abilities. Every movie will be discussed in class. Additionally, each student will watch a supplementary film. By the end of the course, students should have a better command of all their linguistic skills, especially listening comprehension and speaking.

title: Read Like an Egyptian II: Continuing Middle Egyptian
prereqs: Prerequisite COM 222, or equivalent..
descrip: This course will continue "Read Like an Egyptian" (COM 222, Fall '13). First, students will complete the introduction to Middle Egyptian Grammar. The course will then introduce students to a medley of Egyptian texts, including passages from the literary tale the "Shipwrecked Sailor" and other stories, the formula of standard funerary inscriptions, a chapter of the Book of the Dead, and the spells inscribed on ushabti statuettes.

title: The Formation of Christian Art
reviews: A great class, centered on intellectually exciting and interesting lectures. But the course somewhat lacks structure, the lectures can be slightly dull, and the work load is quite heavy, with very demanding criteria. Probably PDF it if you can.

I would recommend this class to students with substantial previous knowledge on the Bible, Greco-Roman mythology, and the early Christian history Many readings are very long and dense, and the professor assumes that students already understood most of them before class. The last research paper requires a lot of independent work outside class and also might require you to look into sources in German or French, given the nature of the topic. Nonetheless Professor Barber was very nice and approachable, and I would highly recommend taking the course if you're interested in the subject.
It's definitely a niche interest, and it was a small course, but if it's a topic for you, I couldn't recommend it highly enough.
Take it if you have a strong background in biblical stories and Roman history.
descrip: Art in late antiquity has often been characterized as an art in decline, but this judgment is relative, relying on standards formulated for art of other periods. Challenging this assumption, we will examine the distinct and powerful transformations within the visual culture of the period between the third and sixth centuries AD. This period witnesses the mutation of the institutions of the Roman Empire into those of the Christian Byzantine Empire. The fundamental change in religious identity that was the basis for this development directly impacted the art from that era that will be the focus of this course.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing wtih the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students/post-docs.

title: Introduction to Engineering Dynamics
reviews: Definitely a great MAE course!
Definitely take!

Do the reading for the lecture (and take notes) before the actual lecture; it'll help provide a book baseline for the material you're about to cover. Ask any and all questions as soon as possible, start problem sets early and try and do a problem a day; that'll make life easier. Take any and all questions to lab TAs; they're awesome. Make sure you review any problems you got wrong or didn't understand when the solutions get released, then you'll be in solid standing for the final.
Dynamics is interesting and the professor/preceptors are awesome.

GO TO THE PRECEPTS. Really, go to them. For me, they were just incredibly helpful in terms of getting through the homework - that one hour in precept would later save me four hours spent on the homework by myself. And don't hesitate to talk to the TAs about questions for the homework.

It's F = ma and then a bunch of vector algebra. I enjoyed it quite a lot, actually. 
Make sure you REALLY understand the notation when he introduces it at the beginning of the year. It's important and the basis for everything else.
Give yourself time on the problem sets!
Go in to get help as often as is needed.
Go to Groff's lectures--they're great. Also, email preceptors questions on homeworks.
Go to lecture!
Go to office hours for help. They are there for you.

If you took PHY 105 you might not learn much but you'll have an advantage. You might get bored. Psets can be tedious but are definitely doable. Reasonable workload. Tests are all take-home but kinda long, specially troublesome for the midterm but that depends on your midterm week.
If you're MAE you have to take it, it isn't terrible, some of it is actually interesting.
Make sure you stay on top of things, start psets early. They are long

My advice would be to consult the textbook to try to figure out any problems for themselves before asking more specific questions. This is because general problem solving from using the text becomes very important for the take home midterms and final exam.
Only take it if you need to.
Pay attention to lectures and read through examples in the book!
Start the problem sets early, and go to precepts and office hours.
Start your problem sets early, do extra problems. Go to office hours.
Take it. It is an excellent course and you will learn a lot. Put in the time and all will be well. :)
You're probably taking this course because you have to, but it's very interesting and rewarding if you devote the time to understand the material.
its basically physics 103 with tedious notation
prereqs: MAT 201 and PHY 103. MAE 223 or CEE 205 recommended. Freshmen may take the course with the instructor's permission..
descrip: Formulation and solution of equations governing the dynamic behavior of engineering systems. Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics. Two and three dimensional kinematics and kinetics of particles and rigid bodies. Motion relative to moving reference frames. Impulse-momentum and work-energy relations. Free and forced vibrations of mechanical systems. Introduction to dynamic analysis of mechanical devices and systems.

title: Directed Research II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research II has to be taken before the General Exam.

title: Biological Oceanography
reviews: Definitely take this course!  The lectures were great and the workload was totally feasible.  I was surprised by how much of the course was focused on phytoplankton, and I was also surprised by how interesting phytoplankton can be.
Do your paper early.
Don't take this class unless you have some background in the topic.
I wish I could take it again. And again. And again.
I would encourage any student interested in biological oceanography to take this course.
Learn more about oceanography and sign up for this course!
prereqs: College level chemistry, biology and physics.
descrip: Fundamentals of Biological Oceanography, with an emphasis on the ecosystem level. We will consider the organisms in the context of their chemical and physical environment; the properties of seawater, atmosphere and ocean dynamics that affect life in the ocean; primary production and marine food webs; global cycles of carbon and other elements; current research approaches. In addition to lectures by the professors, the course will delve deeply into the current and classic literature of oceanography and students will be expected to participate in seminar type presentations and discussions.

title: Research Projects in Molecular Biology (Laboratory Rotations)
reviews: I really enjoyed all of my rotations and worked very hard in all three of them.  I do not think that it was fair that two girls basically had three months off during the second rotation in the Burdine Lab and still passed the rotation.  The other students who rotated in her lab were able to get a lot of work done, and they enjoyed their experience.  I think that we should all be expected to work the same amount during each rotation, no matter what is going on in our personal lives.  Breaking up with your boyfriend does not entail you to three months off.  The fact that they got away with this is, by bashing the Burdine Lab is outrageous!
NA
Pick a good lab.
ya gotta do it. find a lab you enjoy
descrip: Students perform research in the laboratories of potential faculty advisors.

title: The Just Society
reviews: An interesting class.  Focuses almost solely on economic justice.
Definitely do the readings because it will save you time in the long run and make the class a lot more interesting. Lectures are great, so attend those too.
Do it! This course is accessible, interesting, and very relevant to current issues.
Go to office hours for your papers
I think this is a great way to become exposed to key ideas in political theory.
I would suggest they take the course only if they have a handle on how politics courses go. I definitely think it is a challenging course for a freshman to jump into.
I would tell another student to review notes after every lecture. This could help stimulate thinking about the subject even outside of lecture time, which could really help with the essays.
It was a bit dry. Important things to read, but not that interesting all together.

Keep in mind that this is a course about ECONOMIC justice - primarily theories of original appropriation and just distributions. I did not get as much out of the course as I had hoped to - in part because I think the course could be better structured, in part because I was often distracted by material that was tangential to the primary purpose of this course (which is not about the content of the readings, but summaries of the ideas in them), and in part because I did not always put as much time in to the course as I would have liked to.
Take it! Be prepared for alot of readings, but go prepared for every class. Ask questions in precept, pay attention and critically evaluate what you have read. You will learn alot.

Take it! It's a fascinating course taught by a great professor, and albeit a bit theoretical, is really informative and (in my opinion) important to take in order to learn different ways of thinking about justice in our economy today.
Take it! Lots of learning and very manageable workload. Papers are interesting to write.

Take it! Straight-forward class and good for a distribution requirement or a fairly simple PDF. It is also really relevant for understanding and discovering one's own interpretation of what justice means and requires with regard to society.
Take it! Though keep in mind that it mostly focuses on economic justice as opposed to social justice.

This is a great course to pdf.  You don't have to put much time in but you learn a lot about a  really interesting topic.  It's a good overview of justice theory and gives you a basic understanding to work with if you're interested in the subject.

This is a great course to take if you are interested in questions about economic justice. The lectures and readings are excellent, and they may well prompt you to reconsider your own views by the end of the course.
descrip: An introduction to theories of social justice and examination of their implications in areas of contemporary social and political controversy. The first half of the course introduces the problem of social justice and examines two classic positions, as articulated by John Locke (whose name is associated with liberalism, property, and capitalism) and Karl Marx (whose name is associated with the critique of capitalism). The second half of the course focuses on contemporary theories of justice. We will read authors such as John Rawls and Robert Nozick, and examine controversies over poverty, taxation, equal opportunity, and environmental justice.

title: Religion and Philosophy in the Roman Empire
reviews: Do the readings because you'll get more out of it, but in any case you can expect to cover some really interesting general topics and have some good discussions.
This is a fantastic course.  There's a lot of reading, but it's worth it.
prereqs: PHI 205 or a good working knowledge of the major doctrines of the four Greek philosophical schools..
descrip: This course aims to introduce students to the intellectual world of late antiquity, a period of the history of Western cultural development that was, contrary to common belief, far more formative and influential than the cherished classical or Hellenistic periods. Participants will study texts that exemplify the way in which elite discourses of rationality first developed in the context of the Greek polis collided with the religious experiences and sentiments of eastern ethnic groups to create an entirely new paradigm of human existence.

title: Literature and Society - Novel, Epic and Empire
descrip: This course explores how the novel engages with the problem of alienation in the modern world by appropriating and reformulating epic form. What happens when the private systems of novelistic characters are at odds with normative values and social systems? What form does the novel take when alienation is no longer an obstacle to be overcome but a mark of being? What is the historical and philosophical meaning of form in a world that is "gone out of joint" (Lukacs)? We focus on a set of texts that emerge at moments of crisis and transition--from empire to nation, "primitive" accumulation to capitalism, and from slavery to freedom.

title: Public Speaking
reviews: Definitely
Great class to take senior spring. You'll improve your public speaking abilities if you actually take this class seriously!
Let go in lecture.  If you care a lot about what the other people in the class will think, then will not enjoy the class and get nothing out of it

Take this course! It has been by far one of my favorite at Princeton. There is a reasonable amount of work expected, but the class time itself is always enjoyable and I think anyone who has any doubts about their public speaking abilities would benefit enormously from taking this class.
descrip: ENG 230 aims to develop effective public speaking skills, along with a complex understanding of what it means to speak. At the same time as we look at some of the key ways in which voice and speech making have been imagined and theorized, we will draw on a variety of vocal and acting exercises to improve confidence and expression in oral presentation. The culmination of the course will be a public talk.

title: Geodynamics Seminar - Origin and Evolution of the Continental Lithosphere
reviews: Have some background in matlab.
Take this class if you have a solid background in geochemistry and/or geophysics (plus experience writing code) and want to delve into the literature/ play around with other peoples' data.
There was a substantial amount of matlab used in this class, which was great because I learned a great deal. But not everyone in class had the same level of matlab proficiency
descrip: Despite its volumetric insignificance on Earth, the continental lithosphere is an immensely important geochemical reservoir, hosts the terrestrial biosphere, and impacts plate tectonics and therefore mantle convection. This course surveys how and why continental lithosphere is formed, preserved, and destroyed throughout Earth history. We tap into datasets collected using structural geology, geochemistry and petrology, radiogenic and stable isotopes, seismology, gravity, and heat flow, all of which are used to inform numerical and theoretical models.

title: The Ballet
reviews: Attend lectures, they are well presented by one of the best lecturers out there. Try to get into Prof Morrison's precept, it is equally engaging and informative as his lectures.
Easily one of my favorite classes at Princeton so far. Take it for sure if you get the chance! Amazing professor and amazing lectures.

Music knowledge is very helpful in this course. It may not seem like it for the first half but it is a large portion of the second half of the course. That being said, it is not difficult without a music background, especially if it is being taken as a PDF course

Prof. Morrison is brilliant and the topic really interesting. This felt less like a class, and more like a time to just enjoy thinking about and watching one of the most beautiful arts of human civilization. Take it!
Professor Morrison is a fantastic lecturer--take it!
Take it if you're interested in dance or music, but it won't go very in-depth.
This is an excellent course, and I learned a lot. As a musician and a dancer I took away a lot from this class. Please take it. Simon Morrison is a great lecturer and a fair grader. :)
descrip: A history of ballet from its origins in the French courts through its development into a large-scale theatrical spectacle in the 19th century and its modernist deformation. Emphasis will be placed on seminal dancers, choreographers, and composers, nationalist tradition, and socio-political context.

title: Modeling Tools for Cell and Developmental Biology
descrip: Mathematical models of complex natural phenomena can organize large amounts of data, provide access to properties that are difficult or impossible to measure experimentally, and suggest new experimental tests of proposed regulatory mechanisms. Participants will demonstrate these ideas in the context of cell and developmental biology. Using a number of well-established experimental systems, such as dynamic instability of microtubules and circadian clocks, course introduces stochastic and deterministic models of reaction and diffusion processes and computational methods for their analysis.

title: Markov Processes
reviews: Professor Cinlar is a great professor so don't hesitate to take this course (however I don't think he will be teaching it any longer)
Professor Cinlar is retiring next year
descrip: Markov processes with general state spaces; transition semigroups, generators, resolvants; hitting times, jumps, and Levy systems; additive functionals and random time changes; killing and creation of Markovian motions.

title: Economic Development II
reviews: The readings are very important.
This course will provide a great guidance in engaging into research in applied economics.

This is a good class to take to familiarize yourself with not just the contemporary questions in development, but also some long-standing methodological and, indeed, ideological debates. It may also be a good idea to supplement with this class with a class from the econometrics sequence.
prereqs: ECO 562.
descrip: Selected topics in the economic analysis of development beyond those covered in 562. Topics are selected from the theory and measurement of poverty and inequality; the relationship between growth and poverty; health and education in economic development; saving, growth, population, and development; commodity prices in economic development.

title: The Sociology of Crime and Punishment
reviews: Definitely recommend this class to any student of any year.
Definitely take this class!

Please take this class, as well as any other classes Professor Chancer teaches in the future. She is probably one of the most insightful, understanding, and fair professors you will ever have at Princeton!
TAKE it.

The class was slightly disorganized at times, but learning sociological theories of crime and then specific case studies was very enlightening, especially in light of contemporary debates over mass incarceration, the death penalty, etc. The professor really synthesized the information well in the final lecture.

There's not many law-related classes you can take at Princeton, but if you're interested at all in criminal law or criminal justice, this is a great course to take. Professor Chancer does a great job of giving you a comprehensive look at crime and punishment, and I think the course is structured very well (half is dedicated to different theories of crime, and the second half is dedicated to case studies, policies, punishment, etc.). She has an interesting seminar style in that she lectures half the time and runs discussions for the second half. I would've preferred more discussion time, but I definitely learned a lot through her prepared lectures as well. She always works hard to bring in a lot of guest lecturers who tend to be experts in their fields! Professor Chancer is very kind and easy to approach, and she's very flexible as well, always willing to help students out.
This is a very good course with interesting readings and interesting class discussion.

This is one of the best Sociology courses that Princeton has to offer. Make sure that you plan ahead for the final paper, as it is very lengthy. Meet with Prof. Chancer and take advantage of her offer to review drafts
descrip: This course seeks to provide a sociological account of crime and punishment. Why do people commit crime? How should we respond to crime? How has crime policy changed over the past several decades? What are the consequences of recent crime policy? By reading classic and contemporary sociological research, policy analysis, and media coverage, we will explore the themes of crime and punishment in contemporary society.

title: Dangerous Music
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Organic Chemistry II with Biological Emphasis
reviews:
1) Seek help when you need to. Early.
2) Don't be afraid to seek out the profs. They are super helpful and willing to sit down with you to go through any and all problems/questions you may have. They really care about you doing well.
3) Do all practice exams. If you have enough time, do them all again. And maybe again.
4) Don't come in telling yourself you'll never like orgo. Be open to it--the stereotypes about orgo are definitely not much more than myths at Princeton. It's challenging, but as long as you stick with it with an open mind it's more than rewarding.
ATTEND LECTURES.

As a freshman taking the orgo sequence, it wasn't really that bad to be honest. Much less scary than everyone else makes it out to be. Just pay attention and go to lecture. When prepping for exams, read the book and do past exams. Also, for labs, you might want to pick your lab TA carefully - some are more laid back than others; depending on your lab TA, the amount of time and effort put into your lab report varies.
Be engaged. Go to office hours and review sessions, read book before hand. Practice practice, get a tutor.
Do not take this course unless you absolutely have to.
Do the work and try to enjoy the material.
Don't take it unless you have to; so much work.
Easier to keep up than catch up. You're only taking this because you have to, so keep that advice in mind.
Fantastically organized class. Provides so many resources-- take advantage of them!!

Fascinating course, great professors, but getting a good grade is very difficult. There is a reason this class has a reputation of being the archetypal pre-med class in which everyone only wants good grades as the expense of everyone else.
Go to review sessions, resource hours and get a tutor.
Good luck!
Harder than 303, so plan accordingly.

I loved orgo, but this class was a real struggle. Be prepared to put in a lot of work. It's the only way to get a good grade. I'll admit I slacked off a lot, because by second semester, you're so sick of those three exams every month

I mean, if you have to take it, you have to take it. But that being said, I didn't absolutely hate it, and orgo definitely has a worse reputation than it deserves. DO THE PRACTICE EXAMS and go to lecture. Also, start lab reports not the night before they're due.
I would advise them to take it only if they have to
I would tell them to only take this course if they are required to for their department.
If you have a deep passion for biology and chemistry, this class is a must!
If you have the option of taking Semmelhack or Sorrenson, I hear it was a better choice to take Sorrenson.
If you like problem solving, you will like this course. It is challenging but rewarding. Do the practice tests.

It's a good course that can be interesting if you have the right mindset, although it definitely is difficult. If you're considering taking it at another school, it might be easier, but keep in mind that at Princeton the course is open-book and open-notes, which makes a big difference. I still feel I learned what I needed to, but it was so helpful to not have the stress of having to memorize all the reactions that you learn anyway by doing all the practice.
It's challenging, but that means that it can also be great and rewarding.
It's orgo, and it's orgo done really, really well.
It's orgo....if you're taking it you most likely don't have a choice. I enjoyed CHM 304B because of the biological focus. It really helped to keep me engaged and interested.
Just stay on top of your work. Don't slack as the final is important!
Keep up with the material, and go to all lectures. The laboratories are fun!

prereqs: Prerequisite: CHM 301 or CHM 303. Course is open to freshmen..
descrip: The concepts introduced in CHM 303 will be extended to the structures and reactions of more complex molecules, with an emphasis on how organic chemistry provides the framework for understanding molecular processes in biology. The fundamental concepts of organic chemistry will be illustrated, as often as possible, with examples drawn from biological systems. Appropriate for chemistry and engineering majors, premedical students, and students with an interest in organic chemistry and its central position in the life sciences.

title: Visual Art and the Representation of Knowledge
descrip: See website

title: Special Studies in the Nineteenth Century - Victorian Narratives: Ekphrasis, Icongraphy, Illustration
descrip: This seminar focuses on the relationship between written narrative and graphic representation. We look at a variety of forms--poetry, novel, essay, painting, illustration--with an eye to the profound interdependence of word and image in the art of the Victorian age. We consider the Pre-Raphaelites, illustrations of Dickens' novels, Julia Margaret Cameron's photographs, and William Morris' medievalism. Why do novelists include descriptions of paintings in their fiction? How does realist painting replicate and depart from the conventions of literary narrative? Why did photographers and painters so often depend on literary subjects?

title: Special Topics in Dance History, Criticism, and Aesthetics - The Art of Seeing: Choreograpy in the Contemporary Moment
reviews: Claudia gives very thorough feedback on your writing. Discussions tend to go in loops a bit but overall I think it is highly enjoyable.

This was a very very interesting class, and certainly not what I expected. But I certainly learned a lot and have a much broader perspective of dance. Professor La Rocco is also a wonderful teacher, and she makes the 3 hour class much more bearable and engaging than a lot of other seminars I have taken.
descrip: Dance has long since corrupted and been corrupted by an array of disciplines and traditions. The form can be impossibly esoteric, fraught with politics of gender, sex, race and class; meanwhile Beyonce steals moves from European heavyweight Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker and the performance artist Marina Abramovic fashions a dizzying cult of celebrity. How can audiences keep up? This course proposes that the first, difficult step is really seeing what's in front of you. We will place dance within wider cultural and interdisciplinary contexts, meet with artists and thinkers, and focus on writing as an intellectual and artistic practice.

For exams, the free response will focus on graphs from lectures, while the multiple choice will ask some tricky questions about the readings, so be sure to do them! Choose an oral presentation topic earlier in the semester, as you will be graded easier than those who take topics later in the course. Workload is quite manageable: midterm, final, oral presentation, and a non-graded precept response each week. This is a perfect class to take with a senior thesis, as it doesn't kill you with work throughout the semester. For anyone even remotely interested in economic growth theory or the development of the American economy, this course is a must!

prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101. These are firm prerequisites, NOT co-requisites. This course counts towards WWS disciplinary perspectives requirement..
descrip: Modern economic theory is used to analyze growth and fluctuations in U.S. output from colonial times to the present. The course examines the role of labor markets, property rights in land and labor, financial institutions, transportation, innovation and other factors in economic growth. Before examining twentieth century fluctuations, a week is spent on business cycle theory. Then particular emphasis is placed on The Great Depression and its relationship to the recession of 2007-2009.

title: Research Seminar in American Political History
descrip: This course is an intensive research seminar on the political history of the United States from the Revolutionary era to the present. Students work closely with the instructor and with each other in defining and developing original research topics, and then in drafting and revising research papers. During open weeks, we cover readings that either discuss or exemplify changing trends in the writing of American political history. Emphasis falls on the history of formal politics and government, but topics may include matters such as political culture and the interplay of government and social movements.

title: Topics in Germanic Literatures - 1914: Masks, Violence, and Spectatorship in the Shadow of WWI
reviews: A knowledge of some aspect of theater, art history, politics, sociology or psychology would be helpful.  This was a very interdisciplinary class that was nevertheless firmly rooted in German history and culture.

prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: The course will investigate texts written within the context of the rupture of the First World War. Special emphasis will be placed on questions of language and mediality, and on techniques and acts of spectatorship. One central aim is to understand the central metaphors of acting, masks, and masquerade, and the highly important role of the body and physical violence. The narrative of primitivism and the figure of an ecstatic "falling apart" will also be examined within the historical context of German and European modernism.

Just hope that this is restructured for next semester. It was by far the worst lecture course I have taken at Princeton so far. The online and in-person lectures never covered what we needed to know in order to complete problem sets and to succeed on quizzes and tests. Clicker questions were completely frustrating because the answers were rarely explained well. Many students sitting near me would groan in disappointment and confusion when the answers were displayed, yet the professor would simply march on to the next blackbox-type demonstration without making sure that we understood the previous, probably because he insisted on getting through too many examples in each lecture. The online lectures were taken exactly from the textbook, but could not serve as a replacement for reading the chapters because the professor did not even cover all of the material in any chapter. It would have taken me less time and been more effective for me to read the book, but because this class was sucking up so much time already, I rarely went over the text. So, I just went into Monday class always unprepared for the week's material. Because the online and in-person lectures were mandatory, I wasted 2-2.5 hours per week (because sometimes there were two online lectures). Exams were nothing like the quizzes, which were nothing like the WileyPlus assignments, which were nothing like the click questions, which were nothing like the MCAT question that my preceptor spent 45 min on per week. This did not give a well-rounded understanding of the material, but rather a sense of panic and continuous under-preparedness.
Keep doing practice problems!  There are plenty in the textbook!  The course is very time-consuming, but in and outside of classes, but not impossible.

reviews: Take this course. Ruth is the best. Seriously.
absolutely take it. ruth is great, and i was able to become interested in pieces i wasn't previously the biggest fan of. great for delving into some aspects of classical music history
prereqs: Class limited to members of University Orchestra..
descrip: Drawing from the Princeton University Orchestra's spring 2014 repertory, the scores to Mozart's "Prague" Symphony in D Major, and Gustav Mahler 's Third Symphony, also in D, will be the central focus. Lectures and discussions will explore the development of Mozart's and Mahler's symphonic style, dissect what makes these works tick, and examine the historical context of each symphony. A few non-symphonic examples--Mozart's operatic work in Prague and Mahler's songs--will be included to supplement the history of each symphony and guide students to a deeper appreciation of each composer's musical achievements.

title: The Philosophy of Kant
reviews: Be prepared to critically engage with one of the most difficult works in the Western canon.
I would recommend taking any class with professor Hogan; he is a great lecturer and interested in getting to know his students.
If you're interested in Kant, don't shy away from this seminar.

If you're interested in Philosophy, Religion, or Literature, take the course! Prof. Hogan is a great teacher and an awesome guy. Do all of the readings, and attend all of the lectures, and you'll get a lot out of it

Many paths lead to Kant, whether you are studying philosophy, literature, or even the sciences. Kant's philosophy is so pivotal in the history of ideas that  in some way or another, you'll probably encouter him (or already have). This course is a wonderful introduction to his thought. Spending an entire semester with Kant was a challenge (he really isn't the best writer), but don't be intimidated. Professor Hogan's lecture style makes class very entertaining and engaging. The seminar-lecture hybrid style of the course was very fitting, as it seemed to maximize the amount of guidance from the professor and opportunities to address students' individual concerns.
descrip: An examination of Kant's Critique of Pure Reason.

title: Environmental Challenges and Sustainable Solutions
reviews: I would take this course if you are looking to take an easy STL. The material can be boring at times but you learn a lot about an interesting niche of ecology/environmental science. And the labs are cooler than a lot of the other labs at Princeton. Not too much work. Professor Zerba is nice and fun.
It was a really interesting course if you want to look at the campus plan and what Princeton is doing to reduce its impact on the world.
It's a good course for a relaxed lab course.
Lectures are not the best, but this is an easy STL with some fun labs.
Take it!

Take it!! This course was excellent. Any student either interested in the scientific study of the environment or even just looking for an STL should consider taking this course. It is well taught and the labs and subject matter are highly interesting and relevant to one's everyday life.
descrip: Course focuses on environmental challenges and sustainable solutions related to interrelationships between constructed and natural processes. Topic areas include climate, air pollution, toxics, and water. The format of the course is experiential learning with problem-solving research projects, lectures, and discussions. A central theme of the projects is to track the impact of land use and sustainable practices on the ecological balance of environments in and around Princeton's campus.

title: Intermediate Twi II
prereqs: TWI 105.
descrip: This course expands on the language skills acquired from TWI 105 and continues to focus on the communicative approach to studying the language. It includes specific socio-cultural settings and events. Speaking, reading, writing and listening continue to form an integral part of the course and students will build on their grammatical skills. By the end of the course, learners are expected to reach proficiency level ranging between Novice High and Intermediate Low.

title: Exotic Quantum States of Matter
descrip: See website

title: Formal Political Analysis I
descrip: A rigorous introduction to choice theory, social choice theory, and non-cooperative game theory. The course serves as the first formal theory graduate course and draws on mathematics at the level of POL 502.

title: Epidemiology
prereqs: This is a required course for graduate students in the Health and Health Policy certificate program..
descrip: Course covers the basic concepts and methods of epidemiology and demonstrates how these can be applied to improve population health and reduce health inequities. Topics include: measuring the health of the population, understanding the causes of poor health, developing interventions for improving health, translating evidence into practice, and evaluating the impact of policies and programs. Key epidemiological concepts such as association, bias and confounding are covered, as well as the main epidemiological study designs.

title: Advanced French Theater Workshop
reviews: Best professor in the French department, best way to spend your afternoons
Definitely take.  Not too much work, great time with an incredible professor.
Florent is just amazing!

I would strongly recommend this class. It is a rich, engaging class where you will improve your French skills and become immersed in the unique world of French theater. Professor Masse is a special person with a deep devotion to his job.

It's a great class, and you'll feel really comfortable if you've taken FRE 211 before taking this because the class runs in an extremely similar fashion, but with a bit more work involved (like preparing 3 scenes throughout the entire semester and not just 1). It's a unique class in the department in that it's a theater workshop, so it's not all just discussing and analyzing text ? for example, you get to do some interesting theater activities in class.
Learn your lines early!
Rehearse with your scene partner independently!
Strongly recommended, it is a relatively lightweight course, apart from the memorisation, and allows one to develop in ways not necessarily afforded by most other Princeton courses.
TAKE IT!!!
Take it if you have interest in theater, or if you have a desire to improve your French. It will help with either.
Take it!
Take it! It's a really good class! You will learn so much about France's rich culture while improving your French speaking skills in a fun way.
Take it. Super fun and you learn a ton of French, and some acting skills too.
This class is super fun and unique!  Just come at it with an open mind and you'll learn a lot!
prereqs: Professor's approval and/or one two-hundred level French course (preferably FRE/THR 211). To schedule an interview, interested students must contact the instructor at: fmasse@princeton.edu..
descrip: Advanced French Theater Workshop is a continuation of FRE/THR 211, French Theater Workshop. Students focus their work on three French playwrights: one classical, one modern, and one contemporary. The course will place emphasis on refining and improving students' acting and oral skills. It will culminate in the presentation of the students 'Travaux' at the end of the semester.

title: The American Dance Experience and Africanist Dance Practices
reviews: By far the best course I've taken at Princeton. You don't feel like you're at Princeton when taking this course - and I mean that in the best way possible. Also, Professor Harvey-Salaam is one of the nicest people I've met.
Definitely take it!
I would definitely recommend this course to a fellow student.
It is a lot of fun and definitely a different type of dance.
Listen to Mama Dyane.
Take it! it's great.
Take it!!!! You won't regret it.
Take this class!! Literally so fun, best decision I've made.
Take this course if you enjoy dance! Have some sense of rhythm or you won't enjoy yourself but otherwise it's really great! Mama Dy is awesome!
Take this course! Sometimes the class is a bit of a workout, but it is a lot of fun.
Take this course. It's really fun and Mama Dy is hilarious.
prereqs: Some form of social dancing, good, natural movement aptitude, or former dance training. This is an OPEN ENROLLMENT course..
descrip: A studio course introducing students to American dance aesthetics and practices, with a focus on how its evolution has been influenced by African American choreographers and dancers. An ongoing study of movement practices from traditional African dances and those of the African diaspora, touching on American jazz dance, modern dance, and American ballet. Studio work will be complemented by readings, video viewings, guest speakers, and dance studies.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Anthropophagy, Lit. and Culture: Lyrics of Exile in Brazil and Beyond
reviews: Be weary of the amount of reading you have to do, but take any course that Joao is teaching!

Definitely take it! Professor Joao de Castro Rocha's area of study is very interesting and he is very enthusiastic about the subject! That enthusiasm made me want to gain a deeper understanding of the readings and learn new ways to analyze them.
I would say that they should go to a lecture or two before deciding to take it, as the lectures are varied.
If Professor Rocha is visiting ever again, I would certainly recommend this course. He is engaging, relaxed, and enthusiastic in every aspect.
Take it ! It was fantastic!
Take it if he ever comes back to teach at Princeton. He is amazing.
Take the course! You learn a lot about the history of Brazil from a literary perspective.

The class only has two major assignments, so it is not a stressful workload. However, there really are 300  pages of reading per week, so if you are comfortable not fully finishing/understanding all of the material, this is a good class to take.

To another student taking this course, I would say to give themselves enough time to do the reading, breaking it into chunks and tackling them that way. Take careful notes, and you will see that all the material is conceptually connected and maps itself clearly into your understanding. JC is especially good at relating between texts, so if you have any questions do bring them to him.
take it. take any course offered by Joao.
prereqs: Proficiency in Portuguese and Spanish required (reading and writing)..
descrip: How to account for the omnipresence of the metaphor of "anthropophagy" in Brazilian cultural history? Indeed, the first descriptions of European colonizers already invented the link between the New World and anthropophagous rituals. Therefore, the rediscoveries of the theme in literature, cinema, music and the arts have strategically undertaken a double re-reading of both the notion of "anthropophagy" and the colonial reports. In this course, the concept of "lyrics of exile" will be proposed as a new framework to understand the centrality of the "other" in the determination of the "self" - the very core of cultural cannibalism.

title: Making Sense of Market Bubbles
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Finance and Public Policy
reviews: A solid course for anyone looking to gain a broad background in finance.  Professor Shafer is a veteran in the industry, and his firsthand knowledge gives the class a useful personal touch.
Highly recommend, be willing to speak in class during discussion.

If you do not know anything about finance, this course will take a lot of independent work on your part, especially because most of the other students have taken many finance courses. But it is worth taking if you want to learn about the subject.
Plan
Take it, it's more than worth it.
Take this class if you are at all interested in the subject matter. But don't slack off as it will be evident if you do.
Very interesting course if you're interested in the intersection of public policy and finance.
Yes.
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101.
descrip: This course will examine the public policy issues raised by financial markets, including their role in allocating savings to investment, supporting economic growth, preserving systemic stability and pursuing non-economic objectives. It will examine the nature of theoretical efficient financial markets alongside the failures of real markets arising from instability of liquidity, asymmetric information, distorted information, incentives in large complex organizations and the social, cognitive and emotional factors shaping behavior. It will assess government interventions to correct market failures and their unintended consequences.

title: The Landscape of Allusion: Garden and Landscape Architecture, 1450-1750
prereqs: Recommended to have some previous study of history, philosophy, history of art or architecture, or literary criticism..
descrip: To understand Man's changing interpretations of Nature as seen in gardens and landscape architecture, pastoral poetry, and landscape painting.

title: Topics in International Relations - Human Rights
descrip: This course looks at human rights as a public policy issue. It considers debates over the definition of human rights; the possibilities and limits of humanitarian intervention; the ability of human rights activists and international actors to undermine dictatorial governments; and the impact of the laws of war. We will consider historical and contemporary cases around the world, including the Armenian genocide, the Holocaust, Bosnia, China, and more.

title: Social and Political Lives of Humor, The
descrip: See Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Civil Liberties
reviews: A challenging, thought-provoking learning experience!
A great class but certainly a demanding one. I think it is one you should take before graduating.
A lot of reading, don't take as a 5th class
A must-take for POL majors
A must-take.
Best class

Call it Con Interp-lite. It's not your typical EM since a lot of it rests on Supreme Court cases and legal interpretation, with some philosophy and ethics mixed in. Professor George does an excellent job of helping students become more open-minded and receptive to opposing viewpoints on controversial issues.
ConInterp Light.  Make sure to do the readings or else you will have trouble with the final when accountability finally catches up with you.
Don't be too intimidated by the readings, but also you're only going to get out of this class as much as you put in.
Everyone should take this course. It is interesting, a little challening, but not that much work.

Everyone who is even a bit interested in issues of constitutional interpretation and American politics (and even those who aren't) should take this course.  You will learn so much that I don't think you'll regret it.

Fantastic class, really makes you think about issues that are relevant. I think every college student should have to take a course like this. I would say it helps you figure out your true political views on hot-topic issues.

First of all, take the class. You're missing out if you don't. Second, read the philosophical readings because that's what much of the lectures are grounded in those and it's a lot easier to keep up when the concepts are familiar.
George is an excellent lecturer (and preceptor). He's clear and well-spoken regardless of his personal opinions. There is a decent amount of thick reading. This is an excellent PDF option.

George may be the fairest lecturer at Princeton. As a (gay) bleeding heart liberal, I was afraid that his own views would bias his presentation, but that was never the case--George is brilliant and very approachable. Try to get Sullivan as your preceptor (if you can't get George himself).
Go to precept
Good course...dense reading that you don't have to do. Beware that all preceptors and (obviously) Robbie George are extremely and unabashedly conservative. George's lectures are great and insightful!
Great course! Beware - at times it feels like what I imagine a law school course feels like. Heavy emphasis on specific cases and supreme court justices.
Great course, but be prepared for your GPA to take a hit

I recommend it if you're interested at all in Civil Liberties. That said, understand that Prof. George enjoys adding an additional level of grade deflation in his courses, and that most of the discussion will center on a basis of conservative thought.

I took this class out of general Washington, politics, WWS interest. Probably not the best idea. The class focuses about half on constitutional interp and half on civil liberties (despite the course name). George is very good as lecturer (he wanders around the room without notes and is almost amazingly unbiased) but the 80 minute format is too long and this is not a lecture that will keep you awake unless this is your thing - not really a general interest course. The readings are half court cases and half philosophical pieces - I honestly regret doing most of the readings, esp the philosophical ones. Much of the class doesn't. I had George as a preceptor, which was not a good experience. He treated it as a 2nd (again 80 minute) lecture, was highly partisan, and didn't really allow for discussion (in the few times he would let someone who hasn't already taken con interp speak, he would shoot down their idea/opinion instead of pushing them to a better understanding). It was nice to have only one lecture a week though, 80 min lecture and 80 min precept. There is no weekly hw other than readings and only a midterm and final paper. The midterm paper was fun (or at least creative) - you got to decide an imaginary court case.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students.
I would recommend avoiding Russ Nieli as your preceptor, that could improve the course greatly.
I would recommend that other students read the material carefully before lecture so that you understand and can follow clearly the issues that Professor George brings up.
I would suggest students who have more time to commit to take this course and pick a preceptor who fits your working style for the most success.

I've heard a lot of EM courses are bad; this one was okay. If you're interested at all in current political issues, you'll survive. A lot of reading, but you don't have to read it all to do well. It wasn't nearly as interesting as I thought it would be, but I still liked it.
If you are at all interested in constitutional law, take the course!
If you don't take a Robert George class before you graduate, you are missing out on an integral part of the Princeton experience.

If you have an interest in juris prudence and civil rights: take this! It's incredibly interesting and you get to go through a really wide-reaching series of topics and dilemmas, building your own beliefs along the way.
If you're vaguely interested in the subject matter, take Civ Lib. If you're really interested, take Con Interp. If you love it, take both.
Lecture is super awesome. Make sure you go to all of them.
Lectures might be overrated, but take this class to learn more about constitutional law and what it means to be an American.
Lot of reading.
N/A
Not a super easy class to PDF if you're not a POL major
Not an easy course, but a very interesting and engaging course that is worth taking.
Really immerse yourself in the reading and cases to get yourself thinking critically about all sides. Understanding counterarguments is key!
Some really interesting readings and good precept could make this a great course.
Take a course in law/constitution first.
Take if interested in conservative viewpoints.
Take if it sounds interesting. Don't take precept with Oakley.
Take it but don't expect an A unless you put in a ton of work.
Take it for a distribution requirement or if you're really into POL. Would not recommend taking this for a grade unless you're heavily engaged in the material.
Take it if you are slightly interested in the material. It was definitely one of the most interesting, thought-provoking classes I have taken at Princeton thus far!
Take it if you can, even if it isn't necessary for requirements.
Take it!
Take it! A subject literally everyone in this country should understand fully. Everyone should take this class.
Take it! Stay on top of the readings, it will help you participate fully in precept and stay engaged in lecture.
Take it. Its hard, but take it.
Take this class but DO THE READINGS. if you don't you are selling the class short. If it is between this and constitutional interpretation, though, take Con Interp.!
Take this class, you won't regret it.
Take this course if you are interesting in Constitutional law, but understand that you are going to be focusing a lot of ethics and philosophy, perhaps even as much as you do on the case law itself.
Take this course it is amazing and a class every student should take
Take this course.

This class is extremely worthwhile. There is a lot of reading, and it is helpful if you can find someone in the class that you can discuss the readings and ideas with. If you can split the readings with someone, it is very helpful. Definitely go to lectures, because they are extremely relevant. And try to take sides on the topic that is presented every week, as this will help in the exams. However, make sure you understand the point of view of those who disagree with you and are able to present that side clearly.

This class was GREAT.  It is a lot of reading, and it's important to do it so that you can participate in precept and so that you aren't floundering at the end of the semester when you have to write a paper and incorporate sources.  But the lecturers are great, and Professor George is really engaging.
This course will teach you a lot about politics and topical issues of the day. The papers are somewhat difficult, but I would strongly recommend it.

This is a really great course. I honestly don't have much I could do to improve it. It's also a good PDF course - Prof George and the preceptors grade really hard so you're probably not going to get an A on accident and feel like you have to not PDF after the midterm. Really interesting - precepts with Prof George are also really good if you can get into one of them
This is an engaging and interesting course. But be prepared to work!
This is like one of those golden opportunities that don't come around too often in life; it would be a shame for any princeton student to pass it up.
Unless you need the DR or you're just super into the class topic, I wouldn't recommend it.
Very difficult midterm and final but great lectures, readings and precepts. I PDF-d and would do again.
Very good course -- mix of political theory and Supreme Court cases.

You probably won't get an A. Aside from that, there is nothing not to love about Civ. Lib. Prof. George will turn your world upside down. The readings are 95% fascinating. You're going to grapple with some really tough questions. It's kind of an important course to take while you're here.
similar to ethics public policy if you've taken it
take it if you are interested in delving deep into the constitution.
take it!
take it.

take this. Robert George is brilliant, and even if you disagree with him, he is very open to competing arguments. You'll learn a lot about how to address the issues in the course from a moral philosophy and law perspective. if you're at all interested in law this is a must take class
the workload is not bad and the material is interesting
very difficult class, but worthwhile and you learn a lot
descrip: An inquiry into the value of liberty and of particular civil rights and liberties. The course considers competing theoretical justifications for rights and liberties generally, as well as particular problems concerning freedom of speech and the press, religion, sexuality, abortion, and discrimination. Supreme Court opinions regarding the constitutionality of legislation in each of these areas will be discussed and criticized.

title: Cultural Systems - Proust, Freud, Borges
reviews: A great framework is created to approach all of your future work.  I took this as a senior and still can imagine using a tremendous amount of what i learned in assessing the world going forward.
Definitely get Miguel as a preceptor. The 7:30 pm time slot wasn't ideal, but he was incredible.
Excellent class. Would recommend to anyone who is interested in reading Freud.

Honestly, if you're interested in the three thinkers and are looking to p/d/f a class, then take it. I took it without the p/d/f option and actually tried, and was faced with a bizarrely arbitrary grading system in which the results never matched the effort and understanding put into them...but if you want a structured environment in which to read Freud, Borges, and Proust, then definitely go for it. Just...p/d/f and don't spend longer than 5-10 minutes on blog posts.

I highly recommend this course. It is especially a great way to fulfill your LA requirement for PLAS. Ruben is an engaging lecturer and the course has a very fair workload. Make sure to use your selective reading skills to highlight relevant material for the blog posts.
I would recommend this class to anyone remotely interested in the subject, even though it is a lot of work (mostly in terms of the readings), it is ultimately worth it.
It is difficult to do well in this class, because the grading feels somewhat arbitrary.
Take it if you want to read some works of great thinkers and have the ability to connect them to other things you're learning.
descrip: An overview of three of the most influential writers in the twentieth century. All three were fascinated by similar topics: dreams and memory; sexuality; Judaism. All three lived during traumatic historical periods (Proust during WWI; Freud during WWII; and Borges during Peronismo). Discussion will focus on theories of writing, modernity, modernist aesthetics, the conception of spaces and the construction of sexual identity.

title: The American Civil War and Reconstruction
reviews: A great class if you're looking for a reasonable HIS distribution. Lectures are crucial, go to all of them and it's a very doable class.
Be willing to challenge your assumptions about this seemingly well known era of history.
Do the reading. Grasp the 3 main points of each one.
Expect to learn the heights and weights of all major civil war figures.
Great course, if you're interested in the civil war it's worth it.
Highly recommend taking this class.
Not the best course on the Civil War. In a lot of ways it is disappointingly like a high school course. Not indicative of what an actual Princeton lecture course experience should be like.
Not too time demanding. Interesting course on CW

Take it if you are even remotely interesting in the Civil War; there are a lot of different themes, focuses on society, culture, war, etc. You will find something you like. Not a lot of work besides reading and really fun
Take it! It's incredibly interesting and relevant.
Take it! Karp is good lecturer and this is a key period of American history.
Take it. It was quite a good history class and it was interesting and entertaining.
Take this class, go to lecture, and you will get a lot out of it
Take this course!!!!
Take this course-- really enjoyed it! Super interesting readings, great lectures, and fair assignments
This is a very good course about the Civil War. If you're interested in the subject, take it. There's a lot of reading but you can skim for the most part.
This was a great class and it was Karp's first year teaching it at Princeton, so it will only get better.
Try to keep up on the readings, though they can be long and tedious.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: Why did the flourishing United States, by some measures the richest and most democratic nation of its era, fight the bloodiest civil war in the 19th century Western world? How did that war escalate into a revolutionary political struggle that transformed the nation--and then, almost as rapidly, give way to a reactionary backlash? This course will explore the causes, course, and consequences of the U.S. Civil War and Reconstruction, keeping in mind the ways that America's greatest conflict also represented a major event in the history of the global 19th century, and a landmark moment in the making of the modern world.

title: Physics and Chemistry of Earth's Interior
reviews: Great class for students who are interested in exploring currently unsolved problems. Do not take this course if you are trying to learn the fundamentals of the geosciences.
Stay focused in lecture, start problem sets early, study hard for the exams, ask Tom whenever you need help!
Take it if you like physics and chemistry together

Tom is a great professor, who is extremely approachable and helpful. His lectures are very well organized and set out, and clearly illustrates the current state of research for the Earth's interior, providing an excellent starting point for further pursuits in this area. However the class is also just generally useful for better understanding how the Earth's interior works. Great class, I highly recommend it.
Very Good Course
prereqs: One year of college-level chemistry or physics (preferably both) and calculus..
descrip: The Earth is a physical system whose past and present state can be studied within the framework of physics and chemistry. Topics include current concepts of geophysics and the physics and chemistry of Earth materials; origin and evolution of the Earth; and nature of dynamic processes in its interior. One emphasis is to relate geologic processes on a macroscopic scale to the fundamental materials properties of minerals and rocks.

title: Shakespeare II
reviews: A good class to take if you like Shakespeare. Prof. Leo is very engaging and enthusiastic, even if he sometimes overreaches a bit in his analysis. Try taking with Dolven instead.
A good class.
A pretty reasonable courseload and accessible to non-English majors.  Prof. Leo is fantastic.
Definitely take it. If you aren't an English major, consider PDFing. I wish I had!
