Definitely take this course if you are interested in Shakespeare.  Leo is a great lecturer, and the assignments are all reasonable.
He's a tough grader, but always willing to read drafts beforehand (so do that)

If Leo is teaching it, TAKE IT. As long as you don't mind reading Shakespeare, the lectures in this course will captivate you and you will look forward to them. The lectures are funny, thought-provoking, and insightful.
If you like Shakespeare and can put up with a high reading load, this is a very well-done course.
Lots of fun. Lectures are hilarious.
Make sure you get a good precept!

Many of the plays on the syllabus are very famous, so you will probably have read many of them. Still, this course is a great opportunity to look at all these plays at one time. As a result, I think it's helpful to look at the course as a cumulative process in which you gain a greater awareness by drawing connections between different works.
One of the best I've taken - get it done, learn some Shakespeare

Shakespeare   Leo = Awesomeness.
This class is a must for any student regardless of their major. I've had many terrific teachers at Princeton but Russell Leo takes the cake as the very best. He is so smart, so nice, so funny, and not afraid to get nerdy. I'm so happy I took this class, and you will be too.
Superb course-- take it! A little more reading than other courses, but totally worth it.
TAKE THIS. TAKE IT NOW.
Take it - it's a good English class.
Take it for the British Foundation departmental but make sure you get a good reviewed preceptor.
Take it!
Take it! It's great and Professor Leo is really nice.

Take it! Professor Leo is a passionate and great lecturer. Not only does he make a lot of interesting observations and insights, he is very open to students' ideas, which I have found is not true of enough professors. He is very knowledgeable about Shakespeare and he made what could easily have been a dull class exciting and fun. This was possibly the best class I have taken yet at Princeton.

Take it! Shakespeare may sound intimidating if you're not a humanities type, but the class is really very approachable. I would suggest definitely suggest watching the plays while reading along (plenty of free versions online) or reading them out loud with a partner, as it's a lot easier to understand Shakespeare when it's performed than just by reading it.
Take it; not particularly wonderful (Russ leo seems over-hyped...)
Take this class if Professor Leo is teaching!! The material and lectures are amazing, the workload  manageable, and it's a great way to fill an LA or to take as an elective.

Take this course if Professor Leo is teaching it! He is one of the most dynamic lecturers I have ever had, and is such a wonderful person, too. Going to lecture was a treat, and this is a great way to get to know more about Shakespeare, his plays, history, and plays more generally. A must-take!
Take this course if you have the slightest interest in Shakespeare.
Take this course. You'll love it.
Take your time with the reading - the more detailed, the better! And the more you get out of it!

This is a fantastic class! It's great for people who have no background in Shakespeare AND for people who already know and love Shakespeare....Professor Leo is AMAZING! His lectures are so great and so fascinating.
Try to get into Leo's precept. Do the readings.
take even if you are not an english major. leo is the bomb dot com
descrip: A survey of the second half of Shakespeare's career, from Hamlet to The Tempest. We will follow him to the bottom of the great tragedies, and then, in the late romances, partway back.

title: Stochastic Calculus
reviews: Don't take it
N/A
Try to learn the material from the Steele book, as the course itself is not particularly helpful.
prereqs: Prerequisite: ORF 526 or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to stochastic calculus based on Brownian motion.Topics include:construction of Brownian motion; martingales in continuous time; the Ito integral; localization; Ito calculus; stochastic differential equations; Girsanov's theorem; martingale representation; Feynman-Kac formula.

title: Probability and Stochastic Systems
prereqs: MAT 201 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: An introduction to probability and its applications. Random variables, expectation, independence. Poisson processes, Markov chains, and Brownian motion. Stochastic models of queues, population dynamics, and reliability.

title: Analysis & Visualization of Large-Scale Genomic Data Sets
reviews: DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS!!! If you are open minded you will learn a lot.
Definitely take this course if you are interested in the computational aspects of genomics and enjoy discussion-based learning.
I think this is an excellent course if you are interested in computational biology, even if you don't feel that you have all the necessary background you should give it a shot.
Keep track of the terms that you do not understand.

Troyanskaya is not only respected in her field but also very approachable and accommodating. Interacting with the grad students was a cool experience. If you want to take this course I recommend a background in statistics--biology and computer science seemed less important.
descrip: Introduces students to computational issues involved in analysis and display of large-scale biological data sets. Algorithms covered will include clustering and machine learning techniques for gene expression and proteomics data analysis, biological networks, joint learning from multiple data sources, and visualization issues for large-scale biological data sets. No prior knowledge of biology or bioinformatics is required; an introduction to bioinformatics and the nature of biological data will be provided. In depth knowledge of computer science is not required, but students should have some understanding of programming and computation.

title: Summer Course in Geologic Field Methods
descrip: Introduction to modern geologic field methods. Local and regional problems studied from base camp at Red Lodge, Montana. Five weeks during summer usually following sophomore year. Prerequisite: one year of college geology.

title: Themes in Islamic Culture - History 600-1800
descrip: This year the course will be a seminar on Islamic history from 600 to 1800 intended to prepare students for Generals and for eventually teaching such a course.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: One-term full time research internship at a host institution to perform scholarly research directly relevant to a student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by the student's advisor in consultation with the outside host. Monthly progress reports and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students. Students will be permitted to enroll in this one-semester course at most twice. Participation will be considered exceptional.

title: Policy Issues and Analysis of Nonprofits, NGOs, and Philanthropy
descrip: Examines policy issues at international, national and local levels. Provides groundwork on nonprofits, NGOs, and philanthropy that can be followed with specialized courses on management and program evaluation. Emphasis on understanding how philanthropy, nonprofit, and NGO sectors operate, their niche alongside private and public sectors, revenue sources, impact on society, and converse effects of society and its institutions; the policy making process. Explores impact of reliance on government or overseas support for Third World NGOs; faith-based service provisions: accountability and transparency; advocacy; and government regulations.

title: Systematic Ethics
descrip: A graduate seminar in ethics.

title: Ghosts, Vampires, and Zombies in Irish Theatre and Literature
reviews: Don't be afraid to take this class if you have no prior experience, or even much interest, in theater. I certainly didn't and enjoyed it tremendously

If you have an interest in the area then definitely take the class. Professor O'Toole is one of the best. Be warned that sometimes the reading is quite heavy but other times it is very very light. It is pretty easy to balance out if you can plan ahead.
If you have the chance to take a seminar with Fintan O'Toole, DO IT! The reading was a but much at times but I enjoyed them and I found what Professor O'Toole had to say about them fascinating.
Take it! Professor O'Toole is phenomenal and the subject matter is fun and interesting.
Take it.
Try to spread out the reading over a few days because it can be very dense.
descrip: From the spirits and banshees of oral legends to Bram Stoker's Dracula, from the classic works of Yeats, Synge and Beckett to Garth Ennis's Preacher comics and Anne Rice's Vampire novels, Irish culture has been haunted by the Otherworld. Why has the Irish Gothic had such a long ghostly afterlife on page and stage? Can we learn something about modernist works like those of Yeats and Beckett by seeing them through the perspective of popular fictions of the supernatural?

title: Advanced Quantum Mechanics
reviews: Experimentalists will find this a little more valuable than QFT, since the overlap with what they are doing and this course is greater than QFT.
descrip: This is a one-semester course in advanced quantum mechanics. The emphasis is on systems with many degrees of freedom: dynamics, mixed states, entanglement, measurement, coherent states.

title: Analysis III: Integration Theory and Hilbert Spaces
reviews: I have a sense that the course depends a lot on the professor teaching it.

Professor Dafermos teaches rather comfortably yet slowly, and he follows the Stein and Shakarchi text. This book is really good?if you want to get through all of it in the semester, pace yourself and read ahead, since the lectures certainly won't finish everything. The homework also tends to be far more difficult than the lecture pace, though the exams are rather easy.
Take and attend lecture.

You should take this class. I'm not a big fan of analysis, but I found that integration theory is one of the most beautiful areas of math I've encountered. The class is not easy, but it's not insanely hard either.
Your alternative is MAT 325. Yes, of course take this course!
prereqs: MAT 215, 218 or equivalent..
descrip: The theory of Lebesgue integration in n-dimensional space. Differentiation theory. Hilbert space theory and applications to Fourier Transforms, and partial differential equations. Introduction to fractals. This course is the third semester of a four-semester sequence, but may be taken independently of the other semesters.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Negotiation and Conflict
descrip: This course examines the principles of negotiation and provides firsthand experience in simulated negotiations. Sample topics include distributive negotiation, integrative negotiation ("expanding the pie"), conflict management, and coalitions. Research on the variables that affect success in negotiations are discussed. Students engage in a series of bargaining exercises between individuals and teams, and results are analyzed by the class.

title: Elementary Hindi and Urdu II
reviews: More manageable than HIN 101 because the workload stays the same but you're more comfortable with reading/writing
This was a great class! It was so surprising to see how much everyone learned, and it was especially shocking to see how fluent some of the non-native speakers had become by the end!
prereqs: HIN/URD 101 or the equivalent level of proficiency..
descrip: This course provides the second semester of training in Hindi and Urdu, allowing students to acquire linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Equal emphasis is placed on both Hindi and Urdu, including writing systems, vocabulary, and culture. Course will focus on using language for genuine communication. Students will be able to read and write both Hindi and Urdu scripts, communicate in social situations, and narrate in all three time frames: past, present and future. Classes are interactive.

title: The Romantic Period - Coming of Age in the Age of Romanticism
prereqs: Those students wishing to audit (AUD) should speak first to Professor Wolfson about minimal requirements for this status..
descrip: Attending to gender, poetic form, genre, narrative logic, socio-historical contexts and reception, we study 5 brilliant projects of literary imagination from Long Romanticism about growing up in the world: Wollstonecraft's Vindication of the Rights of Woman (1792); Wordsworth's epic poetic autobiography, The Prelude (1798; published 1850), Byron's Don Juan, 1819-1824; Austen's Northanger Abbey (1817, earliest-drafted, posthumously published); selections from E. B. Browning's autobiographically inflected epic poem Aurora Leigh (1856--the same decade as The Prelude.

title: Genghis Khan and the Mongol Empire
prereqs: No prerequisites, though some background in Russian, Middle Eastern, Central Asian, or Chinese history is beneficial. Given the reach of the Mongol Empire, students will have the opportunity to conduct research in Russian, Latin, Arabic, Persian, Armenian, Georgian, Turkish, Chinese, Japanese, and/or Mongolian, according to ability and interest..
descrip: Overview of the history and historiography of the Mongol Empire, including its Inner Asian nomadic origins, expansion, and acculturation to or eviction from the societies of Russia, the Middle East, Central Asia, and China. We will discuss political history alongside the diplomatic, cultural, and technological exchanges engendered by the Mongol Empire and the methodological considerations of modern research on the subject. Class time will include topical mini-lectures and extensive discussions of primary and secondary sources, with occasional library and museum visits to view and discuss manuscripts and artifacts from the Mongol period.

title: Framing American Art
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Harlem Renaissance and Black Arts Movements
reviews: Don't do it

First and foremost, attend lecture. Even if you don't do the readings, go to lecture. Also attend the field trips, they are a great way to get to know Prof. Chika. Try and do the readings as well because most of them are actually very interesting.
Good PDF class and interesting material
I think it is a very good class to take.
Not too hard, Professor Ukeke-Agulu is on the students' side and crazy chill
Take it.
Take this if your interested in learning about African American art and want a relatively relaxed and straightforward class.
Whether you need an LA out of the way or you have an interest in art / African American culture, TAKE THIS COURSE. Best course I took all year.
descrip: This course surveys important moments in 20th-Century African American art from the Harlem Renaissance in the 1920s to the 1960s Black Arts movement. Our close studies of the work of major artists will be accompanied by examination of influential theories and ideologies of blackness during two key moments of black racial consciousness in the United States. We shall cover canonical artists and writers such as Aaron Douglas, James van der Zee, William H. Johnson, Jacob Lawrence, Romare Bearden, Faith Ringgold, Betye Saar, W. E. B. Du Bois, Alain Locke, James Porter and Jeff Donaldson.

title: Social and Political Lives of Humor, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Reading Literature: Fiction
reviews: A wonderful class. Take it!!
Absolutely do the readings, and do them thoroughly. You will only get out of this course what you put in.
Do the readings.
Good class if you want to read some good books and don't mind an hour and a half precept.
I would advise that they do all the readings, because if you do the readings the lectures and precepts are really fun and interesting.
I would recommend this for any students, whether they are English majors or potential majors, or just looking for a distribution requirement or simply interested in the material.
It's a great class. There's bound to be something on the reading list that you're going to love.

Prof. Chihaya is a great preceptor, and the readings were great. I enjoyed writing and the books and discussing the. That said, check out the books on the syllabus before you take the class. ENG 206 was its own loss of innocence --  books and movies involved topics in graphic detail such as murder, gore, war trauma, death, insects, rape, abuse (especially of women), torture, madness, post-apocalyptic dystopias, pedophilia, suicide, loneliness, the general bleakness of the human condition, bureaucracy (yes, bureaucracy), and so on. So be careful. ("Never Let Me Go" is especially devastating.)
Review the works that will be covered for the semester before you decide to continue in the course.
Take it. Do the reading, Maybe do a bit of outside reading, even, when it comes time to do papers - if nothing else than to give you an idea of what literary criticism is supposed to look like.

The reading list is pretty nice and they are loosely tied with one another. The progression in the style of literature is also intriguing. Readings are enjoyable (note: this does not mean they are an easy read).
This class is interesting and has a good reading list. Lectures are interesting but not wonderful. The class doesn't give you a great look at what the English department is really like.

This is a good course to take if you want to do some entertaining reading to balance out your other courses. The lectures vary in quality,  but it's worth taking if you want to try out the English department.
prereqs: Prospective concentrators are required to take ENG 200 and one course from the following: ENG 205, 206, 207, 208..
descrip: This course is designed to introduce and motivate an interest in a wide range of different forms of fiction. The central idea for the class will be that different fictional forms correspond to different ways of understanding the real world; because the word "fiction" derives from the Latin word for fashioning or making, we will suggest that fiction is a way of crafting alternative or other possible worlds. To this end we will consider not only traditional texts, but also some visual texts, unpacking what we mean by "literature," "fiction," as well as "great books."

title: Sociology of Technology
reviews: A fun and interesting course. Not a lot of work during the semester, but the final project can be very involved.
Did not deliver on my expectations.

If you have an interest in the Sociology of Technology, this class will not let you down. The readings are always interesting, the seminars will keep you engaged and excited, and the final research paper is enjoyable to write because of the independence as well as the stimulating material covered throughout the seminar.

Lots of reading in a giant $90 pequod is really the only complaint I have about this class!  Fun discussions with interesting people, a final project with an extremely large amount of leeway to choose and interesting topic, and fascinating guest Skype-ins from sociologists all over.  The midterm was quite do-able.
Take it only if you are 100% sure you will be interested in all topics covered and the research paper aspect
Take it! It's a whole new way to think of technology and Dr. J is great!

Take it, seriously. It changed how I look at tech. It's incredibly useful, whether you're a STEM major wanting a dash of sociology or a SOC major looking for ways to expand your focus. You'll be comfortable no matter what major you are. I loved it.
Take it. Dr. J is the best and the course content is really interesting even if you're not a science-y person.
This isn't a course you can neglect, but it is very interesting and worthwhile.

Very good course. Really interesting readings for science majors (and non-science ones, although I can't speak for them as much), and it'll definitely teach you about how to think about the role technology plays in our lives (which is really important to you, I promise!).
descrip: You are probably reading this course description on a computer. By day's end you may talk to a friend on your cell phone, buy something on the internet with a credit card, bicycle to campus, or drive to the store. Technology is everywhere and it is easy to see how it influences our lives, but where do new technologies come from, how are they picked up and used, and how do our values and social norms influence their design and development? Addressing these questions with examples from the railroad to cybernetics, from the birth control pill to DRM, this course provides an introduction to the field of the Sociology of Technology.

title: Independent Study
prereqs: Students MUST fill out the Independent Research Proposal Project form signed by your advisor & the dept rep. Hand in to E-211 E-Quad during course selection period...
descrip: Independent research in the student's area of interest. The work must be conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and must result in a final paper.

title: Networks, Economics and Computing
reviews: Be aware that it's mainly a class on game theory. Sometimes feels unrelated to COS, although it's still interesting material. Probably one of the easier theory classes.

Between the first time this class was offered and now (it's only the second time this class has been taught), it's become much, much harder and more time-consuming. If you're taking this class because you've heard that it's an easy theory departmental, you're in for a rude awakening. Also, as this is a fairly new class, expect some more changes.

Braverman's a great lecturer, so it's a shame that the material in the course was rather dull.  It's a relatively chill theory class, but it was really hard to put in the effort for the class because the material was so boring.  The programming assignments, though easy, were the most interesting part of the course.
Definitely take it, but make sure you know the COS 340 material well.

Definitely take this class if you're interested in applications of computer science to various problems in economics, or if you need a theory requirement.  It's about the same difficulty as 340, and maybe even easier if you take them in sequence because 340 is really similar stuff to this.  Braverman is awesome.
Good for second theory. Less work than 340. Easier than 340. Some interesting topics covered.
I would recommend this if you want a relaxed but worthwhile course.

If you have any interest in game theory (or if you want a second theory course and are scared of 423), definitely take this course. I'm a huge Braverman fan, and this class did not disappoint. Get a good group for the problem sets and they'll be no problem (they got pretty easy towards the end of the semester).  Take the time to test your agents for the programming assignments.
If you want a theory class on a comparable level of difficulty to COS 340, take this class. You'll need to put in some solid reading and work time.
It might be worth waiting on this course until they get it ironed out. There are other courses in game theory that are well developed in the meantime.
It's a great theory course that I would highly recommend for your second theory requirement.  On a similar level of difficulty to 340, but interesting subjects and very practical material.
It's not a bad option for a theory class, but it is hard to do well in. The lectures and material are interesting, but the problem sets look deceptively easy and turn out to be very hard.
It's not what you might expect going in, but don't let that turn you away from an amazing course.
Logistically the same as 340 but with way more interesting material, which made it a not so torturous theory class (for people who aren't big on theory)
Not a bad way to knock out that 2nd theory requirement. If Braverman is teaching it, it's almost identical to his 340 class, so you know what you're getting into
Pretty interesting stuff, similar in style to 340

Probably the second-easiest theory course after COS340 (although with less interesting computing-related content). The second-half of the course is definitely easier than 340. Recommend as a good class if you're simply looking to fulfill the theory requirement.
Spend a lot of time on the assignments
Start problem sets early!
Study the lecture notes as they will be your main resource for the difficult assignments.
Take it if interested in Econ-CS. Beware, the graders are incompetent and the grading absurd.
Take it if you did 340 and liked the material. This is probably one of the more chill theory classes in the COS department.
Take it if you must (it's a better alternative to 423, I promise you that) or if you generally like COS theory.  The second half actually gets pretty interesting.
Take it! Braverman is excellent and the material is very unique to the course. The theory assignments are quite easy (for a theory course) and the programming assignments are really interesting.
Take this class if game theoretical modeling interests you.

Take this course for your second theory. It follows really well after 340. Mark Braverman is a great professor and a really nice guy at office hours. You will learn a lot of cool stuff in this class. Take it.

This class is fine.  The problem sets and exams are pretty difficult and the averages are low.  Lecture is basically useless because the coursework is kind of orthogonal to what's covered in class, strangely enough.  Take it if you are interested in economics and computer science.  A class like ORF 309 would be helpful though.
This is a pretty painless theory course. If you need a theory course, definitely go with this one.

This is a tremendously mediocre class; Braverman is a tremendously boring lecturer. Do not expect to be very engaged. If you're looking for the storied "easy theory" then this is probably the best you'll be able to do. But don't expect anything riveting.
Very hard course. Easier than 340 but still hard and very time consuming.
While this course is still pretty challenging and somewhat unpredictable, it may be a little bit more manageable than some of the other theory courses.
really good class
prereqs: COS 226, COS 340, MAT 175 or MAT 202 or MAT 204 or MAT 217 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Computation and other aspects of our lives are becoming increasingly intertwined. We will study topics on the cusp between economics and computation. The focus will be on the mathematical and computational tools involved in the interaction of economics and computation. Topics: games on networks, auctions, mechanism and market design, reputation, computational social choice. The aim of the course is: (1) to understand the game-theoretic issues behind systems involving computation such as online networks, (2) to learn how algorithms and algorithmic thinking can help with designing better decision and allocation mechanisms in an offline world.

title: Solitude and Sociability
descrip: This course explores theoretical approaches to solitude and sociability in key works of political theory and of philosophy from antiquity to the present. Political theories divide as to whether or not humans are naturally sociable; ethicists disagree over the value of solitude and its relation to political life and personal projects. Beginning with classical and Hellenistic Greek and Latin authors, the course moves on to consider these themes in authors including Augustine, Montaigne, Rousseau, Emerson, Thoreau, and Nietzsche.

title: Imagining Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Statistical Learning and Nonparametric Estimation
reviews: Background in statistics and R is essential. Covers topics very similar to COS 424, but in greater theoretical detail that will help you understand the algorithms at a deeper level.
Consider the undergrad version if you're not into crazy linear algebra.
Excellent
Get ready to work your a$$ off!
I would strongly recommend other students take this course if you are going to do research or interested in machine learning and statistics.
It's a good class if you don't mind a lot of busywork.
Keep up with the lectures, and definitely attend all of them.
Practice your R coding skills.
Take it by all means!

The minuses: the AI was basically absent, gave very poor answers on Piazza, and didn't spend any time marking, which meant all that mattered for the final grade was the exam. Han Liu doesn't always have very clear explanations of topics, and the final exam was overly ambitious (3.5 hours and still no one finished on time). If you are not an ORF PhD, you will also be slighted in class and told to drop the course. Not cool. 

The pluses: the homework is painstaking but also very rewarding and practical. Students are expected to figure out the computational requirements of their algorithms and find suitable functions and libraries. The lectures are content rich and the content is interesting. Liu, unlike other Professors, is constantly asking for feedback, and cares about it. He is also very approachable and wants to help.
Try to understand/implement ideas as you learn them or before they are even presented in class.
Very good course -- very accessible.
Would highly recommend the course for anyone interested in applying machine learning techniques to big data.
prereqs: ORF 524: Statistical Theory and Methods or instructor's approval..
descrip: A theoretical introduction to statistical learning problems related to regression and classification. Topics covered include: Principle Component Analysis, nonparametric estimation, sparse regression, and Classification and Statistical learning

title: Religious Practices in the Hispanic World
reviews: Come to class and take advantage
Good class.
Take it! It's an engaging experience.

Take this course if an interdisciplinary approach to religion/culture appeals to you, or if you have an interest in seeing the development of hispanic religious practice from the middle ages to the present
prereqs: SPA 200-level course or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course surveys the practice of beliefs in Spain, Latin America, and in Hispanic communities in the United States. It explores how "Catholic" folk piety was established and developed in Spain and what happened to it when it transferred to the New World. By surveying the diverse configurations of religious practices through written texts and visual media, it inquires how identity and social relationships define a person's relation to the divine. Emphasis will be given to the development of spoken and written proficiency in Spanish.

title: Building Real Systems
reviews: A great learning experience.  Although lots of help is available during the first two deadlines, don't expect too much help with the final project, esp if you are using newer technologies like raspberry pis, etc.  Houck and Kahn are great.  This class will be very easy some weeks and then eat up every hour other weeks.  Work ahead of time and work hard.  You will be rewarded.
Awesome course. Absolutely take it, but be prepared to spend time on it. you will want to.
Carlab is fun! Make sure you work early and often!
Enjoy Carlab, its the best ELE class there is.

For the independent project, you need to figure out if you want to attempt something ambitious and come close, or something reasonable that you can nail. Think about what the demo is going to look like on that last day. Some groups had great projects but the demos failed to capture that.
Go in early and often.
Have to take it you're an ELE major. Try to take it even if you're not.
I've learnt so much from this course and enjoyed the whole process. You get as much as help as you need. Working often and splitting into chunks makes this course pretty painless.
If you are prepared to put in a significant fraction of your time and have fun "building things", this is the best possible environment to practice how.
It's a lot of fun and you really get into it.
LOTS of work and stress around deadlines, but completely worth it.
My favorite ELE class so far.
Pick your partner well, and don't be scared of the class. It's alot of fun and you'll learn more from car lab than any other class.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!

THIS COURSE WILL TEACH YOU HOW TO BE A TRUE ELECTRICAL ENGINEER.  Houck is amazing, the TAs are amazing, and what you can do in this course is amazing.  So much freedom!  Favorite course at Princeton.

Take this course! If you're EE, you have to, and almost nobody else takes the course, but hey, if you're another type of engineer and you know something about circuits and programming, you could take it too!
Take this course! It is a lot of work, but well worth it!
The class takes tons of time, but it's definitely worth it.

When the professors say 'start early and work often', its really in your best interest to listen to them. Because it just makes the whole thing so much more enjoyable. Not being crunched for time allows you to be more bold and creative, and take full advantage of this course. There will also definitely always be the one time when your work will be delayed because of something Radd had to do and he didn't, and that's just a lot more frustrating if you don't give yourself that extra time cushion.
Work early, work often.
You'll probably only take this if you have to, because it's definitely very time intensive. It was still a great course, however, and seemingly much improved from previous years.
prereqs: ELE 206 and ELE 301. Permission of instructor..
descrip: Comprehensive, laboratory-based course in electronic system design and analysis. Covers formal methods for the design and analysis of moderately complex real-world electronic systems. Course is centered around a semester-long design project involving a computer-controlled vehicle designed and constructed by teams of two students. Integrates microprocessors, communications, and control.

title: Intensive Elementary Arabic II
reviews: As a native speaker, you'll probably be frustrated often, but if you have the time to dedicate to it, there is much to be gained. However, you still may want to consider taking a placement test and really deciding whether or not you can handle the upper level courses, as those may serve you better.
Definitely take this class if you want to learn arabic!
Definitely take this class! Though I can only really recommend for Prof. Nizar, and unfortunately he will not be here next year :(
I would tell students to show up to each class and to not be afraid to bring up any questions if confused.
It is really sad that Ustaadh Nizar is leaving because he made this course.
Keep up with vocabulary to supplement grammar instruction.

Nizar is no longer teaching at Princeton, so I can't really speak to how this course would be with another professor, but I absolutely loved it with Nizar and am so happy that I took it instead of 101-102.
Take it.

This class is a bit more challenging than ARA 101 and moves faster, but it's manageable. It's definitely the right class for you if you have even the slightest exposure to Arabic, whether colloquial or not.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 103..
descrip: A continuation of 103. The second semester of a full-year language course designed specifically for students who already have some familiarity with any dialect of spoken Arabic. Graduate students who are primarily interested in learning to read Arabic are also welcome. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills.

title: Intensive Intermediate German
reviews: Definitely take it if you are interested in pursuing more German. You learn so much in one semester!

Did you take GER 101? Do you want to learn German? Then take this course!!! You won't regret it. I can't deny it will be scary at first because it goes at light speed, but don't let that discourage you. You'll probably get lower grades than you used to in 101, but you will soon see your improvements. The grammar of the first weeks (ahah I should say the first two thirds of the semester) can be pretty heavy, but once you get to the "literary turn" it all gets chilled and very interesting! It is a demanding course, but it's most definitely worth your time and effort. And you get to go to Munich!
Do not take unless you already know half the material or have no extra curriculars. the workload is fierce.

I have no regrets about taking 1025, and I am still surprised by how much German I learned. If you are willing to make time in your schedule for this course (more than 101, but not as much as two different classes), then the course is definitely worth it.

If you're on the fence about taking 1025 or 102, you should go for 1025, especially if you want to go to Munich in the summer and be able to speak well.  It's a ton of work, because it counts as two credits.  But you ultimately learn twice as much.
It's goddamn early. be aware of that. It's a great course, but the earliness (8:30 every morning) wears on you.
Just do the work and you'll be fine. Enjoy the class while you're in it!
Keep up with assignments.
Keep up with the vocab and readings

Take it. This is a fantastic course and greatly develops your German skills in a short period of time. It is not overwhelming at all, and especially if you had a good/fun group going into this class from GER 101, you will enjoy it a great deal. Work as hard as you can in 101 to get into this course, it is extremely worthwhile. Count as 2 course credits but the workload is far lighter than 2 courses.
Take this to learn intensive German.

The course is quite a bit of work (hence why it counts as two classes), but with some effort, you'll get a lot out of it.  I spoke virtually no German (I couldn't even string a sentence together a year ago), and now I'm writing this evaluation from Germany, where I'm getting along quite well!  I'm far from fluent, but I can handle the essentials like asking for directions, ordering food, etc.
prereqs: GER 101 and permission of instructor. Enrollment by invitation only, following an interview with the course instructor; interviews are normally offered to students in GER 101 attaining a grade of A or A-..
descrip: Intensive training in German, building on GER 101 and covering the acquisitional goals of two subsequent semesters: communicative proficiency in a wide range of syntax, mastery of discourse skills, and reading strategies sufficient to interpret and discuss contemporary German short stories, drama, and film. Intensive classroom participation required. Successful completion provides eligibility for GER 107 or, in exceptional cases, for 200 level courses. Participants are automatically eligible for the Princeton-in-Munich program (107-G), June, 2014.

title: Graphic Design: Visual Form
reviews: David is a cool professor who cares about his students. He is a bit awkward sometimes, but that does not stop him from teaching you a cool way to think about design and design principles. Definitely a fun course for someone interested in thinking about these things.
If you have interest in learning about visual form, take this class.
Take this course if you have a very strong interest in graphic design - its not what you think it is but its cool.
descrip: This course introduces students to techniques for decoding and creating graphic messages in a variety of media, and delves into issues related to visual literacy through the hands-on making and analysis of graphic form. Graphic design relies on mastering the subtle manipulation of abstract shapes and developing sensitivity to the relationships between them. Students are exposed to graphics from the late 19th-century to the present in slide lectures. Studio assignments and group critique will foster an individual ability to realize sophisticated forms and motivate these towards carrying specific meanings.

title: 1968 and the Present: Arts and Politics of Change in Latin America
descrip: This course looks at the different ways in which intellectual and artistic work is reinvented as it engages in practices of intense change at moments of political and economic crisis. Focusing on key moments since 1968, we study how social, cultural, and artistic movements reconfigure a sense of the political that visualizes its expressions in other forms of life, proposing innovative ways of approaching the role of knowledge and affects in contemporary societies. Readings include Althusser, Arguedas, Bolano, Colectivo Situaciones, Fernanda Navarro, Ranciere, Revueltas, Kristin Ross.

title: The Politics of Development
reviews: A pretty broad overview, but with a manageable workload. Definitely take this if you're considering making development your area of focus for independent work, because the readings will give you all kinds of ideas.
Definitely take it if you have a genuine interest in developing countries and development in general.
Definitely take it, although Prof. Lieberman won't be teaching it next year, and he was part of what made the class great!

Depending on the professor, the organization might be different, but the material is interesting for anyone interested in the health or economics of development. Understand that it's a complicated business--don't be too disheartened by what has (and hasn't) worked in development interventions--and do take this course!
Do all the work! It deepens your understanding of the material greatly.
Do the readings and do your country-specific research on time. It helps you later on for your papers.
Do the readings, attend lectures, and precepts. The writing assignments are not the best and lack of clarity on them can give you an unwarranted bad grade.
Don't take it unless you absolutely have to. Do something else. If you care at all about international development, this will make you hate it.
Good intro to development politics if you've never had it before. If you've seen the material, prepare to be bored out of your mind.
Good way to get your politics requirement for WWS!
I would recommend this course for WWS departmental req. Although Prof. Lieberman I believe is leaving so I can't really say how the quality of the course will change.

I'd say take this class if you're interested in expanding your horizons beyond the patriarchal "white man's burden" view on developing countries. If those country-specific assignments are still part of the course then I probably would be less enthusiastic in recommending this class.
If Lieberman is teaching it and you're willing to do the readings, take it and get Lieberman as your preceptor. Great course

If you are interested in development, take it.  If you are taking it just to fulfill a departmental, maybe look elsewhere for a class you are genuinely interested in.  For me it was a bit hard to stay so engaged with topics that I didn't care that much about.
If you have experience in development, will be an easy course.
If you're interested in development programs, take the class for the readings. The lectures aren't so great, but maybe with the new professor that changes a bit.

Interesting course and Prof. Lieberman is great! Quite heavy reading load in terms of pages but not difficult. You can get away pretty well with reading abstract   conclusion if pressed for time. Paper assignments are very easy and exams are fair (no surprises but quite a lot of information). Quite a lot of overlap with e.g. Politics of Africa
Many people in this course say that it is great.
Not hard, but a decent amount of work. The material is fascinating though so take it. Lieberman will grow on you.
Readings are interesting but take a lot of time. Didnt love the professors style.
Take it - not too much work and try to get Peter as your preceptor!
Take it if you are interested in development. Do the readings and you should be fine.
Take it if you are interested.
Take it!
Take it. Very practical knowledge for any person interested in development or why some nations are so much poorer (or richer) than others.
Take this course if you have any interest in development - it provides a great overview and breaks down a lot of things you may assume.
Take this course only if very interested in Africa in particular.
Take this if you're interested in development.
The lectures are more of a survey - precepts are much more informative and engaging. Interesting subject topic, but not very specific
keep up with the readings
new professor next year, best subject there is. so long as prof. lieberman doesn't castrate it.
stay on top of readings. meet with your preceptor!
super interesting!
take it!
take it! do the readings. lectures....uh i dunno
prereqs: Not open to freshmen without permission of instructor..
descrip: This course investigates the key political drivers of human development through careful consideration of theory and comparative analysis. Topics include state-building, colonialism, ethnic conflict, global integration, multi-level governance, and global public health.

title: Topics in Theory and Practice of Anthropology: (Half-Term) - Public Ethnography
descrip: In recent years, the "publicization" of the social sciences has been discussed among sociologists and, to a lesser degree, anthropologists. It consists in rendering the product of research available and debatable in the public sphere, instead of keeping it within the academic realm. Making ethnography public poses specific questions. What operations are involved? Which publics are targeted and for what purpose? What possible epistemological, ethical and political issues are at stake? Based on case studies analyzed from a pluridisciplinary perspective, the course will address the theoretical and empirical challenges of a public ethnography.

title: Topics in Environmental Studies - American Environmental History
reviews: Definitely take this course
Do the readings and participate.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in learning more about development of environmental movements in the US.
I would take this course if you are looking to fulfill any requirements for the Environmental Studies Certificate.
It's actually pretty minimal work and interesting.
Keeping up with the first six weeks of reading helps for the midterm paper.
Take it if you're interested in the material.
This is a good course if you're interested in American history and how thought about the environment has changed over time.
descrip: Explores the diverse connections between America's national development and natural environment. It examines how the U.S. originated, then expanded to cover a continental land mass, and the ways that expansion changed the nation. It analyzes how, why, and with what consequences major parts of the U.S. economy--for instance, farming, energy, services and government--have grown or in shrunk. It looks at how and with what results the U.S. has incorporated different ethnic and racial groups. It shows how, why, and with what outcomes it has historically globalized and conducted its foreign policy, and offers insights into current landscapes.

title: Natural History of Mammals
reviews: Good course though the professor was difficult at times. Study for the final and be diligent during the entire course about the material he lectures on.
I would advise other students to work hard in the field and do their best to contribute evenly in the group settings, to ensure the success of the group reports.
I would take this course. The projects and the traveling make it well worth your time.
Kenya is worth it, this course is the toughest and Dan can be frustrating.

Lots of counting zebras - but counting is more complicated than you think. Also, if you're interested in behavior or ecology, this course has some really cool insights into how ecology informs behavior.

This course has a consistently heavy course load, but it's really fun to travel to new places. Make sure you carefully prepare and organize your thoughts for the paper discussion/presentation that you lead. You can get by with skimming the rest. Make sure you work with Dan to clarify what he wants -- he'll be willing to help you. Try not to get frustrated if something goes wrong (it'll blow over quickly). Ask questions in all discussions, make sure you participate.
prereqs: EEB 211, and EEB 321. Permission of the instructor is required for non-EEB majors. Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya..
descrip: Introduction to concepts, methods, and material of comparative natural history, with African mammals as focal organisms. Perspectives include morphology, identification, evolution, ecology, behavior and conservation. Observations and experiments on a variety of species in different habitats and at a range of scales will provide insights into the adaptive value and underlying mechanistic function of mammalian adaptations. This course will be taught in Kenya at the Mpala Research Center and nearby field sites.

title: Advanced Spanish Language and Style
reviews: ALBERTO IS AMAZING. You could not ask for a more considerate, enthusiastic, or enjoyable professor. You will like this class and you will love him. Very interesting material in a manageable way.  100
Do all of the readings so that you can actively participate in class, because that was how I best learned!
Do all of the readings so that you can participate in class.
Do the readings before class so that you can make comments without having to understand what we're talking about first
Excellent course, well taught
If you have Spa 207, take this course. It will take your Spanish to the next level, it will engage you intellectually, and the workload is rigorous yet easy to manage.
If you need an LA and have a background in Spanish, it's a good distribution requirement. Not too tough, and the professors are good. The material isn't too interesting, though.
Participate in class and don't be afraid to ask the professor questions.

Take this class if you are interested in the intricacies of the Spanish language. It is similar to a high level English analysis course based on tone, motive, and other linguistic tools. It is a lot of reading, but I definitely learned a lot.
Take this! It helps with grammar and isn't too hard.
That it is a standard course with a moderate workload. However, the material is not very intellectually stimulating.

This is the worst class I have taken at Princeton. It is highly unstimulating and rewards those that know how to work a rubric and BS out of their mind. There are so many more rewarding classes in the Spanish department that improve your language through talking about more profound ideas of literature and history. Take these classes that are more academically stimulating. It is hard to develop interest in this class. The material is dry. I thought it was going to be easy, but it was not due to all its technicalities  within its overly complex rubric. 

All in all, this class fails to accomplish anything, as the people who I know to be receiving the highest grades are unimpressive and often those who do not participate in class.

If you enjoy not thinking and following a rubric closely, take this course.

Try to take the course with Profesora Mendez Vallejo.  She's a great teacher and really open to helping out and providing suggestions for assignments and projects.  
One downside of the class is that there are 3 group projects and the final one really eats up a lot of your time because the writing has to be collaborative.  So, not the best thing to really have during reading week, or at least I felt like I could've done it on my own in shorter time.
!Tomala!
prereqs: SPA 207 or 209; or another 200-level Spanish course with instructor's permission. Students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score can take the course only with instructor's permission..
descrip: An advanced language course. Its main purpose is to develop and reinforce accuracy and fluency in both writing and speaking Spanish. Students will also learn to identify linguistic features that characterize different genres as well as social and cultural factors that aid in the interpretation and understanding of different texts and types of speech.

title: Random Heterogeneous Materials
descrip: Composites, porous media, foams, colloidal suspensions, geological media, polymer blends, and biological media are all examples of heterogeneous materials. Often the microstructure of such materials is random. The relationship between the macroscopic (transport, mechanical, electromagnetic, and chemical) properties and microstructure of random heterogeneous materials is formulated. Topics include statistical characterization of the microstructure via n-point distribution functions; percolation theory; fractal concepts; sphere packings; Monte Carlo simulation techniques; and image analysis of microstructures; homogenization theory; effective-

title: Financial Crises
prereqs: ECO 310 and ECO 202 or equivalent..
descrip: This course will consider market bubbles and financial crises from two distinct angles. The first half will focus on bubbles and crashes in the public equity market, with particular emphasis on the productive role that financial speculation can play in the deployment of innovative technologies. We will take a broad conceptual view of historic episodes, so require a large amount of background reading. The second half will focus on the dynamics of the credit system, with particular emphasis on leverage cycles and systemic instabilities, including the global financial crisis of 2008. Recent theoretical literature will be explored in depth.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: Architecture, Globalization, and the Environment
reviews: A bit disorganized, but not too much work and fairly interesting.
Be prepared for lots of reading and discussion.
Be sure to figure out your paper topic early!
Enjoy! Just focus on the big ideas and asking the right questions.

Esther's passion for this subject is contagious, and while you may come away from class feeling depressed about all the enormous social and environmental issues architecture is involved in, it's pretty important stuff for anyone to know!

Get Matthew as a preceptor! Also, take this if you are interested at all social issues as they relate to the built environment. Wide range of topics on that issue are presented (social policy, the environment, engineering, etc.)
Go to lecture.

Great course. Extremely interesting. The last few lectures and lectures from guests seemed less relevant but were still valuable. Get started on the research paper early. At least skim the readings to see what you find interesting, there is a lot of really cool material.

I would only recommend this course if changes similar to ones I recommended above were made. In addition to technical issues, the subject matter is fascinating, revealing, and relevant but presented in a way that is much too broad.

I would recommend this course to freshman and sophomore students who are not sure about what they want to study. This course presents many fields--from engineering to architecture to environmental activism--and their overlaps on the world stage. It not a difficult class necessarily--It's really one of those you get as much out of as you put in.

If you are interested in architecture and how it connects to the environment and globalization Esther will help you have a critical look global/environmental   architecture. But keep in mind those three subjects are not always mixed throughout the course so if you are only interested in one of them it might be a bit boring sometimes. Also every topic on the syllabus deserves more time to be discussed, I hope that as this was the first time this class was taught it will be better planned in the future
If you are not an architecture major, be careful because there are a lot of architecture majors who have the leg up.

It is very straightforward. Its cross-disciplinary approach combines three very important and inter-connected fields of study that you just cannot ignore. I've learned just how complicit (a term the professor loves to use) individuals, developed countries, architecture, and population growth are in current socio-economic and environmental problems. The class was a relatively manageable course load (about 125 pages of reading a week), so it should also be appealing on that front. This class is highly recommended for future leaders and/or those going into public policy, design, urban planning, environmental studies, etc. In fact, anybody should just take it for its relevancy to current issues.
It is worth being double-dipped for a dean's dater and a final. And that's saying something.
It's easier.
It's pretty cool and a great class to take if you want an easy PDF. Just a paper and take home exam at the end!

Not my favorite class but not my least favorite...  As someone pursuing the ENV certificate with some background in architecture I thought this topic would be cool, but I feel like it was a little disorganized since it was a brand new course.  There wasn't too much work/reading during the semester but at the end there was a 15 page final paper AND a final exam, so that was a little much.
Pay attention to the broader themes of the course and don't stress about learning the details of every work presented.
TAKE IT! The lectures are incredible! The only downside is the 15 page paper   3x 2page take-home final
Take if you like art and arc and social issues, do not take for environmental or political itnerests
Take it if you are interested in architecture/globalization/the environment. It's very accessible, and most of the work throughout the year is reading.
Take it!

Take this course. It is interesting, the Professor and preceptors know their stuff, and you won't have to look far outside of the readings, classes and lectures while preparing for the exams and papers.

This is hands down the best course I've taken at Princeton. Much needed break from the monotony that can be Princeton courses at times. This class was challenging, informative, and always interesting. Take it!!

Very disjointed but perhaps b/c its the first year the course is taught. Interesting contemporary material, though. Found Prof DCM other course on Western arch to be a better option if you are looking for a basic foundation in architecture

Wonderful lectures and reading materials that allowed you to learn lots of new information, but also explore on your own. Many had previous experience and were able to share that with the class, but some of us, like me, had no experience and still really benefitted. Really makes you think, so it's not the easiest class, but I think definitely worth it.
none
descrip: This course covers global architecture and urbanism and their relation to climate change and social problems. Special attention will be paid to the erosion of public space, whether it is due to gentrification, gated communities, outright segregation, or to the devastating impact of war in urban zones in many parts of the world. We will study green architecture and issues of sustainability, as well as environmental justice and environmental racism. Architecture's complicities with regard to global warming, its squandering of fossil fuels and its response to rising waters and water scarcity are also central to our approach.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Policymaking in Diverse Societies
descrip: This course investigates how ethnic diversity influences the policymaking process in democratic societies, with a focus on Europe and the United States. We will first address why and how ethnic diversity shapes individuals' and groups' beliefs, preferences, and behaviors in ways that shape the formulation of policy. Next the course will examine the consequences of ethnic diversity on policy areas that all societies confront (such as redistribution and economic development) as well as policy areas that emerge as a result of diversity (such as affirmative action or immigrant integration).

title: Studies in French Language and Style
reviews: Based on stuff I have heard from friends who have taken 207, I think the course REALLY depends on the professor you have. Professor Lee is a very intelligent, but not that strict, and sometimes disorganized teacher.
Good way to practice speaking, but make sure to take initiative learning grammar and vocab.
I found Natasha Lee to be condescending but she is a pretty good teacher.

If you're interested in miscellaneous French cultural artifacts, take the class! They are well-chosen. If you have a strong background in French grammar, the class shouldn't be too challenging for you.
It was easier/less work than I expected, but if you did well in 107/108 and you want to continue to improve your language skills, you might be better off taking a higher-level 200 lit course.
TAKE IT!!! With Prof. Lee!
Take it if you have to, but honestly the best way to improve your French at this point is to study/live in a French speaking country.
Take it if you want your french to stay at a constant level. I think my writing improved but  my speaking stayed fairly constant.
Take it, but try and get a good professor/instructor. You'll only be engaged and do the work if you like your teacher.
Take it. It was well worth it.
The course is a bit step up from FRE 107 and the readings were tough. But it's a great way to improve your general French level and read some fun texts.
This is a pretty laid back class but your French will improve.
Very similar to FRE 108 (we were assigned the same grammar exercises from the same textbook...) but the readings are quite good.
prereqs: FRE 107, FRE 108, or placement based on placement test..
descrip: A study of French contemporary culture and society. Intensive oral and written study of vocabulary, grammar, and idiomatic expressions prepares students for advanced courses in French literature and civilization and for working programs in French-speaking countries. Small class format. Strong emphasis on discussion. Film series. Intensive practical training in oral and written French.

title: Geological Constraints on the Global Carbon Cycle
reviews: Strongly recommended.
This is a great class for getting practical skills in modeling and learning more about the carbon cycle.

While in theory you could enter this class without any experience with MATLAB, I would warn that you would get much more out the course if you had at least some prior introduction to linear algebra-based programming before enrolling in this class. So, while I would not recommend taking this class if you want to use it to learn MATLAB, I would HIGHLY recommend it if you're looking to take your programming/modeling skills to the next level!
descrip: This course explores global geochemical cycles through the use of simple numerical models. Topics covered range from box models of the geologic carbon and oxygen cycles, planetary thermostats, and atmospheric oxygenation, to box models of Cenozoic seawater chemistry (Mg and Ca), to 1D diffusion-reaction modes of the dynamics of carbon and oxygen in sedimentary systems. Previous coursework in differential equations and MATLAB are highly desirable but not absolutely necessary.

title: God Forbid: Religion, Secularism, and Modernity in French Society and Culture
descrip: See website

title: Dramatic Art and Theory - Figurations of the Virtuoso
descrip: The course investigates the discourse on the virtuoso between the 19th century and contemporary discussions around skills, discipline and work in neoliberal economies. Figurations of the virtuosic are examined in relation to images of the artist as genius, technician and "charlatan." Questions concerning notions of excellence and mastery are discussed, as well as the traits of failure--aspects of the virtuoso, understood not as an exception, but rather as a necessity to everyone (Paolo Virno). The course follows the transformations of the terminology and theory of virtuosic performance on the border between epistemology and art.

title: Approaches to American History
reviews: Be prepared! It's a lot of work, but Professor Warren is great and the reading is interesting. If you are serious about the work you put in, you will get a lot out of it.
DEFINITELY take this class if you want to be a history major. It is not the easiest, but you will learn so much and your writing will improve so much.
Do the readings, start assignments early. Have comments prepared.
Don't take it to fulfill your HA!
Great course but the Salem Witch Trials section was terrible!
I would highly recommend this course!
If this course is being taught by Kruse, take it. The opportunity to have two small group precepts with this man a week was one of my favorite experiences from freshman year.
If you are seriously considering history as a major, take this course! You will learn how to read, think, and write like a historian!
If you need a prerequisite for history and you're interested in American history (Little Rock, the Dawes Act and the Salem Witch Trials), then consider taking it.
Keep up with the readings! It's the only way to be engaged with the course and get the most out of it, as well as write thoughtful papers.
Stay on top of your readings!
Take it if you need it to become a history major.
Take it--especially if you are a US concentrator, but even if you're not, it's great to get the opportunity to work this closely with documents.
Take the course if you like history. Be prepared to do a ton of reading.
Take this as your 200 level history pre-req! you won't regret it. Great professors, great lectures, and interesting topics! It's not too much work and you'll learn a ton.

Take this class! It teaches you how to read primary sources and construct a historical narrative using different lenses. To make things easier for yourself come paper time, I would recommend jotting down a few sentences about each 'document' with page numbers in a word doc as you read - later the control F function will help you find things you remember reading but can't put your finger on. The reading is interesting on the whole - do it on time! All in all, take this class - precept discussions are lively and I've really enjoyed this class.

Take this course! I am a politics major, but this course is definitely still in my top five courses I've taken at Princeton. It will really improve your ability to formulate interesting theses from primary source documents, and that is a skill you can use in any field, history major or not. This course is a lot work, and you will need to put in a good deal of reading time each week, but it is definitely worth it!

Taking this course will not convince you to be a history major; in fact, it might turn you in the other direction. Still, I would recommend this course even to undecided students or non-majors because you get to analyze important historical episodes from the primary sources themselves. Be warned, however: readings are DENSE (think 100 pages in a day), and if you already have a difficult course load you might not be able to handle it.
This a great introductory course to history. You should definitely take it if you are considering history as a major.

This is a great course that goes beyond being a pre-requisite. It will teach you how to write and research like a Historian while learning about cool topics like The Salem Witch Trials or the Little Rock Crisis.
prereqs: First priority is given to Sophomores..
descrip: An intensive introduction for history concentrators, particularly those who plan to take their independent work seriously. Students will immerse themselves in documents of three events: the Little Rock school desegregation crisis of the 1950s; Native American policies and the Dawes Act of 1887; and the Salem witch trials of 1692-1693. Interpretation of documents, framing of historical arguments, and construction of historical explanations will be stressed. Lectures introduce a basic vocabulary of analysis.

title: Fundamentals of Queueing Theory
reviews: Do you like Poisson processes? How about Markov chains? Renewal processes? Then this class is for you I guess. Also queuing models are used a lot in computer science to model things like requests to a server, or something like that. So if that's interesting then sure. But the lectures were pretty dull, and the slides are drowned in colors and diagrams making them hard to read. So I would suggest taking notes by hand even though you get slides (but only after the lecture, so you can't take notes on them). The first 3 lectures or so is just review of ORF 309 topics, so you can safely skip those. For a lot of homework problems, you need to use results that you found on previous homeworks, so if you ever get stuck remember this point. Also the notation {Event} is used in this class to represent the indicator random variable that takes the value 1 if Event occurs. Go to office hours, the TAs are very helpful and will show you how to solve problems using approaches you never would have thought of yourself. The median for the homeworks and midterm was something like 93, so one mistake and you should consider dropping.

If you liked ORF 309, you will like this class.  Very cool extension of 309.  Professor Massey is really laid back and willing to help.  The assignments take a while but for the most part are pretty cool.
Kobby is a great TA!
Professor Massey teaches the class very well. I think the subject is also pretty interesting and I would recommend taking it if you liked ORF309.

Some people aren't fans of Massey's lecturing or speaking style, although I think it's fine. 

I liked queueing a lot but some people might find it dull. It doesn't really have much finance applications, and definitely is on the OR side of ORFE. It is a good bit of math, although you won't be writing proofs. You should definitely go to office hours, as questions that will give you a WTF response will often have intuitive or interesting solutions that Professor Massey or the TA will be able to guide you toward.
Take it furrr sure if you liked 309 or 473 at all. Great class!
Take it!
Take the class! Take advantage of the psets. They are enlightening and sometimes fun.
This was a great non-finance ORF class; the math is really cool. After taking this class, I'm thinking about writing my thesis on a topic in Queueing Theory.
go over the slides after every lecture. Go to office hours.
prereqs: ORF 309.
descrip: An introduction to the fundamental results of queueing theory. Topics covered include the classical traffic, offered load, loss and delay stochastic models for communication systems. Through concrete examples and motivations we discuss the theory of Markov chains, Poisson processes and Monte-Carlo simulation. Fundamental queueing results such as the Erlang blocking and delay formulae, Little's law and Lindley's equation are presented. Applications are drawn from communication network systems, inventory management, and optimal staffing.

title: Hispanic Studies: Introduction to Cultural Analysis
reviews: If you want to get better at reading and writing in Spanish and develop your analytical skills, take it.
Keep up with the readings and engage in class discussions.
Take it!
Take it, it will be a great course!
Take the class if you want to really prepare yourself for 300 level Spanish lit classes.

Take this class if you are going for the certificate but expect to have to sit for an hour and a half. Do the readings. He has a very specific view on each one and so you probably will disagree at a point. Grading on the commentaries was fair.
prereqs: Another SPA 200-level course or instructor's permission.
descrip: An introduction to the analysis of contemporary cultural texts (narrative, poetry, film, photography) from Latin America and Spain, with the support of various theoretical ideas. The course's main objective is to provide students with a set of strong conceptual, analytical and linguistic skills, which will be of great help in 300-level literature/culture courses.

title: High Dimensional Statistics
reviews: Do the problems in the notes
I would recommend this course for students who are interested in statistics.
If you are interested in statistics (especially in sparse estimation), then this is worth the hardwork.

Take this class if you can. It's a wonderful introduction to current theoretical statistical machine learning. You will gain an appreciation for complexity, upper and lower bounds, and understanding the kind of results you can expect from statistical learning.
Try practice problems though-out the semester. They are very hard, as is the final. You will need as much practice as possible.
Very good class if you like and already have a good background in stats and linear algebra
prereqs: Statistical Theory and Methods (ORF 524) or approval by the instructor..
descrip: Course is on statistical theory and methods for high-dimensional statistical learning and inferences arising from processing massive data from various scientific disciplines. Emphasis is given to penalized likelihood methods, independence screening, large covariance modeling, and large-scale hypothesis testing. The important theoretical results are proved.

title: Peacemaking
reviews: Definitely do, and make sure to work hard to get the most out of it.
Definitely take the course if you are interested in this subject. Do not be wary of the 3 hour class. Time flies by quickly in class.

Do the readings, come with questions, and go to office hours if you have more questions. You'll learn a lot, and the theory intro at the beginning of the course will be used for the rest of the course. It's very methodical and logical, and very rewarding if you make a point of keeping up with readings. He's a very friendly professor and definitely comes with experience that most professors would be unable to match, making this course particularly unique.

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. Gen. Nash is really engaging, and a great person to get to know. The material is really interesting, and it's an important topic for anyone to know about, regardless of academic background.

If you are interested in development or international institutions, definitely take this course. Professor Nash has so much real-life experience to share on the topics that are covered and his stories are a good enough reason to take this class. The reading is not bad and the grading is fair.
Stay up to date on current peace ops throughout the year, read opinion pieces frequently
Take it! General Nash is easy to talk to and learn from.
The class embodied Princeton's motto. I think it is an extremely important topic to have some background in. I would definitely recommend it.

This has been one of my favorite courses at Princeton. Professor Nash is highly knowledgable and approachable. It is rare that one has the opportunity to take a course with someone so full of real-life experience on the subject matter.
do the readings, research the cases. enjoy writing the op-ed. very few times do you get to do that!
descrip: This seminar will assess the history, objectives, and effectiveness of international peace operations including peacemaking, peacekeeping, peace enforcement, and peacebuilding efforts. Informed by current and recent operations in places such as the Balkans, Africa, and the Middle East, the class will assess progress by the international community in its ability to respond effectively to the political, economic, and social transitions in post-conflict societies. The seminar will also study the development of U.S. policy toward peace operations.

title: What Makes for a Meaningful Life? A Search
descrip: See website

title: Energy and Commodities Markets
reviews: Highly recommend if you are interested in energy commodities types of topics
If you are interested in commodities and are willing to take a more challenging course, this course will be rewarding.

This is an excellent course to understand commodities markets. How they work, what is happening now, and details in derivatives pricing. Professor Carmona is very nice and knowledgable in this career. He also shared a lot of his experience in the market. However, you MUST be familiar with asset pricing and stochastic calculus to take this course. Hence, you should have taken FIN 501 and FIN 503 / ORF 515 before taking this course. Otherwise, the assignments may take you UNNECESSARILY much longer to complete. The difficulty of this course is comparative or maybe slightly easier than FIN 522 (Fixed Income Models & Applications). If you want to take an easy essay-writing course, this is not the course for you.
This was a hard class, and unless you want to do a lot of math that is a step up from ORF 335, I would recommend not taking it.
prereqs: ORF335 or instructor's permission required.
descrip: This course is an introduction to commodities markets (energy, metals, agricultural products) and issues related to renewable energy sources such as solar and wind power, and carbon emissions. Energy and other commodities represent an increasingly important asset class, in addition to significantly impacting the economy and policy decisions. Emphasis will be on the application of Financial Mathematics to a variety of different products and markets. Topics include: energy prices (including oil and electricity); cap and trade markets; storable vs non-storable commodities; financialization of commodities markets; applications of game theory.

title: Tropical Agriculture
reviews: Enjoy this course -- it's much more relaxed than what you'll have before it. However, know that the course is very much skewed toward the end, and your grade is based almost solely on one final project. Make sure you take it seriously and are prepared for the course to step up in the final weeks. Don't get lazy, ask Cheryl for guidance in your final project, and finish strong.
Great class. Lecture heavy but still good.
I would advise students to take this course, especially if it's taught by Cheryl.
It's fun! not too hard, just go with the flow
Take this course! This course gave you more free time than any other, but also worked to get you excited about tropical agriculture. The trip to Embu is especially rewarding.

This class is a bit different from the others - you get to see a bit of Kenya and talk to farmers about their livelihoods. It's really cool. Be prepared for all of the work to come in the last 48 hours.
prereqs: EEB 211 and EEB 321. Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya..
descrip: Kenya has some of the most diverse set of crops and farming systems in Africa allowing students to compare productivity, diversity, and ecological processes. Students will spend their time exploring the varied agro-ecosystems, crops, livestock, climates, and soils under which agriculture is practiced in Kenya. The course includes key readings and discussions, intensive field sampling, GIS applications, and modeling. In addition, students will be exposed to the various ecological processes and ecosystem services provided by or interfered with by agriculture. Limited to students in the Tropical Biology and Sustainability Program in Kenya.

title: Optimal Learning
reviews: Definitely a good ORFE departmental to take with Prof. Powell. Make sure to have a partner for the final project who you're comfortable working with because the final report is long and can be difficult to do alone.

Definitely take this class with Prof. Powell and make sure you get stared on your final report early. We spent over 50 hours on it. Psets are not that time consuming and material is very digestible and highly interesting.
