Great class! Well taught and Powell is really invested in his students. Pick a subject that you are genuinely interested in for the final project and it can be pretty fulfilling. Would recommend even to non-ORF majors

I had very mixed feelings about this class. On one hand, optimal learning is a cool set of equations and concepts with several relevant applications, and Powell has lots of interesting stories and is very invested in the class. Unfortunately, some lectures seemed needlessly heavy on derivations, and there were barely any concrete (i.e., numbers instead of variables) examples of optimal learning shown to us which made the learning experience a lot more painful. I'd recommend the class, but be prepared to be thrown off at first with the confusing notation and lectures.
I recommend this class. Interesting because it's an intro to a pretty new field of research, it's not too hard or too easy, and Professor Powell is a fun lecturer.

I would strongly recommend this course to all ORF majors or anyone who is interested in a unique course on learning with really cool applications. There is a lot of freedom with the final project at the end of the course and you can pick something you are really interested in.

If you're just another bland, mindless finance drone, don't take this class because it's probably not applicable to your soul-sucking career aspirations.  For OR and DS people, take it -- it's quite interesting.  Soft enough on the math for public policy people too, but definitely too black-box-ish for strong math/ORFE students.
It's a very interesting course if you're interested in the concepts of online learning/offline learning and how to optimize when given a set of known variables/information.
It's an relatively easy departmental, but don't expect too much out of the course. There is little help available for the course.
Powell is a fratter

Pretty cool application of Operations Research.  After the midterm, lectures are pretty useless as far as for your grade in the class, but the content is interesting.  Pretty easy and interesting ORF elective.

TAKE IT! This is an awesome departmental to take if you're an ORFE major who wants to make better decisions. Each of the learning policies you will learn in this class you will probably never use theoretically (unless you're in academia) but the gist and psyche behind each of the problems and solution techniques you learn is super-relevant. Imo this class should be informally called the "psychology of decisionmaking under uncertainty/with less info" Some people may be put off by all the intricate math and the amount of coding you have to do for the project (first half of course is math, second half is entirely the project) but the key is to focus on the big picture ideas behind all the mathematical solutions to things like the Secretary problem, the main idea behind KG etc. You will at least get a life philosophy rule for when you should explore and when you should exploit in life. Prof. Powell is very clear and a no-fuss, direct kind of professor who will help you every step of the way with resources, ideas for the project etc. In every which way it is a straightforward class if you dont mind the coding for the project. Get help with MATLAB/find someone to be a partner who likes MATLAB if you dont.
Take it if you're interested at all in decision making!
Take it! Super helpful in thinking about things in different ways and not too difficult.

Take this class if you are interested in operations research. The idea of the knowledge gradient is useful and the programming elements in this course make sure you understand it qualitatively and can actually implement the learning algorithms.

The course is broken into two distinct halves. The first half is a normal lecture-weekly PSet format. The lectures are very very very very notation heavy (to the point that any non math/physics/engineer probably will never be able to reconcile with it) but the subject matter is pretty easy (again for a math-oriented person). Powell says in the first week that we should expect this to be about the difficulty and workload of ORF 245, which sounds about right. The content is interesting and somewhat applicable. The PSets are great - not time consuming and a nice change of pace after ORF 309, it is not Matlab heavy and you can figure out the programming as you go. Then, there is a midterm in week 7 that is hard to study for, since you are not really sure what you could be tested on. But you just look at the few example problems in the book and the test wasn't too hard (the cheat sheet was imperative for the first time in a class for me). The second half of the class is a whole different story. No psets, no final. Just lectures in the course that may or may not be helpful for the final project. Class attendence dropped and most of the lectures were not immediately understandable (and there were no psets to help us to). The project is very open ended without much direction - which is usually worse than it is good. Start simple and small with stuff that you learned. Only then do you bite off stuff from the second half lectures and even then keep your model simple. Also worth mentioning there were no precepts even though score made us sign up for one.
This course is very interesting and relatively laid back, though the final project can take a lot of time
Very interesting departmental, easy introduction to learning problem.s
if you're interested in machine learning, this will blow your mind.

the project at the end is really fun if you choose something original, like a game to model. don't let powell's meticulous / complicated notation confuse you - the class is pretty straightforward and fairly interesting!
prereqs: ORF 245 and ORF 309.
descrip: Optimal learning addresses the challenge of collecting information efficiently when information is expensive. Applications include topics such as finding the best price for a product, identifying the best treatment for a disease, tuning the parameters in a bidding policy, or choosing the best player for a sports team. Students learn how to formulate a learning problem, identify a belief model, and quantify the value of information. The course covers online and offline learning problems, and introduces students to a range of policies for collecting information.

title: Beginner's French II
reviews: Although French 102 doesn't take an enormous amount of work, engaging yourself is very rewarding. The staff in the French department are all very friendly and helpful.

Be sure to read the textbook in advance to going to class so you have a general sense of what the topic that's going to be discussed is. Doing the exercises in the course packet really help to prepare you for the module tests.
Definitely do the readings and exercises at home, even if they won't be collected or graded.
Definitely take the course, and be aware of keeping up with the amount of terms and grammar to memorize EVERY DAY.
Do the nightly homework! It will help you understand the concepts talked about in class.
Don't blow it off, devote time to french every night.

Dont' take French unless you've taken French before coming to Princeton. If you're starting without any prior French experience, it will be really difficult to learn everything expected of you. The classes are way too fast-paced for beginning students in three to four other classes.
Easy class. Applying a few grammar rules and memorizing a few verb conjugations is sufficient to do well on exams.
Focus on studying the methods that Dr. Chanethom outlines.
Go to class and participate in assignments. Really write your compositions on your own (don't use google translate, etc..) and you will learn a lot from them.
If you don't like your professor, try switching into another precept. The instructor is the most important part of the course.
It is a good course if you're interested in French and need to fulfill a foreign language requirement. It isn't too difficult or too much work, and the classes can be pretty fun.
Just read the book for vocabulary; you can learn the rest from class.
Put as much of your own time as possible into learning vocabulary!
Read the textbook before class and use the online resources. The French department here is great!
Review frequently or else it is easy to fall behind.
Take French if you can--it's a relaxed class, but you'll learn a lot.
Take it if you want to learn French.  The department is really great.
Take this class with Vincent
This class is really easy.

This course is more frustrating than it needs to be. The tests often feel like they are designed to trip you up, rather than allow you to show all that you have learned. That is my big complaint. Do not take this course unless you are very self-motivated and disciplined, and do not mind getting a mediocre grade despite all your good faith efforts.
Time consuming but learning a language is worth it!
great teacher, as good as it gets for a language course
know the verbs and verb tenses!
take it if you have to.
work hard and keep up with the reading
prereqs: FRE 101 or Permission Of Instructor. No credit is given for FRE 101 unless FRE 102 is successfully completed..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to enable you to achieve intermediate communication proficiency in French. All four skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing will be actively practiced in realistic communicative situations, through a variety of activities designed to help you strengthen newly acquired vocabulary and grammatical structures. You will learn to talk about events and people, construct narratives in French and develop reading and writing skills that will be a foundation for literacy in the target language. There is a wide use of authentic material from France and the Francophone world throughout the course.

title: Approaches to Islamic Intellectual History
descrip: This seminar provides a broad-ranging introduction to and assessment of approaches to pre-modern and modern Islamic intellectual history. How, and with what success, have scholars tried to place particular developments in their varied intellectual, political, socio-economic, and cultural contexts? What constitutes the relevant context and how should one try to mediate among competing ways of accounting for particular intellectual developments? What assumptions - historiographical, sociological, normative - have guided recent work and how do they compare with an earlier generation's scholarship? These are among the questions we address.

title: Econometric Research Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Directed Research I
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research I is normally taken during the first year of study.

title: Into the Wild
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Asset Pricing II: Stochastic Calculus and Advanced Derivatives
reviews: Ask professor for practice problems ahead of the midterm. Go to office hours if you feel lost at the beginning of the course.
Be advised the second half of the course is much more difficult and dense than the first
Good class if you never dealt with pricing options , exotics, Black-Scholes model, etc
Great course. A lot of weekly work but you really learn the stuff.
I recommend this course if you want to start learning finance. One suggestion is to carefully read the corresponding math book and finance book to gain more understanding.
I recommend this course to anyone who is interested in quantitative finance and/or in basic stochastic calculus applied to pricing.
I would suggest taking this course, especially if the student is interested in fixed-income securities.
If you do not have any experiences in stochastic culculs, study hard.
If you enjoy finance, please take this course.

If you haven't taken stochastic calculus, learn some before the class. Otherwise it will already be too late. You can;t actually rely on the class to teach you the basics the first time around. Learn them yourself or go to office hours and don't be embarrassed to ask a lot of baby questions.....or do poorly on the midterm, come to the remedial sessions, and once again ask baby questions during office hours.
Prepare for a huge workload.
Very important course to understand quantitative finance. Highly recommended!
take it! talk to the prof she is very nice.
descrip: Course covers the pricing and hedging of advanced derivatives, including topics such as exotic options, greeks, interest rate derivatives and credit derivatives, as well as covering the basics of stochastic calculus necessary for finance. Designed for Masters students.

title: Roads Not Taken: Some Critics of American Society, 1880-1960
reviews: Absolutely take this course if you have the opportunity, very worthwhile for the history as well as the philosophy.
Definitely do all the readings and come prepared because that way you can have a much better discussion and really get a lot more out of the class.

Great course! Prof. Ryan is wonderful, very accessible, and quite well known in his field. Also, the readings are excellent and you really won't get a chance to study some of these authors much in other courses.
I think Ryan is retiring but if he is not take whatever class he teaches.
Professor Ryan is leaving.

Unfortunately Alan Ryan, who was a large part of why this course was wonderful, won't be returning to teach it.  I do think that a similar course would still be fascinating.  Since this is an AMS course - not history or politics - it's most useful if you already have a background in American political thought and general American history.  This might also require some additional reading and research during the semester.  That said, the ideas presented in this course are fascinating and challenging; reading them as charitably as possible will help shape your own understanding of the history and scope of American political thought.
While Professor Ryan is departing, I really appreciated the material.  Really made me think a lot about what it means to be American, liberal, and a critic of society.
descrip: Many commentators during the 1950s gave the impression that postwar liberal-democracy was the 'natural' state of the USA. This obscured the work of many interesting, non-mainstream critics of modern industrial America, ranging from insurrectionary socialists to melancholy conservatives, few of them writing from the academy, including novelists, journalists, and activists. The course aims to give students the chance to read these writers and decide for themselves whether they deserved to have more influence than they did, or perhaps even less.

title: Calculus II
reviews: As long as you attend class and do the homework (which isn't extensive), you can do well in this class. If you are having trouble, go to the office hours and review sessions before quizzes to clarify any questions.

Buy Adrian Banner's Calculus Lifesaver and read every chapter related to the course.  Also, use it to create a study guide for each exam/quiz.  This was one of the best decisions I made all semester - actually, all year.  Also, go to office hours often, review sessions always, and don't be afraid to ask questions - the preceptors are extremely nice and usually helpful for this course.
Definitely pay attention in class, and if the textbook doesn't help, get a copy of the Calculus Lifesaver.
Do a lot of practice problems before the quizzes/midterms!
Do all the homework and go to class.
Do not be afraid to ask too many questions. The material is difficult and the course is much more manageable and enjoyable when the student uses all the available resources to the full extent.
Do the problem-sets and make sure to practice with old problems to prepare for the rigorous exams.
Don't ever take this class unless you positively have to. Do not bring this misery on yourself for no reason.
Don't take it if you don't have to.
Go to lecture and memorize the formulas
Go to office hours -- they are so much more helpful than almost anything.
Go to office hours and the review sessions.
Good for those who want to review calc B from high school or just learn calc in general

I did okay in the class but I completely destroyed the final and I don't know why. It was my first final and it may have completely ruined my grade. Basically, don't forget the material and go over practice problems rather than concept problems.
I know it's daunting that you seem to never arrive at complete answers, but you get a lot of partial credit so show your methodology clearly.
I mean, why would you take math if you didn't have to?
I would advise that they take the time to thoroughly understand every problem set, since the quizzes and tests are harder than the problem sets.
If you are thinking about taking 104, take it with Jerry Wang. If you don't get him switch into his class!
If you expect this to be fun, you're either a prospective math major or deluded.
If you have a genuine interest and are willing to work hard take this course.
If you need a QR distribution requirement, take MAT 104. The content learned in this class is very useful and is very well taught.

If you need to take the class, don't worry about it, it is a great course and as long as you put in the effort you will do fine. The professors make sure there are many resources here for you if you need it. Better class than MAT 103, in my opinion!
It is important to read the textbook. Often, people will not bother to do so for math, but i definitely helps.
It's a required introductory class, what are you going to do about it.
Make sure to prepare in advance for the tests. You will learn a lot and it is a very rewarding feeling when you finish.
Might be a little more demanding than you might expect, but overall fairly easy and straightforward.
Moderately difficult class, but still doable. If Xiaoheng (Jerry) Wang is teaching, TAKE HIS SECTION! He's excellent at teaching class and funny too!
Not too much work, but you need to know this stuff for any engineering and science courses
Only take this if you need to. The curve is ridiculous.
Pay attention in class, go to office hours, and go to review sessions!
Practice lots of problems prior to evaluations.
READ THE TEXTBOOK BEFORE LECTURE! Or else, you will be lost.
Stay on top of the material. It stays simple that way.
Study a little of the information after class because it is a complicated topic.
Take it for a QR if you need one. It's not easy, but it's really not a bad class, especially if you get Jerry as an instructor.
Take it only if required!
Take it. Great course.
Take the class! Try to get Jerry as preceptor.
Take this class if you have a genuine interest in math, otherwise you may find it too challenging and time-consuming.
Tests are really hard. Read before class.

This class is hard and I don't think it rocks anybody's socks, but if you decide to get through it, it will make your brain bigger.

If you take it, read the textbook and make an effort to understand the material BEFORE going to class and learning it, so that you understand what's going on. Scribbling down notes without understanding them isn't a good use of time and (if you're like me), it will take a little more than just Benoit's explanations in order to really wrap your mind around the material.

This course teaches math you're expected to know for PHY103/4, which can feel pretty frustrating at times if you're concurrently enrolled (at least it did for me). Still, it's a pretty straightforward class, and it's definitely a good choice if you're looking to brush up on AB Calculus content and/or you didn't take BC in high school.
This course will give you a solid foundation in basic calculus.
Try to pick a professor that teaches to your strengths (if you can't handle theory-heavy explanations, find a teacher who is more practical!!)
Utilize office hours
Work with others!
Your first math class at Princeton will be a culture shock regardless of level. I feel like I think more critically in math than I did before.
don't take unless prereq
good
study hard
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Continuation of MAT103. Topics include techniques of integration, arclength, area, volume, convergence of series and improper integrals, L'Hopital's rule, power series and Taylor's theorem, introduction to differential equations and complex numbers.

title: Special Topics in Creative Writing - The Writer's Room: Creating a Dramatic Series for the New Television
reviews: Always participate in outlining of the material.  Watch all the movies that the Professor recommends.  Stay up to date with current television shows.
Definitely take it - a totally unique writing experience.
Definitely take this course if you're interested in screenwriting or if you enjoy television and want to see how it works from the story-side.
Enjoy it and soak up as much knowledge as possible.
It's a fun course and not too much work, though your experience will be very dependent on the composition of your class, since it is very group-based.
really fun, can be frustrating if you're bored of the tv show you're supposed to be writing.
prereqs: This course is limited to advanced writing students who have previously completed at least two 200-level writing courses. This course cannot be audited. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information.
descrip: Television series on premium cable have, in the last decade, featured more sophisticated writing than on network television and in most feature films. These series afford a writer a heightened sense of character, more complex plots, darker subject matter, frequent surprises and non-linear storytelling. In this class we will create and write a series of this nature, organized around the same principles as a professional writer's room. Students will become the members of the "writing staff" and will write the pilot and bible for the show. Classes will include occasional guest writers/directors/producers, and will focus heavily on writing.

title: Statics of Structures
reviews: For almost everyone who is looking at this course, it is a requirement. However, I think it is a much better course than a lot of the CEE courses and this is thanks to Branko.
Fun class, gets much harder towards the end of the semester.
I would definitely recommend taking statics. Do the problem sets ahead of time!
N/A

Professor has an inspiring ideology towards engineering, especially in an increasingly technology-driven field. Student probably needs the course as a departmental requirement, but nevertheless seems like an important and one of the more unique courses Princeton offers in this field (compared to other universities) to help develop a more intuitive approach towards statics.
Really just pay attention and ask questions and you'll do fine. Branko is really encouraging and generally awesome.
Stay on top of the material. Concepts build.
Take this course from Branko. He is good at explaining information, and if you do not understand, he will hold Ask Professor sessions to review a topic before a quiz or exam.
Understand the concepts early. It gets exponentially harder throughout the year. Do homework resubmissions early! And when you don't understand anything, go to office hours. Branko's really helpful.
prereqs: CEE 205.
descrip: Develops notions of internal forces and displacements, and instructs students how to design and analyze structures. Presents the fundamental principles of structural analysis, determination of internal forces, and deflections under the static load conditions, and introduces the bending theory of plane beams and the basic energy theorems. The theory of the first order will be developed for continuous girders, frames, arches, suspension bridges, and trusses, including both statically determinate and indeterminate structures. Basic principles for construction of influence lines and determination of extreme influences will be presented.

title: Greek History - Methods and Problems
descrip: A comprehensive introduction to central topics and methods of Greek history, offering a chronological overview of periods and significant developments; a survey of research tools and specialized sub-disciplines (e.g., epigraphy and numismatics); as well as important theoretical approaches to the study of the past (e.g., positivism, or the Annales School).

title: Self-Love and the Common Good: from Aristotle to the Invisible Hand
reviews: Just remember that not all precepts are the same, and you will get a lot out of this class. (This one is lecture-y, but all you need to do is feel it out and realize when it is time to make comments and when its better for you to listen.) You will get excellent feedback on papers and you will be allowed lots of office hour time should you want it. It felt like an intellectually stimulating class- the kind you want to find here.
Litwin was a fantastic instructor, this seminar was extremely well organized, and I learned a lot.
descrip: Aristotle opposed self-love to selfishness and regarded the former as the natural reward of virtue. In the Christian tradition, however, self-love is the sinful passion that caused man's fall. Outside of charity, human virtues are but disguised selfishness. Yet, does it matter so much that our private actions be selfish if they benefit society? Early-modern philosophers became increasingly interested in questioning the controversial paradox that encouraging men to be selfish might result in better government than educating them to be virtuous. We will discuss those debates and their role in early-modern moral, political and economic theories.

title: Advanced Questions in Photography
reviews:
Deana is the best! Ask her questions; she truly tries to do her best to help every student grow in her work.
Go to the the field trips. You get to go to galleries, artists' houses, and we even got to go with her on a shoot this semester!
Don't be too bummed if you get locked out or you're not an upperclassmen who wants to take this class. Just send her an e-mail and sit in on the class. People will drop, and if there still isn't enough room, she can ask the registrar to create an extra space for you.
Good class if you like photography!
Take it if Deana is teaching!!
Take it!
descrip: This class will investigate different approaches to the idea of "the intimate" in photography. How might photographs taken in private spaces defy dominant political narratives? To paraphrase Alice Walker, how might photographs connect us, in a caring way, to what feels like a dissolving world? Class lectures will look at the work of such artists as Nan Goldin, Emmet Gowin, Jacob Holt, and Louis Mendes, as well as vernacular images. Students will be expected to engage in research and discussion on the topic and produce a substantial body of photographs for presentation and final critique.

title: Themes in World History, 1300-1850
reviews: Be prepared for readings that are outside of your comfort zone.

I highly recommend this course for any history student, as it is relevant for all regions and time periods. It gives a very strong foundation in the major historiographical debates of the past few decades, especially about divergence, eurocentricity, etc.
This is a challenging, but definitely rewarding class.

To engage with the readings as much as possible, because many of them are deserved classics and most of the rest are also of very high quality. I would also encourage the student to try multiple styles of presentation and to use Prof Adelman's seminar as a space for experimentation with different skill sets. He is very open-minded and receptive, which makes it easy to try new out new things.
descrip: This seminar covers classical and contemporary debates and historiography of world history, from the making of world systems, to the rise and fall of empires, to global revolution and the onset of modernity.

title: Quantitative Investment Management
descrip: A survey of central topics in the area of investment management and financial planning. Integrating pricing methodologies with financial planning models. Linking asset and liability strategies to achieve investment goals and meet liabilities. We model the enterprise as a multi-stage stochastic program with decision strategies.

title: Analysis in a Single Variable
reviews: Be prepared to work! A lot.
I highly recommend this course for everyone, even those not looking to be a math major.

I'm a junior COS major, and this was one of my favorite courses at Princeton. It's work, to be sure, but if you have any interest in math whatsoever I highly recommend it (especially if Fickenscher is teaching).
Prof. Fickenscher is awesome. Class is not so intimidating in spring.
Take it

Take it if you love math; don't take it if you don't like problem sets that will make you bang your head against the wall for hours or to get an A. There are no suckers in this class; as someone who considers himself reasonably good at math (not IMO or anything, but took Calc 3 and Linear in high school) the midterm and final for this course were some of my worst experiences at Princeton (partly due to anxiety, but still....) Fickenscher is great, though.
This is an incredibly difficult course. Start your problem sets early and whatever you do, don't fall behind! Seek help from your peers, the professor, and the TA's.
take it if you want to become a better thinker
descrip: An introduction to the mathematicsal discipline of analysis, to prepare for higher-level course work in the department. Topics include rigorous epsilon-delta treatment of limits, convergence, and uniform convergence of sequences and series. Continuity, uniform continuity, and differentiability of functions. The Heine-Borel Theorem. The Rieman integral, conditions for integrability of functions and term by term differentiation and integration of series of functions, Taylor's Theorem.

title: Cultural Analysis (Half-Term)
descrip: We journey through some key methodological and theoretical issues in the sociological analysis of culture. The questions of how one analytical approach is accomplished and whether it is justifiable form the core of discussions. We survey a selective set of analytical approaches to studying culture, or culture in social actions. We interrogate their epistemological, theoretical, and methodological foundations. This is not necessarily a technique-teaching course, but we cover some basics of useful analytical techniques to mapping the structures and processes of culture.

title: Graduate Seminar in Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering
reviews: I recommend taking this course since it is a requirement.
It was fun.
descrip: A seminar of graduate students and staff presenting the results of their research and recent advances in flight, space, and surface transportation; fluid mechanics; energy conversion; propulsion; combustion; environmental studies; applied physics; and materials sciences. There is one seminar per week and participation at presentations by distinguished outside speakers.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: A Nation of Immigrants
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Public Finance II
descrip: The course presents recent developments in the theory of social choice, fairness, equality of opportunity, inequality measurement, well-being measurement, and their applications in public economics. Recent developments in the analysis of collective risks, future generations, fairness in taxation, behavioral economics, and interdependent preferences are covered.

title: Acting and Directing in Musical Theater
reviews: I would definitely recommend this to any student interested in theatre.
THIS IS THE BEST CLASS EVER. TAKE IT! TAKE IT! TAKE IT!
Take it.
This course is amazing and should be taken by anyone interested in musical theatre.  The closest thing we have to an MT program in the theatre department and we need more of this
take it!
prereqs: THR 201, THR 301, THR 311, THR 366 or THR 411 or MUS 241 or significant experience in the musical form. Please contact the Program Director, Tim Vasen for more information at: tvasen@princeton.edu.
descrip: A practical, hands-on introduction to acting and directing in musical theater. The course will require students to prepare songs and scenes from selected musicals with an eye to how best to approach the particular challenges the scene presents.

title: Perilous Desires: Witches, Saints, and Sinners
reviews: If you're on the fence, take it. It's fairly painless as far as language classes go. Reasonable work load and professor brewer is nice
It's great! I really enjoyed this class and I'd recommend it to anyone.
Loved it! She is a wonderful professor who is very available and very helpful.
Proofread your papers carefully.
Wonderful course if you are interested in the portrayal of women in literature
prereqs: SPA 200-level course.
descrip: This course focuses on representations of women's bodies and sexualities in early Latin American writings. In doing so, we will study the body through a variety of lenses: the anatomical body as a site of construction of sexual difference, the witch's body as a site of sexual excess, the mystic's body as a double of the possessed body, the tortured body as a site of knowledge production, and the racialized bodies of New World women as sites to govern sexuality, spirituality, labor, and property in the reaches of the Spanish Empire.

title: From the Earth to the Moon
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs/ay201314/

title: Intermediate Japanese II
reviews: A massive jump in difficulty and workload from 101/102/105.  It's still a very good language class but be prepared to spend most of your weekdays trying to keep up with the material.

Definitely take this class if you can. My experiences in second year Japanese were some of the best I have had at Princeton. I felt that my Japanese, particularly my speaking, improved immensely during second year, as the grammar structures and vocabulary covered are enough for  daily conversation, and provide the basis for further study of Japanese.
Definitely take this class. It will increase your Japanese skills a lot, and you will learn more about Japanese culture and history as well.
Definitely take this course.
I would recommend the course for those who want to continue with Japanese. It is very helpful and by taking the class you are basically good at conversational Japanese at the end.
If you do the work and put in the effort, you'll learn a lot. There's nothing else to say; it's an extremely valuable and well-taught course.
One of my favorite classes, difficult in amount of work that needs to be done, but the teachers are excellent and very good.
Take it if you're really interested in it. Know that if this class is not your main priority, you'll probably be dedicating more time than you think.
Very good course. Tobira is an excellent book with very interesting readings. I assume you'd take it if you took JPN 105 and have space in your schedule.
prereqs: JPN 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: The course aims at a thorough mastery of modern colloquial Japanese by consistent review and reinforcement of major grammatical points covered in JPN 101, 102, and 105. It is also intended to give students advanced vocabulary and expressions through aural-oral drills, readings, and written exercises. Emphasis will increasingly be on reading, but oral work will still comprise fundamental aspect of the course.

title: Research Seminar in Cognitive Psychology
descrip: Current research and issues in sensation, perception, and cognition. Ongoing research by seminar participants, research methodology, and current issues in the literature will be discussed.

title: Agriculture and Food Security
reviews: Definitely recommend it. Dr. Zerba is a great professors.
Dr. Z is great, a little disorganized, but she is a wonderful person.
Easy and interesting. I would recommend it for anyone who doesn't want a big workload but wants to learn.
I would recommend this course for someone interested in the subject matter but who does not already have a lot of knowledge on the topics.

Take this course! You will become much more aware of some of the crucial issues facing the world today in agriculture and the material will make you rethink how you view and consume food. Dr. Z helps make the course fun and exciting.
The topic is interesting, but Zerba is too disorganized to effectively teach it.
descrip: This course provides an understanding of the complex and challenging public health issue of food security in a world where one billion people are under-nourished, while another billion are overweight. Topics explore the connections among diet, the current food and food animal production systems, the environment and public health, considering factors such as economics, population and equity. Lectures, discussions and case studies will examine these complex relationships and alternative approaches to achieving both local and global food security and the important role public health can play.

title: Topics in Labor Economics
descrip: The course surveys both the theoretical literature and the relevant empirical methods and results in selected current research topics in labor economics.

title: Freaks, Geeks, and Bullies
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: High-Tech Entrepreneurship
reviews: Absolutely take it. Best course I took at Princeton.
Absolutely take this course! It was one of the best classes I took at Princeton, and I learned way more than I ever expected to
An excellent course if you are interested in the topic of entrepreneurship. Do not take casually as the midterm and final projects are a hefty chunk of work.

Excellent class, the material may seem a little soft at times but the frameworks Kuenne uses are actually industry standard among entrepreneurs.  Make sure you are aggressive in your hand-raising to make comments - if you hesitate, someone else will beat you to it, and they will get credit for it for the purposes of grading
Gives you an outlook into the practical world, so I'd recommend it.
Great class, I recommend it for everyone.
Highly recommend taking it regardless of what major you are.

I would highly recommend this course if a student is looking to get exposed to entrepreneurship or if they wish to dive into the deeper details of entrepreneurship. There is enough information in this course to satisfy everyone interested in entrepreneurship.

I would strongly recommend taking this course, it easily is one of the best I've taken at Princeton. I would be prepared to work hard and think about the readings a lot before class so that you can provide insightful comments.

If you're at all interested in entrepreneurship or how young companies grow and shift, this course is fantastic. Probably one of the most relevant courses for my career that I'll take at Princeton, and one of the most enjoyable ones. I always looked forward to class. It's very heavily discussion-based, and participation is a large amount of the grade, so be prepared to do all of the readings (though they're usually very short) and to think about them carefully.

Really great class for anyone interested in entrepreneurship or going to business school. Very well structured. The midterm and final assignments are actually fun to do, which I don't think I've ever said about any other class. The one down side is that a lot of the grade comes from participation, which makes for people trying to speak at all times. They try to correct for this by also grading the quality of your comments so it isn't as bad as other classes. Overall, definitely recommend it.
Really interesting class
Spend the time to prep the cases beforehand with other students. You'll get more out of the discussions!
Strongly recommend taking
TAKE THIS COURSE!! I cannot recommend it highly enough. It's incredibly engaging and you learn so much. Professor Kuenne is fantastic and the case studies are really interesting.
Take it! enjoy the class, and let it change your attitude and outlook.
Take this course. You will learn about venture capital, growing a business, and stuff that everyone should know. Best class at Princeton and on top of that Kuenne is the man.

This course is a great introduction to business school and case-based analysis. Combine that with Prof. Kuenne's organized and clear lectures and 60 Princeton students, at least 30 of whom genuinely know what they are saying, and it becomes hard not to strongly recommend it! On second thoughts, I could take it again just for the quality of the guest lectures.

This course is incredible. Professor Kuenne is an awesome lecturer, discussion facilitator, and is very open to talking to everyone 1-on-1 outside of class, and is incredibly helpful. If you want to go into any kind of business or industry related career, you should take this course. The Harvard Business School cases you read are excellent resources themselves, and discussing them in class brings out even more of their value. Also, the midterm and final assignments really help you get a feel for what goes on inside a startup.
This is a must-take class.
This is an amazing course.  Professor Kuenne is an amazing lecturer with incredible experience.  If you have to chance to take this course during your time at Princeton definitely do.

This is an amazing course. Realize that class participation is 1/3 of your grade, which means that you need to come prepared to speak, having done the reading, every day to class. Start the projects early because you're going to need to rely on contacting people working in the real world, who may have unpredictable schedules that don't work well with yours.
Would recommend to anyone interested in the topic. Do not be intimidated by the 30% participation grade.
Yes, especially if you are starting a venture.
take it!
prereqs: Enrollment for the course is by written application. Applications are available online: http://commons.princeton.edu/kellercenter/2013/11/high-tech-entrepreneurship-course-application-open.html All applications must be completed and returned by November 26, 2013..
descrip: This hands-on course introduces students to analysis and actions required to launch and commercialize a tech company, through the use of Harvard Business School cases, visits from entrepreneurs, and two "field assignments". You will learn conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques for evaluating technologies, markets, and commercialization strategies. Additionally, you will learn how to attract and motivate the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners and venture capital), prepare business plans, structure relationships, refine product-market fit, and create and grow enterprise value.

title: Financial Risk Management
prereqs: ORF 245, ORF 335 or ECO 465 (concurrent enrollment okay) or instructor's permission required.
descrip: This course covers the basic concepts of modeling, measuring and managing financial risks. Topics include portfolio optimization (mean variance approach and expected utility), interest rate risk, pricing and hedging in incomplete markets, indifference pricing, risk measures, systemic risk.

title: Arts and Cultural Policy in Contemporary Cuba
reviews: This course won't be offered for y'all. Sorry!
descrip: This course will address the creation, promotion and consumption of art and culture in Cuba and will analyze the policy framework within which this takes place. It will examine the goals of the revolutionary government with respect to literacy and cultural democracy and will review how these objectives have been realized through changing circumstances since 1959. It will ask how cultural policy relates to diversity, emigration, tourism, the preservation of heritage, and the fraught histories of imperialism and nationalism.

title: Topics in Recent and Contemporary Philosophy - Recent Feminist Philosophical Work
descrip: Feminist philosophy began to be developed in the late 1970s and is now recognized in the profession as one of the sub-disciplines of philosophy. This course is designed to familiarize you with some of the key issues and recent literature in feminist philosophy. Our focus is on recent feminist work in metaphysics, philosophy of language, epistemology, and ethics.

title: Ancient Greco-Roman Medicine: From Hippocrates to Galen
reviews: If you're on the fence about signing up for the class, take it.
Take it! It's a great course and you'll learn a lot. Do the readings early and take time to enjoy them and appreciate the context.
Take this course. It's lots of fun, and if you're at all interested in ancient philosophy, their ideas on the body are fascinating.
descrip: This course is for undergraduates from all backgrounds with an interest in ancient Greco-Roman medicine and the historical roots of contemporary biomedicine. We will examine how a medical tradition forms around the body as an object of knowledge and therapy, paying close attention to socio-historical context. We also explore issues that remain relevant to medicine, such as the construction of scientific authority, pain and knowledge, error and chance in medicine, narrative and disease, the "naturalization" of cultural categories, the privileging of anatomy, and body-mind interaction. Reading from primary and secondary sources in translation.

title: French Literature: Approaches to the Language of Literary Texts
reviews: Do all of the readings so you can participate in discussion!
It is a good class to practice writing and reading at a higher level.

This is a great class to take for a general overview of French literature. Professor Chenoweth is a great professor and makes the class interesting and enjoyable. There are only four 3-page essays and a presentation, so the workload is not too bad.
This is a great course if you want to improve your writing and think better analytically.
prereqs: FRE 107 or FRE 108 or Permission of Instructor. Course conducted entirely in French..
descrip: This course is meant to introduce students to great works of French literature from a range of historical periods and to provide them with methods for literary interpretation through close reading of these texts. The course syllabus is organized around common themes and generic categories. This course is invaluable preparation for more advanced and specialized 300-level literature courses. Classroom discussion and free exchange encouraged.

title: Topics in Cinema and Culture - Latin American Film - Poetics and Politics of the Third World
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher, or instructor's permission.
descrip: An exploration of a series of critically acclaimed contemporary Latin American films, accompanied by readings that provide a theoretical and historical framework for its analysis. Topics to be discussed, among others: subalternity and the Third World; sexual and racial politics; postcolonial poetics; genocide; cultural hybridism and mestizaje; dictatorship and populism; biopolitical fantasies.

title: Topics in Comparative, Regional and Political Sociology (Half-Term) - The Constitutional Law of the Welfare State
descrip: This seminar discusses the development of the German and European constitutional framework of welfare politics from the mid 19th century until the present to mirror parallel and divergent developments in U.S. constitutional law. The discussion focuses upon two key themes. The first explores the constitutional development of the welfare state and social policy. The second explores the foundations of the paradigm of "social rights".

title: Cell and Developmental Biology
reviews: Do not take this course for fun. Memorize everything on the powerpoints. It was interesting, but it was very tough.

Do the readings from the book - it is helpful. Try to learn the material in class and then go over it because there are a lot of minute details that you can forget. It requires time and effort but I think it is a good class overall.
Don't take this unless you have to. If you're a MOL major,just get a good study group and keep up with the memorization.
Get ready.
Good Luck. Buy the book or use the bookshelf on pubmed, which is far superior to buying the book. Seriously, keep up with the material as much as you can.
I think this is a well taught class and I would recommend it, even to someone who doesn't have to take it.
I wouldn't classify it as a fun class, but you do learn a lot and if cell developmental biology is what you are interested in then go for it!
If you are a graduate student, definitely take pass/fail.

If you don't have to take this course and hate memorization and/or absorbing text books, this class probably isn't for you. However, if you're comfortable with extremely fast paced classes, the information you get from this class is very interesting.
If you're interested in the subject, great class to take.  Not easy, but very doable to do well if you put in the hard work and time!
If your MOL you have no choice. Otherwise don't take it. Many of the MOL majors will never most of the material, and it is more stress than it is worth to cover an upper level MOL requirement.
It's an incredible amount of work, but you will learn so much about cell development and just how to think about molecular biology.
It's not nearly as much memorization as people say. If you are really interested in development, then this class is awesome! I wasn't even in the MOL department and I found it fascinating. :)

Not as bad a course as I expected. There is a lot to memorize, but no more than Biochem requires. Be sure to understand the concepts, because eventually they'll repeat themselves in different organisms and mechanisms.
One of my all time favorite courses that I have taken at Princeton.
Take it! The class is great if you want to just learn about cells!

Take it. You're probably taking it because you have to anyway. But come in open minded and leave all the comments about how "cell dev is the worst class ever. Cell dev is the hardest MOL departmental ever" at the door and really try to engage with the material during lecture and precept. Be prepared to work hard, and start the psets early. Since they're all experiment-based, it helps to work with a group.

The first half of the course covers cell biology (including the cytoskeleton, vesicle trafficking, movement, and the cell cycle), and the second half is all about embryo development.  Lectures are quite engaging, with quick-partner-discussion i-clicker questions sprinkled throughout (in addition to three individual graded ones beforehand).  There is a lot of material to memorize, but the 10 problem sets and exams also test you on "thinking like a scientist"--that is, interpreting experimental data and designing new experiments to test hypotheses. I feel like that is effective in developing skills that extend beyond memorizing things specific to this course.
The material in this class is interesting but the class structured so that you are punished if you aren't CONSTANTLY on top of everything you learn. Don't take it with other high stress classes.
The most interesting Mol requirement by far for me, and relatively easy.
The professors and preceptors are very nice and helpful. However, the material is very difficult to digest all at once. It's a lot of information.

There is a strong bias against students who are members of eating clubs.  While it didn't seem to affect grades directly, professors and preceptors were definitely more willing to answer questions for students who were independent.
This class takes a lot of work. It's well taught, but try to study as you go through the semester rather than just at the end.

This is a great course. It's difficult, especially as a sophomore, and very demanding. But the course is very well structured and I left with a very good understanding of the material, such that I feel comfortable reading about almost all molecular biology research, understanding what was done and thinking critically about it.
Unless you HAVE to take it for MOL or med school, do NOT take this course Too much work, memorization and pain for a STN.
You have to take it, so just get ready.
You'll learn a lot in this course that will help you with independent work; not as time consuming as genetics problem sets!
take if have to (pre-meds...)
take it! you're required but actually its not something to dread. enjoy it!
prereqs: MOL 342 or MOL 345 is required..
descrip: The mechanisms that underlie development of multicellular organisms, from C. elegans to humans, will be examined using biochemical, genetic and cell biological approaches. The course will investigate the roles that gene regulation, cell-cell communication, cell adhesion, cell motility, cell death, signal transduction and intracellular trafficking play in the commitment, differentiation and assembly of cells into specialized tissues.

title: The Environment Can Be Funny
reviews: Didn't learn much about the environment. The class started out strong in terms of talking about theory of what comedy was, and what we define as "natural" but later in the class lost focus. The final and group projects were certainly more interesting than writing papers/what you would get out of a typical class.
I doubt this course will be offered again, but if it is I would suggest either PDF'ing it or not taking it at all, unless you're fine with not being able to take clear steps to improve your work.
If you are truly interested in the environment, and don't mind the often difficult and sometimes ugly dissection of humor: GO FOR IT!
It's not worth it.
Take something else. It's not much work but it's not worth it.
This course was only offered once by a visiting professor. If you are reading this evaluation for some odd reason, you are one curious kitten my friend.
descrip: Why isn't it?--and what if it were? While we'll examine the first question (why does environmentalism tend to be so pious and self-serious?), this course will focus on the second, and on the creation of original work. How might we deploy the powers of humor to persuade, to cajole, to break down defenses--but also to expose hypocrisy and to challenge our own assumptions? Students will put their own powers of comedy to work-in op-eds, cartoons, skits-to address climate change, water pollution, environmental justice, and other critical issues

title: The Physical Basis of Human Disease
reviews: A decent course if you like physiology and pharmacology and want a class with little work. Couldn't help but chuckle at all the intense premeds who practically wrote up a thesis for every problem set when just a page or two could have earned full credit. Be smarter with your time, and do think of the AI's. Remember, they have to grade a stack of 80 of these at a time.
A solid class that you will learn a lot from, but it is not essential if you're pre-med.
Absolutely take this course if you are at all interested in the subject matter.
Be careful of the pre-meds.
Definitely take it, but start problem sets early!
Definitely take this course if you get a chance, whether or not you're a CBE major!
Do the problem sets diligently.

Great course! Workload is very reasonable (four problem sets, one final project) and you learn a lot of useful, relevant information. Professor Nelson is WONDERFUL -- very knowledgeable, good at explaining concepts, and always receptive to questions. Take it!
Great course. Lectures and material are interesting and it's not too much work.

I am honestly very conflicted about how to review this class. On the one hand, the workload is very low, the material is interesting, and Nelson provides pertinent reading material for those who are actually interested in delving deeper into a certain topic. As a second semester senior who took this class out of interest, I could choose how much or how little effort to put in, depending on what was being covered in class.
On the other hand, our class had ~80 students and was all lecture based. It would have been much better had there been only ~30 students and if it was discussion-based. Moreover, it is very difficult to get a good grade not because the class is hard, but because the grading for problem sets is rather arbitrary. It doesn't require you to use any knowledge from class, but rather requires you to be good at wikipedia searches and if you don't mention certain details, you will get points off. Now, this wouldn't be a problem if the averages on problem sets weren't ~90% and if problem sets didn't make up almost all your grade. The only other grade is a final project.
Overall, I know Nelson has worked hard to plan this course and she has done a great job of choosing which topics to include, but the class size needs to be smaller, grades need to be based more on class discussion, and grading of problem sets  needs to be less nitpicky.
I loved this course!!! Take it if you have any interest in medicine, disease, human physiology, etc.
I would recommend it! Very qualitative and not like a typical engineering class.
If she improves the format taking. Otherwise you'll just be writing down everything she says every lecture without being able to relax. Oh and 9am is such a bitch.
If you are a pre-med student, this course provides an excellent introduction to disease.
If you are interested in medicine and disease, get class to take! Learn a lot about the drug treatments and how they work within the body.
If you are looking for a lighter yet interesting course, this is definitely one to consider. Dr. Nelson is very well respected in her field.

If you don't like biology, don't take this class. If you do like biology, be warned that you won't be going in-depth into any diseases or physiology in this class. This is very much a "survey" class. If you are an engineer and want to do some math, this isn't the course to take--the only math we do are mass balances.

Go to office hours for the problem sets. That way, you'll get a sense of what the graders are looking for in your answers and not get any points taken off arbitrarily for not including a certain term.

If you have taken a bio class before and are interested in learning about various diseases, then you should take this class. The material is fascinating and is very current. In fact, there were a few times when Prof. Nelson presented articles that were published a few days before class. Really interesting course!
If you like diseases and like to read about their treatments, take this courrse.

If you want to know about the most important diseases in America (and, to a certain extent, the world) today, you should definitely take this class. We covered heart disease, cancer, diabetes, and tuberculosis, which each affects thousands to millions of individuals (or, you could argue, billions in the case of tuberculosis). This class is good if you want to come to the end of a class and feel like you've learned something worthwhile. Note: The problem sets are hard, so go to office hours to figure out the types of things they're looking for. Note II: You get to play with three different organs over the course of the semester (all from pigs): a pancreas, a pair of lungs, and a heart. It is really cool. Note III: The course project at the end of the semester is great because you can do it on whatever disease you want, so it really encourages you to get an in depth understanding of a disease that interests you.
So if you want to learn some very useful knowledge about diseases---but also about how the healthy body works---take this course! It is a great primer on the mechanisms of the body.
It is interesting and not too hard. The goal of the class seems to be learning actual material that matters, not nit-picky stuff.
It was supposed to be an easy senior class, but the competitiveness and need for absolute perfection in all graded work ruined the class for me.
Not a lot of day-to-day work, but the project requires quite some time and the 4 problem sets can too because there are a lot of premeds.
Not too hard of a course load, very interesting class on learning about diseases and treatments. Highly recommended for anybody remotely interested in diseases.
Professor Nelson is really nice and an awesome lecturer! The material is really interesting, probably the most interesting CBE class I've taken yet.
Professor Nelson is really nice and if you put in the time, you can learn a lot from her.  Ask lots of questions!
Super interesting class! Not a terrible amount of work, but be sure to spend a lot of time on the problem sets
Take it if you like more qualitative stuff
Take it if you want an overview of new technologies in health care.
Take it if you're interested in the subject. Not a lot of work but I feel that I really learned a lot in the lectures.
Take it! If you are at all interested in human pathophysiology, this is your class. You get to dabble in a broad area of diseases. Great biology class for CBEs.
Take it! It incorporates anatomy, molecular biology, math, and chemistry - a very comprehensive course.

Take it! Nelson is a great professor, and the course material is interesting. It's a fairly broad overview of different diseases, their biological bases, and various treatments for them. Not too much work - 4 psets, final paper (and proposal for that paper) on an emerging treatment of your choice. Go to lecture because that's the only way you get notes that can help you do the psets. The grading sometimes feels a bit picky and arbitrary, and there are a good number of overachieving premeds in the class, but you can get a decent grade.
Take it! Professor Nelson is a superb lecturer. If you find medicine interesting, you'll enjoy the material in this class. Plus, there are organ demos!
Take it. Great course. Super chill.
Take the course if you're not looking to do much work. The problem sets are really vague and can sometimes be very frustrating. The course doesn't involve much engineering at all.
Take this class if you have the least bit of interest in bio stuff. It's really interesting.
Take this course!  One of the best courses available at Princeton!
Take this course, you learn a lot about diseases and overall health.

This class is relatively low work for a CBE class. Don't expect it to have a huge amount of math/engineering content - for the most part it was a lot of random facts about a bunch of different diseases. Remember that problem sets are worth a huge percent of your grade and you therefore need to perform well on them to do well in the class, starting from the first problem set. 
Choose something you're really interested in for your final project and you'll get a lot out of it.

This class is very chill and easy. There are only 4 problem sets throughout the semester which are pretty doable. Lectures are not necessary for completing the problem sets most of the time. There is no final, so that is great. The final project is easy to do. However, you will not be learning much in this class, so do not take if you do not want to waste your time.
This course is amazing for anyone interested in medicine or research.  Professor Nelson is also an amazing teacher and I would take any course she taught.

This course is awesome. Do you like learning about diseases? Are you ok with some modeling (drawing boxes and thinking about what goes in and out?) Are you keen on emerging treatments and novel ideas on disease? Take this course, go to lecture, and go to office hours for the problem sets. It's worth it for anyone interested in human diseases!
This is a good upper level CBE course.
This is a pretty good class. Definitely not anything mind-blowing. I would highly encourage you to form a study group to cover the problem sets. Also. GOOGLE. Pubmed things, etc.
This was a really fascinating course. The final paper is a great way to learn about whatever disease you want to know more about!
Very, very useful knowledge, especially if you are premed or generally interested in human health. Gets you to think about the aims for designing novel treatments in the future.
You should be genuinely interested in this material to take this class, and really want to learn.
take it :)  just dont expect a ton of depth - but you will learn a whole wide breadth of really aweseom stuff
descrip: This course covers major diseases (cancer, diabetes, heart disease, infectious diseases), the physical changes that inflict morbidity and mortality, the design constraints for treatment, and emerging technologies that take into account these physical hurdles. Taking the perspective of the design constraints on the system (that is, the mass transport and biophysical limitations of the human body), we will survey recent results from the fields of drug delivery, gene therapy, tissue engineering, and nanotechnology.

title: Senior Project with Design
descrip: Similar to 440 with the principle difference that the team or group project must incorporate aspects and principles of design, whether for a system, product, vehicle, device, software, or apparatus. The year-long senior project with design may be used to satisfy a portion of the department's design requirement.

title: Seminar in Modernist Art and Theory - The World of Rauschenberg
descrip: Cotaught with curator Leah Dickerman, this seminar lays the groundwork for a major forthcoming exhibition of the art of Robert Rauschenberg at MoMA. Each week we address his work in conjunction with a key predecessor, peer, or institution, including Kurt Schwitters, Marcel Duchamp, Jasper Johns, Cy Twombly, John Cage, Merce Cunningham, Trisha Brown, Black Mountain College, Judson Church Dance, and Experiments in Art & Technology. Some seminars take place at MoMA.

title: Thesis Studio
prereqs: One course is required for all M.Arch. students. Completion of Pre-Thesis Workshops is required for entry into Thesis Studio..
descrip: The Master of Architecture Thesis is an independent design project on a theme selected by the student. The student begins with a thesis statement outlining an area of study or a problem that has consequences for contemporary architectural production. Marking the transition between the academic and professional worlds, the thesis project is an opportunity for each student to define an individual position with regard to a specific aspect of architectural practice. As an integral part of the design process, it is intended that the thesis project will incorporate research, programming and site definition.

title: Creativity, Innovation, and Design
reviews: Definitely take this course. It is by far my favorite class that I have taken here, mainly because it's different (in a good way) from a traditional course you might take here in so many ways. Lecture wasn't just the professor lecturing at you for an hour - it was a back and forth Q&A about the readings and student's opinions (pretty much like a precept actually). We didn't sit in chairs in lots of rows while the professor stood up, we sat around the professor (who also was also sitting) in a semi-circle. We had different kinds of chairs (regular chairs, floor, big cubes) and could place them wherever we wanted. We had whiteboards everywhere and fun pre-lecture creative warm-ups. Our labs were a good way for us to really explore our own novel, creative, funnily weird ideas, thought processes, and propose our own solutions to problems, and even though we all had the same basic task (for example, redesign [something]), the labs were about us doing the same thing differently, as opposed to say, a chemistry lab where the goal is for everyone to do the same thing and get the most accurate results. This class is the first to have a coffee dispenser in the room, and we also had small snacks, which are good side benefits. Take it, take it, take it.
I strongly recommend this course to students in the Engineering or Science related fields.
I would definitely recommend taking this class. It is the ONLY class at Princeton that will teach anything in the realm of design thinking.
I would recommend it if you are looking for a course that offers a nice alternative to the usual style of a Princeton course.

If you are interested in the design process in any way, shape, or form, then take this course. The material can be applied to any discipline. Every week, there is a "lab" where you work in an unconventional classroom and develop your skills. Beware, it is a lot of work (5 hours of class   reading and a journal every week), but it's a great break from the convergent thinking style of the rest of Princeton's courses. Open up your mind! Professor Lidow knows what he's talking about and is personally invested in each student.

If you're interested in design or creativity, especially improving your skills in them, take this class. It's very different from the typical Princeton class and it's a completely painless way to learn something that will be immensely important for you as an individual. Professor Lidow is a great person too and you'll enjoy learning from him.
It's different and pretty time consuming but very worthwhile

Take it. Take it. Take it. Not learnt as much about myself and about material taught in any other course before. Its a very 'un-Princeton' like course and everything is top notch - the lectures, the TAs, the labs, the classroom itself and obviously Professor Lidow.

This course is really unique.  I definitely recommend this to anyone who is interested in learning how to be creative, especially in the startup world.  Prof. Lidow cares so much about this course and helping all of his students.  This course is definitely not an easy course.  You really have to put in time and energy, but I think that once you do that, it will be very worthwhile.  I also think that now that Lidow has taught this course once, it will be more polished.
Yes, take this class if you can. It is a lot of fun. Professor Lidow is great and so are the TAs. Lab takes a long time. Take it especially if creativity is something that you find daunting.
descrip: The class mission is to give students an understanding of the sources and processes associated with creativity, innovation, and design - three interdependent capabilities essential to our own well being, as well as to the well being of society. We will study the internal and external factors that relate to our own ability to create, innovate, and design. We will also understand the factors that impact a group's ability to act creatively, to innovate, and to produce practical and appealing designs. The class will consist of readings and case studies as well as individual and group projects.

title: Investigative Journalism - Private Interests vs. Public Policy
reviews: Be ready to work on an actual story -- this is not a passive course, where reading and listening will do.
Definitely consider taking it if it is offered again in the future.
Depending on the professor, can be an excellent way to explore the methods of critical thinking and hard work to build an investigative story.
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in journalism and who would like to meet highly qualified professionals in the field.

Investigative journalism is fascinating.  Would recommend anyone with even a passing interest in how social problems are researched  and exposed to take this course.  This one class on journalism really helped to add to how I approach research in world beyond Princeton academia, even though I come from a technical field.
Journalism courses are the best courses at Princeton.
TAKE THIS CLASS YOU WILL LOVE IT!
Take it, and put time into it.
Take it. Professor K is great. You learn a lot from the speakers.
Think hard about picking your investigative topic early on. The later it gets in the semester, the harder it is to pack in all of your interviews and get the kind of material that you want.

This is a course about how to be an investigative journalist. I was surprised and disappointed because I did not learn much about the history and societal effects of journalism. However, this is still a very good course. There were some fantastic guest speakers, the trip to the Times was great, and I really enjoyed one-on-one meetings with the professor. Our final project was to do an investigative story. The workload wasn't much along the way, but I was scrambling to find people to interview at the end. Don't procrastinate! Overall, I'd say to take it, but a lot obviously depends on who the professor is.
This is a great course! I learned a ton, and enjoyed it thoroughly.
prereqs: Enrollment by application - see course web address.
descrip: At a time when trust in public institutions is near historic lows, the ability to uncover and understand the unseen forces influencing democracy is more crucial than ever. With the help of guest speakers from business, journalism and the public sector -- as well as a field trip to an investigative newsroom -- this seminar will explore how various commercial, labor and special interest groups use their power to sway government decision-making. It will also teach students techniques to investigate and write about issues, and influence peddling, with depth and clarity.

title: Ceramic Sculpture
reviews: Ceramics is time-consuming, so be prepared to spend a lot of time in the studio outside of scheduled classes. It's a lot of fun though, and you can make some pretty cool things, so I definitely recommend it if you're willing to put in the effort!
Fun! Less time consuming than painting or printmaking, more time consuming than drawing, I'd say.
I would recommend taking it, thought it is probably more time consuming than the standard sculpture class.
It requires a lot of time!

My biggest piece of advice is to consider if you have the time available for this course.  There are roughly 6 hours of class every week, but you will most definitely have to come in outside of class many additional hours.  Also since ceramics isn't easily movable this means going to the actual studio.  Don't be afraid if you haven't worked with ceramics before because many people in the course haven't but Adam can help you learn as you go.  Finally be prepared to work incredibly hard, and push yourself artistically!
Not enough time to complete the time-intensive projects.
take this course. It will consume all your spare time, but if the idea of all your spare time being transmuted into pottery time is exciting for you, then take this course.
descrip: This course is course designed for students interested in learning the fundamentals of working with clay. A wide variety of hand building techniques will be taught, enabling students to make utilitarian vessels as well as sculptural forms. Students will learn about glazing and colored engobe application methods and how to operate electric and gas kilns. Studio work may be complemented by readings, field trips and slide presentations.

title: Shakespeare 450: Shakespeare and the Contemporary British Theater
reviews: Cadden's style of teaching probably isn't for everyone, but if you enjoy him, this was an excellent and thought-provoking course.

Professor Cadden is so knowledgeable about all things theater related that it is great to be in a seminar setting with him to ask questions. Don't be intimidated to talk to him or email outside of class, he is very sweet and has no idea that students might be afraid to approach such an established member of faculty! He is not always great at facilitating class discussion, and because he didn't draw the line about laptops, a good quarter of the class was always on Facebook or other unrelated sites during class, which was rather frustrating for someone who wanted to interact more with classmates and discuss the material.

Take it! Professor Cadden is brilliant and fabulously entertaining. Plus the spring break trip experience is unparalleled. Even if you're not a 'theater kid,' still take it! This is a very immersive course.
Take it! You won't regret a course with Cadden
Traveling was unbelievable, the class got off topic often, but it always went to an interesting and enlightening place.
go to london!
prereqs: Students who have taken or are taking the HUM sequence, are concentrating or planning to concentrate in English, and/or are pursuing the Certificates in Theater or Humanistic Studies are especially invited to apply..
descrip: In celebration of the 450th anniversary of Shakespeare's birth, this course will focus on how Shakespeare continues to shape the British theater--its institutions (the Royal Shakespeare Company, the National Theater, Shakespeare's Globe), its professions (especially acting, directing and playwriting), and its audiences. We'll attend productions in New York and the U.K. as well as track just how Shakespeare is being feted to investigate the ways in which Shakespeare's ghost continues to demand, "Remember me!" The final shape of the course will be determined once the theatrical season has been announced.

title: Feminist Media Studies /Media Representations of Feminism
reviews: If you enjoy doing independent work, I would definitely encourage you to take this course. It is an incredible opportunity to pursue something you are personally passionate about, explore it in-depth, and share it with the broader community.
Take this course if you like learning about the media and want to understand why women need to take a stand in society in order to have our voices heard and move toward creating an equal society.
descrip: Feminist media studies are a rich field of inquiry, while feminism is a recurring object of media fascination. Media stories of feminism circulate as authoritative. Feminist arguments often become public spectacles where the media leers at and dismisses feminist speech. These spectacularly public representations reduce the multiplicity of feminist positions and voices.

title: International Political Economy
descrip: An introduction to the subfield of international political economy, covering basic topics in the politics of both trade and finance.

title: Evolution and the Behavior of the Sexes
reviews: AA  This class is awesome and Blair is so chill.  Cara is also chill and both great.
Blair is young and awesome, so she will probably improve greatly next semester she teaches it. May be worth trying again.

Depending on the instructors, this course is particularly helpful in understanding the discipline of evolutionary biology around human behavior (especially with the stickier topic of sex/biological difference), and is a good primer for primatology or anthropology.
