I would definitely recommend taking this course if taught by Blair Roberts. It was very interesting and incorporated both up- to-date scientific studies and modern social issues. Exams were fair, emphasizing the most important aspects of the course, rather than focusing on picky and insignificant details. I took this senior spring, and it was by far my favorite EEB departmental.
Interesting STN and definitely a worthwhile perspective for GSS students

It might be taught differently in future semesters but this class was really. There was just a lot of work. But it was prodigiously interesting. Just don't take it just for an STN if you're not super interested/haven't taken an EEB class before.

It's actually pretty difficult. Blair likes to go through a LOT of material and expects a lot out of the exams. You'll have to know a lot of details and examples. Cara's a great preceptor, definitely attend her precepts and office hours -- she's good at explaining all of this.
The assignments can be somewhat tedious, but the material is extremely interesting and relevant. Overall, I think I learned a lot in this class that I can actually apply to real life issues.
The exams are hard and require a lot of detail. Pay attention and keep your notes organized!

This class is extremely interesting and a great STN for non-science majors, but keep in mind that it's npdf, there are a LOT of papers, and exams (especially the midterm) are very detail-oriented and difficult to study for. If you're willing to put in the work, take it. If you're not, don't.

This course covers really fascinating material and Blair is a great lecturer! The course is difficult - it requires quite a bit of paper writing and detailed knowledge of the material for the exams. However, since the material is so interesting, the workload does not feel like too much of a burden.
don't do it. not worth it as an STN. really boring. not actually about sex differences, mainly about memorizing monkey facts. worst class i've taken here.
don't take this unless you HAVE to, ie are an eeb major or gss certitication;
take
descrip: This course, designed to capitalize on diverse student backgrounds, will use principles of evolutionary biology and behavioral ecology to examine mating strategies and their effect on social systems. We will draw examples from vertebrates, with an emphasis on group-living mammals, particularly primates and elephants. Topics will include mate selection, ontogeny of sex differences, sexual diversity, social bonds and cooperation, and intersexual conflict.

title: The Constitution of the Family & Individual Liberty, 1867-1937
descrip: This course explores shifts in the basis of American equality and liberty from sovereign family and corporate franchises, to individual citizenship. Interdisciplinary readings address: household government and corporate society in the nineteenth-century polity; Reconstruction's disruption of this social order and political economy; and its reconstitution by intellectuals, social networks, and constitutional amendments and laws for and against woman suffrage, labor regulation, the social welfare state, public health and education, the income tax, and Prohibition.

title: Complex Analysis with Applications
reviews: Absolutely not. If you want rigor, take the Stein sequence, if you want applications then take MAE 306. MAT 204 did a much better job of straddling this line.

Aizenman is not a great lecturer because he doesn't seem to prepare for his lectures. The last 3 weeks were very confusing because we just did random topics in complex analysis (I think that Aizenman ran out of material, so just started covering whatever he felt like). From a physics major's prospective, this class struck a good balance between applications, rigor, and computation.
Complex analysis is a beautiful subject, and its applications are beautiful too.
Dont take it unless you have to.

For someone who is interested in a career in physics, I don't think this course was not heavy enough on applications. Given the choice between this course and an interesting physics course, I would not choose this unless you really enjoy math classes.
I definitely recommend this course as a natural choice for a math departmental.
If you are interested in both the theory and applications of complex analysis, this is the course for you!

The material covered in complex analysis is extremely interesting, and the methods it explores will be useful in many scientific applications. Also, complex analysis is one of the most beautiful subjects in mathematics and one that applications-minded people can greatly appreciate.

However, if at all possible, do not take this course (or any other) with Prof. Aizenman. He is completely disorganized and his classes suffer heavily because of it.

This course is much harder than MAE 306 and much easier than the course for math majors, but I felt as though I did not learn very much and would have preferred either a more applied or more theoretical alternative.

Uhh..umm..uhh I wouldn't really recommend this class as a math major.  Professor Aizenman is a nice guy but the second half of the class is weird and not well planned out.  He also wears the same sweater everyday, which is kind of funny.  There isn't much complex "analysis" going on, and the applications are very strange.  That being said, the course is not much work and pretty easy if you are comfortable with the prerequisites.
prereqs: MAT 201 and MAT 202 or equivalent..
descrip: The theory of functions of one complex variable, covering power series expansions, residues, contour integration, and conformal mapping. Although the theory will be given adequate treatment, the emphasis of this course is the use of complex analysis as a tool for solving problems.

title: Advanced French Language and Style
reviews: Do all the grammar assignments without relying on the answers the first time to see where you currently stand in terms of grammatical knowledge.
Great course overall!
Great for practicing your French so you don't lose it. Not too much work.

I did improve my language skills, but I don't think that the course uses your time the most effectively, as many of the assignments are tedious. I would recommend skipping this course. Instead, buy the grammar and vocab books yourself and study them on your own, and take a 300-level literature class. That way, you avoid the bad parts of 307 (the grammar and vocab) and get the fun parts (the creative parts and feedback on your writing).
It's a good course to take for learning about the practical aspects of the French language (CV's, cover letters, register, etc.)
Make sure you like the professor, and spend more time on the essays than on the grammar exercises.
Take it! Great for fulfilling certificate requirements and not too much work, but a lot of learning.
Take it! Professor Patterson is wonderful!
This class is pretty easy and has a bunch of little assignments that don't take too much time. That said, it can get repetitive and a bit boring after a while.

This course will give an overview of the French language, its registers and styles of literature and speaking. The professor was engaged and appealing, however, I did not feel that it significantly improved my French.
Yes, definitely take this course.
prereqs: A 200-level French course or permission of instructor..
descrip: To improve spoken and written French through attentive study of French grammatical and syntactic structures and rhetorical styles, with a variety of creative, analytical and practical writing exercises, and reading of literary and non-literary texts.

title: Economic Analysis of Development (Advanced)
descrip: Considers theories and evidence to explain processes of economic development; examines theories of economic growth, and the two-way links between development and poverty, inequality, social institutions, and the family. Policy debates on education, health, and social policy, and governmental and international aid are also covered.

title: Computer Networks
reviews: Anyone who is interested in anything related to the internet, you HAVE to take this course.  It is very interesting and Freedman is a good lecturer.  Be careful with the second assignment because it is way harder than all of the others.
Assignments are time consuming and tests are hard, but extremely useful material
Be ready to invest a good chunk of time into the assignments. Make sure you start as early as possible, because the specifications take a little time to digest.

Course covers a LOT of material, and fast. Not sure if I was at a disadvantage *not* having taken OS. Assignments are hard - start early! Some of the content was pretty interesting but not always well explained. Freedman is an okay lecturer.
Don't take this for a COS certificate unless you're willing to put a lot of time into it. It really is quite a hard course!
Every CS major has to take this class! You're a code monkey if you haven't taken networks and OS, so take that first then take this one.
Great course on the fundamentals of networking. I learn the most from the lectures so worth attending to audit if you do not have the time to commit to the assignments
I liked the course. It could be a bit more rigorous, but overall, a great first introduction to networking.
I recommend this course to whoever are interested in networks.
Interesting content, taught in a style similar to 217. Take it while you're a sophomore and still care about taking classes.
It's okay start early on assignments and you will be fine

It's what you've heard it is. Easier than OS, harder than 217, and all about networks. Maybe it's just me, but I walked out with very little idea how the internet works, and knowledge about every last detail of TCP. Take that as you will.
Its a bit dry if you are not interested in networks. It is very heavy on the applications side of networks and the assignments don't keep pace with the material

Make sure you have good C programming fundamentals. If you came out of OS, this course shouldn't be too hard. If you want to do well, be ready to study lots of technical details about how different protocols work.
Plan to devote a LOT of time to the course, both in the assignments and just understanding the material covered in lecture.
Start early on assignments and take it if you have any interest in networking and how the internet actually runs
Start the assignments early, and talk to the preceptors to get help.

Start the assignments well in advance.  They are not trivial.  Router is probably the hardest, and TCP is tricky to get right.  This course will take you from knowing nothing about networks to understanding most of the stack if you give it the time.
Take it if you like networks.
Take it if you need a Systems course that isn't as much of a time-commitment as OS is.
Take it if you want to know how networks work I guess.
Take it if you want to know how the Internet works.

Take it if you want to understand how the Internet works, though Freedman covers a lot of material really quickly so you'll have to put in a significant amount of time going over everything on your own. Router and TCP assignments can be hard if you haven't already taken OS, start the assignments early.
Take it!
Take it. Be prepared for a lot of self study.
Take the class if you want to understand networks.

Take this class over OS, if you're deciding how to fulfill your systems requirement.  The OS assignments are ridiculously long, while these ones were much more reasonable.  Plus, networks are an active area of research, and if you go into industry, there's a good chance you'll be expected to know a lot of the stuff that you learn in Networks.  So I'd advise every CS major to take Networks.
Take this course for systems!
Take this course if you really like networks and want to build something, but recognize that you could maybe learn a lot of this on your own.

This class takes a lot of time. Quantifying things in all-nighters, assignments 2 and 3 take at least 3. Don't take this class if you're not good at making sense of things on your own, and especially don't take this if you have trouble interpreting directions. The directions on assignments ... there aren't really directions. Just a bunch of words that need to be made sense of. You can do it, dude! The exams...ew. Lecture is essential if you don't read. Obviously.
Valuable because it teaches you about networking, which is something you might actually want or need to know as a tech person, but the exams are horrific.

Very valuable course for understanding how ubiquitous computer networks function. Very demanding assignments and the lectures are just fair (Freedman won't be teaching it next year though, so they might be better for you).
prereqs: COS 217.
descrip: This course studies computer networks and the services built on top of them. Topics include packet-switch and multi-access networks, routing and flow control, congestion control and quality-of-service, Internet protocols (IP, TCP, BGP), the client-server model and RPC, elements of distributed systems (naming, security, caching) and the design of network services (multimedia, file and web servers).

title: Topics in Theory and Practice of Anthropology: (Half-Term) - Science and Technology Studies and Race
descrip: Scientific and social scientific research on health and social disparities continue to reproduce the notion that racial differences are real through a process described as racial recursion. This class explores how research methods contribute to the reproduction of essentialist or behaviorist theories of race and difference. The texts used for this class focus on new research in epigenetics, neuroscience, and economics in order for students to be able to interrogate culture of poverty theories and the use of race as a proxy for DNA and human potential.

title: The United States Since 1974
reviews: A word of caution: don't take this class if you are a conservative. The professors have a liberal predisposition (but doesn't life, after all?)

ABSOLUTELY MUST TAKE!!! You'd be doing a great disservice to yourself otherwise.  Fantastic lectures, each is an experience in and of itself - don't miss a single one!  Precepts and readings are also superb.  This is one of the best classes at Princeton ever!!!
Absolutely take it. You will not regret it.
Anybody who has a solid understanding of recent events has no real reason to take the course, but it may prove useful for people who lack any background in current events.
Attend lectures, as these are really necessary to get a baseline knowledge. You should do all of the readings because they really give you a flavor of the period beyond general facts.
Bad precepts. Lectures are just okay

DEFINITELY TAKE THIS COURSE! for anyone interested in why American politics are the way they are today, this course is a must-take! my US history course in high school pretty much ended where this course began, so I'm happy to have a better understanding of contemporary America. the lectures are absolutely fascinating, and the precepts are pretty great too. reading is about 200 pages a week. readings are interesting and I did them all at the start of the semester, but soon started slacking off. you don't have to do all of it, but at least do some of the reading because it will make precepts far more enjoyable. also, precept participation counts toward your final grade, so yeah... you need to be prepared to talk. but overall, take it. it's great!
Definitely take it, and don't be afraid to talk and ask questions in precept.
Definitely take it, do the readings.
Definitely take this class if you are a history major or not. I know a lot more about current issues because of this class.
Definitely take this class no matter what your major is. It is material that every American should have knowledge of. Excellent class.
Definitely take this class!
Definitely take this course because overall it was one of my best at Princeton. It will help you understand the politics and what is going on in America today.
Definitely take!
Do all of the readings, attend all lectures, and seek out your preceptor outside of class

Do all the readings and go to lecture because the material is really interesting. I would definitely recommend this class not only for those interested in history but for those interested in politics as well.
Don't fall behind on the readings.
Everyone at the school should take this class to understand why the US is the way it is today. Extremely interesting.

Go to all the lectures and definitely write good notes! They don't let you take in laptops but for a good reason; if you went to lectures and weren't paying full attention you'd be missing out on a lot.
Good lecture, but in this course, your preceptor essentially determines your entire grade - he grades exams, paper, and precept - if you end up with a harsh grader, nothing you can really do

HISTORY MAJORS: AVOID THIS COURSE AT ALL COSTS. The course offers no room whatsoever for original thinking, the paper and exams do not test the material well at all, and you learn almost nothing in the course. This is "history for the masses," and you should only take it if you've been living under a rock for the past twenty years. Friends who are not history majors may love the class because they're completely ignorant about current events, but if you ever read the news, DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE.

HISTORY MAJORS: do not take this class. it's frustrating and almost entirely memorization-based. the focus on regurgitation over analysis is really frustrating for someone accustomed to how most other departmentals work
I have no qualms about the class, there is nothing negative to say. It's a pretty good class. Lecture/sermons take some getting used to.
I would advise them to take the class and do the readings!

I would tell students to go to lecture and take very thorough notes. It is also very important to be able to explain the course of the history and the concepts in the form of a story. This makes it as likely as possible that you will know a lot of information on the exams.
If you are interested in US history, and really everyone should know about this area, take the course! It's not too much work and the lectures are really interesting and enjoyable.

If you don't like history, don't expect this course to change your mind. Precepts are not very good, and there is quite a bit of reading each week (200  pages). Lectures are interesting but the professors speak very quickly, and you are not allowed to use laptops to take notes. Not an easy PDF. Honestly, the course should be renamed "American Politics since 1974", so if you aren't interested in that then I would search elsewhere for an easier HA.

If you have the chance to take this course, take it. Don't question the decision, just take it. One of the best courses I've taken here. Kruse and Zelizer are fantastic lecturers and I, honestly, learned so much listening to them each week (and not the everything-goes-away-after-the-test kind of learning, but the legitimate I'm-better-and-smarter-for-having-taken-this-class type of learning). I can almost guarantee you'll feel the same way after you take the class. And if you don't, at least you'll have enjoyed the songs played at the beginning and end of every lecture, as well as the multiple videos Kruse and Zelizer integrate. You really can't beat a class where everything feels as relevant and important (i.e. of actual value) as it does in this class.
TL;DR: TAKE THIS CLASS. You won't regret it.
Incredibly interesting material, great readings, and thought provoking precepts. Definitely recommend.
Interesting and relevant
Keep up with readings and definitely go to lecture!
Kruse and Zelizer complement each other well and the lectures are fantastic. The reading list is also interesting and engaging. Exams and papers were unimaginative but not very hard.
Makes sure to keep on top of the readings.
Material was interesting, but professors were pretty liberal.
Meh, i'd take 1920's to 1970's first. unless you really really like that class, i wouldn't bother with this
Read everything.
Recommend if you have time to internalize what you learned. I didn't so I didn't gain as much as I could've.
Recommend it highly.
TAK IT!!!
TAKE IT
TAKE IT. Even pdfing the course, I got so much out of it--it's so relevant to our lives. No matter your major it's super interesting.
TAKE THIS CLASS! It's amazing.  Lots of reading though, but worth it.
TAKE this course. Not easy but you learn a lot and the lecturers are interesting.
Take it
Take it but make this the class you really try hard in
Take it!
Take it!  Though the exams focus mostly on lecture material, precepts are all about the readings, so do the readings to be able to participate in precept.

Take it! This is a fantastic course and the professors are exceptional.  They are incredibly passionate about history and make lectures fun and engaging with short clips, songs, and media--highly recommended
Take it. Period.
Take the class.
Take this
Take this class! The lectures are awesome.
Take this class.
Take this course if you like learning about US history and make sure to keep up with the readings.
Take this course if you're interested in getting a better idea of current politics, culture etc.
Take this course if you're interested in the topic. It's well-taught.
Take this course! Even if history isn't your strong suit, the lectures are very engaging and everyone should take a US history course on recent times.
Take this course! Kruse and Zelizer are both awesome! It's a manageable work load.
Take this course! The content is both relevant and interesting. The lectures are excellent. One of my favorite courses at Princeton.

The lectures are very good and Zelizer and Kruse tag-team it nicely. Zelizer's are more video, picture based and Kruse have fewer visual aides but longer clips when they come. I liked it better than 1920-1974 for what its worth. If this class sounds interesting to you, it probably will be, but it will not keep you awake in lecture if you are tired or in a food coma. For precept, there is only one choice: Dov. Don't even think about getting anyone else. Not even a professor. No. Dov. Wake up early if you have to. The readings were generally very interesting (I think 7 good ones and 3 not so good ones). The midterm and final are IDs and also essay prompts that are given to you in advance and are reasonable. The paper that they added this year looks pretty innocuous, just your normal 5-pg paper. Great class, but Dov is the best.

The material is very interesting and consists of things not commonly covered in high school American history classes. Lectures are very fun; Professors Zelizer and Kruse are great and funny and they bring in a lot of video material to make lectures more interesting. However, I think since it's such a large class, it's hard to do well grade-wise.
This class is interesting and is good for a PDF class.  There is a lot of reading if you are taking it for a grade.
This class is interesting, not super challenging, and the readings aren't necessary to read thoroughly.

This class is mostly political history, so if you find that interesting I would definitely take it. It's a really important class that provides a deep understanding of the events that have lead us to the current state of politics. I enjoyed it and if you like American politics   history, you probably will too!
This class is so interesting and really helps you understand recent and current events, how complicated they are, and how we can analyze them as historians.
This class provides an informative and engaging overview of the last four decades in American history. Take it if you can!

This is a great course! Especially if you need a HIS distribution, this course goes over the latter half of 20th century history beginning with Nixon and ending with Obama's 2012 campaign. It does a great job of not only presenting the information, but weaving it into a narrative that can be seen through all of the decades, allowing you to understand what actually happened. It focuses heavily on the conservative political shift across America, and if you want to know more about what happened during these decades, this class is a must take. Zelizer and Kruse are amazing lecturers, and the course is designed very well such that you get a lot of information out of it without it feeling like it's too hard of a course. All of the readings (besides the first one) are really interesting books that I'd want to read on the side. Overall, take this course--it'll definitely be worth your time!
This is a great course!! Kruse and Zelizar taught it together and killed it
This is a great pdf class.
Very interesting content. Both professors are great, engaging lecturers. Exams are fair and if you study it is easy to do well. Definitely recommend!
Yes, very interesting
You pretty much have to know what went on in the US in the last 40 years, so for that reason take it. You definitely don't need to do all the reading each week though, there's way too much of it.
get Dov
great class and even better preceptor. really engaging and well informed on the subject
interesting class, I prefer Zelizer to Kruse.  Kruse likes to hear himself talk.
its hard
read the books and don't miss a single lecture, for your own benefit
take it for sure
take it!
take the course
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: The history of contemporary America, with particular attention to political, social and technological changes. Topics will include the rise of a new conservative movement and the reconstitution of liberalism, the end of the divisive Cold War era and the rise of an interconneted global economy, revolutionary technological innovation coupled with growing economic inequality, a massive influx of immigrants coupled with a revival of isolationism and nativism, a revolution in homosexual rights and gender equality coupled with the rise of a new ethos of "family values."

title: Metals in Biology
reviews: I would definitely take this course if you would like to learn about how inorganic and organic chemistry come together in biological systems, which is all very interesting.
If there was someone in my situation next year I would tell them to take the class.
If you're interested in learning more about these transition metals in biology (and they do have a lot of functions) this is a great course. You'll learn a lot in a fairly relaxed class.
Take this class if you are interested in biochemistry or inorganic chemistry.  Its interesting and straight forward.
Take this course if you are really interested in the bioinorganic chemistry.
This is a great course for anyone who has some basic knowledge of inorganic and biochemistry.

This is an exciting and intriguing course. You will get to learn about concepts at the interface of inorganic chemistry and biochemistry: I thought understanding metalloenzymes from these different perspectives was intriguing. The material will let you make connections between different subfields of chemistry. Be ready to learn to think critically about the literature. Such an experience is both inherently fulfilling and good preparation for future scientific work.  I suggest that you both read the textbook to gain a general understanding of the concepts and read the suggested papers to dive more deeply into specific issues and experiments.
prereqs: Prerequisites: CHM 301/302 or CHM 303/304.
descrip: Life processes depend on over 25 elements whose bioinorganic chemistry is relevant to the environment (biogeochemical cycles), agriculture, and health. CHM 544 surveys the bioinorganic chemistry of the elements. In-depth coverage of key transition metal ions including manganese, iron, copper, and molybdenum focuses on redox roles in anaerobic and aerobic systems and metalloenzymes that activate small molecules and ions, including hydrogen, nitrogen, nitrate, nitric oxide, oxygen, superoxide, and hydrogen peroxide. Appreciation of the structure and reactivity of metalloenzyme systems is critical to understanding life at the molecular level.

title: Relief and Intaglio Printmaking
reviews: Challenging and the assignments take quite a bit of out-of-class time, but definitely take it and you will learn a lot!! Daniel is great!
It is a lot of work, but it's worth learning all the different types and applications of printmaking. The range of mediums you can explore is great and can be a rewarding experience.

TAKE THIS CLASS
Seriously
This should be a Princeton bucket list item.
Professor Heyman is a Princeton treasure--not just as an instructor but as a person--and you should take advantage of the opportunity to take a class with him while you can.
Take it.
Take this course, and do the work.
prereqs: Must have taken: VIS 201/202 or VIS 203/204, VIS 211/212, VIS 221/222, VIS 231/232, VIS 214/215 or VIS 219 also.
descrip: This course introduces techniques of copper plate etching, and relief printing. Assignments focus on applications of various printmaking techniques, while encouraging independent development of subject matter. Critiques will occur throughout the term. Students are encouraged to draw regularly outside of class to cultivate themes and content applicable to their prints. Field trips to the University museum and the library's graphics collection will complement class work. Additional independent workshop hours required.

title: Ethics of Persuasion, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Soviet Literature, 1917-1965
descrip: The course surveys major literary texts and trends in the half-century period between the Revolution of 1917 and the end of Khrushchev's Thaw. We will examine works by avant-garde authors, proletarian-minded writers, and those "fellow travelers" who continued to create under a Soviet regime increasingly hostile to them. In reading these texts, we will focus attention on major cultural topics such as: the avant-garde and the fate of art; the Russian intelligentsia and the Revolution; the political regimentation of culture; the nature and method of socialist realism.

title: Advanced Russian through History and Culture
prereqs: RUS 208, or permission of instructor (kblank@princeton.edu)..
descrip: The course aims to improve students' proficiency in idiomatic Russian by using materials on historical and cultural topics. The materials cover Russian history from the days of Kievan Rus' to the post-Soviet era.

title: Topics in Development - Making Government Work in Fragile States
descrip: Reformers exist in many fragile states but few are able to produce sustained improvement in service delivery or in the operation of core government institutions. This course focuses on a set of governance traps that appear to subvert fragile state turnarounds and strategies for escaping these. It also addresses handling of principal-agent problems in remote areas. At a broader level, it engages participants in thinking about patterns of state formation in 21st century, focusing on scaling up of reform in urban centers. We use biography and case studies to spur thinking, plus theory drawn from economics and political science.

title: Advanced Physics (Electromagnetism)
reviews: (Jones & Hasan) You should definitely be aware that the course is not well organized and that you have to really know what is going on with the material to do well in the course. You should definitely do the readings and go to the problem sessions since this semester the TA was super helpful.

Be prepared to do the textbook reading; lectures were not of much help in finishing weekly problem sets. Also, students tend to start psets over the weekend because they're due on Mondays; it's much better if you can start it before the weekly problem session.

Depends on why you want to take it. Don't take it to fill a distribution requirement. Do take it if you're interested in understanding how E&M works at a more fundamental level than you'll get in PHY 104. The class is pretty theoretical, but the things you learn still apply to problems you might encounter outside of physics classes/research. I enjoyed the class (and I'm not a physics or math major--I'm an engineer), but I don't think it's for everyone. It's definitely not for everyone.
Do the problem sets before the quizzes, as quiz problems will sometimes contain problems directly from the problem sets.
Don't do it unless you are a physics major who is highly self-confident and absolutely dedicated to physics. Generally not worth taking over 104, way harder, and harsh grading.

EM is a different beast from PHY 105. They are taught by different professors, and have a different character to them. Even if you hated 105, as I did, you may find that you like 106. If you have never taken 105 before, it might be possible to take 106 - it may, ironically, be a superior alternative to 104. 

One important factor is vector calculus. Although nothing mandates you having taken MAT 203 beforehand, the things that it teaches are absolutely essential to PHY 106. Those who have not taken MAT 203 (or 201) are at a disadvantage, since they will be lacking important knowledge about divergence, gradients, curl, Gauss's theorem, etc. I'm not sure whether or not MAT 201 covers these things. You have to know vector, or at least multivariable, calculus before you take this!

Another thing that helps is having any E&M class prior to this. You will have a tough time if you have never taken E&M before hand; this class is not a good first exposure to the subject.

Finally, if you are uncertain about your ability, take the risk! Shop the course and go to the first problem session. If you find yourself at a significant disadvantage in your skill level with regards to the other students, drop the course and take 104. But don't just skim over it and assume it'll be too hard, because it is very rewarding.

I would not recommend this class if it is taught by Jones. One of the only ways to learn the material was to read the textbook. There was also barely any feedback regarding our performance in the course.

If you did well in 105, you'll probably be fine here. I found this easier than 105. If you are in 103 and considering moving up, I'd be a bit wary, as there is knowledge that is assumed, most of which was taught in 105 (some, on the other hand, is just assumed....so that just sucks for everyone). The class presents really interesting and cool material, but is definitely on the difficult side.
It's quite difficult but if you want a deep understanding of classical e&m I would take this course over 104.
Only take 105/106 if you are interested in pursuing physics as a major, even though I am moving on it was good for me to find out that physics wasn't my passion
Physics majors really should do this class. Others should stay away and do 104.
Take 104, unless you are very confident in your physics ability.
Take it if you must, but be ready to have a hard time.
Take it over the other physics classes.
Take this class, especially if you are interested in physics/math/engineering.
Take this course - beware of organizational problems

Take this course, especially if it's with new professors!  These professors do know what they're talking about, and the material is SUPER INTERESTING, so you should take it regardless, but it would be even better if it were better organized.

Take this if you're interested in physics, but also make sure that you have a strong math/physics background or you will find the material very challenging.  Go to problem sessions; the preceptor is extremely helpful.

Textbook is quite good, homework is manageable, depends on your professors. I was not completely happy with Jones and Hassan because they were rather slow at returning written work, although lecture experiments were a lot of fun and Hassan solved very interesting problems during precept.
The topic is fascinating and the labs are fun, but the lectures are marginally helpful other than to maybe see a few cool demos and sample problems.
There's no real reason to take physics 106 when you could take physics 104 for much less work, get a better grade, and have a more coherent experience.

This class is extremely disorganized. If you've never had E&M before I don't know how you'd survive, as you pretty much had to know everything already and rely on the book for things like relativity. If you're not a physics major, I see no reason to put yourself through this (although I hear 104 wasn't much better), except that there were a few cooler points (such as magnetism arising out of relativity).

This course is really hard! Don't take it unless you are a physics major who wants to be very prepared, or crazy. But you learn a lot, including theoretical stuff that doesn't show up in 104. Also, you should have taken multivariable *BEFORE* you take this course, as you need to use multi very early on.
This course provides so much more context than 104. If you are planning in majoring in physics or a physics-heavy field, I would definitely recommend.
prereqs: PHY 103 or PHY 105..
descrip: This course features the classical theory of electricity and magnetism, with emphasis on the unification of these forces through the special theory of relativity. While the subject matter is similar to that of PHY 104, the treatment is more sophisticated. The topics also include DC and AC circuits and the electromagnetic behavior of matter.

title: Senior Independent Work
prereqs: Senior standing is required for enrollment in this course..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. A student may propose a topic and find a faculty member willing to supervise the work. Or the student may select a topic from lists of projects obtained from faculty and off-campus industrial researchers, subject to the consent of the faculty advisor.

title: Electronic and Photonic Devices
reviews: Arvind is the best. He runs precepts that are super helpful. It is a spiritual experience listening to him teach. Take ELE208 for Arvind

Claire is an amazing, helpful person. She;s a decent lecturer. However, as the instructor for this course, she is awful. There is no supplemental material, if you don't understand a lecture, there's no way for you to figure out what went on except by  spending loads of time skimming the internet for relevant key words. Don't take this course if you don't have to; only take it if Claire changes things up and Arvind is teaching.
Cool course
Do the problem sets throughout the semester and turn them in so you get the solutions.
Don't wait until reading period to start the problem sets! Go to the optional precept!
If you are ELE, you'll be taking this course. Note that it is quite qualitative, and overall an enjoyable class.
If you want to learn how modern-day devices work and you like labs, take this class.
If you've got the will to put into understanding some complicated stuff, this class is cool and the labs are a unique experience.
It's a nice course. Be sure to go to lecture and take good notes, because that's your only source of information.

It's ok. Super interesting labs and the material is very relevant to all electronic devices! But the class makes the material seem super simple, and is a little misleading. Plus, there's no reading so it's hard to know what you're expected to know. Find your own reading online if they don't have any, it helps.
Start on the problem sets early and its easy to fall behind. Everything is dependne ton the next so stay up to speed
TAKE IT!
Take it if you're interested in real lab work!
Take it!
Take it! You'll learn so much about semiconductor devices and build so many things.

Take it. It's a cool introduction ELE course especially for those who enjoy chemistry and conceptual understanding more than physics or math. We go over the basics of semiconductors from the bottom up to see how they are developed into devices that can emit light, absorb light, or other things. This class teaches you the basics of electrical engineering, and comes before ELE 206 if you're trying to go from base to more abstract concepts (ELE 208 -> ELE 206 -> ELE 203 -> ELE 201). There is literally no math in the course (which is good); almost all of it is conceptual understanding. The lectures might not be the most easily understood, but Claire is an awesome professor and she will gladly help you outside of class if you go to her office hours or even ask to meet her. She can explain things really well if you go up to her, and I strongly recommend this. I learned most of my material not from lecture, but from asking her during her office hours and Arvind's precepts. Go to Arvind's precepts. He goes over the material in the course each week in a fast-paced manner, but you'll be able to understand what you've learned so much better than if you had only simply gone to lecture. This is a really cool course, and, while a lot of work for labs, is worth taking, even if you're not an ELE major. (I heard this course is also the most expensive at Princeton due to the labs!)

Take the course if you are interested in semiconductors. The labs are super fun as you get to manufacture semiconductor devices that are worth hundreds of dollars all by yourself (and you get to keep them of course)!

The conceptual nature of the course makes it fairly accessible to those who don't want to do rigorous math, and it teaches some interesting content on low-level electronics (though the immediate relevance to everyday technology may seem somewhat distant). Still, the concepts are sometimes difficult to grasp and will likely need some thought before they click, so be prepared to commit some time to the course.
The labs are solid in this class, and Professor Gmachl cares a lot about her students.

There isn't much guidance in this course. The labs are easy enough to do, but the lectures are fairly unstructured, and you don't have any real problem sets (except for a bunch due at Dean's Date) during the semester, so you don't learn how to actually do problems for the class until right before the exams. It's a bit odd, but you can survive if you study. Still a good class.
This is a very good class for people who want a qualitative approach to understanding semiconductors and the physics behind them.
This was a great class! I really enjoyed the material, and Professor Gmachl was incredible!

Very interesting class, with awesome labs. You get to work in the cleanroom and build your solar cells, LEDs, and FETs in lab. Great learning experience, and made me appreciate quantum mechanics even more.
prereqs: PHY104 is a Pre- or Co-requisite. SEAS chemistry, physics, math requirements or equivalent. Elementary knowledge of circuits is required. Pass/Fail not available to EE majors..
descrip: Explores ways in which semiconductor devices harness and control electrons and photons to generate, store or transmit information. The basics of semiconductor electronics and photonics are introduced. We look at diodes, transistors, LEDs, solar-cells, and lasers, which form the foundations of integrated circuits, microchips, displays, cameras, etc. Nanotechnology, a recent addition to devices and systems, is introduced. Laboratory: fundamentals of micro and nano fabrication and fabrication of Si integrated circuits, semiconductor light emitters, quantum devices.

title: Honors Linear Algebra
reviews: (Kaletha) Kaletha is definitely really helpful (go to his office hours, ask him questions after class). He's just great. The material is definitely abstract. If you have not taken MAT 215 then you should definitely get used to set notation and the ideas of unions, intersections, and the ways that proofs work. The course is pretty good and if you are a math major then you should take this course (that is, if you are not in the 216, 218 track). Linear algebra is great though there is currently no book that actually a good fit for the course so just make sure that you go to all the classes. This class's assignments definitely take a lot of time and digesting the material is not always the easiest thing to do, so you should definitely be sure that you have the time each week to do the assignments in a decent amount of time; no one likes pulling rolling all-nighters. Have fun!!! :)
Absolutely take it! It will be hard, but it will stretch your mind more than you can imagine. Tasho is great.
Definitely review the lecture and psets each week, not just before the exams. Work in groups. Even if it takes a bit longer, you learn a lot more and it's more fun that way too.
Great course. I would not recommend skipping this course if you have the option, especially if it is taught by Kaletha. It'll be hard but very rewarding in the end.

I enjoyed this class a lot for the theory itself -- some of it is really beautiful (like the "uniqueness" of the determinant). Also, linear algebra is crucial to anyone going into math, physics, CS, or economics, so it may be worth taking for the applications.

Notes: - You need to review your notes before and after each class. Lectures move extremely fast, so learn to take neat notes. - Problem sets are extremely long. Fortunately, there are 3 problem sessions and 2 office hours every week. - Learn dual spaces and dual maps well. They're unintuitive but they keep showing up! - When you learn about bilinear forms, read the Wikipedia page on "inner product." That will give you a lot of the intuition you need that isn't covered in the class. - Learn matrix multiplication really well. There are important facts about it that will make your life easier, but that aren't covered in class. - Prof. Kaletha was a great professor, but I think he's leaving. - You can do fine in the class without MAT 215. - There is a ton of formalism, and the cleverness comes in later.
If you've done 215, this is about equivalent, although slightly less time-intensive if you take advantages of resources better.
Start early, go to office hours if you need help, don't skip class.
Take careful notes in class.
Take it if you have taken 215. Great linear algebra class, although some abstract concepts may not be apparent if you have not had exposure to linear algebra before.
Take it!
Tasho was amazing. If he ever comes back, take any class he teaches.
descrip: A rigorous course in linear algebra with an emphasis on proof rather than applications. Topics include vector spaces, linear transformations, inner product spaces, determinants, eigenvalues, the Cayley-Hamilton theorem, Jordan form, the spectral theorem for normal transformations, bilinear and quadratic forms.

title: Renaissance and Baroque Architecture
reviews: Do all the readings, very important for precept discussion.
Highly recommend!
Take it if you're interested in getting into the details about one subject. An interest in architecture would make this class very appealing.

Take it! This course is amazing-- although the professor might not be the same person, I would suggest taking it...and if you happen to see Professor McReynolds teaching another course----Definitely take that course!!!!!
Take this course! It's interesting and will be relevant to your course studies if you are an art history major interested in Italian or French art history.
descrip: European architecture from 1420 to the mid-18th century with particular emphasis on its historical and social background. Various architectural styles - Renaissance, baroque, and rococo - are studied in terms of important architects and buildings especially of Italy, France, and England.

title: Holocaust of European Jews: Witnessing in Literature and Personal Documents
reviews: Be prepared to present! But, feel free to really fit the presentation to your own interests and, since there is no time minimum or maximum, enjoy it!
Don't hesitate

This course is absolutely phenomenal. Professor Irena Gross and Professor Jan Gross are two of the best professors I have ever had and this is one of the best courses I have ever taken. The reading in this course will change the way you think about the Holocaust -- and the world -- and the seminars will do the same. Both professors make themselves available to help you outside of class and they respond to emails quickly and efficiently. Overall, I definitely recommend this course and encourage everyone to take it!
descrip: Representation of the Holocaust is recognized as a deeply problematic challenge. We will examine issues of representation and investigate how the experience is reflected in personal documents and works of fiction.

title: History of Pseudoscience
reviews: A wonderful class with interesting material, and an equally interesting approach. Professor Gordin is a wonderful professor and leads lively, fun, and productive discussions

Definitely definitely take this class! It was one of the top 3 of my Princeton career.  Professor Gordin is an amazing professor and great at running a seminar.  As a result, the discussions were fascinating.  We covered some controversial but super interesting topics like eugenics and parapsychology.  This class taught me how to critically analyze history, historical evidence, historical texts, scientific advancements, and technology's impact on society.  The things I learned can be applied to so many things I see and read about everyday.  The two papers are challenging, but graded fairly and designed to get you to really think hard about your topic and do good research.  Overall, this is an amazing class that I would recommend to a student of any major.  It has really changed the way I think!
Definitely take it! Professor Gordin is great and very interesting subject matter! Would require regular work to get the most out of the class.
I highly recommend this class, but be prepared to participate a lot in discussion and put a lot of effort into your writing. I'd recommend any class with this professor!
Michael Gordon is absolutely one of the best professors at Princeton.
Sometimes the seminars might get a little boring, but for the most part, it was a wonderful experience! Definitely challenged my fundamental assumptions about what science is.

TAKE IT. Be prepared to change your mind about what constitutes 'science.' And it's Prof. Gordin. YOU MUST TAKE IT.
Workload is moderately heavy but oh-so-worth-it.
TAKE THIS CLASS. Seriously, take anything taught by Prof. Gordin. Expect a ton of reading, but it is all completely worth it.
This class was incredible.  I highly recommend taking any class with Professor Gordin.
Well, if it's ever offered again and you can make space for it, take it. Same goes for anything else Professor Gordin teaches.
descrip: The history of the border between what counts as science and what does not tracks the complex tensions in different times and places among science, religion, politics, and culture. This course explores the boundaries science has staked for itself -- or has had staked out for it -- by focusing on the elusive category of "pseudoscience." What have people considered the character of natural knowledge, and how to attain it? What is at stake in appearing scientific? Why exclude certain things from this designation? Each week this course moves backward in time to highlight the diversity of phenomena at the margins of science.

title: Topics in Latin American Literature and Ideology - Poetry, Translation, and Border in Hispanic Caribbean
reviews: Professor Rafael Rojas Gutierrez is extremely knowledgeable about the readings and class material. The readings were interesting (and very short every week!). There was hardly any work in the class (just a two-page midterm reflection and a final paper, but no presentations or other work of any kind besides some readings). I would definitely recommend this class!
Take the class! It's a really interesting way to be introduced to the poetry and literary sphere of the Spanish Caribbean and both Rafael and Jeffrey are awesome.
prereqs: SPA 200-level course or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course explores the history of Cuban, Dominican and Puerto Rican poetry, focusing on the translations and dialogues between the Caribbean and North American poets. We are interested in reading the conversations that the poets of both Americas have made in the last two centuries. By working with this poetry, the course analyzes different modes of figuring the border as well as the images that these poets used in order to identify their own cultures.

title: Corporate Finance
reviews: It's an interesting course. Professor Shin is really good.
This is a "must take" course, if you want to do research in Finance.
descrip: Introduction to corporate finance covering theories and empirical evidence about principal-agent models of firm managerial structure, takeover bids, capital structure, corporate governance; regulation of financial markets; financial markets and institutions with a focus on asymmetric information, transaction costs, or both; dynamic models of market making; and portfolio manager performance evaluation. Pre-requisite: ECO 525.

title: Proseminar in Basic Problems in Psychology: Social Psychology
descrip: Introduction to graduate level social psychology for first year graduate students in psychology. This course will serve as the basis for more advanced graduate courses on specific topics in this area.

title: Tropical Ecology
descrip: This intensive three week field course takes place during January in a suitable tropical locality. Readings, discussions, and individual projects. The content and location are varied to suit the needs of the participants. Students provide their own travel funds.

title: Topics in Russian Literature or Literary Theory - Contemporary Russian Poetry
descrip: This seminar will explore the extraordinary diversity of Russian poetry in the last four decades.

title: Instrumentation and Performance
descrip: The course is a study of the characteristics of individual instruments, including extended contemporary techniques and writing arrangements for chamber ensemble and for orchestra. Special attention is given to problems of combining voice and instruments. The arrangements written for this class are performed by the Composers' Ensemble at Princeton and the Princeton University Orchestra, and problems of performance involving notation, rehearsal, and conducting are dealt with.

title: Dynamical Logics in Architecture
reviews: Take this instead of thesis prep.
descrip: This course is designed as a workshop in architecture derived from material logics. Students will engage in a series of intensive design projects organized around exploring the new implications of the relationship of the part to the whole, force integration, analogue modeling, mass customization, the generic, etc. Ultimately, each project will work through the architectural performance of the complex interplay between material organization, program and form. The primary emphasis of the course will be the development of individual design/research projects, supplemented by background readings.

title: The Anthropology of Memory
descrip: We focus on how humans deal with loss through three major approaches to memory: psychoanalysis (Freud), social organization (Halbwachs), associative temporalities (Sebald). We examine genres in which the memory of loss is retained or displaced. How is the past generally experienced and construed as meaningful in the present? We consider memory from different cultural landscapes and theoretical perspectives. A better understanding of the memory of loss, and the social forms and histories in which this memory remains active, will improve our approaches to cultural observation, documentation, analysis, and interpretation.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: The senior thesis is an independent study for individual students. Work begins in the fall, but enrollment is only in spring term when a double grade is awarded. Students develop their own topic or select a topic from a list of topics prepared by the faculty. Students develop a work plan and select an advisor for their work. A second reader is assigned by the instructor. A written progress report is expected at the end of the fall term. Students submit a written final report and make an oral presentation to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests at the end of the spring term.

title: History of Evolution
reviews: Do not take it unless you already know how to write a strong essay, or PDF the course if you do not know how to write a strong essay.

GET ON YOUR SHIZ and crank out the reading responses right away so you can chill at the end of the semester when things get hot. Precepts are small so they kinda force you to be engaged, but it's challenging in a good way. You will benefit from this course in many ways even if you can't do all the readings, but I wish I had been able to do more of them. The papers are reasonable and not that long. Final not as scary as you'd think. Milam is great.
Great Class if you are interested in it
Take this class if you have even a slight interest in history or science!

This is an amazing course! If you have any interest in taking a history of science or are interested in evolutionary theory, TAKE IT. Take it for amazing lectures, take it for amazing readings, take it if you want a course that will change the way you think about the world and perceive even modern scientific theory. Professor Milam is the best.
prereqs: P/D/F option not available to History concentrators..
descrip: By interweaving intellectual and cultural threads, this course covers the history of evolutionary theory from Charles Darwin, and the scholars on whom he drew, to the late 20th century. We explore how biologists invested in evolutionary theory the capacity to explain our all too human nature and perhaps, therefore, to help us solve some of the world's most pressing problems. We also discuss how and why critics have attacked evolution as amoral and socially dangerous. In doing so, we investigate how scientists have negotiated the dynamic relationship between professional and public science.

title: Biology of Coral Reefs
reviews: All EEB majors should take one of the field programs if at all possible.  This was my favorite of the four courses.
Great course! Probably my favorite in Panama, and that's against some pretty tough competition.
TAKE THIS CLASS! GO TO PANAMA! IT WILL DRASTICALLY IMPROVE YOUR LIFE.
Take this class!!! Bring lots of bug spray and anti-itch cream to Coiba.
Take this course. Easily the best course I've taken at Princeton.

This was probably one of the most important reasons for why I came to Panama. Professor Pacala has been teaching this course for a very long time and is very familiar with the subject material. His personality and his extensive knowledge made it very easy to talk with him about projects and about ecology. I would definitely recommend this course. Even if you think you're terrestrial (I definitely thought I was), you will probably still enjoy this course. Also, make sure you bring bug spray.
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester in tropical biology taught in Panama..
descrip: This field and lecture course provides an in-depth introduction to the biology of tropical coral reefs, with an emphasis on reef fish ecology and behavior. Each day begins with a lecture, followed by six to eight hours on the water, and ends with data analysis, reading and a discussion of recent papers. Students learn to identify fishes, corals and invertebrates, and learn a variety of field methods including underwater censusing, mapping, videotaping and the recording of inter-individual interactions. Each year group projects will vary depending on previous findings and the interests of the faculty.

title: Jazz Theory through Improvisation and Composition I
reviews: Don't take if you already have a good understanding of improvisation.

I would definitely recommend taking this course as an introduction to the basics of jazz theory, especially if Ralph Bowen is teaching it.  You will learn a lot, and have a good time doing it.  Just a word of advice, though:  If you have significant experience with jazz theory and performance already, you may find the class a bit easy.  However, as with all music, there is always more to practice, so any basic material learned in class can be supplemented with extra work.  Mr. Bowen is very approachable, so definitely talk to him if you want to go more in depth into some of the material on your own.  Take this course - you'll enjoy it!
If you like jazz and you'd like to learn more about it, take the class!
Take MUS 104/105 before it, and ask questions if you're lost of your classmates and of Ralph - they're all great resources and help so much.

The class lacked actual improvisation and composition (save for the sole composition assignment during the last week of class), which was a bit disappointing. However, the theory-based instruction and solo analysis assignments, which formed the basis for the course, were really top-notch. Do take this course, and practice and internalize the theory you learn!

This course is pretty interesting if you like jazz.  I had little formal music training before taking it and I don't think it went too fast.  That being said the course is very unstructured and there is no text book or anything, so it is kind of difficult to study for exams and stuff.
This is a great class for all musicians to take.
Very interesting stuff, take it if you're interested in jazz theory but be prepared to be confused sometimes.
prereqs: MUS 105 or instructor's permission..
descrip: An exploration of the melodic, harmonic and rhythmic principles of the bebop paradigm. The course includes analysis of representative works by various jazz masters and will place a strong emphasis on student projects in improvisation, transcription, analysis and composition.

title: Special Topics in Computer Science - Information Technology, Law and Policy
reviews:
495 is Special Topics in CS, so the course we took this semester is unlikely to be offered again.  That said, Reidenberg's lectures were great, and made the otherwise dreary material much easier to get through.

495 is frequently taught by visiting profs, which means grading is a crapshoot.  I have no idea what grade I'll get in this class - still, it could reduce grade deflation pressure depending on who's teaching.
An easy course, but a whole lot of fun. Joel Reidenberg was a treat to have as a professor.
Easy, interesting, fascinating course. Go for it.
Hope he comes back to teach this another semester.
I'd recommend the course. It covers a lot of important issues in the intersection of tech and policy.
IT&Law with Reidenberg was a cool class. He really knows his stuff, and this is a great way to get your bearings on what's going on in the tech world.
Joel Reidenberg = the best
Take it!
Take the opportunity to read through all of the material and read about law and technology news. It is really interesting to apply what you know to current events.
Take this class!
This class was amazing! One of the best I have taken at Princeton! Low workload and very interesting.

This course is great if you're looking for an easy CS departmental, and/or you want to know more about the political debates surrounding internet policy. However, I don't think it will be taught like this again.

This is a really cool course.  The lectures are great, the assignments are short, and all the topics were relevant to current news.  The Heartbleed bug and the Netflix/Comcast-Time Warner deal came out during class so we took time to talk about them.  Strongly Recommend
Very good course! Super interesting and relevant material.
With incoherent lectures and dense, lengthy readings with few guiding questions to give us hints of what to focus on, it's difficult to get much out of this class.
descrip: This course presents an overview of the key regulatory and policy challenges that information technology and the Internet pose for society. The course will explore the technologies, actors and law that frame online activities. The course will address various methods of regulating the Internet, territorial jurisdiction, network management, privacy, intellectual property, and intermediary liability. The course will emphasize the interdependence of legal and technological rule-making and will conclude with a look toward the future of the Internet from the perspective of law.

title: The Artist at Work
reviews: A challenging course at times, but a great way to meet many different artists and see their working practice. A different way to look at art history that is not often presented.

Great course!! Would take it even if you haven't had much exposure to art history. The class involves several field trips into the city but they're all definitely worthwhile. You get to meet important contemporary artists and really get to know their work. The class also attracts very like-minded people so the discussions are intellectually challenging and a lot of fun!

I strongly recommend this course. It stands outside the typical framework of Princeton classes and truly takes advantage of all the resources available to us. I am very happy that I took this course. I learned a lot not only from Professor Small and from the materials covered in class, but also from the students themselves.

If you're interested at all in current issues in art, take it! We talked about everything. Got involved in a lot of debate about current, controversial issues as well, and it was a really fun and thought-provoking course.
Participate as much as possible and be prepared for the studio visits to New York.
TAKE IT

This is an amazing course. Such a brilliant exceptional opportunity to learn about contemporary art. So many great connections made. Free thinkers are truly valued and rewarded after taking this course. Professor Small is the greatest.
descrip: What are the environments, fictions, fantasies, and ideologies that condition the artist at work? This course takes as its investigative locus the artist's studio, a space of experimentation and inspiration, but also of boredom, sociability, exhaustion, and critique. Structured around visits to the studios of multiple practicing artists in New York City, the course tracks the trope of "the studio" from the Renaissance to the present, with emphasis on the concept's reconfiguration and reanimation in contemporary art. Lecture with discussion and field trips.

title: Directed Research
descrip: During the third semester, each student writes a research paper under the direction of a faculty member.

title: Microeconomics Theory Workshop
reviews: Yes, come to seminar!
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Korean Cinema
reviews: I had a blast in this course, and it was definitely the highlight of my week. While the class focuses on Korean films, it is very much a cinema class at its heart. When you finish you will not only have a better understanding of Korean society, but will also have a valuable toolkit that you can use to analyze films in general. Be prepared to have some of the films push you out of your comfort zone, but know that the discomfort is worthwhile.
I would definitely recommend this class. Professor Chung is great.
Take it. It's chill, fun and you'll learn a lot about Korea through the lens of cinema.
YES
descrip: Offers a broad historical examination of Korean cinema from both sides of the DMZ. We start with some rare surviving colonial period films and work our way to the very recent films of the "Korean wave" era. Our thematic focus will be post-coloniality, ideological division, war, national reconstruction, democratization, and intensified global capitalism; our critical focus will be on problems of nation, class, and gender. At the heart of the work for the course will be attention to the films themselves, where we will try to account critically for shifts in style and form.

title: Systematic Ethics
reviews: A strong, comprehensive introduction to ethics (particularly modern) with varied philosophical texts and authors.
Definitely take this if you are at all interested in philosophical thought
Do your reading.

Harman is brilliant and kind, but his lectures and precepts are painful to sit through. All the readings come directly from an (excellent) single book--you'd get as much out of reading the book on your own as you would taking this class.
I would advise students not to waste time doing all of the readings, but to always go to lecture and take thorough notes.
I would take it if you're a philosophy major, don't take it if you're not. Basically, ask yourself if you're really interested in this stuff. Maybe even go online and read a couple metaethics papers.
I would take this course if you are looking for an EM that does not require a lot of work, but do not take this course if you want to be passionate about the subject matter.
Take it if you are interested in moral philosophy and care more about learning and enjoying your time than being up tight and getting good grades. Although it is easy to get a good grade.
There is amazing amount of content covered, so if you are interested in the area, take it.
This is a Very interesting course to take and both the professor and preceptor were very knowledgeable of the material.
With Professor Harman, it doesn't have to be a lot of work.
descrip: A survey of major issues about the nature of morality. Two lectures and one precept per week.

title: The New Testament and Christian Origins
reviews: Don't take it unless you are interested in the course material.
Don't take it unless you're going to pdf it.
Great course if interested! Definitely helps develop other important writing and reading skills.

If you are interested in learning about the New Testament, take this course. I learned a lot and found it quite fascinating. Professor Luijendijk is wonderful, super friendly, try to get in her precept.
If you aren't a religion major, P/D/F the course and coast or don't take it at all.
It's an interesting course. Lectures aren't great but Professor L is an enthusiastic professor.
Pagel's class covers a lot of the same material and is probably more engaging.
TAKE IT. I loved this course. Made me super interested in religion. Loved how we looked at everything from a historical point of view.
Take it if you have any interest in the historical background of the early Christian movement.
Take it only if it really interests you, it is very dense material so don't go in expecting it to be a light survey course.

Take this course if you're at all interested in the history of the New Testament!  And even if you're not!  This course gives a historical perspective that is very interesting.  Do the readings and go to all the lectures and precepts!
This is a decent class for those that are really interested in learning about looking at the Bible with a historically critical eye, but otherwise not that interesting and would be difficult
This is a good course to take.
Very interesting!
descrip: This course investigates how the Christian movement began, using ancient sources - Jewish, Greek, Roman, and Christian - about Jesus of Nazareth. We read the letters of the Apostle Paul and New Testament gospels, along with such recently discovered gospels as the Gospel of Thomas and the Gospel of Mary Magdalene. We will discuss the formation of the New Testament collection; views of Jesus and his message; attitudes toward sexuality, gender, race and community. This course will also include readings and analysis of contemporary perspectives. Accessible to students new to these sources, as well as to those familiar with them.

title: Practice Teaching
prereqs: Admission to the Teacher Preparation Program is usually required. Application for fieldwork placement must be made in advance. Completion of Pre-professional portfolio..
descrip: Supervised practice teaching (a minimum of 12 weeks) in a secondary school. Teaching is done under the supervision of an accomplished teacher and a program staff member who regularly observe and discuss the student's practice teaching. Students gain firsthand experience in developing teaching strategies, planning and implementing instruction, assessing student learning, and classroom management. Must be taken concurrently with TPP 401.

title: The Greek World in the Hellenistic Age
reviews: Be prepared for the tests and quizzes, as a general knowledge of events is not enough.  Be prepared to be asked for details!
I would definitely recommend this course, particularly if you are interested in the Hellenistic period.
I would take this class if you are interested in getting a solid understanding of the Hellenistic period.
If you're at all interested in the Romans or Classical Greeks, this time period in between is definitely worth your attention--some really cool stuff happens.
If you're interested in Greek History, take this course--but be prepared to be surrounded by Classics majors who already know a great deal
Lectures are extremely important!
Pretty interesting history class. Not a lot of work. Would be a great class to PDF.
Read the Readings and pay attention/take notes during lecture
Take it if you're interested in the material, it's really interesting.
none

very little work yet also very interesting (if you're into history/greece/alexander the great). i wish i could have dedicated more time to this course, so i ended up p/d/f-ing it; however, it is definitely a doable class to take for a grade, even as an engineer with a packed schedule
descrip: The Greek experience from Alexander the Great through Cleopatra. An exploration of the dramatic expansion of the Greek world into Egypt and the Near East brought about by the conquests and achievements of Alexander. Study of the profound political, social, and intellectual changes that stemmed from the interaction of new cultures, and the entrance of Rome into the Greek world. Readings include history, biography, and inscriptions.

title: Studies in Later Persian Literature 1200 - 1800 A.D.
descrip: Course acquaints students with the literature of the second great classical language of Islam and its legacy of epics, chronicles, lyric poems, mystical writings and imaginative tales from the traditional Persian-speaking world - including not only from present-day Iran, Afghanistan and Tajikistan but also from Anatolia, Central Asia and the Indian sub-continent. Continuation of NES 539. Treats the literature from 1200 to 1800.

title: Intensive Intermediate and Advanced French
reviews: Definitely take the course if it is taught by Professor Perrier. She is approachable, kind, and a fine teacher. You certainly will learn a lot of French, but as long as you keep up with your homework, the course is totally manageable.
Do it! Be prepared to work really hard, but Murielle Perrier is one of the best professors that I've had at Princeton.
Make sure to keep up with all of the exercises and everything assigned in the textbook and you will be fine.
Stay on top of everything, and seek out Mme. Perrier's help if necessary.
TAKE IT. You'll learn so, so much. Even if Professor Perrier isn't teaching it next year, you'll grow in French!
This course is very difficult and demanding but absolutely worthwhile.

This course is very fast-paced. Grammatical concepts are taught very quickly. Absolutely take this course if you want to take a big step in your French abilities, but be aware that you will have to put in an hour or two of work every day for this course.
prereqs: FRE 101 and Permission of Instructor..
descrip: FRE 102-7 is an intensive double course designed to help students develop an active command of the language. Focus will be on reading and listening comprehension, oral proficiency, grammatical accuracy, and the development of reading and writing skills. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Students will be introduced to various Francophone cultures through readings, videos and films.

title: International Relations
reviews: A lot of work.

A must take for anyone interested in foreign policy or international relations. Be prepared to do a lot of reading, but know that the work is well worth it. Professor Moravcsik is a great lecturer and is extremely engaging.

Be prepared for a LOT of reading. To really get the most out of this class, set aside time to do all the readings and digest them. Not a casual international relations class, would not recommend taking this unless you plan on studying the field.
Be prepared for a class that will be a lot of work.

Be prepared for a lot of reading and prepwork. You can't BS your way out of this course. But Moravcsik is great and hopefully your preceptor will really care about how well you understand what is  often a very complex subject.
Be prepared for the sheer difficulty.
Be prepared to be challenged. You won't necessarily be rewarded for the time and effort you put in.

DON'T TAKE IT, especially if you've never taken an IR class before. Expectations are unnecessarily high, and you need to put in A TON of time to not even get a good grade. Least favorite class I've ever taken and a mistake not to drop it.

Definitely take this with Moravcsik. He is great and the precepts are interactive. However, there is no way to do all of the readings. Instructions for written work is vague and complicated and responses from preceptors often conflict. This class is graded harshly, so don't expect As across the board even if you are an international relations buff.
Do NOT take it. Just don't. Save yourself. You don't need all this negativity in your life.
Do the readings, split up the work with other people if you have to, and show up to lecture.
Do you readings ahead of time and make thorough notes!

Don't have precept with Moravcsik... A lot of people dropped the course because the amount of work was difficult to manage. I think if you have another preceptor, your experience would be much different from mine.
Don't take it with Moravcsik...he grades harshly

Don't take this to satisfy a requirement just because you think it will be easy. It is not. There is a lot of reading, grading is very arbitrary, and the organization of the course will leave you with very little to take away from it. Moravscik is a good lecturer, and I liked my preceptor (Julia Morse), but if you're looking to satisfy, say, the WWS politics requirement, 220 might be a better bet.
Don't take this unless you have to. Choose your preceptor wisely.
Get Richard Jordan as your preceptor. He's a boss and a great guy. Extremely cordial and insightful.
Good course but it takes a lot of time if you want to do well!
Hardest class by far during my time at Princeton and if you're willing to allow your GPA to take a dip, take it.
I was really excited going into this class, and was not quite as excited going out.
It's a lot harder than it appears.
It's a lot of reading and Moravcsik is pretty cold but if you're interested in IR you'll take away a good amount.
