Its a lot of work (readings primarily).  Prepare for precept a lot.  The grading is a bit rough, don't expect an A without putting in a good amount of work and effort.
Know what you're getting into

Learned a ton. However, the written work leaves a lot to be desired. There are some very petty assignments (in which they grade you for grammar) and ones that are so broad that it hurts. If you want to learn, take this class. If you also want to learn how to parse Moravcsik's assignments, take this class as well.
Really challenging! Know that going in.
Take it if interested in IR but be prepared to work. Readings dense but good to know
Take it if you have to
Take it!
Take it. Be prepared to do a fair amount of work, but take it.
They nail you on the papers so be prepared. Try and read everything.
This class is extremely demanding, with a lot of readings and very harsh grading.
This class's curve is tough, even for IR buffs. Be forewarned.

This is a challenging course with a huge amount of reading. Nonetheless, the subject matter is very interesting and you get to learn about the interactions between nations throughout history and today. I would recommend this class if you are interested in the subject matter, but be prepared for a lot of work.

This is a difficult course load for a politics class. Lots of reading, three papers, a midterm, and a final. Precepts are very intense as well. That being said, it's a very informative class for IR enthusiasts

This is an excellent course, and extremely well taught.  There are, however, a LOT of readings, and assignments and exams can be very difficult.  An interesting course, but not one to take during an otherwise loaded semester!
This is not an easy A by any means. It's extremely hard, but very worth it. you will learn a ton!
Very informative course, but keep in mind it focuses on theory a lot.
Very, very, very challenging. Particularly if you are in his precept. But hard work pays off.
Yes.
You will learn a lot about IR but the grading will be tough, and there is a LOT of reading
this is a really hard course. it had turned people away from wws. it has a lot of reading.
descrip: This course is an introduction to the causes and nature of international conflict and cooperation. We critically examine various theories of international politics by drawing on examples drawn from international security, economic and legal affairs across different historical eras from 10,000 BC to the present. Topics include the causes of war, the pursuit of economic prosperity, the sources of international order and its breakdown, and the rise of challenges to national sovereignty, and such contemporary issues as international environmental politics, human rights promotion, global terrorism, and the future of US foreign policy.

title: Topics in Topology - Classical high dimensional manifold theory
descrip: For Spring semester 2014, we plan to discuss the h-cobordism theorem and, in particular, Smale's proof of the smooth Poincare conjecture for dimensions at least 5, theory of engulfing and Stalling proof of the high dimensional piecewise linear Poincare conjecture, and the proof of the topological Schoenflies theorem after Mazur and Brown.

title: Politics of Inequality and Redistribution (Half-Term)
descrip: Study of policy preferences, differential rates of political participation, voting behavior, legislative process, political communication, urban politics and role of race in US political life are central to study of inequality in politics. Though the American case will feature prominently, we will approach issues from a comparative perspective. Thus the course provides introduction to comparative study of welfare states and political economy of advanced industrial countries, including regulation of labor markets and relationship between wage inequality, income distribution and policy preferences for redistribution and social protection.

title: Advanced Topics in Fluid Mechanics I - Advanced Turbulence
reviews: This is a very interesting course.
prereqs: This course is a second course in turbulence and presumes that the student has considerable familiarity with the subject. Completion of an Introductory Turbulence course should meet this requirement..
descrip: Focus is on advanced concepts in turbulence, especially relating to turbulence at different scales of motion and in both statistically stationary and non-stationary situations. Emphasis is on homogeneous turbulent flows, with particular attention to the spectral equations of motion. Classical theories of turbulence, especially similarity laws, receive considerable attention and critiqued in light of recent research. Statistical methods are discussed in some detail with particular attention to POD and spectral analysis.

title: The Politics of European Integration
descrip: This course seeks to explicate and understand the European Union both as a process of international or regional integration, tying existing nation-states such as France, Germany, and the United Kingdom into an 'ever-closer Union of peoples'; and as a polity or political system with its own institutions, policies, and policy processes. The deeper purpose is to give graduate students in politics, public policy and other related disciplines a basic theoretical, substantive and methodological grounding, on the basis of which they can design and conduct original research on the EU.

title: Autobiography and Identity
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in German Intellectual History - Aby Warburg and the History of Science around 1900
descrip: Aby Warburg is not only the inventor of the concept of "Kulturwissenschaft" which he developed on the background of the rediscovery of the "wild origins of culture" in the 19th century by means of a transgression of the principals of art history. He was also occupied with the attempt to develop an energetic theory of culture, the expressions of emotions, and the symbolic praxis of mankind. The seminar studies central parts of his publications and then unpublished notes and analyzes them within the scientific thought of his time which were engaged with approaches beyond both myth vs. science and Natur- vs. Geisteswissenschaften.

title: Wizardry and Wild Romance
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Special Topics in Informations Sciences and Systems - Optimization of Communication Systems
reviews: Interesting class time. Not a lot of work. Might not be the very best class you take but the rewards from taking it are a lot compared to time spent on the course.
good
descrip: Study how problems in point-to-point and networked communication systems can be formulated and solved as optimization, covering both classic results and current research. Introduce the methodologies of linear program, convex optimization, Lagrange duality, and study their theoretical properties and computational algorithms. Sample application topics: information-theoretic and queuing-theoretic problems, coding and equalization, antenna beamforming, network resource allocation and utility maximization, theory of network architecture, wireless network power control, Medium Access Control schemes, IP routing, TCP congestion control.

title: American Revolutions
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Colonization and Spaces of Urban Modernity: Readings
reviews: I highly recommend this course for any history student interested in spatial history, urban history, colonial history, or some intersection of these. It offers good exposure to theorists and their applications.
I strongly recommend taking this course. The readings are very interesting, there is a lot to be discussed and Professor Prakash is excellent!
Interesting topic. Wide, global breadth of readings. Texts a mix of histories and theory (so be prepared to read both), and discussion sometimes becomes difficult when trying to meet the two.
descrip: A seminar that examines theoretical and historical literature on urban modernity as a process of colonization of space - colonization both in the sense of territorial conquest and as an exercise of power to colonize and configure social space.

title: Tonal Syntax
reviews: I would definitely recommend other students to take this course!
I would not take this course unless you are a major unless the material is being strongly permuted for next year.
If you want to know more about Bach's music, and/or be able to write it, take the course! It's great.
It's a lot of fun and you get to listen to nice music; not the most rigorous of courses but difficult enough that you need to pay attention during class.

Take it if you want to try to tackle the very hard to characterize problem of making beautiful tonal music. It is a great class, and you learn a lot about the composition process. It's not too easy, but it is rewarding. It's less structured than MUS 205 and harder to figure out what you are losing points for, but it really opens your eyes to Bach's music.
Take it. Looking BACH, you will have no regrets.

This class is completely arbitrary in its grading. It became very frustrating, and at the end of the day I don't really feel like I gained anything from it. The compositional skill you supposedly gain from this is something that any musician worth their salt could do from day one without spending a semester needlessly scrutinizing Bach. 

I'm told the course content varies from year depending on what Professor Trueman thinks is appropriate, but our year it was a pretty intense waste of time and energy.

If you're not a music major and you're not being forced to take it, I'd skip it.

Professor Trueman's an awesome guy, though.
This is more of a composition course than it is anything else,  but the analysis we do is great and very helpful and interesting.
prereqs: MUS 205 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: MUS 206 begins by making relevant connections between the modal counterpoint of the 16th century (studied in MUS 205) and tonality as it evolved in the 18th century. Fundamental tonal concepts will then be explored in later music including Chopin and Brahms.

title: Moses and Jesus in the Islamic Tradition
descrip: The course will focus on the changing representations of the prophets Musa (Moses) and `Isa (Jesus) within the Islamic tradition. Course materials include readings in translation from the Qur'an, hadith, Sufi poetry, the popular "Tales of the Prophets" as well as modern Islamic texts on social justice, and novels. We will examine the ways in which these prophets, while recognized by Muslims as foundational figures in Christianity and Judaism, played and continue to play a prominent role, as monotheistic prophets and as religious examplars, in many diverse aspects of Islamic thought and practice.

title: Topics of Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Climate Change: Science and Policy
descrip: Designed to improve students' skill, confidence and judgment in use of science in policy applications. Using case studies, real-world examples, and in-class exercises, in the areas of atmospheric and energy policy, the emphasis is on preparing both non-scientists and scientists to use, understand, and critique science in environmental policy applications. Exercises are scaled to the student's background.

title: Sociology of Sports
reviews: A pretty average course. Interesting material, but the professor is just okay.
I'm not sure this class is as great as it could be -- but it starts well and ends well and is worth your time anyway.
It is a great course for athletes who can really related to the subject matter, however, the nonathletes in the course seemed to really take a lot out of it as well.
One of my favorite courses thus far. Must take if you have personal experience with sports.
TAKE IT!! Especially if you are an athlete or big sports fan, it is easy to relate and participate with personal input.
Take this course! It is great!
Take your time to work on the essays because it will be rewarding and the topics are fun to think about and give attention to.

Talk to Professor Kornblum in person.  He is good at responding to emails, but the man is brilliant and so interesting to talk to.  He's never condescending or impatient, and it was a pleasure to talk to him outside the context of class discussion.

This is an amazing class. It is relaxing and definitely my "easy" class this semester, but essays still require a fair amount of attention because Professor Kornblum holds written work to a high standard. As an athlete (even if you are not a sociology major, as I am not) especially, I would say take it. One of my favorite classes here.
good course and Kornblum is a great professor and a good man who is interested his students
descrip: The course will focus on sports and athletes in American communities (not limited to communities in the U.S.), and including sports on the college campus. Students will be asked to write about their own experiences with athletics and to compare them to examples drawn from outstanding first-hand accounts of sports in different community settings. Readings, films, and class discussions will afford opportunities to appreciate the individual and social benefits of participation in athletics, as well as the risks and value distortions that competitive sports may entail.

title: General Plasma Physics II
reviews: A very good course.
If you want to learn MHD really well, take this course.

Not only would I recommend this course to first years, but I would strongly recommend this even to upper years who feel their skills in MHD aren't quite up to par, or who are interested in learning a little more of the history of the subject.

Participation really pays out in this course as Prof Bhattacharjee is very happy about it and definitely answers every question to a highly satisfying degree. It is helpful to refresh your knowledge about vector calculus before, as this is what the math in the course is all about.
Take this course.
descrip: This is an introductory graduate course in plasma physics, focusing on magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) and its extension to weakly collisional or collisionless plasmas. Topics to be covered include: the equations of MHD and extended MHD, the structure of magnetic fields, static and rotating MHD equilibria and their stability, magnetic reconnection, MHD turbulence, and the dynamo effect. Applications are drawn from fusion, heliophysical, and astrophysical plasmas.

title: Capitalist Transformations
descrip: This graduate readings course surveys classic and recent works on the history of capitalism, exposing students to different methodological and interpretive traditions, while focusing on the theme of "capitalist transformations." Readings focus on the Anglo-American context, but will also take into account global and comparative perspectives. Students will finish the course familiar with the basic outlines of capitalism's history, and the course should be of relevance to those interested in the relationship between history and social theory.

title: The Renaissance in England - Renaissance Romance
descrip: An exploration of the fugitive genre of romance in the sixteenth century, with some attention to classical and medieval forebears. Philip Sidney and Edmund Spenser are at the center of our attention, but we go back to Gascoigne, forward to the late Shakespeare, and entertain some others along the way (Greene, Harrington's Ariosto, et al.). Because romance is above all a mode of storytelling, the course also serves as an introduction to the rudiments of narrative theory, and perforce to the theory of genre as well.

title: Introduction to Movement and Dance
reviews: Absolutely take this class!

Absolutely take this course. Aynsley is an amazing teacher who will help you in so many aspects. You will become more aware of yourself and your movements, as well as more appreciative of the arts. Taking this class was one of the best decisions I've made here.
Aynsley is the best! She works so hard to make sure everyone is comfortable in the class!
Come into class ready to let go. Just let go of expectations and angst and  you'll do amazing.
Come into the class ready to do some work. It's not a joke and you'll be rewarded
Def take this class to become more confident in your body.  More work than expected though. Aynsley is absolutely amazing.
Great Class.  The final performance sounds intimidating at first but the class prepares you for it well.  Not only is it a very fun class but it also is a great way to try new things.
If you have any interest in dance at all, take this class! It is incredibly refreshing.

If you're even considering taking this, then definitely take it. Aynsley is a fantastic dance instructor, and the class is designed to make you feel comfortable. If you have two left feet like me, don't feel afraid to take this class; all you need to do is move your body.
Loved this course- I had some doubts when I first enrolled in the course, but they were all gone by the end! So much fun and a great way to de-stress in the middle of the afternoon

People know this is class is not stressful and not necessarily the most demanding. Let me point out an unexpected benefit: you'll meet a cross-section of people you might not meet elsewhere. Every class year and lots of social groups are represented.
Remember that you need to perform at the end. If you don't like doing that kind of stuff, dont do it.
TAKE IT!!!! Don't be discouraged by the fact that it is not your usual princeton class
TAKE THIS CLASS
Take it if you're interested in dance but have never done it before.
Take it!
Take it! It's fun and stress-free. Yes, there's a final solo performance at the end, but don't worry too much about it. Aynsley is so supportive and nice - you'll love this class.
Take it.
Take it.  And do the readings/journal entries in good faith, but don't stress about them.
Take this class! Even if you feel like you don't have a graceful bone in your body. Aynsely will get you movin and groovin!
There are readings. Expect them. However the class is great,  definitely worth while!

This class was awesome!  If you have any interest or passion for learning how to dance, even if you have no talent for dancing whatsoever (because I certainly came in with zero skills), you should take this class!

This was my favorite class I have taken at Princeton. Aynsley is absolutely wonderful, and is clearly very passionate about dance while being fun and silly. The course itself is not a ton of work outside of class, but if you buy into it, will be incredibly rewarding and fun. Come to the first few classes with an open mind.

Very relaxing and a good break to your day. Don't expect to have any choreographed dance - it's more of a time to explore movement on your own. Fair warning, it does take a lot of time and you have journal entries to write before every class, but it's worth it if you're looking for a fun LA.
You get out of this course what you put into it. I became a lot more self-confident in my movement.
take it if you want a chill class
descrip: Designed for people with little or no previous training in dance, the class will be a mixture of movement techniques, improvisation, choreography, observing, writing, and discussing. Students will investigate their own movement patterns and delve into many facets of dance and the cultural questions surrounding it. We will explore the role of dancer, choreographer, audience member, and critic in relation to such topics as aesthetic questions, politics, identity, religion, and complex views of the human body.

title: Molecular Evolution
reviews: This course is geared towards students that are willing to complete a lot of reading each week and to engage in class discussions. The topics are of great general interest and are well introduced by the professor.
attend class
prereqs: MOL 214, MOL 215, or CHM 236..
descrip: How and where did life evolve? This advanced seminar will discuss the evolution of the molecules that sustain life (DNA, RNA and proteins) at both the micro and macro evolutionary levels. We will explore the role of these molecules in the origin and continued evolution of life. Topics include the origin of eukaryotes and organelles, comparative genomics, population genetics, the microbiome, and human evolution. One three-hour seminar. Note that students new to either evolution or genetics will find 309 more appropriate.

title: In the Groove: Technology and Music in American History, From Edison to the iPod
reviews: A good history class for non-history or even non-humanities people. Those with interests in music should find it quite interesting.

I really recommend this course. It didn't feel like too much work; the readings were  interesting. Emily Thompson is extremely nice and approachable. If you like music and/or media, you will enjoy this course.

I would recommend going to office hours to discuss things you feel strongly about and just give simpler responses in precept that don't rely as much on interactivity but still convey that you read the material and thought about it seriously.
If you're even mildly interested in this topic, take it!

Professor Thompson is a really engaging professor and the material is very interesting. The material is easy to understand and Professor Thompson does a good job of making the information easy to understand.
Take notes on what Professor Thompson is saying, not just what the slides say.
Take this class if you would like to better understand the history of recording.  It's very music-oriented so if you enjoy music, it's definitely something to consider.

You should ABSOLUTELY take this course. The readings are fascinating and fun, and the course is accessible to everyone, not just people with extensive music background. Professor Thompson is a really wonderful teacher. 

You won't regret it.
descrip: When Thomas Edison invented the phonograph in 1877, no one, including Edison, knew what to do with the device. Over the next century Americans would engage in an ongoing dialogue with this talking machine, defining and redefining its purpose. This course will track that trajectory, from business tool to scientific instrument to music recorder to musical instrument. By listening to the history of the phonograph, and by examining the desires and experiences of phonograph users, students will perceive more generally the complex relationships that exist between a technology and the people who produce, consume, and transform it.

title: International Trade
reviews: Learn a lot about international trade!

Not bad if you need an econ elective - it's a fair, straightforward course and the professor is kind/helpful. I might be biased because I realized midway that I'm not actually that interested in trade - but if you are, you'll probably enjoy this course.
Quantitatively a little soft (from economics perspective), but gives you a general feel for how micro-foundations motivate trade models.
Take this class. Very interesting material even though its presentation in class may not be so.
The course is pretty standard economics fare. Start the problem sets a little ahead of time.
make sure you understand the concepts behind numerical problems
prereqs: WWS 300 or ECO 300, or ECO 310.
descrip: This course analyzes the causes and consequences of international trade and foreign direct investment. We investigate why nations trade,what they trade, and who gains and who loses from trade. We then study the motives for countries and organizations to restrict and regulate international trade and study the effects of such policies on economic welfare. Topics covered will include trade and growth, trade and wages, labor migration, multinationals and outsourcing, trade negotiations, regional economic integration, and trade policy in developing countries.

title: Latin: An Intensive Introduction
reviews: Don't let the "intensive" part scare you--definitely manageable and a great professor.
If you are willing to put in the effort, take this course!
Take this course. You will not regret it. That said, you WILL be spending 1-3 hours a day depending on the material. But you learn Latin really well. Plus, Kaster is the best.

You simply must take Latin while at University.  Kaster is excellent.  Do this rather than waste an extra semester on the slow introductory courses.  Turbo is not for the faint of heart though.  Vale!
descrip: This is an intensive introduction to the Latin language: LAT 103 covers the material of LAT 101-102 in a shorter time through increased class time. Students completing the course will be prepared to take LAT 105.

title: Physics of Plasma Propulsion
reviews: Discussing these topics with other students was the best way to get a grasp on the material and prepare for the final exam.
descrip: Focus of this course is on fundamental processes in plasma thrusters for spacecraft propulsion with emphasis on recent research findings. Start with a review of the fundamentals of mass, momentum & energy transport in collisional plasmas, wall effects, & collective (wave) effects, & derive a generalized Ohm's law useful for discussing various plasma thruster concepts. Move to detailed discussions of the acceleration & dissipation mechanisms in Hall thrusters, magnetoplasmadynamic thrusters, pulsed plasma thrusters, & inductive plasma thrusters, & derive expressions for the propulsive efficiencies of each of these concepts.

title: Topics in Modern Italian Cinema - The New Italian Cinema (in English)
reviews: Gaetana Maria-Puglia and Giovanni Riotta are excellent and very approachable. Their qualifications are astounding. Expect several very notable guest lecturers - authors, directors, etc.
Professor Gaetana brings in (as guest lecturers) the directors and writers whose works you watch as part of your viewings, which is very cool.
descrip: This course looks at the way Italy has expressed its cultural, political, and social individuality in major cinematic works from the 1980s to the present. Directors such as Bertolucci, Moretti, Tornatore, Ozpetek, and Benigni offer a panorama of a generation of filmmakers that has contributed to the renewal of Italian cinema. Topics will be drawn from current issues, and will include the Holocaust and questions of memory, terrorism, political violence, migration, gender ideologies, the Mafia. Emphasis on film style and techniques.

title: Advanced Electromagnetism
reviews: Do the problem sets thoughtfully and read the textbook.
Excellent course; definitely worth taking.
If you study physics, you probably need to take it.
If you're a physics major you have to take it. If you're not, you can probably find other more interesting E&M courses (maybe look at the ELE department).

If you're a physics major, you need to take this. However, even if you're not a physics major, I'd recommend it. It expands upon and clarifies many of the topics covered in PHY 104/106. The problem sets aren't terribly difficult, just make sure to give yourself enough time.
If you're taking it you probably have to. Read the textbook, it'll tell you everything you need to know.

If you're taking this course, you're probably either a physics or astro major so you don't have much choice. But I can tell you that you don't have to dread this course! You have already seen a lot of the mathematical techniques in quantum, so most of the hardest stuff you've already learned.
It is a pretty good class
Significantly better that my experience with Thermal/QM II in Fall 2013. I thought it was an overall enjoyable course, though the 12 full problem sets and two midterms were a bit tiring.
The organization of this course makes the material easy to digest. Prof. Staggs sometimes bakes pie or brings cookies to class, which is a plus.
This course goes over many standard mathematical techniques that will be useful not only in E&M but also many other areas of physics. Learn it well.

This is an important course, because the ability to readily work with E&M at a high level is useful in many areas of physics. However, it is a very mechanical course, with the problem sets often having you prove standard E&M results, without much theoretical interest.
You probably don't have a choice.  If you do, don't take it.  Purcell and 106 are a lot more fun than this class.
You probably have to take it. It's OK if you don't mind lots of integrals.
You should follow with the weekly material on time and not procrastinate; after spending sufficient time with the material, you will be in good shape to solve the problems! Recommend!
prereqs: PHY 104 or PHY 106 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Electromagnetic theory based on Maxwell's equations. Electrostatics, including boundary valve problems, dielectrics, and energy considerations leading to the Maxwell stress tensor. Magnetostatics and simple magnetic materials. Electromagnetic waves, retarded potentials and radiation. Familiarity with vector calculus is assumed.

title: Fin-de-Siecle Vienna
reviews: Freud, Klimt, Schnitzler or rather Vienna 1900 if this pivotal moment (if not seminal) of European modernism is of any interest to you then Professor Haag can almost take you there in this weekly seminar.
Take it if you would like to be intellectually stimulated by the great works of Freud, Schnitzler, Nietzsche, and Klimt! It was personally one of my favorite classes at Princeton.
This is a great course for those interested in European modernism. There is a lot of reading and the class is very much discussion-based. Be prepared to work hard.
extremely interesting and unique course material, you probably won't find another class like it!
descrip: Focusing on the Vienna metropolis at the turn of the 20th century, this seminar examines key issues in the emergence of European modernism. A booming urban center, the old capital of the Habsburg Empire was a site of innovation in architecture and the applied arts as well as theater, literature and psychology. Through the study of a broad range of both textual and visual works by Freud, Hofmannsthal, Kraus, Loos, Klimt, Herzl and others, we will discuss the complex relationship between the reshaping of urban space, new modes of sensory experience and artistic experimentation.

title: Graphic Design
reviews: I came in with essentially no experience in graphic design, and I enjoyed the class. There's quite a bit of work, but at least for me (a COS major), it was a nice break from everything else.

If you want to enjoy doing some design and learning some basics, this is good. If you want to really hone your skills and get the sort of critiques and feedback you might get from a peer designer at, say, a boutique firm, you're not going to get that. No one is going to tell you your work that week looks awful, and that's to the general detriment of the course.

Some really fun assignments, most with an emphasis on typography and text layout. Most of class consists of critiquing each other's work, so if you have a good group, that's fun. Not a HUGE amount of work during the week, but everyone expends different amounts of time into their projects. Not a ton of formal instruction/example/lecture formatted into class time. Alice is really cool and chill, knows what she's doing, and I definitely left with a better sense of typefaces/text design.
Take the course for sure. You'll discover a side of art you probably never gave much thought before. Give the assignments plenty of time, and use the feedback because it helps you to improve.

The class is very focused on typography. I personally found this very interesting, but you have to want that and prepare for it. There is very little on image illustration or color choice, and much more on typography layout and typeface choices.

This is an interesting course, a good introduction to typography. Be aware that this is a typography class, and not a general introduction to graphic design (as I was initially led to believe by the first course description). Though you will not realize it at first, this class will change the way you see much of the world - the way information is presented, street signs, typefaces, and more.
You should take it if you want to learn what graphic design is. It is amazing!
descrip: This studio course will introduce students to the essential aspects and skills of graphic design, and will analyze and discuss the increasingly vital role that non-verbal, graphic information plays in all areas of professional life, from fine art and book design to social networking and the Internet. Students in the course will explore visual organization through a series of focused, interrelated assignments dealing with composition, page layout, type design, and image. Hands on production will include an array of do-it-yourself printing and distribution technologies, from letterpress and mimeograph to photocopying and websites.

title: Environmental Chemistry of Soils
reviews: Make sure you go to lecture and pay attention to what Professor Myneni is writing down. The answers won't be given to you most of the time in the notes, but they will help your understanding of the big picture concepts as you are studying for the exams.
Take it--Satish is a great professor!  Easy course if you've taken GEO 363.
Yes. It's very easy to not really be engaged until the midterm so I would try hard to review every week, especially since there aren't any problem sets.
if you're looking for a GEO departmental, take it!
prereqs: Prerequisites: CHM 331, or any other basic chemistry course..
descrip: Focuses on the inorganic and organic constituents of aqueous, solid, and gaseous phases of soils, and fundamental chemical principles and processes governing the reactions between different constituents. The role of soil chemical processes in the major and trace element cycles, and the biogeochemical transformation of different soil contaminants will be discussed in the later parts of the course.

title: Survey of Calculus
reviews: Do all the practices problems assigned. The repetition will prove useful on the day of the test.
Do not wait until the last minute to get problem sets done. Do not miss a lecture because it is very hard to catch up on missed information.
Doing the practice problems is helpful.
Don't let the fact that this is mat102 fool you. You need to work and some of the problem sets and questions on exams are difficult.
Get to problem sessions.
Great calculus course with a committed professor.
Love Tatiana! She is really caring and tries to accommodate whatever you are going through! Great professor!
Take it!

This is the easiest math course at princeton but i wouldn't recommend taking it if you've never taken clac before because the material is not well taught. It is much better if it is just a review of calc for you

Very poorly done course (textbook is terrible)
teacher is harsh but as thorough as possible. 
grading makes no sense on hw
Work the problem-sets with other people and try not to miss lectures.
go to class, don't miss quizzes or homework and you'll be fine and have fun
i would recommend it if you want to do econ or something to do with math
only take it if you have to.
take the course. it helps to build a foundation for future math classes here at princeton
prereqs: MAT100 or equivalent..
descrip: Overview of the main topics of differential and integral calculus in one-variable: limits, derivatives and their applications (curve-sketching, optimization), integration and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, introduction to differential equations as time permits. Emphasis on concrete applications to economics, ecology, biology and social sciences.

title: From Passing to Post-Racial: American Literature on the Color Line
descrip: American literature's ambivalent relationship with racial difference has produced many of its most memorable texts. And, perhaps unsurprisingly, that ambivalence has often been figured in the conceit of the passing novel. In this seminar we read literature by white and black authors from both ends of the Jim Crow era - passing novels from the Nadir and Modernist periods, and the neo-passing novels of the so-called "post-racial" moment - to assess the once and future vitality of what Toni Morrison has called the "Afro-American presence in American literature." Readings are supplemented with contemporary critical theory.

title: Dynamical Systems
prereqs: For advanced level Juniors and Seniors. Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course in Dynamical Systems will include differentiable actions of Z or R on manifolds, with emphasis on asymptotic properties of orbits, as well as stability (KAM theory), instability (chaos), and ergodic properties.

title: Ethnographic Tradition
descrip: First in a sequence of four modules designed to train graduate students in ethnographic methods. This class introduces students to classical and contemporary works of ethnography that exemplify the contributions this method has made to sociological theory. Weekly readings are drawn from texts on topics such as the social ecology of the city, the study of the self, race and ethnicity, organizational ethnography, disasters, and social movements. Students who select to do original research papers over the course of the entire sequence begin their preparation in this class.

title: Molecular Spectroscopy
descrip: A survey of atomic and molecular energy levels and the Hamiltonians that describe them. The interaction of radiation with matter, including multiphoton effects and nano-optics. Examples include electronic and nuclear spectroscopy of molecules and crystals, electron spin resonance, microwave spectroscopy, and the uses of lasers in modern spectroscopic research.

title: Topics in Ancient History - Religion in Roman Society
reviews: A challenging, but interesting course. I'd urge those without any background in area to not be afraid of taking the course, but also know that they may be a step behind their classmates

I would strongly recommend this course to students who are VERY interested in the subject matter and who are willing to thoughtfully engage in the readings and course as a whole. I would also recommend any course McCarty ever teaches, as his enthusiasm and expertise make any subject interesting and fun.
Take it, you won't regret it. #PartyWithMcCarty
You will have literally a handful of students and a great professor.  That in and of itself is worth taking.  Just don't underestimate the reading.  It's a lot more than you'd expect.
descrip: This course will provide not only an introduction to the varieties of religious practices, concepts, and communities in the Mediterranean and Europe from 50 BC-AD 400, but using this as a foundation will explore the ways in which social change, competition, conflict, and discussion drove the development of a set of shared religious premises, although with sharply marked community boundaries, in the first three centuries AD. Broad themes covered include: the nature of religion in the ancient world, the development of ideas and identities, imperialism and the negotiation between local and pan-Mediterranean.

title: Neuroimmunology: Immune Molecules in Normal Brain Function and Neuropathology
reviews: As Professor Boulanger will say in the first week, this course is not meant to "teach" you neuroimmunology but how to read and think critically about papers, where the findings relate to neuroimmunology. If you like scientific writing/journalism, there are weekly write-ups geared for a non-science audience so this is definitely a class you should take!

Helped me understand what goes behind writing a paper, paper submitting processes, and reading a paper. Great neuro req!! Put yourself on the waiting list if that's what it takes.you might get depressed at times because you realize science isn't perfect *gasp*
I would most definitely recommend taking this course, as we explore some extremely thought provoking and interesting cutting-edge research.
I would recommend taking this course if you're at all interested in immune systems or neuroscience. If you need to take another neuroscience class for the certificate, this is an excellent choice.
Take it - you'll learn a lot both about the topic and more importantly about scientific writing and reading. It is a really useful class for improving your skills in the research area.
Take it or you're missing out.

Take this class.  Even if you do not have a strong background in MOL or immunology you will be fine as long as you put the work into it (which is not that much in comparison to some other classes).  It is really interesting and prof boulanger is really great.

This class is so great, it should be a requirement for all people who are interested in entering research, becoming doctors, science, being human beings, etc. Dr. Boulanger is a great professor, and the class discussions are so interesting. The presentation is a lot of work, but its worth taking this class.

This is a great course for NEU certificate students. I went into this class with almost no knowledge of immunology, but it's easy to learn the basics of the subject--enough to get into the readings and have a good understanding of the topics discussed in this course.
Very easy workload, which may be exactly what a second-semester senior is looking for.  If you know how to read scientific papers, do not expect to learn much from this course.
Workload is manageable but content is difficult, be prepared to spend a lot of time reading the papers each week.
Write your response papers early so you have time to review them later and see if you like the points you made and if they dug deeply enough
go to class
prereqs: MOL 214 / EEB 214 (Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology). MOL 340 (Molecular and Cellular Immunology) and MOL 348 (Cell and Developmental Biology) are not required, but would provide additional useful background, and may be taken concurrently..
descrip: In this course, we will explore the diverse and complex interactions between the brain and the immune system from the perspective of current, cutting-edge research papers. In particular, we will focus on the molecular mechanisms of these interactions and their role in brain development and function as well as their potential contributions to specific neurological disorders, including autism. In the process, students will learn to read, critically evaluate, and explain in presentations the content of articles from the primary literature.

title: Advanced Russian Reading and Conversation II
reviews: Great! Definitely recommended if you are a Russian major or certificate.
I would suggest that the students going into this class should also study grammar and vocabulary on their own time or at least be extremely comfortable with those topics.

If you took 207, take this course.  Your Russian really starts to improve here on out.

Also, go to office hours. Talk with Ksana in Russian.  She's very helpful and friendly.
prereqs: RUS 207 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of 207. Translation and discussion of the literary texts (20th-century poetry) and the poets' biographies; review of selected grammar topics; work with two movies.

title: Senior Thesis
descrip: A formal report on research involving analysis, synthesis, and design, directed toward improved understanding and resolution of a significant problem. The research is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member, and the thesis is defended by the student at a public examination before a faculty committee. The senior thesis is equivalent to a year-long study and is recorded as a double course in the Spring.

title: Beginner's Spanish II
reviews: Be sure to keep up with the work and be ready to participate in class.
Be sure to spend time studying every day so you can gradually improve on your own.
Definitely take the SPA101/102 course if you are trying to decide which language to begin at Princeton! SPA102 has been one of my favorite classes of the year.

Definitely take the course if you want to learn Spanish, and I highly recommend taking it with Professor Olander. Any advice with regards to the course would simply be to stay up to date with the daily textbook reading, online homework and written homework.
Definitely take this course with Professor Olander. She is a great teacher.
Definitely take this, but then again you have to if you want credit for 101
Do not take this class. Learn another language
Do the homework and study vocabulary and you should be fine.
Do you have a choice?
Don't be afraid to ask for clarification in English. If you fall behind, it's easy to be left behind. Also, study your vocabulary.
Enroll in the Spanish program. It's amazing
Gotta put in the work (I didn't really but that doesn't mean you shouldn't), not a bad course either way though
Have fun and make sure to make the most of each class.

I mean if you took SPA 101 you have to take 102, so it is not a question of whether the course should be recommended or not. It's just like any introductory language course: the more work you put in, the better you will do.

I recommend this course for anyone who wants to learn Spanish- you definitely will learn more. I highly recommend Professor Baranski- she's a great teacher, she makes the material fun, and she's a really nice and cool person to get to know. If you take this class, definitely take it with Professor Baranski.
I would say to take this class.

IF you have previously taken Spanish this class will be easy, and you can get an A- with a little amount of effort. If you have not taken Spanish you are at an extreme disadvantage and this class will be difficult for you.
If you get rina you're good bro
Just place out of your language.
Keep up with daily work
Know it will require a lot of time and repetition.
Language comes with time. Make sure to spend time on this class every day. Do outside readings if possible.
Make flashcards of the vocab either online or by hand and flip through them in your free time/on your way to class because there is A LOT of vocabulary.
Make sure to stay on top of vocal and grammar as you go along.

My feedback to another student taking this course would be to absolutely join. I would warn them, however, that if they are taking it for genuine interest, that they may be surrounded by students taking it only to fulfill a requirement who do not necessarily have the interest.
Not too bad of a class, unless you are trying to get an A. Take it if you want a fairly easy language requirement
Participate and you'll learn a lot
Pray you get a good professor.
Professor Baranski is such a sweetheart. She cares so much about her students!
Professor Zetterstrand is a great teacher. She really engages with the students. She really is devoted, and she made my Spanish experience fun and enjoyable.
Review the textbook daily (and do the readings) to make sure you keep up!
Rina is the best language professor I have had, and this course depends a lot on which professor you take it with.
Spanish is great. If you need to get those language credits out of the way or are generally in learning languages, I would go with Spanish!
Spend time outside of class each day to practice your language skills.
Stay on top of vocabulary words and make sure you study the grammar sections.
Stay on top of your work!
Study a lot for exams, but also have fun
Study every day and take the online practice things seriously. Also go to language tables; using the language casually reinforces what you're learning.
Take Rina's class- she is very caring and a great teacher.
Take Zetterstrand! Excellent professor.
Take it as a requirement and prepare to memorize vocabulary.
Take it for your distribution requirement. Please don't take this if you've already studied Spanish. It makes it so much harder for those who are just starting out.
Take this course it was very helpful in developing my spanish writing skills and understanding of the language.
Take this course, it is actually really interesting and going to the class everyday will allow you to learn and comprehend the material much faster than you would have thought!
This course is a good course. Not my favorite. But I am getting a language requirement out of the way.
Try to speak as much as you can during class.
Try to take Prof. Ramos.
Try to take a class with fewer people in it so you can participate more and get more attention.

While the course is organized well, it is still incredibly easy for a student to simply skirt by with minimal effort. If you truly want to improve your language skills, you're going to have to put in a lot of effort on your own end.
Yes! Especially with Slyvia.
Yes. You will learn a lot of Spanish
You learn a lot and it's fun!
You're going to have to take a language anyways, so do your best to put up with the 5 days a week. If you're not sure about professors, Olander is a good bet.
do the readings. Try and get baranski she is great and really fun
practice speaking as much as possible
study everyday
study hard
take it with this teacher if you want a fun and interactive way of learning spanish.
you have to take it, so it doesn't matter if you want to or not
you have to take it, the professor is easy but not helpful
prereqs: SPA 101. No credit given for SPA 101 unless followed by SPA 102..
descrip: The second course in the elementary Spanish sequence for students with little or no previous knowledge of the language. With its emphasis on the four basic skills (speaking, writing, reading, and listening), SPA 102 continues to provide students with the linguistic, communicative and cultural foundations to engage in basic daily life interactions in Spanish. Hispanic cultures are introduced through a variety of texts, including readings, music, art, video clips, and film. All of these sources provide the basis for classroom activities.

title: French Senior Seminar
prereqs: For senior concentrators in the Department of French and Italian only..
descrip: This course is designed to provide a formal environment for French senior concentrators to refine their command of literature, culture, and thought, as well as to foster their writing skills. In addition, the seminar helps prepare students for the department's final comprehensive examination. Major texts from the French and francophone traditions will be studied weekly, and, in addition to being discussed, will serve as bases for writing workshops. An important part of the seminar will also be dedicated to the art of translation.

title: Molecular Modeling Methods
reviews: Awesome, unique, specialized class to take. Very wide in breadth and sometimes hard to understand because much of the material  is dependent on knowledge from courses that aren't prerequisites.
It's worthwhile taking if you want to learn about molecular simulation.
Potentially interesting/useful material, but Thanos was often really difficult to understand.  Know your thermo

Pretty chill class. Seems harder than it is. I actually understood a lot of stuff that we talked about in thermo. Also you get to use hyperchem and learn a lot of interesting stuff. The math can be confusing to follow at times but its not that bad.
TAKE IT! MOLECULAR MODELING IS A COOL AND GROWING FIELD AND YOU REALLY NEED TO KNOW ABOUT IT!

Take it if you are at all interested in molecular modeling or computational chemistry. It is (generally) not tremendously demanding, and the lack of tests is a delight. If you are interested in the material and put in a decent amount of effort, I think you'll find this class quite rewarding.

Take it!  It's not terribly programming heavy, but can be if you want it to be.  Molecular modeling is a really interesting subject even if you don't have much background or interest.  Anyone who cares about CBE, chemistry, or biology can definitely get something out of this course.

Take it!!! Professor Panagiotopoulos wants to help you learn deeply. It introduces you to a broad range of ideas and tools used in molecular modelling like Monte Carlo, Molecular Dynamics, Quantum, etc. You will collaborate on home works. The final project is fun because you get to learn deeply about one thing relating to the course.
Take this class if you are a CBE major and need another departmental.  Its not too difficult and its very interesting.
prereqs: COS 126 or equivalent, and MAE 305 or equivalent..
descrip: This course offers an introduction to computational chem!istry and molecular simulation methods. Computational chemistry involves using quantum mechanical models to obtain the electronic structure of atoms and molecules. Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics methods use input from quantum chemistry and empirical potentials to obtain equilibrium and non-equilibrium properties of fluids and materials. As computer power continues its exponential growth, these methods find increasing applications in engineering, chemistry, physics and biology.

title: The Orientalizing Phenomenon in Greek Art and Archaeology
prereqs: Undergraduates need to receive instructor's permission to enroll..
descrip: A study of the origins, nature, and impact of Greek contact with the Near East in the Iron Age. Course examines chronology; regional variation and distribution; technology and innovation; differences across media; modes of communication and exchange; patterns of consumption and display; and the social function of the "exotic." Analyzed with a view to changes and developments in settlement and society, particularly migration, colonization, social stratification, and the rise of the polis.

title: The Western Way of War
reviews: A. This is a great class to PDF. There are only three writing assignments (~1000 words each) spaced over an entire semester and a reasonable midterm. Professor Centeno is fun to listen to.
Be prepared to do a lot of reading. But the lectures make everything worth it.

DEFINITELY take this course.  Professor Centeno is one of the best lecturers I have taken at Princeton. I didn't think I would be interested in the topic but I came out loving the topic because Centeno is so engaging.
Definitely take it if you find it interesting, but expect a fair amount of reading and writing.

Definitely take it if you think it sounds interesting, it is worth the time and presents a very interesting view or history and war. A lot of material that can be argued, very fun to work with from a historical standpoint for future research.
Definitely take this class if you have the chance.
Do all of the readings as thoroughly as you can. Ask you preceptor about what they want to see in your memo's.
Do the reading
Do your readings and don't be afraid to participate and speak up in precept!
Dowon this is not too hard and pretty interestin
Enjoy it

Go to lecture. Professor Centeno is an amazing lecturer who loves the material and is one of the leading scholars on it. He keeps the course moving and interesting with history and sociology both highly represented.
I highly recommend this course to other students.

I think the course brings up a lot of interesting material to think about. It's enjoyable if you PDF it, but I did think that the lectures could have benefited from powerpoints or chalkboard writing. Prof. Centeno just speaks during class, and although he is an incredibly engaging speaker, I sometimes got lost in the trees and missed important pieces of the big picture.

I would advise students considering the course to be ready for a fairly substantial amount of reading. They must be aware that they are not optional and that they are indispensable to foster a learning experience in the course.

I would recommend that everyone take this course.  My advice would be to do all the readings as they are assigned because there are a lot and you do not want to get behind.  Writing skills are also very important for this class.

I would recommend this course because it can be an eye-opening experience for many students on campus. At times the professor challenges popular perceptions and some of the readings also help to break down stereotypes in this area of study.
I would strongly recommend it! Start readings early every week.

I would take it if you're interested in military affairs, but if you're just looking for a good grade and don't find the topic interesting, you might want to take something else. It's a good class to PDF if you cannot keep up with the readings though.
If you are interested in Soc or His, take this course

If you like Sociology, take this course. If you are unsure but you are going to take a Soc course to find out, probably take this course. If you don't like Soc, I don't know why you would take this course. I didn't know what to expect going in, and I was never bored in this class, but as the topic did not end up particularly interesting me, it was not my favorite. I would recommend scanning the reading list beforehand (actually pick up some of the books and flip through them) and you'll get a good idea of what you're getting yourself into. If it looks interesting, go for it.
Not all of the readings need to be read completely and thoroughly

Professor Centeno is a great lecturer. Be sure to attend class and precept - the subject matter covered is absolutely fascinating. The reading list for this class is incredibly diverse which I very much liked. The course is very reading-heavy and it can be easy to fall behind. Make sure to stay on top of readings and this will be an enjoyable class.
Stay on top of the readings; it's worth it.
TAKE IT. it's so great. anyone in any major will enjoy this course and find what it teaches relevant.
TAKE THIS CLASS! Professor Centeno is truly amazing, the readings are incredible, and the time commitment is not too bad.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!
Take it! (in the one semester remaining)
Take it! It's only being offered one more time! Professor Centeno is great, the material is fascinating, and the books are actually really really cool.
Take it. Don't miss lectures, and immediately get notes from a friend if you do miss one. Precept will probably be vital too, especially up to the midterm.
Take this course and try to do the reading. Very interesting course and I enjoyed it a lot.
Take this course! Make sure you do the readings because they are just so interesting and very clear.
Take this course!!!! Take it for the professor even if you are not interested in the material because you will find yourself more interested and engaged than you would ever think.
Take this course. Great PDF
This class is a lot of reading! Be ready for it. But really interesting.

This course has a pretty heavy reading load, but the books were very interesting in general.  The lectures were fantastic, and I learned a lot about subject with which I wasn't very familiar when I first started the class. You don't have to be a SOC major to enjoy this course.
a lot of reading but it's pretty fun
definitely a lot of reading but really interesting topic and the preceptors are great
keep up with reading and don't skip lecture, its really interesting
nothign
descrip: A historical and analytical overview of war focusing on the origins and consequences of organized violence, the experience of battle, the creation and behavior of warriors, and the future of such conflicts.

title: Questioning Post-Medium Specificity in Architecture
descrip: This course explores post-medium specificity in architecture and the potential consequences for architectural thinking (a.k.a. the quote-unquote discipline) through representation. This is a design seminar with an emphasis on experimentation and the integration of diverse analytical methods. The results are hardly predictable. The format of the course will combine a seminar and design workshop - our readings/discussion are in the service of hands-on experimentation.

title: Readings in Modern Korean II
reviews: If you're looking into this course, you're probably a native speaker. If you are, TAKE THIS COURSE. It's so amazing and the professor is awesome!!!
Not a light course, but certainly worth the effort.
Take is you want to learn more about Korean literature and history in a fun way
prereqs: KOR 402 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course is designed: to advance students' literacy skills to the Superior level (near native-like); to promote a deeper understanding of the Korean language, culture, society, history and literature; and to further develop their critical thinking through reading and writing in Korean. Focusing on change in the Korean language in relation to history, society, and culture, the course covers a wide range of sociolinguistic and sociocultural issues through various media resources as well as documents written in Middle Korean, literary short stories and poems, traditional and modern.

title: Research Seminar
descrip: Enrolled graduate students in residence will attend one of these seminars each year and present their research. First-year students sign up for 593; second-year students for 594; third-year students for 595; and fourth-year students for 596. The seminars are offered in four fields: political philosophy, comparative politics, American politics, and international relations.

title: Introduction to Graph Theory
reviews: Do not take this course. The curve is brutal. Average above 90% easily.
Go to all the lectures, it's worth it! Also, be careful on the homework, as grading is harsh.

If you're interested in a more theoretical look at Computer Science, or just think this material looks interesting, I would recommend the course. It is not too much work (compared to other math classes), and Seymour is a clear lecturer and an important figure in the field.
Work with others on problem sets.
You learn a ton in this course and I highly recommend it if youre interested in graph theory!
take it to learn graph theory. seymour is a boss.
prereqs: MAT 202 or 204 or 217 or equivalent..
descrip: The fundamental theorems and algorithms of graph theory. Topics include: connectivity, matchings, graph coloring, planarity, the four-color theorem, extremal problems, network flows, and related algorithms.

title: Advanced Persian: Iran through Film
reviews: Persian is one of the best and most interesting languages to learn, and if anyone is in an intermediate level of Persian, they should take this course.
Take it!
This class will really open your eyes about Iranian society and is also very good for improving your Persian!
This is a great, rewarding class and the movies will challenge you to think about Iran in new ways
prereqs: Successful completion of PER 105, or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will engage students thoughtfully with modern Iranian society and politics through documentaries. Each week, students will watch a documentary and prepare for a lively in-class discussion of the issues. Students will be heavily exposed to colloquial Persian.

title: Sedimentology
prereqs: MAT 104, PHY 103, CHM 201 or equivalent..
descrip: This course presents a treatment of the physical and chemical processes that shape Earth's surface, such as solar radiation, deformation of the solid Earth, and the flow of water (vapor, liquid, and solid) under the influence of gravity. In particular, the generation, transport, and preservation of sediment in response to these processes is studied in order to better read stories of Earth history in the geologic record and to better understand processes involved in modern and ancient environmental change. Taught in parallel with GEO 370.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture II: Literature and the Arts
reviews: Be prepared to work really hard. Don't let feedback get you down - just try your best. It'll really help you in the future.

Definitely take this class! It will be the best class you take in your Freshman year. Doing both semesters was an amazing experience. It is a lot of reading but it is all stuff that you should read at some point anyway and you should try and keep up with it to make the most of the class and precept. Go to the lectures because all the professor are absolutely amazing and go to office hours!

Do it, if you are genuinely interested in the material. Changed my thinking. Won't necessarily feel worth it until the end of fall semester - but when it hits you how much you've covered, and how much you've grown, it's staggering.
Don't take hum if you are unwilling to learn about the works outside the lectures and precepts.

HUM requires a lot of time and effort, but it's absolutely worth it. This course was the best part of my freshman year, and I wish a HUM 220/221 were offered for sophomores. This class gives you a strong community of students and puts you in contact with lots of incredible professors. Take it!

I learned about this sequence and felt a strong desire and drive to do it. If you feel the same way DO IT. You won't regret it. You'll come away feeling more enlightened, better equipped to do close readings and essays, enriched from your interactions with students and professors, and completely in awe of having done it all! TL;DR SUPER REWARDING. DO IT.
See other evaluation for HUM 219!
Take this course if you are genuinely interested in completing and discussing the readings. However, do bear in mind- there are quite a few of them!

The texts that you read in the second semester of HUM are fascinating and so much closer to the modern world that you really can see the evolution of ideas to the modern day. It is a wonderful opportunity to read these great books and discuss them with an amazing bunch of students and professors.
You will not sleep but it will be SO worth it.
you get in what you put out, if you don't do the readings, you will not enjoy lectures or precepts as much
prereqs: Students who have not completed HUM 216-217 should submit an application (see the Humanities Council website) with a letter describing their interest in taking 218-219 and their background in classical, biblical and medieval studies. Deadline is December 6 for notification by December 10..
descrip: This team-taught double credit course is the second half of an intensive four-course, interdisciplinary introduction to Western culture that includes history, religion, philosophy, literature and the arts. It examines European texts, works of art and music from the Renaissance to the modern period. Readings and discussions are complemented by films, concerts, museum visits and special events. Although most students will have already taken 216 - 217, it is possible for students to join at this point if they have a strong background in antiquity and the Middle Ages.

title: Religion and Public Life
descrip: Presentation and critical discussion of empirical research in progress by participants. Focuses on the use of social science methods in the study of religion and on applications of recently published work about religion and society. Includes an emphasis on religion and public policy in the U. S. and in comparative perspective.

title: Algebraic Geometry
reviews: Do all of the extra credit.

If you're interested in classical algebraic geometry, this is the course for you.  I would recommend studying up some commutative algebra beforehand, but other than that you'll get everything from class.

It's worth taking if you're interested in pursuing algebraic geometry further. While the class focuses on the classical version of the subject, this builds important intuition for the modern (scheme-theoretic) treatment.
Take it with Fulger, and take any course if Fulger teaches it. He's cool, chill, and very helpful!!
Take this class if you like pure math.
The class discusses some interesting topics such as Bezout's theorem which are good to know.
descrip: Introduction to affine and projective algebraic varieties over fields.

title: Sedimentology
reviews: A: Seds is a tremendously difficult course that will consume much of your life. Each of the problem sets requires some 20 hours, not counting the time it takes to learn mandatory programs like matlab, latex, and illustrator. The trip is fun, but the subsequent lab work and presentation will dominate the second half of the semester. This is almost certainly the most difficult GEO course, and easily on par with any other Princeton course (think MAT 215). However, Adam is an awesome professor who will help IF you put the time in. You won't be babied, but you can expect to be enabled to meet absurdly high expectations. Adam is arguably the best lecturer in GEO. If your a major, definitely take this as either a sophomore or a junior. It is of fundamental importance for understanding Earth and rocks. With respect to subject material, this course is both an introduction to Earth systems and to sedimentology. The class covers everything from Earth's radiative energy balance through atmospheric and oceanic circulation, sand dune migration, basin formation, and glaciers. Because the class covers so much and people enter with radically different specialities, be prepared to do poorly. This is definitely not a class that will help your GPA. However, you will learn a massive amount.

Adam is a great professor, who genuinely cares about his students and spends a great deal of time organizing this course. You will learn skills (Matlab, Latex) that are important to any scientist, and the field trip is a once in a lifetime opportunity. But be warned: the workload in this class is infamously high - however the more you put into this class, the more you will get out of it, and you will learn an incredible amount in this class.

Adam is endlessly anal. He is also tirelessly interested in the development of his students as scientists. This makes him an excellent professor. This course is both fulfilling and frustrating. Don't take this course if you don't want to dig into an exhausting learning experience. Do take this course if you want to suffer with a small group of students and take your work closer to a professional level.
Don't sign up because of the field trip.

If you do not have a background in engineering, you may find this course to be difficult to follow.  New concepts and equations are introduced rapidly and without much build up.  For those who have the background or are particularly fast learners, this can be a fun, engaging class.

ONLY IF YOU WANT TO WORK HARDER THAN YOU EVER HAVE then this course is amazing. You're working your butt off for all of the right reasons and learning an amazing amount of new skills/concepts in the 12 weeks. But its tough, very tough.

THis class is super, super, super intense. Be prepared to spend 15-30 hours on a pset. Sometimes a pset goes fast, but typically it doesn't.!  Be prepared to go on all the field trips and be fully committed. This class will take over your life. But in a great way.

This is the type of class you come to Princeton to take.  It is challenging, engaging, fun, and rewarding.  Adam is an amazing professor who really prioritizes teaching.  He is always available to answer questions and explain difficult concepts and I think he has the fastest email response time of anyone I know.  The class fosters an amazing community that really enables every individual to succeed.  I put a lot of time into this class but I loved (almost) every minute of it.  It is really difficult and the workload should not be underestimated.  Be prepared to work on the problem sets for a few hours every day and then some, but if you start early and work in groups then they are manageable and are great learning tools.  Overall Sedimentology is an amazing class that you should take if you have the opportunity.
take it! you will learn a lot
prereqs: MAT 104, PHY 103, CHM 201 or equivalent..
descrip: This course presents a treatment of the physical and chemical processes that shape Earth's surface, such as solar radiation, deformation of the solid Earth, and the flow of water (vapor, liquid, and solid) under the influence of gravity. In particular,the generation, transport, and preservation of sediment in response to these processes is studied in order to better read stories of Earth history in the geologic record and to better understand processes involved in modern and ancient environmental change.

title: Latin America's Colonial History: A Global Perspective
reviews: At the beginning of the semester, find all the readings that are not on Blackboard from the library or Borrow Direct so that you are not struggling to get ahold of them a couple of days before class.

Don't lose that opportunity.
Important course, reading and experience to students in different fields, like anthropology, literature, philosophy, etc.
Only if highly interested in the materials, professor and readings?do your research before signing up.
Take it if you want to work hard. You will engage with the colonial archive but will have plenty of freedom to bring your own interests to the paper.
Take this course even if it's not your field. It's made to be useful for everyone, and it is.
prereqs: The course will be taught in Spanish..
descrip: A fresh look at Latin America's colonial period under the new lens of global history. The course uses the theories of Chakrabarti, Sloterdijk and others to understand the global flows linking Medieval Europe, the Americas, and other parts of the world. How was history written in the 16th century? How did Europeans arrive at an understanding of non-Christian traditions?

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences II
reviews: NA
Same as 233
See ISC 233
See previous evaluation.
See reviews for 233.
Take it for the friends you make.
prereqs: Familiarity with calculus at the level of MAT 103/104 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses. Students must have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231 and 232 in the Fall..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year long, four course sequence is a multi-disciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: W. Bialek, T. Gregor, J. Shaevitz (PHY); P. Debenedetti (CBE); H. Yang (CHM); O. Troyanskaya (COS); E. Wieschaus (MOL); C. Broedersz, J. Gadd, A. Leifer, B. Machta (LSI). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session each week.

title: Architecture, Cities and Nature
reviews: Take any opportunity you may have to study with Stan Allen.  The course addresses subject areas slightly outside what is typically considered in other courses within the SoA, so it is quite refreshing.  Pick a final paper topic early in the semester and meet with Stan to develop your idea.
The class is an opportunity to further explore your interests, somehow within the context of nature and urbanism, and use the professor's prolific knowledge base as a sort of sounding board.
You will learn a lot from Stan.
prereqs: Undergraduates with permission of instructor only.
descrip: The seminar looks at the history of the city from the 19th century to the present through the lens of landscape and nature. This includes material on the history of landscape and theories of nature as well as the literature of urbanism. Topics covered include reactions to industrialization in the 19th century, the City Beautiful and the Garden City movements, the modernist city, landscape architecture, post-war suburban development, the rise of the environmental movement, and the emergence of Landscape Urbanism in the late 1990's. Close readings of plans, projects and buildings complement readings and in-class discussions.

title: Black Popular Music Culture
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of hard work and reading but if you are truly interested in learned more about this topic, then I would definitely take this class.
Do the readings, obviously.
Don't get behind on readings and try to get some music and black history background.
Don't take it if you aren't really interested in black popular music.
Don't take this class if you don't want to do a good about of reading and writing.  this isn't an easy course. it's demanding
It's a really fun course to take and it counts towards the AAS certificate and covers the LA requirement.
Make sure you do the readings. You really can't slack off in this course. You can't. So don't.

NEVER take this class. You don't talk about popular music but more so black historical music figures. We didn't get to the 70's  until two weeks left to go in the class....the take home assignments were both absolutely ABSURD. The professors took themselves and the material too seriously. Not an easy OR interesting class
Take It
Take it!
Take it!!!!

There are a lot of readings (but you don't REALLY have to do them all - a thorough skim is more than enough to familiarize yourself with the material). This is one of the best classes I have taken at Princeton - don't miss out!
This course will change the way you think about music and what "black" really means. Be prepared to work hard, but it will be worth it.

This is a great class about music. A knowledge of musicology is not needed, but it certainly would help. This offers a great perspective on American cultures and subcultures. It is challenging but worth it.
descrip: An introduction to major historical, theoretical, performative, and aesthetic movements and trends in black popular music culture from the 19th century through the present day.

title: Energy Conversion and the Environment: Transportation Applications
reviews: A must take.  Professor Mueller is one of the best professors you'll come across in the MAE department.  Highly recommend over rockets.

Be prepared to put quite a bit of time into your problem sets and to have EXTREME time pressure on the midterm/final. That being said, Professor Mueller is absolutely amazing, and this was hands down one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton.

Definitely take if Mueller is teaching. Very interesting course covering engines and jets. Keep up with the material. Psets are medium length and generally interesting, leading to a very reasonable weekly time commitment.

Definitely the most practical MAE class I have taken thus far.  I enjoyed the conceptual learning of how engines operate.  The long equations and thermodynamic derivations, not so much.  Problem sets take a long time and can be tedious.  Mueller is a boss though - he's young, funny, and extremely willing to help you out.

Go to class and pay attention and write down everything! You'll be thankful later when you're studying for the exam. Know the lecture notes inside and out for the exam and you'll be good to go. If you don't go to class, find a way to get the completed lecture slides from friends or Mueller's office hours - but do this every week to avoid the pre-exam scramble of gathering lecture notes!! It'll also help you keep up with the material much better.
Great course.  You will learn all you need to know about engines.
It's a difficult class but the material is fascinating and the professor is really cool.

Know that this course if NOT an easy course. If you do take this course it will be a lot of work. 
That being said its very rewarding and worth your time. 
If you have the time and dedication to take this course then I highly recommend it.
Take this class--Mueller is the best professor in the department!
Take this course if you like engines and turbines.

Take this course if you think you may be interested in how engines work, and you have the necessary time and work ethic to invest in the class. Do the problem sets with a group and go to office hours to get the homework done quicker; office hours really help because the instructors actually help you solve problems, unlike in some other courses.
