Print out 6 lecture slides per page (not only one or two)! It really helps you see the bigger picture and tie together course concepts - and definitely aided my learning. In the end, if you invest the necessary effort, you'll be glad you took this course. Prof. M is awesome!
Take this course. Mueller is fantastic and this was the best departmental I've taken in MAE, speaking as a senior.

You probably have to take this. It's this or rockets, and I don't know much about rockets. I don't know what to tell you. This isn't the hardest MAE class but it's tough because there's just so much material you're expected to know. Exams suck.
do it.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222 or equivalent, or by permission of instructor..
descrip: Overview of energy utilization in and environmental impacts of propulsion systems for ground and air transportation. Roughly half of the course will be devoted to reciprocating engines for ground transportation, and the other half of the course will be devoted to gas turbine engines for air transportation. The course will focus on device efficiency/performance and emissions with future outlooks for improvements in these areas including alternative fuels and alternative device concepts. Relevant thermodynamics, chemistry, fluid mechanics, and combustion fundamentals will be reviewed or introduced and will permeate the course material.

title: Seminar in American Politics - Gender and American Politics
reviews: Definitely take if you are interested in the subject!!!!!!

Excellent course that really opened my eyes to many gender issues on our campus and around the country.  I think every Princeton student should be required to take a gender studies course.  Also, the school board research project component of this class was a great chance to explore independent research questions through a collaborative project.  Professor Mendelberg was great.

I highly recommend this class- the material as presented in the readings and in class discussions is interesting, Professor Mendelberg is a great facilitator of discussion and has a lot of expertise on the subject given her own forthcoming book, and the final paper (despite some of its logistical challenges) produced findings that were interesting given the readings we had done. I also think that Lauren was a great resource in the class, especially in terms of giving feedback on papers- I would highly recommend making appointments with her and talking about your paper- I made two appointments with her and found each of them extremely helpful.
I highly recommend this course for anyone who's interested in government or politics (especially at the local level) and who likes talking about gender dynamics.
Make sure to do the readings and stay on top of the workload.
Prof. Mendelberg is GREAT. Definitely take a course with her if you are interested in gender and race!
Take it, but beware of the final research paper. It is very time consuming and was logistically hard to collect research by attending school board meetings.
Take it. Great department for POL and a great course for anyone interested in gender and politics.
descrip: This course examines the intersection of gender and politics in the United States.

title: Race, Gender, and Representation
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Princeton Atelier - Journey Beyond the West: Monkey - A Martial Arts Opera
reviews: A big time commitment during tech week but super fun!
Do it.
If Monkey is ever put on at Princeton (all the other acts) and you have any interest in dance/theater at all, you should take it, and you will not be disappointed.
If this is ever offered again, yes yes a thousand times yes.
OMG. Take this.

Practice the forms as part of your weekly exercise routine. Also, make sure you put power and speed into all your moves, because those aspects make a huge difference in how clean your movements look in martial arts.
Take it if anything like this happens again!
Take it! It's a really unique opportunity at Princeton, unlike anything else you'll experience.
Take this course.
This is the best course I've taken at Princeton.
take it!
prereqs: Students interested in Asian American performance, Martial Arts, Jazz, and Chinese theater are encouraged to apply. This course is designed for martial artists of all styles, acrobats and dancers. Applications are required. For applications and more information, please see the Princeton Atelier course web page..
descrip: In this course students will create a performance of composer Fred Ho's adaptation of the 16th century Chinese novel Journey to the West, an action-adventure musical fantasy told through music, martial arts, and dance. This modern take on a classic tale blends Asian and popular American influences: Peking Opera with jazz and funk; and martial arts with acrobatics, and contemporary dance. Students will train in T'ai Chi, Long Fist, Dragon Fist, Bagua, and Wu Shu; and the fight choreography will draw from Rattan Staff Play, Shaolin Boxing, and Qing Na forms. The 35-minute piece will be performed at the Berlind Theater the week of April 14th.

title: Research Methods in Demography
reviews: Computations in demography are mostly arithmetical; hence, practice makes perfect!

This is a very theoretical approach of a class. If you are very interested in learning about quantitative demography, take it. However, I feel that it could be presented in a more understandable and comprehensive manner.
You should take it if you want to learn the material.
prereqs: POP 501/ECO 571/SOC 531 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Source materials used in the study of population; standard procedures for the measurement of fertility, mortality, natural increase, migration, and nuptiality; and uses of model life tables and stable population analysis and other techniques of estimation when faced with inaccurate or incomplete data are studied.

title: Topics in German Culture and Society - Was ist deutsch?
reviews: Be careful on your response papers. Grading can be tough.

Do the readings thoroughly and go to every class - you won't regret it. Make sure to take the weekly papers seriously - They stimulate your independent thinking and Professor Saman's feedback is also very helpful!
Go for it. You'll get better at German, and, maybe, just maybe, you'll figure out "was ist deutsch." (actually you probably won't, but that's kinda the point).
Make sure you do all the readings to get a good background before the lecture.

Professor Saman is very understanding. The readings are hard, but there is guidance. Not too much work, probably 5 to 6 hours of work/reading per week. I loved the material though, very good if you like thinking about identity.
descrip: German culture, German identity, German history, the German nation -- these are complex, controversial, and problematic notions. This course critically explores the history, the ideologies, and the impacts of these questions up to the present day.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research (Half-Term)
reviews: Take the initiative to be engaged in the discussions if you plan to get something good out of the course.
descrip: This course will cover the essential topics of what constitutes responsible conduct in research.

title: Tragedy
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Experiencing India through Bollywood
descrip: See website

title: Introduction to Cognitive Neuroscience
reviews: Do not take this class unless you intend to complete the neuroscience program. It just is not worth having to sit through long, boring lectures that will sap your interest in the subject matter.
Don't take lab unless you regularly enjoy practices of self flagellation
Go to lecture!
Go to lectures and the take detailed notes. Do the readings.

HIGHLY recommend this class. Professor Botvinick is professional and brilliant with a great sense of humor, and the material for this class is really cool. Also, just TAKE THE LAB. I put that in all caps for a reason! The lab requires little work outside of the three hour lab slot, and the stuff you get to do is incredibly cool (EEG, fMRI, computational modeling).
I would suggest recording lecture for this course-while the information was interesting, it was also very dense, and requires you to listen to it a few times.

Split up the readings between friends so that you each outline about a chapter and don't have to waste time reading because it only appears for a few questions on the exams. Go to lectures and take notes directly on the slides (on your laptop, save the trees) because otherwise your notes may seem scattered
Study early if you can! Seeing as that this class deals with the brain, there is a lot of complex information and detail. Memorization is key!
Study seriously for the midterm.
Take if you like cognitive neuroscience.
Take it if you want to put in the work.

Take this course if you're doing the neuro certificate (you have to...), but don't take it otherwise.  The material (by necessity, because cognitive neuroscience is a young field) is pretty disjoint and not at all cohesive.  I had trouble paying attention during lecture, which is unfortunate, because, as in NEU 258, everything in lecture can show up on an exam.

It probably should have been advertised better that the lab involved MATLAB programming.  I liked it, because I'm a computer science major, but other people struggled.

The labs are great for learning some basic matlab...to a certain extent. You do get more in depth into the methods of neuroscience (EEG, MRI, data analysis) than you otherwise would, but the grading of mini lab reports is too tough and seemingly arbitrary (that is, grades don't correlate with effort, and they give you no criteria upon which they grade your reports--it's all still a black box)
The readings take a longggg time
Prof. Botvinick grew on me. This is a survey course so it goes really fast though.
The lecture slides are difficult to parse if you aren't there. But otherwise, you don't really need to be there. Though you'd like to be.

The lectures are key. Go to lecture, take notes and be a 100% attentive. The instructor is terrific and incredibly responsive to students, so do go up after lecture and ask questions. Use Piazza before exams!

This is a pretty interesting course. But don't expect a ton of super exciting, definitive findings. One of the biggest takeaways I've had is that we don't really know much about the brain... But we do learn some really cool stuff. Also, I definitely recommend the lab portion. We did some really cool things in lab and the outside work is all pretty chill.
prereqs: NEU/PSY 258 or permission of instructor.
descrip: An introduction to cognitive brain functions, including higher perceptual functions, attention and selective perception, systems for short- and long-term memory, language, cerebral lateralization, motor control, executive functions of the frontal lobe, cognitive development and plasticity. Major neuropsychological syndromes (e.g., agnosia, amnesia) will be discussed.

title: Conservation Biology
reviews: Honestly, don't take this course unless you have to. There are better, more interesting EEB courses out there. If you have previous experience in R, the practical portion of this class may be easy for you.

I think you need to make sure you are interested in conservation biology because otherwise you might be bored. However, I thought for someone interested in conversation biology, the class was excellent. It's also very little work.
I would recommend it.

I would recommend this course to EEB majors looking for a solid departmental, but not necessarily to non-majors.  It's not all that difficult (though the problem sets were R-based and could be challenging) but it's also not super engaging.  In essence, don't make it your first choice departmental, but if you need an extra/have already taken most of the others, it's fine.
Not a good course; do not take unless you are REALLY interested in Conservation Biology.
Take this class.  The R is pretty easy and concepts are very relevant.
Take this if you are interested in the subject. You don't need a science background to do well. Be prepared for boring lectures, but the work is not too difficult.
prereqs: EEB 211.
descrip: An in-depth exposure to topics in conservation biology emphasizing the application of scientific concepts to our understanding of the problems that threaten endangered species and ecosystems. Topics include island biogeography, population genetics and viability, landscape ecology, reserve design, and endangered species recovery. To a lesser degree, this course will address some of the political, economic, and cultural aspects of conservation.

title: A History of Early Modern Japanese Thought: An "Ecological" Approach
descrip: This seminar introduces the history, texts, and ideas developed by Tokugawa-period thinkers. A selection of primary and secondary sources, both in English and Japanese, help students familiarize with the terminology, issues and problems of early modern Japanese thought, with the social conditions and organization of intellectual production, and with the changing interpretative paradigms in the intellectual historiography of the last sixty years.

title: Third-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Be aware that getting As in Chinese is a lot of effort. That being said, 303/304 are a lot more interesting than the 100- and 200-level courses. If you took 303, this course is basically identical.
Challenging class, lots of work and memorization. Can be frustrating because your Chinese won't progress super quickly.

I don't think I really improved in terms of my speaking or writing abilities since PiB. Also, I probably knew more characters last year than now, because we are not required to write in characters anymore.
If you are interested in learning Chinese, definitely pursue it until this level, because in 304 you really start to learn how to have intelligent conversations with native speakers.
If you like the language, take it but be prepared to work!

If you're trying to decided whether to continue with Chinese after 2nd year, I'd say continue until at least 3rd year. I had a great experience but you have to be willing to put in the effort in the assignments (there are more oral assignments like debates and presentations), studying for exams (they are more difficult than the past 2 years), and LEARNING CHINESE.
It's a serious workload, make sure you are taking Chinese to learn Chinese, and not for the grade.
Much of the same of second year, but more newspaper articles. Definitely important to continue taking it to keep up speaking skills (don't think you can depend on just going to language tables!)

Only take this class if you are personally invested in learning chinese and interested in cross-cultural comparisons and other advanced topics in chinese. Work is very manageable if you set aside a little time every day
Only take this course if you are really interested in Chinese or trying to get the certificate. Chinese at Princeton is really time consuming.

Practice writing characters, even though you won't be docked points for pinyin. Study a little bit every day. 3rd year Chinese is frustrating because you're not on such a steep learning curve anymore, so sometimes it feels like you're not making any progress at all.
Take it if you are willing to study!
This course is a lot of time, but very good.
prereqs: CHI 303 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of CHI 303, designed to improve the student's facility in written and oral expression through a close study of newspaper essays and commentaries.

title: Ecology and Epidemiology of Parasites and Infectious Diseases
reviews: Definitely go to Panama! This course is a lot more instructive than the other courses (there are quizzes, small write-ups, etc.). I liked some of the other courses more, but that may be because of the timing of this course and the fact that I'm more interested in the other subject matter.
Go to Panama!  This course to me covered the most interesting topics.
I highly recommend all EEB students take one of the field semesters if at all possible. Amazing.
Really take advantage of the modeling component! It was very helpful and educational! Also, start thinking of experiments early on.
The course certainly teaches you a lot about disease ecology. It wasn't my favorite class, but it wasn't my least favorite either.
knowing stats ahead of time will help you a lot, but it's not necessary. i recommend doing a modeling project instead of experimental stuff.
prereqs: EEB 321 and enrollment in the EEB Spring semester in tropical biology taught in Panama..
descrip: An introduction to the biology of viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa, worms, arthropods, and parasitic plants. The major emphasis will be on the parasites of animals and plants, with further study of the epidemiology of infectious diseases in human populations. Studies of AIDS, anthrax, and worms, and their role in human history will be complemented by ecological and evolutionary studies of fig wasps, measles, myxomatosis, and communities of parasitic helminths. The course combines lectures with daily field laboratories to explore the dynamics and abundance of parasite in a variety of host species in the Panama Canal zone.

title: Literature of the American Renaissance, 1820-1860
reviews: An intense study of the American renaissance that students seriously interested in the time period should take
I highly recommend this course. The readings are interesting and Professor Mitchell is amazing. He might be the best professor I've had so far.
It's a great introduction to the foundations of American literature.
TAKE IT. Incredible professor. Great discussions. I loved it.

TAKE THIS COURSE if you have any interest in the material whatsoever, Lee Mitchell is an astoundingly inspiring professor and you will learn a lot both about this period and about how to read and approach literature in general
Take this class! Also, do the readings. There are some more daunting books, but they are worth it.
Take this course
Take this course!

This is a very strong course introducing you to the best works of early American Literature. Take it for a good background of the period, but the course moves too quickly--like most at Princeton-- for any deep consideration of one or two of the authors. Professor Mitchell is a good lecturer and works hard to make seminar involved and stimulating.
descrip: Close study of nine authors--the so-called literary "renaissance" of the new republic--who defined a native brand of literature that would influence all subsequent American writers. Our focus will be on narrative and poetic forms that signaled independence from older ideals, offering an exhilarating yet deeply unsettling transition in literary history.

title: Psychology for Policy Analysis and Implementation
descrip: Course covers basic concepts and experimental findings of psychology that contribute to an understanding of the effects of policy on human behavior and well-being; and psychological factors that affect the formulation, communication, and execution of policy. Topics include a descriptive analysis of boundedly rational judgment and decision making, a consideration of social motives and attitudes, and an introduction to the ways in which agents influence and negotiate with one another, including an examination of the psychological roots of conflict.

title: Modern Fiction
reviews: As an non-English major I can still say this-- this course changed my life. Best course I've ever taken at Princeton and it alone makes my experience here worthwhile more than any other class. Incredible professor, incredible class, incredible journey.
If you are interested into modern literature I would definitely recommend this course. Even if you don't think you are, there is definitely a lot to be explored in this class.

Modernist novels are tough. I would probably suggest this course only to students who are thoughtful, careful readers and are very serious about literature -- not to students who are casually coming in from other departments just to "try something different." It really is a course that demands (and deserves) to be treated with care and respect.
Reading great books and talking about them--what's not to love?
Try and read all of the novels assigned. They are all fantastic. Take this class!
descrip: The Modern movement in English fiction, from Conrad and Joyce to the present.

title: Structural Design
reviews: A new professor is needed for this course to be fruitful for students.
Maybe if you've already taken a structures class then this class is more sensible. I don't know.
Stay on top of the homework and don't put it off to the last minute.
Work with classmates
descrip: Introduction to the design of building structures of steel, timber and reinforced concrete.

title: Mathematical Methods of Engineering Analysis II
reviews: BUY Advanced Calculus Applications by Hildebrand.
Don't take it!
Had better have the background of complex analysis, PDE, ODE before

I think you may want to take mathematics class from another department if the professor still teaches the class. If you insist in taking the class, I will suggest you reading the relevant textbooks in advance.

If you don't have to take this course with this particular professor, then don't.  If you have to take this course, just hope you don't have to take it with Professor Martinelli.  He is knowledgeable and willing to talk, but he doesn't seem at all interested in you truly understanding the material, and doesn't present it well at all.

Regardless of the professor teaching this course, get the recommended readings.  They are extremely helpful and insightful into the material and will help guide you through many of the subjects of the class.  Also, try to work in groups as much as possible (really do this with any class you can) as this helps everyone come to learn the material.

My "recommend against" reply for this course is solely based on the professor.  If there was a different professor teaching it, I would likely recommend the class.
The Hildebrand "Advanced Calculus for Applications" is extremely helpful for this course.
Well, good luck.
You have to figure out all the problems by yourselves. The lectures are less helpful.
You have to take it; I hope you have a better time than I did.
not to take the math course from this professor.
teacher is smart.but it would be much better if you had taken any class related in undergrads.
descrip: A complementary presentation of theory, analytical methods, and numerical methods. The objective is to impart a set of capabilities commonly used in the research areas represented in the Department and more broadly in engineering and the physical and biological sciences. Analytical methods are emphasized, but standard computational packages are made available and some assignments are designed to use them. Topics include Complex variables, PDE, Fourier and Laplace Transforms, and a brief introduction to numerical methods for ODE and PDE.

title: Physical Optics
prereqs: PHY 104 or ELE 351..
descrip: This course presents an introduction to wave dynamics and imaging. Topics include geometrical and Fourier optics, diffraction, microscopy, photography and holography. Modern methods to beat the diffraction limit, including near-field and computational imagining, will be discussed.

title: Creative Non-Fiction
reviews: Definitely take this course.
If he teaches this course again and you get in, you must take it! No questions.
If you can, TAKE THIS COURSE. You won't regret it.
It will change your life.
McPhee gives incredible and meticulous revision notes, but never imposes his views o you.

Probably the best class I've taken at Princeton. John McPhee is legendary, and if you can get into this class, DO NOT pass up the opportunity to learn from him for a semester. The Journalism department is insanely loaded, and even as someone who may not want to be a journalism when I grow up, I felt like a huge amount of doors were opened up for me by just taking this class. The classes are interesting, because Professor McPhee tells great stories. The highlight of this course, though, are the one-on-ones you have with him every other week. I have grown so much as a writer this semester.
TAKE IT.
TAKE IT. You will never regret taking a course with the father of creative non-fiction. Your writing WILL improve with Professor McPhee's personalized feedback and attention.
Take it if you can get in. It is like a 15 percent acceptance rate I think.
Take it if you can. You'll learn from one of the best about structure, prose, description, the world of publishing... What an incredible opportunity.
Take it!
Take it.

This was the best class I've ever taken at Princeton. Seminars can be a little boring, but what's of true value are the biweekly meetings. He tears your writing apart and helps you build it back into something of worth. This class fundamentally changed the way I write, and made me want to become a writer. The personal relationship you develop with McPhee is also incredible.
This was the best course I've taken at Princeton. If you have ever considered writing as a career (or anything related to writing, or just like to write), definitely apply.
prereqs: Applications at http://humanities.princeton.edu. For the writing sample, submit whatever you consider to be your best work, from any source, written since you came to Princeton, including, if you like, a new piece written for the application..
descrip: This is a course in factual writing and what has become known as literary nonfiction, emphasizing writing assignments and including several reading assignments from the work of John McPhee and others. Enrollment is limited to 16 second-year students, by application only.

title: Electronic Commerce
reviews: E-commerce is super important and relevant to our lives today so it's worth learning more about. Be prepared for Kornhauser's unconventional teaching style and don't expect to get a straightforward course on markets and businesses and how to design one. These skills will all come together with some blood, sweat, and tears. Take the class if you're looking to hear from some cool alumni with jobs in the tech industry, perhaps a fifth class that fills some sort of distribution, and maybe to get a dose of the quirky, unabashedly obnoxious and sometimes quite insightful Kornhauser.
Easy ORFE departmental, workload is minimal, lectures are rambling. Nice complement to the other difficult ORFE classes.
Get a good partner for the assignments.

Great guest lectures, and the interesting links he shares are great reads. Pay attention to each lecture, no matter how tangential it may seem; you might very well be tested on it. Also, make sure your programming assignments look nice/engage the user. Sometimes, this matters more than actual functionality.
I would not recommend another student to take this course if they can avoid it.
Kornhauser is nuts.  Take this class if you want to listen to a dude ramble about nothing for long periods of time.
Must take course for everybody. Regardless of who you are, you're missing out if you don't take this course. I can't believe this course wasn't filled up to the max. What a crazy world we live in.
Professor Kornhauser is a very entertaining lecturer and invites many interesting guest speakers.
Sparked my interest in tech, but mostly from the guest speakers.

Take it if you're alright with a super easy class where you fly by the seat of your pants a little bit. It's not super organized but it's a good ORFE class to get one of your departmentals filled. If you're actually interested in business you might want to prioritize high tech entrepreneurship or something but this isn't a bad class. It's just weird and a little unpredictable
Take it!
Take this course if you are interested in electronic commerce; overall very straightforward!
prereqs: COS 126 or equivalent.
descrip: Electronic commerce, traditionally the buying and selling of goods using electronic technologies, extends to essentially all facets of human interaction when extended to services, particularly information. The course focuses on both the software and the hardware aspects of traditional aspects as well as the broader aspects of the creation, dissemination and human consumption electronic services. Covered will be the physical, financial and social aspects of these technologies

title: History of the American West
reviews: Absolutely take this course

Get the most out of it! It's worth prioritizing the readings for this course because even though they're extensive, I found being on the right page and being able to participate in discussions was very rewarding.

I would highly recommend this course. Prof. Sandweiss is an engaging lecturer and dedicated professor. The assignments and readings were exciting and thought-provoking and the course provided the opportunity to discover, in-depth, an oft-overlooked aspect and area of American history.

If you are at all interested in the American west, or even just American history, DEFINITELY take this class. Professor Sandweiss is a really engaging lecturer. There's really not a lot of work at all (two short papers and a final) but you should do all of the reading. The precepts are great - whether you have Sandweiss or Ronny Regev - but you will be expected to participate.
It's worth the readings and lectures to take it.
She is a very hard grader, but an interesting course.
Take it!
Take it. Great material throughout the twelve weeks.
Take this class, but only if you are willing to work very hard

Take this if you are interested in American history and are looking for a smaller, more personal class. Of all the history classes I've taken here, this has been the smallest and my favorite. Professor Sandweiss covers so many aspects of the American West in an eloquent and engaging manner, and even though the course covers a broad range of topics, it manages to do so in depth. You will definitely learn a lot about things that are not usually covered in high school American history classes. Also, the two research papers are so much fun to write because you get so much freedom in selecting your topic.
This course provided an average of two instances of blown-mind per lecture. Take it as soon as you have a relatively light-semester. There is some heavy-duty reading involved, but it is worth it.
This might be more suitable for other students but I don't think I should have taken it in hindsight.
descrip: This course examines the history of the place we now call the American West, from pre-contact to the present. Our primary focus will be on the struggles between and among peoples to control resources and political power, and to shape the ways in which western history is told. We will pay particular attention to the role of visual and popular culture in shaping the national imagination of the region.

title: Making Sense of Market Bubbles
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Irreversible Processes in Plasmas
reviews: Take this course, and read the class notes.
Take this in your second semester of grad school.
descrip: Introduction to theory of fluctuations and transport in plasma. Origins of irreversibility. Random walks, Brownian motion, and diffusion; Langevin and Fokker-Planck theory. Fluctuation-dissipation theorem; test-particle superposition principle. Statistical closure problem. Derivation of kinetic equations from BBGKY hierarchy and Klimontovich formalism; properties of plasma collision operators. Classical transport coefficients in magnetized plasmas; Onsager symmetry. Introduction to plasma turbulence, including quasilinear theory. Applications to current problems in plasma research.

title: Special Topics in Statistics and Operations Research - Probability in High Dimension
reviews: Although a little hard, it's interesting and useful.
Definitely take this course if you have the chance
Don't hesitate, and try not to miss lectures. The notes are great but the lectures are better.
I hope this course will be held next year.
If you are interested in probability you should take it. You will learn a lot.
Interesting material, great professor, fantastic lectures. If you like probability theory you should take this course.
Make sure to work on problems to get the most out of the presentation and lectures.
TAKE IT IF YOU CAN. It's incredible.
take it if you are remotely interested in any of the topics. Ramon is fantastic so you won't regret it.
prereqs: Probability at least at the level of ORF 526.
descrip: An introduction to nonasymptotic methods for the study of random structures in high dimension that arise in probability, statistics, computer science, and mathematics. Emphasis is on developing a common set of tools that has proved to be useful in different areas. Topics may include: suprema of random processes; Gaussian and Rademacher inequalities; generic chaining; entropy and combinatorial dimensions; concentration of measure; functional, transportation cost, martingale inequalities; isoperimetry; Markov semigroups, mixing times, random fields; hypercontractivity; thresholds and influences; Stein's method; selected applications.

title: Spenser
reviews: It's an eye-opening course and really worth while even if you don't know too much about Spenser.
Professor Dolven is an excellent instructor, one of the best in the department and at Princeton. Take this class! It's one of the classes where I can emerge saying I truly learned a lot.
Take if you are willing to slough through Middle English! It will be worth it!
This is a challenging course, especially for one who does not have a great understanding of the humanities in general. But the professor is great, and Spenser's poem is well worth the time.
This is a good class if you need a British foundations class or if you're interested in Spenser at all. Professor Dolven is awesome.
take it.
descrip: A seminar on the work of the poet's poet, Edmund Spenser. Emphasis will fall on his lurid, preacherly, confounding masterpiece The Faerie Queene, but we will also consider his early study of youth and ambition, The Shepheardes Calender; his sonnet sequence, The Amoretti; and selected other works. Exercises both in critical analysis and creative imitation.

title: Space System Design
reviews: Don't take this course unless you have to. The content is fascinating and that was enough to keep me in the course. However, unless this is what you want to do as a career it is probably not worth your time.
Good course! But having a large enrollment was difficult to deal with, and the overall organization made things a bit stressful and confusing at times.
I wouldn't do it, unless you're really set on learning about space system design implementations. It's a lot of hours, confusion, and frustration, and I'm not sure the end result is really worth it.

In a sentence, you design a satellite and then JPL reviews it and critiques it. If you're interested in aerospace, what more could you want? The first half of the semester is a grind, but once you start on the project, it becomes one of the best opportunities you'll get at Princeton.

Interesting class, but not as good as I would have hoped.  Project needs great improvements and more balance needs to be made between lecture material and student interaction at the beginning of the course.  Not as much connection between 341 and 342 as would have hoped.  Really only mattered for a couple subsystem teams.
It's a good course.
It's a great course, especially the project. Huge learning experience, the most real-life project I've done so far.
Solid design course. First half is concepts and problems, second half is design project. Workload steadily increases throughout the semester, so keep that in mind.
Take it! Just be prepared for the work it will require, and go into it with the knowledge that 6 weeks isn't a very long time to get such an involved project completed from start to finish.
Take this class!  One of the best courses I've taken here.

Take this if you're determined to go into the aerospace industry. There's an opportunity to get feedback from JPL and you really get to learn a lot from them. However, lectures and problem sets are a little bit unorganized, and are almost unrelated to the final project (which takes up 6 weeks out of 12).
This subject matter is interesting, but this is a HUGE time sink, especially during Reading Period and Finals Week when you have lots of other work for other classes to do.

Unless you have an unwavering passion for space design, don't take this course. If your passion for aerospace in general is questionable, don't do the aerospace track at Princeton. Honestly it's a mess and only mechanical is worthwhile. I can't speak for the Aircraft dynamics and design track, but I hear it's not much better. Stay away unless you're obsessively committed to aerospace. Bottom line, Princeton MAE needs to do better. What a disappointment.

expect to spend a lot of time on this class, but in the end it's definitely worth it. go to the guest lectures, they're interesting and give you an idea of how things work in the real world. Save the notes posted on Blackboard, they will be helpful!
prereqs: MAE 305. MAE 341 recommended or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course examines the design of a modern spacecraft or complex space system, including the space environment and its impact on design. The principals and design aspects of the structure, propulsion, power, thermal, communication, and attitude subsystems are studied. The course also introduces systems engineering, project management, manufacturing and test, mission operations, mission design, and space policy. Acting as a single project team, students will design a satellite or space system from conception to critical design review.

title: Solar Cells: Physics, Materials, and Technology
reviews: A great primer on solar cells that goes into sufficient detail to be very useful, but is still accessible.
Good intro course to solar cells. I highly recommend if you're interested in alternative energy, electronic devices and materials.
Hard, but professor and AI are there to help if needed. Read a little on solar cells so you understand the basic jargon.  That threw me off for a little.
I will definitely recommend this course to other students who are also interested in the study of solar cells.
I would strongly advise students whose interests (personal or research) involve solar energy take this class.
NA
Take it if you're interested in solar cells.
descrip: Photovoltaic materials and devices are discussed. Topics covered: solar flux distribution and spectra, photovoltaic parameters, loss mechanisms, Shockley-Queisser detailed balance approach, stability, light management, module design and various solar cell technologies, drawing distinctions between heterojunction and homojunction devices. These include crystalline Si and III-V, and thin film cells such as CIGS, CdTe, dye sensitized, and organic. The treatment of organic solar cells will be notably in-depth. Finally, we present methods to go beyond classical limits, such as intermediate band solar cells and multijunction devices.

title: Intensive Third-Year Modern Chinese II
reviews: Can't recommend this course enough. Take it for improving your Chinese, for the wonderful, warm, and funny professors, and for the friends you'll inevitably make from talking with the same small group of people 5 times a week about politics, culture, modern society, fast food, China, dating, and love.
Definitely take it. The teachers are great, workload is manageable, and the other students are awesome!
Definitely take this class. The professors are all amazing and they obviously really care about you. You also learn a lot of Chinese and at a pace you wouldn't think yourself capable of.

Definitely this course, along with 305 before, will improve reading, speaking, and writing skills in Chinese by an unimaginable amount. It's some work (preparing two lessons, three short homework essays, a quiz, and a test a week, typically) but so worth it. If already taken 305, I think this course continues the development at an even greater speed.
TAKE CHINESE HERE. Honestly, third year is more chill than 103/108. More focused on grammar and usage of new vocab, less memorization. It's a great class.
Take it if you want to improve on your chinese. It's a lot of fun and you get really close with your classmates. It is a lot of work though, but is definitely manageable!
Take it! You'll improve so much, and you'll become close with your classmates as well as teachers.
Take this course. This is the best class at Princeton. You make friends in this class
good
prereqs: CHI 305 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A continuation of 305, designed to further improve the student's facility in written and oral expression through a close study of essays published in contemporary Chinese newspapers and magazines.

title: Topics in Arithmetic Geometry - Rational Points on Curves
descrip: This course covers current topics in Arithmetic Geometry. For Fall 2013, we will cover some classical results about rational points on curves over number fields, including the Hasse principle on curves of genus 0, the Morell-Weil theorem on elliptic curves, and the Faltings' theorem on genus greater than 1. If time permits, we will discuss some recent results (and attempts) on the BSD and ABC conjectures.

title: Topics in International Relations - China's Foreign Relations
descrip: This course reviews and analyzes the foreign policy of the People's Republic of China from 1949 to the present. It examines Beijing's relations with the Soviet Union, the United States, Northeast Asia, Southeast Asia, and the Third World during the Cold War, and discusses the future of Chinese foreign policy in light of the end of the Cold War, changes in the Chinese economy, the post-Tiananmen legitimacy crisis in Beijing, and the continuing rise of Chinese power and influence in Asia and beyond.

title: Principles of Quantum Engineering
reviews: Don't let the title fool you. This is entirely a physics course. Be prepared to spend a semester doing lots of physics.

Don't take it unless you're really interested in *deriving* quantum concepts. We spent more than half the semester on forms of wave functions for every potential, 1D 2D and 3D. That's a lot of wave functions.
Take it if you're really interested and willing to put in work. It's a really good class (taught by Professor Shayegan this year).
prereqs: (PHY 103 or PHY 105) and (PHY 104 or PHY 106).
descrip: This course is designed to provide an understanding of the basic principles that govern the operation of modern solid state and optoelectronic devices. The emphasis is on fundamentals rather than applications. The major portion of the course will be devoted to quantum mechanics and statistical physics with examples from solid state and materials physics and quantum electronics. This provides the basic background needed to understand the physics of device operations and also prepares the student for more advanced courses in solid state and quantum electronics (such as ELE 441, 442 and 453). For more details, see Undergraduate Announcement.

title: Physical Oceanography
descrip: Response of the ocean to transient and steady winds and buoyancy forcing. A hierarchy of models from simple analytical to realistic numerical models is used to study the role of the waves, convection, instabilities, and other physical processes in the circulation of the oceans.

title: Studies in Religion and Philosophy - Augustine and Political Augustinianisms
descrip: Recent events and developments in political theory, theology, and the study of late antiquity have led to revived interest in Augustine's ethics and politics within the broader context of his vision of Christian life. This interdisciplinary seminar examines these developments through close reading of primary texts, including Confessions, City of God, and other major treatises, but also some very revealing sermons and letters. Attention is paid to "classical" interpretations and a variety of contemporary authors who lay claim to Augustine or wrestle with his legacy for their constructive purposes.

title: Advanced Spanish
reviews: Although this course is generally taken out of necessity, it is not something to fear or dread. By the time you reach (or are placed into) 108, you are definitely prepared.
Always read the "Gramatica Express" section at the end of each homework assignment. It'll save you time and stress when finals roll around.
Always revise and look over your written work, It can be improved even if you don't think so.
Be ready for a lot of grammar. If you just want to learn to communicate, this might not be your thing. But if you want to elevate your Spanish to a more professional level, this course will help.
Challenge yourself. Try new things with the language and take risks in participating.
Definitely helpful in learning the language; definitely a fine way in which to fulfill the language requirement.
Do all the homework, ask the professor questions if you have any, and do the most you can outside of class to become more comfortable with the language.
Do it, but make sure to keep ahead of your assignments before the cumulative grammar tests.
Even if you haven't enjoyed languages in the past, you'll probably enjoy this class.
Go to office hours for help
Gorka Bilbao is a wonderful professor. His lectures are super engaging. His class is a blast!
Have fun, talk in Spanish
I enjoyed this class and would recommend doing all the work he gives when he gives it, do not wait until the day before it is due.
I recommend participating as much as you can. You really develop your knowledge that way.

I would advise actually engaging in the course and speaking with the professor and other students in Spanish as much as possible. The class is much more helpful and enjoyable that way. Don't be shy about your accent or speaking abilities, because everyone is. Professor Villena is very fun and interesting, and willing to help with problems or language questions. Highly recommended!
I would advise students to do a thorough job on the homework.
I would advise taking this course. It helps solidify grammar and gives you practice in speaking. Also, not too stressful.
I would recommend that they only take the class if they are interested in grammar.
If you have to take this class, take it with Gorka. He is great.
Just do all of the work, be thorough with compositions / projects, study well a night or two before the exams, and you'll be fine. Seriously.
Keep on top of the grammar

Make sure to keep up with all homework assignments as they are assigned and pay attention to the grammar. Also be very careful proof reading your essays for the first draft because they are worth a lot.
Make sure you get help with papers for grammar from him beforehand, and study for tests.
Make sure you triple check all of your papers, they are graded very hard.
Monserrat is great. She grades a bit harder than other professors but I definitely feel that all aspects of my Spanish have improved greatly.
Most people don't have a choice in this one, but it's a good, interesting language class.

My first piece of advice would to remember that even though this is a language course, it is a rigorous course and requires time and dedication.  By doing the homework, you will be in much better shape for exams and studying will be far more manageable.  The big focus of Spanish at the 105 and 108 level is speaking and writing in Spanish at a high level, so be prepared to be graded critically for not only your grammar usage but also for the content and organization of your ideas.
Not too bad at all. Take it.
On the whole, Spanish 108 will improve your abilities, but not in any drastic way. If you can, take the course with Francisco Villena, he's great!
Overall, SPA108 is a very well-structured course. Also, Gorka is great!
Pick Prof. Villena as your teacher!

Professor Villena-Garrido is really helpful in class - he keeps class interesting and is very personable. Take any Spanish class with him if you can - he makes it less nerve-wracking to stumble in Spanish in class.
Stay focused as the class gets redundant
Take Francisco's class!
Take it and try to get Professor Villena-Garrido.
Take it if you have to
Take it with Monserrat.  She is super helpful and easier to understand than some professors.  She makes class interesting and fun too.
Take it!
Take it, it's really fun! Your Spanish will improve a lot and you'll learn a lot about Hispanic culture as well.
Take it--it's probably required. Try to get Profesora Monserrat.
Take the course if you love Spanish but be wary of grade deflation.
Take this class with Monserrat, she's great!
Take this course with Bores, she is the best!
Take this course! Francisco is great and you be much more confident in your Spanish by the end.
Take this course.
This is definitely one of the classes where the amount of work you put in will reflect on your grade. Don't take it for granted and write it off.
Want to learn more Spanish? Take it.
Write your compositions early, so you have a lot of time to edit!
go to office hours
i would definitely recommend taking this course it was fun enjoyable and taught me a lot
take it with professor bores. she is the best
prereqs: SPA 105 or satisfactory score on the Department's Spanish language placement test..
descrip: An advanced course that consolidates comprehension of oral and written Spanish and develops fluency and precision in speaking and writing. The course aims to broaden vocabulary and improve grammatical accuracy while providing opportunities to engage in oral and written communication. Through the interpretation and analysis of texts, images, film, paintings and songs, students will explore the Spanish speaking cultural identity in Los Angeles and Mexico City.

title: Introduction to Music
reviews: A good 5th class

Attend lectures! Professor Burnham is a really interesting person. Also, to use the study guides they give you effectively because that's what they feel is the most important material (and what they'll test on, duh).
Be prepared for a LOT of memorizing, but the material is interesting and the Prof. Burnham really cares about his subject.

Daniil Zavlunov is the bomb and if anything you should take this course just for him. He's a really great preceptor who is really funny and can relate the material to you in a super understandable fashion. Also, be warned that this isn't a music theory class but more like music history. Chances are, if you're interested in theory you'll like this class anyways.
Do the listenings and memorize the composers
Don't bother going to lecture. Memorize the glossary terms. Listen to the CD a lot. Pay attention in precept.
Don't!

Dont take if you are looking for some music theory.   All you will get out of this class is being able to identify what genre classical music is and generalize when it may have potentially been written
Even if it is time consuming, do it for the Professor.
Fun PDF course! Prof. Burham is great.
GREAT PDF class. And interesting intro to music. Burnham was awesome.
Go to lecture!

I am not sure if this was the case in previous semesters, but there was no curve for the midterm this semester. Be prepared to stay on top of the material or to P/D/F the class if necessary. The workload is not that much, so you should be able to stay on top of readings and assignments pretty easily.

If Scott Burnham is teaching, take it. He is an excellent lecturer - funny, engaging, knowledgeable, easily approachable and passionate about music - and try to get him as your preceptor, as well. The workload is nonexistent, the material is easy to understand, readings are unnecessary, and the final is extremely easy with minimal studying, BUT only if Burnham is teaching. If you have any background in music, the class will be a joke and super boring. Great for anyone remotely interested in listening to Western music from all time periods, looking for an easy 5th class/dis req, but again, only if Scott Burnham is teaching. Otherwise, you're in for a surprise.

If you are looking to take a class with barely any coursework, this is it. Only 3 very short writing assignments (~2 paragraphs each) and a 2 page concert review. If you are pdf'ing, make sure you study a decent amount for the midterm and final, it's not as easy as "clapping for credit" sounds.

If you played an instrument and have played in an orchestra before, you've probably played like half the listening IDs already which is nice. Very easy and a good survey of musical history. Don't expect it to be a theory class.

It's a good course to take for an LA requirement, especially if you're interested in music but don't have a lot of experience in theory. Theory is minimal. The main focus is on listening, learning the history, and acquiring an ear for different genres, instruments, eras, etc.
It's a music history class not a music class.
Its a good fifth course to PDF, but is not the "clapping for credit" you're expecting. You will have to study for the exams and do some assignments along the way.
KEEP THE GLOSSARY PAGES when you realize the book is useless and decide to throw it away.
My advice would be to go to the lectures. They are pretty fun if you decide to actually attend. Professor Burnham is a great lecturer.
No reservations, if you're an amateur of music history like me, definitely take it! Scott is a wonderful lecturer and role model in music in general and the preceptors are all pretty chill.
Not a BS class. If you are not musically inclined like me, this is a hard class due to listening.
Put in effort and it seems like it could be interesting
Stay up on the readings and do your concert review early.
TAKE IT! You'll learn a lot about music and it's very non-stressful. You'll look forward to coming to this class!
Take it!

Take it! As a cellist in the PUO, I was at first hesitant about taking an Introductory Music class. But Professor Burnham is simply too amazing to pass up. He is a wonderful source of knowledge and one of the kindest professors at this university. Try to get his precept!
Take the course if you have little or no music background and want to know more about the history of music.
Take this class if you have some musical background and want a chill 5th class without too much work. You'll learn some stuff too.
Take this course!

Take this course, especially if it is being taught by Burnham. He is funny and engaging, and his passion for music really shines in the Mozart and Beethoven lectures. It teaches material that all cultured people should know, but very few do - great experience!
Take this course.
Take under Scott Burnham.
This is a good course for anyone with a general musical interest. No background is required
This is a great class to P/D/F, especially if you do not have a great musical background. Professor Burnham is great and makes class a lot of fun.
This is a very interesting course, and great if you need an LA requirement.
This is not an "easy course" as many seem to think. But take it if you are interested in music.
This is probably the easiest class you can take at Princeton. Take it if you need an A, but I wouldn't describe it as a "hidden gem" humanities class that will be really interesting and relaxing.
This was the first time Scott Burnham taught the course, and I am so glad I happened to take it.  He is hilarious.  This course makes for a great balanced schedule.

Took the class because I have no music background or inclination at all. Great class to PDF. Not much work. Don't have to keep up during the semester and you'd be fine studying the few days before the final. Scott Burnham is an excellent lecturer, very engaged with the material and tries to make it exciting. Actually more of a music history class- exams consist of identifying songs by and composers by genre, era, etc.
i'd take it! good general interest for students with or without musical backgrounds
it's a pretty interesting class
take it
descrip: Music 103 is an introduction to Western Art Music (works from 1100 to the present). The course defines the basic elements of music - pitch, rhythm, melody, harmony, and form - and the historically significant styles and genres of composition. Emphasis is placed on significant premiere performances, music and politics, and music and the other arts (film, dance, literature).

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
reviews: Fun class, you get to work on projects of your choice in community service.
Take it. It's fun!
prereqs: Juniors only (except for sophomores who have completed EGR 251)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: History and Cinema: Fascism in Film
descrip: See website

title: Religion: An Anthropological Introduction
reviews: I think this course is amazing.
I would recommend this class to someone who is passionate about the topic, but if you're taking it out of passing interest or for a distribution requirement, you can probably find something better.

If you are planning to shop the course, do not make your decision based on just one session. Each class varies significantly in terms of content covered in discussions; some might be interesting to you, some might not.
Participate as much as possible in class.
Take the class if you enjoy anthropology and sociology. Realize that you're going to be doing a lot of reading, and that however much effort you put into the class, you'll get out of it.
This is a good course if you are considering anthropology- studies on religion were some of the earliest reasons for the development of the field and this is a good primer.
descrip: This course covers the basics of the anthropology of religion from its origins to the development of some new models. The course will not itemize beliefs or behaviors. Rather, by examining some of the most important works on religion, as well as some key concepts associated with religion - ritual, belief, magic, possession, symbolism, ethics - we will see how the category of religion came to be constituted in anthropology and the social sciences.

title: Linear and Convex Optimization
descrip: Topics discussed include: the simplex method and its complexity, degeneracy, duality, the revised simplex method, convex analysis, game theory, network flows, primal-dual interior point methods, first order optimality conditions, Newton's method, KKT conditions, quadratic programming, and convex optimization. A broad spectrum of applications are presented.

title: The Philosophy of Kant - Theoretical Philosophy
descrip: An examination of central themes of Kant's theoretical philosophy.

title: Beginner's Russian II
reviews: Definitely take this class. It follows up on 101 very well, picking up where it left off, and does a great job of expanding your knowledge of Russian as a language. Also, I cannot recommend Professor Pettus enough-He is absolutely brilliant at what he does, and it is always great to learn under him.
Don't fall behind, and don't be afraid to ask for help.
Good and challenging

Great introduction to the language, and starts to immerse you more in the culture and literature of Russia. Professor Pettus is a great instructor, but some TAs are definitely more helpful than others, so choose your section accordingly. Also be prepared for random nights with *way* more homework than you were expecting and exams that are occasionally *far* too long to finish (luckily, they're usually graded with this in mind).
If you took 101 then you know what you're getting into. It's the same.

If you've enjoyed RUS 101, I strongly recommend that you continue! The second semester is especially rewarding because the curriculum grounds you in all the basics of Russian grammar (case, aspect, tense, etc.). Coming out of this semester, you will be able to speak about a wide range of things, and your speaking skills will vastly improve if you put effort into oral quizzes. You will also get the chance to learn a lot more about Russian culture and history, which I found particularly exciting about this semester.
Just be engaged and participate and it's a really enjoyable and exciting class.
Learn the vocabulary and read the chapters sooner rather than later.
Make sure to go to the Monday and Friday classes for sure and learn new vocab every day!
Make sure to read the book and vocab at the end of each chapter because the exams follow each chapter very closely.

Russian is such a beautiful language that everyone should take even if they have just a slight interest! We read a lot of poetry this semester, as well as a short story by Chekhov, and it was amazing to read this kind of literature in the original text. Take this class. Mark Pettus and Elizabeth Stern are terrific teachers.
Take it--it's an engaging and rewarding class.
This course is as difficult as the language is, but that can't be helped. Russian is awesome, take it!
This is good if you want to learn Russian and have some sort of prior exposure. Try to get into Elizabeth Stern's class!

You've taken 101 so 102 is the next step! Vocabulary learning becomes easier, and patterns emerge in the grammar that make it easier to learn too! While the difficulty does increase because of new concepts, it's worth it - Russian is a beautiful language, as you know, and Mark is a great professor! You should take it!!
prereqs: RUS 101 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The objective of RUS 102 is to give a basic knowledge of Russian: basic training in speaking, reading, writing, and comprehending the Russian language in a cultural context.

title: Roman Letters
prereqs: LAT108 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This class aims to improve students' ability to read good Latin prose for both comprehension and appreciation. We will observe three masters of Roman prose - Cicero, Seneca, Pliny - as they present themselves and their society in the most immediate of all prose forms, the letter.

title: O.P.R. Seminars
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Monte Carlo Methods and Randomized Algorithms
descrip: The purpose of this course is to give an overview of Monte Carlo methods and various randomized algorithms. Emphasis is placed on trying to provide a unified viewpoint to various applications in physics, statistics and other subjects. Topics covered include: basic sampling strategies, variance reduction, analyzing MC data, global and exploration techniques, optimization and inverse problems. The course will be organized in a seminar format. The principal lecturer will lead the discussion and participants will also be involved in the presentation.

title: Industrial Organization and Public Policy II
reviews: The empirical toolbox of IO can be very useful for doing research in applied economics.
descrip: Theoretical and empirical study of the public regulation and deregulation of rate of return, prices, and entry in public utilities and franchise oligopolies. Theory and practice of antitrust policy is examined, including some elements of antitrust law. In addition, regulation of product quality, advertising, and safety is examined. This course draws heavily on material developed in 541.

title: Independent Study I
prereqs: Must fill out Independent Study form signed by Advisor & DGS. Bring signed form to Minmin Fan in E-211..
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies.

title: Transformations of the Self
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Viscous Flows and Boundary Layers
reviews: It is a great course and I enjoyed it.  Definitely read the book (by White) ahead of time, as we should with all classes.  The book gives great information and goes along well with lectures, and most questions can be clarified in class.  Talk with the Professor whenever you can to clarify, as he was very helpful.
Its ok, read as much of White as you can.
Knowing some numerical methods apriori would be advantageous.

Learn well! Dan is smart and a great professor! Would take him again for another course. Previous instantiation of the course I heard were extremely theoretical leaving the student wondering the relevance. Dan let's the student see the big picture. It was refreshing and I liked that.
NA
Start the project very early, and talk about it with someone.
The course was useful in teaching fluids concepts and as an introduction to computational fluid dynamics.
Wait to take with Howard Stone.
Wait until Howard Stone teaches it again.
descrip: An introduction to the mechanics of viscous flows. The kinematics and dynamics of viscous flows. Exact solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations. Lubrication theory. The behavior of vorticity. The boundary layer approximation. Laminar boundary layers with and without pressure gradients. Introduction to stability. Introduction to turbulence.

title: British Empiricism
descrip: An examination of the metaphysical and epistemological teachings of some central figures of the British empiricist tradition.

title: History of the Italian Language
reviews: Gather the main ideas from the readings. Do not focus too much on details.
Go to every class - Professor Weinapple is an amazing professor and such a fascinating person. Try to do - and hopefully understand - the reading, and ask as many questions as you'd like!
I would recommend doing the readings early so you can go back and read again to try to understand more.
Take it!

This course was very interesting.  The reading load can be quite demanding, especially depending on how strong you are in the language.  I definitely looked forward to this class each week, which is saying something considering it was a long seminar.
Very easy class and absolutely worth it just to hear Fiorenza talk about the Italian language and tell stories every week. Take it!
descrip: This course will deal with the development of the Italian language from the Early Middle Ages to the present. Special attention will be given to the passage from Latin to Italian from the 10th to the 14th century; to the fundamental "Questione della lingua" in the 16th-century; the establishment of Italian literary language; the problems of Standard Italian versus dialects; and the influence of foreign languages (mainly American English) in the 20th and 21st century.

title: Framing American Art
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: Nonlinear Processes in Fluids and Plasmas
reviews: For plasma students who want to do theory or simulation, this is a must class.

It really helps a lot to read the chapters about the upcoming class, as Prof Hammett always encouraged us to do. On this way you are way better prepared, already used to the Notation and can directly ask questions.
It's worth taking.
descrip: A comprehensive introduction to the theory of nonlinear phenomena in fluids and plasmas, with emphasis on turbulence and transport. Experimental phenomenology; fundamental equations, including Navier-Stokes, Vlasov, and gyrokinetic; numerical simulation techniques, including pseudo-spectral and particle-in-cell methods; coherent structures; transition to turbulence; statistical closures, including the wave kinetic equation and direct-interaction approximation; PDF methods and intermittency; variational techniques. Applications from neutral fluids, fusion plasmas, and astrophysics.

title: Comparative Ethnicity, Nationalism and Race II: Race in the Americas (Half-Term)
descrip: This is the second mini in a two-mini sequence designed especially for students who are interested in comparative Ethnicity, race and nationalism (or CERN). The first mini will be taught by Andreas Wimmer in the first half of the spring semester and students are encouraged to take both minis together. The course seeks to understand some basic literature on race and ethnicity, which has been mostly based on the U.S. case.

title: Environmental Implications of Energy Technologies
reviews: Ask for topics or practice questions for what might be on the exam because we  went into it blindly without knowing what material we would be tested on, and most people failed the midterm. He gave a makeup one anyway though, but it shows that there was a lack of communication.
Do not take this course.

Prof. Schwartz likes to hear himself talk but isn't a great lecturer. I would not recommend the course if he's teaching it. That being said, if you like the topics, I think the class has the potential to be really interesting with a different professor.
Take a different CEE course.
Take it. Kinda easy

Take this course if you are looking to learn more about energy technologies! The Professor is very interesting just to talk to. However, problem sets can be frustrating, and it might be a bit more time consuming  than you'd expect, especially with two group projects.

Take this course mainly for the topics covered - you get a good overview of the many different types of energy industries we have today. However, the lack of organization in the course may be frustrating at times.
This class was okay. I would not recommend taking it unless you're really into the energy industry.

This course was not well organized and lacked a precept section. It was difficult to understand the material without substantial research on course material, often from other universities' course websites.
good if you have no background in environmental studies, otherwise fairly boring
prereqs: CHM 201 and MAT 104 (can be taken concurrently) or permission of the instructor.
descrip: The course uses materials balance, energy balance, and life cycle assessment tools to examine the environmental impacts of energy technologies. Environmental implications include those associated with water quality, air quality, land use, and climate change. The course first builds the tools for investigating energy technologies and then examines technologies including conventional fossil fuel combustion, advanced fossil energy systems, solar, wind, geothermal, hydroelectric, and nuclear energy. The course is focused primarily on scientific and technological principles, but socioeconomic aspects are also addressed.

title: Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
reviews: Great course, especially if you have studied translation in a theoretical context.  It helps a lot in understanding what sets translations apart from each other.
Take it if you are remotely interested in translation and if you are a creative person. This class convinced me that I want poetry translation to be part of my life going forward.
This is a wonderful class--Idra is incredibly kind and supportive, and knows so much about literature, translation, and writing in general. Strongly recommend!!!
prereqs: This class is open to any student with fluency in a language in addition to English, by application only. Students apply with either 3-4 pages of original literary translation, or a paragraph explaining their interest in the course. See the Creative Writing Program webpage for application information..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students must be fluent in their chosen language.

title: Developmental Psychology
reviews: A great class to take, take it with Ozturk. She is an amazing teacher.
Absolutely take it! Go to lecture, do the readings and you should get an A. One of the only straightforward classes I've taken here.
Be present for lecture.
Be ready for only 3 exams that will determine your grade, it puts alot of pressure on each exam.
Best EC Course you will take, if you take with Ozge. Take it if she's teaching. Really recommend it. Fun and easy-going.
Best/Easiest class I've ever take here. Did 70% of the chapter readings and got an A on everything. Also the professor is the nicest lady on the campus
Chill and super easy. Not too interesting/engaging though. Take it if you want an easy A.
Could easily be taken as a fifth class. It was fun and generally interesting, but not very challenging if you already know a good deal about psychology.
Definitely take - material is interesting and workload is not too heavy. Great fifth class.
Definitely take it, especially if you're looking for an EC. You'll learn a lot about a fascinating subject, and it's a very manageable workload.
Do the book readings.
Do the reading! It's so interesting.

Don't take! Used to be a fun, interesting class, but with the new professor the whole format changed. It is a very dry course, and I did not learn anything extraordinarily interesting or useful. Choose another EC.
Easy EC!  Professor Ozturk is also really sweet and funny.  The exams just require memorization so it isn't difficult to do well, but the material wasn't always very interesting.
Easy PDF
Great course, super easy but stay vigilant to avoid deflation!
Great course. Very interesting. Light work.
I have a feeling that it largely depends on the professor. I didn't love it. However, it was easy.

I loved this class! You get to see cute videos of babies but you also learn a lot! It is almost a Parenting 101 course to some extent because it tells you all the ways bad parenting can affect a child's future. You definitely need to study for the exams (primarily lecture notes, videos and articles from precept).
I really enjoyed this course. Ozge made precepts and lectures interesting and fun to be in.
I would recommend this course to all, people interested in psychology, and those looking for a fun, engaging distribution requirement.

If Ozge Ozturk is teaching it, it's a straightforward course with very little work. Would recommend for an EC. You can PDF it if you want, but the exams are all multiple choice and fairly straightforward, so you can do well if you put in a little effort.
If Ozturk is still teaching it - very easy --> 4 exams, you get to drop your lowest, and that's your grade (plus precept). As long as you do textbook reading and study lecture slides, you'll do well

If Ozturk is the professor, I would NOT recommend taking it. She's not used to the rigor of Princeton classes, and this class was so slow-paced that I found it extremely boring. Lectures are so slow that you can do other homework and take effective notes at the same time. All the material is so intuitive that wasting time with a class is useless. It might be better with other Professors, but don't take it with Ozturk unless you just need a class to absolutely not care about at all. Even PDF-ing it would be a waste of a class slot.
If you keep up with the material, this course is very manageable.
If you want a lot of multiple choice tests, that are straight from the book take this class.
It felt to me very much like a high school course. Study for the tests and you'll be fine.
It is a fun and interesting course. Take it if you need the distribution credit.
It is a pretty easy course if you attend lecture and keep up with readings.
It is an easy course! It would be a great pdf!

It was definitely on the easier side as courses go, and a super easy PDF. Professor Ozturk is really committed to engaging students, but at the end of the day not everyone will find the material interesting.
It's a textbook course, take it if interested in the content, which is awesome!
Its a good introduction to developmental psychology, even if the lectures are a bit long
Make sure you really engage yourself in this course the get the most out of it.

Make sure you stay focused, even if things seem easy or you've "learned this in high school." Test questions often come from readings and videos, so you do actually have to read/watch all class material to do extremely well.
Make sure you watch all the videos!

My advice would be to go to all lectures. It's hard to catch up on what you miss considering the lectures were 2 hours and only once a week. The lecture slides couldn't substitute what you learned via the professor.
Overall an easy class, good for EC
PDF if you can
Pretty good class. I think this semester was peculiarly easy, but I thoroughly enjoyed it.
Professor Ozturk is a great person - extremely friendly and approachable, seems very understanding of students. I took it PDF, but either way it was not a difficult course.
Professor is very nice and is an easy grader, but the lecture is 2 hours and gets very tiresome.

READ THE TEXTBOOK. It's not badly written and sometimes, the material isn't covered in lecture. Watch ALL the videos, yes they are tested on. Overall, pretty easy EC. Not a lot of work (less than 1 hour a week for out of class work).
Read the book and study in advance.
Read the textbook and go to class!
Read the textbook material - exams are based off lecture and textbook!
Really depends on the professor. Was a very chill, easy class under Ozge Ozturk, but she was a visiting professor so that may change.
Study the text book and lectures for the tests and make sure to watch all the videos.
Such a great, interesting class! One of my favorite psychology classes at Princeton thus far.
Super easy class. Don't expect to learn that much or have your mind blown, but take it as an easy 5th class.
TAKE IT!
Take it if you are interested in the material and don't want to spend a lot of time on a class.
Take it if you don't mind taking exams every few weeks.
Take it with Professor Ozturk! Great, fun, easy!
Take it!
Take it! Easy EC! (But actually. No final...)
Take it. Probably the easiest class of all time.
Take it. Super easy, not much work, and super interesting!
Take the course, it's fun and not difficult, and you get to learn about babies!
Take this class if you want to major in Psychology. It was well worth it for me and very enlightening.
Take this class! It's so interesting!
Take this class!! Professor Ozturk is so great and you can tell she loves doing what she does :)
Take this course as a GPA booster or if you are genuinely interested in the material.
