Take this course if you are interested in psychology or learning about babies or whatever else may qualify it. It was very worth it.
Take this course if you have any interest in the subject!!
Take this course! Not too much work and very interesting.
Take this for your EC requirement. It is a fairly easy course.
Take this if you want to do absolutely nothing in the class and still do fairly well.
The course is very interesting and very applicable to life, especially if you want to be a mother. The tests are kind of hard though.
The topic is interesting, but the class is not particularly well taught. Not a bad option for an EC, but look elsewhere for a good class.
This course is fairly easy, but it's also not as interesting or engaging as it could be.
This course is perfect for every student interested in developmental psychology at all, no matter how much experience with psych one may have.
This course was very interesting. If you're interested in developmental psychology you should definitely take it. You'll do well in the class if you put in the effort and do the work.
This is a good course to take if you want to fulfill the EC requirement.
This is an excellent class to fulfill a distribution requirement or for anyone interested in psychology!
This is the easiest course I've ever taken at Princeton, and I still managed to learn something and enjoy it.
This professor was very easy. I cannot tell you what the class would be like with a different professor.
Very easy, don't skip watching videos, and at least look over the textbook briefly
Was an easy class this semester, but beware if there is someone else teaching. It might get a lot harder.
easy PDF!
descrip: A survey of human development emphasizing the nature of children's minds and experience, developmental change, and the relation between child and adult mentation. How do children at different periods in development think, feel, and experience the world around them? Students will be involved in preschool settings.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - The Eurozone Crisis and Beyond
descrip: In the second half of 2011, the crisis in the eurozone threatened to run out of control. This course discusses four themes: 1) the critiques of the concept of the eurozone prior to January 1999; 2) why the eurozone appeared a major success at its 10th anniversary, which coincided with the beginning of the global economic crisis; 3) the interconnected nature of the crisis, weak sovereigns, weak banks, and weak growth prospects; and 4) the domestic and multilateral measures to deal with the crisis. The course also considers the future of the eurozone.

title: Introduction to Psychology
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of extra unexpected work. Reading the textbook is not really necessary, but definitely attend the lectures and labs and take good notes.
Come get your easy STL. Stay for the Skittles.
DON"T TAKE IT
Definitely a very fun and interesting class. Need to make sure to reach out and ask for help if you are struggling, especially if you haven't taken a psych class before.
Definitely take this class if you want to be able to look at the world in a well-understanding and equal manner. I would HIGHLY suggest it.
Definitely take this class, but do not miss lecture - that is where the exams come from.

Definitely take this course! Professor Gould is the best! She cares about the students and she is passionate about the subject. She's not out to trick you. She wants the students to learn and love the subject as much as she does.
Do not expect the course to be easy.  Multiple choice tests can be very tricky.
Do not take this course.
Do the readings and review the lecture notes weekly.
Don't take it for an STL. Be wary of the nitpickiness of the class and grading.
Don't take it.

Dry at times, but material very organized and well-presented. Was sometimes hard to see the point of certain lab activities, but the lab reports were very straightforward and graded fairly. Exams weren't too hard in the sense that they were nearly all multiple choice and relatively short - however, doing well on the exams could be a little dicey since it often came down to small details in the course material. Since the exams were so short, just a few mistakes could really set you back.
Ew
Go to all of the lectures and read!
Go to all of the lectures and take very detailed notes.
Go to every lab and lecture.
Go to lecture and take notes!
Go to lectures and pay attention in lecture; this will help you retain the information that will be tested on the midterm and final.
Good STL class.
Great class---take it if you have time!
I would definitely recommend this course if you have never taken any other psychology classes. It is a good class to introduce you to the field.

I would recommend this class if you are not BSE and you want to fulfill your lab requirement easily. The labs are not too time consuming and the material is quite interesting. However, if you took AP Psychology in high school then you would know a lot of the information covered in the lecture portion. I would really recommend this class!
I would recommend this class to anyone who has a general interest in psychology and who needs to satisfy an STL. Professor Gould is great!
If you are a little bit interested in people, or the brain, take this class! It is a must.
If you need the distribution requirement, go for it
If you need to take an STL course, take this one!
If you took AP Psych, go ahead and take this course. Go to lecture!
If you want to learn about things you already know. Then, take this course.
If you're looking for an STL, take a real class and PDF it. PSY101 is an abject waste of time.
If you're taking it with Gould, go to the review sessions. She tells you exactly what you need to study for the test.

It's a good and fair class. Especially for students who fear or don't love the sciences this class is engaging and you'll find yourself using the knowledge that you learn in this class in your daily life.
Kinda boring, but a fine STL.
Labs are annoying but lectures and tests are really easy.
Listen to the professor, don't try to memorize every fact that is in the book about Psychology.
Make sure to pay attention in lecture.

Make sure you go to class and stay engaged.  If there is a concept you do not understand, take it upon yourself to research it further, whether that means looking it up in the book or asking the professor for clarification.
Never miss a lab!
Not the most involved or interesting class, but really easy. Take it as a lab requirement or as an easy STL.
Painless way to fill an STL!

Pretty easy way to knock out your STL. I put in absolutely 0 effort for the first half and got a B  as a midterm grade, if that gives any idea. If you put in a modicum of effort you can do well. The "labs" can be fun. Some of the material is really interesting, though most of it is just giving jargony names to phenomena you already know exist.
Read the textbook as an overview (don't read it extremely throughly because it is not as useful as reviewing lectures notes.)
Spend a lot of time on the lab reports.
Stay on top of readings and go to lecture!
Stay on top of the readings, and be prepared for lab.
Study the lecture slides in detail for the tests and you will do well.

Take it for an STL or if you are generally interested in psych - it is a little too general to be very exciting, although it does provide a solid foundation for other classes, I believe. The labs are easy and if you go to the lectures, you will be fine.
Take it for getting the STL out of the way.
Take it if you are interested; however, don't be prepared to be blown away by the class.
Take it if you want a manageable STL that teaches you basic concepts of psych and scientific methods.
Take it if you want an easy STL!
Take it if you want, but get ready to be surprised by the grades you get in lab
Take it to fulfil the STL, not much work
Take it!

Take it! It's really interesting and such knowledge is very applicable and relevant to our lives. Attend lectures and take notes, use the readings as a supplement to the lectures, ask questions and enjoy the course. Be careful of the labs though: make sure you have clarified with your TA what exactly is expected.
Take it, but don't buy the book!
Take it.  It's kinda boring and repetitive.  Lectures suck, she needs a microphone. But overall a sub decent course.
Take it. the labs are interesting and the lectures are very informative.

Take lectures and labs seriously- even though a lot of psychology can feel like "common sense," the course will be a lot more rewarding if you take the extra time to learn about the specific research and terminology that's covered in lecture.
Take really good lecture notes. Especially if you have Gould.
Take the course. Whether you need the distribution filled or not, take it. It is a great course, provides a solid base for anyone interested in psychology, and is well worth taking.
Take this course as an STL or for general interest. Not too taxing and very interesting!
Take this course for a non-hard-science STL or if you're interested in psych.

Take this course if you are both interested in psych and need to fill the distribution requirement (or even if you only need to fill the dist. req.), but based on my own experience of not enjoying the labs all that much, or finding them particularly useful, if you are able to take a different psych class without a lab, do so. At the same time, as someone who had not taken any kind of psych class previously, this class did a lot to add to my general knowledge of the subject in a way that a more streamlined class probably would not.
Take this course if you are even remotely interested in psychology. Even if you aren't, it is a great course to get the lab requirement out of the way.
Take this course. If you need an STL, this one is very low-stress, and it's super interesting in general.
Take this if you are not a science person but want an interesting STL!
The labs are interesting and the lecture material helps you understand a lot of everyday things that you overlook.

This class is not that easy, you will have to dedicate a good amount of time and effort to really get what you want out of this class. Don't just take it for the STL if you are not willing to put in a lot of work.
This course is harder than you think, and the exams require a lot of studying of factual information. The lab work and reports was pretty manageable however.
This course will give you a good, general knowledge of the field of psychology.
This is a good, basic introduction to psychology. It covers a great breadth of topics and explores the connections between research and the real world.

This is a really great STL option - it's interesting, relatively straightforward and low stress, and I actually think it enhanced my knowledge of scientific research. Prof Gould focuses more on neuroscience, which might make this course a bit different from your typical intro psych experience, but it's all very engaging.
This was not my favorite course however if you are looking for a very general introduction to psychology this is the course for you.
Use the lecture notes to study for exams. Start lab reports early.
You'd be better off taking a more specialized course. Also pay attention to who's lecturing, I've heard Comer and Turk-Brown are better.
ugh
descrip: The study of human nature from the viewpoint of psychological science. Topics range from the biological bases of human perception, thought and action to the social-psychological determinants of individual and group behavior. This course is a prerequisite for majoring in psychology and can also be used to satisfy the science and technology with laboratory general education requirement.

title: Quantum Optics
reviews: Follow the lectures notes.

I loved this course. If you are an undergraduate and have a good physics background (have taken at least one, hopefully two, quantum mechanics classes) and are interested in the quantum nature of light, then you should definitely take this. Tureci is a very good, clear lecturer and the paper and presentations at the end of the semester really let you explore modern quantum optics research.
It's a very time intensive, difficult class. Do not be fooled into thinking otherwise (as many in our year were).
Take it! But make sure you have the time to devote to really doing it right.

Take it.  You'll get way more out of it if you keep up with lectures by previewing them (with the notes on blackboard) and reviewing them (with your personal notes from lecture and the notes on blackboard).  And ask questions.  Prof. Tureci is good at answering them.
Think very carefully before choosing the final project over the oral exam.

This is an interesting but potentially difficult course. If you're at all interested in physics and are sure you have the time, you can't go wrong. Most of the homework questions are genuinely interesting rather than busywork. The grading is based entirely on problem sets and a final presentation, which was nice. Prof. Tureci and Moein were good and probably would have been helpful if I hadn't been too intimidated to approach them.

This stuff is SO COOL!  The entire semester of this class is one big beautiful story.  The problem sets are really tough, but their purpose is to fill in some of the gaps Tureci intentionally leaves in his lectures.  So you feel like you're doing meaningful work.  Also, for the final project, you write a paper about one of the important recent papers in quantum optics, and they all have material from what you learn in class!  It really makes you feel like the stuff you're learning is important.
descrip: Semiclassical field theory of light-matter interactions. Quantum theory of light, vacuum fluctuations and photons. Quantum states and coherence properties of the EM field, photon counting and interferometry. Quantum theory of light-matter interactions, Jaynes-Cummigns (JC) model. Physical realizations of JC model, case study:circuit QED. Quantum theory of damping. Resonance fluorescence. Coupled quantum non-linear systems.

title: Advanced Arabic II
reviews: Always talk to Ustadh Tarak if you have any questions or concerns. He's very willing to help out his students, and he very much wants them to succeed.
Do the readings before class; You will enjoy discussion more and derive a greater value from the course. Try and meet with Ustaadh Tarek after class, he is always available!
Take it - Tarek is a great teacher!
Take it with Tarek. He's amazing.
Take this if you're invested in learning Arabic. Tarek is fantastic.

Tarek is amazing. He is smart, funny, articulate, and always energetic. Papers are on very general topics. Once you realize that the papers are more about practicing Arabic than writing for a specific topic, you do much better. Take it with this man!!
Tarek is the best Arabic professor at Princeton.
great class, take it if Prof. Tarek is teaching it!
prereqs: ARA 301 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Study of Modern Standard Arabic at the advanced level, continued from ARA 301. Attention given to speaking, listening, reading and writing, with special emphasis on grammar and readings in a variety of authentic texts.

title: Policy Research Seminar
reviews: A required course, so my hope is that it is better organized and has better content in the future.

At first glance, this seems like (and probably is) a really good class to have. In reality, this class was, unfortunately, a terrible waste of time. I felt really bad, because both Higgins and Locke are really nice guys, and it was obvious that no one in the class was paying attention.

The quantitative section was particularly poorly designed. I don't think it was Higgins's fault, either. The issue was that almost everyone had taken WWS 200, which focused more on teaching R than teaching stats (see http://pastebin.com/raw.php?i=tbTtAV4y for gripes with WWS 200). The problem is that the methods lab's goal appears to be to teach programming to people who already know stats but don't know any programming. But because of WWS 200, everyone already knew programming and didn't know any stats! As a result, almost everything Higgins went over in lab was identical to what Ratkovic tried to go over in WWS 200. This, of course, led to disastrous results (one girl in my task force literally asked what a linear regression was about four weeks into my research seminar... and the rest of the seminar vigorously nodded and said, "yes, what's that?"). Suggestion: make WWS 200 a stats-only class with no programming, and let Higgins teach the programming in the methods lab (he's a better teacher than Ratkovic anyway).  That way, you might actually learn something in the quantitative section.

The qualitative section's grading was ridiculously arbitrary. The reason for this was that the guidelines were very unclear, and as a result, people were marked down for things that weren't on the instructions (e.g. "this was all good but you could have added a paragraph about x, so B+").

The lab assignments are supposed to theoretically help you with your JP. Unfortunately, none of them do that. Why? You take two sections: the quant and the qual. During the first section, you're too early in planning your JP to actually do anything useful. During the second section, you've already done a d

Avi is unfortunately going back to Hebrew University, so it's unlikely this will be offered again.  But I recommend writing a quantitative JP in a seminar like this if you want to do a quantitative thesis.

Be prepared to be frustrated, confused, and recognize that you will need to take a lot of initiative to get things done. I think this class structure needs a serious overhaul to really benefit WWS students.
Choose a good research seminar! Ask about the quality of the seminar professor to other students!
DO NOT TAKE IT if you can avoid it.
Do not take a research seminar with an Economics professor unless you want to write a quantitative paper - there are pros and cons to being forced to do so.
Get Prof. Davis. She knows what she's doing. In terms of method lab, pray that they come to their senses and get rid of it.
Get ready to spend a significant amount of time for this class.

I recommend you take Tienda's class.  If you want to work hard, this will really pay off.  She is dedicated, and even more so if you are.  Participate and have fun!  Research seminar is definitely way more demanding than task force in my opinion (besides task force's final presentation) so think about then when planning which semester.  Also, I would take quantitative first, because if you're not into R (coding) you're going to want to get that over with.  The methods lab usually gets out early (qual earlier than quant and with easier assignments).  Don't worry too much about the methods lab.
If you have the opportunity to have KYM as an advisor, take it. She is really helpful in the independent research process and will make you think about writing rigorous politics papers in a new way.
If you want to be coddled, go elsewhere. If you want to learn how to write serious, research-oriented policy papers, take your research seminar with Professor Tienda.
It's a requirement so doesn't matter what I put here
Methods lab is a nightmare. An utter nightmare. The lecturers, however, are very kind and helpful, but their talent is wasted on methods lab.
NA - you have to take it if you're Woody Woo
Pick a seminar you're interested in.
Prof. Meunier is one of the greatest professors you'll meet at Princeton. Take her seminar.
See written evaluation
Start researching early. Figure out what your professor wants.
Start writing drafts early.
Take the quantitative section first

The topic in the research seminar doesn't matter much, as you'll likely have enough flexibility to find something that interests you. I think it's more important to pick off of the professor teaching, and if you tend to procrastinate then Prof. Jacobs will help you chip away at the project. This will depend most on your needs and interest.
Think about a topic before you start class
This is a WWS requirement, so they must take it. I would recommend Sophie Meunier's class in particular.
Very interesting material, but organized in a jumbled, incohesive manner. Professor Yarhi-Milo only gives negative feedback
You have to take it

You have to take this if you're a WWS student, but the research seminars are poorly designed in that they don't teach the statistics you need to know in order to do JPs, and they assume we know how to do statistical computer programming when we don't know.
You have to take this, but don't expect it to be good.
no choice you have to take it
descrip: The junior policy research seminar serves to introduce departmental majors to the tools, methods, and interpretations employed in policy research and writing. Students may choose from a range of topics.

title: Composition
descrip: Emphasis will be placed upon the individual student's original work and upon the study and discussion of pieces pertinent to that work.

title: History of Anthropological Theory
reviews: It's a required course. You do learn some theory here.

Professor Clark-Deces is great! This class is best suited for and targeted at anthro majors but look forward to it if you are an anthro major and look for another class with Professor Clark-Deces if you are not!
prereqs: One course in anthropology or permission of Departmental Representative or Instructor.
descrip: We will survey the development of social anthropology as a discipline through theoretical debates related to kinship (ways in which peoples of different cultures marry and relate within and outside the family; means by which generations relate within and outside the family). We begin with discussion of what kinship means to the social anthropologist as distinct from the biologist and consider different ways to approach the subject within social anthropology itself. We will also explore how recent work on gender, person and the body have challenged and modified earlier assumptions about, for example, descent, succession and familial alliances.

title: Beginner's Italian II
reviews: Be wary that this class meets everyday, and therefore requires a lot of dedication to it.
Do it! Light workload, fun class, and it's chill.
Go to class everyday.
Great class, Teardo is the teacher to have because she makes learning a language very engaging and enjoyable.

I loved having daily homework to reinforce what we had learned in class, and it was a good balance compared to longer term assignments from other courses. Teardo especially is an enthusiastic and warm professor, but Spinazzi is also an effective teacher. If you are interested in Italian, take it!
I would highly recommend they take this class.
I would tell you to still take this course! All the other Italian teachers are awesome. I would totally do it.
If you're taking Italian as a language... well then I can't not recommend this, because you have to take it!

It is necessary to invest oneself into actively pursuing an understanding of Italian outside the course; the assignments are important, and one should commit to practicing outside of class in order to effectively contribute during the lesson.
Italian is very chill at Princeton. It's not a lot of work and the professors are marvelous! Take this if you need to choose a language!
Pay attention and go to class!
Stay on top of learning each piece. if you don't have a strong foundation its hard to move on
Take if you need to for language requirement or if you're interested in Italian.
Take it due to the fun environment of learning a possible new language with others
Take this course with Prof. Teardo. You'll learn a lot, have fun doing it, and hear a lot of funny stories about Italians.
Take this course!  It's tons of fun and you learn a lot, plus you get to learn a beautiful language!
Take this course!!!! Especially with professor Teardo.
Take with Teardo or Weinapple... stay away from Antonucci.
This is a really fun class!  It's relaxing but you learn a lot.
Try speaking as much Italian as possible!
take this class!
prereqs: ITA 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Further study of Italian grammar and syntax with increased emphasis on vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. Skills in speaking and writing (as well as understanding) modern Italian will also be further developed. Some aspects of Italian culture and civilization will be touched upon.

title: Forms of Literature - The Saga and the Medieval Imagination
reviews: A fun course on the Icelandic sagas, not read as often as they deserve.
Do all the readings, and speak up in class. If you're thinking it, and no one else has said it, don't assume everyone else is thinking it.

I think this is one of those courses that you're not sure if you want to take it until you take it. If you're considering this course because it seems kind of interesting, I would say by all means take the plunge!
If you can, take Professor Anderson's classes. I promise you won't regret it.

Take this course! Professor Anderson is a caring and brilliant professor and knows this material like no one else. The subject matter itself is so rich. I didn't know anything about sagas and do not consider myself overly enthusiastic when it comes to blood and gore, but this is not what these sagas are about. They are some of the most opaque, intuitive texts I have read. Anyone who is interested in English, or history, or just the way the human mind works should not miss out on taking this course!
prereqs: No prior knowledge of the Middle Ages, of medieval Scandinavia, or of the Old Icelandic saga is assumed. Students from outside Humanities disciplines are welcome..
descrip: The medieval Icelandic saga is the most striking and fully developed narrative form in the pre-modern West. Sagas represent and contain the terrible and terrifying, the funny and passionate, fantasizing a past time, remembering history, responding to cultural change. Positioned between fact and fantasy, these texts contain meticulous reports of the quotidian, volcanic eruptions of the marvelous, and searching treks inward. We will read key sagas in translation, illuminating a narrative tradition that survives in fabulous variety.

title: Computational Finance in C++
reviews: Absolutely. I think that doing projects in C   that would otherwise be tested in an exam in more theoretical courses is key to obtaining an MFin. I am surprised why this is not a core class.
Be prepared to do a lot of work on your own.
Careful with the pre-requisites, it's better if you do know a little bit of C   beforehand.
Depending on the lecturer, this course could be interesting.
I recommend this course since the lecture style fits me well: a rigorous math is there (but it might be abstract.) However, the instructor would go to other university next semester.....

I took this course knowing that Matt Lorig can be sloppy in his lectures. It is a big problem for students in the class that have to deal with his notational clarity or lack thereof. 

Despite this, I enjoyed the class, because the content is cool, and very practical on the job (especially if you do your coding in C   and don't slack with MATLAB). Matt does understand his material well, so if you press him, he will provide good explanations verbally. Also, Max was a bonus this year as you could really tell he put in the effort to help out.

One complaint is that the grading was not curved, so everyone got As. This ended up making those below the median happy and those above it unhappy. For those who worked harder and participated more, there was no reward.
I you plan on going into quant. finance this is a very useful course. It is accessible even for people without coding backgrounds (although that helps)
If you are willing to put in the work on the assignments and are interested in the material then this course is a great choice.

It is a great course. It looks like Matt is not going to teach it next year. However, if someone else teaches it, try your chance. It touches upon the theoretical things in class whereas the homeworks are highly applied and fun to do.
It is not a course to learn C  . You will learn about numerical methods. But they teach very important topics for finance.
Probably it would be much better if you have a very patient lecturer.
Take it, it helpful.

Taking the course as a chemical engineer with minimal background in finance, it was an interesting elective that was informative from a finance perspective and also reasonable in its challenge and workload.
The work load of this course is not very high. The course covers asset pricing theory well.

This course is very useful to those who are interested in pursuing a job in quantitative finance. You don't have to have much background in C  . You'll learn it pretty fast through the programming homeworks
steep learning curve
talk to Max--he is  a great help
prereqs: Junior & Senior enrollment by Instructor permission only--must contact instructor PRIOR to signing up.
descrip: The intent of this course is to introduce the student to the technical and algorithmic aspects of a wide spectrum of computer applications currently used in the financial industry, and to prepare the student for the development of new applications. The student will be introduced to C++, the weekly homework will involve writing C++ code, and the final project will also involve programming in the same environment.

title: Options, Futures and Financial Derivatives
reviews: Be comfortable with programming.
Definitely recommend the course
Great class to consider. There is a steep learning curve though (if still designed this way). You need to put your efforts to fully understand the subjects particularly in the second half.
Highly recommend if you are interested in derivatives/volatilities types of topics
I recommend taking the course.
I would not take this course unless you want to continue doing a PhD with a research focus on derivatives.
MFins can't afford to graduate without knowing about derivatives. No stocal required.
Take it if the course is divided into two parts because the second part provides an education in more advanced and yet interesting topics in derivatives.
The course can be helpful, but expect a lot of work.
Understand the intuition behind each financial instrument. Read the slides. Better if you have some programming background.
useful
prereqs: ECO 362, ECO 202, or equivalent statistics course, and calculus..
descrip: The course offers an introduction to financial derivatives and the models used to price them. Pricing techniques include the Black-Scholes formula (awarded 1997 Nobel Prize in economics), as well as extensions to accommodate time-varying volatility. We also consider counterparty credit risk in derivatives trading and the market mechanisms that have arisen to mitigate this risk. This course is technical by nature, and requires extensive use of calculus, statistics, and spreadsheet programming.

title: Building Envelope: Technology and Architecture
prereqs: ARC 311 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This seminar explores the intersection between building technology and architectural history through building envelopes. We will describe the building enclosure from within, as an embodiment of cultural, social, and technological processes. The aim is to help students to develop an integrated critical view, a balance between technology and culture. The main part of the seminar will present three facade types in detail: curtain walls, rain screen facades, and panel facades. Technical topics will be introduced during a weekly two-hour lecture; the last hour will be devoted to the discussion of case studies and team work.

title: Financial History
reviews: Definitely take this course if you are interested in economics and finance. The course helps understand development of global macroeconomics. Readings are extremely interesting.

I would recommend the course to anyone with an interest in finance, even if you don't have previous knowledge. It's a great way to learn about all the topics from the bottom up. I would suggest keeping up with all of the readings and seeking assistance if any of the topics confuse you.

Prof James is brilliant -- so brilliant that sometimes he doesn't understand that we just don't follow. There's an enormous amount of technical terms, finance and macroeconomics thrown at you, so only take the class if you're willing to take the time to synthesize it on your own.

That said, if you're willing to put in the time, and you're really interested in learning about how finance develops, themes across centuries, and a bit of an absent-minded prof -- then take it!
Take it after you have sufficient background in finance and economics and are ready to read a lot
Take the class if you would like to know some financial history, especially if you already took macroeconomics.
Yes.
sometimes there is a lot of reading assigned. for some of the papers, only very elementary understanding of the basic concepts is required for the course.
descrip: The course examines the history of financial innovation and its consequences. It examines the evolution of trading practices, bills of exchange, government bonds, equities, banking activity, derivatives markets, and securitization. How do these evolve in particular state or national settings, how are the practices regulated, how do they relate to broader development? What happens as financial instruments are traded across state boundaries, and how does an international financial order evolve? What are the effects of international capital mobility? How is resulting conflict and instability managed, on both a national and international level?

title: Intensive Korean II
reviews: If you can speak Korean already this course will be easy. If not you will have some work to do to catch up.
If you need a language requirement, definitely take Korean with Professor Choi. He is such a great teacher!
It's a constant stream of assignments.
Take it!
prereqs: KOR 103 and KOR 108 are designed as a year-long sequence. Credit for KOR 103 will not be given unless it is followed by KOR 108. Students who have completed both courses will be considered to have fulfilled the language requirement equivalent to completing two-year study of a foreign language..
descrip: A continuation of Korean 103. This course covers the 2nd Year Korean material focusing on complex grammatical structures, reading, and writing. Journals are kept for writing practice. The students who have successfully completed KOR 103 and KOR 108 will be placed in the 3rd or 4th year Korean if they wish to continue.

title: Number, Shape and Symmetry
prereqs: Students who take MAT 189 may not take MAT 190 for credit. This course is designed for students who have not satisfied the quantitative reasoning (QR) distribution area requirement. Students who have already satisfied the QR distribution area requirement should not enroll.
descrip: Mathematics is both art and science, and many of its greatest discoveries are generated as much by considerations of abstract beauty as they are by cold logic and utilitarian concerns. This highly interactive, discovery-based course explores some of the intriguing ideas of elementary number theory together with geometry and symmetry. Emphasis will be placed on the development of mathematical reasoning and literacy.

title: Ottoman Turkish (Intermediate)
prereqs: TUR 405 (or permission of the instructor).
descrip: The course will provide the students with fluency in reading and understanding Ottoman Turkish written in various periods. The texts will consist of printed and handwritten materials: articles, letters, newspapers and archival documents.

title: Automatic Control Systems
reviews: Almost everything in this course is done well. The material is decently interesting and presented well by Professor Rowley, the readings are excellent, the problem sets are fair and manageable, and the un-graded laboratories are decent supplements.  However, I do warn that the take-home-exam format is different than most others, and even though the material itself on the exams isn't overly egregious, the format makes it way more stressful than it possibly needs to be.  Of course, most people in this are doing at as a requirement anyway.  Regardless, most of the course has really good stuff in it.  The exams just could be altered a bit for sanity's sake.
Class to take for control theory

Decent class, Rowley is a great professor and his lecture notes are a wonderful summary of basic controls.  Lot of material to cover in this class, though, and it's pretty abstract at times.  Never really got into the subject myself, but many others did - depends on your preferences, I guess.
Do not leave Princeton without taking Professor Rowley's MAE 433 course in Automatic Control Systems. MAE 433 is the bread and 'butterworth' of the engineering curriculum!
Don't take it at the same time as other heavy p-set courses.

Easily one of the best MAE classes. Rowley is an excellent lecturer, and the labs and HWs are all really reasonable. Psets do take time, so plan accordingly. The fact that non-MAEs take this speaks to how the course is both well-done and accessible.

Find a good group to work on problem sets with, and keep up with the theory of the course. It's very helpful to read the notes as you solve the problem sets, to reinforce your (probably foggy) perception of the lecture material.
Go to all the lectures. Write everything as thoroughly as possible in assignments
Go to lecture, go to office hours. Make sure to read the notes thoroughly on a regular basis.
Great course for anyone with any interest in control theory, or really any engineering aplications

If you are interested in controls, take this course. It is a challenge, but it is well worth it, and Professor Rowley explains the material very well and makes it interesting. Labs are also very engaging.
If you work together with other students on p-sets, make sure you can still do them on your own as you'll need to for the exams.

If you're interested in computer science, mechanical or aerospace engineering, or electrical engineering, or want to build things related to any of these fields, this is a great class to take. Controls is immensely useful in so many fields. The workload is reasonable, the labs are fun, and all of the topics in the course are interesting.
Interesting, accessible lectures. Super interesting topic. Definitely worth taking.

Make sure you keep up with the course! Material builds on each other so it's tough to try to cram it all at once before the exams - and it'll make problem sets unbearable as you'll find yourself just begging other people for help. Just read the lecture notes carefully before starting the problem set and you'll be fine - though you'll definitely want/need to collaborate on them. Go to class and pay attention - Rowley is worth it! It's not very intuitive stuff, so it'll take a while to get used this way of thinking - spend the time in the beginning of the course and you'll thank yourself later.
Material is interesting but man this course was hard!

Professor Rowley is amazing. That being said, be prepared for a lot of weekly confusion until you finish the problem set. Then you'll understand the theory, but not how it translates into the real world...until you finish Lab, where you'll learn what it means physically...but still have no idea what exactly you did to make it work...and then you'll do it over and over again...until you look back to study for the exam and have an "ah-ha!" moment, realizing that everything you learned in the class is beyond awesome.

Read Astrom and Murray. Don't rely on the lecture notes... they are high quality but somewhat incomplete, and are generally updated too infrequently to be of use for the current problem set. Make use of office hours.
TAKE IT! Prof. Rowley is very devoted and helpful. The labs are well designed so they really can reinforce the ideas covered in lectures. Problem sets and exams are manageable.
Take it and get simon as a ta.
Take it for the material and not for the grade. The material is engaging but the grading is nit-picky.
Take it, Rowley is the BOMB. Read the book. Watch online videos, they help.
The workload is a little heavy but it's an interesting course to take and well taught. The notes are great.
This course may be required for MAE's but I'd recommended it to anyone who is qualified to take it. Rowley is awesome, and you do a ton of interesting things with control theory.

This is a great course for MAE majors or anyone interested in feedback systems and controls. It is a fair amount of work, but by no means unreasonable. The labs are pretty fun and low-stress. Take it!
This is a hard course. Don't take it unless you have to, or really dig controls.

This is a very interesting course. The problem sets are a lot of work though are doable. The exams are the same. The Professor Rowley is very good at explaining the concepts in lecture and I wish I went to his office hours more often. If you are interested in feedback control and have space for a hefty engineering course in your semester, this is a good course. MAEs, take this junior year. This is not a good course to have second semester senior year.
This is an excellent course. If you're at all interested in controls or anything like it, take this course!
This is an excellent course; anybody interested in automatic control systems should take it!
You should take this class.
You will learn a lot in this class, and everything comes together in the final week, so make sure you understand everything from week 1. Start problem sets early, as some end up taking a long time.
prereqs: MAE 305 or permission of instructor..
descrip: To develop an understanding of feedback principles in the control of dynamic systems, and to gain experience in analyzing and designing control systems in a laboratory setting.

title: Origins and Nature of English Vocabulary
reviews: A great intro to linguistics. Katz is a must-take professor while at Princeton and I don't see why you shouldn't do it through LIN 208.
A lot of work, and not an "easy" 200 level by any means, but you will get a lot out of it.
AN AMAZING COURSE. JTK is hilarious and informative, and you'll learn a lot. Take it.

Absolutely one of the best courses that I've taken at Princeton!  Katz is a brilliant lecturer, who really tries to get students engaged.  If you ever have the opportunity to take a class with Katz, TAKE IT!

Attend the lectures. You feel you are learning but at the same time entertained (in an intellectually stimulating fashion, of course). They also save you the time going through the readings covering points that are not necessarily important.

Budget at least 15hrs for the psets. And start early enough so that you can email the professor for much needed clarification. And email him. Take advantage of the fact that he's really interesting and is more than willing to respond to emails.
Definitely take it! But be prepared to work.
Definitely take it! It's a bit of work but very rewarding and fun!
Definitely take the class. Joshua Katz is amazing. The problem sets are hard, but the class is worth it. The readings are annoying, but do them.
Definitely take this course. Very interesting, great lecturer, and a fascinating introduction to linguistics. Not too much work, though the problem sets are deceivingly hard.

Don't be intimidated by the students who seem better-versed in the subject matter. You will be fine as long as you do your best. Katz and the preceptors are very readily available and willing to discuss or help. Take advantage of their accessibility. Also engage in lectures!
Enjoy the lectures and study for exams.
Fun, interesting, and fairly easy class on topics that you could easily miss entirely during your Princeton career. Katz is a good lecturer. I recommend it.

I found the lectures to be by far the most central part to this course, above the readings, the precepts, the homeworks, and the handouts. Make sure you attend lecture. Notes aren't that necessary, just make sure you hear Professor Katz lecture and the handouts will remind you what you need to know when the time comes. My only criticism was that some of the discussions among students often got on the sillily nerdy side. A perfect class for auditing.

I really enjoyed this course! Katz is a really interesting lecturer. Sometimes he forgets that his audience doesn't know quite as much as he does, but in general he engages with the class and makes the material interesting. You may find yourself questioning your long standing beliefs about language and right and wrong. Definitely do study the lecture notes for the midterm and final. Ask preceptors for more clarification on assignments, if you need it. And I would advise taking this course. By learning about where English has come from and its current nature you learn a lot about language in general and fun features in English you never  would have thought about.

I still don't know what a word is, but I know a lot more about them. It should be a requirement to take a class with Josh Katz before you graduate. Watching Katz lecture is like watching Coltrane play, or watching Picasso paint.
I think that if you are interested in the subject matter, you will love the course. On the flip side, I would stay far away if this is not a passion - you will be bored and frustrated very quickly.

I would recommend learning the phonetic alphabet, but this really is not a hard class. I would recommend taking it but warn them that it could be better. Also I mostly just like small classes so I might have not liked being in a rather large lecture.
I would take this course! You can be from pretty much any department and you will enjoy it as long as you have some interest in linguistics.

If you are looking for this class as a distribution and do not have / are not interested in linguistic, it will be a difficult class. Do not expect a good grade. The lectures are enjoyable but unless you can catch up with those who have studied linguistics before, do not expect to do well.
If you're interested in language at all, take it. If you want a chance to go to genuinely entertaining lectures, take it.
It is a fair amount of work, but totally worth it.  TAKE THIS COURSE.
It's an excellent course, has a fair amount of work, but it's well worth it!
JTK is amazing!!! Take the course even if you are not interested in the topic,but be prepared for a decent amount of work.
Joshua Katz is the man. This course is a challenge with no prior linguistics background, but it is very much worth it.
Katz is a great lecturer! If you're interested in how English came to be as it is, definitely take this class!
Only take this if you are very interested because grading is very harsh.

Please do not take this course. It is by far the worst course I have ever taken at Princeton.  Even though I've taken 6 years of Latin and LIN 20, it took me over 25 hours to complete each of the five impossible homework assignments.  The workload was unbearable (including a Dean's Date 7-10 page research paper AND a final exam), Katz was more show than substance (e.g. he liked to show off that he knew everyone's names but he was not a great lecturer), the readings are boring, grading is unnecessarily harsh, the midterm and final test the tiniest details that have nothing to do with the overall significance of the course, and the course had zero structure whatsoever.  This is all coming from a student who had, at one point, considered majoring in Classics, English, or even completing an independent concentration in Linguistics - I now run from these departments and will probably never take a course again in any of these.  This was a terrible course not worth the hours of work (I feel like I learned nothing even though I labored away for hours) and it was a massive disappointment.  My biggest regret about this class was not dropping it.  If you want the OED to be your only friend for a semester (the work this class requires will actually prevent you from maintaining friendships and good grades in other classes, trust me on that), then go for it. I was not about that life and hated living on my computer, constantly looking at the OED or digging through Google for information that should have been taught during lectures. I don't think I can emphasize this enough: please do not take this.  Don't be fooled into thinking that the course will be simple after the first few lectures, where I actually believed Katz would be a good lecturer. Save yourself the stress, especially if you're not a humanities student, and find a better LA.  I have nothing but hatred for this course and regret the time I spent suffering through it.

So. I have to say that this is a definitely interesting course, but I'll start with the professor. Joshua Katz' got attitude, though he is a very good lecturer and his notes are interesting and need-to-be-memorized for the exams. The material is super interesting. We went over how spelling changes and sound changes marks English as an individual language (though we never get to adequately define 'word', 'language' or 'dialect'). I heard that Katz does not teach this every year, so if it comes up then if you are really into Linguistics and are good with humanities classes then you should take it. I was not a humanities-person so I did not do as well as I would have liked, but definitely memorize his notes because he wants you to know them explicitly for the exams. It is hard to say that I would recommend or not recommend the course. Let me put it this way... It's that one course that you take and are glad that it is over but are glad that you took it. I do not want to ever take this course again though I would be tempted since the class is lots of fun since Katz is really funny and you go over really interesting things but I struggled with the exams and the problems sets. It is a very interesting course, but for that you must pay the consequences. However I did talk to a person who was not into it and couldn't get into it no matter how much they tried but the thing is that I also met people who really struggled with grades and assignments. I would definitely recommend it if it were pdf-able, but sadly it is not.
Stay on top of the readings and review lecture notes frequently.
Such an interesting class with really enjoyable lectures. Take it!

TAKE IT. Seriously. Professor Katz is amazing and learning about English is interesting, though the man could probably teach a course about paint drying and make it engaging. The materials in the lectures were easily modified according to student questions and interests, which was great, but also meant that the curriculum wasn't very well-defined. As a result, the exams felt like a collection of trivia, which was frustrating. The course would have made more sense if it was only based on papers. Regardless, I recommend it unconditionally.
TAKE THIS COURSE - it is not easy but it really made me think about so many things in so many new ways.  I do not regret taking this course for a moment.  and my friends regret not taking it.
Take it!  Even if you don't like linguistics, you probably will after taking this course.

Take it! But really. It's the best course at Princeton. Every lecture was a crazy & dreamy miasma of knowledge and humor, like stumbling into an uncringeworthy version of Dead Poets Society. You think I'm exaggerating here. I'm actually just being as specific as possible.

Take it! Or take anything taught by Joshua Katz. I took this class because I needed something to fill a slot and a distribution requirement and it looked mildly interesting. It turned out to be much more than that, and I'm really glad I took it. I learned a lot about an interesting subject that I otherwise may never have thought about. Best class I've taken at Princeton yet.

Take it!!! Katz's lectures are always entertaining, and the information is fascinating. Be aware, though, that (at least Spring 2014) you can't PDF the class, and the problem sets do take a long time. Even so, I thoroughly enjoyed the class. If you can't take this class, try to take at least one class with Professor Katz while at Princeton!
Take it, but be prepared to work very hard. This is no easy A class.

Take it, but know that it requires work. If you find words and origins fascinating, you'll learn so many new things and love it the entire time. Sometimes Katz likes to poke fun, but the class generally is really interactive and structured by the students' active feedback. Katz is also super accessible.
Take this course if Professor Katz is teaching it.

Take this course the next time it's offered! I'm an engineer and was extremely glad to have this class in my schedule. Language is such a fundamental thing for humans that it's really enlightening to break it down and study where it came from and how it's developed and what it means. Professor Katz is wonderful and lectures are always engaging. The tests, exams, and homework are all fair and if you work hard it will pay off directly.

Take this course!  The material is interesting, the lectures are incredible, the grading is fair, and it fills an LA requirement.  This class is probably the best way for STEM majors to fill their requirement; as a physics major, this was one of my all time favorite classes.
Take this! Everyone should take a class with Katz at some point. If you like the English language, taking this class will also help you appreciate its history.

The class is fantastic because Professor Katz is amazing, but do be cautious that it is challenging, takes a lot of effort and time, and it really helps to have background in Latin, Greek, or linguistics to be in this class despite how it is advertised. But if you are willing to put in the work, it will be truly rewarding to be in a class with Professor Katz- especially if you get his precept!

They say you don't need previous linguistic/classical knowledge but it REALLY affects problem sets and grades. That was annoying. Also, preceptors grade pretty harshly, so read every little instruction and make your answers very thorough in homework assignments. Lectures were really interesting and engaging in the beginning. If this class were PDFable, it would be more enjoyable.

This class is cross-listed English, Classics, Translation, and Linguistics. Less so on translation, but it has qualities of all of these. It may not be for you if you do not find these kinds of things interesting. If you are interested in this and generally humanities-driven, while it has dull moments, decent dedication to the class and simply showing up to lecture and precept will provide you with a great experience.
This class is great!  If you're at all interested in words and language, take this course.
This course is actually a lot of work, but if you are willing to put in the effort, it is so much fun. Take a class with Professor Katz.

This course was great, but since everyone else will likely be raving about Katz, I'll provide another angle on it. One thing that can be tiresome about the lectures is that it can seem like Katz is just trying to get laughs by shooting down students who speak up, without actually being constructive in helping us actually learn.

This course was very thought-provoking, and the professor was an incredibly good lecturer.  I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in language and linguistics in general, though students should be aware that it can be a lot of work (though this work is usually very well spread out across the semester).

This is a very good fifth class to take, as you can get by without doing the readings - even with no P/D/F option. Professor Katz's lectures are amazing and almost unparalleled on campus. Assignments are relatively short, and the projects towards the end of the semester do not take too much time. Because the course material is general enough to be accessible to all students regardless of major, and because Professor Katz teaches it, everyone should seriously consider taking this class.
This is probably a good way to figure out if you like linguistics or not. However, if you decide it is not a good fit, you may be quite frustrated and miserable.

This is the only course I've taken at Princeton that I would recommend, without hesitation, to any Princeton student. We all use language on a day-to-day basis, and hardly anybody ever thinks about what it is or how it got to be that way. This course covers both in a rigorous and eye-opening way while still managing to throw in oodles of fascinating trivia and general discussion. Students of humanities, social science, and engineering will all find much of interest here. That's not to say this is a perfect course: it isn't. Lectures (though spectacular in general) sometimes get sidetracked, precepts are less than they could be, and the problem sets and exams are occasionally frustrating (in addition to being moderately tough overall). Even so, it is very much worth your while to take this, no matter who you are at the university. (To give some perspective: highly respected professors from other departments regularly sat in on the class through the whole semester.) Just make sure to sign up for it early-- Katz's courses fill up fast!
This was the best course I took freshman year. I can't recommend it more.
Word hard.  It's worth it.  You'll be amazed how much you'll learn for its own sake and not because you have to know something for an exam.
You should definitely AUDIT this class.  The assignments are okay, but a bit much and a bit tedious.  The Katz lectures are great though.
You should take it.
take it!
talk to katz as much as you can.
descrip: The origins and nature of English vocabulary, from Proto-Indo-European prehistory to current slang via Beowulf. Emphasis on linguistic tools and methodology. Topics include the Greek and Latin elements of English, the Roman alphabet and spelling, social and regional variation, the matter of "proper" language, and the "National Language" debate.

title: Microsociology: Social Interaction (Half-Term)
descrip: Where does social order come from? Theorists since the 1960's have tackled this question from a micro perspective, looking not to grand institutions or structures for an explanation, but to the routine, practical, interactional aspects of everyday life. This course delves deeply into several branches of microsociology - including symbolic interactionism, ethnomethodology, and conversation analysis - with an emphasis on both the theoretical aspects of each school, and their practical application to microsociological study.

title: The Soviet Empire
reviews: Attend every lecture!!! Try to do most of the readings, especially the novels (even though it seems excessive) because they will keep reocurring in later weeks and they are also great pieces of literature to have under your belt.
Challenging course but you'll learn a lot. Definitely try to make a draft for both papers and bring it in to either Kotkin or your preceptor to get advice.
Definitely take it if you are interested in the Soviet Union, just be prepared to learn on your own as well.
Definitely take it. All the hard work is worth it.

Do all the readings. Twice. And then you might survive the final. 
Otherwise, this is the greatest class. Definitely take it.
Don't take it if you want to get a good grade without killing yourself
Don't take it! Just sit in on the lectures if you're interested. It is soooo unnecessarily hard.
Don't take this class if you're looking for a grade booster. But if you can at all fit this into your schedule you have to take it.
Don't take this if you are concerned with your GPA, but it is a very interesting course.

Excellent course which you get a lot out of if you put in the effort. Kotkin is a fantastic lecturer, very funny and knows the USSR inside and out. You have to work hard in this course but it is totally worth it.
Go to lecture and do the readings.

I do not regret taking this course in the slightest. I learned a lot and that knowledge will stay with me. But if you expect that knowledge to translate to a good grade, think again. Paper grades reflect the effort you put into the course but the exam was brutal. But it was a wonderful course, and that cannot understated.
If you are interested in the subject, definitely take it. Kotkin is the authority.

It's a lot of work but definitely worthwhile - whether you are a BSE or BA student doesn't matter, this is a course about human nature, institutions and world history and everyone has something to contribute and will get a lot out it.
It's a lot of work, but the understanding you'll gain of the USSR and post-Soviet Russia is well worth it.
Kotkin is not everyone's cup of tea.

Kotkin is one of a kind. His lectures are quite interesting, but often repetitive. Don't get caught up in the whole 'you must take this class' nonsense. Only take the class if you are genuinely interested in the subject and are willing to do a tremendous amount of work. You will have to learn much of the nuts and bolts of the historical events yourself, as Kotkin more paints a wide ranging picture. However, at the end of the slog is a fine start at understanding the question mark of the USSR.

One of the hardest classes I have taken at Princeton but also one of the most interesting and rewarding class. Russian History is truly fascinating with its multiple players and series of wacky coincidences and events. This course summarizes it well and allows you to gain a critical understanding as to what was one of the greatest superpowers of the 20th Century, and what eventually led to its demise.

Only take this course if you have the time to deal with reading large quantities of readings and writing gigantic, non-trivial essays: especially if you're in engineering. As a non-humanities engineering major dealing with two other humanities classes, I found myself in a perpetual state of extreme stress around dean's date. Other than that, this was a great course with great lectures, material, and precepts. It's too bad my GPA might get beaten to a pulp.
Prepare for hard work, excruciatingly difficult tests, 2 papers and Pr. Kotkin's satyre of communism.
Professor Kotkin is a joy to listen to. Definitely take this class!

TAKE THIS COURSE! Kotkin is the single greatest professor I've had. He is a bit intimidating at first, but he loves to joke and wants to know you outside of the classroom. It's graded harshly and the final is hard, but don't let the map quiz or the thought of a B stop you from taking the class. He only teaches it once every two years but he is the authority on the Soviet Empire and a former vice dean of Woody Woo so he knows what's going on. Even if you have just a mild interest in the subject you should take this class. Kotkin and the class is a large part of the reason I want to take Russian next year and am now way more interested in being a History major. You will learn so much more than just Russian history; he sprinkles in tidbits from his life as well as broader themes that relate to all authoritarian regimes. I plan on taking all of his future classes. Bottom line: Kotkin is amazing, the class is fantastic, and if you pass this class up you will regret it.
THis is my favorite course I've taken at Princeton so far.  Its hard but I feel like I learned a lot about Russia and how to study history.  Kotkin is great.
Take this class if you enjoy history or if you are looking for an engaging lecture.

Take this course if you're interested in history or politics in any way. You will complain about the length of the readings, you will cry at the harshness of the grading, but it will all be worth it in the end.
Take this course. Changed the way I understand history.
This class was great, and I learned a ton, but it was a lot of work.  I loved it, but be prepared to really study a lot for the map quiz and exam.

This is easily one of the best courses I have taken at Princeton. Not only is the subject matter fascinating, but Professor Kotkin lectures very well and knows his subject matter inside and out. Moreover, his methods in writing and looking at history have taught me much about how to be a better writer and historian. Be aware that the grading standard are rigorous and his expectations for work are very high. It is PDF-able should you want to take that route. Especially for history majors, this is a must-take class. 

If you can, get in James Pickett's precept.

This is probably one of the most difficult history classes you can take. Don't do it if you are not very interested in the material. The course was many times one-sided and professor Kotkin can be irritating, but he is an expert in this field.
Too arbitrary.  Don't count on doing well despite your best efforts and providing what would be good work for another, equivalent class.
Turn up to lectures, they are more interesting and worthwhile than the readings

Very very challenging course, but very very very stimulating and fascinating. Take it if you are a history major but only if you are willing to put in the work. If you are not a history major I would recommend PDFing this class if you can/want.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: An examination of the transformation of the Russian Empire into the Soviet Empire. Topics include: the invention and unfolding of single-party revolutionary politics, the expansion of the machinery of state, the onset and development of Stalin's personal despotism, the violent attempt to create a noncapitalist society, the experiences and consequences of the monumental war with Nazi Germany, and the various postwar reforms. Special attention paid to the dynamics of the new socialist society, the connection between the power of the state and everyday life, the bloc, and the 1991 collapse.

title: History and Theory
reviews: It is only theory class in History Department. I would highly recommend!
descrip: This graduate seminar provides an introduction to readings in modern social theory. Each week we read selections from a different analytical and/or disciplinary perspective. By no means a comprehensive survey, students from all disciplines will acquire the critical interpretive skills to integrate theoretical tools into their own research agenda.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture II: History, Philosophy, and Religion
reviews: Be prepared to be disappointed in the lectures.
Do it, but be prepared to read a lot. If you don't read consistently, you may be able to get away with it, but the class would be a waste of time.
Do it. It's a lot of reading, but if you do the work, you'll be glad.
Don't listen to other people who haven't taken the class. Just take it and do the reading. You won't regret it.
I cannot say enough good things about the Humanities Sequence. It will challenge and inspire you more than any class you probably have ever taken or ever will take.
Take it! If you like reading. Or even if you don't, you will learn to like reading. Which is a life skill!
Take the class if you took the first semester of HUM. It's completely worth it and the course material gets even more interesting.
This course is the best of Princeton. It will be worth whatever it demands.

This is a demanding course, I won't lie. We read over sixty books all year during the whole HUM 216-219 sequence, but it is unbelievably rewarding. You bond so much with the other students and you learn so so much. This may be the best course I take at Princeton. Absolutely amazing.
prereqs: See HUM 218.
descrip: In combination with 218, this is the second half of a year-long interdisciplinary sequence exploring Western culture from the 15th to the 20th centuries. Students must register for both HUM 218 and HUM 219, which constitute a double-course. The lecture component for 219 is listed as TBA because all meetings are listed under HUM 218. There are no separate meeting times for 219.

title: Design of Large-Scale Structures: Buildings
reviews: Always work ahead and put a lot of time into this class week to week so the end is not that work intensive.

Even if you are not a CEE student I would recommend taking this class.

In the future a similar class like this should be offered to non-CEE, non-engineers who are interested in real estate development

I highly recommend taking this course if you are interesting in testing your problem solving skills as a civil engineer. More importantly, you will gain confidence to make and test your own assumptions.
This class is a fair amount of work. Get stuff done in the beginning of the semester. You will thank yourself later.
You learn a lot but you will be working very hard.

You'll probably be taking this because you have to, but definitely be excited for it! It will be a decent amount of work (you'll be designing an entire tall building in a fair amount of detail), but it was incredibly refreshing to take a class that was very real-world engineering focused, as opposed to more theoretical.
sure.
prereqs: Students should have taken both CEE 312 and CEE 366, or have permission from the instructor..
descrip: This course will focus on the structural design of buildings and is open to students of engineering and of architecture who meet the prerequisites. The course will culminate in a major building design project incorporating knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work. Structural design is considered from concept development to the completion of detailed design while incorporating appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints.

title: The Great War in the Middle East
reviews: I would recommend this course to NES majors or anyone generally interested in WWI history or military history.
If you're interested in learning how the borders of the Middle East got how they are today, this gives a great history of the lead-up to and the impact of the First World War.
If you're on the fence about whether this will be interesting or wondering if it will be too much work, take it!
It's an interesting course, but be prepared for some long classes and relatively heavy reading lists. Reynolds has a ton of great stories but they can often bog down class.

Take this course if you want to learn about the complex, fascinating and highly pertinent history of how the Middle East was shaped by the Great War. Prof. Reynolds does a great job of parsing the key themes and dynamics of this history.
descrip: World War I changed - and ended - the lives of millions. Its impact upon the Middle East is widely acknowledged but not often explored. The war destroyed the old imperial Ottoman order, paving the way to the elimination of the Caliphate and the emergence of nation-states across the Middle East and the Caucasus. It fundamentally altered concepts of identity, patterns of authority, notions of religion, and ethnic and political borders. This seminar examines the Great War in the Middle East from right before WWI through the immediate post-war period. Topics include geopolitics, empire, Pan-Islam, nationalism, ethnic conflict, Zionism, and oil.

title: Introduction to Programming Systems
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of work in learning both the application and theory of C, must-take with Dondero if you want to pass this course.
Be prepared to dedicate a lot of time to the assignments, and be willing to reference all of the sources of help they have available, like lab hours.
Be prepared to put in a significant amount of time in the projects, but you will find them really helpful in understanding the material.
COS 217 is a really interesting class. If you stay on top of the assignments and don't procrastinate, it is easy to finish everything.

Compared to COS226, I thought this class was much easier. Precepts were so helpful in walking you through major aspects of the assignment, and the assignments were spaced out enough to give you lots of time to work on them. Start them early and get Dondero as your preceptor and this class will be completely manageable and not too stressful.
Course is very technical and requires a different kind of thinking than computer science (algorithms) and mathematics.
DO IT

Definitely a heavier workload, but incredibly interesting and as long as you work hard, it's a class you can get a good grade in. This class will definitely teach you how to program. Liked it better than COS226!
Definitely take this class

Do keep up with the readings. Since the exam is heavily lecture / reading-based and precepts are more helpful for the assignments, do keep up with the lectures and reading. (Don't cram it all the night before the final/midterm like me -- your grade will suffer.)
Do not take it in a busy semester
Do the reading!

Don't miss precepts, and make sure you leave plenty of time in programming assignments for debugging. Get really good at working with gdb! Quick debugging can prevent a fairly straightforward assignment from turning into a nightmare.
Don't take it unless you have to, or unless you're really into C and Assembly and even machine code
GET DONDERO AS YOUR PRECEPTOR. He made the course for me and was instrumental in my learning. Take this course either for your major or for interest--it's a good base course for COS.

Get started on the coding assignments early (even if they don't seem like they'll take that long, you'll spend a ton of time trying to figure out bugs).  Take the course if you're interesting in programming at all, not necessarily just systems, because you'll learn a lot about how to properly design programs (encapsulation, modularity, etc.) and useful tools (testing, debugging, etc.).
Give yourself a lot of time for the assignments, and go to office hours for debugging.
Great class. Lots of work, but very rewarding.
Great intro to systems programming. However, do be prepared to work hard for this class.
I learned a lot, even if it was a struggle. First quarter was easier than the second, in my opinion.
I personally was not a huge fan but I can see this being an essential for any COS major.
I really enjoyed 217, and it wasn't nearly as difficult as I thought it would be from all that I had heard about it. If you start on assignments early, you will be in fairly good shape.
I strongly recommend taking it with Robert Dondero as the lecturer.
I would take COS226 first.

I'm a future COS major and I really enjoyed it and loved the material. However, it is rather technical, more in the direction of electrical engineering, compared to COS 226 which is more like theoretical math. If you didn't like the circuits and TOY part of COS 126, this course probably isn't for you, though this is required for COS certificates and concentrations, so it's likely you don't have too much choice.
I'm not sure.
If Dondero is precepting, make SURE you get him. It's a solid class, and a great introduction to computer systems, as promised.
If you're interested in COS and have any Java, C  , or C programming experience at all (even if you're not majoring in COS) take it!
It is more difficult than COS 226. It gives you a greater understanding of what your computer is actually doing. So take it if you want to know.

It's a challenging course; the initial assignments may not be too difficult, but the difficulty and time commitment does ramp up significantly with latter, more complicated assignments, so don't underestimate the amount of time this course will demand of you.
It's been said before, but only because it's true: getting Dondero as your preceptor can change your life!
It's painful but rewarding.
Make a summary of each lecture as they happen so you will be very prepared for the midterm and final.
Make sure you get Dondero as your preceptor.

Only take this course if you have a very low workload in your other courses. It would probably be better to take the course in the fall so that you can work on assignments during breaks, especially the final project. If you do take the course, don't leave anything until the last minute and pay attention in precept.
Pay attention in class and especially precepts, and the course will be relatively straight-forward.
Read the book and go to office hours.
Read the textbooks - even though many areas are not always required, they help for all the assignments.
Really do not let the work after break hit you. The length of assignments after break really inccreases. The course load in general is quite heavy
Start assignments early!
Start early on assignments, be careful
Start programs early.
Start the assignments early, do a bunch of practice midterms and finals to prepare for the exams.

Start the programming assignments early and don't check out of lectures after the midterm...that's when they actually become important. The second half has a lot more memorization that you might expect.
Take if interested.
Take it if you like computer science. It's an excellent, challenging course.
Take it if you'd like to strengthen skills in C
Take it only if you're set on working in the industry.
Take it to learn a lot, feel stupid, and waste a lot of time on bugs.
Take it, its a tough class but extremely rewarding and improves your programming skills considerably.
Take it. If you're a computer science major, it's a requirement, but it's valuable anyway to understand low-level programming. Start the shell assignment early.
The course is rough.  Really only take it out of necessity or strong interest in the subject.
The course is useful and interesting.
The readings are really helpful.

This class is interesting if you want to learn more about C as well as how a computer carries out certain tasks. I would recommend this class to those who are going to be doing a lot of programming in the future. Also if you want to be a more serious programmer. However, if you are someone who enjoyed 126, take 226 first, then decide if this class is right for you because it is a harder than 226. Lectures are helpful but not entirely necessary. If you want to stay up to date with the material, the lectures are far better than the books. You 100% need to go to precepts. Precepts are where you will learn what you need for the assignments. Also, precepts are way more code based than the lectures. Thus, for someone who is more interested in programming than theory, the precepts are solid. I had Dondero and he is a very good preceptor. He explains everything very well and talks about the assignments in precept, sometimes even giving hints. The assignments are hard, start very early. Learn how to use gdb early. It will help for assignments 1-3. Try to be as careful as possible when writing your code because sometimes the problem can come down to missing one letter and it could take 5 hours to find the bug. They are incredibly difficult to debug. While lab ta's are definitely helpful, they generally aren't very well prepared for helping on 217 assignments. Assembly and heap manager are hard assignments. For the exams, first look at the past exams that your professor has given out. For example, I had Pai and his previous tests were Spring 2010 and 2012. The exams have an enormous amount of variation from professor to professor. So find the ones from your professor's years then practice those. Read the systems book for the final exam, it will help a lot, depending on who your professor is. 
I took 226 with 217 and it is doable. If you decide to take them at the same time you have to work ahead. At first, the two classes together are manageable. However, later in the semeste

This course is valuable only because of Dondero.
