I can't necessarily speak for all of the other preceptors, but the course itself has a number of issues, in that its lectures are pretty detached from the core of the course, and grading can sometimes be very harsh, though they are very transparent in their grading. All things considered, I did not do well in this course, but feel as if I learned a lot.
This course requires a little more time for the assignments, but is not as heavy on the theory as COS 226.  It is a fun course, though, and you will learn a lot.

This course was pretty interesting and really begins to give students a feel for the machine underneath, especially students coming from 126.
If you come into this class knowing any C, you will find the first half of the semester very easy/boring as the systems part of the course does not really begin until after midterms.

This is a class that will put you through a lot of work that is focused on recreating simple versions of important programming tools. Some find the work tedious and uninteresting, but it does give you a good appreciation and understanding of how to really use tools to write good, high-performing code.

This truly is a great course that is both a lot of fun and teaches you fascinating things about how computers truly work. Even as experienced programmers, computers can seem magical at times and this course really illuminated their inner workings. Bob Dondero is obviously the most amazing teacher ever, and although he is lecturing next semester, he is still teaching one precept, so go for it! He answers every question on Piazza in minutes and his way of explaining concepts with the utmost clarity and precision is astonishing. If you take it with him, you will probably find COS 217 to be one of your favourite classes at Princeton, as I definitely have.
Very good course but I would not recommend it if you're trying to get the COS certificate.
You must get Dondero as your preceptor. Do anything to make that happen.
necessary evil for cos majors and possibly even certificates... pretty interesting IF you take with dondero. lectures are not good
start assignments early, get sleep
prereqs: COS 126, ISC 231-234, or approval by the COS placement officer..
descrip: Introduction to programming systems, including modular programming, advanced program design, programming style, test, debugging and performance tuning; machine languages and assembly language; and use of system call services.

title: Seminar. Renaissance Art
reviews: A great course! One of the best professors around.
descrip: "Medici Florence: Art, Patronage and Collecting" examines the artistic interests of this eminent family in relation to cultural, economic, political and religious transformations in Florence from the 15th through 17th centuries. More broadly, it explores the value of patronage studies in art history, considering issues such as the agency of the artist, political propaganda, corporate identity, female patronage and religious sponsorship. Class readings combine the study of documentary sources with primary sources as well as, secondary sources on specific family members, artists, and works of art and architecture.

title: The Economics of Uncertainty
reviews: Expect to put in around 15 hours a week outside of class at least. Very demanding.
I think this course is definitely worth taking if you're interested in mathematics applied to economics and have a general interest in finance/ portfolio/ the theory of insurance, auctions, etc.

Prof. Abreu (amazing) taught this small group of about 6 students. Made it entirely worth it. That being said, it was definitely not easy, especially in the second half. Not a huge time commitment, and for the most part interesting. I think this covers a lot of the first half of Econ 501.
Strongly Recommended for anyone who thinks they might want to do advanced work in Econ.
Take it with Professor Abreu.
Take the class if you are interested in probability models and uncertainty.
prereqs: ECO 310, MAT 175 (or MAT 201 & 202), ECO 202 (or equivalent knowledge of probability theory).
descrip: This is an advanced microeconomic theory course. Using the concepts and mathematical techniques developed in ECO 310, the following topics are studied: [1] Theories of choice under uncertainty. [2] Risk aversion and applications to insurance and portfolio choice. [3] Equilibrium under uncertainty with applications to financial markets. [4] Asymmetric information: moral hazard and adverse selection. [5] Applications to the design of incentives and contracts.

title: Experimental Physics Seminar
reviews: Definitely take it, if you have any interest. Be aware that the responsibility to learn, however, is on you (since there are no homeworks to drill the information into your head).
No work outside of class, first half of labs are super fun and then it becomes more important that you understand what is going on.
Take it! Professor Tully is so caring and helpful, and will really get you excited even if you never knew you liked the subject matter!
Take the course; don't get discouraged by the  lectures which can get a bit technical. You will have support from the professor and TAs during the lab portion.

This class requires literally no work outside of the classroom.  There are no readings, no problem sets, no papers, no exams-- nothing.  All you have to do to pass is show up.  Take it your senior spring and thank yourself.  Also Prof. Tulley is incredibly smart and nice.
This course is a chill way to get an STL. However, it isn't always the best organized, and the lecture component isn't very clear, meaning you might not end up learning as much as you hoped to.
Very fun course! Take it with friends. Professor Tully is very friendly and helpful
You must take this course!
descrip: The seminar introduces students to the basic techniques of electronics and instrumentation used to conduct experiments in the physical sciences. The course begins by teaching a foundation in analog and digital circuits including programmable digital logic devices using an iPad interface for data acquisition. Students develop measurement techniques in a wide range of experimental areas.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
prereqs: This class is available for 300-level (departmental) credit, by application only, for any student who has previously taken two 200-level workshops in the Creative Writing program. Students must have fluency in a language in addition to English. Applications must include 3-4 pages of either original literary translation or original work from their previous workshops. See Creative Writing website for application information..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students must be fluent in their chosen language.

title: Between Resistance and Collaboration: The Second World War in Europe
reviews: Do the readings to have something to discuss during precept. Exams were easy - just make sure you can identify events and terms that may not have been mentioned that thoroughly in lecture. The professor is very nice and knowledgeable!

Even though Jan Gross has a ton of expertise, he often had trouble articulating his points in an engaging way. The course is more about Nazi policy towards Eastern Jews than Resistance and Collaboration in general, so keep that in mind when considering this course.
It's kind of boring. Take it if you love WW2. I mean LOVE.
Take it
Topic is interesting and readings are good. Professor Gross is a little hard to follow. Good distribution course.
prereqs: PDF option not available to History concentrators..
descrip: In the broader context of conflict between fascism, communism, and liberal democracy, we shall examine various patterns and methods of occupation, collaboration, and resistance during World War II in Western and Eastern Europe. The Holocaust of European Jewry and the technology of terror will be discussed. We will try to ascertain how elites and different social strata were affected by the impact of war and occupation. Students will be asked to read historical studies as well as personal narratives by eyewitnesses and participants.

title: Introduction to Differential Equations
reviews: Come to lectures and pay attention closely.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WITH PROFESSOR E.  Seriously, don't.  I've never taken a worse class at Princeton.  The problem sets consist of one easy problem that everyone gets perfect scores on, so everything comes down to one 24-hour final exam.  He also writes the HW on the blackboard, so you better come to every class and pay attention.  He moves through material at land-speed records.  We spent three weeks covering ALL of ODE theory.  Then we spent 6 weeks on PDEs of all sorts and finished with calculus of variations.  It would be fine except Professor E does not seem to have any interest in teaching classes, and it certainly comes through in this class.
Don't take it with this professor.
Good overview of the material

It isn't really an engineering course even though it's cross-listed under CEE. It's still fun, though, and it gives you what you need to know about differential equations. And Professor E's lectures are entertaining.
Pretty easy for a 300-level math course. Relatively low time commitment.
Satisfying theory/practice balance, will learn a lot (3/4 of course) about PDE. Grading/assignments a little disorganized.

Take it instead of MAE 305, especially if you'd like to dip into understanding the theory more rather than just solving ODEs. This class covers two semesters worth of material (ODE   PDE) in one semester, so it could be a bit heavy.
This class does not take much time outside of lectures. However, it is not the most organized class either.
This class goes at a really quick pace, but there is relatively little work per week, just 3-4hrs on Psets if you follow okay in class. Take it!
This class won't take much time at all. As a math major, I felt that I was not working enough in this class, and I didn't have a strong grasp of the material until reading period.
descrip: This course will introduce the basic theory, models and techniques for ordinary and partial differential equations. Emphasis will be placed on the connection with other disciplines of science and engineering. We will try to strike a balance between the theoretical (e.g. existence and uniqueness issues, qualitative properties) and the more practical issues such as analytical and numerical approximations.

title: Cases in Financial Risk Management
reviews: A great class to take. Do attend every lecture session and follow Professor Shin's lecture. You will learn a lot from the class.
Excellent course, Professor Shin's teaching methods made the material very interesting and relevant.
I highly recommend taking this course.
I would suggest to take this course because the information presented is fundamental to a well rounded education in finance.

If you want to sit through a boring class and sometimes fake interest. Other times, do your homework from other classes while ignoring the professor, take it. No one puts any work into the class. Especially if you want a relatively light class, and one where you won't have to figure out too much stuff, go for it.
It's a good explanation of financial crises.
Review the models on your own time, not just the intuition but the derivation, you will need to know them for the final and there won't be any homework to help.
Take it if it opens again
Take this class - not too time consuming either.
recommend
yes
prereqs: FIN 501, FIN 522.
descrip: Course examines the concept of risk and its mitigation, and how the ideas can be applied in the practice of risk management for financial and non-financial companies. The basic toolkit draws on economics, probability theory and statistics, and they are integrated with more advanced concepts drawn from portfolio choice, derivative securities and dynamic hedging. Overall aim of the course is to demonstrate how the main concepts have practical applications.

title: Problems in Late Antique and Byzantine Art and Architecture - Illuminated Manuscripts
descrip: This seminar builds upon the legacy of manuscript studies at Princeton University. The manuscript seminar led by Kurt Weitzmann from the 1930's until the 1970's shaped this field of study in the United States. Deploying the Weitzmann archive and Princeton's extensive manuscript resources we re-examine the methodological impact of Weitzmann's Illustrations in Roll and Codes. We then explore newer and broader means of understanding Byzantine manuscripts, considering questions of agency, materiality, reception, use, word-image dynamics and memory. The focus is on the illuminated manuscripts of the homilies of Gregory Nazianzus.

title: Topics in Low Dimensional Topology - Bordered Algebras & Knot Floer Homology
prereqs: The course assumes familiarity with basic low-dimensional topology..
descrip: In this course we study Knot Floer homology and related constructions. In the first part of the course we review the basic construction of knot Floer homology, and also some the algebraic constructions that are used in bordered Floer homology. These include Heegaard diagrams, holomorphic disks, differential graded algebras, A and D-modules and DA bimodules. In the second part of the course we use these algebraic constructions to study some computational problems in knot Floer homology.

title: Structures and the Urban Environment
reviews: A pretty easy course but interesting because Princeton has a lot of detailed resources (both online and physical models around campus) that you can use to understand the structures you learn better. Some lectures and precepts were kind of dry and the math was basic, but if you're coming into the class just expecting to learn a little more about some cool structures you'll enjoy it.
Definitely a good class to satisfy a distribution requirement. Try to get into a precept with Ted Segal. If you're interested in structures, this is a very interesting class.
Definitely do as much of the reading as you can. There is a lot of information in lecture, and doing the readings beforehand really helps you to remember everything that is thrown at you.
Enjoyable, if outside the field it will change your perspective on structures.
If you are interested in learning about the basic science behind structures like bridges and buildings, take this course! There is a decent amount of work for it.
Interesting stuff.
Interesting, relatively easy course. Take it if you'd like to look at a bunch of bridges, buildings, and shells for a semester. The exams are easy, and the lectures are enjoyable.
It is a very fun course, so I definitely recommend it. At the end you feel like you know can talk about some major structures and architects.
Much easier to retain the information if you do the readings before lecture.
PDF if you want an easy class for a distribution requirement, otherwise it's probably not worth taking unless you really love large structures and their history.
Start the term paper early, especially the calculations. Pick a well-known structure so it is easy to find specifications.
Study in advanced since  a lot of what is on the midterm is not explicitly stated in lecture.
Take STL if you're AB. Reconsider taking it for an LA.
Take it for LA or STL
Take it if you want a relatively easy course where you still learn a lot and get a real appreciation for structures.
Take it if you're interested in CEE (structures)!
Take it! Go to lectures!
Take it! It will change the way you look at the world around you.
Take it!!!!!!!!! Love Maria love Ted yay this course is amazing if you just put in a teeny little bit of effort
Take it.  It's not too much work, but not too little that you can easily get behind.
Take the course.
Take this, super easy too
Take your time and enjoy the course.  It is one of the best courses.  The material is very interesting and taught very well.
Taking the A section of this class is not as easy as everyone says given that there is a 12-15 page paper and a final at the end of the semester.
This is a really fun course
keep up with the lectures. take the course.
descrip: This course focuses on structural engineering as a new art form begun during the Industrial Revolution and flourishing today in long-span bridges, thin shell concrete vaults, and tall buildings. Through critical analysis of major works students are introduced to the methods of evaluating structures as an art form. Students study the works and ideas of individual structural artists through their elementary calculations, their builder's mentality and their aesthetic imagination. Students examine contemporary exemplars that are essential to the understanding of 21st century structuring of cities with illustrations taken from various cities.

title: Programming Languages
reviews: Be sure you know what you're getting into. This is for the most part a formal theory course with a ton of derivations; additionally, it has programming elements that assume you can pick up Haskell more or less on the fly. I would strongly recommend taking COS 326 before this so you can get at least a sense for both. If you liked 326, though, do go ahead and take this course; it's well-taught, interesting once you understand what's going on, and quite reasonable as far as work goes.
Dave is a great professor and this was an excellent course.  I would highly recommend taking 326 first.

Easiest and most fun COS theory course I've taken.  If you're ok with learning a new programming language quickly, the 326 course is by no means a required pre-req, I did just find learning on my own.
Suggestion for undergrads taking this course: Work with grad students! You'll learn more and produce better stuff, plus make new friends!
Great class. Awesome environment to learn. Prof Walker is great at teaching.

Having a lot of experience in formal logics will help. Knowledge of a functional programming language is a requirement. I thought that this would be a theory course where computer science majors would have an advantage over more mathematically-oriented people, but it's not. However, you will learn a tremendous amount about the theory of programming languages in this course.
I recommend this course to whoever want to learn what a real programming language course is like.
If you're going to take the course, you might as well put in the extra effort to get really good at Haskell.
It's helpful to talk to other people about the assignments and share ideas.
Take it if you are interested in PL
Take it! Good course. Assignments are fair and balance theory and programming well. Walker is a great professor, too.
Take it. Walker makes the course pretty easy, dunno how it is with Appel.

The course is fairly dry, but I ended up learning a lot about programming languages.  Walker is a great lecturer, but you might still find the material extremely boring.  Give it a try and decide then.  I also ended up learning Haskell pretty well.

This class is mostly logic based. If you find logic a dry topic, you probably won't be too interested in the material. This class is about the foundations behind programming languages, not decisions in programming language design so much (besides general concepts like the principle of orthogonality). If after that you're still interested, I highly recommend. Take with Walker if you want a logic introduction to programming languages, or with Appel if you want a Coq-based introduction to theorem proving.
This course is a must take. Prepare for some proof derivations, but overall it will be enjoyable.
This is a course to start knowing about research in programming languages if you are interested in.
This is a great CS theory course and a good introduction into the field of Programming Languages. If you have any interest in graduate study in CS, I recommend taking this course as an undergrad.

This is a theory class, but it's different from most of the others. There's a lot of logic (the first half felt a lot like PHI 312 to me), which means the proofs are different than in say, theory of algorithms or computation. In my opinion, they're a lot easier. The programming assignments were trickier for me, but I think the homework had a good balance to keep happy both the people that prefer theory and those that would rather write code than proofs.
if you like programming languages, take it. if you like functional programming, take it but be warned that you may or may not like the theory.
prereqs: Undergraduates: COS326 or permission of instructor. Graduates: none.
descrip: Logic and formal reasoning about software, treating programs and programming languages as mathematical objects about which precise claims can be made. Basic concepts and techniques such as operational semantics and axiomatic semantics for specifying programming languages; structure, definition and properties of type systems; invariants and assertions for specifying programs. Use of automated tools such as interactive proof assistants, model checkers, and/or satisfiability-modulo-theories solvers.

title: Research Seminar in Empirical Investigation
descrip: Preparation of research papers based on field observation, laboratory experiments, survey procedures, and secondary analysis of existing data banks.

title: Theories of Psychotherapy
reviews: Everyone take this class. Go talk to Professor Hambrick after class. Do all of the readings. Invest yourself in it and you will get so much out of it.
Godspeed.
I would strongly recommend this class. Even if you're only remotely interested in the topic, take it. You'll thank me later.
If you take this course make sure to have other courses that have easier workloads. this class takes up a lot of time.

It's a pretty great class. One of the classes I most wish I had more time to devote to, particularly given that each week is a new full book (or more) to read. Hambrick is a cool dude, and his clinical experience makes the class very interesting. Only real downside is that even though it's a seminar, there's a precept for which you essentially have to write a group JP. I was stuck with a particularly horrific group, so that definitely colored my experience, but the seminars are great, and Hambrick is a rockstar who definitely deserves your attention.
It's time consuming and can be difficult, but very worth it if this subject is of interest to you.
Pace yourself with the readings... They're a doozy. But I loved this class. Learned a lot about clinical practice!
Take this if you're interested in clinical psychology / abnormal functioning!
You will learn a lot about the field of psychotherapy in this class. Take it!
this class is interesting, but be prepared to be a little surprised by the paper topics. in that regard, make sure to take good class notes.
prereqs: PSY 207 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course will examine the different theories, models, techniques, and settings that comprise the practice of clinical psychology in general, and psychotherapy in particular.

title: Modern Japanese Literature: Early Years
descrip: This course introduces modern Japanese fiction by focusing on the production of the "modern body." We will examine the ways in which discoveries of new sexuality, the new male/female subjects, are inextricably linked to the nationalization process in Japan.

title: Contemporary Art: 1950 to the Present
reviews: A really great course for learning about contemporary art. Be prepared to engage with some difficult concepts and push yourself cognitively, but you will come out better for it. Do the readings and really listen in lecture and precept.
Definitely take it if you have any curiosity at all about modern and contemporary art. Well taught and easy enough to keep up with.

Do all the readings, participate in precept, take really thorough notes because you'll need it for the midterm and final. Also, don't try to sound smart by using terms that you think are "art" terms because the professor and preceptors can tell that you're bullshitting. Come to this class with an open mind toward modern art because it's easy to roll your eyes and dismiss it and say "well I could do that" but if you pay attention in this class you will realize there's a lot more to it than that!!

Go to lectures and use whatever note-taking appartus you can use fastest (I had to switch to a laptop to even write down half of what Professor Small said). The readings are not essential to the exams, but will aid you in the essay sections and may also be somewhat fun to read.
I highly recommend this course to anyone. It will change the way you approach art, and indeed most other things. Even if you have no experience in art, this would be an amazing class to PDF.
If you like contemporary art I recommend the course but try to leave your preconceptions about all of it at the door, it can get pretty esoteric.
Perhaps you have in interest in contemporary art, or just want to learn how to look and understand the art object, either way ART 214 with Professor Small is a good way to do so.

This course is brain food! It is really hard and get ready to grapple with some complicated political, ethical and aesthetic ideas. Sometimes it gets very abstract- lots of theory reading that gets philosophical- but the art we look at is really interesting. The course addresses questions like why is that pedestrian object in a museum? And why we should look at art that a two year old could have created. A hard, but enriching course. Changed my outlook on aesthetics and the world!

This course is not an easy blow off course. It is difficult, but totally worth it if you are willing to put the effort in it. Go to office hours, build a relationship with the preceptor, and talk to your peers. Group studying was SUPER helpful for the midterm and final.

This is a great course, regardless of whether you intend to pursue art history, another related subject area, or a totally unrelated course of study.  Professor Small is a great lecturer.  The class was both informative and enjoyable.
descrip: A critical study of the major movements, paradigms, and documents of postwar art--abstract-expressionist, pop, minimalist, conceptual, process and performance, site-specific, etc. Special attention to crucial figures (e.g., Jackson Pollock, Andy Warhol, Robert Smithson) and problems (e.g., "the neo-avant-garde", popular culture, feminist theory, political controversies, "postmodernism").

title: City Narratives: The Urban Landscape in Contemporary African American Literature
reviews: Go to office hours. She was a big help. Do your best to read the readings and everything else will fall into place.
None.
descrip: This course considers various imaginings of urban life in contemporary African American literature. In the past three decades, visions of urban space in black literature have ranged from the transcendent to the near-apocalyptic. What do increasingly "postmodern" conditions signal for black writers? Is the city a beacon of hope or a site of urban decay? What tools does one need to navigate it? Finally, if the term 'black community' is evoked with a sense of its internal fractures, what new models of collectivity does this literature imagine?

title: Innovation Process Leadership
prereqs: Understanding of the basic principles of science, engineering, technology and business. A keen interest in the role that creativity, ingenuity, entrepreneurial spirit, leadership and discipline play in the generation of new ideas/concepts and their transformation into successful products and/or services that can be commercialized..
descrip: In today's hypercompetitive global marketplace, innovation is the lifeblood of any business enterprise. This practical course covers the fundamental aspects of entrepreneurship and leadership in the management of the technological innovation process: from strategy formulation, idea and inventiondevelopment, through business plan preparation, design, and decision making to commercialization, critical success factors, process optimization and corporate agility. It explains the basic practices required to become a technology-savvy leaders in a complex technological society.

title: Pirates in the Early Modern World
descrip: See website

title: Greek Ethical Theory
reviews: Absolutely take this course. I am a philosophy major, and it was the best philosophy course I have taken at Princeton. Professor Lorenz is an extraordinarily clear lecturer, and he is so approachable and willing to help his students. The material is important to know about even for non-philosophy majors. I didn't think I liked ancient philosophy before I took this course, and now I want to incorporate it into my thesis. Especially if you are already interested in philosophy, definitely take this course.

Excellent course. Prof. Lorenz is super clear; one of the best I've had at Princeton. Luckily we didn't have any idiots take the class to hear themselves talk. Paper topics help you learn the material and are graded fairly.

My favorite Princeton course so far, professor Lorenz is amazing!! Definitely try to take a class with him. Although the material is dense he explains it very well and has reasonable expectations for the assignments. I personally enjoy ethics, but  as a freshman non-philosophy major, I would strongly encourage anyone to take it. Expect a moderate amount of work.
The class could sometimes be a bit dry, but I felt I got a pretty in-depth understand of the material
prereqs: One previous philosophy course required..
descrip: We shall study the ethical theories and contributions to moral philosophy of Socrates, Plato, Aristotle and the Hellenistic philosophers.

title: Introduction to Mesoamerican Material Culture
descrip: This course explores the art and archaeology of Mesoamerica, including the cultures and regions of the Olmec, West Mexico, Teotihuacan, Oaxaca, Maya, and Aztec. From temple pyramids and carved stone monuments located in plaza centers to the broken ceramic sherds and stone tools found in household trash deposits, material culture comprises one of the basic resources archaeologists examine to understand past ways of life. The course will explore the inferences scholars make in the analysis of material remains as well as the ways in which material culture was integral to the making of ancient political, economic, religious, and social systems.

title: Women's Leadership in Modern America
reviews: Definitely take this class if you are considering it -- even if you aren't considering it..take it! Professor Weaver is amazing (and Dr. Geathers as well). Every student at Princeton should take this class!
Every woman on this campus should take this class.

I highly recommend this course- the course material is very engaging and relevant, the course takes you on engaging and educational field trips that show you how the course material really is relevant to the real world, the group that chooses to take it is probably very interested in the course material and will have great discussions about it, and Professor Weaver is fantastic- she is very committed to making this course engaging and educational, and she is very committed to helping her students produce the best work that they can through offering to give them extensive feedback. I highly recommend that you not only take the class but also get to know Professor Weaver (who's awesome) and ask for her feedback on your paper drafts a few days before you turn them in, because her feedback is extremely helpful and will help you write a better paper.

I really liked this class.  It doesn't necessarily bring anything mind-blowingly new to the table, but it's refreshing to spend hours upon hours discussing and analyzing the issues for women and other minority groups in leadership positions.  Prof. Weaver is great and very helpful.
Please, I would love to have a male take this course. It's a great experience.
TAKE IT! Most meaningful class I've taken at Princeton

This has been one of my favorite courses at Princeton. If you're interested to hearing, contributing, and discussing complicated ideas about equality, feminism, and women's leadership, I would really recommend taking this course. Professor Weaver is warm, welcoming, and highly knowledgeable, and I have really appreciated the opportunity to learn so much from her and my classmates.

This is a great class.  It really motivated me to want to work for women's leadership in the future.  The workload is very reasonable and Prof. Weaver is understanding, supportive, and an excellent discussion leader.
descrip: This course examines issues related to gender, race, and class as substructures which shape the leadership of women in modern America. One of the focuses of the course will be to critique meanings of leadership particularly as we study the meaning of freedom in American society within the context of the civil rights and women's movements. Drawing upon a myriad of primary sources including speeches, autobiographical accounts, newspapers, television and film programs, we will highlight how several contemporary American historiographies situate women as activists versus leaders and the significance of this projection.

title: Modern Classical Dynamics
reviews: Definitely take it. Almost every class had a mind-blowing insight.

This is an amazing course. Essentially a successor to PHY 205, this course covers numerous topics from Hamiltonian theory to fluid mechanics. It uses rather advanced math, but Prof. Polyakov does a good job of covering the new concepts. Most importantly, this course develops a number of advanced concepts (eg. symmetries) that are central to physics but only hinted at in other courses. Highly recommended.
descrip: Discussion of the most beautiful and important parts of classical dynamics: variational principles, ergodicity and chaos, fluid dynamics of vortices, shock waves and solitons as well as the theories of developed turbulence.

title: Operations and Information Engineering
prereqs: ORF 245/ECO 300, ORF 307/MAT 305, ORF 309.
descrip: The management of complex systems through the control of physical, financial and informational resources. The course focuses on developing mathematical models for resource allocation, with an emphasis on capturing the role of information in decisions. The course seeks to integrate skills in statistics, stochastics and optimization using applications drawn from problems in dynamic resource management which tests modeling skills and teamwork.

title: South African History, 1497 to the Present
reviews: A good course with manageable workload
Decent amount of work. average amount of readings. Kreike is fantastic, doesnt grade too easy. take for sure
Don't take this course.  If you're really interested in South Africa, buy the books that he assigns and read them on your own.  The class is a waste of time.
Pay attention in lecture!
This is a great introductory course to the overall history of sub-Saharan Africa. Highly recommended.

pay close attention in lecture so that you don't miss something because once you get behind on notes it's hard to catch up! definitely a fairly comprehensive and interesting look into Southern Africa though
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available to History concentrators.
descrip: South Africa's past and present were and are closely intertwined with those of its neighbors, including Angola, Zimbabwe, and Mozambique. South Africa's industrial expansion, for example, relied on thousands of migrant laborers from its neighbors. The course will highlight a variety of themes, including the rise and fall of African empires (Great Zimbabwe and the Zulu kingdom), the effects of European colonization, and the repression caused by the Apartheid system. The course will also focus on the dramatic political changes that occurred in the 1990s, including the end of the wars in the region and the rise of democracy.

title: Microeconomic Theory II
reviews: I didn't take 501, but 418 and 317 were extremely helpful. With 418, I didn't feel lost having not taken 501.
I would advise students to make sure they stay on top of the material covered in lecture.
If you like Micro, do it. Everybody else please take sth else.
Memorize the lecture notes.

My comments are targeted towards undergrads, since this class is required for econ grad students: take this if you are interested in demonstrating ability for a grad school application, but not if you are interested in specific topics or applications in microeconomics, as this is a fundamental theory class.
descrip: This course is the second term of a 2 term sequence in Microeconomics.

title: History of Medicine - Freud to fMRI - Readings in the Histories of Mind and Brain
reviews:
-Take this course if you want an interdisciplinary challenge with a highly competent and stimulating professor
-Readings are heavy, but when are they not??
Although many students have strong opinions, feel comfortable?Katja appreciates input, especially interdisciplinary!
Great class that conveys a thorough understanding of the history of the medicine and sciences of the mind and brain.
I would highly recommend this course. It has been one of the most stimulating I have taken at Princeton.
Strongly recommend.
descrip: This course offers an historical survey through the medicine and science of the brain - from psychoanalysis (and a little before) to modern neuroimaging. It pays particular attention to the ways in which the mind and brain sciences have played a role in "making up people" (Hacking). Amongst others, it examines the birth of the asylum; the psyche in the secularizing politics of 19th c. France; how a discourse of nerves fed into a discourse on modernity; the role of the laboratory in the formation of 19th c. psychological sciences; the origins and reception of psychoanalysis; and the various cultures of contemporary neuroscience.

title: Founders: The Early American Republic in American History
reviews: Prof. Dun is great!

Really fun, interesting class but it's a ton of work. So definitely don't take it if you have other hard classes you're planning on taking at the same time. If you don't, however, it's really awesome for teaching you about the period and about primary sources and definitely rarely ever got dull

This course has a HUGE focus on primary source research. There are weekly assignments and a final project that involve primary-only research and writing. We spent half the seminar either reading rare books or doing in-class research. This got old and boring after the first few weeks. I am glad I developed extensive historical research skills, but I do not feel I learned as much about the time period as I would have liked to, because Dun doesn't lecture at all. He's a very friendly and accessible professor. I recommend the class, but be prepared to do a lot of research and writing.
This course is too much work. You have writing assignments every week, a 30-page research project due Dean's Date and a final 10 page take home exam. Themes were often repetitive.
prereqs: Preference given to students who have taken History 372 and/or History 373..
descrip: This seminar offers students the opportunity to dig into readings treating American history during the early national period, roughly 1783-1820, when the ideals of the Revolution met the realities of statecraft, when the social institutions of British America were strained through a new national idiom, and when many important issues that would prove vital to subsequent American history were first raised. We will read and talk about Washington, Jefferson, and the like, but also people and groups who are less familiar. An excellent course for those contemplating independent work in this period.

title: Clientelism and Redistributive Politics
descrip: Clientelism has evolved from the analysis of archaic and mostly agrarian political structures to a more general study of opportunistic electoral strategies. It has also become a central debate in comparative politics, on how to turn democratic reforms into better governance and effective development policies. The goal of this course is to document and analyze clientelism and discuss conditions under which it can be replaced with or evolve in programmatic, universalistic and more efficient electoral and policy-making practices.

title: Problems in Greek Literature - Philostratus' Life of Apollonius Tyana
descrip: This seminar considers the early third century Life of Apollonius of Tyana, Philostratus' fictionalised biography of a well-known first century sage. More than a birth to death narrative, the Life is encyclopedic in its range: through Apollonius Philostratus examines the cultural priorities of his day in an adventerous and exploratory literary work. We set the Life in its cultural and political context, and use the text as a launching point to discuss topics such as ancient biography, fiction, ethnography and travel writing, paradoxography, wisdom traditions, and the margins of the Greco-Roman world.

title: America in Judaism
descrip: Although the idea of an "American Judaism" emerged in the early decades of the nineteenth century, scholars have yet to define this concept in precise terms and explain how it differs from a simpler historical understanding of "Judaism in America." Our seminar will examine the Americanization of Judaism beginning with the earliest transplanted Iberian concepts of Judaism in the "new world" to the transformation of Jewish religious life in the United States. Special attention will be paid to Jewish theology, the rabbinate, gender, denominationalism and the polity of the American synagogue.

title: Topics in the Hellenic Tradition - Classical Scholarship and/as Reception
descrip: Reception Studies has been one of the main growth areas of Classics in the last two decades. This course offers an introduction to the situation of Reception Studies by way of looking at the history of Classics itself as a modern, institutionalized discipline. Examples, covering the late eighteenth to the late twentieth century are drawn from Germany, England and America, with regard to their specific, and sometimes linked, practices. The course combines readings in cultural and intellectual history with examining actual interpretations of ancient materials, works and authors as offered by classical scholarship.

title: Biophysical Chemistry II
prereqs: Some background in chemistry and familiarity with basic biochemical terms is assumed, but there are no specific prerequisites..
descrip: Broad introduction to major contemporary techniques used to study structures, functions, and interactions of biological macromolecules, including quantitative theory of molecular interactions. Aims to convey to students with diverse backgrounds and interests the utility of various experimental methods for solving molecular problems. Emphasis is on applications, practical aspects, and experimental design, and on strengths and limitations of individual methods and complementarities among them.

title: Art for Everyone
reviews: Definitely take this course. It's a lot of fun. You learn about all contemporary art in an interactive way. And it's just a great course for a change.
Fia is incredibly accessible to talk to about the class material.  The class is a great mix of fun and intellectually engaging-I'd 110% recommend it if you enjoy/appreciate art!
It's an easy class but if you want to learn real art take a different one. This is more art history.

Take this course if you can get into. 
Fia is a wonderful person, and you will
love this course
prereqs: Restriction: This course is not open to students who took VIS 472, Special Topics in Visual Arts - Art for Everyone.
descrip: This studio class will address the increasing social pressure on art to become more widely distributed, immediately accessible, and democratically produced. For the past fifty years, expanding definitions of what art might be fueled by a greater emphasis on active audience participation have encouraged an atmosphere in which anyone can claim to be an artist. Through studio work in a wide range of graphic and digital media, supported by readings and discussions, this class will take a hands-on approach to the question of whether art by everyone for everyone constitutes a dreamed-of utopia, a universal banality, or a cultural nightmare.

title: Topics in Number Theory - Modular Forms and L-functions
prereqs: Prerequisites: MAT 214 and 346 or equivalent. (e.g. Algebraic Number Theory with Skinner in Fall 2013).
descrip: Introduction to the theory of modular forms, with an emphasis on geometric aspects of the theory. Topics include modular curves and their moduli interpretation, q-expansions, elliptic curves, Hecke correspondences, the Eichler-Shimura relation.

title: What is Vernacular Filmmaking?
reviews: A diamond in the rough
Easy grade, extremely boring seminars, some good movies.
Take it.

This is a good course to take if you're interested in film.  You watch over a dozen or so movies over the course of the semester - most of them either foreign or avant-garde films.  The course does a great job in expanding your mind on how to look at these types of films, and Professor Erika Kiss does a great job in conveying the details and love with the material.  Great course.
descrip: In this course we will study films that address global audiences yet ground themselves in particular, local, vernacular sources of artistic creation. Our focus will be on three exciting postwar cinematic movements (Italian Neorealism, Iranian New Wave, the Danish Dogma 95), but we will also discuss parallels in American filmmaking. Familiarity with Homer's Ulysses, Virgil's Aeneid and Shakespeare's Hamlet will be helpful since they serve as the frame of reference for many of the examined films.

title: Qualitative Methods
descrip: This seminar provides a broad introduction to research design and analysis for political scientists interested in qualitative research and mixed-method research. The emphasis is on systematic measurement and inferential strategies when considering a few cases in-depth. Topics to be covered include case selection, periodization, comparative-historical analysis, the integration of qualitative and statistical methods, the design and implementation of field research, in-depth interviewing, and archival research. The class will critically practice the implementation of various techniques.

title: Reasoning about Computation
reviews: A lot of work but not incredibly difficult
A rewarding class that you can get a lot out of if you haven't seen much of the material before and are willing to put in the time to really understand everything.

A very tough course -- find good partners with whom to work on the problem sets. If you are not theoretically inclined and have not taken any proof-based math courses in the past, expect to struggle. Don't fall behind on the readings. Good luck!

As someone who likes math and theory, I loved this class. 

Notes: - It can be a bit of a grab bag of random math sometimes. Certain topics were only covered for a week before moving to entirely different ones. This is also a good thing if you want to be exposed to many areas of math. - Psets every week. Watch out, graders often make mistakes. - I really liked Prof. Charikar as a lecturer. Some lectures were mindblowing. - Trickier than some upper-level math classes I've taken. Less formalism, more cleverness required. - Ask questions in lecture! - Learn probability well. That's most of what we cover, and it keeps coming up. - Having a solid pset group made my life so much better. - Two take-home midterms and a take-home 36-hour final. - Shiva Kintali is a good preceptor. Try to get him.

As with many courses here, it's always good to do the readings before lecture blah blah blah...but it is immensely important to start the problem sets early.  If you work on them for short periods of time days in advance, you will spend less time overall, feel less stressed, and honestly accomplish more.  Plus, this will allow you to attend office hours.
Assignments are a huge time sink and are really hard.. find partners

COS 340 is basically a survey of all of the different kinds of theoretical math used in engineering and computing. It starts off with stuff like counting, but jumps to probability, graph theory, linear programming, number theory, reductions, etc., and provides a good overview of each topic. The homework assignments each week are really hard, and make sure you have people in your group who can support you and help you figure out the answers (a math major or a theory-COS major wouldn't hurt either). That being said, the course is a really good introduction to all of these different concepts, and presents a bunch of different interesting ideas to think about and explore.

DO NOT TAKE THIS UNLESS YOU HAVE TO. Of course you do if you're COS but this really was a miserable experience. I definitely learned some cool stuff but it wasn't without hours upon hours of work every week between working with my group and then typing up the problem sets. MAKE SURE TO FIND A GOOD GROUP (2 other students to work with) because you will need them and you will spend a lot of time together. GOOD LUCK!
Definitely don't fall behind. Keep up with the readings and the material.
Difficult, but you'll learn a lot.
Do the readings.
Don't do it unless you absolutely have to
Dont take it if you dont have to unless you have experience with proof based math

Easy for the math or orf majors who take this class, hard for people who have never done proof-based classes. Shiva is really good, just ask him a lot of questions. Overall a valuable class that touches on many key math/computing concepts
Excellent course if you want a survey of a bunch of topics in theoretical computer science. The psets take 10-20 hours each, so make sure you actually have time for this class.

For someone who never did much proof-based math before this, it was a great introduction to proofs and discrete math. Of course, it was also a HUGE time drain for me. It helps so much to find a good group. Also, for CS majors, try to take it sophomore year (especially if you're AB; doing this alongside independent work should be avoided at all costs!).
Get a good group and don't wait until the last minute.
Go to office hours and start problem sets early; it helps to sleep on some of the problems.
Good class, but prepared to put in the time.
Good luck. Don't drop -- you'll have to do it eventually anyway.
Grading is sometimes too picky (even wrong in the sense that mathematically and logically correct proofs get points off); be prepared psychologically. There are some fun and interesting topics! :)
Huge time sink, I would only take this if you have a very light course load.

I hated this class because I am one of the people who had never seen the problems before. It was frustrating to be surrounded by people who already knew the answers to all the problems. I don't even see why they were in the course to begin with. Too bad everyone has to take this.

I think that this is an important course which prepares students for real challenging problems that appear in surprising places (not just theory classes). That being said, it is certainly a challenging course for anybody without a strong prior background in proofs, graph theory, or probability and expected values. I'd give the class high marks for teaching me as much as it did (and I'm not getting an A).

I'm a CS major, and this class was the hardest math class that I've ever taken.  It's not about memorizing formulas and tricks like MAT 201 or 202.  Solving the problem sets requires real insight, and it can be frustrating when you can't get a problem, because you might spend countless hours to no effect.  So I wouldn't recommend this course to non-CS majors, unless you're really lusting after a totally unnecessary challenge.  For CS majors, my advice would be to make arrangements to be in a good pset group well in advance.
If you are a computer science major, then you definitely need to take it. But even if not, still take the class if you like Maths and want to know the Maths behind many algorithms.
If you have to take it, you have to take it. If you don't, only attempt if you really love math.
If you're a COS major you're going to have to take this. Make sure you do the readings and start the problem sets early.
Interesting material but don't take unless necessary.
It's a huge time sync.

Moses is a decent lecturer--soft-spoken but clear. There is a decent amount of work, but if you get in a good group you'll manage. The graders were horrible my semester, but hopefully that'll get fixed.

Problem sets were very hard and time consuming (10-15 hours a week), with 2 midterms and 36 hour take home final. I spent more time working on these problem sets than on any other course I've taken at Princeton. Only take this course if you have a prior background in proof based math and enjoy math, or if you have to, like all computer science majors.
Start problem sets early because lots of questions require moments of inspiration that you may not get in one sitting.
Start psets early.
Switch to Philosophy to avoid taking this class.
Take a proof based course before taking this course, or it will be really challenging for you.
Take it if you are interested in the mathematical underpinnings of things you learned about in 226.
Take it only if you are a math major, or a cos major who has to take this class. Very badly taught though.
Take it only if you have team partners who are good at maths.
Take it with a group of friends. PSets are undoable otherwise.
Take it! It's so much fun. Do find a problem set group (up to three people) that you work really well with -- that might have been the reason I enjoyed this class so much.
Take the course, and take it with Professor Charikar!

Take this class with some math major friends (or just really smart people). Otherwise you'll end up spending over 10 hours a week on the problem sets (and 10 is probably an underestimation). I took MAT215-218 and that experience prepared me well for the difficulty of the course, but even though i ended up spending much more time than I expected. That being said, to all COS majors, this course is definitely worth it if you don't have a background in theoretical computer science, and is probably one of the easiest theory track departments out there.
Take this course if you need to or if you have a very strong math background. Very interesting but make sure you have your big boy pants on - this class is hard.

The course comes close to living up to it's intimidating reputation, but if you put in the time and are good at math (even through just 201/202), it's not impossible.  Be prepared to put in a lot of work though.  Also, the 36-hour take-home final was kind of awful.
The people in this class are quite competent, so even if the problem sets look somewhat easy, triple check for minor logical mistakes so you don't get points taken off. Start psets early.
The problem sets will become very time intensive near the end of the semester but are very satisfying and fun to do.

This class is difficult but rewarding. Very very interesting material, but hard to grasp fully. The math is interesting, but "eureka math", you either see it or you don't when working on the homework. You can bang your head against the wall on one problem for hours and make no progress while another student might get it in 10 minutes, and vice versa. Make sure you find good partners.

This course either needs to be reworked or made so as not to be a requirement. There are too many problems with the course to list here, and most center around the fact that an artificial curve is imposed on students such that the actual material of the class is not tested, but rather one's general ability to invent a proof on the spot. Problem sets take a disproportionate amount of time, and the final exam was a 36-hour take home exam which defies description. That being said, some of the material itself is very interesting, once you are done being frustrated at the fact that the intent is not for you to understand but to make it difficult enough to create a curve. Find yourself a math major friend and have fun.
This course is incredibly difficult and time consuming, but worth it.

This course is infamous - yes. I'm not one of those COS majors who is great at writing proofs. But if you go into the class with an open mind, you'll learn a lot. It's a hard but intellectually rewarding class. Take it and get help! The staff is really there for you. So don't worry so much and take COS 340.

This course wrecked my semester. I loathed it so unbelievably much I just wanted to cry every time I had to do it. Bless Moses because he was decent, but the material is just horrible. Sincerely, the very best of luck.

This is essentially a math course, although math majors may find that it's not as rigorous as they're used to and cs majors may find that it's quite unforgiving... getting problem sets back is like taking a week to test code and having bad error messages. But if you like math and proofs and you always wanted to know some of the theory of cs, this is the start of it. Otherwise, be prepared to start really early and struggle a lot. 

Finding a good group is paramount. Of course, people who are good at this probably won't want to group with people who are struggling, so that could be sticky, but it's always good to be able to explain things well.

You will learn a lot, but it is really hard. Really, really hard if you haven't done proof-based math before. Take some time over the summer or winter break or intercession to get familiar with proof-based mathematics. That might help mitigate some of the difficulty.
find a good group for problem sets!

if you love math and/or have a good group to work with, you will find the course material interesting and enjoyable. Unfortunately, the homework deadlines this year were very inflexible to the student's schedules - it was impossible to get an extension on homeworks even in the case of severe temporal conflicts. So if the homework policy has not changed, I would be wary of taking this course if you have other large time commitments.

never take this unless you have to. you will spend hours upon hours upon hours on the problem sets, and sometimes still do horribly. not a fun class at all, wouldn't recommend it. if you're a cos major, just suck it up and try to take it with 2 friends so you can work with people you like, because youll be spending a ton of time on psets
nice course. and survival depends on your group mates. choose wisely.
prereqs: COS 126 and 226 (or sufficient mathematical background), and MAT 175, 202, 204. COS 226 can be taken along with COS 340 in the same term. Please contact the professor directly with any questions you may have..
descrip: An introduction to mathematical topics relevant to computer science. Combinatorics and probability will be covered in the context of computer science applications. The course will present a computer science approach to thinking and modeling through topics such as dealing with uncertainty in data and handling large data sets. Students will be introduced to fundamental concepts such as NP-completeness and cryptography that arise from the world view of efficient computation.

title: Topics in the History and Theory of the Media - Reading Faces - Methods of deciphering in literature, sciences and art
descrip: A person's face is often regarded as a site of "natural" signs, which render visible the inner character, emotions, and thoughts. Yet the methods of deciphering such signs depend on artefacts--pictures, sculptures, descriptions--whose various modes of representing faces are themselves the product of interpretations, codes, constructions, and definitions. The course will study textual sources from literature, art theory, psychology, evolution theory, critical theory, and visual images from portraiture, photography, film, and science. Beginning with contemporary examples, it will undertake a genealogy and archeology of methods of deciphering.

title: Music Theory through Performance and Composition
reviews: A lot more work than 105, and grading was very harsh compared to 105. Although Professor Tymoczko is a really good professor!

Generally, I would recommend music theory.  It's fairly interesting, especially if you like music or want to get a music certificate.  However, I would recommend not taking music theory with Professor Tymoczko, because it's very confusing and frustrating.
I would advise them to always do extra practice and seek help if they are falling behind.
I would recommend spending a good amount of time on the weekly assignments, as they all involve composition and require a good deal of thought and deliberation.

If you don't already have a theory background, be prepared for a rapid pace and challenging tests/assignments. Read the optional handouts on Blackboard - they're much clearer explanations of the topics discussed in lecture.
It's often just a requirement. Save time to do compositions- they're difficult.
Leave enough time to do the homework assignments. They are hard, and if you want to get a good grade, make sure you put in the effort.
Listen!
Lots of work but you get to learn a lot about how to understand and appreciate classical, romantic, and 20th century music.

Make sure that you take the time to actually do the work and think about the music. This course is definitely for you if you love music theory, but if you don't put the thought into it, just knowing and memorizing things is not going to help as much as understanding concepts deeply in your soul. Prof. Tymoczko is basically a genius and will teach you amazing things, but his test-making can be somewhat sadistic, and I've heard that his precepts get graded rather more harshly than others, so if that's something you want to avoid, that's your heads up. :)
Only take it if you need it for a prerequisite, etc. I would not take it for fun or just general interest at all.
Take it
Take it if you have some music theory background. Otherwise it could be a major struggle, and your skills may have to be augmented to keep up.
Take it if you're a music major because you have to. Otherwise, take it if you want to know how music works from the perspective of Western classical harmonic structure.
Take this class if you have any interest in composing or gaining a better understanding of classical music theory.

Take this class, especially if you have an interest in music. I think this class doesn't get as much respect as it does... compared to other places, I wouldn't be surprised to learn that this class is on par with some top music schools' theory classes.
This course is challenging, and probably only a good idea to take if you are a musician. It is a lot of fun, though, and Professor Tymoczko is great.
This is a hard course. Get your p/d/f buttons ready.
prereqs: MUS 105 or permission of the instructor. This course is a prerequisite for all upper-level theory work, and should be taken by any freshman considering majoring in music, entering the Certificate Program, or taking upper-level music courses..
descrip: A continuation of MUS 105, with an emphasis on the harmonic and formal principles of Western classical music. We will focus on modulation, chromatic harmony, and form, continuing to study and compose music in classical and other styles.

title: Salafi Islam
descrip: Salafism and Salafi Muslims have irrupted on the global and Middle Eastern political scenes in the last decade, and are often described by pundits in the media as the enemies of the West and all that is modern. This course will interrogate such common, and mistaken, assumptions, looking more carefully at the medieval theology and law of the Salafi movement as well as the beliefs and actions of its modern and contemporary followers.

title: Infection: Biology, Burden, Policy
reviews: Definitely take this course! Professor Mahmoud and Professor Shenk are great. Also Professor Grenfell guest lectures!
Easy class. Arbitrary grading.
Good senior spring class.

I thoroughly enjoyed this course, as I felt like it gave a very comprehensive view of the subject, from various perspectives, and it was in depth, but also accessible to someone without a thorough background in molecular biology, like me.
If you're interested in taking a MOL course on infections and disease, take it-->especially if Shenk and Mahmoud are still teaching it
Mahmoud is really into class participation so come prepared with questions.
Take it to balance out a heavy problem set and final exam laden semester!
Take it!
Take this course! It is definitely my favorite MOL class thus far at Princeton!
This class is great--not too work intensive and very interesting.  Good for senior spring!
This course is fantastic. Professors Mahmoud and Shenk are wonderful. Take this course!
This course is very worthwhile, it isn't a lot of work and it is a pleasure to get to hear from both Professors.
This is a wonderful class--Professors Mahmoud and Shenk are very enthusiastic and encouraging, and the material is really interesting.  Definitely recommend.
great senior year class.  Pretty easy too.
will be ridiculously easy for MOL/CHM/CBE etc. majors, the science is minimal in comparison to your departmental requirements; recommend to someone interested in policy or boosting MOL GPA
prereqs: MOL101, MOL 214, MOL 215 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will examine fundamental determinants of human microbe interaction at the biological and ecological levels. The focus will be on major global infectious diseases, their burden of illness and policy challenges for adequate prevention and control. Each infectious agent will be discussed in terms of its biology, mechanisms of pathogenesis, disease progression, epidemiology, as well as strategies for its control. Specific emphasis will be placed on the public health aspects of each disease.

title: Topics in International Relations - US Diplomacy, The Arab Gulf States and Their Neighbors
descrip: Seminar examines the political, social, economic and strategic dynamics within the six members of the Gulf Cooperation Council and their neighbors. Course explores the context and complexities of these regional actors, the effect of recent US policies, the impact of the Arab Awakening and opportunities and limitations of US influence on national interests. Topics include sectarianism, Islamism, political liberalization, post-oil globalized economies; intra-GCC and intra-regional rivalries and competitions, and the rise of new powers, including Turkey, India and China.

title: Civitas Foundation Finance Seminar
reviews: I strongly advice any graduate student interested in finance and financial economics to take this course.
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Nonlinear System Theory
prereqs: Prerequisite: ELE521/MAE547 or MAE434.
descrip: This course covers topics in nonlinear dynamical systems including phase plane analysis, Lyapunov stability, input-output stability, passivity, averaging and singular perturbations for time-scale separation.

title: Educational Psychology
reviews: A decent class that is a lot of writing. Much of the writing feels like busy work. Still, the field of educational psychology is dynamic and not too difficult to get into.
Be prepared to participate actively in class discussions; that's the most important part of the class!
Expect a lot of work in this course, but Professor Glat is really great to work with.

I would strongly recommend this course.  Professor Glat is dedicated to the class and is really good at explaining the theories and teaching educational psychology.  In addition, he is pretty easy-going, approachable, and fun.  He is flexible with assignments and is a very nice guy on top of being a great professor.  This was my first psych class and I had a lot of fun- it was eye-opening, very informative, and I learned a lot about ed psych.  We also went on a field trip and did observations which were great for pre-teachers to see and I felt this was a very fun and eye-opening experience as well.
If you are interested in education policy or practice, this is probably the best course you can take at Princeton (though I haven't taken any of the TPP courses).

If you are interested in education, it is worth every bit of effort this course will require of you.  The workload is demanding, and at times, it was grueling, but the breadth and depth of material is fantastic and the regular writing we are required to do taught me so  much.  Professor Glat is a dedicated teacher and an engaging seminar leader.  He also did a wonderful job of helping all of us to lead a seminar.
Schedule your observations early. They involve a lot of work and there can be some trouble with school schedules not overlapping with Princeton's.
This class is great, especially if Professor Glat is taking it. Take it if you're interested in the psychological research behind educational practices!
Unless you have to for Teacher Prep, don't take it.
yes take it!! such an engaging lecture
prereqs: This course is required for students enrolled in the Teacher Preparation Program (TPP). Priority is given to Juniors and Seniors in TPP. Other Juniors and Seniors may enroll only with permission of instructor..
descrip: Principles of psychology relevant to the theory and practice of education. Through selected readings, discussion, and classroom observations, students study theories of development, learning, cognition (including literacy), and motivation, as well as individual and group differences in these areas; assessment; and the social psychology of the classroom. The course focuses on how learning by children and adolescents at the elementary, middle, and secondary school levels is influenced by their own characteristics and experiences and the various contexts in which they learn: family, school, community and culture.

title: Biogeochemical Cycles in Earth History - Isotope Geochemistry of the Biologically Important Elements
reviews: Attend class.
Good primer for learning about isotope processes in a general geochemical context.
Have some more background on the topic.
Highly recommended.
This course should be on the list of any student interested in using isotopes in their research.
descrip: Examines the use of stable isotope measurements to reconstruct important biogeochemical and environmental processes, today and over geologic time. Following a review of fundamentals and terminology, application of the isotope systems of carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur, and other elements will be investigated. Introductory lectures by the instructor and student presentations based on readings from the scientific literature.

title: The Great Russian Novel and Beyond: Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov, and Others
reviews: A great introduction to Russian literature with a professor who loves the material and her students with equal magnitude. No language experience is necessary, so for anyone who's even a little curious to learn what the big deal is about all these old Russian novels is, I highly recommend this course.
Absolutely take this course with Professor Chances!
Do the readings. READ READ READ. Anyone remotely interested in literature should take this class--the richness and depth of Russian literature will blow you away.
Take it!
Take this class if you like Russian Literature and want to know the significance and connections between the novels and how they developed.
Take this class!
Take this course if you are interested in Russia or Literature in general!
Take this course! Write down quotes mentioned in class to study for the exam. Enjoy the beauty of the literature.
The reading is pretty heavy during the first half of the semester.  After that, things die down. Enjoyable, and not too stressful, especially if you plan to PDF.
This course is an absolute gem.
prereqs: Curiosity. Knowledge of Russian not required. Open to first-year students as well as to sophomores, juniors, and seniors in any department..
descrip: An examination of significant trends in Russian literature from the 2nd half of the 19th century to the Russian Revolution and a bit beyond. The course focuses on many masterpieces of 19th & 20th-century Russian literature. The works (mostly novels) are considered from a stylistic point of view and in the context of Russian historical and cultural developments. The course also focuses on questions of values and on the eternal "big questions" of life that are raised in the literature. Authors read include Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov, Bely, Nabokov, and Kharms.

title: Elementary Turkish II
prereqs: TUR 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Familiarity with all grammatical aspects of Modern Turkish. Reading text of moderate difficulty; developing communicative skills: ability to comprehend and engage in daily discourse; ability to write short compositions.

title: Cognitive Psychology
reviews: Attend lectures. Do the readings. You must do both.
Avoid this course unless you have to take it for a certificate.

Do NOT take this course. Unless you enjoy having to attend EVERY single lecture to copy down EVERY single topic and have your progress in the class measured entirely by a series of multiple choice questions throughout the semester.

Do not take! There is not curve, because the quizzes and exams are so easy. For our 3 hour final, we had a 30 question multiple choice question. 
If you do take it, be sure to attend lecture - so many of the quiz and exam questions come from there!
Don't take this course.
Don't underestimate the class since the curve still is difficult even though the material is easy.
Easy course, probably a total of 24 hours of outside work over the course of the semester. Lectures are pretty dry, but the book is interesting. Quiz questions from lecture were often poorly written
Go to all of the lectures and do the readings! Then the quizzes are pretty straightforward and you should have no trouble participating in precept.
Go to lecture and do the readings.
HORRIBLE
I would advise a student to take a different psychology class, unless they are particularly interested in cognitive psychology.
If you are really interested in the subject, then take it, but be aware that you will be doing most of your learning from the textbook and precepts.
If you're a really fast typer, go for it. Great course to P/D/F, but if you're looking for an EC or psych departmental, I'd recommend other classes instead.
It is the most PDF-able class here, but taking it for a grade is tough.
It's a decent course that doesn't require a ton of effort, though you're not guaranteed an A because the quizzes/exams have a lot of arbitrary questions on them.

Lectures could be a bit dry, but went by very quickly and are not posted. Try to pay attention and take good notes. Quizzes and exams are all multiple choice. Since wording could be somewhat ambiguous, it's easy to get a few wrong. The curve is terrible for the class since the material itself is pretty easy and straightforward. Ended up with a B in the class, which is fine since I didn't put much effort into it. Standards changed throughout the semester. At the beginning the prof said we would not be tested on anything neuro-related, but those questions came up. Also my preceptor said the participation grade would not be based on active participation, but later forgot he said that. I enjoyed reading the textbook, but not going to lecture.
Not a good class. Grading is arbitrary for precept participation, and the quizzes are completely arbitrary from lectures.
Not a lot of work. just do the readings. Lecture is kind of frustrating if you can't write/type notes fast enough.
Only take this course if you love psychology, are are committed to learning by your lonesome.
Read the textbook. Memorize the glossary terms. Get someone else's lecture notes. If you can't, P/D/F it.
Take if you're interested.
Take it! Even if you don't have to for a certificate, it's definitely low-stress.

The lectures and the textbook are good, but even so, there?s not much reason to take the course if it?s not a requirement. Poor course design and required participation in psychology studies make the course feel like it?s checking boxes rather than educating.
The readings were interesting, and I thought that the lectures were fairly engaging. If you need an EC that doesn't require too much work, this is the class for you.

This course provides the wonderful balance of light coursework and interesting, useful material.  There isn't much reading and the exams and quizzes are minimal.  The workload is light, but be sure to keep up with it.
This course teaches you some interesting material about cognitive psychology. It is very manageable and not a huge time commitment, and worth taking as it immediately applies to your everyday life.
This course will teach you more about yourself and how you think. You'll also learn some cool things about animal cognition, which is a plus.
This is the first psychology course I have ever taken and I really enjoyed it!

Write down everything he says. 
Do well on every single quiz.
only take this course for the requirement or if you are truly interested in it
descrip: The course will survey the major themes and experimental findings of Cognitive Psychology. We will address the question of how scientists probe the nature and underlying structure of human thought. Topics covered include attention, perception, imagery, memory, language, thinking, decision making, and cognitive neuroscience.

title: Advanced Topics in Modern Architecture - The Perversions of Modern Architecture
reviews: A very interesting theory and history course
Do the readings! Participate in class!

Get as close as you can to Professor Colomina. Try to get from her in person or via email what you are missing in class. Don?t be shy or intimidated. She is very open to student-professor interaction.
I heard a rumor before joining this seminar, that Beatriz ends up giving much of the time to students and taking a back seat, which I may confirm and found it slightly frustrating.
Stay on top of the readings.
Take it
descrip: Modern architecture was never straightforward. Despite the surface rhetoric of rationality, clarity and efficiency, modern architects were engaged with everything that escapes rationality: sexuality, violence, exoteric philosophies, occultism, disease, the psyche, pharmacology, extraterrestrial life, artificial intelligence, chance, the primitive, the fetish, etc. Through a series of case studies from the early twentieth century till today, of both mainstream figures and misfits, the class will explore the backwaters of modern architecture to reveal the astonishing richness and eccentricity of the field.
