title: Biology of African Animals and Ecosystems
reviews: Be aware that Dustin is a rather sarcastic person and not particularly approachable. He is knowledgeable though.

Have a clear and organized presentation for your paper discussion. You can get by with skimming the rest, but try to read as many as you can. Work hard in the projects, as they define most of your grade. Don't be too stressed about the presentations. Make sure you participate.
Take this course! It was a great experience and a great introduction to Kenya/field work/environmental biology.
This class is a good intro to what you'll be doing for the next 3 months. It's intense, but a lot of fun and you learn tons.
kenya is just a no brainer no matter the courses.
research experimental methods beforehand. Generally good course.
prereqs: EEB 211 and EEB 321. Open to students enrolled in the field semester in Kenya..
descrip: Students will be immersed in an intensive field experience in Kenya gaining sophisticated training in fieldwork and biological research on African animals and ecosystems. In addition to this training, participants will observe and study organisms ranging from acacia ants to giraffes, go-away-birds to zebras. The course is designed to give students a broad, hands-on understanding of ecology, evolution, and conservation. Lectures include core topics in ecology and evolution. Students will gain experience with experimental design, data collection, and analysis. Limited to students in the Tropical Biology and Sustainability Program in Kenya.

title: The Great Theorems of Mathematics
descrip: See website

title: Introduction to Ancient Philosophy
reviews: An OK PDF if you're looking for something to satisfy the EC distribution. Do not take it unless you are interested in the theoretical aspects of philosophy. I thought that this course was going to be more historical (as that is not the case). Also, I would only recommend for people who have prior experience writing philosophical papers. The class does not teach you how to write a philosophical treatise, yet the professor still grades papers very harshly (which are almost all of your grade).

As far as ECs go, I guess this one is tolerable. The Plato part of the class is much more interesting than Aristotle. I PDF'd for the EC credit, and you should too (if this is for your gen ed requirements).
Complete the readings
Do not take. Horrible grading criteria and weak lectures. Although, the reading material is quite interesting.
Easy P/D/F course
Easy PDF
Easy PDF, but boring nonetheless.
Focus on writing clear, focused philosophy papers.
Go to class and take notes if you want to write a paper on a topic that the class will discuss.  Do the readings conscientiously.
Go to lecture even if you have not read the material.
I think a good preceptor is instrumental for enjoying this class, as the material is pretty complex
I would recommend that they invest themselves in precept and participate as much as possible to help with material comprehension.

I would recommend this to a student if they need to fulfill their EC. However, if they are really interested in philosophy I would recommend that they take a different course. A student should be aware that this is a survey course and that they should not expect to gain a whole lot of knowledge from it.

If you are looking for an EC to PDF, and care about learning about philosophers that were foundational for Western civilization before you graduate, definitely take this course! I would recommend attending most of the lectures, then you won't really have to do the readings for the essays as Prof. Lorenz does a great job explaining the main arguments and giving references from the text that you can rely on.

If you have a real interest in the material, you should do fine. The kids I knew who wanted to be philosophy majors did very well in the class and seemed to enjoy it. I was less engaged which made the class a bit more of a struggle, but the workload was still very minimal. The essays are short and as long as you read at least every other reading assignment, you can do well in this class.
If you want a very interesting, easy distribution requirement, take this class!
If you're interested in Ancient Philosophy, it's worth taking. If you're not, don't bother.
It's a really interesting class and makes you think. It's not very much work, but you do have to put in a lot of thought if you want to get an A.
Lectures are not very exciting, but the precepts are great! Make sure you get a good preceptor because he or she is going to be the one who explains everything to you.

Lorenz is a really boring lecturer. If you have interest in philosophy great class. Make sure you get a chill preceptor. You don't have to do all of the readings, but enough to be able to write decent responses.

Lorenz is a really nice guy. He often repeats himself in lecture, which I dislike, but some may find that helpful. It is definitely a history of philosophy course, so take it if that interests you. You will be reading and criticizing the arguments of some very influential thinkers.
Not difficult at all, but Lorenz was extremely boring. There were 5 (easy) assignments plus a midterm and final.
Of all of the philosophy courses I know of, this is the best.
Solid course although the lectures can be boring.
Study

Sure, the readings are very strage for the first six weeks. However, the material becomes more familiar as time goes on. I personally thought that presocratic ideas about the nature of the universe were incredibly fascinating. The ethical theory comes later in the course. I thought this latter segment of the course was more interesting.

Take advantage of the precepts to make sure you really understand the arguments in the readings, and also keep up with the readings - it was sometimes tempting to put off readings for this class because you're not immediately held accountable for them, but come time to write your essay assigned every other week, the process runs a lot more smoothly if you've kept up with the syllabus and as a result gotten the most out of lecture and precept.
Take it for a good distribution requirement.
Take it if you are at all interested in the works of Plato and Aristotle.
Take it if you are interested in general knowledge in philosophy.
Take it if you want to really learn about ancient philosophy. Be prepared to read hard material.
Take it!
Take it! And make sure that you have done the readings before class, and come to class with questions.
Take this class! And if you can get Lorenz as a preceptor do it!
Take this course if you're interested in at all or need an EC. It's great!
Take this course. Minimum workload and interesting material

The class is a good 5th class or EC because it does not have much work (by way of papers or readings). But it is not particularly interesting so do not expect it to be (unless you know you are interested in Plato and Aristotle in particular).
The readings make it worth it.
This class is an excellent introduction to the 'highlights' of ancient Greek philosophy.
This class is dry but Lorenz makes topics clear and understandable
This course is excellent for majors and non-majors alike, very approachable and very interesting
This course should be a requirement
This is a very good course to PDF. Reading is minimal, assignments are short. If you PDF its a breeze.

This is an easy PDF class. For the minimal amount of work, show up to the precepts, read the essay prompts when they come out and read the relevant readings for whichever prompt you decide to do. Every "essay" will take you 30-90 minutes to complete. The midterm and final may be a little longer. 
The only problem with this class is that the assignments were pretty frequent, one assignment every other week. I took this class because I don't do well on in class midterms and finals. So the frequency of work was an ok tradeoff.
Very stimulating material. Recommended to anyone wanting to fill an EC.
Would recommend if interested in the material or looking for a decent distribution class
definitely take this! not very difficult, interesting, just put in the time for readings and such
i'd take it for a distribution requirement, it's a pretty interesting class and the knowledge you gain goes beyond the course as well
descrip: This course discusses the ideas and arguments of major ancient Greek philosophers and thereby introduces students to the history and continued relevance of the first centuries of western philosophy. Topics include the rise of cosmological speculation, the beginnings of philosophical ethics, Plato's moral theory and epistemology, Aristotle's philosophy of nature, metaphysics and ethics. The course ends with a survey of philosophical activity in the Hellenistic period.

title: Information and Signals
reviews: Be ready to work, attend as many lectures as you can, even though they are online, and 100% go to OO for problem set help.

Don't bother reading the book. Even though lecture notes are posted, it's good to attend lecture and actually take notes because otherwise it can be easy to get distracted and lose chunks of information.
Don't let the fact that this is an ELE course fool you: this is entirely a math course. A decent one with interesting subject matter if you have some idea what you are getting into.
Don't procrastinate on the problem sets (some of them are quite hard!) and try not to get lost in some of the math of signal theory--take time to step back and examine the physical "big picture."

ELE 201 basically teaches you what it says: signals and systems. This includes fourier, different transforms--you have to take it as an ELE major. However, the class is tricky to figure out, as the material isn't presented in a logical or structured manner, and Paul's lectures are hard to parse since he goes so slowly. However, if you actually understand what's going on (perhaps by watching the video lectures he posts online), it's actually not that bad of a class and covers some interesting material. There are a bunch of misstatements and inconsistencies in the way problems are worded and presented, but hopefully if those are cleared up, it can be a better class than it is now. It definitely gets a worse rap than it actually is, but don't expect it to be an easy walk in the park. Having more office hours would be nice because then I can actually udnerstand the material.
ELE department prereq. Interesting material but a little too challenging and discouraging at times. The labs were quite fun, though.
Go to office hours
Good class. But, make sure you understand the reason behind every idea and concept, before just plugging in the equation and formulas. Otherwise, you won't be prepared for exams.
Great course, take it!

If you are an ELE, you will be taking this course. However, do not be discouraged by the reviews of the labs last year -- Shazam was definitely not the hellish ordeal it was last year. They are working to get the kinks out of this course, which showed.
If you are interested in the subject I definitely recommend
If you need an STL or are interested in signal processing, definitely take this course.

It's not bad, you get to learn really interesting and relevant material like how JPEG and MPG compression works. Lectures can be a little dry though and a lot of the course is pretty much about Fourier Transform.

Not a good first ELE class to take. Kind of turned me off to the discipline, take ELE 203 instead. Prof. Cuff is a good guy, but a dry and verbose lecturer. Had a hard time following things the first time around. That said, the material is pretty cool.
TAKE IT! It's an awesome STL! I'm an Economics major, and though I really love my department, this class was a good change of atmosphere. You won't regret it!
Take it if you're very good at math.  If you need to take it its not that bad.  But expect a lot of annoying math.
Take it. It's fun, interesting, and not too much work.
There's a good amount of concepts that you have to remember, so make use of office hours and the videos if you don't get it the first time.
This class is rather hard.  Be prepared to spend a lot of time on the homework.
This is one of those courses that you can't afford to get behind in because everything builds on one another. I didn't really enjoy the course, but if you have to take it, find a good study group!
Work with others!
prereqs: The prerequisite for this course is knowledge of elementary calculus..
descrip: Signals that carry information play a central role in technology and engineering---ranging from sound and images to MRI, communication, radar, and robotic control. This course teaches mathematical tools to analyze, manipulate, dissect, and preserve information signals. For example, many continuous signals can be perfectly represented through sampling (Nyquist theorem), which leads to digital signals. A major focus of the course is the Fourier transform. We also study linear time-invariant systems, modulation, quantization, and stability (Laplace transform and z-transform). Lab design projects in Matlab include a "Shazam" music ID system.

title: Intermediate Korean II
reviews: 10/10 would take again. The Korean department is just awesome.
As with KOR105, this class is a must take. Prof. Choi is an excellent instructor and he makes class worth going to everyday.

If you liked KOR 101 and 102, then you should definitely take this! It's basically the same format, but it gets more fun because everybody's a little bit more proficient so there's more stuff you can discuss.
It's a lot of work, but fun
Make sure you keep up with the hw, and ask for help if you need it! Prof. Choi is so willing to help you, he really wants you to succeed! Take this course!
TAKE IT!
prereqs: KOR 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A continuation of KOR 105. Continued development of four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) in Korean. Complex grammatical structures and irregularities will be taught while the basics are reviewed. Idiomatic expressions will be introduced; journals will be kept for writing practice.

title: Topics in Film: All About Hitchcock
reviews: Because this class deals with only one director, much of the class rests on the critical texts--if you are not interested in theory you probably won't enjoy this class. I learned a lot and rather enjoyed the experience, though.
Definitely take it, one of my favourite courses at Princeton.
If your interested in film this is a good course to take. Not too much of a time commitment but you can still get a lot out of it.
Take this course only if you know you already like Hitchcock films.
Take this course! You get out of it what you put into it. My recommendation would be to go all-in; it really paid off for me.
This class is great. Anne Cheng is a challenging and effective professor yay.
descrip: This course offers an in-depth formal and critical analysis of the art and peculiarities of the "Master of Suspense." The course will be organized along a series of thematic tensions, such as "Doubling and Singularity," "Surveillance and Blindness," "Melancholia and Pleasure," "Suspense and Knowledge," "Maternity and Taxidermy." We will study Hitchcock as filmmaker and as cultural critic. Theoretical readings will accompany each film discussed and will draw from psychoanalysis, feminism, Marxism, poststructuralism, and film theory.

title: Intermediate Syriac
descrip: Study of selected passages from various genres of Syriac literature. Knowledge of Syriac is required.

title: Ancient Greek: An Intensive Introduction
reviews: Be prepared to work like crazy for this course. You must be entirely devoted to sacrificing a lot of things in order to keep on track with this course. But it is worth it.

Besides doing all the assigned work, always try to devote extra time to review.  After you cover a certain topic, it won't be reviewed extensively in class.  And I highly recommend that you take only 4 courses if you chose to do CLG 103 - you really want to devote a lot of time (1.5 - 2 hours a day, ideally) to studying so you can retain and master the material.

If you are ready to work extremely hard and have multiple hours of homework a night, you will learn Greek in a semester, which is fantastic. But the pace of this course is extremely fast (On multiple days we had to learn 50  forms in one night, so if you are taking other hard classes I would suggest going the 101/102 route.
If you love languages and/or Classics, 100% take this course. It will keep you on your toes, but you will feel so accomplished when you're done!

Take the course if you are very interested in Greek (for whatever reason) and don't already have a loaded semester schedule.  It can seem brutal at times but for many, gaining that extra semester (103 instead of 101 and 102) is worth it.
This is a ton of work.  Take at your own risk.  If you really want to know ancient Greek but don't have the time to split it into 101-102, then go ahead and do this.  But don't say I didn't warn you.
Unless you absolutely have to take the intensive course, opt for the regular two semester sequence.
descrip: This is an intensive introduction to Greek grammar. It covers in one semester material usually done in the standard two-semester introductory sequence (CLG 101/102). Students who complete this course and then take CLG 105 in the fall will be able to complete the usual three semesters' sequence in two and can fulfill the language requirement by taking only one additional course, typically CLG 108. This course aims at providing a reading knowledge of Classical Greek, quickly.

title: Muslim South Asia
descrip: Religious, cultural, and political developments in South Asia, home to nearly a third of the world's Muslim population, have long exerted considerable influence on the greater Muslim world. This seminar is concerned with religio-political thought and movements in Muslim South Asia from the 18th century to the present. Topics include: Sufism; the impact of colonialism on Islamic thought and institutions; evolving Islamist trends from late colonial times to the present; and debates on Islamic law and the position of women in India and Pakistan.

title: Seminar in Observational Astrophysics - Exoplanets
reviews: Overall, it is a nice seminar that we finally have for the exoplanet field.
Prepare your talk well in advance. If you have difficulty paying attention to the speakers, try taking notes; this method helps me stay focused
Take it if there is no personal problem with you.
The course prepares you well to give talks in broad topics of current research. The topics are interesting and engaging. I definitely recommend it.
This is a good course for learning a specific astronomy topic through papers, and it helps you get better at presenting academic work.
Very good seminar about observation of planets.
Well prepare for the presentation and positively ask many questions!
You will learn a lot if you are not working in Exoplanets, if you are, it's still a good practice of literature review and presentation skills.
descrip: Students prepare and deliver presentations on topics in exoplanetary science, and critique and discuss each other's work.

title: Lighting Design
reviews: Fun and instructive no matter what kind of experience or background you have!
Take it!
Take it! Your mind will be blown multiple times during the semester. This was one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton.

Take this course.  It works for both people looking to just have a good time with light and people who are striving to become serious lighting designers.  The course is taught brilliantly by the passionate, energetic, and extremely talented Jane Cox.  And because it's PDF-only, your motivation comes through love of the material, and that's how a great course should work.  You'll read great plays, make images come to life through the magical world of lighting, and work with great people, all while free of the typical stresses of ordinary courses.  I highly recommend this one.
This course is great!  Jane is fantastic and I feel like I've gained a new way to look at theater.
prereqs: This course is by Open Enrollment..
descrip: An introduction to the art and craft of lighting design for the stage and an exploration of light as a medium for expression. Students will develop an ability to observe lighting in the world and on the stage; to learn to make lighting choices based on text, space, research, and their own responses; to practice being creative, responsive and communicative under pressure and in company; to prepare well to create under pressure using the designer's visual toolbox; and to play well with others-working creatively and communicating with directors, writers, performers, fellow designers, the crew and others.

title: Human Evolution
reviews: A great way to fulfill an EC. Readings are not necessary to do well in the class. Professors Mann and Monge are awesome and good at answering all your questions :)
An interesting class, but may not be interesting to EEB majors.
Be prepared for disorganization but overall an interesting course

Don't have high expectations for getting something done every time you are in class. Just absorb the material and ask lots of questions, because that's where interesting things come out. Professor Mann is WELL worth getting to know.
Fun and interesting class, has very good professors.
I thought this class was very fun and interesting, would make a good PDF, never really had to do any of the readings.  Professor Mann is a wonderful professor, definitely take it if it is with him.
If you have a background in evolutionary biology, this class will be a breeze, but also very boring.
It's a pretty good class, but I was super interested in the subject matter - if you're not interested in human evolution, you will probably get bored.
TAKE THIS COURSE!
Take the course!
The material is interesting, and Profs. Mann and Monge are both entertaining and informative lecturers. Consider taking the lab portion if you like a more hands-on approach.
This class is very reading/writing based. You have to really identify the main trends/arguments/controversies in the material and understand how the course material fits around that.
take this class, it's great and you will learn a lot!
prereqs: ANT 206B is cross-listed as EEB 306 and is appropriate for students who wish to receive EEB credit for the course Human Evolution. EEB (or MOL) majors who do not need to receive EEB credit for taking this course may choose to enroll in ANT 206A instead of ANT 206B; please consult your adviser in EEB (or MOL)..
descrip: An investigation of the evidence and background of human evolution. Emphasis will be placed on the examination of the fossil and other evidence for human evolution and its functional and behavioral implications.

title: Black & White Photography
reviews: Film is a slow process. Dedicate the time this course requires and it will be extremely rewarding.

If you are going to take this class and have time commitment issues already (i.e. sports, clubs, etc.) think twice about taking this class. It's a HUGE time commitment, especially if you want to do well in the class and keep up with other class work.

If you want a class with very little work, this is not the class to take, for countless hours are spent in the dark room. It is an awesome class, though, if you do take it and stay on top of your work. It has probably been my favorite class at Princeton so far.
Take this course and do not worry about the grade. Use the course to gain experience in the darkroom / shooting black and white.
descrip: An Introduction to the processes of analog photography through a series of problems directed toward the handling of film-based cameras, light-sensitive paper, darkroom chemistry, and printing. Weekly laboratory sessions will explore the critical issues of working with black and white imagery today, supported by slide lectures, readings, and discussions of photography as a documentary tool, a political device, an art form. Class critiques of student work are augmented by feedback from guest photographers.

title: Fakes, Frauds, and Charlatans
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Construction and Interpretation
descrip: This seminar will examine the relation of construction, structure and building services to the production of meaning through a series of case studies of buildings and bridges and as well as general surveys of the work of specific engineers and architects.

title: Rocket and Air-Breathing Propulsion Technology
reviews: Don't leave your studying for the midterm and final all to the last minute, like I did.
Good if interested in rockets/propulsion. If not, don't bother. Material is almost exclusively about rockets and hypersonic propulsion, so only take if interested. I enjoyed it a lot

Most of the material in this course is similar to MAE 427. Therefore, you should give serious thought to which course you want to take. 427 seems to be better-organized and more comprehensive. In retrospect I wish I had shopped 427 to compare the two courses, even though 426 is what I want to do for a career.
Take it, just be aware of what you're getting yourself into. In spite of the things that make this class a little annoying logistically, I enjoyed the material I learned, and I did learn quite a bit.

The course material is interesting. The problem sets are short and easy. The exams require an extensive knowledge of the notes so ability to cram a lot of information in before the exam is key for success in this course. The lectures are good if you are willing to be engaged by the professor. The professor is very nice and he is usually understandable. Ask him to post the notes earlier in advance before the lectures.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222.
descrip: The study of principles, flight envelopes, and engine designs of rocket and ram/scramjet propulsion systems. Topics include jet propulsion theory, space mission maneuver, combustion control, and system components of chemical and non-chemical rockets (nuclear and electrical propulsion), gas turbine, ramjet, and scramjet engines. Characteristics, optimal flight envelopes, and technical challenges of combined propulsion systems will be analyzed.

title: Theories of History
reviews: Be prepared. This is an intense class, but also intensely rewarding

If you are interested in historiography, or even just a history student that wishes to be mindful of theory while writing history, you will get something out of this course. There's a lot of reading, but there's no other course like this.
If you like difficult, philosophical readings then take this course.

If you're an intellectually minded history major, or someone interested in how/with what focuses in mind history is written, I would definitely recommend this course. Not an insignificant amount of work, but generally worth it.
Take it
This course provides a great overview of the changing trends in theory that shaped the practise of history. It was an very interesting combination of historiography and intellectual history.

This is a course in philosophy of history from church history (Bossuet) to postcolonial history (Chakrabarty). This course is CRUCIAL for any serious history student. An awareness of the theory and assumptions embedded in the ways we do history is necessary if one wants to do history honestly and make attempts to get at historical truth and objectivity. This course, firmly rooted in the western tradition, lost popularity with the advent of post-colonial, transnational, and subaltern history, but it really should be a core course for all history majors. excellent philosophy, excellent history.
descrip: This course is an advanced, upper-level seminar intended for undergraduates interested in the philosophy of history, and its relationship to historical practice. The course begins with a survey of key works in the philosophy of history from the Enlightenment through the early twentieth century. It then continues with a survey of the most important historical schools of the twentieth and early twenty-first centuries, and the theories undergirding them. Students should have taken at least one 300-level course in intellectual history, philosophy or political philosophy. Graduate students are welcome.

title: Topics in Critical Theory - Comparative Literature Writing and Dissertation Colloquium
descrip: The Writing and Dissertation Colloquium is a biweekly forum for graduate students in Comparative Literature to share works in progress with other graduate students. The seminar welcomes drafts of your prospectus, article, dissertation chapter, conference paper, exam statement and grant or fellowship proposal. Work is pre-circulated. The 90 minute sessions, done in conjunction with a rotating COM faculty member, are designed to offer written and oral feedback.

title: Neuroscience of Being Human, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Into the Woods! What Disney Didn't Tell You About Fairy Tales
descrip: See website

title: Ethics and Public Health
reviews: I really loved this class. I'm generally interested in the field, and I thought it was well taught. Assignments are interesting, and not too onerous. Though the reading load was kind of heavy, since there is no final, it not completely necessary to do all of the readings every week. During busy weeks, I had to skim some of the readings and it ended up being fine.
If you have any interest in public health, this is a great class to take; you'll be exposed to many important topics related to public health.
Readings are fun to do and the class allows you to become more informed about current events from the ethical perspective.

Take it - this was my favorite course of the semester. The readings were all interesting and were selected for specific reasons (no busy-work reading). The papers are flexible and allowed me to basically write about anything that I was personally interested in, and the course overall gave me a pretty good sense of contemporary issues and common ethical frameworks used in public health ethics. The course is not as focused on theory as much as a philosophy course would be, but I didn't think that took away from the course at all.
Take it, especially if Jason Schwartz is teaching. Great way to get thinking critically on very topical issues.
Take this course, even if you know very little about public health issues! It's not too much work, but you'll always feel engaged. Professor Schwartz is amazing.

While the subject itself is extremely broad, Professor Schwartz presented it in a vey organized and logical way that wasn't overwhelming in the least. I very much enjoyed this class, and it gave me a general overview of how to look at the ethics of public health policies for a variety of topics.
definitely take it! material is interesting and Prof Schwartz is engaging!
descrip: This course will examine issues at the intersection of ethics, policy, and public health, paying particular attention to the centuries-long tension between individual rights and the common good. Ethical arguments are increasingly visible in public health activities in the United States and worldwide, demonstrating the continued relevance of long-standing debates over the proper role of government in promoting the health of individuals and communities. The course will explore ethical, historical, and policy aspects of public health activities, and it will consider the relationship between public health ethics and bioethics.

title: Superhero Trials
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Contemporary Feminist Theory
reviews: Everyone should take this class. Seriously.
Keeping up with the reading is very important, so try to read as much as you can. This class is very enjoyable, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who is currently reading this review.

Take this course! Students will probably get more out of the course if they already have some background in gender studies. I do think "contemporary feminist theory" might be a bit misleading of a title for some students who are looking for what I usually mean by "contemporary" (I think almost all of the reading was at least several decades old.)
do it!!! professor salamon's a boss. the course can be tough at times, and the readings require some going through, but it's super rewarding and thought-provoking and an all-around great time.
prereqs: GSS 201 or equivalent..
descrip: We will take as our primary text the new translation of Simone deBeauvoir's landmark volume The Second Sex, one of the most significant origin points of current understandings of gender. In our sustained consideration of The Second Sex, we will explore Beauvoir's ideas about the influence of sex and gender on childhood, the family, sexuality, relationships, aging, work, the social order, and the philosophical imaginary. We will also consider contemporary fiction and film alongside that text, taking Beauvoir as our tour guide as we encounter and interpret contemporary representations of gender.

title: Points of Focus in 20th-Century Music
descrip: We will compose music for small unaccompanied vocal ensemble, to be workshopped by Gallicantus in the spring and performed at a fall PSK concert. We will explore the mysterious vocal repertoire of the period 1550-1650 from a composer's perspective focusing less on correctness and more on what this music can mean for us today. We will also look at applicable contemporary repertoire. We will explore some of Dmitri's obsessive-compulsive theory work about this music, focusing on the deep logic of voice leading, the origins of functional tonality, and the strange connections between the 16th-century and contemporary rock.

title: Economics of Health and Health Care
reviews: Be cautious. It'll be a lot more work than it should be.

Do not take this course unless (1) you absolutely have to take another eco course; (2) you have a strong background in economics already so you can BS your way through it; or (3) you are really, really interested in health care.
Do the readings to get the main idea.
Exams are hard, study and know the readings by heart don't just wing it.
Go to lecture. Hear Professor Reinhardt's wisdom. Don't bother with the textbook, but do the other readings.
I recommend the course. Very informative!
I would recommend taking this course if you are interested in the material, but don't expect a well-structured course.
It is a very interesting topic, but not as organized as it could be.
It's not that fulfilling... If you like/are good with micro, you'll probably get a good grade but you won't really learn anything.

LOTS of reading, difficult to anticipate what will be expected of you on exams - not a lot of week to week work though (few p-sets, though a lot of reading). Good PDF if you're not ECO and are interested in the subject

Not a lot of work -- occasionally homework assignments and readings that you didn't actually have to do. As long as you have a solid microeconomics foundation and can skim through most of the readings you can do pretty well in the class. Reinhardt might not be the most engaging lecturer but he really knows what he's talking about and is an interesting person. It's been a pretty positive experience and I'm pretty happy I took the class. Take it if you think you might want to learn more about the health care industry and are looking for a moderately-easy class.
Not really worth taking if it doesn't fulfill a requirement.

Reinhardt's lectures aren't the most organized, and he tells a lot of stories, but they're interesting, I guess. I have difficulty walking away from a lecture and knowing what could possibly be on the exam from the last 80 minutes, but if you're interested in the material, you should definitely shop the class and see how you like the lecture style.

TAKE IT. Reinhardt is the best prof here, and the leader in the healthcare field. It goes over everything and anything to do with healthcare, and unlike many profs here, Reinhardt is very unbiased and will tell you how it actually is.
TAKE THE CLASS
Take if interested in health care economics, but be prepared to learn material on your own as the lectures are no very structured.
Take it if you know ECO well already. Otherwise, PDF it.
Take it. You learn a ton.
This class is extremely valuable for informing your opinion of the U.S and other international health care economies. It is, however, a bit disorganized and you receive a lot of information.

This course should be required for all premedical students, many of whom fail to appreciate how important it is to explore beyond basic science and become familiar with the healthcare system they intend to enter. Professor Reinhardt has an encyclopedic knowledge of health policy and a deeper understanding of healthcare than probably most physicians do. Definitely take!
Unless you are extremely interested in the topic and don't mind learning most of it from the book, don't take it.
Yes, but be aware that the course is pretty disorganized which can be frustrating. Not a lot of work. Reinhardt is fun to listen to, but lecture sometimes seemed like a waste of time.
You will learn a fair amount, but it might not be in the most organized manner.
avoid jung as a preceptor
prereqs: ECO 100 or equivalent..
descrip: This course explores aspects of health systems primarily through the prism of micro-economic theory and analysis. It will be structured around a well-known textbook on the subject. Students successfully completing the course should have a better understanding of this complex system which now absorbs 17% of GDP and will soon claim a fifth.

title: Anthropology In and Of the City
reviews: A lot of freedom with the papers so make sure you plan wisely and don't leave the papers until the last minute.

Definitely take the course. The subject is extremely interesting, it's not that much work, and it's a great way to enter the field of anthropology. The lectures were a bit disorganized, but that was the only con.
Don't take this, you won't learn anything new.
I was worried that my background was inappropriate, but this turned out to be an excellent introduction to the Anthro department.
I would recommend this course for anyone who wanted to take an intro-level anthropology class or just gain some general knowledge on the subject.
I would strongly recommend it! I would also tell them to make sure they get into Prof. Ellison's precept!
If Professor Ellison is teaching it, take it! She was a great professor and her precepts were amazing, so definitely make sure you choose her as your preceptor!
If extremely interested in urban anthropology, do not take. If needing a first-time anthro course, this is a fair introduction.
If you are broadly interested in urban studies, sociology, or anthropology I would definitely recommend this course with Prof. Ellison!
Take it if you are interested in ethnographic readings. Light workload.
Take it if you're interested in urban studies, as it taught me a lot about important concepts in that field. It would also be relevant to people interested in race and class issues.
Take it!  A very interesting social science perspective on the dynamics of cities.  The workload was manageable and the assignments/exams were fair.  Really good, especially for a brand new class.
Take it! Great, relatively easy class that is low-stress but will get you thinking.

Take it! Very good class, super interesting and I would recommend getting into Prof Ellison's precept! Coming from someone who has never taken anthro before this was a very great first class, and I hope to take another!
Take the course because it is interesting and has interesting instructors. This is a side of anthropology that many would miss out on otherwise because it is not the most common field of study.
Take this course! you will learn a lot and it is not a tough work load.
Take this only if you'd like to be exposed to anthropology and are interested in the topic of the city
The lectures can be dry, but the readings and precepts are worth your time if you need to fulfill a departmental or distribution requirement.
The readings are incredible but I don't think I'd recommend the course as a whole.
This class rocks, do the readings because they are really interesting and make lecture way more fun!
This is a great class, especially for people who have not taken an anthro class before.

This was by far the best course I have taken at Princeton, and I am a graduating senior. The workload is VERY reasonable and the material is accessible to everyone, even people who are non-humanities people.
don't take it.
meh
descrip: This course will introduce you to urban anthropology. Urban anthropologists study everything from squatter settlements to the gleaming institutions of global capitalism on Wall Street. What does it mean to "make do" in global cities? How do those experiences shape our understanding of plurality? How do we talk about urban violence without pathologizing cities and the poor? We will explore the city as a stage upon which social, economic, and political struggles are waged, and examine the walls, fences, and security cameras that inscribe social exclusion onto the urban built environment, producing fortified enclaves and zones of abandonment.

title: Advanced Political Institutions
descrip: Designed to expose students to substantive and methodological controversies that are currently engaging scholars of political institutions. Integrates theoretical and quantitative skills by focusing on the processes of extracting hypotheses from formal models, stating hypotheses in a manner conducive to tests, collecting data, conducting tests, and making inferences. Assumes prior completion of POL 542.

title: Israeli Literature and Film, 1948-Present
descrip: Through fiction and film, the course explores the key topics in Israeli society and culture: the construction of the sabra, kibbutz and collectivist ideology, the impact of the Holocaust, military service and traumatic memory, gender and women's writing, Sephardim and Mizrahim, Israeli-Palestinian relations, and the religion nationalism and ultra-Orthodoxy.

title: Modern Dance: Beginning/Intermediate Technique and Choreography
reviews: Go for it, you have nothing to lose and so much to learn!
TAKE IT.
Take this course if you want to learn about modern dance and exercise, but there are easier ways to PDF since you have to actually go to all these classes
Worth it for even beginners.
prereqs: DAN 219, equivalent previous training, or instructor's permission. Interview information: there is no application for this course. In order to assure correct placement, interested students should contact Professor Lazier (rlazier@) by email to schedule an interview during the time period of November 11th through 22nd, 2013..
descrip: Dance technique and choreography for beginning and intermediate levels. Technique class will start with awareness and coordination exercises designed to organize the body and prepare for more technical movement. Class will build in physical intensity culminating in phrasework that is vigorous and challenging. In choreography, students will develop their understanding of the ways in which structural elements and movement vocabularies contribute to a dance's impact and content.

title: Contemporary Critical Theories - Marxist Theory
descrip: This year's Marxism seminar addresses questions of intellectual and epistemological difference, ideology, and the question of Marxism and cultural/literary forms. We begin with the question of ideology as Marx inherits it from the French eighteenth century, and continue through selections from Capital, Rosa Luxemburg, Gramsci, Lukacs, Sohn-Rethel, Adorno, Althusser, Balibar, Sara Kofman, Raymond Williams and others.

title: Biotechnology
reviews: Can be kind of dry sometimes, but you do learn a lot. Also the course is not a lot of work.
Do it
Eh.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in how biological sciences are applied to solve problems in society.
Make sure you read and understand all of the readings and studies before coming to class so you are prepared to participate.
Professor Flint cares as much about teaching as she does about good science, which is not always an easy combination to find.
This is a very interesting and demanding course, which covers important developments in biotechnology and their application in medicine.
This is an excellent class if you are thinking about a career in biology, chemistry, or medicine. The focus is on practical application, not theoretical academia.
go to class
this course is good if you want to obtain a Ph.D. in biotech... if pre-med you might be a leg behind...
prereqs: MOL 342 or MOL 345, or permission of the Instructor.
descrip: This course will consider the principles, development, outcomes and future directions of therapeutic applications of biotechnology, with particular emphasis on the interplay between basic research and clinical experience. Topics to be discussed include production of hormones and other therapeutic proteins, gene therapy, oncolytic viruses, and stem cells. Reading will be from the primary literature.

title: Energy Storage Systems
reviews: Great class. If you don't understand Python code, learn it ASAP and the class will go much better for you.
If you want to learn more about energy, especially batteries, this is the class for you
Professor Steingart is really amazing and has a really great attitude about learning.  He will make you want to try your best and you will learn more from the course because of that.
Take it.
Take this course whether you're particularly interested in chemistry or not. I was not and still found the course to be fun and intellectually stimulating.
Take this if you want to learn about batteries.
prereqs: MAE 221 or Equivalent, Freshman Physics, Freshman Chemistry, Knowlege of ODE/PDE.
descrip: This is a survey course on energy storage systems with a focus on electrochemical energy storage. Fundamentals of thermodynamics will be reviewed and fundamentals of electrochemistry introduced. These fundamentals will then be applied to devices such as batteries, flywheels and compressed air storage. Device optimization with respect to energy density, power density, cycle life and capital cost will be considered.

title: Introduction to Media Theory
reviews: Devin Fore is an absolute gem--one of the most engaged and engaging professors this school has to offer. I've taken two classes with him and both were excellent. If you have any interest in continental philosophy or media theory, you will love his classes.
Do the readings! Come to class with questions! Go to office hours! You'll learn a lot!
Highly recommended for anyone interested in media theory and how it might relate to their own discipline (philosophy, architecture, art/music/film/dance/etc., technology ...)
It is an interesting class but more theoretical than I expected. I would recommend it to someone interested in philosophical thought.
Take this course. The readings are sometimes difficult, but the material is fascinating.
Very good.  Works as a PHI cognate too.  Do it if you like talking in class.
Wonderful course for anyone interested in history and philosophy of technology, aesthetics, human experience in general. Prof. Fore is fantastic.
Yes. Definitely.
descrip: Through careful readings of a wide range of media theoretical texts from the late 19th to early 21st century, this seminar will trace the development of critical reflection on technologies and media ranging from the printing press to photography, from gramophones to radio technologies, from pre-cinematic optical devices to film and television, and from telephony and typewriters to cyberspace. Topics include the relationship between representation and technology, the historicity of perception, the interplay of aesthetics, technology and politics, and the transformation of notions of imagination, literacy, communication, reality and truth.

title: Fakes, Frauds, and Charlatans
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Painting
reviews: She is very nice person and flexible, she was very helpful to me, especially she encouraged me to try different things which I really enjoyed.
Take it if you want to work on your painting and take it in a direction you choose. Don't take it if you're looking for a low time commitment class.
prereqs: VIS 203/204 or VIS 309.
descrip: Painting has always entailed artists establishing a particular link between thinking, seeing and making. This course explores a variety of possible "equations" by which a painting gets made. Students will experiment with different media and approaches: direct observation, ways to use photography, digital images and post-digital imagery. Translation and transformation will be emphasized. Experimentation will provoke students to work in new and unpredictable ways, as well as enable them to discover and develop their own artistic preoccupations. Slide lectures, critiques, and weekly assignments with readings are integrated into studio practice.

title: Dynamics in Cognition
reviews: Good course if you're engaged and interested.
Take it and pay attention. It seems dry but it's really amazing stuff.

hopefully they will clarify the pre-requisites. I loved this class but I absolutely got in over my head; coding in some language should definitely be a requirement and I would even suggest a higher mathematics requirement than simply calculus. Otherwise supplemental material explaining how to parse out equations
prereqs: Calculus or higher (e.g. MAT 102 and 104; 103 and 104; 201; 202; 203; 204; etc); Fundamentals of Neuroscience (NEU/PSY 258). Experience with computer programming and/or linear algebra not required but beneficial. MatLab will be used..
descrip: The brain is made up of billions of neurons, each sending and receiving signals from thousands of other neurons. This densely connected network of neurons gives rise to rich spatial and temporal dynamics. This course will investigate these dynamics. The course will present experimental results from systems-level neuroscience and then discuss the theoretical implications of these findings, particularly as they relate to higher-order, cognitive behaviors.

title: Bioarchaeology of the Peoples of the Past
reviews: A lot of reading but lectures cover it all.
Do papers early.
I would absolutely recommend this class, and any class with Professor Monge.
If you are interested in archaeology in any way, definitely take this!
If you're interested in biology, archaeology, anthropology or history, I recommend this class.
Readings aren't really necessary. You should be genuinely interested in the class-- otherwise, the 3 hours each week will be unbearably long. I loved listening to her talk about things.
The lectures are long, but if you are interested in the subject it is a great place to start
The readings are extra. Don't overextend yourself to do them.

This class is a very interesting, INCREDIBLY low-stress HA for anyone who'd rather learn about bones and diseases than wars and famine. The classes are basically three-hour long lectures but Professor Monge is so funny and tells the most bizarre stories that time goes by pretty quickly. I guess there are technically readings every week, but since there aren't any discussions, the readings are kind of optional. All this being said, there are only three written assignments contributing to your final grade and I very much have no I idea what I'm getting in this class.
descrip: Bioarchaeology is the study of human remains in archaeological contexts. In this class we will study the reconstruction of the lifeways of peoples in the past. The course will focus on the population (rather than on the individual) level and covers much of human history and prehistory through a series of case studies. Using the basic techniques of analysis of the human skeleton, and in recognition of the dynamic nature of bone as it responds to changes in the environment, population parameters can be used to understand the efficacy of humans, both biologically and culturally, to respond to the ever changing physical environments of the globe.

title: Themes in Islamic Law and Jurisprudence
descrip: Selected topics in Islamic law and jurisprudence. The topics vary from year to year, but the course normally includes reading of fatwas and selected Islamic legal texts in Arabic.

title: Readings in Modern Japanese II
reviews: If you are serious about improving your Japanese ability, taking this class should be a foregone conclusion. That said, it is quite demanding and it being the highest level attracts students of very high ability, which can be daunting. Still, this should not discourage one from the rich material and instruction on offer.
It's a decent class if you want to improve your Japanese skills!
descrip: One or two short novels will be used to read for critical thinking. Reading is under focus but speaking, listening and writing (including translation) are intensively practiced. This course is designed to help students develop critical thinking through reading and discussing Japanese novels.

title: Topics in Conformal and Cauchy-Rieman (CR) Geometry
prereqs: Undergraduates require permission of the instructor.
descrip: This course covers current topics in Conformal and Cauchy-Rieman (CR) Geometry. More specific topic details are provided when the course is offered.

title: Dynamics in Cognition
prereqs: Calculus or higher (e.g. MAT 102 and 104; 103 and 104; 201; 202; 203; 204; etc); Fundamentals of Neuroscience (NEU/PSY 258). Experience with computer programming and/or linear algebra not required but beneficial..
descrip: The brain is made up of billions of neurons, each sending and receiving signals from thousands of other neurons. This densely connected network of neurons gives rise to rich spatial and temporal dynamics. This course investigates these dynamics. The course presents experimental results from systems-level neuroscience and then discusses the theoretical implications of these findings, particularly as they relate to higher-order, cognitive behaviors.

title: Seminar on Student Learning and Methods for Teaching
reviews: Absolutely take it if you plan to teach even short term in the future. If you're interested in working in education but not necessarily in teaching, I think that this course will still benefit you tremendously.

Take it seriously.  Work hard.  Reach out to the teachers you meet during your observations and at your labs.  Talk to Professor Kent and your advisors outside of class.  They are all wonderful and more than eager to share their wisdom.  Keep going even when you have doubts.  The seminar is about teaching and education, but it is really a philosophy course in disguise.  It will make you examine what you really think about life.

This class is AMAZING.  I learned a ton from all of the sources (readings, classmates, school visits, and guests).  Although I do not yet feel like I can handle a whole year, I am confident in my ability to create teach in smaller chunks (like a class).

This class is great, especially if you are considering going into teaching, this will let you dip your foot in the pool and get a taste of it. Don't underestimate the amount of time it takes however, it is a huge time commitment.
This is a great introduction to the Teacher Prep program -- the only thing is you might not get as much out of it if you try to take it while dealing with too many other commitments.
This is a time-intensive course. There are lots of school visits during the semester. Just be aware of that.
prereqs: The course is required for students in the Program in Teacher Preparation and is open to non-program students provided space is available. Interested non-program students should contact the Teacher Preparation Office for permission to take the course..
descrip: A study of essential methods of learning and teaching, including learner characteristics and needs, organization and structure of educational institutions, development of curriculum and instructional goals, preparation of evaluation and assessment, and design of subject/level specific methodologies and classroom management techniques. Required course work includes 18 hours of site-based field experience and evening laboratory sessions.

title: Multivariable Calculus
reviews: Ask for help when needed
Do the readings before class, go to office hours. and DEFINITELY go to review sessions.
Do the textbook reading BEFORE coming to class, that makes everything a lot easier.

Don't leave your p-set until the day before it's due. Take your time to work it out and it won't be too bad. Do the extra problems in preparations for the tests and you'll be good! MAT 201 can be a lot of fun, if you approach it with the right spirit :)
Don't take it if you don't have to.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take it unless you have to. Get a good instructor.
Don't take it unless you have to. Shop preceptors. Penka is very good but quiet.  It's tough to do well, but McGraw and group work help.
Don't take this unless you have to. It's hard, and it will suck up time. I'm not the best at math, so it was extra rough for me.
Dont take this unless you need to take it or love math way too much.
Easier concepts are taught than 203 but still a challenging class. Wouldn't take lightly, as it requires some time to get used to and prepare for the exams.
Go to office hours!
Great class, tough, but manageable. Take it if you like math.
I thought it was a fair course for students. It takes a bit of visualization to see the different shapes and what's happening in each problem, but still cool stuff to learn.

I would recommend doing every p-set. You're allowed to drop the lowest two grades so I know many people just don't do to of them but this will set inhibit you're ability to understand the material. Make sure to attend the lectures as well since they are vey useful and often go over problems that are similar to those seen on p-sets.
I would suggest that you stay on top of the material. The course is rather fast-paced--especially towards the end when the concepts are entirely different from those previously introduced.
If you are good in Calculus and choosing between 201 and 175, go for 201!
If you can place out of 104 and go directly in to 201, do it. This class is much better in almost every regard.
If you need to take it, take it...
If you're BSE, you have to take it. Don't be afraid to shop sections.
It's a good class that will help you prepare a good foundation for higher level math classes and science classes.
It's required for BSEs, but it's not a bad class at all! Pay attention in class -- they are super helfpul.
Its a tough course, but find study groups and go to McGraw if you're struggling!
Just make sure to do a lot of exam review and you'll be fine.

Just your average multi class. Do the PSets, classes are pretty much optional, do well on the quizzes and study the hell out of exams and you'll do ok. Don't feel compelled to take it if not a math/science major.
Keep on top of the concepts, as they very much build upon each other throughout the course.
Keep up. The material builds on itself.
Make sure you do not fall behind.
Make sure you take the psets seriously, go through the practice problems and seek out help when confused. This course is doable!
Necessary, but unrewarding.
Only take it if you have to.
Pay attention to the problem sets and don't be afraid to ask questions. Once you're behind, it sucks to catch up.
Penka Georgieva is great! Most of the people who take this course are engineers, satisfying a requirement, so keep up with the work because it goes fast.
Practice the online exams.
Read the textbook. The material is mostly self taught and not going to lecture doesn't really hurt you.
Shop around and try out a few different preceptors until your find one you like.
Study hard for the exams. Do plenty of practice tests.
Study well and do lots of practice problems
Study. It's hard otherwise.
Take MAT 203 if you can, but this course is also a solid backup. It's neither extremely hard nor ridiculously easy but the curve is ruthless. Stay on top of things.
Take it only if necessary.
Take it-it's worth learning.
Take this course if you have to and only if you like math.
Take this course if you need to.
Take this if you enjoy math and can think about math spatially.
Take this with Penka! Great class.
The book is a crucial part of the class. When I didn't understand something, I relied primarily on the book and reading back through the chapter to help clarify my understanding.
The course is challenging but worth the effort. Don't be afraid to ask for help - from the teacher and other students. This is perhaps my biggest regret concerning the course.

The course is mostly well designed. While it is hard and you will probably feel like you failed your exams, there are a lot of resources available for you to improve. If you're reading this, you probably have to take it anyways.
The second half of the course is much harder than the first - don't get complacent.
This class is not too bad. I don't recommend taking it for fun, but if you need to take it it is manageable.

This isn't a good class. However, you probably are taking it to fulfill the BSE requirement. The material isn't so difficult, but it's very difficult to keep up in the class if you get a bad lecturer. I watched the Khan Academy videos for the course, which were way better than the lectures.
Try to be in Chad/Steven Sivek's section

Unless you absolutely have to, DO NOT take this course. Take it at another institution if you can. Even if you do all the readings and problem sets, you will still always feel like you are left behind. Professors often rush through class because of the insane amount of material that they have to cover in a week, leaving you with a huge sense of helplessness. Even if you are in the natural sequence and just took MAT 104 last semester, there is not as seamless as a transition as you would expect it to be. The professor assumes that you know some of the core foundations of multi, so they don't even bother explaining them. I had a relatively high interest in math, but this course absolutely killed it. Probably one of the biggest disappointments of my Princeton career.
Watch the Banner videos.

When taking this class be sure to attend precepts and take notes that will allow you to complete the homework efficiently. Study groups are definitely recommended. Don't be afraid to ask for help from either classmates and peers or from your instructor.
Work hard and don't do the problem sets last minute, they do take longer than expected.
don't bother going to class, read the book and do extra problems, watch youtube
don't take it unless you have to!
hard
hard, dont take it if you dont need to, if you do then this doesnt matter much anyway. make sure you have a good teacher!
it's math. it's not exciting, but you'll probably only be taking it because you have to
its a good course
keep up with your notes and get clarification right away because concepts don't go away.
you should be careful because the curve does not look very good
prereqs: MAT 104 or equivalent..
descrip: Vectors in the plane and in space, vector functions and motion, surfaces, coordinate systems, functions of two or three variables and their derivatives, maxima and minima and applications, double and triple integrals, vector fields and Stokes's theorem.

title: Race, Gender, and Representation
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: Sociological Studies of Inequality(Half -Term)
descrip: This segment of the JDP seminar covers theory and research on social stratification, the major subfield in sociology that focuses on inequality. Course begins by reviewing major theories, constructs, measures, and empirical work on inequality. Weeks two through six focus on institutions that are expected to produce (and reproduce) inequalities, including families, neighborhoods, schools, labor markets, and penal policy.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Psychology and Inequality
descrip: Two major areas of psychology contribute to the study of social policy and inequality.The first is social psychology, which focuses on inter-group relations, interpersonal perception, stereotyping, racism, aggression, justice and fairness. The second domain involves the fields of social-cognition, judgment and decision making, areas of research that study human information processing in a way that is not about individual differences, and often not social.

title: Problems in Ancient History - The Transition from Antiquity to the Middle Ages: Numismatic Evidence
descrip: Coin evidence provides a unique view of the transition from the height of the Roman and Parthian Empires in the first centuries CE through the development of distinctly Latin, Byzantine, and Islamic zones by the end of the eighth century. Attention is given to cases where the numismatic evidence of change and identity varies from that supplied by written, archaeological, and other visual sources. The coin finds from Princeton's Antioch excavations supply a test case for this transition and a point of comparison for other sites. No previous numismatic training is expected.

title: Advanced Social Statistics
descrip: Thorough examination of the linear regression model with a focus on both the theory underlying the model and the application of regression using contemporary software. Topics include 1) probability theory underlying statistical modeling and hypothesis testing in general, 2) assumptions underlying the linear model, 3) estimation of the model via least squares, maximum likelihood, and Bayesian approaches, 4) diagnosing violations of assumptions, assessing the consequences of violations, and remedying them, and 5) extending the model and estimation methods to other data settings.

title: Contemporary Literary Theory
reviews: Definitely take this course. Commit to genuinely understanding the readings though, because if you want a class to skim through without really investing, this isn't it.
Good course, but be prepared for tough reading that takes a while to get used to.
Take this course. The readings are had but you will feel so rewarded for having done them
This class is challenging and requires a lot of work and effort.  This is not an intro class.  Go to office hours and participate in class for the best results

This class is super interesting. The material will make you question everything you take for granted in life (language, truth, preception). If you don't do the readings there's no point in taking the class. I would highly recommend it to non english majors--its honestly more of a philosophy course than an english course and requires no previous knowledge. The prof is not looking to give you bad grades either, so put in a little effort and you'll do well.
descrip: What is the relation between language and the worlds it describes? This course uses 20th-century literary and critical theory to explore the delights and dangers of the written word. We will engage phenomenology to show how language describes things that appear, and psychoanalysis to show how language can disclose things that do not appear. Deconstruction and discursive analysis emerge in response to these traditions, offering language as something that produces rather than describes the subject. We will follow Foucault in asking how language shapes what we can know and Derrida in seeing how it reveals contradictions in what we already know.

title: Interdisciplinary Research - The Anthropology of Becoming
descrip: This seminar draws from ethnography and critical theory to explore the significance of the idea and process of "becoming" for contemporary anthropology. How can we ethnographically apprehend individual and collective struggles to come to terms with structural determinants of all kinds in order to endure them or to create something new? How can people's plasticity and alternative world-making become figures of thought that might animate comparative research, political critique, and anthropology to come?

title: Religion and Culture: Muslims in America
reviews: Definitely take this course!!

Definitely take this course, even if you aren't particularly familiar with the practice of Islam (either generally or in America).  I learned a great deal from the readings and in-class discussions that revealed a lot about themes regarding religion and culture in America.
If you're interested in the topic, definitely take it!
Yes.
descrip: This course is an introduction to Muslim cultures in the United States. Each week we will draw upon texts from anthropology, sociology, history, and other fields to develop an understanding of the historical and present diversity of Muslim communities in America. The first half of the course provides a survey of Muslim communities in this country from the 17th to the 21st centuries. The second half features a thematic approach to a variety of topics: 9/11, women and gender, religious conversion, interfaith relations, youth, mosques as institutions, and Islamophobia.

title: Personal Identity
reviews: A strong, comprehensive introduction to personal identity, and classes and readings are particularly engaging.

If you like the material, definitely take this course-absolutey incredible!  However, the class is a high level PHI course so be expected to think deeply and hard about the material.  A familiarity with philosophical methods and background in similar topics would be really helpful as it would provide context to further inquiry on similar or congruent subjects.
Take for an interesting class without much outside work.
Take this course if you like abstract, analytical philosophy. Prof Johnston is brilliant.  He is incredibly passionate about personal identity and you will learn from the best
descrip: This course will focus on the conditions for personal identity over time, with implications for the beginning and end of life. We will investigate what it is rational to care about in caring about survival or continued existence, and whether our account of what it is rational to care about should change if we discover either that (1) there is no human soul or (2) no self or subject behind our various conscious acts.

title: Elementary Japanese II
reviews: A simply fantastic course. The professors are just phenomenal (as well as ridiculously funny), and the class really becomes a community of sorts by the second semester.
Definitely take it if you have the time for it. It will be a large workload, but it is fun and you will learn a lot about Japanese. The ???? are all great, as well!
For those who are interested in Japanese and willing to pay time and effort, this is the course you may want. Tough, yet time-worthy and unimaginably interesting.
I would tell other students to enter the class prepared to work every day.
If you are at all interested in learning Japanese, definitely consider taking this class.
If you have the slightest interest in languages and /or Japanese or Japanese history/culture, you can't go wrong here.
If you're at all interested in Japanese, by all means take 101 and 102!

If you're interested in studying Japanese, definitely take this course. It's really fun and you learn a lot. Obviously you'll have to put some work into it to get something out of it, but it's a really enjoyable class and the professors are great.

If you've taken 101, you have to take this to get credit for both courses. The pace of grammar learning is certainly faster than 101, but personally at least I found that by the 2nd semester I had sufficiently entered the mindset of the language to not be bothered by the accelerated pace. Practice the Kanji or they will come back to haunt you! Some people in the class are Chinese and don't need to study for them at all. If you care enough to learn Japanese you'll be able to put up with annoying curve, or with the overall obsessiveness with anime in the course.
Japanese is so fun! Take it if you have any interest in Japanese culture.
Know what you are getting into- this class will require a lot of memorization and hard work consistently through the year.
Listen to the senseis, put in a lot of time and work, and talk with the other students.
Make sure to know all your kanji. Kanji is very important!

Plan to time to spend with the material - a lot of a language is use and time spend with material. Also, while there are no problems set still use study groups they are really helpful and Japanese students are the coolest (so get to know one another).
This is a great course to take for anyone interested in learning Japanese. It's a lot of work, but definitely well worth it.

This isn't an easy A class, so don't take it for that reason, but if you're genuinely interested in Japanese, then you will love this class. The teachers are super friendly, helpful, and accessible, so whenever you need help, make an appointment and/or email them! There will be a good number of quizzes and assignments, but as long as you stay on top of things and do a little bit every day, you'll be fine!
prereqs: JPN 101 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Continuation of JPN 101, which emphasizes the basic four skills to achieve survival proficiency level.

title: Contemporary Music through Composition and Performance
reviews: Although Prof. Lansky has now retired, this class was great. It definitely got me to compose in new styles and took my compositional ability to a more mature level. Definitely worth taking.
Definitely take it. I don't know how it would be taught with Prof. Lansky gone but it's very interesting, if you're into modern classical music.
descrip: The course is aimed at performers and composers interested in deepening their understanding of the techniques and philosophies of contemporary and early modern music. Activities will include performing, analyzing, and composing.

title: Philosophy of Law
reviews: Don't take it unless you are a philosophy major and even then there are probably better classes.
I thought this was going to be interesting. It wasn't.
I would encourage students to take the course if they are truly interested in the material, and are willing to spend the time teaching themselves a lot of the readings.
If you're interested in learning about law from a philosophical standpoint (exactly what it says on the tin), then I think you'll find this course worth your while.
Take it if you're interested in how the law functions
Take this course if you're interested in law.
Take this subject matter with a different lecturer. Its interesting but the lectures are boring and not too helpful.
prereqs: One course in philosophy or permission of instructor.
descrip: Conceptual and moral problems in the foundations of law. Topics may include: morality and criminal justice; the justification of punishment; moral and economic problems in private law (torts and contracts); fundamental rights and constitutional interpretation.

title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
reviews:
Be sure to read the textbook. It is very clearly written and will help you gain a deeper understanding of the material. 

It says in the syllabus that MATLAB will be used but not to a great extent--this is NOT true. You will be doing a lot of MATLAB coding, so if you are uncomfortable with MATLAB, make sure you start early with the problem sets.
Best CBE course so far. Make sure you understand the problem sets and you'll be fine.

CBEs have to take it. It is not that bad. Easier than pipes. Just make sure that you actually understand the concepts. Though it may seem easy to you, come exam time, you might not actually understand "reactors".
Go to office hours a lot for the problem sets, the TA's are generally helpful.
Go to office hours to check your homework. The AIs are very helpful at pointing you in the right direction.
If you're not the most experienced with MatLab, start those assignments early!
It's required.
Learning Matlab can be a little annoying, but really useful.  Plus, if you're considering taking this class, you're going to take it because you're a CBE and you have to.  Overall, a great class!
Make sure to study a lot for the tests - they're trickier than the hw, so make sure you really understand all of the concepts and can do problems quickly before taking the exam.
Make sure you get an intuition for the material and not just memorize equations.
Read the textbook and make sure you understand the theory behind all of the material presented. Also, be good at MATLAB. It will save you some time on the problem sets.
Review all precept and homework problems before an exam.
Spend time on this course, don't just do the problem sets.

Sundar's an amazing professor - one of the few CBE professors who actually care about their students. He's smart, patient, kind, and actually responds to emails in a timely manner! The only CBE class I've actually strongly recommended in my entire Princeton career.
The book is pretty.

The class material is so cool, because it mixes thermodynamics, reaction kinetics, reactor analysis, catalysts, and more. This class has the surface appearance of being easy, so people don't put work in and then the exam kills them. It's not an "easy" class, and it requires attention and studying the book and class notes carefully.

Way harder than the previous year indicated. Problem sets are doable and not terrible unless your Matlab code runs incorrectly. There was not enough prep material for the exams. This was an issue because the knowledge expected to be shown on the exams were not trained at all during the problem sets.
You gotta take it and it's not too bad!

You have to take it if you're a CBE anyway. It's meh. The concepts and psets aren't that bad, but the exams are definitely harder than the psets. I personally couldn't pay attention much during lecture.
You have to take this course, right?
You have to take this. but it's not as bad as pipes or thermo. psets also aren't that bad.
prereqs: CBE 341.
descrip: Introduction to chemical reaction engineering and reactor design in chemical and biological processes. Concepts of chemical kinetics for both homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions. Coupled transport and chemical/biological rate processes.

title: Topics in Inorganic Chemistry - Symmetry, Diffraction and the Structures of Non-molecular Solids
reviews: A good introduction to the topics and ways of thinking surrounding crystallography and non-molecular solids.
I highly recommend it!
Just do it!
Make sure you print the lecture notes and bring them to every class. It's much easier to take notes directly on Dr. Cava's outline than to use a blank piece of paper.
Must take this course if interested in solid state chemistry.
Take it if you are interested in crystallography or solid state chem.
Take it if you are interested in solid state chemistry?its relaxed but you learn a lot.
descrip: Topics covered vary from year to year. The subject matter will be selected from among the following, related to the inorganic chemistry of solids: point group and space group symmetry, irreproducible representations, structure-property relations, crystallography, methods in X-ray, neutron and electron diffraction science, the structures of solids and molecules, the electronic structure of molecular and non-molecular solids, the optical, electronic and magnetic properties of molecular and non-molecular solids and their relation to crystal structure.
